   9: You don’t know the true success of survival till you’ve experienced the adrenaline of a too-close death.
  10: 
  11: What is there to fear when you’ve licked the edge?
  12: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  13: It is going to be an oppressively hot summer, theNew York Postsays, but I’ve got a few of my own stowed away, enough to occupy a foreign desert.
  14: 
  15: There was one summer, his name wasTitoand my sisters still say his name just like that, “Tee-toww,” theOa benchmark in the bottom of the jaw.
  16: 
  17: I was just 12 but the gaze itself made me a flame, so no one could tell, I guess,
  18: or no one would tell.
  19: 
  20: He was the kind of heavy swelter that had the whole block at mercy, everyone’s connect to whatever they needed, which was much and in bulk.
  21: 
  22: Power is a switch that yokes me up at the waist — I was young & enamored by this pattern of men who shouldn’t want me but would risk day to touch the stark chant of me.
  23: 
  24: Each time, I imagined a witchcraft enveloping the bone.
  25: 
  26: I remember,
  27: once, at some low hour in the trough* of that summer — my mouth a voyaging boat, Tito’s spine a current of illicit knots, his hand a spindle on the back of my coarse head — he looks down at me, & moans out “Who the fuck are you?
  28: 
  29: I say, and the answer is always the same thereafter: nobody, who are you?
  30: 
  31: *Okay, in any event, Elizabeth and I were in the pool, swimming and playing.

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   6: 
   7: THEN I had religion, THEN I had a vision.
   8: 
   9: I could not turn from their revel in derision.
  10: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  11: THEN I SAW THE CONGO, CREEPING THROUGH THE BLACK, CUTTING THROUGH THE FOREST WITH A GOLDEN TRACK.
  12: 
  13: Then along that riverbank A thousand miles Tattooed cannibals danced in files; Then I heard the boom of the blood-lust song And a thigh-bone beating on a tin-pan gong.
  14: 
  15: And “BLOOD” screamed the whistles and the fifes of the warriors, “BLOOD” screamed the skull-faced, lean witch-doctors, “Whirl ye the deadly voo-doo rattle, Harry the uplands, Steal all the cattle, Rattle-rattle, rattle-rattle, Bing.
  16: 
  17: Boomlay, boomlay, boomlay, BOOM,” A roaring, epic, rag-time tune From the mouth of the Congo To the Mountains of the Moon.
  18: 
  19: Death is an Elephant, Torch-eyed and horrible, Foam-flanked and terrible.
  20: 
  21: BOOM, steal the pygmies, BOOM, kill the Arabs, BOOM, kill the white men, HOO, HOO, HOO.
  22: 
  23: Listen to the yell of Leopold’s ghost Burning in Hell for his hand-maimed host.
  24: 
  25: Hear how the demons chuckle and yell Cutting his hands off, down in Hell.
  26: 
  27: Listen to the creepy proclamation, Blown through the lairs of the forest-nation, Blown past the white-ants’ hill of clay, Blown past the marsh where the butterflies play: — “Be careful what you do, Or Mumbo-Jumbo, God of the Congo, And all of the other Gods of the Congo, Mumbo-Jumbo will hoo-doo you, Mumbo-Jumbo will hoo-doo you, Mumbo-Jumbo will hoo-doo you.

  14: Some be crouching, others duck walking and given dat femme realness.
  15: 
  16: The lines are sketchy and rough through de mid sections of the figures.
  17: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  18: The line weight is thicc, but thin scribbly line flows throughout most of the figures connecting de ancestors to their descendants.
  19: 
  20: This werk is done on tracing paper with the opaqueness coming through in the center.
  21: 
  22: The top left corner of the paper is light with the bottom left & right plus the top right corner being darker.
  23: 
  24: There are maybe seven hazy figures located in de center of de paper and spreading out.

#5: 63154_Seasonal Cycle - Chapter 04 - Pre Winter_Kalidasa_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Seasonal Cycle - Chapter 04 - Pre Winter
Author: Kalidasa
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 18
Avg verse line length: 40.0
Avg prose line length: 328.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Seasonal Cycle - Chapter 04 - Pre Winter
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: "Delightful are trees and fields with the outgrowth of new tender-leaves and crops, Lodhra trees are with their blossomy flowers, crops of rice are completely ripened, but now lotuses are on their surcease by far, for the dewdrops are falling… hence, this is the time of pre-winter that drew nigh…
   4: "The busts of flirtatious women that are graced by bosomy bosoms are bedaubed and reddened with the redness of heart-stealing saffrony skincare, called Kashmir kumkum, on which embellished are the white pendants that are in shine with the whiteness of whitish dewdrops, white jasmines, and whitely moon…
   5: "Undecorated are the hiplines of kittenish women with gem-studded golden strings of girdle, nor their lotus like feet that have the brightness of lotuses with jingling anklets, whose jingling is correlative to the clucks of swans, for the cold touch of coldish metal gives cold quivers…
   6: "Unbearable is the touch of metallic circlets on wrists and bicep-lets on upper-arms of the couple of arms of vivacious women, or the touch of new silk cloths on the discoid of their waistline, or fine fabric on their robust breasts…
   7: "The womenfolk are rubbing fragrant wood-turmeric powder on their bodies, and their lotus-like faces are tattooed with erasable tattoos of foliage, and their head-hair is fumigated with the fumes of aloe vera resin, and they are doing all this for merrymaking in an enjoyable lovemaking…
   8: "Thoughgood fortune is bechanced in the happiness of lovemaking, the women of age are with sallowish and whitened faces owing to the strain of lovemaking, and though they want to laugh heartily, they desist from it, noticing very painful lower lips that are bitten with the edges of teeth of their lovers in lovemaking, lest the lip is lengthened, the pain is sharpened…
   9: "On reaching the valleys of bosomy busts of women of age, the winter breeze is attaining their coolant splendidness, but when those bosoms are pressingly hugged by their lovers it is incarcerated there with an unable pain, and that pain is expressed by the Hemanta season, as though it is bewailing for a release of that breeze at least at dawn time, with tear-like dewdrops clinging on to the spires of grass-blades…
  10: "Overspread with abundant rice crops and ornamented with herds of she-deer, and delightfully reverberated by the ruddy geese, with their calls and counter-calls, the complacent corridors of confines are captivating hearts…
  11: "Now the lakes are adorned with fully blossomed black-lotuses, and elaborated with swan-like waterfowls in their excitement, and sheeted with considerably coldish waters that are depurated, thus these lakes are stealing the hearts of men, for men look up to them as the visages of women that are with black-lotus-like hairdo, with swanlike eyes, and whose bodies are cold, wanting a warm hug…
  12: "Oh, dear, the Priyangu plants that give fragrant seeds are ripened by the snow caused coldness, and they are frequently wobbled by the snowy winds, and they now appear like the fragrant and frisky women gone into paleness and wobbliness by their dissociation from their lovers…
  13: "These days the mouths of people are fragranced with the fragrance of liquors made from the essential oils of flowers, and their bodies are fragrant with the same fragrancy by their puffs of suspires, and while lying on beds jointly with their bodies in tight embrace, they are slipping into sleep, entwined with the essence of passion…
  14: "The young and beautiful ladies that are new to their adulthood have bruises and marks of teeth notches on their lips, and even their bosoms are incised with nails of their lovers, thus these marks and incisions clearly indicate that they have enjoyed lovemaking consummately…
  15: "Some woman of age staying in the warmth of tender sun to warm up herself, is holding a mirror and applying cosmetics on her lotus-like face, and while doing so, she is pouting her lips and examining them that are dented with teeth bites of her lover, whose quintessence is guzzled down by her lover in last night…
  16: "One more woman whose body is fatigued by the strain of excessive lovemaking, and who is quiet sleepless last night, and whose eyes are palish like white lotuses, and whose bun is slithered and plaits of head-hair are loosened and hair tousling on her shoulders, bust, and on her bosoms, is tripping into sleep, warmed up by the rays of tender sun…
  17: "Bedraggled are the loose ends of cloudlike blackish head-hair onto the lofty busty bosoms of some other slender-bodied women of age, by which busty weight crouching are their bodies, as slim pearly pendants would crouch onto their bosoms, and they are taking away the circlets of flowers from their hairdos, as those flowers are already utilised and devoid of their heart-pleasing fragrance of yester night, and now they are grooming their hair, afresh…
  18: "On examining her body that is completely enjoyed by her lover, another woman is highly gladdened, and she remade her pleasant lips resplendently with lip-colouring, and on examining her bust with nail scratches, she embarrassedly wore her bodice, and while doing so the pain of friction of bodice with nail-scratches made her eyes to twitch, on which eyes dangling are her dark, delicate, and twitchy hair-curls…
  19: "By the exertion in their long-lasting games of lovemaking other women of age are wearied, and their slim bodies are thrilling at their flanks from bosoms to thighs, thereby those prettily pretty women are applying bodily oils and pastes to take an oil bath, that relieves these tingling sensations…
  20: "Pleasant with many an attribute, stealer of the hearts of women, and at which time the confines of villages are overspread with many an abundant rice-crop on earth, and overlaid is the sky with the garlanded flights of ruddy gees, that which is always with a heart-stealing environ, such as it is, let this season Hemanta, pre-winter, endow comfort to all of you passionate people…

#6: 63170_Seasonal Cycle - Chapter 05 - Winter_Kalidasa_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Seasonal Cycle - Chapter 05 - Winter
Author: Kalidasa
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 16
Avg verse line length: 36.0
Avg prose line length: 365.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Seasonal Cycle - Chapter 05 - Winter
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: "Oh, dear with best thighs, heart-stealing is this environ with abundantly grown stacks of rice and their cobs, or with sugarcane, and it is reverberated with the screeches of ruddy gees that abide hither and thither… now heightened will be passion, thereby this season will be gladdening for lusty womenfolk, hence listen of this season, called Shishira, the Winter…
   4: "At this time, people enjoy abiding in the medial places of their residences, whose ventilators are blockaded for the passage of chilly air, and at fireplaces, in sunrays, with heavy clothing, and along with mature women of age, for they too will be passionately steamy…
   5: "Presently, not the sandal-paste, which will be coolant like moonbeams of moon, nor the building tops, that were once rendered pleasant with the immaculate moonshine, nor the breezes, that are chilled by dense sleet… any of them is delightful for the people…
   6: "The nights are unenjoyable for the people, for they are chilled with the huddles of snow, and further chilled by moonbeams of the moon, besides, these nights are ornamented very whitish clusters of cluttered and lacklustre stars…
   7: "On taking betel leaves and their enclosing material like lime and areca-nut parings, and other fragrant material for chewing, and even handling body creams and tassels of flowers, for it is cool to wear them on, and with their lotus-like faces that are fragranced with delightful recreational drinks, the women are enthusiastically entering their bedchambers, that are desirably fragranced with the fumigation of aloe vera resin…
   8: "On entering bedchambers seen are the irritant husbands irritating for the arrival of their wives, but once these husbands were at fault and they were daunted repeatedly earlier, hence they are now wavery, for their hearts are ciphered by their hesitation, and on looking at such husbands, who are now longing for lovemaking, the lustful women are overlooking their faults, lest time and opportunity fritters away… thus this season unites couples, though they are at loggerheads…
   9: "The women that are new to adulthood are relentlessly gratified for a long time in longish nights, by young men who are muchly impassioned and lusting for their women, thus these young women after the end of night are moving about sluggishly in the morning, with their aching busts that are strained during last night's escapade…
  10: "The womenfolk's breasts are tightly bound by breast-bands thus they are squeezy, and on them the upper fringe of their colourful silk wraparound is wrapped, and such busts are ornamented, and in their hairdo interposed are flowers, thus those women are delightful and it appears that they themselves are embellishing the wintry season as its ornaments…
  11: "Nowadays the chests of lustful men are ocherish for they are rubbed against bosoms of their flirtatious women, whose busts are adorned with vermilion coloured skincare, and which young women are befitting for a comfortable close self-indulgence, for they are new to adulthood, and have warmish bosoms, and the men are sleeping while overly pressing the bosoms of their ladyloves against their own, thus the men are brazening out the chilling coldness of winter, and thus the women of age have an edge on the frostiness of this season…
  12: "In nights the gladdened women of age, desirous of lovemaking are consuming best, heart-stealing, excitant, and stimulant hard drinks along with their lovers, in which drinks lotus petal are placed for fragrance, and which lotus petals are undulated by the richly scented lusty suspirations of those women…
  13: "In the morning, one woman on getting rid of her penchant of passion, examined her own body, and observed that her nipples are subdued by her lover's embrace, and thus concluding that her body is completely enjoyed by her lover, she is going out of the bedchamber to another chamber, laughingly…
  14: "At dawn, another charmingly delightful and attractive woman, whose rumps are heavy and whose waistline is slender, on joggling the ends of her slithered hair plaits from which discarded are the circlets of flowers, that adorned her bun last night but now withered, and on furling up that hair which is fragrant, for it was fumigated with the resin of aloe vera during last night, is leaving the bed…
  15: "With their discoid faces that look like golden lotuses, cleansed just with water, and with their wide and medially whitish eyes, whose edges touch the edges of ears, and with their just cleansed hair dangling and clasping their shoulders, those women of age are snugly in the heart of their houses in these days, and they appear to be many a personified prosperity, Goddess Lakshmi-s, amidst Her golden lotuses…
  16: "Other women of age, uneasy with the weight of their beamy behinds, a little bent down at waist by the weight of their breasts, which weight of breasts and behinds is making them to walk slowly and slowly, but they are quickly disrobing themselves of their night-time and love-time getups, and enrobing themselves with the getups befitting for daytime…
  17: "On observing the areas of their bosoms that are puckered at their tops with edges of nails of their lovers during last night, and while touching the teeth-cracked tender-leaf like lower lips with their tongues, those women of age are rejoicing, for all this is according to their sought-after delectation, thus they are applying makeup on their faces, at the dawn time of the sun, that rejoicingly…
  18: "In this season, abundant are the new sugar-candies and their modified sweetmeats, new rice is relishable, juice of new sugar-cane is delightful, intensified will be the disport of lovemaking, for the self-conceit of Love-god occasions anew, but this season alone will be the cause for scorching the hearts of those that are devoid of their loved ones, and thus let this winter season be always there for your propitiousness…

Author: Kalidasa

Avg prose line length: 148.7

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 572: 
 573: Kashyap: My son, reascend the chariot of Indra with thy consort and child, and return happy to thy imperial seat.
 574: 
 575: King Dushyant: Be it as Marichi ordains.
 576: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 577: Kashyap: Henceforth may the god of the atmosphere with copious rain give abundance to thy affectionate subjects; and mayst thou with frequent sacrifices maintain the Thunderer's friendship! By numberless interchanges of good offices between you both, may benefits reciprocally be conferred on the inhabitants of the two worlds!
 578: King Dushyant: Powerful being, I will be studious, as far as I am able, to attain that felicity.
 579: 
 580: Kashyap: What other favours can I bestow on thee?
 581: 
 582: King Dushyant: Can any favours exceed those already bestowed ?
 583: 
 584: –Let every king apply himself to the attainment of happiness for his people; let Saraswati, the goddess of liberal arts, be adored by all readers of the Véda; and may Siva, with an azure neck and red locks, eternally potent and self-existing, avert from me the pain of another birth in this perishable world, the seat of crimes and of punishment.
 585: 
 586: [All go out.

#8: 63254_A Sandal On The Head_Brew, Kwesi_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: A Sandal On The Head
Author: Brew, Kwesi
Prose starts at line: 26
Lines to remove: 9
Avg verse line length: 31.9
Avg prose line length: 105.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  21: And the Master of the House
  22: Now Master of Rags
  23: Stays behind on the rocks
  24: To rummage in the rubbish heap
  25: For cast-away morsels of power!

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  26: This poem is about the overthrow of Ghana's premier President Kwame Nkrumah in February 1966 and his exile in Guinea.
  27: 
  28: The poem does not mention the President by name rather it uses certain character traits such as "Master of the House" and "Master of Rags".
  29: 
  30: Anyone who is knows about the events that rocked Kwame Nkrumah's government will appreciate the point the poet is driving home.
  31: 
  32: The breakdown and emotional disappiontment felt by the President's suppoters before his fall.
  33: 
  34: Note by Emmanuel Kalusian For Oldpoetry Classics.

#9: 63291_Answer To The Winter Piece_Munford, Robert_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Answer To The Winter Piece
Author: Munford, Robert
Prose starts at line: 151
Lines to remove: 15
Avg verse line length: 42.6
Avg prose line length: 147.9

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 146: Impels me in the loudest notes to raise,
 147: Oh birch-deserving * * * thy song of praise.
 148: 
 149: A NOTE BY THE PUBLISHER.
 150: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 151: The poem to which the above was written, as an answer, has, I believe, been long since forgotten; and as the author was acknowledged to be a very worthy and respectable man, though a very bad poet, his shame should be forgotten also.
 152: 
 153: The satire is therefore published without the name of the author, and thus it is hoped, some instruction to other writers, and some diversion to the reader my be gathered from it, without injuring the feelings of any person whatever.
 154: 
 155: Those who have read the work alluded to, (which the reader will observe, was printed many years ago with no name annexed,) will judge for themselves, whether its sentence here pronounced, was just or not; and those who never have, and probably never will, may consider the answer as a description of bad poetry in general, in which light it is now given to the world, and may be serviceable in restraining those who scribble prophanely or indecently, without the skill to compose verse, or sense to entertain their readers.
 156: 
 157: THE PUBLISHER.
 158: 
 159: From: A Collection of Plays and Poems, by the Late Col.
 160: 
 161: Robert Munford, of Mecklenburg County, in the State of Virginia.
 162: 
 163: Now First Published Together.
 164: 
 165: Printed by William Prentis, 1798

Author: Ernst, K S
Prose starts at line: 11
Lines to remove: 9
Avg verse line length: 39.0
Avg prose line length: 118.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   6: 
   7: S.
   8: 
   9: Ernst and Sheila E.
  10: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  11: Murphy's collaborations is how seamless they are, as if created from one intelligence, even though the poets come from different areas of major practice.
  12: 
  13: Ernst is highly attuned to the world of the visual arts, producing works designed for gallery spaces.
  14: 
  15: Murphy is an active textual poet and a more recent participant in visual poetry.
  16: 
  17: In "Vortextique," the vortex before us is literal: a maelstrom of words that suggests the ultimate artificiality of linguistic signs, the ambiguity of speech, and the impossibility of absolutely accurate communication.
  18: 
  19: —Geof Huth More About Visual Poetry >>

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]

   9: 
  10: Howcome they don’t give an academic award to all the movie stars thatdie?
  11: 
  12: they’re still acting, ain’t they?
  13: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  14: even if they are dead, it shouldnot be held against them, after all they still have the public on theirside, how would you like to be a dead movie star & have people sit-ting on your grave?
  15: 
  16: A rare me is more certain than desirable, that’s all the terror, thereare too many basketball players in this world & too much progressin the burial industry, lets have old fashioned funerals & standaround & forgive & borrow wet handkerchiefs, & sneak out fordrinks & help load the guy into the wagon, & feel sad & make adate with the widow & believe we don’t see all of the people sink-ing into the subways going to basketball games & designing babysitters at Madison Square Garden.
  17: 
  18: A certain me is desirable, what is so rare as air in a Poem, why can’ti write a foreign movie like all the other boys my age, I confess to allthe crimes committed during the month of April, but not to savemy own neck, which is adjustable, & telescopes into any size noose,I’m doing it to save Gertrude Stein’s reputation, who is secretlyflying model airplanes for the underground railroad stern gang ofoz, & is the favorite in all the bouts .
  19: 
  20: 
  21: not officially opened yetHolland tunnel is the one who writes untrue phone numbers.
  22: 
  23: A desirable poem is more rare than rare, & terror is certain, whowants to be a poet & work a twenty four hour shift, they never askyou first, who wants to listen to the radiator play string quartets allnight.
  24: 
  25: I want to be allowed not to be, suppose a man wants toswing on the kiddie swings, should people be allowed to stab himwith queer looks & drag him off to bed & its no fun on top of alady when her hair is full of shiny little machines & your assreflected in that television screen, who wants to be a poet if youfuck on t.
  26: 
  27: v.
  28: 
  29: & all those cowboys watching.

#13: 63505_Girl Soup_Nakayasu, Sawako_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Girl Soup
Author: Nakayasu, Sawako
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 13
Avg verse line length: 9.0
Avg prose line length: 174.9

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Girl Soup
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: I get tired of being the one to make all the decisions so when they ask me where I want to eat, I say that I don’t care, I’d eat anything  at this point.
   4: 
   5: Next thing I know, I am face to face with a bowl of Girl Soup and I just can’t bring myself.
   6: 
   7: Some of us at the table are in a hurry to eat the soup, they are specifically trying to eat the  girls quickly because they seem to know that if you wait too long they turn into cyborgs or robots, and those are harder to chew.
   8: 
   9: I can see that some of the girls are still alive and perhaps would like to be extracted from the soup, but when I squint I see that there are girls all over the floor with varying amounts of soup clinging to their clothes (you didn’t think they were naked, did you?
  10: 
  11: ) and so there goes that idea.
  12: 
  13: Just at the moment I think I am running out of options, something comes over me and I take a deep breath and I do it, I jump right in there, that bowl of Girl Soup, no one is checking IDs or questioning my size or gender or race or voter affiliation, and I quick round up all the girls in the bowl into a large huddle.
  14: 
  15: We have now obliterated two major problems: huddled together we are too large to eat, and also we’ve taken care of the problem of the eater.

 579: 
 580: ' Independently of his other singular accomplishments, James particularly excelled in music, not only as a performer, but a composer: and it is to his admirable genius, that the musical world is so much indebted for the invention (amidst the gloom of solitude and confinement) of that sweet and plaintive Scotch and Italian melody, which, as the above mentioned author, justly remarks, 'has given pleasure to millions in every succeeding age.
 581: 
 582: Alexandro Tassoni mentions James king of Scotland, having, of himself, invented a new kind of music, plaintive and melancholy, different from all others, in which he was imitated by Carlo Gesualdo, prince of Venosa, who in our age (says Parsoni) has improved music with new and admirable inventions.
 583: 
 584: As the prince of Verona imitated king James, the other musicians of Italy imitated the prince of Venosa.
 585: 
 586: 'The most noble Carlo Gesualdo, the prince of musicians in our age (says sir John Hawkins, vol.
 587: 
 588: iii.
 589: 
 590: p.
 591: 
 592: 212) introduced such a style of modulation, that other musicians yield the preference to him; and all singers and players on stringed instruments, laying aside that of others, every where embraced his.
 593:

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  44: "Of Afric's mourners round thy tomb!": In Jamaica it is customary on the death of a white person, for all the domestic negroes to attend the funeral.
  45: 
  46: If the deceased has been a particular favourite, it is usual for the female slaves to raise after the interrment, a funeral song or dirge over the grave.
  47: 
  48: This consists of the good qualities of the deceased; such as, 'O my good massa!' 'O my dear massa!' accompanied with clapping of hands, and violent gesticulations of sorrow.
  49: 
  50: ~ The Poetical Works of Hector MacNeill, 1815.

#16: 63554_The Pastoral, Or Lyric Muse Of Scotland. Canto First_MacNeill, Hector_unknown.txt

Title: The Pastoral, Or Lyric Muse Of Scotland.  Canto First
Author: MacNeill, Hector
Prose starts at line: 333
Lines to remove: 11
Avg verse line length: 39.1
Avg prose line length: 194.5

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 328: 
 329: "Smiles amid eternal snow:" See Icelandic and Lapland Poetry.
 330: 
 331: 262.
 332: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 333: "Thinks of his home, and weeps!": 'There is a dance in Switzerland which the young shepherds perform to a tune played on a sort of bag-pipe.
 334: 
 335: The tune is called Rance des Vaches; it is wild and irregular, but has nothing in its composition that could recommend it to our notice.
 336: 
 337: But the Swiss are so intoxicated with this tune, that if at any time they hear it when abroad in foreign service, they burst into tears; and often fall sick, and even die, of a passionate desire to revisit their native country; for which reason, in some armies where they serve, the playing of this tune is prohibited.
 338: 
 339: This tune having been the attendant of their childhood and early youth, recals to their memory those regions of wild beauty and rude magnificence; those days of liberty and peace; those nights of festivity; those happy assemblies; those tender passions, which formerly endeared to them their country, their homes, and their employments; and which, when compared with the scenes of uproar they are now engaged in, and the servitude they now undergo, awaken such regret as entirely overpowers them.
 340: 
 341: " - Beattie on Poetry and Music.
 342: 
 343: ~The Poetical Works of Hector MacNeill, 1815.

#17: 63563_The Scottish Muse_MacNeill, Hector_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Scottish Muse
Author: MacNeill, Hector
Prose starts at line: 559
Lines to remove: 7
Avg verse line length: 39.1
Avg prose line length: 240.5

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 554: 
 555: 15.
 556: 
 557: ADVERTISEMENT.
 558: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 559: Under the influence of a distressing state of health, which had continued unabated for six years, the following poem was composed in the island of Jamaica, whither the author went with a view of trying the effects of a tropical climate.
 560: 
 561: If it possesses no other merit, it may at least lay claim to simplicity of sentiment and diction, and to a faithful representation of events during a life of vicissitude, of which the present piece may be considered as a poetical epitome.
 562: 
 563: These, it is true, furnish little to excite astonishment or rouse imagination; and, consequently, perhaps, little to procure public approbation.
 564: 
 565: They may, however, tend to illustrate an important truth to the afflicted, namely, that in the human mind there are resources which, if called into action, can amuse and solace in the hour of adversity when all the allurements of pleasure and all the luxuries of wealth will fail; for often 'Ingenium res adversae nudare solent celere secundae.

  55: *This engraving had been at some period thrown off for the use of a Literary Society in London, likewise called the Sober Society.
  56: 
  57: The representation was a female figure with the finger of one hand pointing to the moon (horned) and six stars over-head; and the finger of the other hand pointing to the ground with this motto -- Virtus tandem Vicebat.

  59: 21.
  60:

  62: 
  63: e.
  64: 
  65: retire or remain as long as he chose; and as this last liberty was generally productive of sober happiness, it was called the Beate.

#20: 63588_Scotland's Scaith, Or, The History O' Will And Jean. Owre True A Tale. In Two Pa_MacNeill, Hector_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Scotland's Scaith, Or, The History O' Will And Jean. Owre True A Tale. In Two Parts
Author: MacNeill, Hector
Prose starts at line: 372
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 37.7
Avg prose line length: 165.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 367: 
 368: It therefore, only rests with me at present, to inform the public, that by this address, my object is not to solicit a patron to what has already been so liberally patronized, but to communicate a fact which I cannot in justice prevail on myself to conceal; namely, that without the kind interference, and friendly assistance of Dr.
 369: 
 370: Doig, the poem of Scotland's Scaith, in all likelihood, would never have been published.
 371: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 372: My motives for having depicted, and yours in publishing this too faithful portrait of modern depravity, were the same.
 373: 
 374: Impressed with the baneful consequences inseparable from an inordinate use of ardent spirits among the lower orders of society, and anxious to contribute something that might at least tend to retard the contagion of so dangerous an evil; it was conceived in the ardor of philanthropy, that a natural, pathetic story, in verse, calculated to enforce moral truths, in the language of simplicity and passion, might probably interest the uncorrupted; and that a striking picture of the calamities incident to idle debauchery, contrasted with the blessings of industrious prosperity, might (although insufficient to reclaim abandoned vice) do something to strengthen and encourage endangered virtue.
 375: 
 376: Visionary as these fond expectations may have been, it is pleasing to cherish the idea; and if we may be allowed to draw favorable inferences, from the sale of ten thousand copies in the short space of five months, why should we despair of success?
 377: 
 378: Having said so much on so trivial a subject, allow me, in conclusion, to add a few words to the person who has been the chief cause of the present publication.
 379: 
 380: On this opportunity, I must confess, I am strongly tempted to say much; but the recollection of a modesty as remarkable as the genius and erudition of its possessor, restrains the fervor of friendship, and witholds the just tribute of applause.
 381: 
 382: A more lively, and more pleasing recollection of virtues, which are superior to all that literature or talents can bestow, inclines me, however, to think, that indifferent as you have long been, to the 'obstreperous trump of fame,' the 'still small voice of gratitude' and esteem will not be unpleasant to your ear; and that you will believe me to be, without farther profession,
 383: My dear Sir,
 384: Your affectionate
 385: And most obedient Servant,
 386: Hector MacNeill.
 387: 
 388: -Edinburgh, July, 1795.
 389: 
 390: ~ The Poetical Works of Hector MacNeill, 1815.

#21: 63594_To J. W. On His Birth Day. A Dialogue Between Seventy Two and Twenty Seven_MacNeill, Hector_unknown.txt

Title: To J. W. On His Birth Day. A Dialogue Between Seventy Two and Twenty Seven
Author: MacNeill, Hector
Prose starts at line: 204

Avg verse line length: 33.4
Avg prose line length: 175.5

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 199: 
 200: : His daughter and three sons.
 201: 
 202: Last line, "Thy friend!" &c.
 203: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 204: :  The excellent person here mentioned, was one of the most dear and intimate friends the Author ever had.
 205: 
 206: He was a man who (independently of the most amiable virtues) possessed great genius: but like many others of distinguished abilities, too indolent to prosecute or apply his talents to advantage.
 207: 
 208: His memory was so extraordinary, that he could get by rote eight hundred lines of poetry in a day without the omission of a word; and he once offered, in the Author's presence, to lay a considerable bet, that without any assistance whatever, he would in three days play over every move in Philidore's Treatise on Chess.
 209: 
 210: He was an admirable critic, and no contemptible poet; both of which arts he cultivated with care; and his excellence in painting, had it been encouraged, would have entitled him to eminence.
 211: 
 212: He likewise possessed an exquisite taste in music, and what renders the character singular is, that with these gifts of genius, mathematics, calculation, and abstract science seemed to be his forte.
 213: 
 214: ~ The Poetical Works of Hector MacNeill, 1815.

  22:

   4:

   6:

   8: 
   9: Yet old Prometheus punished for his rape.
  10: 
  11: Thus poor thieves suffer when the greater ‘scape.

   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: Three sorts of serpents do resemble thee:  That dangerous eye-killing cockatrice,  The enchanting siren, which doth so entice,  The weeping crocodile—these vile pernicious three.
   4: 
   5: The basilisk his nature takes from thee,  Who for my life in secret wait dost lie,  And to my heart sendst poison from thine eye:  Thus do I feel the pain, the cause, yet cannot see.
   6: 
   7: Fair-maid no more, but Mer-maid be thy name,  Who with thy sweet alluring harmony  Hast played the thief, and stolen my heart from me,  And like a tyrant makst my grief thy game:
   8: 
   9: Thou crocodile, who when thou hast me slain,
  10: 
  11: Lamentst my death, with tears of thy disdain.

 225: He is the “wise old doctor” of Snow-Bound.
 226: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 227: Count Francois de Vipart with his cousin Joseph Rochemont de Poyen came to the United States in the early part of the present century.
 228: 
 229: They took up their residence at Rocks Village on the Merrimac, where they both married.
 230: 
 231: The wife of Count Vipart was Mary Ingalls, who as my father remembered her was a very lovely young girl.
 232: 
 233: Her wedding dress, as described by a lady still living, was “pink satin with an overdress of white lace, and white satin slippers.
 234: 
 235: ” She died in less than a year after her marriage.
 236: 
 237: Her husband returned to his native country.
 238: 
 239: He lies buried in the family tomb of the Viparts at Bordeaux.

#34: 66033_Funeral Tree of the Sokokis_Whittier, John Greenleaf_unknown.txt

Author: Whittier, John Greenleaf
Prose starts at line: 126
Lines to remove: 9
Avg verse line length: 35.0
Avg prose line length: 108.6

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 121: Of form and creed, and outward things,
 122: To light the naked spirit brings;
 123: Not with our partial eye shall scan,
 124: Not with our pride and scorn shall ban,
 125: The spirit of our brother man!

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 126: Polan, chief of the Sokokis Indians of the country between Agamenticus and Casco Bay, was killed at Windham on Sebago Lake in the spring of 1756.
 127: 
 128: After the whites had retired, the surviving Indians "swayed" or bent down a young tree until its roots were upturned, placed the body of their chief beneath it, then released the tree, which, in springing back to its old position, covered the grave.
 129: 
 130: The Sokokis were early converts to the Catholic faith.
 131: 
 132: Most of them, prior to the year 1756, had removed to the French settlements on the St.
 133: 
 134: Francois.

 607: 
 608: Fields, of Boston, in grateful acknowledgment of the strength and inspiration I have found in her friendship and sympathy.
 609: 
 610: The poem in its first form was entitled The Wife: an Idyl of Bearcamp Water, and appeared in The Atlantic Monthly for January, 1868.
 611: 
 612: When I published the volume Among the Hills, in December of the same year, I expanded the Prelude and filled out also the outlines of the story.

#38: 66442_I've Worn My Bits o' Shoon Away_Waugh, Edwin_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: I've Worn My Bits o' Shoon Away
Author: Waugh, Edwin
Prose starts at line: 52
Lines to remove: 20
Avg verse line length: 41.6
Avg prose line length: 68.3

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  47: 
  48: The repeated phrase ""th' water i' my e'een"" is both a reference to tears of anticipation at the prospect of living amongst his beloved countryside and also the effects of the sharp moorland wind blowing in his face and making his eyes water.
  49: 
  50: Two terms which Waugh didn't think worth translating which might confuse modern readers are
  51: The dule --- The Devil

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  52: Cloofs --- Cloughs (a feature of peat moorland caused by water erosion producing deep gulleys.
  53: 
  54: The Text and main Glossary were taken from Waugh's Poems and Songs published by John Heywood and edited by George Milner.
  55: 
  56: Like most of Waugh’s verses the meaning is fairly clear if only one speaks the words carefully.
  57: 
  58: The apparently awkward spelling is simply the best possible phonetic rendition of the words as they sound when delivered in the local dialect (Rochdale, Lancs.
  59: 
  60: 
  61: A few of the words have fallen into disuse in other areas and I have tried to indicate their meaning here.
  62: 
  63: Shoon --- Shoes
  64: Bar-fut --- Bare-foot
  65: Th' layrock --- The Sky-Lark
  66: Dainty rindles --- Pretty rills of singing water
  67: Moor sense than prouder folk --- More sense than prouder people
  68: Wick an' warm at wark an' fun --- Lively and earnest at work and fun
  69: Last neet I laft the city thrung --- Last night I left the city throng
  70: Wi' th' water i' my e'een --- With the water in mine eyes
  71: Jim Saville

#39: 66447_Neet Fo -- Night Fall_Waugh, Edwin_unknown.txt

Title: Neet Fo -- Night Fall
Author: Waugh, Edwin
Prose starts at line: 79
Lines to remove: 20
Avg verse line length: 34.6
Avg prose line length: 55.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  74: 
  75: Mark how she personfies so many household items as eagerly anticipating the arrival just as she does.
  76: 
  77: Like most of Waugh’s verses the meaning is fairly clear if only one speaks the words carefully.
  78: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  79: The apparently awkward spelling is simply the best possible phonetic rendition of the words as they sound when delivered in the local dialect (Rochdale, Lancs.
  80: 
  81: 
  82: A few of the words have fallen into disuse in other areas and I have tried to indicate their meaning here.
  83: 
  84: JS
  85: Key words
  86: Tet – a person’s name, probably a servant girl
  87: Keyther—A coocking pot
  88: Baggin’-time – the end of the day when a workman puts his tools in his bag to carry them home.
  89: 
  90: Sneck – a metal latch on a door or gate, or the sound made by someone using such a latch.
  91: 
  92: Fain – fine / cheerful / happy /proud or a mixture of these
  93: An' th' tin things winkin' upo' th' wole, -- metal ornaments glinting on the wall
  94: Wick – quick
  95: This little duck – the baby
  96: Teeny wondows blue – little eyes
  97: Clock-hummers – small hammers that strike the hour in a chiming clock’s mechanism
  98: Hoo – she

#44: 66483_The Pipe_Mallarme, Stephane_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Pipe
Author: Mallarme, Stephane
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 9
Avg verse line length: 8.0
Avg prose line length: 403.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: The Pipe
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: Yesterday I found my pipe while pondering a long evening of work, of fine winter work.
   4: 
   5: Thrown aside were my cigarettes, with all the childish joys of summer, into the past which the leaves shining blue in the sun, the muslins, illuminate, and taken up once again was the grave pipe of a serious man who wants to smoke for a long while without being disturbed, so as better to work: but I was not prepared for the surprise that this abandoned object had in store for me; for hardly had I drawn the first puff when I forgot the grand books I was planning to write, and, amazed, moved to a feeling of tenderness, I breathed in the air of the previous winter which was now coming back to me.
   6: 
   7: I had not been in contact with my faithful sweetheart since returning to France, and now all of London, London as I had lived it a year ago entirely alone, appeared before my eyes: first the dear fogs that muffle one’s brains and have an odor of their own there when they penetrate beneath the casements.
   8: 
   9: My tobacco had the scent of a somber room with leather furniture sprinkled by coal dust, on which the thin black cat would curl and stretch; the big fires! and the maid with red arms pouring coals, and the noise of those coals falling from the sheet-iron bucket into the iron scuttle in the morning—when the postman gave the solemn double knock that kept me alive! Once again I saw through the windows those sickly trees of the deserted square—I saw the open sea, crossed so often that winter, shivering on the deck of the steamer wet with drizzle and blackened from the fumes—with my poor wandering beloved, decked out in traveller’s clothes, a long dress, dull as the dust of the roads, a coat clinging damply to her cold shoulders, one of those straw hats with no feather and hardly any ribbons that wealthy ladies throw away upon arrival, mangled as they are by the sea, and that poor loved ones refurbish for many another season.
  10: 
  11: Around her neck was wound the terrible handkerchief that one waves when saying goodbye forever.


====================================================================================================
#45: 66490_Autumn Plaint_Mallarme, Stephane_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Autumn Plaint
Author: Mallarme, Stephane
Prose starts at line: 10
Lines to remove: 17
Avg verse line length: 37.0
Avg prose line length: 193.4

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   5: 
   6: - I have always loved solitude.
   7: 
   8: How many long days I have passed alone with my cat.
   9: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  10: By alone I mean without a material being, and my cat is a mystic companion, a spirit.
  11: 
  12: I can say then that I have passed long days alone with my cat and alone with one of the last authors of the Roman decadence; for since the white creature is no more I have loved, uniquely and strangely, everything summed up in the word: fall.
  13: 
  14: So, in the year, my favourite season is the last slow part of summer that just precedes autumn, and, in the day, the hour when I walk is when the sun hesitates before vanishing, with rays of yellow bronze over the grey walls, and rays of red copper over the tiles.
  15: 
  16: Literature, also, from which my spirit asks voluptuousness, that will be the agonised poetry of Rome’s last moments, so long as it does not breathe a breath of the reinvigorated stance of the Barbarians or stammer in childish Latin like Christian prose.
  17: 
  18: I was reading then one of those dear poems (whose flakes of rouge have more charm for me than young flesh), and dipping a hand into the pure animal fur, when a street organ sounded languishingly and sadly under my window.
  19: 
  20: It was playing in the great alley of poplars whose leaves, even in spring, seem mournful to me since Maria passed by them, on her last journey, lying among candles.
  21: 
  22: The instrument of sadnesses, yes, certainly: the piano flashes, the violin gives off light from its torn fibres, but the street organ in memory’s half-light made me dream despairingly.
  23: 
  24: Now it murmured a delightfully common song that filled the faubourgs with joy, an old, banal tune: why did its words pierce my soul and make me cry, like any romantic ballad?
  25: 
  26: I savoured it slowly and did not throw a coin through the window for fear of troubling my spirit and discovering that not only the instrument was playing.


====================================================================================================

   6: 
   7: " and I should laugh to myself and keep quite quiet.
   8: 
   9: I should slyly open my petals and watch you at your work.
  10: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  11: When after your bath, with wet hair spread on your shoulders, you walked through the shadow of the champa tree to the little court where you say your prayers, you would notice the scent of the flower, but not know that it came from me.
  12: 
  13: When after the midday meal you sat at the window reading Ramayana, and the tree's shadow fell over your hair and your lap, I should fling my wee little shadow on to the page of your book, just where you were reading.
  14: 
  15: But would you guess that it was the tiny shadow of your little child?
  16: 
  17: When in the evening you went to the cow-shed with the lighted lamp in your hand, I should suddenly drop on to the earth again and be your own baby once more, and beg you to tell me a story.
  18: 
  19: "Where have you been, you naughty child?
  20: 
  21: "I won't tell you, mother.
  22: 
  23: " That's what you and I would say then.

#47: 66730_I Cast My Net Into The Sea_Tagore, Rabindranath_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: I Cast My Net Into The Sea
Author: Tagore, Rabindranath
Prose starts at line: 5
Lines to remove: 14
Avg verse line length: 34.0
Avg prose line length: 96.6

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: I Cast My Net Into The Sea
   2: 
   3: In the morning I cast my net into the sea.
   4: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   5: I dragged up from the dark abyss things of strange aspect and strange beauty -- some shone like a smile, some glistened like tears, and some were flushed like the cheeks of a bride.
   6: 
   7: When with the day's burden I went home, my love was sitting in the garden idly tearing the leaves of a flower.
   8: 
   9: I hesitated for a moment, and then placed at her feet all that I had dragged up, and stood silent.
  10: 
  11: She glanced at them and said, "What strange things are these?
  12: 
  13: I know not of what use they are!"
  14: I bowed my head in shame and thought, "I have not fought for these, I did not buy them in the market; they are not fit gifts for her.
  15: 
  16: Then the whole night through I flung them one by one into the street.
  17: 
  18: In the morning travellers came; they picked them up and carried them into far countries.

1473: 
1474: And you sit there smiling.
1475: 
1476: 103.
1477: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1478: In one salutation to thee, my God, let all my senses spread out and touch this world at thy feet.
1479: 
1480: Like a rain-cloud of July hung low with its burden of unshed showers let all my mind bend down at thy door in one salutation to thee.
1481: 
1482: Let all my songs gather together their diverse strains into a single current and flow to a sea of silence in one salutation to thee.
1483: 
1484: Like a flock of homesick cranes flying night and day back to their mountain nests let all my life take its voyage to its eternal home in one salutation to thee.
1485: 
1486: In the introduction to Gitanjali, W.
1487: 
1488: B Yeats says of Tagore’s poetry.
1489: 
1490: “At every moment the heart of this poet flows outward to these without derogation or condescension, for it has known that they will understand; and it has filled itself with the circumstance of their lives.
1491: 
1492: “An innocence, a simplicity that one does not find elsewhere in literature makes the birds and the leaves seem as near to him as they are near to children, and the changes of the seasons great events as before our thoughts had arisen between them and us.

   4:

   8: 
   9: You seemed to me like a terror and I shut my door.
  10:

#50: 66863_I Found A Few Old Letters_Tagore, Rabindranath_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: I Found A Few Old Letters
Author: Tagore, Rabindranath
Prose starts at line: 4
Lines to remove: 7
Avg verse line length: 14.0
Avg prose line length: 252.5

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: I Found A Few Old Letters
   2: 
   3: XIV

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   4: I found a few old letters of mine carefully hidden in thy box—a few small toys for thy memory to play with.
   5: 
   6: With a timorous heart thou didst try to steal these trifles from the turbulent stream of time which washes away planets and stars, and didst say, “These are only mine!” Alas, there is no one now who can claim them—who is able to pay their price; yet they are still here.
   7: 
   8: Is there no love in this world to rescue thee from utter loss, even like this love of thine that saved these letters with such fond care?
   9: 
  10: O woman, thou camest for a moment to my side and touched me with the great mystery of the woman that there is in the heart of creation—she who ever gives back to God his own outflow of sweetness; who is the eternal love and beauty and youth; who dances in bubbling streams and sings in the morning light; who with heaving waves suckles the thirsty earth and whose mercy melts in rain; in whom the eternal one breaks in two in joy that can contain itself no more and overflows in the pain of love.


====================================================================================================
#51: 66882_Chicago- A Historical & Literary Review_Horton, Randall_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Chicago: A Historical & Literary Review
Author: Horton, Randall
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 13
Avg verse line length: 39.0
Avg prose line length: 177.3

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Chicago: A Historical & Literary Review
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: chicago: city of ice-cold wind — elbow city of the rectangular block, where bigger thomas choked mary dalton in a drunken stupor on cottage grove, that great avenue divider between the haves & have-nots, where my uncle sydney fled after escaping an alabama chain gang a quarter after midnight &, consequently, cleaved the tennessee river (shackles & all) into another state of freedom.
   4: 
   5: chicago: home of the case pocketknife, the nickel-plated snub nose, the banana-suit wearer, gold tooth & all.
   6: 
   7: they migrated from alabama red dirt, from arkansas cotton fields bowlegged & pigeon-toed, & if you’ve ever resided on the west side, then you might as well been living in lil’ mississippi: natchez, vicksburg, grenada, yazoo city, booneville.
   8: 
   9: chicago: home of the winding el, the circling loop, the midnight cruise down lake shore from hyde park straight to buddy guy’s  legends; all them blues in one locale.
  10: 
  11: the one-night stands the city gives you — the identity it injects then sucks from your marrow; the lives gunned down.
  12: 
  13: chicago: where gwendolyn brooks scribedIn the Meccafeaturing  pepita, our tragic protagonist: assaulted, murdered & forgotten by blue lives matter in ’68 & today nothing has changed.
  14: 
  15: chicago: come sit in the corrupted light.

   3: Last summer I found a small box stashed away in my apartment,a box  filled with enough Vicodin to kill me.
   4: 
   5: I would  have swornthat  I'd  thrown it away years earlier,  but apparently not.
   6: 
   7: I staredat the white pills blankly for a long while, I even took a picture ofthem,  before  (finally, definitely)  throwing  them away.
   8: 
   9: I'd beensober  (again)  for  some years  when  I found that box,  but everyaddict  has  one— a  little  box,  metaphorical  or  actual— hiddenaway.
  10: 
  11: Before I flushed them  I held them in my palm,  marvelingthat  at  some  point in  the  not-so-distant  past it seemed a goodidea  to  keep a  stash of  pills on hand.
  12: 
  13: For an emergency, I toldmyself.
  14: 
  15: What kind of emergency?
  16: 
  17: What  if  I needed  a root canalon  a  Sunday  night?
  18: 
  19: This little  box  would  see me through untilthe   dentist   showed   up  for   work  the  next  morning.
  20: 
  21: Half  mybrain  told  me  that,  while  the other half  knew that  looking intothat  box  was  akin  to  seeing  a photograph of myself standing onthe  edge of a bridge,  a bridge  in the  familiar  dark neighborhoodof  my  mind,   that   comfortable  place   where  I  could  somehowbelieve thatfuck itwas an adequate response to life.

#53: 67296_The Rose Of The Wilderness (Gathered In Crossing A Portage On The River Winnipeg_Mountain, George Jehoshaphat_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Rose Of The Wilderness (Gathered In Crossing A Portage On The River Winnipeg)
Author: Mountain, George Jehoshaphat
Prose starts at line: 202
Lines to remove: 20
Avg verse line length: 68.1
Avg prose line length: 179.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 197: 
 198: We were pursuing our way upon a little sluggish stream, not wider than a large ditch; the guide had put out all our other men, except one, to proceed on foot, in order to lessen the draught of water: my chaplain remained with me in the canoe, and we could speedily have filled it, while we went along, with the roses and water-lilies which we gathered on both sides, as we sat; the former not only fringing the water, but, actually, as well as the latter, growing in it.
 199: 
 200: There was also growing plentifully in the water, a large kind of blue orchis.
 201: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 202: On our left hand, the thick shrubs and bushes which delight in proximity to the water, softened down, with their full and rounded foliage, into one dense mass of verdure, formed, in a manner, the bank of the stream, receding, in a slope, to a rising ground, which was covered by a growth of larch-trees -- this soft mass of bushes was gemmed all over with roses, producing an effect which no art could ever match.
 203: 
 204: From the right margin, after a small space of level swamp, the ground swells into a moderate and broken eminence, scattered over with large pines, and covered with heather-like shrubs.
 205: 
 206: The stream was mean enough, and the whole landscape was of a somewhat confined character; but the scene, in a bright and beautiful day, was really enchanting, and the lavish decoration of the wilderness, a refreshment in itself to the spirit of man, was like the loveliness of all that mercy which sweetens the troubled pilgrimage of life.
 207: 
 208: The mespilus is called by the French Canadians, who eat the berry, it is needless to say very incorrectly, the poirier sauvage.
 209: 
 210: It is exceedingly common in Canada.
 211: 
 212: The rowan, or mountain-ash, is among the prime ornaments of the Canadian forest; elegant in form, beautiful in its delicate leaves and branches, very handsome in flower, and quite brilliant in its profuse flat clusters of scarlet berries, which long continue to enliven even the months of winter.
 213: 
 214: The choke-cherry is also very ornamental, particularly when it grows as a large shrub, in which case it often assumes, when it has free scope, a very ample and rounded form.
 215: 
 216: Its dropping clusters of flowers, when they have passed into fruit, give the name to the plant, among the French, of cerise a grappes.
 217: 
 218: I should have been glad, for the sake of many of my hoped-for readers, to have given the botanic names and scientific classification of some dried flowers which I gathered on the route; but my part here is
 219: -- quod non didici, saue nescire fateri.
 220: 
 221: ~Songs of the Wilderness (1846).

  40: Sure mercies sworn by God, but hid to those
  41: Whose soul no want and no compunction knows:
  42: Blessed are they that mourn! to them belongs
  43: Joy on their heads, with everlasting songs.
  44: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  45: 'Whatever may be the merits or demerits of these lines in other respects, I venture to say that the description of the falls and rainbow, as viewed about five o'clock on a bright afternoon in the end of July, is closely accurate and faithful.
  46: 
  47: The cataract, always  excepting Niagara, which stands alone and supreme, is by far the grandest and most striking which I have ever seen.
  48: 
  49: The summer of the fall exhibits, in a remarkable manner, what is observable in many of the streams of Canada, where they break over stones or rocks, that appearance which is described in an exquisite simile by the hand of Scott -- a master-hand, indeed, in portraying, with effect in every touch, at once the poetry and the vivid reality of the face of nature:
  50: Each wave was crested with tawny foam,
  51: Like the mane of a chesnut steed.
  52: 
  53: I should guess the fall to be not less than two hundred feet high.
  54: 
  55: The gentleman who travelled with me as my chaplain, first called my attention to a tremulousness in the whole atmosphere as we approached the fall, to which allusion is made in the first line.
  56: 
  57: ~Songs of the Wilderness (1846).

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  15: Thy mother goes, within His house of prayer,
  16: Blest rite with hundreds of her race to share.
  17: 
  18: 'Popularly, but not very properly, so called.
  19: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  20: It is not a rocking receptacle, but simply a kind of ornamented bag, into which the child is put, up to the neck, lacing in front, and attached to thin flat boards behind, which rest upon the shoulders of the mother, the child's face being outward.
  21: 
  22: The annexed engravings from the drawings of a valued friend, taken from a specimen which I brought from the Red River, among the presents there made to me, will give a better idea of it than the description.
  23: 
  24: The lacing, however, is not left open before, as represented in the engraving, which gives a front view, the bag behind being closed, in the case of the living subject, up to the throat.
  25: 
  26: ~Songs of the Wilderness (1846).

#58: 67305_Le Lac Des Morts_Mountain, George Jehoshaphat_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Le Lac Des Morts
Author: Mountain, George Jehoshaphat
Prose starts at line: 96
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 44.8
Avg prose line length: 235.4

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  91: 
  92: A few particulars of information, however, may here and there be stated, which may seem to add something to their interest, and which are not found, so far as his recollection serves him, in the journal mentioned in the Preface.
  93: 
  94: He speaks from recollection only, the original letters which form the journal having been sent off, as fast as they were written, to England.
  95: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  96: The Lake of the Dead is not laid down, or not under that name, in any of the maps which I have seen; nor mentioned, so far as I am aware, in any book.
  97: 
  98: Maps and books, indeed, will readily be understood to pass without notice a multitude of lesser lakes, forming part of the extended chain of waters through which the route of the traveller is carried, and which exhibit every variety, from Lakes Superior, Huron, and Winnipeg, which may be called fresh-water inland seas, down to the clear pond embosomed in wooded hills which bears the name of Cold Lake,-- or among rivers, from the magnificent Ottawa to obscure and skulking streams, where you seem to be stealing your way along, as if to hide from pursuit, which barely afford passage for the canoe.
  99: 
 100: The more experienced voyageurs have names for them all, although it does not invariably happen that they are agreed which is which.
 101: 
 102: The Lake of the Dead, however, was not the subject of any such difference among our people.
 103: 
 104: It is a fine sheet of water studded with islets, and, according to the account of our guide, about a dozen miles in length, by perhaps rather more than half as many in breadth.
 105: 
 106: A spot is pointed out in the portage as one of its extremities, in a thick wood, composed, in part, of straight and nobles pines, where a man is said to have been killed by the fall of a tree; but the name of the lake, though ambiguous in point of number, in English, cannot, in the original French, be traced to this circumstance, since in this language it is in the plural (for which reason I have headed the stanzas with the French title).
 107: 
 108: The portage is also called the Portage des Morts, but, with little doubt, after the Lake.
 109: 
 110: We passed many whole days on the journey without getting a glimpse of even a solitary savage gliding by in his little canoe, or of a straggling half-naked family peeping out of the opening of the conical tent of bark-covered poles, among the trees; but in this part of the route we were five days and a half without encountering a single human being.
 111: 
 112: Respecting the quondam brigades of canoes which passed by this route laden with peltries, and the song of the voyageurs, I may refer to The toils of the Voyageur in this volume; and respecting the crosses erected to mark the graves of persons drowned on the way, to the journal above noticed.
 113: 
 114: ~Songs of the Wilderness (1846).


====================================================================================================
#59: 67307_Mosquitoes (Sonnet XV.)_Mountain, George Jehoshaphat_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Mosquitoes (Sonnet XV.)
Author: Mountain, George Jehoshaphat
Prose starts at line: 22
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 39.4
Avg prose line length: 111.9

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  17: To arm the face: men there whose dwellings rest
  18: Crouch in thick smoke; like help their cattle gain.
  19: 
  20: O wise in trials great, in troubles small,
  21: Who know to find mementos of the fall!

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  22: The author had been travelling by canoe in the Hudson's Bay territory (Rupert's Land, a part of central Canada) in the summer of 1844.
  23: 
  24: In the Preface of his book, Songs of the Wilderness (1846), he makes specific mention of the mosquitoes:-- ".
  25: 
  26: 
  27: the poems were all composed upon the journey; now lounging in the canoe; now lying awake, for some short portion of the night, under my tent; now sitting upon a stone or a fallen tree, while the people were carrying their loads across a portage; and first drawing, perhaps, my veil round my neck, to protect my face and ears from the mosquitoes,--in such a situation specially apt to be annoying.
  28: 
  29: 
  30: like help their cattle gain.
  31: 
  32: ': I have been assured, that the cattle, in situations where this protection is provided for them, come lowing to the house to have the fire renewed, if it happens to fail.
  33: 
  34: It is necessary, sometimes, that they should stand in a thick smoke to be milked.
  35: 
  36: ~ Songs of the Wilderness, by George J.
  37: 
  38: Mountain.
  39: 
  40: LONDON: Francis & John Rivington, 1846.

  16: 
  17: O years ill fill'd! — yet, to redeem the time,
  18: Thy grace bestow, and bid me upward climb!
  19: 'Some of the Meditations of St.
  20: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  21: Bernard are interspersed with hexameter, or hexameter and pentameter lines, or occasionally with Leoline verses.
  22: 
  23: They are, as I presume, quotations, but I do not profess to know from whence they are taken.
  24: 
  25: The expression of sentiment in the line here quoted, may seem to some readers very strong; but if it was not too strong for St.
  26: 
  27: Bernard, the Author does not feel it to be too strong for himself; nor, indeed, can it be considered stronger than the language of our confessions in the Liturgy, especially in the Communion-office, which every devout Christian worshipper, viewing himself and his own doings as before God, sincerely and feelingly applies to his own case.
  28: 
  29: ~Songs of the Wilderness (1846).

#62: 67314_Sunday Morning On Lake Superior (Sonnet X.)_Mountain, George Jehoshaphat_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Sunday Morning On Lake Superior (Sonnet X.)
Author: Mountain, George Jehoshaphat
Prose starts at line: 17
Lines to remove: 15
Avg verse line length: 45.8
Avg prose line length: 191.5

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  12: Beneath the sun, and roll on surges rude,
  13: Culling thel eaves; nor can the sadness mask
  14: Which will, ill-timed, on thankful thoughts intrude:
  15: Yet bless us, Lord, and bless the distant Word
  16: Preach'd to our flocks, and be those suppliants heard!

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  17: 'We did not lie by on Sundays, except when it occurred, upon three occasions, that we fell in with one of the posts, and even then we made advantage of some part of the day to prosecute our voyage.
  18: 
  19: This arrangement, which was not without its pain to my feelings, was considered to be a work of necessity; for, independently of my having particular reasons for not prolonging my absence from the diocese, it had been so strongly represented to me that I must not attempt to cross Lake Superior on my return, after August, on account of the commencement of the windy season about the close of that month, as to induce me, conceiving that I had not a day to lose, to alter some public appointments of duty at Quebec, in order to set out a week earlier than the time which I had originally fixed.
  20: 
  21: On Lake Superior itself, it is specially necessary, at all seasons, not to lose any favourable weather for proceeding,-- the liability of detention, in the case of travellers by canoe, being very great.
  22: 
  23: With, perhaps, this exception, I could undertake the journey, if I had to repeat it, without infringing on the repose of the Sabbath.
  24: 
  25: The canoe-men, who were all Romanists, were given to understand that they had the option of attending our services, when the circumstances under which we performed them left it practicable; but there was only one among them who ever availed himself of this invitation.
  26: 
  27: He did so at one of the posts.
  28: 
  29: Had they wished it, the service would have been performed to them in French.
  30: 
  31: ~Songs of the Wilderness (1846).

#64: 67603_Shanghaied_Kemp, Harry_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Shanghaied
Author: Kemp, Harry
Prose starts at line: 52
Lines to remove: 9
Avg verse line length: 25.4
Avg prose line length: 82.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  47: Shanghaied!
  48: From CHANTEYS AND BALLADS, by Harry Kemp, published by Brentano's, New York, US, © 1920, p.
  49: 
  50: 49.
  51: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  52: "Shanghaied" means to be sent to sea against one's will, drugged by the shipping agents or their suppliers.
  53: 
  54: Originally the term may have been used for securing crew for the long voyage to Shanghai, China, but later meant being forced to sail on any voyage.
  55: 
  56: The word is used by merchant sailors, it is the equivalent of "press-ganged" in the navy.
  57: 
  58: Adapted for singing by Dave Robinson from Swansea, UK.
  59: 
  60: Charley Noble


====================================================================================================
#65: 67611_Ship's Glamour_Kemp, Harry_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Ship's Glamour
Author: Kemp, Harry
Prose starts at line: 58
Lines to remove: 13
Avg verse line length: 54.1
Avg prose line length: 115.1

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  53: 
  54: The
  55: South Sea King
  56: answered on a deep-toned dignified note.
  57: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  58: There was something so poignant and beautiful about the sound, that, standing alone, bundled in my oilskins, on the vacant deck streaked with brine and shining in the sun, I thrilled to wonder and the infinite mysticism of the sea.
  59: 
  60: "Ten years later, on a winter night in Provincetown, I was sitting alone in my shack there, reading by kerosene lamp.
  61: 
  62: The windows were sighing against a strong wind.
  63: 
  64: The wind must have touched a row of pots hung on the rough log wall outside, and clinked them together, because out of that dark cold night was born an exact incarnation of the sound of faintly ringing ships bells, invoking for me the identical mood of that brilliant summer dawn at sea off Good Hope.
  65: 
  66: I picked up a pencil and wrote the poem 'Ship's Glamour'.
  67: 
  68: The first version never needed revision.
  69: 
  70: Charley Noble
