----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  45: We're outward bound!
  46: From CHANTEYS AND BALLADS, by Harry Kemp, published by Brentano's, New York, US, © 1920, pp.
  47: 
  48: 32-33.
  49: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  50: This poem is composed in the form of a traditional nautical work song or shanty where a leader, the shantyman tells the story while the rest of the work crew choruses.
  51: 
  52: In the poem the work crew marches around the capstan, drawing the anchor cable in, prior to setting sail.
  53: 
  54: With its reference to "sand dunes" the location could be some dusty Western South American or Southern Californian port in the late 19th century.
  55: 
  56: The shantyman is waxing philosophical about their recent spree ashore.
  57: 
  58: This poem has been adapted for singing by Dave Robinson of Swansea, UK.
  59: 
  60: Charley Noble


====================================================================================================

Title: Liberty Lighting The World
Author: OReilly, John Boyle
Prose starts at line: 70
Lines to remove: 13
Avg verse line length: 45.5
Avg prose line length: 78.6

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  65: 
  66: One brain forges a constitution; but how shall the million souls be won?
  67: 
  68: Freedom is more than a resolution—he is not free who is free alone.
  69: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  70: Justice is mine, and it grows by loving, changing the world like the circling sun;
  71: Evil recedes from the spirit's proving as mist from the hollows when night is done.
  72: 
  73: I am the test, O silent toilers, holding the scales of error and truth;
  74: Proving the heritage held by spoilers from hard hands empty, and wasted youth.
  75: 
  76: Hither, ye blind, from your futile banding; know the rights, and the rights are won;
  77: Wrong shall die with the understanding—one truth clear and the work is done.
  78: 
  79: Nature is higher than Progress or Knowledge, whose need is ninety enslaved for ten;
  80: My word shall stand against mart and college: THE PLANET BELONGS TO ITS LIVING MEN!
  81: And hither, ye weary ones and breathless, searching the seas for a kindly shore,
  82: I am Liberty! patient, deathless—set by Love at the Nation's door.

 105: 'It is well, aye well, old Erin! The sons you give to me
 106: Are symbolled long in flag and song—your Sunburst on the Sea!
 107: All mine by the chrism of Freedom, still yours by their love's belief;
 108: And truest to me shall the tenderest be in a suffering mother's grief.
 109: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 110: Their loss is the change of the wave to the cloud, of the dew to the river and main;
 111: Their hope shall persist through the sea, and the mist, and thy streams shall be filled again.
 112: 
 113: As the smolt of the salmon go down to the sea, and as surely come back to the river,
 114: Their love shall be yours while your sorrow endures, for God guardeth His right forever! '

#70: 67913_from Beachy Head_Smith, Charlotte_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: from Beachy Head
Author: Smith, Charlotte
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 9
Avg verse line length: 16.0
Avg prose line length: 306.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: from Beachy Head
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: On thy stupendous summit, rock sublime! That o’er the channel reared, half way at sea The mariner at early morning hails, I would recline; while Fancy should go forth, And represent the strange and awful hour Of vast concussion; when the Omnipotent Stretched forth his arm, and rent the solid hills, Bidding the impetuous main flood rush between The rifted shores, and from the continent Eternally divided this green isle.
   4: 
   5: Imperial lord of the high southern coast! From thy projecting head-land I would mark Far in the east the shades of night disperse, Melting and thinned, as from the dark blue wave Emerging, brilliant rays of arrowy light Dart from the horizon; when the glorious sun Just lifts above it his resplendent orb.
   6: 
   7: Advances now, with feathery silver touched, The rippling tide of flood; glisten the sands, While, inmates of the chalky clefts that scar Thy sides precipitous, with shrill harsh cry, Their white wings glancing in the level beam, The terns, and gulls, and tarrocks, seek their food, And thy rough hollows echo to the voice Of the gray choughs, and ever restless daws, With clamor, not unlike the chiding hounds, While the lone shepherd, and his baying dog, Drive to thy turfy crest his bleating flock.
   8: 
   9: The high meridian of the day is past, And Ocean now, reflecting the calm Heaven, Is of cerulean hue; and murmurs low The tide of ebb, upon the level sands.
  10: 
  11: The sloop, her angular canvas shifting still, Catches the light and variable airs That but a little crisp the summer sea, Dimpling its tranquil surface.


====================================================================================================

Avg prose line length: 152.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Explaining Villanelles to an Alien
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: With “Waltzing Matilda,” funnel web spiders, and echidnas out of the way, you move on to the villanelle.
   4: 
   5: The alien learns quickly, and soon the rhyme scheme and refrain are being applied to whatever it encounters: moonlight filling a green bucket by the door, a dog’s tooth in furniture, the sound of a nail gun.
   6: 
   7: You go to bed and dream of planets disappearing like balls in a perfect snooker clearance.
   8: 
   9: In the morning you find the walls papered with villanelles, each one signed by what appears to be a bar code.
  10: 
  11: When you scan one with your phone, the screen lights up with footage of a satellite flyby through the heliosphere, trailing the sound of whale song, children crying, sustained applause, and Blind Willie Johnson’s “Dark Was the Night, Cold Was the Ground.

  46: In distant days, when time is o'er;
  47: But chide not thou, though tears I shed:
  48: It is enough -- my joy is fled,
  49: And far, far off the joy which thou hast promised.
  50: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  51: 'Though there seems every probability that the above song is intended as the lament of a lady at her separation from a knight who had followed St.
  52: 
  53: Louis to the crusades, it is possible that the separation might be occasioned by the unrelenting persecutions which were directed against the Albigenses.
  54: 
  55: The ultimate result of the contest was the complete extinction of chivalry and poetry in the South; and the lady would in this view of the case be a sorrower over the loss of her heretical love.
  56: 
  57: ~Lays of the Minnesingers, 1825.
  58: 
  59: A la fontana del vergier,
  60: On l' erb er vertz, josta 'l gravier,
  61: A l' ombra d' un fust domesgier,
  62: En aiziment de blancas flors
  63: E de novelh chan costumier,
  64: Trobey sola, ses companhier,
  65: Selha que no vol mon solatz.

#74: 68921_The Soul of the World_Crosby, Ernest Howard_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Soul of the World
Author: Crosby, Ernest Howard
Prose starts at line: 4
Lines to remove: 18
Avg verse line length: 31.0
Avg prose line length: 88.1

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: The Soul of the World
   2: 
   3: THE SOUL of the world is abroad to-night—

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   4: Not in yon silvery amalgam of moonbeam and ocean, nor in the pink heat-lightning tremulous on the horizon;
   5: Not in the embrace of yonder pair of lovers either, heart beating to heart in the shadow of the fishing-smack drawn up on the beach.
   6: 
   7: All that—shall I call it illusion?
   8: 
   9: Nay, but at best it is a pale reflection of the truth.
  10: 
  11: I am not to be put off with symbols, for the soul of the world is itself abroad to-night.
  12: 
  13: I neither see nor hear nor smell nor taste nor touch it, but faintly I feel it powerfully stirring.
  14: 
  15: I feel it as the blind heaving sea feels the moon bending over it.
  16: 
  17: I feel it as the needle feels the serpentine magnetic current coiling itself about the earth.
  18: 
  19: I open my arms to embrace it as the lovers embrace each other, but my embrace is all inclusive.
  20: 
  21: My heart beats to heart likewise, but it is to the heart universal, for the soul of the world is abroad to-night.

#76: 69620_The Lanawn Shee_Ledwidge, Francis_unknown.txt

Title: The Lanawn Shee
Author: Ledwidge, Francis
Prose starts at line: 145
Lines to remove: 7
Avg verse line length: 36.4
Avg prose line length: 123.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 140: 
 141: This poem taken from "Last Songs" by Francis Ledwidge, Published by Herbert Jenkins, London 1918 [page 73-80]
 142: Poem Dated:   Belgium, July, 1917
 143: Words and spelling verified JS
 144: NOTE

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 145: The Lanawn Shee is an Irish spirit who whispers in the poets' ears the secrets of our unseen world and makes them write them all down.
 146: 
 147: Those who hear the Lanawn-Shee whisper are said to be consumed by an unquenchable fire; they feel they must write down all she says, but so incessant is her muttering that they can never keep up with her.
 148: 
 149: They'd not be able to write it all down even if they had three lifetimes to do it.
 150: 
 151: Allegedly she saps their strength and leaves them old before their time.

  36: 
  37: Corn I am the corn quail.
  38: 
  39: What I do is quick.
  40: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  41: You will know only  The muffled clucking,  The scurry, the first  Shiver of feathers  And I will be up,  I will be in your Head with no way out,  Wings beating at the  Air behind your eyes.
  42: 
  43: Celery The hope with  water is that it will conceal nothing, that a clearness will follow upon it  like the clearness  after much rain, or the clearness  where the air  reaches to the river and touches it, where the rain  falls from the trees  into the river.
  44: 
  45: Bell Pepper To find enough rooms for the gathering  The walls go on alone not waiting  For corners but thinking of sleeves And how the wind fills them and the snow  Fills them and how cold it is without  Fires when there are not enough rooms.
  46: 
  47: Potatoes It had been growing in her like vegetables.
  48: 
  49: She was going into the ground where it could  Do better, where she could have potatoes.
  50: 
  51: They would be small and easily mistaken  For stones.
  52: 
  53: It would fall to her to  Sort them out, persuade them to stay Close to her, comforting her, letting her  Wear them on her body, in her hair,  Helping her hold always very still.

#79: 69830_Ch 02 The Morals Of Dervishes Story 47_Shirazi, Saadi_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Ch 02 The Morals Of Dervishes Story 47
Author: Shirazi, Saadi
Prose starts at line: 22
Lines to remove: 9
Avg verse line length: 65.4
Avg prose line length: 115.7

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  17: He does not sit at the door of pretence away from people
  18: To fight against them if they oppose him
  19: Because when a millstone rolls from a mountain
  20: He is not an A’rif who gets out of the way of the stone.
  21: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  22: The way of dervishes is praying, gratitude, service, obedience, almsgiving, contentment, professing the unity of God, trust, submission and patience.
  23: 
  24: Whoever possesses these qualities is really a dervish, although he may wear an elegant robe, whereas a prattler who neglects his orisons, is luxurious, sensual, turns day into night in the bondage of lust, and night into day in the sleep of carelessness, eats whatever he gets, and speaks whatever comes upon his tongue, is a profligate, although he may wear the habit of a dervish.
  25: 
  26: O thou whose interior is denuded of piety
  27: But wearest outwardly the garb of hypocrisy
  28: Do not display a curtain of seven colours.
  29: 
  30: Thou hast reed mats inside thy house.

   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: A vezier paid a visit to Zulnun Misri and asked for his favour, saying: "I am day and night engaged in the service of the sultan and hoping to be rewarded but nevertheless dread to be punished by him.
   4: 
   5: " Zulnun wept and said: "Had I feared God, the great and glorious, as thou fearest the sultan, I would be one of the number of the righteous.
   6: 
   7: If there were no hope of rest and trouble
   8: The foot of the dervish would be upon the sphere
   9: And if the vezier feared God
  10: Like the king he would be king.

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Ch 01 Manner Of Kings Story 35
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: I was sitting in a vessel with a company of great men when a boat which contained two brothers happened to sink near us.
   4: 
   5: One of the great men promised a hundred dinars to a sailor if he could save them both.
   6: 
   7: Whilst however the sailor was pulling out one, the other perished.
   8: 
   9: I said: "He had no longer to live and therefore delay took place in rescuing him.
  10: 
  11: " The sailor smiled and replied: "What thou hast said is certain.
  12: 
  13: Moreover, I preferred to save this one because, when I once-happened to lag behind in the desert, he seated me on his camel, whereas I had received a whipping by the hands of the other.
  14: 
  15: When I was a boy I recited: He, who doth right, doth it to his own soul and he, who doth evil, doth it against the same.
  16: 
  17: As long as thou canst, scratch the interior of no one
  18: Because there are thorns on this road.
  19: 
  20: Be helpful in the affairs of a dervish
  21: Because thou also hast affairs.

#82: 69839_Ch 03 On The Excellence Of Contentment Story 20_Shirazi, Saadi_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Ch 03 On The Excellence Of Contentment Story 20
Author: Shirazi, Saadi
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 13
Avg verse line length: 47.0
Avg prose line length: 130.3

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Ch 03 On The Excellence Of Contentment Story 20
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: A king with some of his courtiers had during a hunting party and in the winter season strayed far from inhabited places but when the night set in he perceived the house of a dehqan and said: ‘We shall spend the night there to avoid the injury of the cold.
   4: 
   5: ’ One of the veziers, however, objected alleging that it was unworthy of the high dignity of a padshah to take refuge in the house of a dehqan and that it would be best to pitch tents and to light fires on the spot.
   6: 
   7: The dehqan who had become aware of what was taking place prepared some food he had ready in his house, offered it, kissed the ground of service and said: ‘The high dignity of the sultan would not have been so much lowered, but the courtiers did not wish the dignity of the dehqan to become high.
   8: 
   9: ’ The king who was pleased with these words moved for the night into the man’s house and bestowed a dress of honour upon him the next morning.
  10: 
  11: When he accompanied the king a few paces at the departure he was heard to say:
  12: ‘Nothing was lost of the sultan’s power and pomp
  13: By accepting the hospitality of a dehqan,
  14: But the corner of the dehqan’s cap reached the sun
  15: When a sultan such as thou overshadowed his head.

#83: 69848_Ch 04 On The Advantages Of Silence Story 13_Shirazi, Saadi_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Ch 04 On The Advantages Of Silence Story 13
Author: Shirazi, Saadi
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 12
Avg verse line length: 43.0
Avg prose line length: 119.9

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Ch 04 On The Advantages Of Silence Story 13
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: A man used to shout superfluous calls to prayers in the mosque of Sinjar and in a voice which displeased all who heard it.
   4: 
   5: The owner of the mosque, who was a just and virtuous amir, not desirous to give him pain, said: ‘My good fellow, in this mosque there are old muezzins’ to each of whom I pay five dinars monthly but to thee I shall give ten, if thou wilt go to another place.
   6: 
   7: ’ The man agreed and went away.
   8: 
   9: Some time afterwards however, he returned to the amir and said: ‘My lord, thou hast injured me by turning me away for ten dinars from this place because where I next went they offered me twenty dinars to go to another locality but I refused.
  10: 
  11: ’ The amir smiled and said: ‘By no means accept them because will give thee even fifty dinars.
  12: 
  13: No one can scrape the mud from gravel with an axe
  14: As thy discordant shouting scrapes the heart.

#84: 69850_Ch 03 On The Excellence Of Contentment Story 10_Shirazi, Saadi_unknown.txt

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Ch 03 On The Excellence Of Contentment Story 10
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: A grain dealer to whom Sufis were owing some money asked them for it every day in the town of Waset and used harsh language towards them.
   4: 
   5: The companions had become weary of his reproaches but had no other remedy than to bear them; and one of them who was a pious man remarked: ‘It is more easy to pacify a hungry stomach with promises of food than a grain dealer with promises of money.
   6: 
   7: It is preferable to be without the bounty of a gentleman
   8: Than to bear the insults of the gate-keepers.
   9: 
  10: It is better to die wishing for meat
  11: Than to endure the expostulations of butchers.

   3: One year discord had arisen in a caravan among the walking portion and I also travelled on foot.
   4: 
   5: To obtain justice we attacked each other’s heads and faces, giving full vent to pugnacity and contention.
   6: 
   7: I saw a man sitting in a camel litter and saying to his companion: ‘How wonderful! A pawn of ivory travels across the chess-board and becomes a farzin, and the footmen of the Haj travelled across the whole desert only to become worse.
   8: 
   9: Tell on my part to the man-biting Haji
  10: Who tears the skins of people with torments:
  11: Thou art not a Haji but a camel is one
  12: Because, poor brute, it feeds on thorns and bears loads.

#86: 69878_Ch 01 Manner Of Kings Story 34_Shirazi, Saadi_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Ch 01 Manner Of Kings Story 34
Author: Shirazi, Saadi
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 15
Avg verse line length: 30.0
Avg prose line length: 82.7

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Ch 01 Manner Of Kings Story 34
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: One of the sons of Harun-ur-Rashid went to his father and angrily informed him that the son of an official had used insulting expressions towards him whereon Harun asked his courtiers what requital he deserved.
   4: 
   5: One of them proposed capital punishment, another the amputation of the tongue whilst a third recommended fine and imprisonment.
   6: 
   7: Then Harun said: "Oh my son, it would be generous to pardon him but, if thou art unable to do so, use likewise insulting expressions concerning his mother; not however to such a degree as to exceed the bounds of vengeance because in that case the wrong will be on thy side.
   8: 
   9: He is not reputed a man by the wise
  10: Who contends with a furious elephant
  11: But he is a man in reality
  12: Who when angry speaks not idle words.
  13: 
  14: An ill-humoured fellow insulted a man
  15: Who patiently bore it saying: "O hopeful youth,
  16: I am worse than thou speakest of me
  17: For I am more conscious of my faults than thou.


====================================================================================================
#87: 69884_Ch 02 The Morals Of Dervishes Story 14_Shirazi, Saadi_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Ch 02 The Morals Of Dervishes Story 14
Author: Shirazi, Saadi
Prose starts at line: 5

Avg verse line length: 58.0
Avg prose line length: 108.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Ch 02 The Morals Of Dervishes Story 14
   2: 
   3: A dervish who had fallen into want stole a blanket from the house of a friend.
   4: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   5: The judge ordered his hand to be amputated but the owner of the blanket interceded, saying that he had condoned the fault.
   6: 
   7: The judge rejoined: ‘Thy intercession cannot persuade me to neglect the provision of the law.
   8: 
   9: ’ The man continued: ‘Thou hast spoken the truth but amputation is not applicable to a person who steals some property dedicated to pious uses.
  10: 
  11: More over a beggar possesses nothing and whatever belongs to a dervish is dedicated to the use of the needy.
  12: 
  13: ’ Thereon the judge released the culprit, saying: ‘The world must indeed have become too narrow for thee that thou hast committed no theft except from the house of such a friend.
  14: 
  15: ’ He replied: ‘Hast thou not heard the saying: Sweep out the house of friends and do not knock at the door of foes.
  16: 
  17: If thou sinkest in a calamity be not helpless.
  18: 
  19: Strip thy foes of their skins and thy friends of their fur-coats.

#88: 69885_Ch 04 On The Advantages Of Silence Story 10_Shirazi, Saadi_unknown.txt

Avg verse line length: 43.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Ch 04 On The Advantages Of Silence Story 10
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: A poet went to an amir of robbers and recited a panegyric but he ordered him to be divested of his robe.
   4: 
   5: As the poor man was departing naked in the world, he was attacked from behind by dogs, whereon he intended to snatch up a stone but it was frozen to the ground and, being unable to do so, he exclaimed: ‘What whore-sons of men are these?
   6: 
   7: They have let loose the dogs and have tied down the stones.
   8: 
   9: ’ The amir of the robbers who heard these words from his room laughed and said: ‘O philosopher, ask something from me.
  10: 
  11: ’ He replied: ‘I ask for my robe if thou wilt make me a present of it.
  12: 
  13: We are satisfied of thy gift by departure.
  14: 
  15: A man was hoping for the gifts of people.
  16: 
  17: I hope no gift from thee.
  18: 
  19: Do me no evil.
  20: 
  21: The robber chief took pity upon him, ordered his robe to be restored to him and added to it a sheepskin jacket with some dirhems.

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Ch 03 On The Excellence Of Contentment Story 13
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: A dervish wanted something and a man told him that a certain individual possessed untold wealth who, if he were made aware of his want, would not consider it proper to fail in supplying it forthwith.
   4: 
   5: The dervish answering that he had no acquaintance with him, the man proposed to show him the house and when the dervish entered he caught sight of a person with hanging lips and sitting morosely.
   6: 
   7: He returned immediately and being asked what he had done replied: ‘I excused him from making me a present when I saw his face.
   8: 
   9: Carry not thy necessity to a sour-faced fellow
  10: Because his ill-humour will crush thy hopes.
  11: 
  12: If thou confidest thy heart’s grief, tell it to one
  13: Whose face will comfort thee like ready cash.

#90: 69890_Introductory 03_Shirazi, Saadi_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Introductory 03
Author: Shirazi, Saadi
Prose starts at line: 135
Lines to remove: 14
Avg verse line length: 71.7
Avg prose line length: 149.6

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 130: Take a leaf from my rose-garden.
 131: 
 132: A flower endures but five or six days
 133: But this rose-garden is always delightful.
 134: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 135: After I had uttered these words he threw away the flowers from his skirts, and attached himself to mine, saying: ‘When a generous fellow makes a promise he keeps it.
 136: 
 137: On the same day I happened to write two chapters, namely on polite society and the rules of conversation, in a style acceptable to orators and instructive to letter-writers.
 138: 
 139: In short, some roses of the garden still remained when the book of the Rose-garden was finished but it will in reality be completed only after approbation in the court of the Shah, who is the refuge of the world, the shadow of God, the ray of his grace, the treasury of the age, the asylum of the Faith, strengthened by heaven, aided against enemies, the arm of the victorious government, the lamp of the resplendent religion, the beauty of mankind, the boast of Islam, Sa’d son of Atabek the great, the majestic Shahanshah, owner of the necks of nations, lord of the kings of Arabia and Persia, the sultan of the land and the sea, the heir of the kingdom of Solomon, Muzaffaruddin Ibu Bekr, son of Sa’d Zanki, may Allah the most high perpetuate the prosperity of them both and direct their inclinations to every good thing.
 140: 
 141: Perused with a kind glance,
 142: Adorned with approbation by the sovereign,
 143: It will be a Chinese picture-gallery or design of the Arzank,
 144: Hopes are entertained that he will not be wearied
 145: By these contents because a Pose-garden is not a place of displeasure.
 146: 
 147: The more so as its august preface is dedicated
 148: To Sa’d Abu Bekr Sa’d the son of Zanki.


====================================================================================================
#91: 69892_Ch 02 The Morals Of Dervishes Story 26_Shirazi, Saadi_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Ch 02 The Morals Of Dervishes Story 26
Author: Shirazi, Saadi
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 18
Avg verse line length: 38.0
Avg prose line length: 72.4

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Ch 02 The Morals Of Dervishes Story 26
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: I remember having once walked all night with a caravan and then slept on the edge of the desert.
   4: 
   5: A distracted man who had accompanied us on that journey raised a shout, ran towards the desert and took not a moment’s rest.
   6: 
   7: When it was daylight, I asked him what state of his that was.
   8: 
   9: He replied: "I saw bulbuls commencing to lament on the trees, the partridges on the mountains, the frogs in the water and the beasts in the desert so I bethought myself that it would not be becoming for me to sleep in carelessness while they all were praising God.
  10: 
  11: Yesterday at dawn a bird lamented,
  12: Depriving me of sense, patience, strength and consciousness.
  13: 
  14: One of my intimate friends who
  15: Had perhaps heard my distressed voice
  16: Said: "I could not believe that thou
  17: Wouldst be so dazed by a bird’s cry.
  18: 
  19: I replied: "It is not becoming to humanity
  20: That I should be silent when birds chant praises.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Ch 05 On Love And Youth Story 02
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: It is said that a gentleman possessed a slave of exquisite beauty, whom he regarded with love and affection.
   4: 
   5: He nevertheless said to a friend: ‘Would that this slave of mine, with all the beauty and good qualities he possesses, had not a long and uncivil tongue!’ He replied: ‘Brother, do not expect service, after professing friendship; because when relations between lover and beloved come in, the relations between master and servant are superseded’:
   6: When a master with a fairy-faced slave
   7: Begins to play and to laugh
   8: What wonder if the latter coquets like the master
   9: And the gentleman bears it like a slave?
  10: 
  11: A slave is to draw water and make bricks.
  12: 
  13: A pampered slave will strike with the fist.

   1: Ch 02 The Morals Of Dervishes Story 41
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: A company of vagabonds met a dervish, spoke insulting words to him, struck him and otherwise molested him; whereon he complained to his superior and explained the case.
   4: 
   5: The pir replied: ‘My son, the patched frock of dervishes is the garment of resignation and who, wearing it, cannot bear injuries is a pretender not entitled to the frock.
   6: 
   7: A large river will not become turbid from stones.
   8: 
   9: The Arif who feels aggrieved is shallow water yet.
  10: 
  11: If he injures thee, bear it
  12: Because pardon will purify thee from sin.
  13: 
  14: O brother, as the end is dust, be dust before thou art turned into dust.

#94: 69934_Ch 01 Manner Of Kings Story 33_Shirazi, Saadi_unknown.txt

Author: Shirazi, Saadi
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 16
Avg verse line length: 30.0
Avg prose line length: 68.1

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Ch 01 Manner Of Kings Story 33
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: One of the veziers of a king treated his subordinates with kindness and sought the goodwill of his colleagues.
   4: 
   5: Once he happened to be called to account by the king for something he had done whereon his colleagues endeavoured to effect his liberation.
   6: 
   7: Those who guarded him treated him leniently and the great men expatiated upon his good character to the padshah till he renounced all further inquiry.
   8: 
   9: A pious man who took cognizance of this affair said:
  10: "In order to gain the hearts of friends
  11: Sell even the garden of thy father.
  12: 
  13: In order to boil the pot of well-wishers
  14: Burn even all the furniture of the house.
  15: 
  16: Do good even to a malevolent fellow.
  17: 
  18: Tie up the mouth of the dog with a sop.

   1: Ch 05 On Love And Youth Story 06
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: I remember that one night a dear friend of mine entered when I jumped up in such a heedless way that the lamp was extinguished by my sleeve.
   4: 
   5: A vision appeared in the night and by its appearance the darkness was illuminated.
   6: 
   7: I was amazed at my luck exclaiming whence this felicity?
   8: 
   9: He took a seat and began reproving me saying that when I beheld him I extinguished the lamp.
  10: 
  11: I said: ‘I thought the sun had risen and wits have said:
  12: When an ugly person comes before the lamp
  13: Arise to him and pull him into the assembly
  14: But if it be a sugar-smiled, sweet-lipped one
  15: Pull him by the sleeve and extinguish the lamp.

   2:

   3: It is related that a hermit consumed during one night ten mann of food and perused the whole Quran till morning.
   4: 
   5: A pious fellow who had heard of this said: ‘It would have been more excellent if he had eaten half a loaf and slept till the morning.
   6: 
   7: Keep thy interior empty of food
   8: That thou mayest behold therein the light of marifet.
   9: 
  10: Thou art empty of wisdom for the reason
  11: That thou art replete with food up to the nose.

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Ch 01 Manner Of Kings Story 36
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: There were two brothers: one of them in the service of the sultan and the other gaining his livelihood by the effort of his arm.
   4: 
   5: The wealthy man once asked his destitute brother why he did not serve the sultan in order to be delivered from the hardship of labouring.
   6: 
   7: He replied: "Why labourest thou not to be delivered from the baseness of service because philosophers have said that it is better to eat barley bread and to sit than to gird oneself with a golden belt and to stand in service?
   8: 
   9: To leaven mortar of quicklime with the hand
  10: Is better than to hold them on the breast before the amir.
  11: 
  12: My precious life was spent in considering
  13: What I am to eat in summer and wear in winter.
  14: 
  15: O ignoble belly, be satisfied with one bread
  16: Rather than to bend the back in service.

   3: A pious man saw in a dream a padshah in paradise and a devotee in hell whereon he asked for the reason of the former’s exaltation and the latter’s degradation, saying that he had imagined the contrary ought to be the case.
   4: 
   5: He received the following answer: ‘The padshah had, for the love he bore to dervishes, been rewarded with paradise and the devotee had, for associating with padshahs, been punished in hell.
   6: 
   7: Of what use is thy frock, rosary and patched dress?
   8: 
   9: Keep thyself free from despicable practices.
  10: 
  11: Then thou wilt have no need of a cap of leaves.
  12: 
  13: Have the qualities of a dervish and wear a Tatar cap

#99: 69959_Ch 06 On Weakness And Old Age Story 04_Shirazi, Saadi_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Ch 06 On Weakness And Old Age Story 04
Author: Shirazi, Saadi
Prose starts at line: 3

Avg verse line length: 38.0
Avg prose line length: 74.5

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Ch 06 On Weakness And Old Age Story 04
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: One day, in the pride of youth, I had travelled hard and arrived perfectly exhausted in the evening at the foot of an acclivity.
   4: 
   5: A weak old man, who had likewise been following the caravan, came and asked me why I was sleeping, this not being the place for it.
   6: 
   7: I replied: ‘How am I to travel, having lost the use of my feet?
   8: 
   9: ’ He said: ‘Hast thou not heard that it is better to walk gently and to halt now and then than to run and to become exhausted?
  10: 
  11: O thou who desirest to reach the station
  12: Take my advice and learn patience.
  13: 
  14: An Arab horse gallops twice in a race.
  15: 
  16: A camel ambles gently night and day.

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Ch 03 On The Excellence Of Contentment Story 02
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: Two sons of amirs were in Egypt, the one acquiring science, the other accumulating wealth, till the former became the ullemma of the period and the other the prince of Egypt; whereon the rich man looked with contempt upon the faqih and said: ‘I have reached the sultanate whilst thou hast remained in poverty as before.
   4: 
   5: ’ He replied: ‘O brother, I am bound to be grateful to the most high Creator for having obtained the inheritance of prophets whilst thou hast attained the inheritance of Pharaoh and of Haman, namely the kingdom of Egypt.
   6: 
   7: I am that ant which is trodden under foot
   8: Not that wasp, the pain of whose sting causes lament.
   9: 
  10: How shall I give due thanks for the blessing
  11: That I do not possess the strength of injuring mankind?

#101: 69966_Ch 08 On Rules For Conduct In Life - Maxim 57_Shirazi, Saadi_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Ch 08 On Rules For Conduct In Life - Maxim 57
Author: Shirazi, Saadi
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 9
Avg verse line length: 45.0
Avg prose line length: 115.3

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Ch 08 On Rules For Conduct In Life - Maxim 57
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: The meekness of the camel is known to be such that if a child takes hold of its bridle and goes a hundred farsakhs, it will not refuse to follow, but if a dangerous portion occurs which may occasion death and the child ignorantly desires to approach it, the camel tears the bridle from his hand, refusing any longer to obey because compliance in times of calamity is blamable.
   4: 
   5: It is also said that by complaisance an enemy will not become a friend but that his greed will only be augmented.
   6: 
   7: To him who is kind to thee, be dust at his feet
   8: But if he opposes thee fill his two eyes with dust.
   9: 
  10: Speak not kindly or gently to an ill-humoured fellow
  11: Because a soft file cannot clean off inveterate rust.

   4:

   6:

   8:

#103: 69968_Ch 02 The Morals Of Dervishes Story 37_Shirazi, Saadi_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Ch 02 The Morals Of Dervishes Story 37
Author: Shirazi, Saadi
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 16
Avg verse line length: 38.0
Avg prose line length: 104.4

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Ch 02 The Morals Of Dervishes Story 37
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: A dervish arrived in a place, the owner of which was of a noble disposition, and had surrounded himself with a company of distinguished and eloquent men, each of whom uttered something elegant or jocular, according to the fashion of wits.
   4: 
   5: The dervish who had travelled through the desert and was fatigued had eaten nothing.
   6: 
   7: One of the company asked him by way of encouragement likewise to say something.
   8: 
   9: The dervish replied: ‘I do not possess distinction and eloquence like you and have read nothing so you must be satisfied with one distich of mine.
  10: 
  11: ’ The company having agreed with pleasure he recited:
  12: ‘I am hungry and opposite to a table of food
  13: Like a bachelor at the door of a bath of females.
  14: 
  15: The company, having thus been apprised of his famished condition, produced a table with bread but as he began to eat greedily the host said: ‘Friend, at any rate stop a while till my servants roast some minced meat’; whereon the dervish lifted his head and recited:
  16: ‘Do not order pounded meat for my table.
  17: 
  18: To a pounded man simple bread is pounded meat.

#104: 69971_Ch 07 On The Effects Of Education Story 19_Shirazi, Saadi_unknown.txt

Title: Ch 07 On The Effects Of Education Story 19
Author: Shirazi, Saadi
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 9
Avg verse line length: 42.0
Avg prose line length: 82.5

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Ch 07 On The Effects Of Education Story 19
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: I asked an illustrious man for the reason of the tradition: Account as an enemy the passion which is between thy two loins.
   4: 
   5: He replied: ‘The reason is because whatever enemy thou propitiatest becomes thy friend, whereas the more thou indulgest in a passion, the more it will oppose thee.
   6: 
   7: Man attains angelic nature by eating sparingly
   8: But if he be voracious like beasts he falls like a stone.
   9: 
  10: He whose wishes thou fulfillest will obey thy command
  11: Contrary to passion, which will command, when obeyed.

#105: 69980_Ch 03 On The Excellence Of Contentment Story 07_Shirazi, Saadi_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Ch 03 On The Excellence Of Contentment Story 07
Author: Shirazi, Saadi
Prose starts at line: 5
Lines to remove: 14
Avg verse line length: 45.0
Avg prose line length: 103.1

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Ch 03 On The Excellence Of Contentment Story 07
   2: 
   3: Two Khorasani dervishes travelled together.
   4: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   5: One of them, being weak, broke his fast every second night whilst the other who was strong consumed every day three meals.
   6: 
   7: It happened that they were captured at the gate of a town on suspicion of being spies; whereon each of them was confined in a closet and the aperture of it walled up with mud bricks.
   8: 
   9: After two weeks it became known that they were guiltless.
  10: 
  11: Accordingly the doors were opened and the strong man was found to be dead whilst the weak fellow had remained alive.
  12: 
  13: The people were astonished but a sage averred that the contrary would have been astonishing because one of them having been voracious possessed no strength to suffer hunger and perished whilst the other who was abstemious merely persevered in his habit and remained safe.
  14: 
  15: When eating little has become the nature of a man
  16: He takes it easy when a calamity befalls him
  17: But when the body becomes strong in affluence
  18: He will die when a hardship overtakes him.


====================================================================================================
#106: 69985_Ch 05 On Love And Youth Story 16_Shirazi, Saadi_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Ch 05 On Love And Youth Story 16
Author: Shirazi, Saadi
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 20
Avg verse line length: 32.0
Avg prose line length: 105.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Ch 05 On Love And Youth Story 16
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: I remember having in the days of my youth passed through a street, intending to see a moon-faced beauty.
   4: 
   5: It was in Temuz, whose heat dried up the saliva in the mouth and whose simum boiled the marrow in my bones.
   6: 
   7: My weak human nature being unable to endure the scorching sun, I took refuge in the shadow of a wall, wishing someone might relieve me from the summer heat and quench my fire with some water; and lo, all of a sudden, from the darkness of the porch of a house a light shone forth, namely a beauty, the grace of which the tongue of eloquence is unable to describe.
   8: 
   9: She came out like the rising dawn after an obscure night or the water of immortality gushing from a dark cavern, carrying in her hand a bowl of snow-water, into which sugar had been poured and essence of roses mixed.
  10: 
  11: I knew not whether she had perfumed it with rose-water or whether a few drops from her rosy face had fallen into it.
  12: 
  13: In short, I took the beverage from her beautiful hands, drank it and began to live again.
  14: 
  15: The thirst of my heart cannot be quenched
  16: By sipping limpid water even if I drink oceans of it.
  17: 
  18: Blessed is the man of happy destiny whose eye
  19: Alights every morning on such a countenance.
  20: 
  21: One drunk of wine awakens at midnight,
  22: One drunk of the cupbearer on the morn of resurrection.


====================================================================================================

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: One of the ullemma had been asked that, supposing one sits with a moon-faced beauty in a private apartment, the doors being closed, companions asleep, passion inflamed, and lust raging, as the Arab says, the date is ripe and its guardian not forbidding, whether he thought the power of abstinence would cause the man to remain in safety.
   4: 
   5: He replied: ‘If he remains in safety from the moon-faced one, he will not remain safe from evil speakers.
   6: 
   7: If a man escapes from his own bad lust
   8: He will not escape from the bad suspicions of accusers.
   9: 
  10: It is proper to sit down to one’s own work
  11: But it is impossible to bind the tongues of men.


====================================================================================================

====================================================================================================
Title: Ch 02 The Morals Of Dervishes Story 07
Author: Shirazi, Saadi
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 15
Avg verse line length: 38.0
Avg prose line length: 70.1

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Ch 02 The Morals Of Dervishes Story 07
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: I remember, being in my childhood pious, rising in the night, addicted to devotion and abstinence.
   4: 
   5: One night I was sitting with my father, remaining awake and holding the beloved Quran in my lap, whilst the people around us were asleep.
   6: 
   7: I said: ‘Not one of these persons lifts up his head or makes a genuflection.
   8: 
   9: They are as fast asleep as if they were dead.
  10: 
  11: ’ He replied: ‘Darling of thy father, would that thou wert also asleep rather than disparaging people.
  12: 
  13: The pretender sees no one but himself
  14: Because he has the veil of conceit in front.
  15: 
  16: If he were endowed with a God-discerning eye
  17: He would see that no one is weaker than himself.

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Ch 02 The Morals Of Dervishes Story 29
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: A man had a friend, who held the office of devan to the padshah, but whom he had not seen for a long time; and, a man having asked him for the reason, he replied: "I do not want to see him.
   4: 
   5: " A dependent however of the devan, who also happened to be present, queried: "What fault has he committed that thou art unwilling to meet him?
   6: 
   7: " He replied: "There is no fault in the matter but a friend who is a devan may be seen when he is removed from office.
   8: 
   9: Whilst in greatness and in the turmoil of busines
  10: They do not like to be troubled by neighbours
  11: But when they are depressed and removed from office
  12: They will lay open their heart’s grief to friends.

#110: 70029_Ch 04 On The Advantages Of Silence Story 03_Shirazi, Saadi_unknown.txt

Title: Ch 04 On The Advantages Of Silence Story 03
Author: Shirazi, Saadi
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 13

Avg prose line length: 65.4

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Ch 04 On The Advantages Of Silence Story 03
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: An intelligent youth possessed an abundant share of accomplishments and discreet behaviour so that he was allowed to sit in assemblies of learned men but he refrained from conversing with them.
   4: 
   5: His father once asked him why he did not likewise speak on subjects he was acquainted with.
   6: 
   7: He replied: ‘I fear I may be asked what I do not know and be put to shame.
   8: 
   9: Hast thou heard how a Sufi drove
  10: A few nails under his sandals
  11: And an officer taking him by the sleeve
  12: Said to him: ‘Come and shoe my horse.
  13: 
  14: For what thou hast not said no one will trouble thee
  15: But when thou hast spoken bring the proof.

#111: 70030_Ch 01 Manner Of Kings Story 15_Shirazi, Saadi_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Ch 01 Manner Of Kings Story 15
Author: Shirazi, Saadi
Prose starts at line: 20
Lines to remove: 16
Avg verse line length: 78.8
Avg prose line length: 119.3

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  15: " He replied: "It is a sign of sufficient intelligence not to engage in such matters.
  16: 
  17: The homa excels all other birds in nobility
  18: Because it feeds on bones and injures no living thing.
  19: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  20: A donkey, having been asked for what salary he had elected to attend upon the lion, replied: "That I may consume the remnants of his prey and live in safety from my enemies by taking refuge under his bravery.
  21: 
  22: " Being again asked that, as he had entered into the shadow of the lion’s protection and gratefully acknowledged his beneficence, why he had not joined the circle of intimacy so as to be accounted one of his favourite servants, he replied: "I am in the same way also not safe of his bravery.
  23: 
  24: Should a Guebre kindle fire a hundred years
  25: If he falls one moment into it he will be burnt.
  26: 
  27: It may happen that a companion of his majesty the sultan receives gold and it is possible that he loses his head.
  28: 
  29: Philosophers have said that it is necessary to be on guard of the fickle temper of padshahs because sometimes they are displeased with politeness and at others they bestow robes of honour for rudeness.
  30: 
  31: It is also said that much jocularity is an accomplishment in courtiers but a fault in sages.
  32: 
  33: Abide thou by thy dignity and gravity.
  34: 
  35: Leave sport and jocularity to courtiers.

   1: Ch 05 On Love And Youth Story 08
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: I remember how in former times I and another friend kept company with each other like two almond kernels in one skin.
   4: 
   5: Suddenly a separation took place but after a time, when my companion returned, he commenced to blame me for not having sent him a messenger during it.
   6: 
   7: I replied: ‘I thought it would be a pity that the eyes of a messenger should be brightened by thy beauty and I deprived thereof.
   8: 
   9: Tell my old friend not to give me advice with the tongue
  10: Because even a sword will not compel me to repent.
  11: 
  12: I am jealous that anyone should see thee to satiety.
  13: 
  14: Again I say that no one will be satiated.

 123: Expect not that I shall withdraw my hand from thy skirt.
 124: 
 125: If escape be impossible from this crime which I committed
 126: I trust to the clemency which thou possessest.
 127: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 128: The king replied: ‘Thou hast adduced this wonderful sally and hast enounced a strange maxim but it is impossible according to reason and contrary to usage that thy accomplishments and eloquence should this day save thee from the punishment which I have decreed; and I consider it proper to throw thee headlong from the castle that others may take an example.
 129: 
 130: ’ He continued: ‘O lord of the world, I have been nourished by the bounty of this dynasty, and this crime was not committed only by me in the world.
 131: 
 132: Throw another man headlong that I may take the example.
 133: 
 134: ’ The king burst out laughing, pardoned his crime and said to his dependents who desired the qazi to be slain:
 135: ‘Everyone of you who are bearers of your own faults
 136: Ought not to blame others for their defects.

#114: 70041_Ch 02 The Morals Of Dervishes Story 04_Shirazi, Saadi_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Ch 02 The Morals Of Dervishes Story 04
Author: Shirazi, Saadi
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 16
Avg verse line length: 38.0
Avg prose line length: 76.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Ch 02 The Morals Of Dervishes Story 04
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: A thief paid a visit to the house of a pious man but, although he sought a great deal, found nothing and was much grieved.
   4: 
   5: The pious man, who knew this, threw the blanket upon which he had been sleeping into the way of the thief that he might not go away disappointed.
   6: 
   7: I heard that men of the way of God
   8: Have not distressed the hearts of enemies.
   9: 
  10: How canst thou attain that dignity
  11: Who quarrelest and wagest war against friends?
  12: 
  13: The friendship of pure men, whether in thy presence or absence, is not such as Will find fault behind thy back and is ready to die for thee before thy face.
  14: 
  15: In thy presence gentle like a lamb,
  16: In thy absence like a man-devouring wolf.
  17: 
  18: Who brings the faults of another to thee and enumerates them Will undoubtedly carry thy faults to others.

#115: 70043_Ch 06 On Weakness And Old Age Story 03_Shirazi, Saadi_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Ch 06 On Weakness And Old Age Story 03
Author: Shirazi, Saadi
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 13
Avg verse line length: 38.0
Avg prose line length: 94.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Ch 06 On Weakness And Old Age Story 03
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: I was in Diarbekr, the guest of an old man, who possessed abundant wealth and a beautiful son.
   4: 
   5: One night he narrated to me that he had all his life no other son but this boy, telling me that in the locality people resorted to a certain tree in a valley to offer petitions and that he had during many nights prayed at the foot of the said tree, till the Almighty granted him this son.
   6: 
   7: I overheard the boy whispering to his companion: ‘How good it would be if I knew where that tree is that I might pray for my father to die.
   8: 
   9: ’ Moral: The gentleman is delighted that his son is intelligent and the boy complains that his father is a dotard.
  10: 
  11: Years elapse without thy visiting
  12: The tomb of thy father.
  13: 
  14: What good hast thou done to him
  15: To expect the same from thy son?

   2:

   3: A hermit, having been invited by a padshah, concluded that if he were to take some medicine to make himself weak he might perhaps enhance the opinion of the padshah regarding his merits.
   4: 
   5: But it is related that the medicine was lethal so that when he partook of it he died.
   6:

   8: Was but skin upon skin like an onion.
   9: 
  10: Devotees with their face towards the world
  11: Say their prayers with their back to the Qiblah.
  12: 
  13: When a worshipper calls upon his God,
  14: He must know no one besides God.

   1: Ch 08 On Rules For Conduct In Life - Maxim 36
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: Even after falling into mud a jewel retains its costliness, and dust, although it may rise into the sky, is as contemptible as before.
   4: 
   5: Capacity without education is deplorable and education without capacity is thrown away.
   6: 
   7: Ashes are of high origin because the nature of fire is superior, but as they have no value of their own, they are similar to earth and the price of sugar arises not from.
   8: 
   9: the cane but from its own quality.
  10: 
  11: The land of Canaan having no natural excellence,
  12: The birth of a prophet therein could not enhance its worth.
  13: 
  14: Display thy virtue if thou hast any, not thy origin.
  15: 
  16: The rose is the offspring of thorns and Abraham of Azer.

   3: Abu Harirah, may the approbation of Allah be upon him, was in the habit of daily waiting upon the Mustafa, peace on him, who said: "Abu Harira, visit me on alternate days that our love may increase.
   4: 
   5: " A man said to a devotee: "Beautiful as the sun is, I never heard that anybody took it for a friend or fell in love with it", and he replied: "This is because it may be seen daily, except in winter when it is veiled and beloved.
   6: 
   7: There is no harm in visiting people
   8: But not till they say: "It is enough!"
   9: If thou findest fault with thyself
  10: Thou wilt not hear others reproaching thee.

   1: Ch 08 On Rules For Conduct In Life - Maxim 50
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: A disciple without intention is a lover without money; a traveller without knowledge is a bird without wings; a scholar without practice is a tree without fruit, and a devotee without science is a house without a door.
   4: 
   5: The Qaroon (Korah) was revealed for the acquisition of a good character, not for chanting written chapters.
   6: 
   7: A pious unlettered man is like one who travels on foot, whilst a negligent scholar is like a sleeping rider.
   8: 
   9: A sinner who lifts his hands in supplication is better than a devotee who keeps them proudly on his head.
  10: 
  11: A good humoured and pleasant military officer
  12: Is superior to a theologian who injures men.
  13: 
  14: One being asked what a learned man without practice resembled, replied: ‘A bee without honey.
  15: 
  16: Say to the rude and unkind bee,
  17: ‘At least forbear to sting, if thou givest no honey.

   1: Ch 01 Manner Of Kings Story 38
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: A company of philosophers were discussing a subject in the palace of Kesra and Barzachumihr, having remained silent, they asked him why he took no share in the debate.
   4: 
   5: He replied: "Veziers are like physicians and the latter give medicine to the sick only but, as I perceive that your opinions are in conformity with propriety, I have nothing to say about them.
   6: 
   7: When an affair succeeds without my idle talk
   8: It is not meet for me to speak thereon.
   9: 
  10: But if I see a blind man near a well
  11: It is a crime for me to remain silent.

   4:

  10: Succours not those whose minds are distressed,

  12: He will enjoy in the mansion of the next world.

   4:

   6:

   8: Is pardoned when he once makes a slip
   9: But if he becomes noted for lying,
  10: People do not believe him even when speaking truth.

   3: The son of a wealthy but avaricious old man, having fallen sick, his well-wishers advised him that it would be proper to get the whole Quran recited or else to offer a sacrifice.
   4: 
   5: He meditated a while and then said: ‘It is preferable to read the Quran because the flock is at a distance.
   6: 
   7: ’ A holy man, who had heard this, afterwards remarked: ‘He selected the reading of the Quran because it is at the tip of the tongue but the money at the bottom of the heart.
   8: 
   9: It is useful to bend the neck in prayers
  10: If they are to be accompanied by almsgiving.
  11: 
  12: For one dinar he would remain sticking in mud like an ass,
  13: But if thou askest for Alhamdu he will recite it a hundred times.

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Ch 04 On The Advantages Of Silence Story 02
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: A merchant, having suffered loss of a thousand dinars, enjoined his son not to reveal it to anyone.
   4: 
   5: The boy said: ‘It is thy order and I shall not tell it but thou must inform me of the utility of this proceeding and of the propriety of concealment.
   6: 
   7: ’ He replied: ‘For fear the misfortune would be double; namely, the loss of the money and, secondly, the joy of neighbours at our loss.
   8: 
   9: Reveal not thy grief to enemies
  10: Because they will say ‘La haul’ but rejoice.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   8: They refrain from putting their hands to the sword.
   9: 
  10: What bravery will they display in battle array
  11: When their hands are empty and affairs deplorable?
  12: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  13: I was on terms of friendship with one of those who had acted treacherously and reproached him, telling him that it was base, ungrateful, despicable and undutiful to abandon an old master when his affairs have changed a little and to disregard the obligations incurred for benefits received during many years.
  14: 
  15: He replied: "If I inform thee, perhaps thou wilt excuse me for my horse had no barley and my saddle-cloth was pawned.
  16: 
  17: A sultan who grudges money to his troops, they cannot bravely risk their lives for him.
  18: 
  19: Give gold to the soldier that he may serve thee.
  20: 
  21: If thou witholdest gold, he will serve elsewhere.
  22: 
  23: When a warrior is full, he will be brave in fight but if his belly be
  24: empty, he will be brave in flight.

   2:

   3: It is contrary to what is proper, and against the opinion of to partake of medicine by guess and to go after a caravan without seeing the road.
   4: 
   5: The Imam Murshid Muhammad Ghazali, upon whom be the mercy of Allah, having been asked in what manner he had attained such a degree of knowledge, replied: ‘By not being ashamed to ask about things I did not know.
   6: 
   7: The hope of recovery is according to reason,
   8: That he should feel thy pulse who knows thy nature.
   9: 
  10: Ask what thou knowest not; for the trouble of asking
  11: Will indicate to thee the way to the dignity of knowledge.

   1: Ch 01 Manner Of Kings Story 25
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: One of the Arab kings ordered his officials to double the allowance of a certain attendant because he was always at the palace expecting orders while the other servants were engaged in amusements and sports, neglecting their duties.
   4: 
   5: A pious man who heard this remarked that high degrees at the court of heaven are similarly bestowed upon servants:
   6: If a man comes two mornings to serve the shah
   7: He will on the third certainly look benevolently on him.
   8: 
   9: Sincere worshippers entertain the hope
  10: That they will not be disappointed at the threshold of God.
  11: 
  12: Superiority consists in attending to commands.
  13: 
  14: The neglect of commands leads to exclusion.
  15: 
  16: Who possesses the criterion of righteousness
  17: Places the head upon the threshold.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   4: ‘Would that before my death
   5: I could one day enjoy my wish
   6: That a river’s waves might strike my knee
   7: And I might fill my water-bag.
   8: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   9: In the same manner another traveller lost himself in an extensive region having neither any strength nor food left but he possessed some money and roamed about and the road leading him nowhere he perished from exhaustion.
  10: 
  11: Some people afterwards discovered his corpse with the money in front of it and the following written on the ground:
  12: If possessed of all the Ja’feri gold,
  13: It will avail nothing to a hungry man.
  14: 
  15: To a poor man burnt in the desert
  16: Boiled turnips are more valuable than pure silver.

#129: 70082_Ch 03 On The Excellence Of Contentment Story 04_Shirazi, Saadi_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Ch 03 On The Excellence Of Contentment Story 04
Author: Shirazi, Saadi
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 15
Avg verse line length: 47.0
Avg prose line length: 95.3

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Ch 03 On The Excellence Of Contentment Story 04
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: One of the kings of Persia had sent an able physician to wait upon the Mustafa, the benediction of Allah and peace be on him; and he remained for some years in the Arab country without anyone coming to him to make a trial of his ability or desiring to be treated by him.
   4: 
   5: He went to the Prophet, salutation to him, and complained that although he had been sent to treat the companions, none of them had up to this time taken notice of him or required the services incumbent upon him.
   6: 
   7: The Apostle, salutation to him, replied: ‘It is a law with these people not to eat until appetite overpowers them and when some of it yet remains they withdraw their hands from food.
   8: 
   9: ’ The doctor said: ‘This is the cause of health’, and kissing the earth of service departed.
  10: 
  11: The sage begins to speak
  12: Or points his fingers to the dish
  13: When silence would be dangerous
  14: Or abstinance would bring on death.
  15: 
  16: No doubt his wisdom is in speaking
  17: And his eating bears the fruit of health.


====================================================================================================

   2:

   3: The beautiful wife of a man died but her mother, a decrepit old hag, remained in the house on account of the dowry.
   4: 
   5: The man saw no means of escaping from contact with her until a company of friends paid him a visit of condolence and one of them asked him how he bore the loss of his beloved.
   6: 
   7: He replied: ‘It is not as painful not to see my wife as to see the mother of my wife.
   8: 
   9: The rose has been destroyed and the thorn remained.
  10: 
  11: The treasure has been taken and the serpent left.
  12: 
  13: It is better that one’s eye be fixed on a spear-head
  14: Than that it should behold the face of an enemy.
  15: 
  16: It is incumbent to sever connection with a thousand friends
  17: Rather than to behold a single foe.

   4: 
   5: " He had a stupid negro, Khosaib by name, whom he made governor of Egypt but his intellect and discrimination were so limited that when the tribe of Egyptian agriculturists complained and stated that they had sown cotton along the banks of the Nile and that an untimely rain had destroyed it he replied: "You ought to have sown wool.
   6: 
   7: " A pious man heard this, and said:
   8: "If livelihood were increased by knowledge
   9: None would be more needy than the ignorant.
  10:

  12: At which the learned stand aghast.
  13: 
  14: The luck of wealth consists not in skill
  15: But only in the aid of heaven.
  16: 
  17: It happens in the world that many
  18: Silly men are honoured and sages despised.
  19: 
  20: If an alchemist has died in grief and misery,
  21: A fool discovered a treasure amidst ruins.

  58: author’s note: “The crux and turning-point of the World War is usually assigned to the dawn of July 18, 1918.
  59: 
  60: At that time, after a feverish mobilization in the great woods near Soissons of Highlander, Moroccan, and other units, including the first and second American divisions, General Mangin, under Marshall Foch’s orders, attacked eastward, threatening the German Marne salient.
  61: 
  62: The desperate rush to the front in the great beech forests during that rainy night and the attack at 4:35 remain one of the outstanding epic actions of the war.
  63: 
  64: The overtones of the event and its portentous significance obscurely felt by those who took part in it.

  43: 2.
  44: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  45: Bulbul, or Nightingale- This is a special Persian bird found in gardens and proverbially engaged in melodious music round flowers.
  46: 
  47: It is imagined to be and is described as an ardent lover of flowers in Persian and Urdu literature, specially poetry.
  48: 
  49: Figuratively, it means the point of view which, contrary to the discursive analysis, tries to look at the phenomena of beauty in its integral status and with reference to a manifestation of the Divine Beauty.
  50: 
  51: 3.
  52: 
  53: This alludes to the anatomy of the rose flower, whose petals are innumerable, look like tongues and also add to its beauty, which proclaims the artistry of its Creator in spite of the apparent silence of the flower.

  55: 4.
  56:

  59: 5.
  60:

 534:

#137: 70365_The Phenomenon_Nicholson, John_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Phenomenon
Author: Nicholson, John
Prose starts at line: 39
Lines to remove: 13
Avg verse line length: 33.4
Avg prose line length: 118.9

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  34: Their trade must cease - they could not dye
  35: So many went - the heath and bent
  36: Were by their footsteps worn away
  37: When they were there what did appear
  38: For Crowhill bog had run away!!

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  39: Not the greatest of poetry but Nicholson would have earned many a drink reciting this in alehouses around the area.
  40: 
  41: The bog at Crow Hill, which lies south of Nicholson's West Yorkshire home in the nearbye village of Haworth, was drying up after a hot summer when there was a heavy cloudburst on 2nd September 1824.
  42: 
  43: The peat absorbed so much water in a short space of time that it burst and was swept away through Ponden and the River Worth and river Aire.
  44: 
  45: The resulting discoluration was so severe it lasted for 4 or 5 days and was noticeable 20 miles away in Leeds where the water was too polluted to be used for cloth dying because of it.
  46: 
  47: On the same day as this was written Patrick Bronte (of the famous Bronte family)preached a sermon about the same incident.
  48: 
  49: Unlike the sermon this was not published for over 150 years until 1976.
  50: 
  51: JS

#140: 70963_The Crossing At Fredericksburg_Boker, George Henry_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Crossing At Fredericksburg
Author: Boker, George Henry
Prose starts at line: 131
Lines to remove: 7
Avg verse line length: 32.2
Avg prose line length: 162.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 126: And one more for Michigan!"
 127: In the winter of 1862, Union General Ambrose Burnside found himself faced with a dilemma: how to cross the 400-foot-wide Rappahannock River at Fredericksburg, Virginia, and get at General Robert E.
 128: 
 129: Lee and his Army of Northern Virginia.
 130: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 131: Although General Edwin Sumner had had an opportunity to make an uncontested (albeit hasty) crossing on November 18, Burnside had denied him permission, preferring to wait for the arrival of a pontoon train.
 132: 
 133: The equipment finally appeared November 25, but Burnside did not begin his bridges until December 11.
 134: 
 135: After two days of work under heavy fire from the entrenched Confederates, five bridges were completed, and Burnside launched what what ultimately prove to be a disastrous attack.
 136: 
 137: Almost 13,000 of the 106,000 Union troops who took part in the Battle of Fredericksburg were killed or wounded (as compared with 5,300 of the 72,500 Confederates).
