#141: 71057_Dirge For A Soldier_Boker, George Henry_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Dirge For A Soldier
Author: Boker, George Henry
Prose starts at line: 47
Lines to remove: 15
Avg verse line length: 23.9
Avg prose line length: 170.6

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  42: In the clover or the snow!
  43: What cares he?
  44: 
  45: he can not know:
  46: Lay him low!

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  47: According to Life Stories of Civil War Heroes, New York native "Philip Kearny was a flamboyant adventurer and soldier who most notably fought for the United States of America in the Mexican, Indian, and Civil Wars.
  48: 
  49: During his brilliant military career he proved himself honorable, chivalrous, and compassionate towards his men, with a joie de vivre that inspired his troops in battle.
  50: 
  51: Kearny's courage earned him the respect of his soldiers and fellow officers alike, the greatest of which came from General-in-Chief Winfield Scott who called him 'the bravest and most perfect soldier' he had ever known.
  52: 
  53: The "bravest and most perfect soldier" met a less-than-perfect end on September 1, 1862, at the Battle of Chantilly when, against all advice, he rode out to check an unguarded gap in his lines.
  54: 
  55: Accosted by waiting Confederates who demanded his surrender, Kearny refused and was shot in the backside as he galloped away.
  56: 
  57: Although his prowess in battle was impressive enough to guarantee him a place in American military history, Kearny is also remembered as the originator of the corps badge.
  58: 
  59: So that he could more easily identify his troops in the field, Kearny ordered the men in his Third Corps to sew diamond-shaped pieces of red flannel onto their caps.
  60: 
  61: The scheme quickly found favor with other corps in the Army of the Potomac and is still used in today's army.


====================================================================================================

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Indian Dancers
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: Eyes  ravished with rapture, celestially panting, what passionate bosoms aflaming with fire
   4: Drink deep of the hush of the hyacinth heavens that glimmer around them in fountains of light;
   5: O wild and entrancing the strain of keen music that cleaveth the stars like a wail of desire,
   6: And beautiful dancers with houri-like faces bewitch the voluptuous watches of night.
   7: 
   8: The scents of red roses and sandalwood flutter and die in the maze of their gem-tangled hair,
   9: And smiles are entwining like magical serpents the poppies of lips that are opiate-sweet;
  10: Their glittering garments of purple are burning like tremulous dawns in the quivering air,
  11: And exquisite, subtle and slow are the tinkle and tread of their rhythmical, slumber-soft feet.
  12: 
  13: Now silent, now singing and swaying and swinging, like blossoms that bend to the breezes or showers,
  14: Now wantonly winding, they flash, now they falter, and, lingering, languish in radiant choir;
  15: Their jewel-girt arms and warm, wavering, lily-long fingers enchant through melodious hours,
  16: Eyes ravished with rapture, celestially panting, what passionate bosoms aflaming with fire!

   3: AN inventory clear of all she needs Lamira offers here; Nor does she fear a rigid Cato's frown When she lays by the rich embroidered gown, And modestly compounds for just enough- Perhaps, some dozens of more flighty stuff; With lawns and lustrings, blond, and Mechlin laces, Fringes and jewels, fans and tweezer-cases; memory Gay cloaks, and hats of every shape and size, Scarfs, cardinals, and ribbons of all dyes; With ruffles stamped, and aprons of tambour, Tippets and handkerchiefs, at least three score; With finest muslins that fair India boasts, And the choice herbage from Chinesan coasts; (But while the fragrant hyson leaf regales, Who'll wear the homespun produce of the vales?
   4: 
   5: For if 'twould save the nation from the curse Of standing troops; or-name a plague still worse- Few can this choice, delicious draught give up, Though all Medea's poisons fill the cup.
   6:

  10: 
  11: -they're but the sex's due.
  12: 
  13: In youth, indeed, an antiquated page Taught us the threatenings of an Hebrew sage 'Gainst wimples, mantles, curls, and crisping-pins; But rank not these among our modern sins; For when our manners are well understood, What in the scale is stomacher or hood?
  14: 
  15: 'Tis true, we love the courtly mien and air, The pride of dress and all the debonair; Yet Clara quits the more dressed negligee, And substitutes the careless Polanee; Until some fair one from Britannia's court, Some jaunty dress or newer taste import; This sweet temptation could not be withstood, Though for the purchase paid her father's blood.
  16: 
  17: Can the stern patriot Clara's suit deny?
  18: 
  19: 'Tis Beauty asks, and Reason must comply.

#144: 71216_John Adams Monarchical Ideas_Warren, Mercy_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: John Adams Monarchical Ideas
Author: Warren, Mercy
Prose starts at line: 85
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 94.0
Avg prose line length: 159.6

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  80: 
  81: Is not the above sufficient to warrant everything that I have said relative to your monarchic opinions ?
  82: 
  83: Had you recollected the conversations alluded to above, you would not I have asserted on your faith and honor that every sentiment in a paragraph you refer to is 'totally unfounded.
  84: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  85: ' On your return from Europe it was generally thought that you looked coldly on your Republican friends and their families, and that you united yourself with the party in Congress who were favorers of monarchy; that the old Tories, denominating themselves Federalists, gathered round you.
  86: 
  87: And did not your administration while in the presidential chair evince that you had no aversion to the usages of monarchic governments?
  88: 
  89: Sedition, stamp, and alien laws, a standing army, house and land taxes, and loans of money at an enormous interest were alarming symptoms in the American Republic.
  90: 
  91: Your removal from the chair by the free suffrages of a majority of the people of the United States sufficiently evinces that I was not mistaken when I asserted that 'a large portion' of the inhabitants of America from New Hampshire to Georgia viewed your political opinions in the same point of light in which I have exhibited them, and considered their liberties in imminent danger, without an immediate change of the Chief Magistrate.
  92: 
  93: However, I never supposed that you had a wish to submit again to the monarchy of Great Britain, or to become subjugated to any foreign sovereign.
  94: 
  95: An American monarchy with an American character at its head would, doubtless, have been more pleasing to yourself.
  96: 
  97: The veracity of an historian is his strongest base; and I am sure I have recorded nothing but what I thought I had the highest reason to believe.
  98: 
  99: If I have been mistaken I shall be forgiven; and, if there are errors, they will be candidly viewed by liberal-minded and generous readers.
 100: 
 101: PLYMOUTH, MASS.
 102: 
 103: , 28 July, 1807.

Author: Anees, Mir Babar Ali
Prose starts at line: 321
Lines to remove: 10

Avg prose line length: 113.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 316: 
 317: e.
 318: 
 319: an elegiac poem written to commemorate the martyrdom and valour of a noted man.
 320: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 321: The form of the marsia generally consists of six-line units, with a rhyming quatrain, and a couplet on a different rhyme and the best versions seem to have arisen in and around Lucknow (a city in Northern India), probably because it was the centre of the Shia Muslim community.
 322: 
 323: The Shia community regarded it an act of piety and religious duty to write eulogies to such martyrs and it is generally agreed that this version by Mir Babar Ali Anis is the best there is.
 324: 
 325: The are two main parts of marsia known as noha and soz (lamentation and burning)
 326: To continue on to the second part of this poem please click here.
 327: 
 328: http://oldpoetry.

  17: day in and out this subject        in diction        in peace punctuates               is aware of the case for :ialism     pm writhes in her circadian rhythm             barbed wire whose                          disentanglement should be a paid position


====================================================================================================

  14: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  15: , the poet's only son, "of the most amiable disposition, and heir to his father's classical taste," was heir to the bulk of his uncle's (John Strong Ensor) estates.
  16: 
  17: He devoted the principal part of his time to travelling, had a good notion of drawing, and in 1776 and 1777 seems to have held some official post at the court of France.
  18: 
  19: Mr.
  20: 
  21: Longstaffe remarks; " He grieved his uncle by not settling down to money-making; and by staying among his Warwickshire friends instead of meeting Mr.
  22: 
  23: Ensor in London, lost the opportunity of a good appointment in America, much, perhaps, to his own contentment.
  24: 
  25: He died in London in 1782, aged but 31.

Prose starts at line: 58
Lines to remove: 7
Avg verse line length: 24.3
Avg prose line length: 84.5

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  53: JUDGE GIVES NEGRO 90 DAYS IN COUNTY JAIL!
  54: From THE LANGSTON HUGHES READER, p.
  55: 
  56: 101, © 1957.
  57: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  58: This poem by Langston Hughes grew out of conditions in New York City’s Harlem in the 1930’s.
  59: 
  60: In graphic terms it describes the escalation of anger and frustration that tenants experienced trying to get landlords to make basic repairs.
  61: 
  62: It is structured like an old time blues song until the final verse where the rhythm changes.
  63: 
  64: Charley Noble

#150: 71876_Bitter-Sweet_Worth, Patience_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Bitter-Sweet
Author: Worth, Patience
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 16
Avg verse line length: 12.0
Avg prose line length: 107.3

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Bitter-Sweet
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: How long I sat before that slender goblet, knowing well that I must sup! How long I sat in wonderment! Fragile was I, and fearful, my lips thirsting for the contact, my will strong, my desire beckoning me.
   4: 
   5: Yet before me was the wine untouched, and I shrank, fearful that I lay my lips upon its brim.
   6: 
   7: And the hot winds rose and enwrapped me, and my tongue was parched and my thirst was sore, and the goblet was before me.
   8: 
   9: And the wrath of the winds became more, and the heart of rebellion descended and seared me, And in a fearful moment when the lightnings split the heavens asunder, lo, did I tremulously lay my hand upon the slender stem and with prayer-
  10: holied lips drank, drank to the very dregs.
  11: 
  12: And the bitterness! Ah, the bitterness clave unto my tongue! Yet I was uplifted, exalted with a new strength; I forgot my thirst, yea, and looked upon the empty goblet in wonderment.
  13: 
  14: That was yesterday, yea, only yesterday, and today, remembering the bitterness, I lift my glass
  15: anew and drink sweet wine.
  16: 
  17: A troth to the sup of yesterday, whose bitterness steeped my
  18: soul in honey!

#151: 72084_The Wicket Gate_Worth, Patience_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Wicket Gate
Author: Worth, Patience
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 14
Avg verse line length: 15.0
Avg prose line length: 66.7

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: The Wicket Gate
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: My heart is a wicket gate; hung at a garden 'twixt me and the dinning day it stands.
   4: 
   5: Beyond is the teeming roadway and the agony of day's pageantry as it writhes past,
   6: And I am the garden, and my heart the wicket gate.
   7: 
   8: He who enters unto this sacred spot first should turn the gate upon its pivot;
   9: Yea, entering he shall know the inner land with its shadeful seclusions,
  10: With its white-lit eves and its gilded days, with its shuttling songsters.
  11: 
  12: He shall know the bordered plots; he shall become immersed in the perfume of peace,
  13: I am a garden, and my heart a wicket gate;
  14: And the road beyond, the teeming road with its writhing agony, is remote;
  15: For I shall let no stranger pass the wicket gate,
  16: Save that I greet him with a delicate intimacy.

#152: 72167_Willy-Wag and Sparrow_Cato, Nancy_unknown.txt

Author: Cato, Nancy
Prose starts at line: 50
Lines to remove: 7
Avg verse line length: 23.1
Avg prose line length: 76.5

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  45: 
  46: It's a very fast bird and it needs to be, too! It belongs to the family of the fly catchers.
  47: 
  48: So it catches all sorts of insects.
  49: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  50: Therefore it is forever darting to and fro, looking in all directions for its next prey.
  51: 
  52: It is for that reason that it wags its tail continuously back and forth, as it forever changes directions.
  53: 
  54: If you see it on a fence post or on the ground it is wagging its tail constantly.
  55: 
  56: Hence the name 'Willy Wag Tail.

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 250: 
 251: Erasmus Darwin, pointed out to me the vegetable eunuchs, which I own had escaped my observation: for this and other useful hints I desire he will be pleased to accept a very considerable share of the reputation arising from this work.
 252: 
 253: My ingenious friend, Brooke Boothby, Esq.
 254: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 255: with a liberality not always found amongst men of science, accomodated me with the Aristographia of Johannes Schenzerus, the first page of which thoroughly satisfied me.
 256: 
 257: Dipping, however, into the body of the book, I accidentally met with these remarkable words: Isiera, Kuren Pullu.
 258: 
 259: Enraptured as we all are with what we do not understand, I declared this, like Abracadabra, to be a charm for the ague; but my youngest boy, who has a smattering in languages, says rather for the tooth-ache; and thus translates the sentence: -- "Isiera Kuren Pullu:" "I'll either cure or pull you out.
 260: 
 261: " But I leave him to dispute this point with Jacob Bryant, Esq.
 262: 
 263: the celebrated interpreter of the Apamean medal.
 264: 
 265: To the animated and elegant Miss Seward, and the two gentlemen above-mentioned, the existance of this trifle is entirely owing: for nothing but my desire of shewing attention to their obliging and flattering notice of my productions could have prompted me to this undertaking.

 154:

 156: 
 157: Il y a longtemps qu'elles ont cessé de briller.
 158:

 160: 
 161: Ce philosophe estimé pensait que la vérité était moi-tié juive et moitié chrétienne.
 162: 
 163: L'absolue Vérité, n'étant jamáis que l'ambition dé-mesurée de toute Vérité, la question que l'on serait en droit de se poser, alors, est celle-ci: «Comment peut-on divisar, en deux, ce qui est toujours en devenir?
 164: 
 165: «Avoir, pour témoin, le livre - écrivait un sage - c'est avoir l'univers entier pour répondant.
 166: 
 167: Sauvés par le livre sauvé.
 168: 
 169: Le juif fait face au juif, comme la page du Livre á la page du Livre.

  26: 
  27: Alex Kerr, in The Classic Tradition of Haiku, edited by Faubion Bowers)
  28: Bowers' comment:

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  29: This was Shuushiki's death poem, meaning that when she awakens from "life's dream" she will see radiant irises.
  30: 
  31: 'Kakitsubata' or rabbit-eared iris, is another five-syllable word favored in haiku.
  32: 
  33: The intensely purple petals were used as dye-stuff, their color being associated with young girls.
  34: 
  35: 
  36: I wake and find
  37: the colored iris
  38: I saw in my dream.
  39: 
  40: (trans.
  41: 
  42: Yoel Hoffmann)
  43: Portrait of the poetess Ome Shushiki (1668-1725) looking at a poem attached to a tree at Ueno from “Eight Views of Accomplished Women” by Utagawa KUNIYOSHI (1797-1861) signed: Ichiyusai Kuniyoshi ga.

  18:

  28:

  31: 
  32: You make the hours work like fragile perceptions for the food they get, the warmth they get, for the variable, contradictory spontaneities imposed on their bodies as love or triumph in mistaken assertions.

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]

 104: 
 105: In The Book of Ironies they forgot to write that a superstitiouswoman will end up marrying an atheist.
 106: 
 107: Curiously, in all the cases Iknow, it’s the man who doesn’t believe.
 108: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 109: The woman is always openat the very least to the possibility of that “something out there.
 110: 
 111: ” Attimes her superstitions are proof of God’s constant tinkering withthe cogs and wheels of the soul.
 112: 
 113: There are atheists with proof of afinite world, atheists in need of a finite world, reformed atheistswhose image of God has become so pure over the years that it hasgone from inevitable to unnecessary to simply impossible.
 114: 
 115: Onebeliever argues that only the next life makes this one tolerable andlends it purpose, that only the idea of being part of something cir-cular can keep us from going mad, because true madness is linearand the points at either end are clearly defined.
 116: 
 117: This is an uncom-fortable thought for her.
 118: 
 119: I wonder if her belief is, more than any-thing, a way to keep at bay this linear derangement.
 120: 
 121: The atheist lyingbeside her is beginning to sink into sleep when she speaks: she hascarefully chosen this moment, thinking he’s vulnerable enough tosay what she wants to hear.
 122: 
 123: He sits on the edge of the bed and won-ders for a moment what it would be like to take that leap forward;or backward, which is something she doesn’t mention: believers ofher kind tend to discount any previous incarnations, as if eternitybegan here.
 124: 
 125: Being here, he says to himself as he has said to her somany times,isthe point.
 126: 
 127: Then he tries to think his way back to sleep:wedding band, crown, zero, smoke ring, lasso, hula hoop.

#160: 73080_Road-Side Dog_Milosz, Czeslaw_unknown.txt

Author: Milosz, Czeslaw
Prose starts at line: 7
Lines to remove: 9
Avg verse line length: 70.7
Avg prose line length: 162.6

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   2: 
   3: I went on a journey in order to acquaint myself with my province, in a two-horse wagon with a lot of fodder and a tin bucket rattling in the back.
   4: 
   5: The bucket was required for the horses to drink from.
   6: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   7: I traveled through a country of hills and pine groves that gave way to woodlands where swirls of smoke hovered over the roofs of houses, as if they were on fire, for they were chimneyless cabins; I crossed districts of fields and lakes.
   8: 
   9: It was so interesting to be moving, to give the horses their rein, and wait until, in the next valley, a village slowly appeared, or a park with the white spot of a manor house in it.
  10: 
  11: And always we were barked at by a dog, assiduous in its duty.
  12: 
  13: That was the beginning of the century; this is its end.
  14: 
  15: I have been thinking not only of the people who lived there once but also of the generations of dogs accompanying them in their everyday bustle, and one night - I don't know where it came from - in a pre-dawn sleep, that funny and tender phrase composed itself: a road-side dog.

#161: 73097_Sarajevo_Milosz, Czeslaw_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Sarajevo
Author: Milosz, Czeslaw
Prose starts at line: 9
Lines to remove: 13
Avg verse line length: 64.5
Avg prose line length: 122.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   4: 
   5: While a country murdered and raped calls for help from the Europe which it had trusted, they yawn.
   6: 
   7: While statesmen choose villainy and no voice is raised to call it by name.
   8: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   9: The rebellion of the young who called for a new earth was a sham, and that generation has written the verdict on itself.
  10: 
  11: Listening with indifference to the cries of those who perish because they are after all just barbarians killing each other.
  12: 
  13: And the lives of the well-fed are worth more than the lives of the starving.
  14: 
  15: It is revealed now that their Europe since the beginning has been a deception, for its faith and its foundation is nothingness.
  16: 
  17: And nothingness, as the prophets keep saying, brings forth only nothingness, and they will be led once again like cattle to slaughter.
  18: 
  19: Let them tremble and at the last moment comprehend that the word Sarajevo will from now on mean the destruction of their sons and the debasement of their daughters.
  20: 
  21: They prepare it by repeating: "We at least are safe," unaware that what will strike them ripens in themselves.

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 120: 
 121: King Canute is dead and gone: Parasites exist alway.
 122: 
 123: Here Thackeray is retelling the legend of Canute, an early King of Britain.
 124: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 125: Canute after a long and hectic reign was bemoaning his weakness and age whilst walking on the sea-shore one day.
 126: 
 127: His courtiers in an effort to curry favour praised him as an omnipotent personage with God-like powers.
 128: 
 129: (The Jewish captain is a reference to the Old Testament warrior Joshua - see Joshua chapter 10, verses 12-13.
 130: 
 131: 
 132: The king shows them they are wrong by telling the tide to turn back which, of course, it does not do.
 133: 
 134: The final line says that the king is dead and gone but idiotic sycophantic courtiers still remain.
 135: 
 136: JS Oldpoetry Team

  18: 
  19: Never mind that.
  20: 
  21: The sickle moon turns the sky into a man’s mouth slapped sideways to keep him from spilling what no one wouldunderstand: you call me God when it gets good though I do not exist to you outside this room.
  22: 
  23: Be yourself or no one else here.
  24: 
  25: Your do-rag is camouflage-patterned and stuffed into my mouth.

   8: 
   9: She dreams your dead daddy still puts his hands on her waist.
  10: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  11: She calls his name then crosses herself, calls the police then crosses her fingers.
  12: 
  13: Cross me and get cut across your cheek, its fat bag full of   bad words and cheap liquor you hide from your badass kids.
  14: 
  15: Make a wish for bad weather when the hoodlums get to shooting in a good summer’s heat.
  16: 
  17: Cross the territory between two gangs and feel eyes stare and cross in a blur of crosshairs.
  18: 
  19: When a shot man lands in the garden of trash the block flares up like an appetite spurred on by the sight of prey, by the slurred prayer of a man so death-close he sees buzzards burrow their bladed beaks into his entry wound.
  20: 
  21: Tune the trumpets.
  22: 
  23: Make way through dusk’s clutter.
  24: 
  25: After death the dead cross over into song, their bones tuning-forked into vibrancy.
  26: 
  27: Cross your lips, mutiny against all speech when a corpse starts singing despite its leaded larynx.
  28: 
  29: Don’t say miracle when butterflies break from a death-gaped skull, rout the sky, and scatter.

  37: As she was to do throughout her life she wrote about the people she met along the way.
  38: 
  39: The Plains of Mexico http://oldpoetry.
  40: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  41: com/opoem/55400 tells the story of a cowboy in the North of the USA and The Traveller http://oldpoetry.
  42: 
  43: com/opoem/46475 tells of an old sailor she met in Canada and looks back over his life.
  44: 
  45: This ability to “tell the tale” of people she met can be seen throughout her poetry but was put to good use in her writings for the magazine Punch where she told stories of people caught up in the first World War in a humorous way that made them accessible to everyone.
  46: 
  47: For example the returning soldier in The Call http://oldpoetry.
  48: 
  49: com/opoem/55844 Cicely had returned to England at the start of the conflict and quickly became a regular contributor submitting work throughout the next 40 years.
  50: 
  51: She was a contemporary of Kipling and Masefield and in many respects was their equal (some say better).
  52: 
  53: Her ability to chronicle the decline of the great age of sail will probably be her lasting legacy but she was also a novelist (both in her own right and as a collaborator with her sister Madge).
  54: 
  55: She was a collector of sailor songs, a writer of travellers tales and an anthologist.
  56: 
  57: In short a multi-faceted character.
  58: 
  59: Happy Birthday
  60: Cicely Fox Smith


====================================================================================================

 137: mientras tú apaciguabas la luz en la montaña…
 138: Cósmicamente mía… Norte, Sur, Este, Oeste,
 139: nupciales, cuatro vientos te velaban el sueño.
 140: 
 141: THE SECRET

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 142: To borders of the fable, secretly mine, from the blood tree where the beat is born that is shown to your pulse, your language, wet flower, were sésamo hidden for the naked, falling apart floral mórbido landscape of your in pudores and loving wild slopes, the shade of your sines in vilo, beehives of the cluster whose flight guided the oldest kiss.
 143: 
 144: Everlasting hills with petals and juices, yes and did not guess right, doubtful of your aroma; golden booty of kisses, harassed armpits, most fleeting image brought in your lightning, opening to me between irises doves and moluscos.
 145: 
 146: 
 147: And you, already almost a clear one of moon in your eyelashes, arcángel without age eras simply.
 148: 
 149: And aqueduct without rain, the light of the rainbow overturned the flaming secret of the kiss, the solitude opening to our together souls where the birds beam their alcoves of trinos.
 150: 
 151: Loved Oh mine! Always your inaccessible summit; and already in you, I hurl over a cliff yours virgíneamente to me, when the air and the river smell to you close from the invisible tattoo of the skin of your aroma.
 152: 
 153: And then, I am lowering by the incline of the shout, the fulgor and the stone, the wind and the snow; bird I am sealing with the flight summits; Fallen angel I am shut in in your eyes, biting in your hair its pendular fruits, unfolding in my torso its funeral flag, your ardent mountain range measuring with my arms… With my equinox I surround your clear hemispheres of antipodal caresses, when they explore my kisses the lukewarm nomadic blood of your blue veins.
 154: 
 155: The moon was ex—libris of the nocturnal éxtasis, the stem of flower born of your own seed, solitude without the trees that maintain the sky, the delight ignoring to drink in your language, as the stone ignores the language of the bird.
 156: 
 157: If the kiss were not a symbol created in your tribute, its corola in your breath had sweet petals to impregnate the Earth with sufficient honeys whose dulzor appeared by the root of the world.
 158: 
 159: I knew you in the mineral bed of the planet, while you calmed the light in the mountain… Cosmically mine… North, the South, This, West, nuptial, four winds guarded the dream to you.
 160: 
 161: Translated by Pierre Richards via babblefish.

 306: Æglogue he bewayleth the death of some mayden of greate bloud, whom he calleth Dido.
 307:

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 344: 
 345: Hye thee home shepheard, the day is nigh wasted.
 346: 
 347: Agument.
 348: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 349: THis Æglogue is rather morall and generall, then bent to any secrete or particlar purpose.
 350: 
 351: It specially conteyneth a discourse of old age, in the persone of Thenot an olde Shepheard, who for his crookednesse and vnlustinesse, is scorned of Cuddie an vnhappy Heardmans boye.
 352: 
 353: The matter very well accordeth with the season of the moneth, the yeare now drouping, & as it were, drawing to his last age.
 354: 
 355: For as in this time of yeare, so then in our bodies there is a dry & withering cold, which congealeth the crudled blood, and frieseth the wetherbeaten flesh, with stormes of Fortune, & hoare frosts of Care.
 356: 
 357: To which purpose the olde man telleth a tale of the Oake and the Bryer, so lively, and so feelingly, as if the thing were set forth in some Picture before our eyes, more plainly could not appeare.

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]

 207: 
 208: [Vivitur ingenio, caetera mortis erunt.
 209: 
 210: Argument.
 211: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 212: THis Æglogue (euen as the first beganne) is ended with a complaynte of Colin to God Pan.
 213: 
 214: wherein as weary of his former wayes, he proportioneth his life to the foure seasons of the yeare, comparing hys youthe to the spring time, when he was fresh and free form loues follye.
 215: 
 216: His manhoode to the sommer, which he sayth, was consumed with greate heate and excessiue drouth caused through a Comet or blasinge starre, by which he meaneth loue, which passion is comenly compared to such flames and immoderate heate.
 217: 
 218: His riper yeares hee resembleth to an vnseasonable harueste wherein the fruites fall ere they be rype.
 219: 
 220: His latter age to winters chyll & frostie season, now drawing neare to his last ende.

Author: Harington, Henry
Prose starts at line: 94
Lines to remove: 7
Avg verse line length: 34.1
Avg prose line length: 170.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  89: 
  90: Quoted from Percy's Reliques, 'The following contains some variations from the original copy, which it is hoped the author will pardon, when he is informed they came from the elegant pen of the late Mr.
  91: 
  92: Shenstone.
  93: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  94: Wokey-hole is a noted cavern in Somersetshire, which has given birth to as many wild fanciful stories as the Sybil's Cave in Italy.
  95: 
  96: Through a very narrow entrance it opens into a large vault, the roof whereof, either on account of its height or the thickness of the gloom, cannot be discovered by the light of torches.
  97: 
  98: It goes winding a great way under ground, is crost by a stream of very cold water, and is all horrid with broken pieces of rock: many of these are evident petrifications, which, on account of their singular forms, have given rise to the fables alluded to in this poem.
  99: 
 100: ' ~ This 'Wokey-hole' is modernly spelled 'Wookey-hole' and can be found deliciously on Google.

#171: 75269_All-Souls' Night_Shorter, Dora Sigerson_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: All-Souls' Night
Author: Shorter, Dora Sigerson
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 20
Avg verse line length: 16.0
Avg prose line length: 80.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: All-Souls' Night
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: O MOTHER, mother, I swept the hearth, I set his chair and the white board spread,
   4: I prayed for his coming to our kindly Lady when Death's doors would let out the dead;
   5: A strange wind rattled the window-pane, and down the lane a dog howled on,
   6: I called his name and the candle flame burnt dim, pressed a hand the door-latch upon.
   7: 
   8: Deelish! Deelish! my woe forever that I could not sever coward flesh from fear.
   9: 
  10: I called his name and the pale ghost came; but I was afraid to meet my dear.
  11: 
  12: O mother, mother, in tears I checked the sad hours past of the year that's o'er,
  13: Till by God's grace I might see his face and hear the sound of his voice once more;
  14: The chair I set from the cold and wet, he took when he came from unknown skies
  15: Of the land of the dead, on my bent brown head I felt the reproach of his saddened eyes;
  16: I closed my lids on my heart's desire, crouched by the fire, my voice was dumb.
  17: 
  18: At my clean-swept hearth he had no mirth, and at my table he broke no crumb.
  19: 
  20: Deelish! Deelish! my woe forever that I could not sever coward flesh from fear.
  21: 
  22: His chair put aside when the young cock cried, and I was afraid to meet my dear.

 283: 
 284: For never more shall my steel shine in war.
 285: 
 286: I remember the days of my youth with grief, when I feel the weakness of my arm.
 287: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 288: Happy are they who fell in their youth, in the midst of their renown! They have not beheld the tombs of their friends, or failed to bend the bow of their strength.
 289: 
 290: Happy art thou, O Oscar, in the midst of thy rushing blast! Thou often goest to the fields of thy fame, where Caros fled from thy lifted sword!
 291: Darkness comes on my soul, O fair daughter of Toscar! I behold not the form of my son at Carun, nor the figure of Oscar on Crona.
 292: 
 293: The rustling winds have carried him far away, and the heart of his father is sad.
 294: 
 295: But lead me, O Malvina! to the sound of my woods, to the roar of my mountain streams.
 296: 
 297: Let the chase be heard on Cona: let me think on the days of other years.
 298: 
 299: And bring me the harp, O maid! that I may touch it when the light of my soul shall arise.
 300: 
 301: Be thou near to learn the song; future times shall hear of me! The sons of the feeble hereafter will lift the voice of Cona; and looking up to the rocks, say, "Here Ossian dwelt.
 302: 
 303: " They shall admire the chiefs of old, the race that are no more, while we ride on our clouds, Malvina! on the wings of the roaring winds.
 304: 
 305: Our voices shall be heard at times in the desert; we shall sing on the breeze of the rock!

 184:

 192:

 194:

Ye Sons of the chase, stand far distant nor disturb my rest The bard of other times holds discourse with his fathers! the chiefs of the days of old! Sons of the chase, stand far distant! disturb not the dreams of Ossian!

 384:

  24: Nothing but the deeds of the just live on in a flower that's blessed.
  25: 
  26: Sweetness comes from the grave where a good man lies dead.
  27: 
  28: (Collage by Stanton Hager)

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  29: Astonishing are the poems of Fortunatus, who was a 6th century Catholic Bishop, and later elected saint.
  30: 
  31: Astonishing because he sounds much more like secular poets, as Ben Jonson or Robert Herrick, than a religious one.
  32: 
  33: His subjects and presentation are not religious, much less saintly.
  34: 
  35: This "time's-a-flying poem" could have been written by any English poet from Marlowe to Marvell, but never by St.
  36: 
  37: Augustine.

#177: 75750_[Un Citadin - A City Dweller]_Réda, Jacques_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: [Un Citadin / A City Dweller]
Author: Réda, Jacques
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 15
Avg verse line length: 29.0
Avg prose line length: 147.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: [Un Citadin / A City Dweller]
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: The street I walk along I often see  As if I'd long since left the moving surface  Of the world for the endless other side that disperses  Us all some day without return but free  Of care.
   4: 
   5: I apply myself so well to this fragile proceeding  That very quickly my gaze ceases to be  Part of the cloudy clump of hope and memory  I'll have given my name to.
   6: 
   7: But for this to succeed,  A feeling of absolute happiness has to make  Itself felt, as if from outside me, so much  That at that moment the very street has a hunch  That it, the entire city, and its uncertain space  Have become one with the mobile but faithful pattern  Of phrases written by our steps when we move about.
   8: 
   9: I no longer know who's walking and marking out  The ground, bit by bit, to the corner.
  10: 
  11: My gaze then patterns  Itself on tomorrow's unknown eyes, which will shine  When from the roofs, posthumous and vague, mine glow,  And my invisible trace on the asphalt below
  12: 
  13: Might guide the élan of hardier passersby.
  14: 
  15: Will they know what I sometimes suspect: what appears  To be the distracted gaze with which we see  The world is the world itself?
  16: 
  17: —It sees and hears  Itself through the thin transparency of our screens.

#178: 75986_The Name Is Nothing_Ligotti, Thomas_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Name Is Nothing
Author: Ligotti, Thomas
Prose starts at line: 5
Lines to remove: 7
Avg verse line length: 31.0
Avg prose line length: 244.5

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: The Name Is Nothing
   2: 
   3: "The Unholy City" is a convenient misnomer.
   4: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   5: For one thing, it has none of the usual features which define a city of any size, and might be better described as a small town or village; an out-of-the-way place long gone to see.
   6: 
   7: Unlike cities both ancient and modern, the unholy city has never been marked on a map.
   8: 
   9: It is merely an ever changing name without a location, and is far more likely to find it's way to you, than you are to find your way to it - unless of course, you have been provided with special instructions that lead to an infinite barren landscape and end in the heart of nowhere.
  10: 
  11: As for the quality or characteristic of unholiness, this is also misleading, a nominal facade designed to make things interesting for a world born out of blackness, where nothing holy or unholy has ever existed, where nothing exists at all except dreams and fevers and names for nothing, the creations, so to speak, of that original blackness which pulls itself over every world like a hangman's hood over a condemned man's head.


====================================================================================================
#179: 75988_No One Knows The Big News_Ligotti, Thomas_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: No One Knows The Big News
Author: Ligotti, Thomas
Prose starts at line: 5
Lines to remove: 15
Avg verse line length: 48.5
Avg prose line length: 159.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: No One Knows The Big News
   2: 
   3: For all practical purposes almost no one is concerned with the big news.
   4: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   5: They have other things, more urgent matters, inscribed within their skulls, and all kinds of business to carry out.
   6: 
   7: Their heads are just too heavy with so many plans and schemes, thousands of tasks that will not allow them to focus on anything that is so strange, anything that is so uncertain.
   8: 
   9: They have no time to confront some ultimate revelation.
  10: 
  11: They have no desire to find out so incredibly big news.
  12: 
  13: Such a thing would take everything they know and arrange it in another way altogether, telling a story so different from the one that is already familiar to them.
  14: 
  15: Yet the big news is always there.
  16: 
  17: Like a tiny voice on a radio it chatters away through heavy static in a darkened room where people are trying to sleep, filling their heads with plans and schemes, inscribing thousands of tasks and urgent matters inside of their skulls, all kinds of business to carry out - little errands, oddjobs, atrocities both great and small - all of which, when taken together, arrange things a different way that compose a secret story that no one cares to make their concern, yet the big news is always there.
  18: 
  19: And so few will ever seek to discover, and none of them will ever be allowed to tell, that we ourselves are the dark language in which the big news is forever being written.


====================================================================================================
#180: 75990_You Do Not Own Your Head_Ligotti, Thomas_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: You Do Not Own Your Head
Author: Ligotti, Thomas
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 9
Avg verse line length: 24.0
Avg prose line length: 186.4

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: You Do Not Own Your Head
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: There are so many heads in the world, wherever you go there are heads, every day there are more of them sprouting up in the blackness.
   4: 
   5: At one time there was nothing at all, only blackness; and then, within the infinite space of that blackness things started to develop.
   6: 
   7: But as soon as those heads came along nothing much has happened - or nothing worthy of note: the whole world reached its peak and turned into an enormous heads factory.
   8: 
   9: Everyday there are more and more of them sprouting up in the blackness - which was there at the beginning - the blackness that, perhaps by chance, began to produce all these heads, and continues to produce so always calling out for more heads to carry out the business it wants done, its black voice roaring across the infinite black space of its heads factory.
  10: 
  11: But none of the heads has any ideas about the blackness that surrounds them or the blackness that hides itself inside each one of them.

#181: 75993_Welcome to the Unholy City_Ligotti, Thomas_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Welcome to the Unholy City
Author: Ligotti, Thomas
Prose starts at line: 5
Lines to remove: 15
Avg verse line length: 48.0
Avg prose line length: 145.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Welcome to the Unholy City
   2: 
   3: In some form or another, everyone must pay a visit to the Unholy City.
   4: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   5: There is simply no avoiding it since everything has been designed to lead you to this place.
   6: 
   7: Any road may present a detour that unexpectedly sends you on your way into a great barren landscape where only a sliver of horizon wavers in the empty distance and no road signs exist to hint at your destination.
   8: 
   9: Any hospital may be equipped with the special elevator where someone wheels you inside and then quickly abandons you.
  10: 
  11: As the doors clamp tightly closed you finally notice that there are no buttons to push, no controls of any kind.
  12: 
  13: This is when the elevator begins to move, dipping and twisting like a carnival ride, taking you toward the Unholy City.
  14: 
  15: After enduring such episodes, or others of a similar sort, you may only wake up screaming, vowing to never again close your eyes in sleep.
  16: 
  17: Or you may fall into a fever that no thermometer is able to indicate and from which there is no recovery.
  18: 
  19: In more extreme cases you begin to glimpse a blackness like none you have ever seen, and wonder for a time whether this blackness is inside your head or outside, which makes no difference once it begins to compose the outline of the Unholy City you're about to enter.


====================================================================================================
#182: 76220_The Laughter of Women_Willis, Mary-Sherman_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Laughter of Women
Author: Willis, Mary-Sherman
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 11
Avg verse line length: 21.0
Avg prose line length: 150.3

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: The Laughter of Women
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: From over the wall I could hear the laughter of women  in a foreign tongue, in the sun-rinsed air of the city.
   4: 
   5: They sat (so I thought) perfumed in their hats and their silks,  in chairs on the grass amid flowers glowing and swaying.
   6: 
   7: One spoke and the others rang like bells, oh so witty,  like bells till the sound filled up the garden and lifted  like bubbles spilling over the bricks that enclosed them,  their happiness holding them, even if just for the moment.
   8: 
   9: Although I did not understand a word they were saying,  their sound surrounded me, fell on my shoulders and hair,  and burst on my cheeks like kisses, and continued to fall,  holding me there where I stood on the sidewalk listening.
  10: 
  11: As I could not move, I had to hear them grow silent,  and adjust myself to the clouds and the cooling air.
  12: 
  13: The mumble of thunder rumbled out of the wall  and the smacking of drops as the rain fell everywhere.

Title: Sea Holly
Author: Burnett, Elizabeth Jane

  22:

  15: Of the Tachists, the master said to his friend Harry, “They paint white on white, and they believe that this is an achievement.
  16: 
  17: ” Harry said,  “I dare you to paint a white rose in a white room with a window looking onto a landscape covered with snow.
  18: 
  19: ” Now this — which even Loulou, color-blindish, can tell is red — is the master’s grandiose response to an intoxicating challenge.
  20: 
  21: Synesthetically, the rose fills Loulou’s pom ears with the echoes of torch songs, longing for the wrong.
  22: 
  23: Loulou is practically drunk from the smell: a heady pink, and juicy, and almost obscene.
  24: 
  25: Like crushed up candies, lingering and sweet, but with an adult musk at the core: a powerful flower.
  26: 
  27: In looking, Loulou’s heart becomes a house at dusk about to force  something to happen.

#187: 76627_Butchers_Williams, C K_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Butchers
Author: Williams, C K
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 13
Avg verse line length: 8.0
Avg prose line length: 215.7

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Butchers
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: 1 Thank goodness we were able to wipe the Neanderthals out, beastly things,from our mountains, our tundra—that way we had all the meat we might need.
   4: 
   5: Thus the butcher can display under our very eyes his hands on the block,and never refer to the rooms hidden behind where dissections are effected,where flesh is reduced to its shivering atoms and remade for our delectationas cubes, cylinders, barely material puddles of admixtured horror and blood.
   6: 
   7: Rembrandt knew of all this—isn’t his flayed beef carcass really a caveman?
   8: 
   9: It’s Christ also, of course, but much more a troglodyte such as we no longer are.
  10: 
  11: Vanished those species—begone!—those tribes, those peoples, those nations—Myrmidon, Ottoman, Olmec, Huron, and Kush: gone, gone, and goodbye.
  12: 
  13: 2 But back to the chamber of torture, to Rembrandt, who was telling us surelythat hoisted with such cables and hung from such hooks we too would revealwithin us intricate layerings of color and pain: alive the brush is with pain,aglow with the cruelties of crimson, the cooled, oblivious ivory of our innards.
  14: 
  15: Fling out the hooves of your hands! Open your breast, pluck out like an Aztecyour heart howling its Cro-Magnon cries that compel to battles of riddance!Our own planet at last, where purged of wilderness, homesickness, prowling,we’re no longer compelled to devour our enemies’ brains, thanks to our butcher,who inhabits this palace, this senate, this sentried, barbed-wire enclosurewhere dare enter none but subservient breeze; bent, broken blossom; dry rain.

#189: 76633_The Nail_Williams, C K_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Nail
Author: Williams, C K
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 8.0
Avg prose line length: 88.9

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: The Nail
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: Some dictator or other had gone into exile, and now reports were coming about his regime,
   4: the usual crimes, torture, false imprisonment, cruelty and corruption, but then a detail:
   5: that the way his henchmen had disposed of enemies was by hammering nails into their skulls.
   6: 
   7: Horror, then, what mind does after horror, after that first feeling that you’ll never catch your breath,
   8: mind imagines—how not be annihilated by it?
   9: 
  10: —the preliminary tap, feels it in the tendons of the hand,
  11: feels the way you do withyournail when you’re fixing something, making something, shelves, a bed;
  12: the first light tap to set the slant, and then the slightly harder tap, to em-bed the tip a little more .
  13: 
  14: 
  15: No, no more: this should be happening in myth, in stone, or paint, not in reality, not here;
  16: it should be an emblem of itself, not itself, something that wouldmean,not really have to happen,
  17: something to go out, expand in implication from that unmoved mass of matter in the breast;
  18: as in the image of an anguished face, in grief for us, not us as us, us as in a myth, a moral tale,
  19: a way to tell the truth that grief is limitless, a way to tell us we must always understand
  20: it’s we who do such things, we who set the slant, embed the tip, lift the sledge and drive the nail,
  21: drive the nail which is the axis upon which turns the brutal human world upon the world.


====================================================================================================
#190: 76635_Shame_Williams, C K_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Shame
Author: Williams, C K
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 18
Avg verse line length: 5.0
Avg prose line length: 83.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Shame
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: A girl who, in 1971, when I was living by myself, painfully lonely, bereft, depressed,
   4: 
   5: offhandedly mentioned to me in a conversation with some friends that although at first she’d found me—
   6: 
   7: I can’t remember the term, some dated colloquialism signifying odd, unacceptable, out-of-things—
   8: 
   9: she’d decided that I was after all all right .
  10: 
  11: 
  12: twelve years later she comes back to me from nowhere
  13: 
  14: and I realize that it wasn’t my then irrepressible, unselective, incessant sexual want she meant,
  15: 
  16: which, when we’d been introduced, I’d naturally aimed at her and which she’d easily deflected,
  17: 
  18: but that she’d thought I really was, in myself, the way I looked and spoke and acted,
  19: 
  20: what she was saying, creepy, weird, whatever, and I am taken with a terrible humiliation.

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]

 128: 
 129: Translated by:  Jack Iverson
 130: 
 131: 
 132: Voltaire's Notes

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 133: [1] This book of the Three Imposters is a very dangerous work, full of coarse atheism, without wit and devoid of philosophy.
 134: 
 135: [2] In France, in order to be accepted as procurer, notary, clerk, one needs two witnesses who confirm the Catholicism of the recipient.
 136: 
 137: [3] Tamponet was, in fact, a doctor at the Sorbonne.
 138: 
 139: [4] La Bletterie, as I have been told, has stated in print that I have forgotten to have myself buried.

   1: Watermark

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: From a microlight, the Owens River,cut and siphoned to an aqueduct:a corridor through banks of trees, into scuffed desert dunes, mountainsscaling to the right, to the left dry veinsin the valley, saline and pink, the waterchanneled slowly through scatch grass,under dirt tracks and fences, twenty miles,thirty — black line turning silver in midday sun,dipping beneath the roar of Route 395into the shade of the alkaline hills.
   4: 
   5: It zigzags past farms, arcs around quarries,swipes the bar code of a glinting new town,the alien discs of pivot irrigationgrowing sunflowers, roses, and corn.
   6: 
   7: Then follows the highway, just after Big Pine,rejoins the river north of Fish Springs,is diverted again, south of the reservoir — And does water care, if it’s riveror aqueduct?
   8: 
   9: Its vessel curved concrete,but the same constant flow, gunneling south,hugging the contours of eastern Sierra,past Independence, the airport,the golf course, along the right hand of Owens’dry lake bed, red swirling dust clouds kept downby sprinklers.
  10: 
  11: From up in the airthe twin Haiwee Reservoir is knuckleand knee joint where the line disappears — becomes pipeline and conduitunder the desert, punching for groundwater,surfacing riveted over Mojave,two hundred miles on from its native cradle,gray zombie spring tracing through forestto Santa Clarita, the treatment plant:the last reserve and loud cascadesabove the lights and life of Los Angeles.

   3: A crevice! shouts the Emperor in his sleep, and the canopy of ostrich plumes trembles.
   4: 
   5: The soldiers who pace the corridors with unsheathed swords believe the Emperor dreams about a siege.
   6: 
   7: Just now he saw a fissure in the wall and wants them to break into the fortress.
   8: 
   9: In fact the Emperor is now a wood-louse who scurries across the floor, seeking remnants of food.
  10: 
  11: Suddenly he sees overhead an immense foot about to crush him.
  12: 
  13: The Emperor hunts for a crevice in which to squeeze.
  14: 
  15: The floor is smooth and slippery.
  16: 
  17: Yes.
  18: 
  19: Nothing is more ordinary than the dreams of Emperors.

   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: First there was a god of night and tempest, a black idol without eyes, before whom they leaped, naked and smeared with blood.
   4: 
   5: Later on, in the times of the republic, there were many gods with wives, children, creaking beds, and harmlessly exploding thunderbolts.
   6: 
   7: At the end only superstitious neurotics carried in their pockets little statues of salt, representing the god of irony.
   8: 
   9: There was no greater god at that time.
  10: 
  11: Then came the barbarians.
  12: 
  13: They too valued highly the little god of irony.
  14: 
  15: They would crush it under their heels and add it to their dishes.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  46: This song, which first appeared in the Worcester Spy around Thanksgiving 1861, was written to commemorate the death of Lt.
  47: 
  48: John William Grout of the 15th Massachusetts Infantry, who was killed at the Battle of Ball's Bluff.
  49: 
  50: Although it had been set to music at least once, it enjoyed no success until the famous George F.
  51: 
  52: Root took it in hand and wrote this tune to accompany it.
  53: 
  54: The song was as popular in the Confederacy as it was up North and spawned at least three Southern versions.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: fromWhat the Heart Longs For When It Only Knows Heat ["We spend the afternoon together watching a docudrama..."]
   2: 
   3: We spend the afternoon together watching a docudrama about wild horses that roamed the ancient Arctic Circle.
   4: 
   5: Surprisingly sleek, built for speed and not the weather, they were remarkable for their recklessness.
   6: 
   7: They careen headlong down ice bluffs to fall into a broken heap.
   8: 
   9: We can hear the small, tinny sounds of their terror as they plunge across vast, glowing glacial faces.
  10: 
  11: All of this takes place alongside an abstractly relentless gunmetal sea.
  12: 
  13: I can feel you turn to me, wetness marking the corners of your lips and eyes.
  14: 
  15: I, too, am mesmerized, my vision limited to a sense of motion on the peripheries.
  16: 
  17: Later, I am summoned for an impromptu scan and, miraculously, I pass.

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: fromWhat the Heart Longs For When It Only Knows Heat ["We spend the afternoon together watching a docudrama..."]
   2: 
   3: We spend the afternoon together watching a docudrama about wild horses that roamed the ancient Arctic Circle.
   4: 
   5: Surprisingly sleek, built for speed and not the weather, they were remarkable for their recklessness.
   6: 
   7: They careen headlong down ice bluffs to fall into a broken heap.
   8: 
   9: We can hear the small, tinny sounds of their terror as they plunge across vast, glowing glacial faces.
  10: 
  11: All of this takes place alongside an abstractly relentless gunmetal sea.
  12: 
  13: I can feel you turn to me, wetness marking the corners of your lips and eyes.
  14: 
  15: I, too, am mesmerized, my vision limited to a sense of motion on the peripheries.
  16: 
  17: Later, I am summoned for an impromptu scan and, miraculously, I pass.

#204: 78020_The Book of Equality_Borzutzky, Daniel_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Book of Equality
Author: Borzutzky, Daniel
Prose starts at line: 5
Lines to remove: 13
Avg verse line length: 33.5
Avg prose line length: 456.9

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: The Book of Equality
   2: 
   3: Here the readers gather to watch the books die.
   4: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   5: They die suddenly, as if thrown from an airplane, or from spontaneous cardiac arrest.
   6: 
   7: They live, and then suddenly they die, and the reader who watches this is at the moment of the books' death bombarded with images documented through the smiling lipstick face of a journalist who has shown up to report on the death of the books.
   8: 
   9: The milk was poisoned and forty-two babies died, she laughs, as she fondles the ashes of the dead books.
  10: 
  11: And the death of forty-two babies is equal in value to the death of this book which is equal in value to the ninety-year old woman who shot herself while the sheriff waited at her door with an eviction notice which is equal in value to the collapsing of the global economy which is equal to the military in country XYZ seizing the land of the semi-nomadic hunters and cultivators of crops who have lived in the local rain forest for thousands of years.
  12: 
  13: The reader opens a dead book and finds an infinite amount of burnt ash between the bindings, and when the ash blows in the wind the lipstick says that every death in the world is equal to every other death in the world which is equal to every birth in the world which is equal to every act of dismemberment which is equal to the death of a jungle which is equal to the collapse of the global economy; and hey look there’s another lady falling out of a window; she looks about equal to the poet hurled out of his country for words he wrote but which did not belong to him and whose death is about equal to the girl who was shot on the bus on her way to school this morning which is just about the same as the bearded man whose head was shoved into a sac while water was dumped over it and he died for an instant and came back to life and talked and talked and that’s about equal to the steroid illegally injected into the arm of a beautiful man who makes forty million dollars a year for injecting his arms with steroids so he can more skillfully wave a wooden stick at a ball, and in the ash we see the truest democracy there ever was: hey look it’s a little baby found in a dumpster how equal you are says the smiling lipstick to the civilized nation whose citizens walk the flooded streets looking for their homes, and in the ashes of the dead book the dead streets are equal to the eating disorders of movie stars which are equal to the dead soldiers who are equal to the homeruns which are equal to the bomb dropped by country ABC over weddings in the village of country XYZ which is equal to the earth swallowing up and devouring all of its foreigners which is just about equal to the decline in literacy in the most educated nation in the planet.
  14: 
  15: There is no end to this book.
  16: 
  17: There are no paragraph breaks to interrupt the smiling lipstick that goes on and on in one string of ashy words about how the declaration of peace is equal to the resumption of war and how the bodies that fall are equal to the birds that ascend and how the bomb in the Eiffel Tower is equal to the rising cost of natural gas, and the murmurs of the voices in the mud are equal to the murmurs of the expensive suits falling out of buildings and these are equal to the silence that kills with one breath and coddles life with another.


====================================================================================================

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  10: 
  11: And the readers found the carcasses strewn across the pages and the readers came and stripped their innards and twirled intestines above their heads like lassos.
  12: 
  13: The carcasses fell onto the pages and were taken away in wagons and trucks and they were replaced with new carcasses that were sold for words before the flies laid eggs and the wounds had time to fester.
  14: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  15: FALSE CARCASS ECONOMY! Will the souls of the carcasses miss themselves when they die?
  16: 
  17: Will the bodies whose lips slurp out the souls of the carcasses miss themselves when they die?
  18: 
  19: Will the words from the bodies who slurp out the souls of the carcasses cease to exist when the bodies themselves die?
  20: 
  21: The readers grovel in the pages and find themselves in ditches with the carcasses but they do not know the rules of the false carcass economy.
  22: 
  23: In this book the readers can feel their feet being removed.
  24: 
  25: In this book the readers can feel the splash of the abattoir blood that sprinkles the page with poems.
  26: 
  27: How do you know if the poems have too many bubbles?
  28: 
  29: That is, how do you know if the blood of the poems has too many bubbles?
  30: 
  31: When we speak of our own lives, says the collective voice of the readers, we certainly don’t mean human life.
  32: 
  33: On the page the readers find themselves crawling around like quadrupeds with hands full of grass and earth uprooting plants and trees setting out for home and not getting far counting corpses on the fields to hell with animals there is God grinding his teeth with joy forging his way through the ruins of failing flesh there is the machine that has annihilated the bulk of humanity is it semen or is it a carburetor that makes us unrecognizable we know who we are through decay and in someone else’s story this is a lot worse than knocking your own brains out with good results then drinking tea with sugar and milk and suddenly feeling revived then exploding with words and speaking with animals and sinking in mud and being found by peasants who clean turds and who are like silent gods with holes in their shoes it is horrible to eat horrible to bulge in the belly with food horrible to blink when so many can’t blink oh to ruminate once more on the air polluted with liability on the hair singed from pollution the eyes burning fingers shrivelling the exact moment of ending will not come for many millennia we will not be able to document it it will document us it’s okay to kill some bodies speak of nothing and you’re lucky to make friends flank kidney liver swollen body on the sand who are you now that I am speaking with a mouth full of words that do not belong to me I crawl across the page and I don’t know if I’m dying or dead.

  10:

  12:

  14: 
  15: Because the sky blackens, but morning finds them always safe on the raindrenched land, bird on the windowsill.

  71: Squalor and filth with a sweet cur nestling in the grimy blankets of your bed and on better roads striplings dreaming of wealth and happiness.

  26: 3

  30:

  32: 
  33: Ha! the dark canals are whistling, whistling for who will cross to the other side.
  34: 
  35: If I remain with hands in pocket leaning upon my lamppost—why—I bring curses to a hag's lips and her daughter on her arm knows better than I can tell you—best to blush and out with it than back beaten after.
  36: 
  37: In Holland at daybreak, of a fine spring morning, one sees the housemaids beating rugs before the small houses of such a city as Amsterdam, sweeping, scrubbing the low entry steps and polishing doorbells and doorknobs.
  38: 
  39: By night perhaps there will be an old woman with a girl on her arm, histing and whistling across a deserted canal to some late loiterer trudging aimlessly on beneath the gas lamps.

Avg prose line length: 88.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Bath
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: The day is fresh-washed and fair, and there is a smell of tulips and narcissus in the air.
   4: 
   5: The sunshine pours in at the bath-room window and bores through the water in the bath-tub in lathes and planes of greenish-white.
   6: 
   7: It cleaves the water into flaws like a jewel, and cracks it to bright light.
   8: 
   9: Little spots of sunshine lie on the surface of the water and dance, dance, and their reflections wobble deliciously over the ceiling; a stir of my finger sets them whirring, reeling.
  10: 
  11: I move a foot and the planes of light in the water jar.
  12: 
  13: I lie back and laugh, and let the green-white water, the sun-flawed beryl water, flow over me.
  14: 
  15: The day is almost too bright to bear, the green water covers me from the too bright day.
  16: 
  17: I will lie here awhile and play with the water and the sun spots.
  18: 
  19: The sky is blue and high.
  20: 
  21: A crow flaps by the window, and there is a whiff of tulips and narcissus in the air.

#212: 78616_Towns in Colour_Lowell, Amy_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Towns in Colour
Author: Lowell, Amy
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 17
Avg verse line length: 15.0
Avg prose line length: 174.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Towns in Colour
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: Red slippers in a shop-window, and outside in the street, flaws of grey, windy sleet!Behind the polished glass, the slippers hang in long threads of red, festooning from the ceiling like stalactites of blood, flooding the eyes of passers-by with dripping colour, jamming their crimson reflections against the windows of cabs and tram-cars, screaming their claret and salmon into the teeth of the sleet, plopping their little round maroon lights upon the tops of umbrellas.
   4: 
   5: The row of white, sparkling shop fronts is gashed and bleeding, it bleeds red slippers.
   6: 
   7: They spout under the electric light, fluid and fluctuating, a hot rain—and freeze again to red slippers, myriadly multiplied in the mirror side of the window.
   8: 
   9: They balance upon arched insteps like springing bridges of crimson lacquer; they swing up over curved heels like whirling tanagers sucked in a wind-pocket; they flatten out, heelless, like July ponds, flared and burnished by red rockets.
  10: 
  11: Snap, snap, they are cracker-sparks of scarlet in the white, monotonous block of shops.
  12: 
  13: They plunge the clangour of billions of vermilion trumpets into the crowd outside, and echo in faint rose over the pavement.
  14: 
  15: People hurry by, for these are only shoes, and in a window, farther down, is a big lotus bud of cardboard whose petals open every few minutes and reveal a wax doll, with staring bead eyes and flaxen hair, lolling awkwardly in its flower chair.
  16: 
  17: One has often seen shoes, but whoever saw a cardboard lotus bud before?
  18: 
  19: The flaws of grey, windy sleet beat on the shop-window where there are only red slippers.

 320: and I remember a sad breeze through the olive trees.
 321: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 322: Ignacio Sánchez Mejías was a Spanish bullfighter, one of the greatest in history.
 323: 
 324: When he died after a goring (cornada) in the Plaza of Manzanares, he was memorialized by many famous poets but this is probably the best.
 325: 
 326: "Llanto por la muerte de Ignacio Sánchez Mejías" ("Weeping for the Death of Ignacio Sánchez Mejías").
 327: 
 328: For many people this is the best Spanish elegy since the Coplas of Jorge Manrigue.

#216: 79146_Bell Birds_Kendall, Henry_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Bell Birds
Author: Kendall, Henry
Prose starts at line: 70
Lines to remove: 20
Avg verse line length: 49.1
Avg prose line length: 109.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  65: 
  66: This poem was first published in a work entitled "Leaves from Australian Forests" by Henry Kendall in the year of 1869.
  67: 
  68: The Bellbird itself is a very small greyish bird.
  69: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  70: Its call or melody is simply one singular chiming note which seems to ring through their environmental habitat - the mountains and the hills of Eastern Australia.
  71: 
  72: They may be heard clearly in the quietness of the mountains and hills, although are rarely seen, unless an attitude of patience is adopted.
  73: 
  74: It is clear that to Henry Kendall, the mountains were a place of refuge and beauty.
  75: 
  76: The Australian mountains are concentrated in a reasonable narrow band known as the "Great Dividing Range" which runs from the tip of Cape York in the north, down the eastern coast - over 3000 kilometres - through the Snowy Mountain region and all the way to the Dandenong Mountain Range in Victoria, and no doubt the same range extends under the Bass Straight and down into the wilderness areas of Tasmania.
  77: 
  78: The nature of the mountain lands is captured here in the poetry of Henry Kendall and it is equally clear that this nature is not restricted to Australia, but extends to all the planetary mountain lands and the refuges they afford to those who would journey therein in search of peace, harmony and the chance to experience the natural world.
  79: 
  80: Listen to the bird
  81: home.
  82: 
  83: iprimus.
  84: 
  85: com.
  86: 
  87: au/punkclown/Punkclown/Bellbird.
  88: 
  89: htm
