Title: Untitled
Author: Meserve, James Monroe
Prose starts at line: 105
Lines to remove: 9
Avg verse line length: 31.3
Avg prose line length: 172.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 100: No — my heart is clinging to thee,
 101: As the ivy clings in death.
 102: 
 103: James Monroe Meserve was born in Banstead, New Hampshire, on May 20, 1820.
 104: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 105: Although he was a family man with six living children and a seventh on the way and was considered (at 44) to be past the age of enlistment, he nevertheless volunteered for service with Company A of the First New Hampshire Cavalry in March 1864.
 106: 
 107: His natural abilities gained him the rank of sergeant a month after his enlistment, but he was captured by Confederate forces shortly thereafter and sent to Andersonville prison in Georgia.
 108: 
 109: Sergeant Meserve died in Andersonville on August 22, 1864.
 110: 
 111: Although Sergeant Meserve was not a poet by training, this poem, which he wrote for his family while he was away fighting, illustrates the highly literate nature of the 19th century mind.
 112: 
 113: Even men and women with little education, whose spelling, grammar, and punctuation left much to be desired, were nonetheless capable of turning a flowery phrase with the best of them.


====================================================================================================

   2: 
   3: I am tired of work; I am tired of building up somebody else’s civilization.
   4: 
   5: Let us take a rest, M’Lissy Jane.
   6: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   7: I will go down to the Last Chance Saloon, drink a gallon or two of gin, shoot a game or two of dice and sleep the rest of the night on one of Mike’s barrels.
   8: 
   9: You will let the old shanty go to rot, the white people’s clothes turn to dust, and the Calvary Baptist Church sink to the bottomless pit.
  10: 
  11: You will spend your days forgetting you married me and your nights hunting the warm gin Mike serves the ladies in the rear of the Last Chance Saloon.
  12: 
  13: Throw the children into the river; civilization has given us too many.
  14: 
  15: It is better to die than it is to grow up and find out that you are colored.
  16: 
  17: Pluck the stars out of the heavens.
  18: 
  19: The stars mark our destiny.
  20: 
  21: The stars marked my destiny.
  22: 
  23: I am tired of civilization.

  20: 
  21: The same you saw in heavenly seat Is he that now sucks Mary’s teat; Agnize your king a mortal wight, His borrowed weed lets not your sight.
  22: 
  23: Come, kiss the manger where he lies, That is your bliss above the skies.
  24: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  25: This little babe, so few days old, Is come to rifle Satan’s fold; All hell doth at his presence quake.
  26: 
  27: Though he himself for cold do shake, For in this weak unarmèd wise The gates of hell he will surprise.
  28: 
  29: With tears he fights and wins the field; His naked breast stands for a shield; His battering shot are babish cries, His arrows looks of weeping eyes, His martial ensigns cold and need, And feeble flesh his warrior’s steed.
  30: 
  31: His camp is pitchèd in a stall, His bulwark but a broken wall, The crib his trench, hay stalks his stakes, Of shepherds he his muster makes; And thus, as sure his foe to wound, The angels’ trumps alarum sound.
  32: 
  33: My soul, with Christ join thou in fight; Stick to the tents that he hath pight; Within his crib is surest ward, This little babe will be thy guard.
  34: 
  35: If thou wilt foil thy foes with joy, Then flit not from this heavenly boy.

#220: 80198_The Burning Babe_SJ, Robert Southwell_unknown.txt

Author: SJ, Robert Southwell
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 10
Avg verse line length: 16.0
Avg prose line length: 192.6

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: The Burning Babe
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: As I in hoary winter’s night stood shivering in the snow, Surpris’d I was with sudden heat which made my heart to glow; And lifting up a fearful eye to view what fire was near, A pretty Babe all burning bright did in the air appear; Who, scorched with excessive heat, such floods of tears did shed As though his floods should quench his flames which with his tears were fed.
   4: 
   5: “Alas!” quoth he, “but newly born, in fiery heats I fry, Yet none approach to warm their hearts or feel my fire but I! My faultless breast the furnace is, the fuel wounding thorns, Love is the fire, and sighs the smoke, the ashes shame and scorns; The fuel Justice layeth on, and Mercy blows the coals, The metal in this furnace wrought are men’s defiled souls, For which, as now on fire I am to work them to their good,
   6: 
   7: So will I melt into a bath to wash them in my blood.
   8: 
   9: 
  10: With this he vanish’d out of sight and swiftly shrunk away,
  11: 
  12: And straight I called unto mind that it was Christmas day.

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]

  36: 
  37: No  me  tienes que  dar  porque  Te  quiera;
  38: Porque,  aunque lo  que  espero  no  esperara,
  39: Lo  mismo que  te  quiero Te  quisiera.
  40: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  41: An old  prayer in  sonnet  form  which is  taken  from  a  prayer  book  called  <<Handbook  of  Prayers>>  by  priests  Charles  Belmonte  and  James  Socias.
  42: 
  43: The  rhyming  is  ABBAABBA CDECDE  both  the  Spanish  and  English  translation  which  is  a  Petrarchan  form  of  sonnet    though  the  count  is  in  iambic  pentameter.
  44: 
  45: Petrarchan  is  originally  counted  in  11  syllables per  line.
  46: 
  47: More  than  a  sonnet  it  became a  prayer  because  the  words  itself  touches  the  spirit.
  48: 
  49: JS

1267: The harden'd flesh of mountain-deer.
1268: 
1269: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1270: ): The Scottish Highlanders, in former times, had a concise mode of cooking their venison, or rather of dispensing with cooking it, which appears greatly to have surprised the French, whom chance made acquainted with it.
1271: 
1272: The Vidame of Chartres, when a hostage in England, during the reign of Edward VI.
1273: 
1274: , was permitted to travel into Scotland, and penetrated as far as to the remote Highlands (au fin fond des Sauvages).
1275: 
1276: After a great hunting party, at which a most wonderful quantity of game was destroyed, he saw these Scottish Savages devour a part of their venison raw, without any further preparation than compressing it between two battons of wood, so as to force out the blood, and render it extremely hard.
1277: 
1278: ~ Select Poetical Works of Sir Walter Scott, vol.
1279:

#224: 80974_MacKrimmon's Lament_Scott, Sir Walter_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: MacKrimmon's Lament
Author: Scott, Sir Walter
Prose starts at line: 46
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 49.1
Avg prose line length: 103.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  41: macjams.
  42: 
  43: com/song/22577
  44: It's very likely that Sir Walter Scott wrote this in the year 1815, when he took a tour of Dunvegan.
  45: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  46: In his Journal for 24th of August, he says, "MacLeod's hereditary is called MacCrimmon, but the present holder of this office has risen above his profession.
  47: 
  48: He is an old man, a Lieutenant in the army, and a most capital piper, possessing about 200 tunes, most of which will probably die with him, as he declines to have any of his sons instructed in the art.
  49: 
  50: He plays to MacLeod and his Lady, but only in the same room, and maintains his minstrel image by putting on his bonnet as soon as he begins to play.
  51: 
  52: These MacCrimmons formerly kept a college in Skye for teaching the pipe music.
  53: 
  54: MacLeod's present piper is of the name but scarcely as yet a deacon of his craft.
  55: 
  56: He played every day at dinner.
  57: 
  58: "  That Lieutenant was Donald Ruadh MacCrimmon (b.
  59: 
  60: 1743, died in London, 1825), who was nephew to Donald Bann MacCrimmon.
  61: 
  62: Donald Bann is supposed to have written the original lament, or at least the music for it, before he went off to battle in the Rout of Moy and was killed.
  63: 
  64: His sister is considered to have written the original lyrics.

 254: y

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 255: ow' though), the original seat of the clan Hamilton, dating back to the battles of Independence.
 256: 
 257: The town was later named Hamilton, and the infamous and utterly magnificent Hamilton Palace was built (the grandest non-royal residence in Scotland).
 258:

 260: 
 261: , after it had been used as a hospital during the war; as well, mining underneath compromised the grounds.

 264: 
 265: The mausoleum is famous for having the absolute
 266: worst
 267: acoustics in any building in the whole of Europe.
 268:

 270: 
 271: Arran: the Hamilton's had the title of the Earl of Arran, the first earl being the son of the 1st Lord Hamilton who married the daughter of King James II in the 1400's.

#231: 81547_Emancipation Of The Slaves_Bell, James Madison_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Emancipation Of The Slaves
Author: Bell, James Madison
Prose starts at line: 300
Lines to remove: 11
Avg verse line length: 34.8
Avg prose line length: 115.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 295: Ever in God, who is faithful and just.
 296: 
 297: The full title of this poem is:
 298: Emancipation of the slaves in the District of Columbia and in the British West Indies
 299: Introductory note:

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 300: The Poet laments the discord of his Harp, and its disuse, until answering Freedom's call he again essays its harmony.
 301: 
 302: He portrays the conflict, and gives thanks to God for the dawning day of Freedom.
 303: 
 304: He rejoices that Columbia is free; he eulogizes the moral heroes, and describes how America is "marching on" in the footsteps of the warlike "Hero John.
 305: 
 306: The cause of this fratricidal war is next given, and the challenge of Slavery to Liberty.
 307: 
 308: He then invokes the spirits of our "sleeping sires" from their "beds of dust," and bids the nation listen to their warning voices.
 309: 
 310: He concludes by prophecying that a glorious peace will be secured when Liberty is inscribed upon the banners of the Union.


====================================================================================================
#232: 81552_The Progress Of Liberty_Bell, James Madison_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Progress Of Liberty
Author: Bell, James Madison
Prose starts at line: 901
Lines to remove: 11
Avg verse line length: 34.6
Avg prose line length: 188.7

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 896: From that bright, hoary autumn, he will look back and see
 897: This broad land — all happy and free.
 898: 
 899: Introductory Note.
 900: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 901: The "Progress of Liberty" is delineated in the events of the past four years -- the overthrow of the rebellion, the crushing of the spirit of anarchy, the total extinction of slavery, and the return of peace and joy to our beloved country.
 902: 
 903: The invincibility of Liberty is illustrated in the beautiful episode of the Swiss patriot, William Tell, wherein the goddess is personified by an eagle towering amidst the clouds.
 904: 
 905: The poet claims the full enfranchisement of his race from political, as well as personal thraldom, and declares that the "Progress of Liberty" will not be complete until the ballot is given to the loyal freedmen.
 906: 
 907: The noble actions and self-sacrificing spirit of the immortal Lincoln is next sung, and in mournful strains the poet bewails his martyrdom.
 908: 
 909: This concludes with a touching eulogy on our sainted martyr.
 910: 
 911: The reconstruction policy of President Johnson is reviewed, and, while objecting, the poet does not wholly condemn his motives, but warns the ruling powers that, unless the spirit of rebellion is wholly obliterated and every vestige swept away, it will only slumber to awake again with renewed ferocity.


====================================================================================================
#233: 81553_The Triumph Of Liberty_Bell, James Madison_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Triumph Of Liberty
Author: Bell, James Madison
Prose starts at line: 1015
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 35.1
Avg prose line length: 98.6

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1010: 
1011: Preface.
1012: 
1013: The wonderful change that has taken place in the political character of the United States, in the last ten years, is well calculated to excite the poetic feelings of any man having a spark of poesy in him.
1014: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1015: The march of events have been peculiarly romantic, outstripping all human expectations, and leaving even prophecy in the rear.
1016: 
1017: The present poem is given to the public with the hope of perpetuating, to some extent, the remembrance of the "good time," and of sending to the future some little knowledge of the trials, struggles, and triumph of Liberty in our land.
1018: 
1019: The author felt his incompetency to do justice to the task -- it being an unexplored field -- but he has opened the way, and leaves to others the duty of following, if they will.
1020: 
1021: This poem was written during hours snatched from other occupations.
1022: 
1023: Still, we send it forth, confident that the theme of which it treats, and the earnest sincerity of the author, will win for it the public approbation.
1024: 
1025: It is a statement of facts -- not fiction -- and, gentle reader, we ask you to follow it to the close, trusting it may nerve you anew for the right, and encourage you in the cause of humanity.
1026: 
1027: HON.
1028: 
1029: JOHN D.
1030: 
1031: RICHARDS.
1032: 
1033: Detroit, Michigan.


====================================================================================================
#234: 81556_The Day And The War_Bell, James Madison_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Day And The War
Author: Bell, James Madison
Prose starts at line: 853
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 35.0
Avg prose line length: 124.7

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 848: 
 849: He shows how this wicked Rebellion, instituted to perpetuate Slavery, will cause "the final abolition" of the accursed institution.
 850: 
 851: -- The Colored people are incited to prove themselves worthy of the position they must assume, by patriotism, fortitude and virtue.
 852: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 853: The deceitful policy of the European Governments is examined and criticised -- their jealousy of the growing power of the American Union; their sympathy with the Rebels; the material aid and comfort they render unto the Confederacy, and their desire to effect the dismemberment of the Republic.
 854: 
 855: England, remembering the loss of the Colonies, is covertly aiding the Rebellion, and, while professing neutrality, is supplying them with ships and munitions of war.
 856: 
 857: He next sings of the heroism of the colored troops -- their deeds of valor at Milliken's Bend -- bravery of Miller's men, of which company all save one were either slain or wounded -- and of the heroic achievements of the Black Brigade.
 858: 
 859: He relates a vision of the War, and portrays in vivid colors the horrors of a battlefield after the fight.
 860: 
 861: An angel appears, who announces the advent of Peace.
 862: 
 863: The warrior returns from the carnage of battle; his sword is turned into a plowshare, his spear into a reaping-hook, and a "real Republic" is formed.
 864: 
 865: In conclusion, he eulogizes the God-approving act of President Lincoln in issuing the great Emancipation Proclamation, and predicts that when posterity is enumerating the benefactors of mankind, "great Lincoln's name will lead the host.
 866: 
 867: P.
 868: 
 869: A.
 870: 
 871: BELL.


====================================================================================================

  36: ][In the future, the streets are stillthe same, and in December, on aTuesday afternoon in 2016, one ofyour descendants will be stabbedmerely for standing in the day.
  37: 
  38: The Northside knows scar, knowsbody, when it needs to mourn.
  39: 
  40: ][Move in packs, march the streetstogether, keep the body flickering,make the voice resist quiet, thisgoing, this coming, is resistance.
  41: 
  42: ][This is how we mean business:you come to school, bien fino,and we will teach you the fourwinds, the reason we are alwaysarmed to the touch of a blade, weare always blades, bien filosos.
  43: 
  44: ][One day all these classroomswill no longer hold any of us,leave no evidence we were here,we exist in the whisper,the tender cinnamon strings inmuscle.
  45: 
  46: Marcha ya.

 143: 
 144: But I no longer know what it is if I climb to the top of a tree (one of these trees on the border between language and the world), from where you can see far into language and far into the world at the same time.
 145: 
 146: 21.
 147: 
 148: Because I have scaled a tree, I know that beyond language is a huge plain, with dark flowers and little mazy footpaths.

  22: bearing strange symbols to the new dawn.
  23: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

  25: 
  26: … but I cannot stay… for the smell… I know… how the days pass… The prison squats with granite haunches on the young spring, battened under with its twisting green… and you… socket for every bolt piercing like a driven nail.
  27: 
  28: Eyes stare you through the bars… eyes blank as a graveled yard… and the silence shuffles heavy dice of feet in iron corridors… until the day… that has soiled herself in this black hole to caress the pale mask of your face… withdraws the last wizened ray to wash in the infinite her discolored hands.
  29: 
  30: Can you hear me, Sasha, in your surrounded darkness?

  55: ): Ernicus was one of the Argonauts, who distinguished himself in the games celebrated at Lemnos by its hospitable queen Hypsipile, as victor in the foot-race of men clothed in armour.
  56: 
  57: He was prematurely gray-headed, and therefore derided by the Lemnian women before he had given this proof of his vigour.
  58: 
  59: It is not impossible that Psaumis had the same singularity of appearance.
  60: 
  61: There is a sort of playfulness in this ode, which would make us suspect that Pindar had no very sincere respect for the character of Psaumis.
  62: 
  63: Perhaps he gave offence by it ; for the following poem to the same champion is in  a very different style.

 247: ): Like all other very early tombs, the monument of Pelops was a barrow or earthen mound.
 248: 
 249: The spot is very accurately pointed out, and such works are not easily obliterated.
 250: 
 251: (line 182: God, who beholdeth thee and all thy deeds.
 252: 
 253: ): The solemnity of this prayer contrasted with its object, that Hiero might again succeed in the chariot-race, is ridiculous to modern ears.
 254: 
 255: I do not indeed believe that the Olympic and other games had so much importance attached to them by the statesmen and warriors of Greece as is pretended by the sophists of later ages ; but where the manners are most simple, public exhibitions, it should be remembered, are always most highly estimated, and religious prejudice combined with the ostenation of wealth to give distinction to the Olympic contests.
 256: 
 257: ~ The Poetical Works of George Herbert and Reginald Heber.

 251: 
 252: (line 175: To Juno, queen of deities.
 253: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 254: ): Such passages as this appear to prove, first, that the Odes of Pindar, instead of being danced and chanted by a chorus of hired musicians and actors, in the absurd and impossible manner pretended by the later Grecian writers (whose ignorance respecting their own antiquities is in many instances apparent), were recited by the poet himself sitting, and accompanied by one or more musicians, such the Theban Æneas whom he here compliments.
 255: 
 256: Secondly, what will account at once for the inequalities of his style and the rapidity of his transitions, we may infer that the Dircæan swan was, often at least, an "improvisatore.
 257: 
 258: " I know not the origin of the Bœotian agnomen of swine.
 259: 
 260: In later times we find their region called "vervecum patria.
 261: 
 262: (line 199: Mark with no envious ear a subject praise.
 263: 
 264: ): Either the poet was led by his vanity to ascribe a greater consequence to his verses than they really possessed, when he supposes that the praise of Agesias may move his sovereign to jealousy; or we may infer from this little circumstance, that the importance attached to the Olympic prize has not been so greatly overrated by poets and antiquaries, and that it was indeed "a gift more valuable than a hundred trophies.
 265: 
 266: ~ The Poetical Works of George Herbert and Reginald Heber.
 267: 
 268: With Memoirs.
 269: 
 270: Gall & Inglis, ca.
 271: 
 272: 1870's.

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 216: That the deil's big stane is on ilka ane's back
 217: Wha has love for nocht but gear.
 218: 
 219: 'In the very centre of the deep gorge of this linn is an immense boulder, estimated at thirty tons weight.
 220: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 221: It is a mass of water-worn granite, probably from the Isle of Arran, as its granulated particles seem to be precisely of the same character of those that compose the granite of Goatfell.
 222: 
 223: It must have been conveyed in the age of the northern drift, or dropped from the base of some massive iceberg as it sailed the waters that erst covered these heights.
 224: 
 225: It is rounded like an egg, and has a belt of finer grain begirding its bulk like an iron hoop around a barrel.
 226: 
 227: Simpson's "Voice from the Desert.
 228: 
 229: Such is the account given by the late Dr Simpson of Sanquhar; but in the neighbourhood the boulder in question is known by the dignified appellation of the "Deil's Stane.
 230: 
 231: " How it came to get such a title I have not been able to learn.
 232: 
 233: Long ago, a pedlar was murdered near the spot for the sake of the petty wares he traded with among the hills.
 234: 
 235: They still show you his blood in the channel of the Orchard burn, close to where the stone is lying.
 236: 
 237: This, like all other blood shed in like circumstances, will not wash out.
 238: 
 239: I have, in the following poem, with the license usually granted to rhymers, wandered from received tradition in order to "point a moral and adorn a tale.

  90: Should lay this rhythmic offering with a sigh
  91: On the young Schiller of dreamers—David Gray.
  92:

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  93: I was lately sent by a friend a copy of the new edition of David Gray's poems, now issued by Maclehose.
  94: 
  95: I had read them years before, and on reading them again, a desire to add a tribute, however feeble, to their worth and freshness grew within me.
  96: 
  97: The result was this poem.
  98: 
  99: What is in the book can be seen by all, but that which slumbers with him of his early dreams and high hopes can never be known.
 100: 
 101: He sleeps his last sleep in Kirkintilloch Churchyard, one of 'the inheritors of unfulfilled renown.

Author: Anderson, Alexander
Prose starts at line: 346
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 30.4
Avg prose line length: 63.3

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 341: An express train tears like the wind,
 342: And twenty minutes late.
 343: 
 344: 1.
 345: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 346: The following poem was the result of a visit which I, along with three others, paid to Pamphy linns, a romantic spot lying hidden in a wood which stretches along the Barr Moor in the neighbourhood of Sanquhar.
 347: 
 348: I have availed myself of a poetical license, and described the linns as swollen by rains, and foaming down the waterfall which forms the pièce de resistance of the place.
 349: 
 350: The friends who accompanied me will pardon me where I have deviated from fact to fiction, especially my young Edinburgh friend whom I have bored in the text.
 351: 
 352: The poem is warmly dedicated to the three.
 353: 
 354: 2.
 355: 
 356: I writ two lines to say--
 357: 'O, happy time of love's young prime,
 358: Would it could last alway.
 359: 
 360: ' ---
 361: 'O, das sie ewig grünen bliebe,
 362: Die schöne zeit der yungen liebe.
 363: 
 364: Das lied von der Glocke

   1: “I used to love the run-up to a storm”
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: I used to love the run-up to a storm, watching from the porch as the grown-ups hurried to bring things in, my mother rummaging through drawers for a flashlight, cursing: nothing was where it was supposed to be in our house.
   4: 
   5: It can’t be so, but the only people I ever remember huddled in the basement were my mother and me, suspended in that eerie half-light like bats.
   6: 
   7: We’ve just spent a week like this, my mother perched in a chair above the water keeping watch for the next bad thing.
   8: 
   9: We were happy so sometimes she’d let the vigil rest, the sentry of her shoulders easing to a more receptive pose, a quarter moon, until something called her back to the watch, mother first no longer but this white, foremost light.
  10: 
  11: You can read by it.
  12: 
  13: You can see.

   4:

  12:

  14:

#254: 85093_“Cuando tenía seis años”_Giorgio, Marosa Di_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: “Cuando tenía seis años”
Author: Giorgio, Marosa Di
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 17
Avg verse line length: 24.0
Avg prose line length: 76.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: “Cuando tenía seis años”
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: Cuando tenía seis años, ocho años, la abuela dictaminó vestido de liebre, que me librase de todo mal.
   4: 
   5: Y, entonces, hizo un sacón de piel de liebre y lo ajustó, y, adentro, puso lápices y libros.
   6: 
   7: Al alba, antes, en la noche, yo iba para la escuela, vestida así, y en cuatro pies, entre las hierbas parpadeantes y las dalias.
   8: 
   9: Cientos de metros; a ratos, me detenía y preparaba café en un pequeño frasco, y proseguía.
  10: 
  11: Mas, una vez, los niños feroces me descubrieron.
  12: 
  13: Gritaban: ¡Ahí, va Rosa la liebre! ¡Va la liebre, la liebre! ¡Va la liebre! Y me cercaban.
  14: 
  15: Las estrellas extendieron sus ramos, para que trepase y huyera con ellas.
  16: 
  17: Pero empezó la aurora a pintar.
  18:

#255: 85096_Advance Australia Fair_McCormick, Peter Dodds_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Advance Australia Fair
Author: McCormick, Peter Dodds
Prose starts at line: 71
Lines to remove: 14
Avg verse line length: 34.2
Avg prose line length: 109.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  66: 
  67: B.
  68: 
  69: Fuller Esq.
  70: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  71: , dated 1 August 1913, McCormick described the circumstances that inspired him to pen the lyrics of his famous song:
  72: “One night I attended a great concert in the Exhibition Building, when all the National Anthems of the world were to be sung by a large choir with band accompaniment.
  73: 
  74: This was very nicely done, but I felt very aggravated that there was not one note for Australia.
  75: 
  76: On the way home in a bus, I concocted the first verse of my song and when I got home I set it to music.
  77: 
  78: I first wrote it in the Tonic Sol-fa notation, then transcribed it into the old notation, and I tried it over on an instrument next morning, and found it correct.
  79: 
  80: Strange to say there has not been a note of it altered since.
  81: 
  82: Some alteration has been made in the wording, but the sense is the same.
  83: 
  84: It seemed to me to be like an inspiration, and I wrote the words & music with the greatest ease.

#256: 85359_High Wood_Purvis, John Stanley_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: High Wood
Author: Purvis, John Stanley
Prose starts at line: 50
Lines to remove: 13
Avg verse line length: 38.6
Avg prose line length: 143.9

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  45: altitude 930 m.
  46: 
  47: John Purvis wrote this poem under his pseudonym of Philip Johnstone in 1918
  48: In France High Wood is known as Bois des Fourceaux.
  49: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  50: It was a major German stronghold until it was taken and held by the British, after almost three months of heavy fighting.
  51: 
  52: Various British attack methods were employed: cavalry charge, infantry assaults, gas attacks, flame thrower attacks, machine gun barrages, tanks - and mine warfare.
  53: 
  54: Craters dating back to these mine attacks can still be seen when visiting the Cameron Highlanders and Black Watch Memorial at High Wood.
  55: 
  56: The final capture of the hill was not achieved until the 15th September 1916 when the 47th London Division (men of the Post Office Rifles and Civil Service Rifles among them) took the wood.
  57: 
  58: Amazingly, it was felt to be a failure.
  59: 
  60: Lack of Push, was the verdict on the Division by High Command and the Divisional Commander was replaced.
  61: 
  62: Two years later John Stanly Purvis wrote his poem, in which he pictures a scene wherein tourists visit High Wood: He was correct too as in 1919 the Front was flooded with people looking at places where their loved ones had died or out of sheer curiosity.

   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]

   3: I’d like to be a shrine, so I can learn from peoples’ prayers the story of hearts.
   4: 
   5: I’d like to be a scarf so I can place it over my hair and understand other worlds.
   6: 
   7: I’d like to be the voice of a soprano singer so I can move through all borders and see them vanish with every spell-­binding note.
   8: 
   9: I’d like to be light so I illuminate the dark.
  10: 
  11: I’d like to be water to fill bodies so we can gently float together indefinitely.
  12: 
  13: I’d like to be a lemon, to be zest all the time, or an olive tree to shimmer silver on the earth.
  14: 
  15: Most of all, I’d like to be a poem, to reach your heart and stay.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: alwaysendeavor
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: Bob Dahlquist is an artist whose work I first noticed in New York City's Bryant Park, where I saw staring down at me an imaginative logo for a sandwich shop.
   4: 
   5: The logo demonstrated Dahlquist's grasp of what I call the printer's fist—an understanding of the visual and intellectual significance of typographic characters.
   6: 
   7: His "alwaysendeavor" replicates the look of old-fashioned office signs etched into translucent glass doors, but in this case we see the text from both sides at once, and we must pull apart the strands of overlapping text to reconstitute the meaning.
   8: 
   9: —Geof Huth
  10: 
  11: More About Visual Poetry >>

   1: Releasing the Sherpas
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: The last two sherpas were the strongest,faithful companions, their faces wind-peeled,streaked with soot and glacier-light on the snowfieldbelow the summit where we stopped to rest.
   4: 
   5: The first was my body, snug in its cap of lynx-fur, smelling of yak butter and fine mineral dirt,agile, impetuous, broad-shouldered,alive to the frozen bite of oxygen in the larynx.
   6: 
   7: The second was my intellect, dour and thirsty, furrowing its fox-like brow, my calculating brainsearching for some cairn or chasm to explainmy decision to send them back without me.
   8: 
   9: Looking down from the next, ax-cleft serac I saw them turn and dwindle and felt unafraid.
  10: 
  11: Blind as a diamond, sun-pure and rarefied,whatever I was then, there was no turning back.

#264: 87261_A Poet Of Provence_Miller, Jewell_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: A Poet Of Provence
Author: Miller, Jewell
Prose starts at line: 650
Lines to remove: 11
Avg verse line length: 34.6
Avg prose line length: 147.3

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 645: 
 646: All the starry firmament grew dim
 647: As breath, and life itself passed out from him.
 648: 
 649: 'AUTHOR'S PREFATORY NOTE:--

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 650: For many centuries the Lascaris of Tenda (Counts of Ventimiglia), the imperial Doria of Dolceaqua, and the Grimaldi of Monaco held sway over Liguria and part of Provence.
 651: 
 652: The ramifications of the various branches of these noble houses extended far and wide, and many members of these three families distinguished themselves in political life as well as earning renown as admirals and generals.
 653: 
 654: But it remained for Count Ludovico Lascaris who became one of the most brilliant Provencal poets of his period, the fifteenth century, to write his family name in the history of the art of the land.
 655: 
 656: Two of his poems "Las Miserias daequest mond" and "La Paurilha" are still extant.
 657: 
 658: A Poet Of Provence, with the grateful appreciation of the author, is dedicated to Lilian Victoria MacDougall, founder of the "Salon of Seven Arts," who gave the manuscript its first public reading.
 659: 
 660: ~ 5 Poets, 1929.

#265: 87414_'This year again there is spring'_Poswiatowska, Halina_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: "This year again there is spring"
Author: Poswiatowska, Halina
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 13
Avg verse line length: 33.0
Avg prose line length: 128.6

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: "This year again there is spring"
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: This year again there is spring, spring incredibly familiar, so why does poetry suffocate on its own breath.
   4: 
   5: The tree under my window commits plagiarism for the twentieth year in a row, green leaves upon green leaves.
   6: 
   7: This year's cherry blossoms are not different from those when the cherry tree began, the same perfume permeates the air.
   8: 
   9: And - although the old declare it tiresome - my sister kisses under trees as I did; she kisses passionately, forever plagiarizing her first kiss.
  10: 
  11: I could as well recall grasses, all the grasses which have germinated from seed, faithfully and without compromise, like those of several months ago.
  12: 
  13: Life giving birth does not fear plagiarism, just as death - stubborn in its repetition - always stupefies.
  14: 
  15: Why then censure love poems, why object to their lack of shame and primitive disorderly groan of rapture repeated perpetually for centuries oblivious of readership.

#266: 87427_'To produce a poem'_Poswiatowska, Halina_unknown.txt

Title: "To produce a poem"
Author: Poswiatowska, Halina
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 9
Avg verse line length: 19.0
Avg prose line length: 121.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: "To produce a poem"
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: To produce a poem - once a vibrating pain in the tissues was enough and a stock of words no greater than an animal's scream.
   4: 
   5: Nowadays, one needs an outline and an argument, and comparative explorations into the depth of dictionaries.
   6: 
   7: There are surgical interventions around words, there are word-hybrids, half-words, quarter-words, and there is an ambiguity of letters swollen with wisdom.
   8: 
   9: And my thirst - a fledgling nightingale is silenced by all these scores and instruments.
  10: 
  11: And when you ask me for meaning, I feel how the branch that supports the frail nest snaps under the crushing load of a grand piano.

  22:

  24: 
  25: He knows that children are careless, and that there will come a time when he will be free to move his house to some secluded place, where he will relight his candle, take out his catalogues and read until at last he yawns.
  26: 
  27: Then he’ll bury his head in his arms and sleep.
  28: 
  29: 
  30: That is, until another child picks up his house.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: untitled (for Natalee and Jeremy)
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: derek beaulieu often works at the edges of language, using isolated letters to create visual, instead of verbal, patterns and deconstructing found texts to tease out hidden meanings.
   4: 
   5: His "untitled (for Natalee and Jeremy)," produced for two of his friends, is either a visual poetry epithalamium or simply a joyous celebration of the physical beauties of lettershape and writing.
   6: 
   7: The resulting poem, which is created with press-on type, gains most of its effects from the repetition of identical letters, visual poetry's equivalent to rhyme, consonance, and assonance.
   8: 
   9: —Geof Huth
  10: 
  11: More About Visual Poetry >>

  16: Now that I seek for thee in human faces;
  17: Answer my prayer or set my spirit free
  18: Again to drift along the starry places.
  19: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  20: The title 'Anadyomene' is an epithet of Aphrodite (Venus), which was expressive of her having sprung from the foam of the sea.
  21: 
  22: There was a famous painting by Apelles where she was represented under this title as if she just emerged from the sea and in the act of wringing her hair.
  23: 
  24: The painting was created for the temple of Asclepius at Cos, which was taken to Rome, Augustus in part gave payment of tribute and set it up in the temple of Cæsar.
  25: 
  26: There have been several paintings of this from that period on.
  27: 
  28: The painting above is said to be painted by Titian (Tiziano Vecellio) (1485-1576)

#272: 89113_The Tree_Finch, Countess of Winchilsea Anne_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Tree
Author: Finch, Countess of Winchilsea Anne
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 11
Avg verse line length: 8.0
Avg prose line length: 188.3

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: The Tree
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: Fair tree! for thy delightful shade'Tis just that some return be made;Sure some return is due from meTo thy cool shadows, and to thee.
   4: 
   5: When thou to birds dost shelter give,Thou music dost from them receive;If travellers beneath thee stayTill storms have worn themselves away,That time in praising thee they spendAnd thy protecting pow'r commend.
   6: 
   7: The shepherd here, from scorching freed,Tunes to thy dancing leaves his reed;Whilst his lov'd nymph, in thanks, bestowsHer flow'ry chaplets on thy boughs.
   8: 
   9: Shall I then only silent be,And no return be made by me?
  10: 
  11: No; let this wish upon thee wait,And still to flourish be thy fate.
  12: 
  13: To future ages may'st thou standUntouch'd by the rash workman's hand,Till that large stock of sap is spent,Which gives thy summer's ornament;Till the fierce winds, that vainly striveTo shock thy greatness whilst alive,Shall on thy lifeless hour attend,Prevent the axe, and grace thy end;Their scatter'd strength together callAnd to the clouds proclaim thy fall;Who then their ev'ning dews may spareWhen thou no longer art their care,But shalt, like ancient heroes, burn,And some bright hearth be made thy urn.

  16: Vnto the blisse of Heven that is eternall.
  17: 
  18: Amen:

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  19: St Cross is a medieval almshouse near Winchester which still provides sheltered accomodation for elderly men, known as Brothers.
  20: 
  21: Henry Beaufort, who re-founded and extended it, was a cardinal and Bishop of Winchester.
  22: 
  23: However, he wasn't born until 1375, so a man who died in 1352 (mcccl and two) could not have been a follower of his.
  24: 
  25: Perhaps it is an error for 1452?

====================================================================================================

Avg prose line length: 72.6

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Everybody, Somebody, Anybody, and Nobody
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: This is a little story about four people named Everybody, Somebody, Anybody, and Nobody.
   4: 
   5: There was an important job to be done and Everybody was sure that Somebody would do it.
   6: 
   7: Anybody could have done it, but Nobody did it.
   8: 
   9: Somebody got angry about that because it was Everybody's job.
  10: 
  11: Everybody thought that Anybody could do it, but Nobody realized that Everybody wouldn't do it.
  12: 
  13: It ended up that Everybody blamed Somebody when Nobody did what Anybody could have done
  14: There are many versions of this popular piece

#278: 89469_Let us go to the woods_British, Anonymous_unknown.txt

Title: Let us go to the woods
Author: British, Anonymous
Prose starts at line: 73
Lines to remove: 7
Avg verse line length: 34.3
Avg prose line length: 111.5

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  68: "We will hire seven cooks," says Richard to Robin,
  69: "We will hire seven cooks," says Robin to Bobbin,
  70: "We will hire seven cooks," says John all alone,
  71: "We will hire seven cooks," says every one.
  72: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  73: There is an old tradition, possibly Celtic, of hunting and capturing a wren on St Stephen's Day (26 December).
  74: 
  75: Originally the wren would have been killed, possibly as a way of banishing winter and bringing back spring.
  76: 
  77: In the few places where this tradition is carried on today a wooden wren is used.
  78: 
  79: This strange, ritual-sounding poem still has humour in it - the cart with six horses and the seven cooks contrasting with the tiny size of the wren.

  13: Had sundry virtues that excused his faults.
  14: 
  15: You that on Bacchus have the like dependance,
  16: Pray copy Bob in measure and attendance.
  17: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  18: Found in the footnotes of Washington Irving's The Sketch-book, Boar's Head Tavern, Eastcheap.
  19: 
  20: 'Adjoining the church, in a small cemetery, immediately under the back window of what was once the Boar's Head, stands the tombstone of Robert Preston, whilom drawer at the tavern.
  21: 
  22: It is now nearly a century since this trusty drawer of good liquor closed his bustling career, and was thus quietly deposited within call of his customers.
  23: 
  24: As I was clearing away the weeds from his epitaph, the little sexton drew me on one side with a mysterious air, and informed me in a low voice, that once upon a time, on a dark wintry night, when the wind was unruly, howling and whistling, banging about doors and windows, and twirling weathercocks, so that the living were frightened out of their beds, and even the dead could not sleep quietly in their graves, the ghost of honest Preston, which happened to be airing itself in the churchyard, was attracted by the well-known call of ''waiter'' from the Boar's Head, and made its sudden appearance in the midst of a roaring club, just as the parish clerk was singing a stave from the ''mirre garland of Captain Death''; to the discomfiture of sundry trainband captains, and the conversion of an infidel attorney, who became a zealous Christian on the spot, and was never known to twist the truth afterwards, except in the way of business.
  25: 
  26: 
  27: honest Preston's epitaph lauds him for the sobriety of his conduct, the soundness of his wine, and the fairness of his measure.

#282: 89509_Leslie's March To Scotland_British, Anonymous_unknown.txt

Title: Leslie's March To Scotland
Author: British, Anonymous
Prose starts at line: 49

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  44: Lousy and lecherous,
  45: Objects of misery, scorning, and laughter;
  46: Never, O happy race!
  47: Magnified so was grace;
  48: Host of the righteous! rush to the slaughter!

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  49: [The hero of this song is the celebrated David Leslie (who is also immortalized in the song called Leslie's March to Longmaston) who commanded a division of the Whig army at the battle of Marston Moor, and contributed so materially to that victory, where the Earl of Leven, who commanded above him, fled.
  50: 
  51: His cruelties in Scotland, after his victory over Montrose and some other successes, must have provoked some of the cavaliers to write these two songs in mockery of him and his army of furious zealots.
  52: 
  53: They are both written to a tune that is well known to have been his favourite march, and to which his troopers always entered or left every town on their route.
  54: 
  55: The March to Scotland is the most perfect thing of the kind to be found in that or any other age; and, wild as some of the expressions are, must be viewed as a great curiosity.
  56: 
  57: It is the very essence of sarcasm and derision, and possesses a spirit and energy for which we may look in vain in any other song existing.
  58: 
  59: ] ~Hogg's Jacobite Relics, vol.
  60: 
  61: i.
  62: 
  63: , p.
  64: 
  65: 163.
  66: 
  67: 1819.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 148: [This poem belongs to a class of publications which have always been peculiar favourites with the peasantry, in whose cottages they may be frequently seen, neatly framed and glazed, and suspended from the white-washed walls.
 149: 
 150: They belong to the school of Quarles, and can be traced to the time when that writer was in the height of his popularity.
 151: 
 152: These religious dialogues are numerous, but the majority of them are very namby-pamby productions, and unworthy of a reprint.
 153: 
 154: The modern editions preserve the old form of the broadside of the seventeenth century, and are adorned with rude woodcuts, probably copies of ruder originals -

#284: 89537_A Chant of Army Cooks_British, Anonymous_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: A Chant of Army Cooks
Author: British, Anonymous
Prose starts at line: 58
Lines to remove: 14
Avg verse line length: 35.9
Avg prose line length: 86.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  53: 
  54: Denison & Company, 1922, p.
  55: 
  56: 66.
  57: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  58: There are many specialist references within this piece that would indicate it was truly written by an old soldier
  59: get a square - On early sailing ships sailors would be served on square wooden plates which were easy to stow away safely.
  60: 
  61: Marine soldiers carried on board ship would pick up the term square meal in this way.
  62: 
  63: Napoleon is famous for saying "an army marches on its stomach"
  64: KP is often thought of as an abbreviation of Kitchen Patrol or Kitchen Punishment and is an oft used military expression for a punishment duty.
  65: 
  66: In this sense police has its old meaning of watching or cleaning.
  67: 
  68: So picking up the KPs means collecting those on this "extra duty"
  69: The use of the word gay is also old fashioned meaning blithe or happy and does not hold its modern sexual meaning here.
  70: 
  71: JS

  20: 
  21:

  90: 
  91: Young's ball, May, 1671.
  92: 
  93: The tune is in Popular Music.
  94: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  95: The May- pole, for so the song is called in modern collections, is a very popular ditty at the present time.
  96: 
  97: The common copies vary considerably from the following version, which is much more correct than any hitherto published.
  98: 
  99: Footnote: {1} The common modern copies read 'St.
 100: 
 101: Leger's Round.
 102: 
 103: Footnote: {2}The common stall copies read 'Pan,' which not only furnishes a more accurate rhyme to 'Nan,' but is, probably, the true reading.
 104: 
 105: About the time when this song was written, there appears to have been some country minstrel or fiddler, who was well known by the sobriquet of 'Pan.
 106: 
 107: ' Frequent allusions to such a personage may be found in popular ditties of the period, and it is evidently that individual, and not the heathen deity, who is referred to in the song of Arthur O'Bradley:-
 108: 'Not Pan, the god of the swains,
 109: Could e'er produce such strains.
 110: 
 111: '--See ante, p.
 112: 
 113: 142.

#290: 89645_Montem Ode, June 9, 1829. -- From Eton College_British, Anonymous_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Montem Ode, June 9, 1829. -- From Eton College
Author: British, Anonymous
Prose starts at line: 186
Lines to remove: 14
Avg verse line length: 25.5
Avg prose line length: 171.3

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 181: Or Tartar, or Hun.
 182: 
 183: Farewell, the world hath been, and must be,
 184: To poets, statesmen, fiddlers, and to me.
 185: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 186: Preceding the poem in Hone's Year Book, is an exhaustive description of the Eton Montem procession, beginning with this explanation, "The origin of this very curious and singular custom, which is triennially celebrated on Whit-Tuesday, is involved in doubt and obscurity.
 187: 
 188: Some suppose that it was coeval with the foundation of Eton college, and that it derives its title from a Monkish procession taking place annually to a small mount (perhaps formerly a Saxon barrow, bear a village, at present situated on the Bath road,) called Salthill;.
 189: 
 190: 
 191: There are copies of doggrel verses distributed on the occasion, and, having fortunately one of the last before me, it is annexed.
 192: 
 193: It will be instantly perceived that there is no attempt at euphuism in them -- the names are those of the Boys in their order in the procession.
 194: 
 195: Proceeding the poem is a little comment, "It must be confessed that, in point of sense -- I had well nigh said nonsense -- this Ode comes up to its subject.
 196: 
 197: Really I am surprised that something better is not produced, considering that one Montem is three years distant from another, and that Eton boys have a reputation for talent, which such a composition tends to falsify.
 198: 
 199: March, 1831.

#291: 89685_Smoking Spiritualized_British, Anonymous_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Smoking Spiritualized
Author: British, Anonymous
Prose starts at line: 133
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 36.6
Avg prose line length: 127.4

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 128: 
 129: He was one of the thirty-three children of Ralph Erskine of Shieldfield, a family of repute descended from the ancient house of Marr.
 130: 
 131: He was educated at the college in Edinburgh, obtained his licence to preach in June, 1709, and was ordained, on an unanimous invitation, over the church at Dunfermline in August, 1711.
 132: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 133: He was twice married: in 1714 to Margaret Dewar, daughter of the Laird of Lassodie, by whom he had five sons and five daughters, all of whom died in the prime of life; and in 1732 to Margaret, daughter of Mr.
 134: 
 135: Simson of Edinburgh, by whom he had four sons, one of whom, with his wife, survived him.
 136: 
 137: He died in November, 1752.
 138: 
 139: Erskine was the author of a great number of Sermons; a Paraphrase on the Canticles; Scripture Songs; a Treatise on Mental Images; and Gospel Sonnets.
 140: 
 141: Smoking Spiritualized is, at the present day, a standard publication with modern ballad-printers, but their copies are exceedingly corrupt.
 142: 
 143: Many versions and paraphrases of the song exist.
 144: 
 145: Several are referred to in Notes and Queries, and, amongst them, a broadside of the date of 1670, and another dated 1672 (both printed before Erskine was born), presenting different readings of the First Part, or original poem.
 146: 
 147: In both these the burthen, or refrain, differs from that of our copy by the employment of the expression 'DRINK tobacco,' instead of 'SMOKE tobacco.
 148: 
 149: ' The former was the ancient term for drawing in the smoke, swallowing it, and emitting it through the nostrils.
 150: 
 151: A correspondent of Notes and Queries says, that the natives of India to this day use the phrase 'hooka peue,' to DRINK the hooka.

 106: [This traditional version of the preceding ancient dialogue has long been popular at country festivals.
 107: 
 108: At a harvest-home feast at Selborne, in Hampshire, in 1836, we heard it recited by two countrymen, who gave it with considerable humour, and dramatic effect.
 109: 
 110: It was delivered in a sort of chant, or recitative.
 111: 
 112: Davies Gilbert published a very similar copy in his Ancient Christmas Carols.
 113: 
 114: In the modern printed editions, which are almost identical with ours, the term 'servantman' has been substituted for the more ancient designation.
 115: 
 116: The alternative title for this ballad is
 117: God Speed The Plow, And Bless The Corn-Mow.

 266:

#294: 89698_Ring a Ring O' Roses_British, Anonymous_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Ring a Ring O' Roses
Author: British, Anonymous
Prose starts at line: 7
Lines to remove: 11
Avg verse line length: 19.6
Avg prose line length: 128.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   2: 
   3: Ring a Ring O' Roses,
   4: A pocketful of posies,
   5: Atishoo!  Atishoo!
   6: We all fall down!

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   7: It is sometimes suggested that the rhyme relates to the Black Death - the bubonic plague that spread through Europe in the 1340s, or to the Great Plague of London, 1665/6.
   8: 
   9: The plausible-sounding theory has it that the 'ring' is the ring of sores around the mouths of plague victims, who subsequently sneeze and fall down dead.
  10: 
  11: However the victims of the bubonic plague suffered swellings (or bubos) in their groins or armpits and not mouth sores or sneezing.
  12: 
  13: The earliest written reference seems to be in Kate Greenaways book "Mother Goose" of 1881 The picture is taken from that book.
  14: 
  15: However there are other references to similar verses over the previous hundred years though they mostly talk of bowing down and springing up, which the plague victims certainly did not.
  16: 
  17: JS


====================================================================================================
#295: 89895_from The Nerve Meter_Artaud, Antonin_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: from The Nerve Meter
Author: Artaud, Antonin
Prose starts at line: 36
Lines to remove: 15
Avg verse line length: 80.8
Avg prose line length: 132.1

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  31: 
  32: This dialogue in thought.
  33: 
  34: The ingestion, the breaking off of everything.
  35: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  36: And all at once this trickle of water on a volcano, the thin, slow falling of the mind.
  37: 
  38: To find oneself again in a state of extreme shock, clarified by unreality, with, in a corner of oneself, some fragments of the real world.
  39: 
  40: To think without the slightest breaking off, without pitfalls in my thought, without one of those sudden disappearances to which my marrow is accustomed as a transmitter of currents.
  41: 
  42: My marrow is sometimes amused by these games, sometimes takes pleasure in these games, takes pleasure in these furtive abductions over which the sense of my thought presides.
  43: 
  44: At times all I would need is a single word, a simple little word of no importance, to be great, to speak in the voice of the prophets: a word of witness, a precise word, a subtle word, a word well steeped in my marrow, gone out of me, which would stand at the outer limit of my being,
  45: and which, for everyone else, would be nothing.
  46: 
  47: I am the witness, I am the only witness of myself.
  48: 
  49: This crust of words, these imperceptible whispered transformations of my thought, of that small part of my thought which I claim has already been formulated, and which miscarries,
  50: I am the only person who can measure its extent.


====================================================================================================

  21:

  30: 
  31: For Grammar says (O this dear Stella weigh,)
  32: 
  33: For Grammar says (to Grammar who says nay) That in one speech two Negatives affirm.

   1: Astrophil and Stella 101: Stella is sick, and in that sick-bed lies
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: Stella is sick, and in that sick-bed lies Sweetness, that breathes and pants as oft as she; And grace, sick too, such fine conclusions tries That sickness brags itself best graced to be.
   4: 
   5: Beauty is sick, but sick in so fair guise That in that paleness beauty’s white we see; And joy, which is inseparate from these eyes, Stella now learns (strange case!) to weep in thee.
   6: 
   7: Love moves thy pain, and like a faithful page, As thy looks stir, runs up and down, to make All folks prest at thy will thy pain to assuage; Nature with care sweats for her darling’s sake,
   8: 
   9: Knowing worlds pass, ere she enough can find
  10: 
  11: Of such heaven stuff, to clothe so heavenly mind.

   4:

   6:

   7: But thorns of roses  spring and seize the surface  of  fey airs  before the roses come.
   8: 
   9: I’ve seen thorns huddle in a harmony alone, hunkered down on green, wiry canes,  smoothed blades of whipping rose stalks,  and curl their polished tridents  to night’s call.
  10: 
  11: They are like stars  digging into firmament  with such desire, you don’t quite get it,  and so healthy that  they almost have to wound,  or like bodies that can’t be argued,  borrowed, tamed.
  12: 
  13: The touch of a thorn  is a wry, deep telling  of the senses not to bloom without a wish to,  without belief  in pain  to hold us true.

#300: 91988_Lucy Gray [or Solitude]_Wordsworth, William_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Lucy Gray [or Solitude]
Author: Wordsworth, William
Prose starts at line: 88
Lines to remove: 9
Avg verse line length: 30.1
Avg prose line length: 172.4

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  83: 
  84: found
  85: He wrote
  86: Written at Goslar in Germany.
  87: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  88: It was founded on a circumstance told me by my Sister, of a little girl who, not far from Halifax in Yorkshire, was bewildered in a snow-storm.
  89: 
  90: Her footsteps were traced by her parents to the middle of the lock of a canal, and no other vestige of her, backward or forward, could be traced.
  91: 
  92: The body however was found in the canal.
  93: 
  94: The way in which the incident was treated and the spiritualising of the character might furnish hints for contrasting the imaginative influences which I have endeavoured to throw over common life with Crabbe's matter of fact style of treating subjects of the same kind.
  95: 
  96: This is not spoken to his disparagement, far from it, but to direct the attention of thoughtful readers, into whose hands these notes may fall, to a comparison that may both enlarge the circle of their sensibilities, and tend to produce in them a catholic judgment.

   1: The Order In Which Things Are Broken
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: Ancients threw the masks down the cenote—the faces smashed first in little ways before the long drop, an eye or an ear broken, a mouth snapped in half.
   4: 
   5: Then, lifted from the well, two thousand years later, still grinning and golden.
   6: 
   7: The loose spooling of two people fast unravels—how we let go of time spent, how heat fades, how a body forgets fully what it knew.
   8: 
   9: I have learned your face as you will never.
  10: 
  11: The third day we met you gave me all your secrets until I held an ocean in a cradle.
  12: 
  13: Now all I ask for is more.

   4: 
   5: Scepter and crown
   6: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   7: Must tumble down And in the dust be equal made With the poor crooked scythe and spade.
   8:

  10: 
  11: Early or late
  12: 
  13: They stoop to fate And must give up their murmuring breath, When they, pale captives, creep to death.
  14: 
  15: The garlands wither on your brow, Then boast no more your mighty deeds; Upon death’s purple altar now See where the victor-victim bleeds.
  16: 
  17: Your heads must come
  18: 
  19: To the cold tomb; Only the actions of the just Smell sweet and blossom in their dust.

#303: 92068_Deer's Cry or St. Patrick's Breastplate_Patrick, Saint_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Deer's Cry or St. Patrick's Breastplate
Author: Patrick, Saint
Prose starts at line: 81
Lines to remove: 9
Avg verse line length: 32.9
Avg prose line length: 139.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  76: Eternal Father, Spirit, Word.
  77: 
  78: Praise to the Lord of my salvation:
  79: Salvation is of Christ the Lord.
  80: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  81: The coming of Patrick to Ireland about the middle of the fifth century initiated the "most peaceful invasion and lasting conquest of all".
  82: 
  83: It is believed that Patrick wrote this hymn as a corslet of faith for the protection of body and soul against all forms of evil -- devils, vice, and the evil which humans perpetrate against one another.
  84: 
  85: Legend has it that the High King of Tara, Loeguire resolved to ambush and kill Patrick and his monks to prevent them from spreading the Christian faith in his kingdom.
  86: 
  87: As Patrick and his followers approached singing this hymn, the King and his men saw only a herd of wild deer and let them pass by.
  88: 
  89: The word 'cry' also has the sense of a prayer or petition.

 110: 
 111: It was here that, in 1687, the Marquis de Nouvellé fought his famous battle with the Seneca Indians.
 112: 
 113: The word 'Swan-ne-ho-out' refers to the position of the Senecas in the Confederacy of the Iriquois.
 114: 
 115: 'Na-do-wa' is the title by which the Five Nations were known to the tribes of Algonquin stock.

  10: 
  11: I say this slowly, as if unaffected:their apartment quiet, on the floor, dirty water from their boots.

   3: When the fog slunk in with that salivary,  close, coyote panting, its hue a very  huelessness, like breath huffed on a glass,  like the void stretched and still stretching past  where we’d thought it could, we felt less wary.
   4: 
   5: We felt our shoulders loosen, surrendering  to phantom hands and softly vanished feet.
   6: 
   7: The sensation was a first and last: sweet  to feel the vigilance at last suspending,  the chronic stress of constantly pretending  to know—have known!—what all the others knew.
   8: 
   9: Loopy, sly, we leered at one another  (what we just assumed was one another)  and did the things we weren’t supposed to do,  grinning as if seated in the back pew  of a church that worshipped fuss and bother,  a dour church where facial expression
  10: 
  11: of any kind had been prohibited,  and where the chinking, hefty plate we shifted  hand to hand held such a vast collection  of their coin, we pocketed a fraction  for when the fog would lift, if it lifted.
  12: 
  13: But stealing from them puts you in their power.
  14: 
  15: Since then we have been paying for that hour.

#308: 94045_fromThe Sleepers_Whitman, Walt_unknown.txt

Title: fromThe Sleepers
Author: Whitman, Walt
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 16
Avg verse line length: 16.0
Avg prose line length: 66.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: fromThe Sleepers
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: I see a beautiful gigantic swimmer swimming naked through the eddies of the sea,
   4: His brown hair lies close and even to his head, he strikes out with courageous arms, he urges himself with his legs,
   5: I see his white body, I see his undaunted eyes,
   6: I hate the swift-running eddies that would dash him head-foremost on the rocks.
   7: 
   8: What are you doing you ruffianly red-trickled waves?
   9: 
  10: Will you kill the courageous giant?
  11: 
  12: will you kill him in the prime of his middle-age?
  13: 
  14: Steady and long he struggles,
  15: He is baffled, bang’d, bruis’d, he holds out while his strength holds out,
  16: The slapping eddies are spotted with his blood, they bear him away, they roll him, swing him, turn him,
  17: His beautiful body is borne in the circling eddies, it is continually bruis’d on rocks,
  18: Swiftly and out of sight is borne the brave corpse.

#309: 94070_Song Of Myself, XLI_Whitman, Walt_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Song Of Myself, XLI
Author: Whitman, Walt
Prose starts at line: 19
Lines to remove: 20
Avg verse line length: 52.0
Avg prose line length: 81.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  14: Buying drafts of Osiris, Isis, Belus, Brahma, Buddha,
  15: In my portfolio placing Manito loose, Allah on a leaf, the crucifix engraved,
  16: With Odin and the hideous-faced Mexitli and every idol and image,
  17: Taking them all for what they are worth and not a cent more,
  18: Admitting they were alive and did the work of their days,

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  19: (They bore mites as for unfledg'd birds who have now to rise and fly and sing for themselves,)
  20: Accepting the rough deific sketches to fill out better in myself, bestowing them freely on each man and woman I see,
  21: Discovering as much or more in a framer framing a house,
  22: Putting higher claims for him there with his roll'd-up sleeves driving the mallet and chisel,
  23: Not objecting to special revelations, considering a curl of smoke
  24: or a hair on the back of my hand just as curious as any revelation,
  25: Lads ahold of fire-engines and hook-and-ladder ropes no less to me than the gods of the antique wars,
  26: Minding their voices peal through the crash of destruction,
  27: Their brawny limbs passing safe over charr'd laths, their white foreheads whole and unhurt out of the flames;
  28: By the mechanic's wife with her babe at her nipple interceding for every person born,
  29: Three scythes at harvest whizzing in a row from three lusty angels with shirts bagg'd out at their waists,
  30: The snag-tooth'd hostler with red hair redeeming sins past and to come,
  31: Selling all he possesses, traveling on foot to fee lawyers for his brother and sit by him while he is tried for forgery;
  32: What was strewn in the amplest strewing the square rod about me, and not filling the square rod then,
  33: The bull and the bug never worshipp'd half enough,
  34: Dung and dirt more admirable than was dream'd,
  35: The supernatural of no account, myself waiting my time to be one of the supremes,
  36: The day getting ready for me when I shall do as much good as the best, and be as prodigious;
  37: By my life-lumps! becoming already a creator,
  38: Putting myself here and now to the ambush'd womb of the shadows.


====================================================================================================
#310: 94072_Song Of Myself, XXXVI_Whitman, Walt_unknown.txt

Title: Song Of Myself, XXXVI
Author: Whitman, Walt
Prose starts at line: 5

Avg verse line length: 38.7
Avg prose line length: 74.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Song Of Myself, XXXVI
   2: 
   3: Stretch'd and still lies the midnight,
   4: Two great hulls motionless on the breast of the darkness,

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   5: Our vessel riddled and slowly sinking, preparations to pass to the one we have conquer'd,
   6: The captain on the quarter-deck coldly giving his orders through a countenance white as a sheet,
   7: Near by the corpse of the child that serv'd in the cabin,
   8: The dead face of an old salt with long white hair and carefully curl'd whiskers,
   9: The flames spite of all that can be done flickering aloft and below,
  10: The husky voices of the two or three officers yet fit for duty,
  11: Formless stacks of bodies and bodies by themselves, dabs of flesh upon the masts and spars,
  12: Cut of cordage, dangle of rigging, slight shock of the soothe of waves,
  13: Black and impassive guns, litter of powder-parcels, strong scent,
  14: A few large stars overhead, silent and mournful shining,
  15: Delicate sniffs of sea-breeze, smells of sedgy grass and fields by the shore, death-messages given in charge to survivors,
  16: The hiss of the surgeon's knife, the gnawing teeth of his saw,
  17: Wheeze, cluck, swash of falling blood, short wild scream, and long, dull, tapering groan,
  18: These so, these irretrievable.
