#311: 94161_When I Heard at the Close of the Day_Whitman, Walt_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: When I Heard at the Close of the Day
Author: Whitman, Walt
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 13
Avg verse line length: 36.0
Avg prose line length: 95.6

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: When I Heard at the Close of the Day
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: When I heard at the close of the day how my name had been receiv’d with plaudits in the capitol, still it was not a happy night for me that follow’d,
   4: And else when I carous’d, or when my plans were accomplish’d, still I was not happy,
   5: But the day when I rose at dawn from the bed of perfect health, refresh’d, singing, inhaling the ripe breath of autumn,
   6: When I saw the full moon in the west grow pale and disappear in the morning light,
   7: When I wander’d alone over the beach, and undressing bathed, laughing with the cool waters, and saw the sun rise,
   8: And when I thought how my dear friend my lover was on his way coming, O then I was happy,
   9: O then each breath tasted sweeter, and all that day my food nourish’d me more, and the beautiful day pass’d well,
  10: And the next came with equal joy, and with the next at evening came my friend,
  11: And that night while all was still I heard the waters roll slowly continually up the shores,
  12: I heard the hissing rustle of the liquid and sands as directed to me whispering to congratulate me,
  13: For the one I love most lay sleeping by me under the same cover in the cool night,
  14: In the stillness in the autumn moonbeams his face was inclined toward me,
  15: And his arm lay lightly around my breast – and that night I was happy.


====================================================================================================

#313: 94252_Song Of Myself, XXXVII_Whitman, Walt_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Song Of Myself, XXXVII
Author: Whitman, Walt
Prose starts at line: 12
Lines to remove: 10
Avg verse line length: 46.0
Avg prose line length: 71.7

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   7: And feel the dull unintermitted pain.
   8: 
   9: For me the keepers of convicts shoulder their carbines and keep watch,
  10: It is I let out in the morning and barr'd at night.
  11: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  12: Not a mutineer walks handcuff'd to jail but I am handcuff'd to him and walk by his side,
  13: (I am less the jolly one there, and more the silent one with sweat on my twitching lips.
  14: 
  15: Not a youngster is taken for larceny but I go up too, and am tried and sentenced.
  16: 
  17: Not a cholera patient lies at the last gasp but I also lie at the last gasp,
  18: My face is ash-color'd, my sinews gnarl, away from me people retreat.
  19: 
  20: Askers embody themselves in me and I am embodied in them,
  21: I project my hat, sit shame-faced, and beg.


====================================================================================================
#314: 94261_The World Below the Brine_Whitman, Walt_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The World Below the Brine
Author: Whitman, Walt
Prose starts at line: 5
Lines to remove: 9
Avg verse line length: 36.3
Avg prose line length: 94.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: The World Below the Brine
   2: 
   3: The world below the brine,
   4: Forests at the bottom of the sea, the branches and leaves,

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   5: Sea-lettuce, vast lichens, strange flowers and seeds, the thick tangle, openings, and pink turf,
   6: Different colors, pale gray and green, purple, white, and gold, the play of light through the water,
   7: Dumb swimmers there among the rocks, coral, gluten, grass, rushes, and the aliment of the swimmers,
   8: Sluggish existences grazing there suspended, or slowly crawling close to the bottom,
   9: The sperm-whale at the surface blowing air and spray, or disporting with his flukes,
  10: The leaden-eyed shark, the walrus, the turtle, the hairy sea-leopard, and the sting-ray,
  11: Passions there, wars, pursuits, tribes, sight in those ocean-depths, breathing that thick-breathing air, as so many do,
  12: The change thence to the sight here, and to the subtle air breathed by beings like us who walk this sphere,
  13: The change onward from ours to that of beings who walk other spheres.


====================================================================================================
#315: 94276_Song Of Myself, XXXVIII_Whitman, Walt_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Song Of Myself, XXXVIII
Author: Whitman, Walt
Prose starts at line: 11
Lines to remove: 15
Avg verse line length: 35.6
Avg prose line length: 57.5

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   6: Stand back!
   7: Give me a little time beyond my cuff'd head, slumbers, dreams, gaping,
   8: I discover myself on the verge of a usual mistake.
   9: 
  10: That I could forget the mockers and insults!

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  11: That I could forget the trickling tears and the blows of the bludg- eons and hammers!
  12: That I could look with a separate look on my own crucifixion and bloody crowning.
  13: 
  14: I remember now,
  15: I resume the overstaid fraction,
  16: The grave of rock multiplies what has been confided to it, or to any graves,
  17: Corpses rise, gashes heal, fastenings roll from me.
  18: 
  19: I troop forth replenish'd with supreme power, one of an average unending procession,
  20: Inland and sea-coast we go, and pass all boundary lines,
  21: Our swift ordinances on their way over the whole earth,
  22: The blossoms we wear in our hats the growth of thousands of years.
  23: 
  24: Eleves, I salute you! come forward!
  25: Continue your annotations, continue your questionings.

#316: 94278_Kosmos_Whitman, Walt_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Kosmos
Author: Whitman, Walt
Prose starts at line: 4
Lines to remove: 10
Avg verse line length: 21.5
Avg prose line length: 98.5

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Kosmos
   2: 
   3: Who includes diversity and is Nature,

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   4: Who is the amplitude of the earth, and the coarseness and sexuality of the earth, and the great charity of the earth and the equilibrium also,
   5: Who has not look’d forth from the windows the eyes for nothing, or whose brain held audience with messengers for nothing,
   6: Who contains believers and disbelievers, who is the most majestic lover,
   7: Who holds duly his or her triune proportion of realism, spiritualism, and of the æsthetic or intellectual,
   8: Who having consider’d the body finds all its organs and parts good,
   9: Who, out of the theory of the earth and of his or her body understands by subtle analogies all other theories,
  10: The theory of a city, a poem, and of the large politics of these States;
  11: Who believes not only in our globe with its sun and moon, but in other globes with their suns and moons,
  12: Who, constructing the house of himself or herself, not for a day but for all time, sees races, eras, dates, generations,
  13: The past, the future, dwelling there, like space, inseparable together.


====================================================================================================
#317: 94306_Virginia--The West_Whitman, Walt_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Virginia--The West
Author: Whitman, Walt
Prose starts at line: 20
Lines to remove: 9
Avg verse line length: 52.2
Avg prose line length: 180.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  15: 
  16: When you yourself forever provide to defend me?
  17: 
  18: For you provided me Washington -- and now these also.
  19: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  20: Written 12 years after the conclusion of the War, Whitman's poem expresses the anguish felt by many when Virginia ("the noble sire") left the Union ("the Mother of All") and cast her lot with the Confederacy.
  21: 
  22: Virginia had always prided herself on being "the mother of states and statesman.
  23: 
  24: " Not only had she provided many of the most prominent political leaders and military men of the Revolutionary War era, but many of those who moved further west as the new nation expanded its borders could boast of roots in the Old Dominion as well.
  25: 
  26: Whitman's poem points out the folly of Virginia's rebelling against a government and a country that she herself had done so much to establish.
  27: 
  28: Those who came from Ohio, Indiana, and other Midwestern states to join the Union Army were, in a sense, returning to bear arms against the one who had sent them forth to begin with -- an irony that was not lost on Whitman.


====================================================================================================
#318: 94374_One Shies at the Prospect of Raising Yet Another Defense of Cannibalism_Bell, Josh_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: One Shies at the Prospect of Raising Yet Another Defense of Cannibalism
Author: Bell, Josh
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 13
Avg verse line length: 71.0
Avg prose line length: 213.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: One Shies at the Prospect of Raising Yet Another Defense of Cannibalism
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: “You can’t kiss a movie,” Jean-Luc Godard said, and this is mostly true, in that you cannot initiate the kiss.
   4: 
   5: The Movie could initiate the kiss if The Movie wanted, as it is so much taller, leaning in, no way to demur, you would be too polite anyway, and, as the Roman poets have stressed, there is always something porous in the decorous.
   6: 
   7: So there can be kissing between you and The Movie, and it would be amazing, better the more incoherent The Movie is and the more you had to pay to see it, though in the movies it is said that prostitutes don’t like to kiss as kissing is too personal, though I disagree, as sometimes the human will make a show of locating you with a kiss, almost to prove to you that you are a real person with a face and that, absolutely, they know where the face is and the face isn’t, and this is how you know, for sure, that both of you have been paid.
   8: 
   9: But I don’t want to make you feel bad here, and I apologize, for you are entirely kissable, as I have watched you through windows and keyholes even though, up to this point, you do not appear in movies.
  10: 
  11: Often you appear holding a book in your hand and with God knows what playing in your head––I imagine you repeating to yourself, over and again, “the horse knows the way, the horse knows the way”––and remember: even someone as learned in film as Jean-Luc Godard got it a little wrong.
  12: 
  13: Youcankiss The Movie, if The Movie wants to kiss you.
  14: 
  15: It’s just that The Movie, finally, isn’t all that interested in your mouth.

   5: Then the Count began afresh: My lords, he said, I am not pleased with the young man if he is not also a musician, and if, besides his cunning upon the book, he have not skill in like manner on sundry instruments.
   6: 
   7: There is no ease of labor more honest and more praiseworthy, especially at court, where many things are taken in hand to please women, whose tender breasts are soon pierced with melody.
   8: 
   9: Then the Lord Gasper: I believe music, he said, together with other vanities, is mete for women, also for them that have the likeness of men, but not for them that be men indeed, who ought not with such delicacies womanize their minds and so bring themselves to dread death.
  10: 
  11: — The First Booke of the Courtyer of Count Baldessar Castilio

   3: Blacksmithing demonstration, mountain arts and crafts fair, Monteagle, TN
   4: 
   5: 
   6: “But can you forge a nail?
   7: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   8: ” the blond boy asks,And the blacksmith shoves a length of  iron rodDeep in the coal fire cherished by the bellowsUntil it glows volcanic.
   9: 
  10: He was a godBefore anachronism, before the tasksThat had been craft were jobbed out to machine.
  11: 
  12: By dint of   hammer-song he makes his keen,Raw point, and crowns utility with rose:Quincunx of facets petaling its head.
  13: 
  14: The breeze-made-visible sidewinds.
  15: 
  16: The boy’sBlonde mother shifts and coughs.
  17: 
  18: Once Work was wedTo Loveliness — sweat-faced, swarthy from soot, heReminds us with the old saw he employs(And doesn’t miss a beat): “Smoke follows beauty.

#321: 94862_Actaeon_Stallings, A E_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Actaeon
Author: Stallings, A E
Prose starts at line: 5
Lines to remove: 7
Avg verse line length: 22.5
Avg prose line length: 174.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Actaeon
   2: 
   3: The hounds, you know them all by name.
   4: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   5: You fostered them from purblind whelps At their dam’s teats, and you have come To know the music of their yelps: High-strung Anthee, the brindled bitch, The blue-tick coated Philomel, And freckled Chloe, who would fetch A pretty price if you would sell— All fleet of foot, and swift to scent, Inexorable once on the track, Like angry words you might have meant, But do not mean, and can’t take back.
   6: 
   7: There was a time when you would brag How they would bay and rend apart The hopeless belling from a stag.
   8: 
   9: You falter now for the foundered hart.
  10: 
  11: Desires you nursed of a winter night— Did you know then why you bred them— Whose needling milk-teeth used to bite The master’s hand that leashed and fed them?

#322: 94864_Two Violins_Stallings, A E_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Two Violins
Author: Stallings, A E
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 9
Avg verse line length: 11.0
Avg prose line length: 159.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Two Violins
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: One was fire red,   Hand carved and new— The local maker pried the wood From a torn-down church's pew, The Devil's instrument Wrenched from the house of God.
   4: 
   5: It answered merrily and clear Though my fingering was flawed; Bright and sharp as a young wine, They said, but it would mellow, And that I would grow into it.
   6: 
   7: The other one was yellow And nicked down at the chin, A varnish of Baltic amber, A one-piece back of tiger maple And a low, dark timbre.
   8: 
   9: A century old, they said, Its sound will never change.
  10: 
  11: Rich and deep on G and D, Thin on the upper range, And how it came from the Old World Was anybody's guess— Light as an exile's suitcase, A belly of emptiness: That was the one I chose (Not the one of flame)   And teachers would turn in their practiced hands To see whence the sad notes came.

   8:

  10: 
  11: Why do you resist?
  12: 
  13: When will you learn That this is what your weary dreams are of— Succumbing to Her unconditional love?

#324: 94877_Written on the eve of my 20th high school reunion, which I was not able to atten_Stallings, A E_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Written on the eve of my 20th high school reunion, which I was not able to attend
Author: Stallings, A E
Prose starts at line: 11
Lines to remove: 9
Avg verse line length: 62.5
Avg prose line length: 247.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   6: 
   7: 
   8: 
   9: 
  10: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  11: Just what I needed, Just when the dreams had almost totally receded, The dreams of roles for which I learned no lines and knew no cues, Dreams of pop quizzes with no pants on and no shoes, Just when I understood I was no longer among Those ephemeral immortals, the gauche and pitiable young, Suddenly come phone calls, messages sift out of the air To ask who will be there: Names I haven't given a thought to in a score (A score!) of years, and names I used to think about but don't much anymore, And those I think of all the time and yet Have lost somehow like keys to doors I've closed, and some I have tried to forget— And some who will never arrive at this date Here in the distant future where we wait Still surprised at how We carry with us the omnipresent and ever-changing now.
  12: 
  13: We wince at what we used to wear, Fashion has made ridiculous the high hubris of our hair.
  14: 
  15: Heartbreak, looked at through the wrong end of distance's glasses, Is trivial, and quickly passes, Its purity embarrasses us, its lust, The way we wept because it was unjust.
  16: 
  17: Why should we travel back, who've come so far— We know who we are.
  18: 
  19: How can we be the same As those quaint ancestors we have left behind, who share our name— Why have we inherited their shame?

#325: 94878_Sestina- Like_Stallings, A E_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Sestina: Like
Author: Stallings, A E
Prose starts at line: 37
Lines to remove: 17
Avg verse line length: 47.5
Avg prose line length: 95.9

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  32: Whatever.
  33: 
  34: I’m all like .
  35: 
  36: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  37: ” Take “like” out of our chat, we’d all alike Flounder, agape, gesticulating like A foreign film sans subtitles, fall like Dumb phones to mooted desuetude.
  38: 
  39: Unlike With other crutches, um, when we use “like,” We’re not just buying time on credit: Like Displaces other words; crowds, cuckoo-like, Endangered hatchlings from the nest.
  40: 
  41: (Click “like” If you’re against extinction!) Like is like Invasive zebra mussels, or it’s like Those nutria-things, or kudzu, or belike Redundant fast food franchises, each like (More like) the next.
  42: 
  43: Those poets who dislike Inversions, archaisms, who just like Plain English as she’s spoke — why isn’t “like” Their (literally) every other word?
  44: 
  45: I’d like Us just to admit that’s what real speech is like.
  46: 
  47: But as you like, my friend.
  48: 
  49: Yes, we’re alike, How we pronounce, say, lichen, and dislike Cancer and war.
  50: 
  51: So like this page.
  52: 
  53: Click Like.

#326: 95114_I WANT SKY_Bazeed_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: I WANT SKY
Author: Bazeed
Prose starts at line: 103
Lines to remove: 20
Avg verse line length: 36.4
Avg prose line length: 103.1

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  98: ​​​​​​​     ​​​​​​​​​​​​​​     ​​​​​​​​​​​​​​     ​​​​​​​I am a sapling old enough to cast a shadow—
  99: ​​​​​​​     ​​​​​​​​​​​​​​     ​​​​​​​​​​​​​​     ​​​​​​​I am the tree pulling sap up my body to nourish sprouting leaves for spring—
 100: ​​​​​​​     ​​​​​​​​​​​​​​     ​​​​​​​​​​​​​​I am flowing water—
 101: ​​​​​​​     ​​​​​​​​​​​​​​     ​​​​​​​​​​​​​​I am a community garden overrun by aphids in bloom—
 102: ​​​​​​​    ​​​​​​​​​​​one day I decay and the next I am the moon

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 103: ​​​​​​​     ​​​​​​​​​​​​​​     ​​​​​​​​​​​​​​I am mountain my tears flow from bare stone—
 104: ​​​​​​​     ​​​​​​​​​​​​​​     ​​​​​​​​​​​​​​     ​​​​​​​My body is rock and dust—
 105: ​​​​​​​     ​​​​​​​​​​​​​​     ​​​​​​​​​​​​​​I am ascendant—
 106: 
 107: 
 108: ​​​​​​​     ​​​​​​​​​​​​​​     ​​​​​​​​​​​​​​The sky I want is blue.
 109: 
 110: ​​​​​​​A Note:
 111: 
 112: This cento features at least one line from every writer whose work appears inI Want Sky, a journal the author edited celebrating Sarah Hegazy and queer SWANA life, edited by Bazeed and co-published in 2021 by the Asian American Writers Workshop and Mizna.
 113: 
 114: To name and thank them for words ripe for stealing: ’mad, AMA, Amir Ferdjani, Banah elGhadbanah, donia salemharhoor, Eman Desouky, Gamal ElSawah, Ghinwa Jawhari, Janine Mogannam, Kamelya Omayma Youssef, Layla Zbinden, Mejdulene B.
 115: 
 116: Shomali, Mish Ismy, Nada Almosa, Niki Afsar, Nour Kamel, Nusaiba Imady, Qais Kamran, Shiyam Galyon, and Walid Daou.
 117: 
 118: The lines of Arabic that appear in the cento are either immediately preceded or followed by Bazeed’stranslation into English.
 119: 
 120: The title of the poem,and the eponymous journal from which its lines are sourced, is borrowed from the last sentence in Sarah’s suicide note, translated from the Arabic:
 121: أنا عاوزه السما
 122: أنا عاوزه السما

#327: 95115_from “Origins of Poetry”_Lipman, Joel_unknown.txt

Title: from “Origins of Poetry”
Author: Lipman, Joel
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 9
Avg verse line length: 24.0
Avg prose line length: 88.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: from “Origins of Poetry”
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: Joel Lipman has worked for years with rubber stamps, creating poems on yellowing acidic pages torn out of old books.
   4: 
   5: This technique produces a frisson between the apparently unrelated base text and Lipman's overtext.
   6: 
   7: As evidenced by the meter and movement of the words on the page above, it is clear that Lipman is writing real poetry, but it is poetry enhanced by the distinctive appearance of the words.
   8: 
   9: —Geof Huth
  10: 
  11: More About Visual Poetry >>

#328: 95335_from Don't Let Me Be Lonely- “There is a button on the remote control called FAV_Rankine, Claudia_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: from Don't Let Me Be Lonely: “There is a button on the remote control called FAV...”
Author: Rankine, Claudia
Prose starts at line: 25
Lines to remove: 11
Avg verse line length: 57.9
Avg prose line length: 120.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  20: 
  21: Where?
  22: 
  23: Not going to make it where?
  24: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  25: On some level, maybe, the phrase simply means not going to make it into the next day, hour, minute, or perhaps the next second.
  26: 
  27: Occasionally, you can imagine, it means he is not going to make it to Carson City or Texas or somewhere else out west or to Mexico if he is on the run.
  28: 
  29: On another level always implicit is the sense that it means he is not going to make it to his own death.
  30: 
  31: Perhaps in the back of all our minds is the life expectancy for our generation.
  32: 
  33: Perhaps this expectation lingers there alongside the hours of sleep one should get or the number of times one is meant to chew food—eight hours, twenty chews, and seventy-six years.
  34: 
  35: We are all heading there and not to have that birthday is not to have made it.


====================================================================================================
#329: 95337_Don't Let Me Be Lonely- “A father tells his son the thing he regrets most about _Rankine, Claudia_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Don't Let Me Be Lonely: “A father tells his son the thing he regrets most about his life...”
Author: Rankine, Claudia
Prose starts at line: 35
Lines to remove: 13
Avg verse line length: 67.4
Avg prose line length: 101.1

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  30: 
  31: Give way to anxiety, unease, or disquietude: allow one’s mind to dwell on difficulties or troubles.
  32: 
  33: He waits for his father’s death.
  34: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  35: His father has been taken off the ventilator and clearly will not be able to breathe for himself much longer.
  36: 
  37: Earlier in the day the nurse mentioned something about an electroencephalogram (EEG), which measures brain waves in the cerebral hemispheres, the parts of the brain that deal with speech and memory.
  38: 
  39: But his brain stem is damaged; it seems now the test will not be necessary.
  40: 
  41: The son expects an almost silent, hollow gasp to come from the old man’s open mouth.
  42: 
  43: Those final sounds, however, are nothing like the wind moving through the vacancy of a mind.
  44: 
  45: The release is jerky and convulsive.
  46: 
  47: There is never the rasp or the choke the son expects, though one meaning of worry is to be choked on, to choke on.

#332: 95343_from Don't Let Me Be Lonely- “I don't usually talk to strangers...”_Rankine, Claudia_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: from  Don't Let Me Be Lonely: “I don't usually talk to strangers...”
Author: Rankine, Claudia
Prose starts at line: 21
Lines to remove: 7
Avg verse line length: 56.4
Avg prose line length: 241.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  16: 
  17: I don't respond.
  18: 
  19: Hers is an Operation Iraqi Freedom answer.
  20: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  21: The war is on and the Department of Homeland Security has decided we have an elevated national-threat level, a code-orange alert.
  22: 
  23: I could say something, but my packages are getting heavier by the minute and besides, what is there to say since rhetorically it's not about our oil under their sand but about freeing Iraqis from Iraqis and Osama is Saddam and Saddam is “that man who tried to kill my father” and the weapons of mass destruction are, well, invisible and Afghanistan is Iraq and Iraq is Syria and we see ourselves only through our own eyes and the British, but not the French, and Germany won't and Turkey won't join us but the coalition is inside Baghdad where the future is the threat the Americans feel they can escape though there is no escaping the Americans because war, this war, is about peace: “The war in Iraq is really about peace.
  24: 
  25: Trying to make the world more peaceful.
  26:

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Two Traveling Together
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: I came to encounter a coyoteI left all sorts of things behindYou couldn’t get on a plane unless you traveled lightBack then there were weight restrictions for planes, they don’t have them any longer, American bodies have no restrictions, they’ve become so big that there aren’t restrictions on the weight of bodies or luggage any more, but back then, I can’t even count how many times I picked up my bags and stepped on the scale, no matter how many times I weighed myself, I still wasn’t the least bit lighterNot knowing what else to do, I took out my booksThen I took out my clothesThen I went to the bathroom and defecatedThen I took out more clothesThen I threw upThen I took out more booksThen I stripped off all my clothes, held my bag, and stood on the scale, but I wasn’t the least bit lighterKnow what I mean?
   4: 
   5: That’s what it means to go on a tripThat’s what it means to leave the place where you liveTrips and then more tripsThere are things you need to carry with you to surviveNot knowing what else to do, I called my husband, filed for divorce, talked to my children and told them Mommy wouldn’t be home for a while, in other words, it was only after I abandoned my relationships, my attachments, and even my language that I was light enough to get on the plane, when I arrived, all I had was a few changes of clothes, some cash, my passport, my visa waiver, my credit cards, and an  international driver’s licenseIn California, the sky was blue, there was nothing but seashore, wild land, and housing developments, it was hazy and hard to see in the evenings, it was as if everything was immersed in mother’s milk, my toes got cold, I bought some socks, but after wearing them three days, the cheap things were ready to fall apart, I looked long and hard at them, feeling like a coyote(Yeah, I tell people I came aloneBut that is not entirely trueI was always thinking about the coyoteThe two of us traveling together)I saw dead raccoonsI saw dead skunksI smelled them tooSomeone I met the first day said to meThe whole place smells like skunk, must be a dead one somewhereIt was an unfamiliar scent, but now I know it wellThe whole place smells like skunk, must be a dead one somewhereI know to say that to people nowIn any case, I didn’t seeAny coyotes(Two traveling together)Someone in the streetTold me to get the hell out of hereWhy had I come?
   6: 
   7: I couldn’t find what I wanted, I had come so far but,get the hell out, this isn’t the place where the coyotes are, they’re farther away, in deeper places, where there is nothing, where there is much more emptinessSo I headed eastFrom the western edge of the continent to the eastThe interstatesWith odd numbers run north and southWhile even numbers run east and westThose in the 500s are the bypasses for I-5 (north-south)Those in the 800s are the bypasses for I-8 (east-west)I took I-5 south to I-580I went further south to I-8 then went eastEast, east, eastAnd even further eastIn Arizona, I took I-17At Flagstaff, I took US Route 89I dashed into a roadside motel, slept, and wokeAnd started driving againThe morning light shone brilliantlyEach time I stopped to fill up with gas, I bought some brownies, each individually wrapped, I tore off the wrappers with one hand and ate them as I drove, the ridiculously sweet lumps stuck to the roof  of my mouth, when I stopped in front of a motel that night, my fingers didn’t want to leave the steering wheel, at the registration desk, the words I needed to say in English didn’t rise to my lips, even though  I knew them all too well(Two traveling together)There was a woman standing at the side of the road, I called out to her in broken English, asking her what was the matter, she answered in what was also broken EnglishWould you mind taking me to the nearest gas station?
   8: 
   9: She sat in the passenger’s seatI’m NavajoWhere are you from?
  10: 
  11: From California, I answeredNo, that’s not what I meantWhat tribe are you from?
  12: 
  13: she asked(Two traveling together)From Kayenta I took US Route 163 toward Monument ValleyI had heard that coyotes lived there long agoThat it’s an amazing place, the moon rises, the sun setsI imagined it would be like seeing the oceanBut when I got there, it wasn’t like the ocean at allRocks soared into the airRocks, rocks, even more rocksRed rocksIn the dustI watched the sun set over themBy the time I got back to Route 163, the sun had sunk deep beyond the horizon, the only thing I could see was the road in front of me,  I drove on looking for a place to sleep, but I didn’t see a thing, there wasn’t anything to see, air rushed through my cracked window,  letting out a long, thin, high-pitched whistleHii-iuu-uuuuuHii-iuu-uuuuuLike a reed fluteMy thin, hard window was slightly open, the wind rushed in but couldn’t escapeHii-iuuuUuu-uuuuuUuu-hiiuuuuu(Two of us heard it)I drove a long way before spying a large motel, I saw the vacancy sign as I approached, I thought I’d have to drive for hours and hours before finding a place to sleep, I thought I wouldn’t stop, that I’d drive all night without stopping, but the place I found was part of a chain you see in every city, the bed was big and deep, and there was lots of hot water in the tub(Two of us were there)The next morningThe car was completely filthyThe whole thing was covered with bright red dirt and sandThe windshield was covered with the splattered bodies of countless insectsNo one knew I had slept there, nor that I was leaving, nor which direction I was headed, no one knewIt was a day that invitedDeath along the roadsideI hadn’t even driven for five minutes before I saw it —A single, dead coyoteLying on its back, legs in the air(It was both me andMy travel companion, too)
  14: Translated from the  Japanese

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 463: (8) Gavin Douglas, Bishop of Dunkeld, and John Maitland, late Earl of Lauderdale.
 464: 
 465: (9) Greenock and PortGlasgow, two large Sea Port Towns near the Mouth of the Clyde.
 466: 
 467: (10) This Marble Chair was the seat in which the Kings of Scotland were crowned at Scone; but was carried away by Edward I into England, when he had almost subdued Scotland.
 468: 
 469: And as tradition says of the inscription on the bottom of this Chair, viz.
 470: 
 471: That where-ever it was to be carried to, the Kings of Scotland would become Sovereigns of that country, which was fulfilled by James VI.
 472: 
 473: succeeding Queen Elizabeth in the Crown of England.
 474: 
 475: This Marble Chair makes part of the Seat in Westminster.
 476: 
 477: From: Glotta, Or The Clyde, A Poem.
 478: 
 479: Printed by Henry Reynell, #21, Piccadilly.
 480: 
 481: 1810

  44: 
  45: But eventually I couldn’t help but only see the large dark field.
  46: 
  47: Its silent twitching.
  48: 
  49: By then it was already early fall, and the fact is, it tore us apart.

   1: Tourist
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: Warsaw, October: rose-madder by four,the soldierly grey boulevards slipperywith tickets to winter.
   4: 
   5: After forty years rebuilding,the Old Town is like this beautiful girl I knewwhose face was wheel-broken in a crash,and remade so well it was hard to say howshe looked wrong.
   6: 
   7: I’d brought two questions here—holding them as if they might slip: who weremy mother’s people?
   8: 
   9: Where did they die?
  10: 
  11: In an attic-archive—deep card indexes, ink turned lilacwith age—I handed my questions to a love-laborerin a yarmulke; with sad palms and a shakeof the head he regretted that any answers nowlay probably beyond our reach.
  12: 
  13: SoI abandoned questing and went back to tourism;joined the passeggiata, drank black tea, got stickiedunder sooty lime trees, saw boisterous children,all knees and elbows, skyline-caperingon the wall at the river-divide.
  14: 
  15: Beyondtheir frail silhouettes against the petrol duskhuge cranes were moving, courtly, confident,building another new Warsaw across the Vistula.

#356: 97700_Welcome, bonny brid_Laycock, Samuel_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Welcome, bonny brid
Author: Laycock, Samuel
Prose starts at line: 93
Lines to remove: 15
Avg verse line length: 27.9
Avg prose line length: 87.4

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  88: Munno fear --- Mustn't frighten
  89: Beawn to beigh --- Going to buy
  90: Skrikes --- Shrieks or loud crying
  91: Bally --- Belly
  92: Middlin' thrung --- Rather crowded

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  93: This was written in the 1860's during the cotton famine,whilst Laycock's wife was actually giving birth to their 4th child.
  94: 
  95: He stuck himself out of the midwife's way in the corner of the room with pen and paper!
  96: Obviously this was a time of great worry due to the economic situation in Lancashire caused by the cotton embargoes during the American Civil war.
  97: 
  98: But, equally obviously, Laycock was also as happy as any other proud father at the latest addition to the nest (a common image in poetry of the time).
  99: 
 100: Laycock claimed to have been inspired to write this but unfortunately his inspiration let him down somewhat.
 101: 
 102: The newcomer was a hen not a cock.
 103: 
 104: It was his first daughter!
 105: This has been recorded as a song by a number of artists but I believe it to be currently out of print.
 106: 
 107: Jim Saville

  25: 
  26: From John Wood,
  27: Endurance and Suffering: Narratives of Disease in the 19th Century
  28: (Germany: Edition GALERIE VERVAIS, 2007).
  29: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  30: John Wood, the only  twice-winner of the Iowa Poetry Prize, came upon a book by George Henry Fox (1846-1937), an American pioneer in the treatment of syphillis, leprosy, and a host of other skin diseases.
  31: 
  32: At his dispensary in New York City, Fox began taking compassionate but un-idealized photographs of his afflicted patients.
  33: 
  34: John Wood, a noted photo historian as well as an eminent contemporary poet, was moved by Fox's work and wrote twenty-five poems inspired by Dr.
  35: 
  36: Fox's photographs.
  37: 
  38: The book that resulted, ENDURANCE AND SUFFERING, won a prestigious German gold medal in 2009.

  65: After some years of betrothal and impediment arising from the jealousy of Edward I, she and Llywelyn were married in 1278.
  66:

  68: 
  69: Maesmynan; by Caerwys in Flintshire; where Llywelyn lived retiredly in youth.
  70: 
  71: The thousand-years' kingdom; The descent of the royal house of North Wales is legendarily traced from Caradoc-Caractacus.
  72: 
  73: But the accepted genealogy of the Princes of Gwynedd begins with Cunedda Wledig (Paramount) cir.
  74: 
  75: 400: ending in 1282 with Llywelyn son of Gruffydd.
  76: 
  77: The scorn-diadem'd head; On finding whom he had slain, Frankton carried Llywelyn's head to Edward at Rhuddlan, who, with a barbarity unworthy of himself, set it over the Tower of London, wreathed in mockery of a prediction (ascribed to Merlin) upon the coronation of a Welsh Prince in London.
  78: 
  79: Rhodri and Owain; Rhodri Mawr, (843), who united under his supremacy the other Welsh principalities, Powys and Dinefawr; Owain Gwynedd, (1137),--are among the most conspicuous of Llywelyn's royal predecessors.

#360: 98108_On Friday Nights_Trejo, Ernesto_unknown.txt

Title: On Friday Nights
Author: Trejo, Ernesto
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 16.0
Avg prose line length: 86.9

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: On Friday Nights
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: On Friday nights I go to the bakery two blocks away and talk to the woman behind the counter.
   4: 
   5: When the customers leave, she moves around pretending not to see me, which signals that it is time to put on my act.
   6: 
   7: I will talk too much or not at all, I'll pretend to be a salesman, a customer shopping for a birthday cake, a detective taking fingerprints, or a blind man who has lost his cane.
   8: 
   9: She smiles, unimpressed.
  10: 
  11: Sometimes she will join in the act when customers walk in, like the time when, pretending I had fainted, she let a woman smear perfume on my nose and an old man slap my face.
  12: 
  13: One time I pinched her infinite ass and explained I was shopping for watermelons.
  14: 
  15: Isn't this the supermarket?
  16: 
  17: I know that when I leave she writes down who I have been and has a grading scale of 1 to 100.
  18: 
  19: Late at night, walking home I feel relieved.
  20: 
  21: It's over, but who will I be next week?

#362: 98419_Said Grenfell to my Spirit_Lawson, Henry_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Said Grenfell to my Spirit
Author: Lawson, Henry
Prose starts at line: 18
Lines to remove: 13
Avg verse line length: 59.6
Avg prose line length: 129.6

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  13: Of the place your kin were born in and the childhood that you knew,
  14: And your father’s distant Norway (though it has some claim on you),
  15: Though you sing of dear old Mudgee and the home on Pipeclay Flat,
  16: You were born on Grenfell goldfield – and you can’t get over that .
  17: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  18: The Grenfell goldfields lasted for 10 years and in that time produced £1,500,000 worth of gold, including the highest production of gold in New South Wales in 1870-71.
  19: 
  20: Birthplace of Henry Lawson The bushranger Ben Hall lived in the area, taking up the Wheogo Station north-west of the town in the 1850s.
  21: 
  22: Henry Lawson was born, quite humbly, in a tent on the Grenfell goldfields where his father, Niels Hertzberg Larsen - Peter Lawson, was part-owner of a mine.
  23: 
  24: He spent only the first six months of his life in Grenfell before his family moved to Eurunderee near Gulgong.
  25: 
  26: By the time that the gold had run out and the diggers had moved on, wheat had become the town's main product.
  27: 
  28: Grenfell was declared a municipality in 1883, one of the smallest municipalities in the State at that time.
  29: 
  30: The coming of the railway in 1901 and the building of the first wheat silo in 1921 confirmed Grenfell's role in the region.

#364: 98564_'Possum' A Lay of New Chumland_Lawson, Henry_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: 'Possum' A Lay of New Chumland
Author: Lawson, Henry
Prose starts at line: 145
Lines to remove: 17
Avg verse line length: 56.5
Avg prose line length: 175.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 140: 
 141: “Possum”
 142: “A Lay of Newchumland”
 143: 1890
 144: Henry Lawson

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 145: WILL you allow me space in your columns to refer to a social question of some importance, and that is with regard to the utterly reckless way in which young men are drafted off from England to Australia! Not a steamer reaches us in the colonies without bringing scores of these unfortunates, who are simply run out of their homes by their parents.
 146: 
 147: The situations they occupy in the colonies are potato-peelers at inferior hotels, washers-up at sixpenny restaurants, billiard markers and similar menial and degrading positions.
 148: 
 149: Let anyone take a turn along the Yarra and the wharves in Melbourne, or through the domain in Sydney, and he will find new chums by the score.
 150: 
 151: In all the cities and bush towns of the colonies they are the outcasts of our civilisation, without money and without a trade.
 152: 
 153: We are told that these young men come here to seek their fortunes, but from what they say, it is evident that, in reality, their parents and relatives pay their passage to Australia in the hope of never seeing them again.
 154: 
 155: Let me say in conclusion that to send to Australia a poor young man without a good trade is to confuse him to hopeless drudgery in the centres of civilisation, or to oblivion and death in the vast silent wastes where even the blacks sometimes die for want of water.
 156: 
 157: —Sydney correspondent LONDON FIELD.
 158: 
 159: “The poem ‘Newchumland’ was founded on the diary of a newchum in West Australia, and is at least true as a description of newchum life in Australia.
 160: 
 161: The verses, which are by a member of the BOOMERANG staff, were printed in an Albany tri-weekly paper last winter.


====================================================================================================

   1: Between The Griffon and Met Life
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: I am totally enamored of every person passing in this unseasonably warm mid-March evening near 39th and Park
   4: 
   5: The young women, of course, with their lives in front of them, and the young men too, just standing here as I am, checking it out, hanging out, talking
   6: 
   7: But everyone here, every age, every type, is beautiful, the moment, somehow, the weather, has made them all real and for this moment, before it turns to night, they're all fantastic
   8: 
   9: The light is such that I can see everyone and can imagine what they are imagining for the night ahead, what dreams, what fulfilled fantasies of togetherness
  10: 
  11: And the two guys who were here a moment ago, paused, have moved on, and the light is deepening, every moment or so, actually falling into a deeper stupor, which is night
  12: 
  13: But if I look south I still see the pink flush of desire there at the bottom, the southness of all our lives, and it's okay that it's darkening here, people accept it as they concoct plans for tonight, Thursday
  14: 
  15: Soon I'll have to go too, lose this spot, this moment, but some we've met and some experience we had somewhere else is becoming ever more important

Author: Thompson, Frank
Prose starts at line: 18
Lines to remove: 15

Avg prose line length: 81.1

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  13: Write on the stones no words of sadness -
  14: Only the gladness due,
  15: That we, who asked the most of living,
  16: Knew how to give it too.
  17: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  18: Thompson volunteered although under age and was commissioned in the Royal Artillery in 1940, subsequently serving in the GHQ Liaison Regiment in Libya, Persia, Iran and Sicily.
  19: 
  20: Parachuted into Yugoslavia, he was ambushed in May 1944 with a group of Bulgarian partisans near Sofia.
  21: 
  22: Although he was wearing uniform when captured, he was treated as a spy.
  23: 
  24: 'Tried' at Litakovo, he defended himself in fluent Bulgarian condemning Fascism.
  25: 
  26: He was shot on 10 June 1944.
  27: 
  28: Thompson had a working knowledge of nine European languages.
  29: 
  30: This poem compares with the best of the First World War.
  31: 
  32: The title of this poem is Latin, and means 'having promised better things'.

   4:

   6:

   8: 
   9: I have arranged with the coiffeur for your hair to be made to grow into mine and my hair to be made to grow into yours.
  10: 
  11: I have persuaded (not without bribery) the world's most famous Eskimo sealing-wax maker to perform the delicate operation of sealing us together so that I am warm in your depths, but though we hunt for him all night and though we hear various reports of his existence we can never find the young wizard who is able so they say to graft the soul of a girl to the soul of her lover so that not even the sharp scissors of the Fates can ever sever them apart.

#368: 99378_Oh my blacke Soule! now thou art summoned_Donne, John_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Oh my blacke Soule! now thou art summoned
Author: Donne, John
Prose starts at line: 29
Lines to remove: 10
Avg verse line length: 51.5
Avg prose line length: 135.7

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  24: Overall Explanation
  25: It is reasonable to assume that this poem was written during a time of sickness for Donne, because it explores the idea of Donne's death with some anguish.
  26: 
  27: Donne looks into his soul and finds it full of evil ("black").
  28: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  29: He compares it first to someone who has committed a terrible wrong in some country and doesn't dare return.
  30: 
  31: In this comparison, the country which has suffered this horrible wrong represents God.
  32: 
  33: In his second comparison, his soul is a thief, who wants to get out of prison until he is sentenced to death, at which time life in prison looks quite appealing!
  34: Donne builds up the intensity of the poem with circular reasoning - he needs the grace to repent, but will not have grace until he repents.
  35: 
  36: The ending is a poweful one, partially because Donne employs the paradox of red blood dying something white to create a strong image in the mind.
  37: 
  38: What he means here of course is that the reality of Christ dying for to save humans' souls - the tangible red blood, is enough to make us pure in the eyes of God (white souls).


====================================================================================================

  30:

  34:

Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 11
Avg verse line length: 40.0
Avg prose line length: 166.5

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: What did you learn here? (Old Man House)
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: How to fall asleep easily on the beach, to dig clams, to dream a net made of nettles, a medicine of marsh tea boiled out to the open air, a memory of cedar bark coiled, resting for months in cold water to be fashioned into our so-called lifestyle, clothes for ceremony as well as our dailiness, canoe bailers, diapers, we used the wood for our half-mile longhouse and totems, dried fish, a hard smoke, wooden oval plates that hooked together filled with clear oil of salmon, to wet our palates and smooth our bodies.
   4: 
   5: A shawl of woolly dog (now extinct) they were bred on tiny islands we can still identify, Tatoosh Island off of Cape Flattery, where there were whaling tribes too, the Makah, one of whose villages collapsed, preserved in silt (later unearthed) and how else?
   6: 
   7: Which other ceremonies or necessary edges of objects?
   8: 
   9: Our ivory needles, otter pelts, mat creasers, our dances.
  10: 
  11: What else do you remember dreaming of?
  12: 
  13: A kind of rake to skim the waves, to catch tiny fish on rows of twisted nails.

  15: Monk, monk, a boy monk-
  16: Buy our baby for a disciple.
  17: 
  18: The third day of the third month by the lunar calendar.
  19: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  20: On this festive day, married women traditionally bathe for purification; swallows return; and butterflies appear.
  21: 
  22: People would read their fortunes in the butterflies, taking yellow swallowtails as a sign that their wishes would be fulfilled and white butterflies as a sign that a parent would die.
  23: 
  24: *1 Mothers recite this in play with little children; they also recite the nonsense verse of lines four and five, while making flapping arm gestures
  25: *2 Crescent rice cakes: bite-sized rice cakes shaped like a half-moon and filled
  26: with bean-paste.
  27: 
  28: When flavoured with mugwort, they are green.

   3: I SAW a telegram handed a two hundred pound man at a desk.
   4: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

   6: 
   7: Cross my heart, the two hundred pound man had just cracked a joke about a new hat he got his wife, when the messenger boy slipped in and asked him to sign.
   8: 
   9: He gave the boy a nickel, tore the envelope and read.
  10: 
  11: Then he yelled "Good God," jumped for his hat and raincoat, ran for the elevator and took a taxi to a railroad depot.
  12: 
  13: As I say, it was like a set of crystals in a chemist's tube and a whispering pinch of salt.
  14: 
  15: I wonder what Diogenes who lived in a tub in the sun would have commented on the affair.
  16: 
  17: I know a shoemaker who works in a cellar slamming half-soles onto shoes, and when I told him, he said: "I pay my bills, I love my wife, and I am not afraid of anybody.

  14: The newspapers asked.
  15: 
  16: Cigarettes, tulips, pacing horses, took her name.
  17: 
  18: Twenty years old … thirty … forty …

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  19: Forty-five and the doctors fathom nothing, the doctors quarrel, the doctors use silver tubes feeding twenty-four quarts of blood into the veins, the respects of a prize-fighter, a cab driver.
  20:

  24:

  28: A memory, a stage and footlights out, an electric sign on Broadway dark.
  29: 
  30: She belonged to somebody, nobody.
  31: 
  32: No one man owned her, no ten nor a thousand.
  33: 
  34: She belonged to many thousand men, lovers of the white chiseling of arms and shoulders, the ivory of a laugh, the bells of song.
  35: 
  36: Railroad brakemen taking trains across Nebraska prairies, lumbermen jaunting in pine and tamarack of the Northwest, stock ranchers in the middle west, mayors of southern cities
  37: Say to their pals and wives now: I see by the papers Anna Held is dead.

   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: THE DOUBLE moon, one on the high back drop of the west, one on the curve of the river face,
   4: The sky moon of fire and the river moon of water, I am taking these home in a basket, hung on an elbow, such a teeny weeny elbow, in my head.
   5: 
   6: I saw them last night, a cradle moon, two horns of a moon, such an early hopeful moon, such a child's moon for all young hearts to make a picture of.
   7: 
   8: The river-I remember this like a picture-the river was the upper twist of a written question mark.
   9: 
  10: I know now it takes many many years to write a river, a twist of water asking a question.
  11: 
  12: And white stars moved when the moon moved, and one red star kept burning, and the Big Dipper was almost overhead.

#378: 100820_Out Of White Lips_Sandburg, Carl_unknown.txt

Author: Sandburg, Carl
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 9
Avg verse line length: 17.0
Avg prose line length: 133.4

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Out Of White Lips
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: OUT of white lips a question: Shall seven million dead ask for their blood a little land for the living wives and children, a little land for the living brothers and sisters?
   4: 
   5: Out of white lips:-Shall they have only air that sweeps round the earth for breath of their nostrils and no footing on the dirt of the earth for their battle-drabbed, battle-soaked shoes?
   6: 
   7: Out of white lips:-Is the red in the flag the blood of a free man on a piece of land his own or is it the red of a sheep slit in the throat for mutton?
   8: 
   9: Out of white lips a white pain murmurs: Who shall have land?
  10: 
  11: Him who has stood ankle deep in the blood of his comrades, in the red trenches dug in the land?

   2: 
   3: I asked the mayor of Gary about the 12-hour day and the 7-day week.
   4: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   5: And the mayor of Gary answered more workmen steal time on the job in Gary than any other place in the United States.
   6: 
   7: "Go into the plants and you will see men sitting around doing nothing—machinery does everything," said the mayor of Gary when I asked him about the 12-hour day and the 7-day week.
   8: 
   9: And he wore cool cream pants, the Mayor of Gary, and white shoes, and a barber had fixed him up with a shampoo and a shave and he was east and imperturbable though the government weather bureau thermometer said 96 and children were soaking their heads at bubbling fountains on the street corners.
  10: 
  11: And I said good-bye to the Mayor of Gary and I went out from the city hall and turned the corner into Broadway.
  12: 
  13: And I saw workmen wearing leather shoes scruffed with fire and cinders, and pitted with little holes from running molten steel,
  14: And some had bunches of specialized muscles around their shoulder blades hard as pig iron, muscles of their forearms were sheet steel and they looked to me like men who had been somewhere.

   8: 
   9: I shall be eaten by gray creepers in a bunkhouse where no runners of the sun come and no dogs live.
  10: 
  11: And yet-of all "and yets" this is the bronze strongest-

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]

  13: 
  14: The broken foot goes to a hole dug with a shovel or the bone of a nose may whiten on a hilltop-and yet-"and yet"-
  15: There is one crimson pinch of ashes left after all; and none of the shifting winds that whip the grass and none of the pounding rains that beat the dust, know how to touch or find the flash of this crimson.
  16: 
  17: I cry God to give me a broken foot, a scar, or a lousy death.
  18: 
  19: I who have seen the flash of this crimson, I ask God for the last and worst.


====================================================================================================

  15:

  17: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

  19:

  21: 
  22: We were three in all, the other being a Lithuanian who got drunk on pay day at the steel works and got to fighting a policeman;
  23: All the clothes he had was a shirt, pants and shoes—      somebody got his hat and coat and what money he had left over when he got drunk.

#387: 100879_Chicago_Sandburg, Carl_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Chicago
Author: Sandburg, Carl
Prose starts at line: 11
Lines to remove: 20
Avg verse line length: 41.6
Avg prose line length: 75.1

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   6: Stormy, husky, brawling,
   7: City of the Big Shoulders:
   8: 
   9: They tell me you are wicked and I believe them, for I have seen your painted women under the gas lamps luring the farm boys.
  10: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  11: And they tell me you are crooked and I answer: Yes, it is true I have seen the gunman kill and go free to kill again.
  12: 
  13: And they tell me you are brutal and my reply is: On the faces of women and children I have seen the marks of wanton hunger.
  14: 
  15: And having answered so I turn once more to those who sneer at this my city, and I give them back the sneer and say to them:
  16: Come and show me another city with lifted head singing so proud to be alive and coarse and strong and cunning.
  17: 
  18: Flinging magnetic curses amid the toil of piling job on job, here is a tall bold slugger set vivid against the little soft cities;
  19: Fierce as a dog with tongue lapping for action, cunning as a savage pitted against the wilderness,
  20: Bareheaded,
  21: Shoveling,
  22: Wrecking,
  23: Planning,
  24: Building, breaking, rebuilding,
  25: Under the smoke, dust all over his mouth, laughing with white teeth,
  26: Under the terrible burden of destiny laughing as a young man laughs,
  27: Laughing even as an ignorant fighter laughs who has never lost a battle,
  28: Bragging and laughing that under his wrist is the pulse, and under his ribs the heart of the people,
  29: Laughing!
  30: Laughing the stormy, husky, brawling laughter of Youth, half-naked, sweating, proud to be Hog Butcher, Tool Maker, Stacker of Wheat, Player with Railroads and Freight Handler to the Nation.


====================================================================================================
#388: 100882_Streets Too Old_Sandburg, Carl_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Streets Too Old
Author: Sandburg, Carl
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 11
Avg verse line length: 15.0
Avg prose line length: 173.5

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Streets Too Old
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: I WALKED among the streets of an old city and the streets were lean as the throats of hard seafish soaked in salt and kept in barrels many years.
   4: 
   5: How old, how old, how old, we are:-the walls went on saying, street walls leaning toward each other like old women of the people, like old midwives tired and only doing what must be done.
   6: 
   7: The greatest the city could offer me, a stranger, was statues of the kings, on all corners bronzes of kings-ancient bearded kings who wrote books and spoke of God's love for all people-and young kings who took forth armies out across the frontiers splitting the heads of their opponents and enlarging their kingdoms.
   8: 
   9: Strangest of all to me, a stranger in this old city, was the murmur always whistling on the winds twisting out of the armpits and fingertips of the kings in bronze:-Is there no loosening?
  10: 
  11: Is this for always?
  12: 
  13: In an early snowflurry one cried:-Pull me down where the tired old midwives no longer look at me, throw the bronze of me to a fierce fire and make me into neckchains for dancing children.

#390: 100898_The Four Brothers_Sandburg, Carl_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Four Brothers
Author: Sandburg, Carl
Prose starts at line: 183
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 48.4
Avg prose line length: 82.1

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 178: 
 179: The stubs and stumps of arms and legs, the eyesockets empty, the cripples, ten times a million.
 180: 
 181: The crimson thumb-print of this anathema is on the door panels of a hundred million homes.
 182: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 183: Cows gone, mothers on sick-beds, children cry a hunger and no milk comes in the noon-time or at night.
 184: 
 185: The death-yells of it all, the torn throats of men in ditches calling for water, the shadows and the hacking lungs in dugouts, the steel paws that clutch and squeeze a scarlet drain day by day-the storm of it is hell.
 186: 
 187: But look! child! the storm is blowing for a clean air.
 188: 
 189: Look! the four brothers march
 190: And hurl their big shoulders
 191: And swear the job shall be done.
 192: 
 193: Out of the wild finger-writing north and south, east and west, over the blood-crossed, blood-dusty ball of earth,
 194: Out of it all a God who knows is sweeping clean,
 195: Out of it all a God who sees and pierces through, is breaking and cleaning out an old thousand years, is making ready for a new thousand years.
 196: 
 197: The four brothers shall be five and more.
 198: 
 199: Under the chimneys of the winter time the children of the world shall sing new songs.
 200: 
 201: Among the rocking restless cradles the mothers of the world shall sing new sleepy-time songs.

  13: There was a summer.
  14: 
  15: It is so long ago I saw this wild pigeon and listened.
  16: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

  20: 
  21: So there is memory.
  22: 
  23: So there is a pigeon, a summer, a gray wing beating my shoulder.

#393: 100903_John Ericsson Day Memorial, 1918_Sandburg, Carl_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: John Ericsson Day Memorial, 1918
Author: Sandburg, Carl
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 11
Avg verse line length: 32.0
Avg prose line length: 276.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: John Ericsson Day Memorial, 1918
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: INTO the gulf and the pit of the dark night, the cold night, there is a man goes into the dark and the cold and when he comes back to his people he brings fire in his hands and they remember him in the years afterward as the fire bringer-they remember or forget-the man whose head kept singing to the want of his home, the want of his people.
   4: 
   5: For this man there is no name thought of-he has broken from jungles and the old oxen and the old wagons-circled the earth with ships-belted the earth with steel-swung with wings and a drumming motor in the high blue sky-shot his words on a wireless way through shattering sea storms:-out from the night and out from the jungles his head keeps singing-there is no road for him but on and on.
   6: 
   7: Against the sea bastions and the land bastions, against the great air pockets of stars and atoms, he points a finger, finds a release clutch, touches a button no man knew before.
   8: 
   9: The soldier with a smoking gun and a gas mask-the workshop man under the smokestacks and the blueprints-these two are brothers of the handshake never forgotten-for these two we give the salt tears of our eyes, the salute of red roses, the flame-won scarlet of poppies.
  10: 
  11: For the soldier who gives all, for the workshop man who gives all, for these the red bar is on the flag-the red bar is the heart's-blood of the mother who gave him, the land that gave him.
  12: 
  13: The gray foam and the great wheels of war go by and take all-and the years give mist and ashes-and our feet stand at these, the memory places of the known and the unknown, and our hands give a flame-won poppy-our hands touch the red bar of a flag for the sake of those who gave-and gave all.


====================================================================================================

   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: THE BABY moon, a canoe, a silver papoose canoe, sails and sails in the Indian west.
   4: 
   5: A ring of silver foxes, a mist of silver foxes, sit and sit around the Indian moon.
   6: 
   7: One yellow star for a runner, and rows of blue stars for more runners, keep a line of watchers.
   8: 
   9: O foxes, baby moon, runners, you are the panel of memory, fire-white writing to-night of the Red Man's dreams.
  10: 
  11: Who squats, legs crossed and arms folded, matching its look against the moon-face, the star-faces, of the West?
  12: 
  13: Who are the Mississippi Valley ghosts, of copper foreheads, riding wiry ponies in the night?
  14: 
  15: -no bridles, love-arms on the pony necks, riding in the night a long old trail?
  16: 
  17: Why do they always come back when the silver foxes sit around the early moon, a silver papoose, in the Indian west?

Author: Sandburg, Carl
Prose starts at line: 5
Lines to remove: 7
Avg verse line length: 44.0
Avg prose line length: 154.5

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Improved Farm Land
   2: 
   3: Tall timber stood here once, here on a corn belt farm along the Monon.
   4: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   5: Here the roots of a half-mile of trees dug their runners deep in the loam for a grip and a hold against wind storms.
   6: 
   7: Then the axemen came and the chips flew to the zing of steel and handle—the lank railsplitters cut the big ones first, the beeches and the oaks, then the brush.
   8: 
   9: Dynamite, wagons, and horses took the stumps—the plows sunk their teeth in—now it is first class corn land—improved property—and the hogs grunt over the fodder crops.
  10: 
  11: It would come hard now for this half mile of improved farm land along the Monon corn belt, on a piece of Grand Prairie, to remember once it had a great singing family of trees.

  24:

  34:

  36: 
  37: Why do I go again to the balloons on the wires, something for nothing, kin women of the half-moon, dream women?
  38: 
  39: And the half-moon swinging on the wind crossing the town—these two, the half-moon and the wind—this will be about all, this will be about all.
  40: 
  41: Eaters, go to it; your mazuma pays for it all; it’s a knockout, a classy knockout—and payday always comes.

  40: 
  41: These and: There is a God, there must be a God, how can there be rain or sun unless there is a God?
  42: 
  43: So from the wrongs of Napoleon and the Cheshire cat smile on to the buffaloes and blizzards of Texas and on to his mother and to God, so the blurry grey rain dreams of Alexander have gone on five minutes, maybe ten, keeping slow easy time to the raindrops on the window glass and the raindrops sliding off the green blinds and down the siding.

  12:

   1: Clocks
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: HERE is a face that says half-past seven the same way whether a murder or a wedding goes on, whether a funeral or a picnic crowd passes.
   4: 
   5: A tall one I know at the end of a hallway broods in shadows and is watching booze eat out the insides of the man of the house; it has seen five hopes go in five years: one woman, one child, and three dreams.
   6: 
   7: A little one carried in a leather box by an actress rides with her to hotels and is under her pillow in a sleeping-car between one-night stands.
   8: 
   9: One hoists a phiz over a railroad station; it points numbers to people a quarter-mile away who believe it when other clocks fail.
  10: 
  11: And of course .
  12: 
  13: 
  14: there are wrist watches over the pulses of airmen eager to go to France.

  33: In a shanty out in the Wilderness, ghosts of to-morrow sit, waiting to come and go, to do their job.
  34: 
  35: They will go into the house of the Dead and take the shivering sheets of paper and make a bonfire and dance a deadman’s dance over the hissing crisp.
  36: 
  37: In a slang their own the dancers out of the Wilderness will write a paper for the living to read and sign:
  38: The dead need peace, the dead need sleep, let the dead have peace and sleep, let the papers of the Dead who fix the lives of the Living, let them be a hissing crisp and ashes, let the young men and the young women forever understand we are through and no longer take the say-so of the Dead;
  39: Let the dead have honor from us with our thoughts of them and our thoughts of land and all appurtenances thereto and all deposits of oil and gold and coal and silver, and all pockets and repositories of gravel and diamonds, dung and permanganese, and all clover and bumblebees, all bluegrass, johnny-jump-ups, grassroots, springs of running water or rivers or lakes or high spreading trees or hazel bushes or sumach or thornapple branches or high in the air the bird nest with spotted blue eggs shaken in the roaming wind of the treetops.
  40: 
  41: And so, it is a shack of ghosts, a lean-to they have in the Wilderness, and they are waiting and they have learned strange songs how easy it is to wait and how anything comes to those who wait long enough and how most of all it is easy to wait for death, and waiting, dream of new cities.


====================================================================================================

   4: 
   5: how if summer misses one of us the two of us miss summer-

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   6: Summer when the lungs of the earth take a long breath for the change to low contralto singing mornings when the green corn leaves first break through the black loam-
   7: And another long breath for the silver soprano melody of the moon songs in the light nights when the earth is lighter than a feather, the iron mountains lighter than a goose down-
   8: So I shall look for you in the light nights then, in the laughter of slats of silver under a hill hickory.
   9: 
  10: In the listening tops of the hickories, in the wind motions of the hickory shingle leaves, in the imitations of slow sea water on the shingle silver in the wind-
  11: I shall look for you.

   9: motion for a new trial, speaking in a soft voice, speaking in a voice slightly colored with bitter wrongs
  10: mingled with monumental patience, speaking with mythic Atlas shoulders of many preposterous,
  11: unjust circumstances.

#410: 101028_A Million Young Work Men_Sandburg, Carl_unknown.txt

Title: A Million Young Work Men
Author: Sandburg, Carl
Prose starts at line: 4
Lines to remove: 10
Avg verse line length: 51.0
Avg prose line length: 132.7

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: A Million Young Work Men
   2: 
   3: A million  young workmen straight and strong lay stiff on the grass and roads,

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   4: And the million are now under soil and their rottening flesh will in the years feed roots of blood-red roses.
   5: 
   6: Yes, this million of young workmen slaughtered one another and never saw their red hands.
   7: 
   8: And oh, it would have been a great job of killing and a new and beautiful thing under the sun if the million knew why they hacked and tore each other to death.
   9: 
  10: The kings are grinning, the Kaiser and the czar—they are alive riding in leather-seated motor cars, and they have their women and roses for ease, and they eat fresh-poached eggs for breakfast, new butter on toast, sitting in tall water-tight houses reading the news of war.
  11: 
  12: I dreamed a million ghosts of the young workmen rose in their shirts all soaked in crimson … and yelled:
  13: God damn the grinning kings, God damn the kaiser and the czar.

   9:

  11: let 'em howl.
  12: 
  13: Galoots fat with too much, galoots lean with too little, galoot millions and millions, snousle and snicker on, plug your exhausts, hunt your snacks of fat and lean, grab off yours.

   2:
