   4: 
   5: Two Swede boys go upstairs and see Joe.
   6: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   7: His wife is dead, his only son is dead, and his two daughters in Missouri and Texas don't want him around.
   8: 
   9: The boys and Uncle Joe crack walnuts with a hammer on the bottom of a flatiron while the January wind howls and the zero air weaves laces on the window glass.
  10: 
  11: Joe tells the Swede boys all about Chickamauga and Chattanooga, how the Union soldiers crept in rain somewhere a dark night and ran forward and killed many Rebels, took flags, held a hill, and won a victory told about in the histories in school.
  12: 
  13: Joe takes a piece of carpenter's chalk, draws lines on the floor and piles stove wood to show where six regiments were slaughtered climbing a slope.
  14: 
  15: "Here they went" and "Here they went," says Joe, and the January wind howls and the zero air weaves laces on the window glass.
  16: 
  17: The two Swede boys go downstairs with a big blur of guns, men, and hills in their heads.
  18: 
  19: They eat herring and potatoes and tell the family war is a wonder and soldiers are a wonder.
  20: 
  21: One breaks out with a cry at supper: I wish we had a war now and I could be a soldier.

#418: 101098_Snow_Sandburg, Carl_unknown.txt

Title: Snow
Author: Sandburg, Carl
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 12
Avg verse line length: 4.0
Avg prose line length: 116.6

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Snow
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: SNOW took us away from the smoke valleys into white mountains, we saw velvet blue cows eating a vermillion grass and they gave us a pink milk.
   4: 
   5: Snow changes our bones into fog streamers caught by the wind and spelled into many dances.
   6: 
   7: Six bits for a sniff of snow in the old days bought us bubbles beautiful to forget floating long arm women across sunny autumn hills.
   8: 
   9: Our bones cry and cry, no let-up, cry their telegrams:
  10: More, more-a yen is on, a long yen and God only knows when it will end.
  11: 
  12: In the old days six bits got us snow and stopped the yen-now the government says: No, no, when our bones cry their telegrams: More, more.
  13: 
  14: The blue cows are dying, no more pink milk, no more floating long arm women, the hills are empty-us for the smoke valleys-sneeze and shiver and croak, you dopes-the government says: No, no.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   2: 
   3: CLOWNS DYINGFIVE circus clowns dying this year, morning newspapers told their lives, how each one horizontal in a last gesture of hands arranged by an undertaker, shook thousands into convulsions of laughter from behind rouge-red lips and powder-white face.
   4: 
   5: STEAMBOAT BILLWhen the boilers of the Robert E.
   6: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   7: Lee exploded, a steamboat winner of many races on the Mississippi went to the bottom of the river and never again saw the wharves of Natchez and New Orleans.
   8: 
   9: And a legend lives on that two gamblers were blown toward the sky and during their journey laid bets on which of the two would go higher and which would be first to set foot on the turf of the earth again.
  10: 
  11: FOOT AND MOUTH PLAGUEWhen the mysterious foot and mouth epidemic ravaged the cattle of Illinois, Mrs.
  12: 
  13: Hector Smith wept bitterly over the government killing forty of her soft-eyed Jersey cows; through the newspapers she wept over her loss for millions of readers in the Great Northwest.
  14: 
  15: SEVENSThe lady who has had seven lawful husbands has written seven years for a famous newspaper telling how to find love and keep it: seven thousand hungry girls in the Mississippi Valley have read the instructions seven years and found neither illicit loves nor lawful husbands.
  16: 
  17: PROFITEERI who saw ten strong young men die anonymously, I who saw ten old mothers hand over their sons to the nation anonymously, I who saw ten thousand touch the sunlit silver finalities of undistinguished human glory-why do I sneeze sardonically at a bronze drinking fountain named after one who participated in the war vicariously and bought ten farms?

   4:

   6: Fixed this lone red tulip, a woman's mouth of passion kisses, a nun's mouth of sweet thinking, here topping a straight line of green, a pillar stem?
   7:

   9: 
  10: -nodding balloon-film shooting its wireless every fraction of a second these June days:
  11: Love me before I die;
  12: Love me-love me now.

   1: In The Shadow Of The Palace
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: LET us go out of the fog, John, out of the filmy persistent drizzle on the streets of Stockholm, let us put down the collars of our raincoats, take off our hats and sit in the newspapers office.
   4: 
   5: Let us sit among the telegrams-clickety-click-the kaiser's crown goes into the gutter and the Hohenzollern throne of a thousand years falls to pieces a one-hoss shay.
   6: 
   7: It is a fog night out and the umbrellas are up and the collars of the raincoats-and all the steamboats up and down the Baltic sea have their lights out and the wheelsmen sober.
   8: 
   9: Here the telegrams come-one king goes and another-butter is costly: there is no butter to buy for our bread in Stockholm-and a little patty of butter costs more than all the crowns of Germany.
  10: 
  11: Let us go out in the fog, John, let us roll up our raincoat collars and go on the streets where men are sneering at the kings.

#423: 101147_Savoir Faire_Sandburg, Carl_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Savoir Faire
Author: Sandburg, Carl
Prose starts at line: 5
Lines to remove: 11
Avg verse line length: 40.0
Avg prose line length: 211.3

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Savoir Faire
   2: 
   3: CAST a bronze of my head and legs and put them on the king's street.
   4: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   5: Set the cast of me here alongside Carl XII, making two Carls for the Swedish people and the utlanders to look at between the palace and the Grand Hotel.
   6: 
   7: The summer sun will shine on both the Carls, and November drizzles wrap the two, one in tall leather boots, one in wool leggins.
   8: 
   9: Also I place it in the record: the Swedish people may name boats after me or change the name of a long street and give it one of my nicknames.
  10: 
  11: The old men who beset the soil of Sweden and own the titles to the land-the old men who enjoy a silken shimmer to their chin whiskers when they promenade the streets named after old kings-if they forget me-the old men whose varicose veins stand more and more blue on the calves of their legs when they take their morning baths attended by old women born to the bath service of old men and young-if these old men say another King Carl should have a bronze on the king's street rather than a Fool Carl-
  12: Then I would hurl them only another fool's laugh-
  13: I would remember last Sunday when I stood on a jutland of fire-born red granite watching the drop of the sun in the middle of the afternoon and the full moon shining over Stockholm four o'clock in the afternoon.
  14: 
  15: If the young men will read five lines of one of my poems I will let the kings have all the bronze-I ask only that one page of my writings be a knapsack keepsake of the young men who are the bloodkin of those who laughed nine hundred years ago: We are afraid of nothing-only-the sky may fall on us.


====================================================================================================
#424: 101149_Wind Song_Sandburg, Carl_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Wind Song
Author: Sandburg, Carl
Prose starts at line: 4
Lines to remove: 16
Avg verse line length: 20.5
Avg prose line length: 58.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Wind Song
   2: 
   3: LONG ago I learned how to sleep,

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   4: In an old apple orchard where the wind swept by counting its money and throwing it away,
   5: In a wind-gaunt orchard where the limbs forked out and listened or never listened at all,
   6: In a passel of trees where the branches trapped the wind into whistling, "Who, who are you?
   7: 
   8: I slept with my head in an elbow on a summer afternoon and there I took a sleep lesson.
   9: 
  10: There I went away saying: I know why they sleep, I know how they trap the tricky winds.
  11: 
  12: Long ago I learned how to listen to the singing wind and how to forget and how to hear the deep whine,
  13: Slapping and lapsing under the day blue and the night stars:
  14: Who, who are you?
  15: 
  16: Who can ever forget
  17: listening to the wind go by
  18: counting its money
  19: and throwing it away?

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Jug
   2: 
   3: THE SHALE and water thrown together so-so first of all,

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   4: Then a potter's hand on the wheel and his fingers shaping the jug; out of the mud a mouth and a handle;
   5: Slimpsy, loose and ready to fall at a touch, fire plays on it, slow fire coaxing all the water out of the shale mix.
   6: 
   7: Dipped in glaze more fire plays on it till a molasses lava runs in waves, rises and retreats, a varnish of volcanoes.
   8: 
   9: Take it now; out of mud now here is a mouth and handle; out of this now mothers will pour milk and maple syrup and cider, vinegar, apple juice, and sorghum.
  10: 
  11: There is nothing proud about this; only one out of many; the potter's wheel slings them out and the fires harden them hours and hours thousands and thousands.
  12: 
  13: "Be good to me, put me down easy on the floors of the new concrete houses; I was poured out like a concrete house and baked in fire too.
  14: 
  15: em/jug/#ixzz18PE5TC3G

   2: 
   3: SELL me a violin, mister, of old mysterious wood.
   4: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

   6:

   8:

  10:

#427: 101184_Sandhill People_Sandburg, Carl_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Sandhill People
Author: Sandburg, Carl
Prose starts at line: 7
Lines to remove: 11
Avg verse line length: 39.7
Avg prose line length: 135.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   2: 
   3: I TOOK away three pictures.
   4: 
   5: One was a white gull forming a half-mile arch from the pines toward Waukegan.
   6: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   7: One was a whistle in the little sandhills, a bird crying either to the sunset gone or the dusk come.
   8: 
   9: One was three spotted waterbirds, zigzagging, cutting scrolls and jags, writing a bird Sanscrit of wing points, half over the sand, half over the water, a half-love for the sea, a half-love for the land.
  10: 
  11: I took away three thoughts.
  12: 
  13: One was a thing my people call "love," a shut-in river hunting the sea, breaking white falls between tall clefs of hill country.
  14: 
  15: One was a thing my people call "silence," the wind running over the butter faced sand-flowers, running over the sea, and never heard of again.
  16: 
  17: One was a thing my people call "death," neither a whistle in the little sandhills, nor a bird Sanscrit of wing points, yet a coat all the stars and seas have worn, yet a face the beach wears between sunset and dusk.

   2:

   4: 
   5: Let the engineer open her up for ninety miles an hour.
   6: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]

   7: Take in the prairie right and left, rolling land and new hay crops, swaths of new hay laid in the sun.
   8:

  12:

  14: 
  15: Sumach And Birds
  16: IF you never came with a pigeon rainbow purple
  17: Shining in the six o'clock September dusk:
  18: If the red sumach on the autumn roads
  19: Never danced on the flame of your eyelashes:
  20: If the red-haws never burst in a million
  21: Crimson fingertwists of your heartcrying:
  22: If all this beauty of yours never crushed me
  23: Then there are many flying acres of birds for me,
  24: Many drumming gray wings going home I shall see,
  25: Many crying voices riding the north wind.

   1: High Conspiratorial Person
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: OUT of the testimony of such reluctant lips, out of the oaths and mouths of such scrupulous liars, out of perjurers whose hands swore by God to the white sun before all men,
   4: Out of a rag saturated with smears and smuts gathered from the footbaths of kings and the loin cloths of whores, from the scabs of Babylon and Jerusalem to the scabs of London and New York,
   5: From such a rag that has wiped the secret sores of kings and overlords across the milleniums of human marches and babblings,
   6: From such a rag perhaps I shall wring one reluctant desperate drop of blood, one honest-to-God spot of red speaking a mother-heart.
   7: 
   8: December, 1918.
   9: 
  10: Christiania, Norway

   8:

  10: 
  11: Let love go on; the heartbeats are measured out with a measuring glass, so many apiece to gamble with, to use and spend and reckon; let love go on.

   8: 
   9:

  14: 
  15: Watching the light accumulating in the tree was the only thing I could do at the time.
  16: 
  17: I was subtracted from the world.
  18: 
  19: I saw light as not a form but life; light not a concept but a rhythm.
  20: 
  21: Light not understanding but inspiration after all.

  61: With the people in the train.
  62: 
  63: Authors Note: "In June 1915, having week-end leave from W.
  64: 
  65: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  66: Camp, in Surrey, I spent the Sunday with my sister roaming through the moors and woods round Rickmansworth and the Chalfonts.
  67: 
  68: We had not seen one another for many months, and in close conversation forgot all the world except our two selves.
  69: 
  70: This experience of intimate aloofness reached its climax when, having missed the train at a wayside station — a chance which meant my being late in my return to Camp — we lay down in a field by the track and, waiting for the train, read ballads to one another.
  71: 
  72: The sudden rediscovery of the verse quoted — a sixteenth century anonymous lyric — so intense, personal, and modern in its vivid cry, among the long objective ballads, startled us both back to the world of pains and desires, where we two must leave one another, and the return to School and I to Camp and the Army.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: My Father
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: My father was a tall man and yet the ripened ryeWould come above his shoulders, the spears shot up so high.
   4: 
   5: My father was a tall man and yet the tasseled cornWould hide him when he cut the stalks upon a frosty morn.
   6: 
   7: The green things grew so lushly in the valley of my birth,Where else could one witness the luxuriance of earth?
   8: 
   9: The plow would turn so rhythmically the loose, unfettered loam,There was no need of effort to drive the coulter home.
  10: 
  11: My father walked behind his team before the sun was high,Fine as a figure on a frieze cut sharp against the sky.
  12: 
  13: And when he swung the cradle in the yellow of the grain,He could command all eyes around, or when he drove the wain.
  14: 
  15: I wonder if his acres now that lie so far awayAre waiting for his footprint at the coming of the day.
  16: 
  17: I wonder if the brown old barn that still is standing longAnd ghostly cattle in the stalls are waiting for his song.

Author: Root, George Frederick
Prose starts at line: 66
Lines to remove: 15
Avg verse line length: 49.1
Avg prose line length: 107.1

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  61: 
  62: What made Root's song so compelling?
  63: 
  64: According to Kenneth A.
  65: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  66: Bernard, author of "Lincoln and the Music of the Civil War," the tune appeared at just the right time, "expressing just the sentiments that were needed, with music that was singable and words that were appropriate" and played "an immeasurably important part in restoring and sustaining morale at home and at the front throughout the entire war.
  67: 
  68: A measure of the song's success can be seen in the flurry of imitations that appeared soon after its publication.
  69: 
  70: William H.
  71: 
  72: Barnes, the manager of the Atlanta Amateurs, a group of volunteer musicians who performed for the benefit of various soldiers' relief funds, penned a set of Confederate lyrics that were adapted to Root's tune (with some rhythmic changes) by composer Hermann L.
  73: 
  74: Schreiner.
  75: 
  76: Another knock-off, "Rally Round the Flag," had mundane lyrics and was produced by James T.
  77: 
  78: Fields and William B.
  79: 
  80: Bradbury.

#437: 101341_Tramp! Tramp! Tramp!_Root, George Frederick_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Tramp! Tramp! Tramp!
Author: Root, George Frederick
Prose starts at line: 26
Lines to remove: 7
Avg verse line length: 42.4
Avg prose line length: 163.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  21: That shall come to open wide the iron door,
  22: And the hollow eye grows bright, and the poor heart almost gay,
  23: As we think of seeing home and friends once more.
  24: 
  25: CHORUS

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  26: Composed in 1863, at a point in the War when many men from both armies had exchanged the dangers of life in the field for the rigors of life in the prison camps, this song is possibly the most famous prison song ever written.
  27: 
  28: It quickly caught on with the public and with the soldiers as well, who found that its catchy tune made it an ideal marching song.
  29: 
  30: So popular was Root's melody that it was used in 1867 by the Irish in a song to commemorate the Manchester Martyrs executed by the British Government and by the International Workers of the World in 1910.
  31: 
  32: It is also well known to Sunday school attendees everywhere as "Jesus Loves the Little Children.

   1: Of All Things
   2:

   3: And he said to himself, if primates, rodents, and hoofed mammals each have their place, so must noodles, tinned fruit, and cheeses.
   4: 
   5: If hoofed mammals are channelled into camels, pigs, and goats, then let there be cheeses soft and blue and smoked.
   6:

  12: 
  13: The power was his.
  14:

  30: "Bill" is one of the poet's favorite sailor philosophers, along with Mike Murphy and a few others.
  31:

#444: 101698_Homeward_Smith, Cicely Fox_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Homeward
Author: Smith, Cicely Fox
Prose starts at line: 47
Lines to remove: 15
Avg verse line length: 50.8
Avg prose line length: 145.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  42: 216-218.
  43: 
  44: First published in FIGHTING MEN by Elkin Mathews in 1916 pp 48-50.
  45: 
  46: During World War 1, horses were conscripted as well as men!

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  47: This poem is written from the view-point of a soldier laying at temporary ease one evening in Flanders.
  48: 
  49: He hears the sound of harnessed horses pulling gun carriages and is reminded of his peace-time life in Hampshire (Southern England) when he would hear the same evening sounds but of horses pulling carts carrying the labourers back from the fields.
  50: 
  51: He mourns 'both horse and man' but also the passing from peace to war.
  52: 
  53: Note the slight changes in the refrain verse.
  54: 
  55: Sarah Morgan (UK) has adapted this poem for singing ("Home Boys Home") and a version may be heard on "SING THE SUN INTO THE SKY" as recorded by Two Black Sheep & a Stallion; Morgan found a version of the poem, called "Going Home Together," in the magazine THIS ENGLAND in 1984, as contributed by a soldier who considered the poem anonymous.
  56: 
  57: It is interesting to note that CFS probably intended this as song when she wrote it since it is published with a chorus (enclosed in brackets) that can be used throughout though slightly altered in the final repetition.
  58: 
  59: The header graphic shows British artillery troops passing village bombed by enemy aircraft, photographer unknown.
  60: 
  61: Jim Saville and Charley Noble


====================================================================================================

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  65: 49-50.
  66: 
  67: First published in PUNCH magazine, Volume 184, April 26, 1933, p.
  68: 
  69: 462

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  70: The "Téméraire" was second to the "Victory" in line of battle at Trafalgar and tried to shield Nelson's flagship by sailing in front only to be called back unceremoniously by Nelson himself.
  71: 
  72: Many prisoners-of-war seamen in those days would while away their time carving models of ships.
  73: 
  74: In this case out of cattle bones.
  75: 
  76: The epitaph quoted in the final lines is to be read upon a stone in the churchyard at Odiham, Hampshire, England.

#448: 101743_Sou’ Spain_Smith, Cicely Fox_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Sou’ Spain
Author: Smith, Cicely Fox
Prose starts at line: 65
Lines to remove: 9
Avg verse line length: 32.2
Avg prose line length: 153.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  60: 
  61: Compare this poem with "Outward Bound" and "Rio Grande.
  62: 
  63: "Donkey’s breakfast" is slang for the sailor's straw mattress.
  64: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  65: "The Peter flying free" refers to the signal flag "Blue Peter" that was flown to alert sailors ashore that their ship was about to depart.
  66: 
  67: "Pierhead jump" describes how some tardy sailors would join the ship's crew by literally leaping from the dock to the deck as the mooring lines were cast loose.
  68: 
  69: "Sou' Spain" is a curious geographic reference, used by both Masefield and Smith, which may refer to sailors who have traveled south of the Equator, around the Cape of Good Hope, to India and South Asia.
  70: 
  71: This poem has been adapted for singing by William Pint (US) as recorded with Felicia Dale and Tom Lewis on MAKING WAVES, © 1992; an alternative setting was done in 1995 by Alan Fitzsimmons as recorded on SEABOOT DUFF & HANDSPIKE GRUEL by Pinch o' Salt.
  72: 
  73: Charley Noble


====================================================================================================
#449: 101746_Mariquita_Smith, Cicely Fox_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Mariquita
Author: Smith, Cicely Fox
Prose starts at line: 33
Lines to remove: 7
Avg verse line length: 63.0
Avg prose line length: 118.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  28: 
  29: This poem reflects the memory of an old sailor for the days of his youth when he roamed the dockside of some west coast South American country and met a lovely young local woman that he fell in love with.
  30: 
  31: But there is more than nostalgia in this poem.
  32: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  33: There's acknowledgment that the sailor has also changed through the years, as have the ships and ports he knew so well.
  34: 
  35: The reference to "Dagoes" is a little hard to take for contemporary readers but it's an accurate representation of how sailors referred to residents of South America, not to mention residents of Southern Europe.
  36: 
  37: The header graphic is of a young Peruvian girl dancing in colonial costume at a festival in Trujillo, from a photo by Robert Frerck.
  38: 
  39: Charley Noble


====================================================================================================
#450: 101751_Hic(Ks) Jacet_Smith, Cicely Fox_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Hic(Ks) Jacet
Author: Smith, Cicely Fox
Prose starts at line: 36
Lines to remove: 17
Avg verse line length: 32.7
Avg prose line length: 108.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  31: 
  32: From
  33: The Manchester Courier and Lancashire General Advertiser
  34: , Wednesday, 24 January, 1900.
  35: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  36: This early poem was prefaced with a reference to Canon Hick's sermon: "Manchester Cathedral, January 21st 1900.
  37: 
  38: The title, "Hic Jacet" is Latin and translates as "here lies" or an "epitaph" and the poet is making a play on words.
  39: 
  40: The column heading over the poem is "RADICAL CLERICS AND THE WAR.
  41: 
  42: " For the poet to call the poem "HIC(KS) JACET" indicates that she is directing the poem towards Canon Hicks, of Manchester Cathedral, who was criticized by three other correspondents to the paper for remarks he had made - from the pulpit - concerning the Boer War.
  43: 
  44: The poet was an ardent supporter of the British in their war against the Boers of South Africa.
  45: 
  46: She followed the campaign closely in the newspapers and wrote many poems in tribute to the ultimately victorious British troops.
  47: 
  48: "Gloze" means to minimize or underplay; gloss; as in, "glozed over the embarrassing part".
  49: 
  50: Thanks to Jake Wade for finding this poem and providing the valuable insights on what it means.
  51: 
  52: Charley Noble


====================================================================================================
#451: 101752_John Company's Ships_Smith, Cicely Fox_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: John Company's Ships
Author: Smith, Cicely Fox
Prose starts at line: 58
Lines to remove: 11
Avg verse line length: 45.7
Avg prose line length: 88.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  53: 
  54: The poet sub-titles this poem "East India Docks" to indicate at which point in her rovings (or "dock walloping" as she used to say) she recalled the memories of these fine ships and cargoes.
  55: 
  56: The term "John Company" was often used to describe the East India Company.
  57: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  58: The East India Company was not actually a single corporate body, consisting as it did of a variety of individuals and other interests but it was sufficiently closely linked to be treated as such.
  59: 
  60: Its ship's Captains and officers were not very well paid but were allowed sufficient space on board to trade for themselves as well as "the company" and so could earn a goodly amount.
  61: 
  62: The general crew had no such freedom.
  63: 
  64: The header graphic is by Phil W.
  65: 
  66: Smith, the poet's brother, and was used to illustrate this poem in ROVINGS.
  67: 
  68: Jim Saville


====================================================================================================

  59: 
  60: First published in PUNCH magazine, Volume 153, October 17, 1917, p.
  61: 
  62: 274.
  63: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  64: In the context of the time, the beginning of World War 1, "Hank" is a surrogate for all Germans.
  65: 
  66: Although Hank is apparently oblivious that the War had begun, he gets evicted from his comfortable abode by his savior when M'Larty learns of the War, and an entirely innocent concertina gets destroyed.
  67: 
  68: Still M'Larty is somewhat constrained by the fact that he saved Hank's life and doesn't bash his head in.
  69: 
  70: Charley Noble

#454: 101790_Lumber_Smith, Cicely Fox_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Lumber
Author: Smith, Cicely Fox
Prose starts at line: 68
Lines to remove: 11
Avg verse line length: 31.0
Avg prose line length: 122.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  63: 
  64: 33-34; first published in PUNCH magazine, Volume 160, January 12, 1921 p.
  65: 
  66: 30.
  67: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  68: The poet was based in Victoria, British Columbia, for much of the time that she was on the West Coast of Canada, roughly 1904 to 1913.
  69: 
  70: She describes in vivid detail walking the docks, watching the sunsets, admiring the sailing ships, listening to the yarns of the ship-keepers and other sailors, and nosing around the waterfront.
  71: 
  72: The Village of Steveston is located in Richmond, BC, adjacent to Vancouver where she likely also visited.
  73: 
  74: Curiously, there is no record of a Steveston Lumber Mill, although lumber was shipped by rail to Steveston and then shipped out of its harbor to ports beyond.
  75: 
  76: The header image is of lumber being loaded into a ship with her "bow-ports open wide" at the Chemainus docks on Vancouver Island, BC.
  77: 
  78: Charley Noble

#455: 101802_The Good Intent_Smith, Cicely Fox_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Good Intent
Author: Smith, Cicely Fox
Prose starts at line: 94
Lines to remove: 8
Avg verse line length: 33.3
Avg prose line length: 89.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  89: 
  90: Later reprinted in the same form in RHYMES OF THE RED ENSIGN in 1919, pp.
  91: 
  92: 59-62.
  93: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  94: "Farmer George" is a reference to King George III of England the reigning monarch (1760-1820) when The Good Intent was built and first sailed.
  95: 
  96: "Seventy-four" is a reference to a ship-of-line having 74 guns, a major class of fighting ships in the Napoleonic period.
  97: 
  98: The poet added this note:
  99: The ketch "Good Intent", built at Plymouth of British oak 128 years ago, is probably the oldest (1919) British merchant-vessel afloat.
 100: 
 101: Charley Noble & Jim Saville

#456: 101803_Dan's Epitaph_Smith, Cicely Fox_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Dan's Epitaph
Author: Smith, Cicely Fox
Prose starts at line: 40
Lines to remove: 13
Avg verse line length: 28.9
Avg prose line length: 86.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  35: 
  36: , London, UK, © 1931, pp.
  37: 
  38: 80-81.
  39: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  40: This is another tribute by the poet to one of her favorite sea shanty and yarn sources, and possibly close personal friend, who was lost at sea.
  41: 
  42: "whack" is a reference to what a sailor was supposed to get every day for rations according to the current shipping regulations.
  43: 
  44: It is still a common term in the England for one's allotted portion.
  45: 
  46: "trick" is a reference to a period of time when the sailor has a specific task to do such as manning the helm or standing watch.
  47: 
  48: The header graphic is from a photograph taken of the assistant sailmaker by Eric Newby while serving aboard the four-masted steel barque
  49: Moshula
  50: in 1938-39; it is not really a photo of Dan but maybe a good stand-in.
  51: 
  52: Charley Noble

#458: 101807_Mother Carey_Smith, Cicely Fox_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Mother Carey
Author: Smith, Cicely Fox
Prose starts at line: 42
Lines to remove: 12
Avg verse line length: 50.9
Avg prose line length: 121.7

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  37: 
  38: This version taken from SONGS & CHANTIES: 1914-1916, edited by Cicely Fox Smith, published by Elkin Mathews, London, UK, © 1919, pp.
  39: 
  40: 100-102.
  41: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  42: It also appears in her earlier book Sailor Town: Sea Songs and Ballads, Elkin Mathews, 1914
  43: "Mother Carey" as a nautical fantasy character is no benevolent spirit as the poet undoubtedly knew, being familiar with John Masefield's poem "Mother Carey (as told me by the Bo'sun).
  44: 
  45: " Mother Carey in sailor's legends is the wife of Davy Jones and they dwell together under the ocean and call to sailor's in the same way as siren's in order to drown them.
  46: 
  47: This poem was probably composed near the end of her stay in Victoria, British Columbia, when she was apprehensive about the fate of her beloved "shipmate" Dan who was ultimately lost at sea.
  48: 
  49: The "Strait" referred to in the poem is Juan de Fuca and the "lighthouse blinking" is on Race Ledge.
  50: 
  51: Tom Lewis (CA) has adapted this poem for singing as recorded on TINKER TAILOR SOLDIER SINGER!, © 1995.
  52: 
  53: Charley Noble

Title: The China Sea
Author: Smith, Cicely Fox
Prose starts at line: 52
Lines to remove: 7
Avg verse line length: 57.1
Avg prose line length: 97.6

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  47: 
  48: This version taken from SONGS AND CHANTIES: 1914-1916, edited by Cicely Fox Smith, published by Elkin Mathews, London, UK, © 1919, pp.
  49: 
  50: 92-94.
  51: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  52: It also appears in her earlier book Sailor Town: Sea Songs and Ballads, Elkin Mathews, 1914
  53: The Peter (or the blue peter) is the name given to a square blue flag with a white centre square that indicates a ship is outward bound
  54: "Hooker" is sailor slang for any old ship and in this case we have a classic old rust bucket heading out for maybe her last voyage.
  55: 
  56: "Plimsoll line" is a reference to an official waterline indicating the maximum that a ship could be legally loaded to.

#461: 101819_Salvage_Smith, Cicely Fox_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Salvage
Author: Smith, Cicely Fox
Prose starts at line: 42
Lines to remove: 8
Avg verse line length: 44.1
Avg prose line length: 102.6

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  37: 
  38: and reprinted in RHYMES OF THE RED ENSIGN, p.
  39: 
  40: 41, but without the final line.
  41: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  42: Composed during the first year of World War 1 as a tribute to the sailors in the merchant marine.
  43: 
  44: Their life may not have had the "glamour" of battle but it did have the danger even if, as in this case, it is of running aground and having to await rescue in imminent danger of enemy attack.
  45: 
  46: NB
  47: Cicely Fox Smith naturally used the English spelling as she was an Englishwoman but she also used vernacular spelling or the phonetic equivalent of the speech of the day, especially sailor speak.
  48: 
  49: Charley Noble & Jim Saville

#464: 101849_The Conversation Book_Smith, Cicely Fox_unknown.txt

Title: The Conversation Book
Author: Smith, Cicely Fox
Prose starts at line: 44
Lines to remove: 9
Avg verse line length: 56.6
Avg prose line length: 111.4

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  39: 
  40: First published in PUNCH magazine, Volume 149, December 8, 1915, p.
  41: 
  42: 470.
  43: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  44: The poet is said to have served in World War 1 as a volunteer and no doubt heard an ironic conversation like this which haunted her until she transformed it into a poem.
  45: 
  46: It captures a moment, amidst unbearable chaos, when people from different cultures can still connect as simple human beings.
  47: 
  48: Tipperary  ---  Refers to the popular soldiers marching song "It's a long way to Tipperary" which every British "Tommy" and French soldier would have known.

#465: 101856_London River_Smith, Cicely Fox_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: London River
Author: Smith, Cicely Fox
Prose starts at line: 32
Lines to remove: 7
Avg verse line length: 50.4
Avg prose line length: 102.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  27: 
  28: Crowell, New York, US, © 1918, p.
  29: 
  30: 48.
  31: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  32: In tribute to the merchant sailors in World War 1 who after being mined or torpedoed went back to sea on the next available ship.
  33: 
  34: "Peter at the fore" is a reference to the Blue Peter signal flag that was flown to inform sailors ashore that their ship was about to leave.
  35: 
  36: "Duster" or sometimes "Red Duster" refers to the British Mechant Navy's ensign flown on merchant ships at sea.
  37: 
  38: Jim Saville and Charley Noble

#466: 101857_The Charge Of The 21st Lancers_Smith, Cicely Fox_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Charge Of The 21st Lancers
Author: Smith, Cicely Fox
Prose starts at line: 34
Lines to remove: 9
Avg verse line length: 47.2
Avg prose line length: 89.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  29: , London, UK, © 1899, pp.
  30: 
  31: 43-44.
  32: 
  33: Note by the poet:

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  34: "At the battle of Omdurman, September 2nd, 1898, the 21st Lancers were ordered to clear off a number of Dervishes who were harassing our troops.
  35: 
  36: The number was much greater than was believed when the order was given, owing to a depression in the ground which sheltered a large force.
  37: 
  38: The loss of life among the Lancers was very heavy.
  39: 
  40: In B troop, only four men out of twenty rallied at the further side.
  41: 
  42: Contributed by Ian "Nobby" Dye of Bristol, UK.

#467: 101859_A Meeting_Smith, Cicely Fox_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: A Meeting
Author: Smith, Cicely Fox
Prose starts at line: 35
Lines to remove: 15
Avg verse line length: 28.4
Avg prose line length: 60.6

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  30: South o' Cape Stiff in the frost and the hail --
  31: Wherever we be
  32: Fact is that we
  33: Can't meet without scrapping, can't Billy and me,
  34: And -- just like old times it was, Billy and me!

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  35: Unpublished poem composed at Stoke Charity, Sutton Scotney, Hampshire between 1933 and 1938; from the archives of the National Maritime Museum, Greenwich, UK.
  36: 
  37: There is another similar "Billy Magee" poem in this collection entitled "Follow The Sea".
  38: 
  39: Smith may not have thought this one was good enough to have published.
  40: 
  41: There is also a poem with "Billy" in more reflective mood "The Eternal Feminine".
  42: 
  43: Charley Noble

  45:

  47: http://oldpoetry.
  48: 
  49: com/opoem/56620-Cicely-Fox-Smith-The-Eternal-Feminine

#470: 101902_Omdurman_Smith, Cicely Fox_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Omdurman
Author: Smith, Cicely Fox
Prose starts at line: 36
Lines to remove: 13
Avg verse line length: 39.8
Avg prose line length: 73.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  31: Avenged is Gordon slain!
  32: This was taken from pages 41-42 of Miss Fox Smith's book Songs of Greater Britain (and other poems) published by Sherratt and Hughes, 27 St.
  33: 
  34: Anne's Street, Manchester, England in 1899.
  35: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  36: It was published when she was only 19 years of age and shortly after she, like the rest of Great Britain, had undergone the mass celebrations for Queen Victoria's Diamond Jubilee in 1897.
  37: 
  38: It is hardly surprising that this last mass celebration of the British Empire at it's height influenced the young Cicely to such patriotic outpourings.
  39: 
  40: It is fairly obviously a reference to the British victory on 1898 over the forces of Mahdi Mohammed Ahmed, Abdullah al-Taashi following the defeat and death of General Gordon at Khartoum in 1885.
  41: 
  42: ref:
  43: http://en.
  44: 
  45: wikipedia.
  46: 
  47: org/wiki/BattleofOmdurman
  48: JS

#472: 101908_In Memoriam- H.M.S. Warspite_Smith, Cicely Fox_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: In Memoriam: H.M.S. Warspite
Author: Smith, Cicely Fox
Prose starts at line: 31
Lines to remove: 16
Avg verse line length: 30.9
Avg prose line length: 55.9

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  26: 
  27: From PUNCH Magazine, Volume 212, May 14, 1947, p.
  28: 
  29: 411.
  30: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  31: In 1947 HMS Warspite, originally a World War 1 Queen Elizabeth class battleship, en route to the breakers yard, was wrecked.
  32: 
  33: She had broken free from her tugs near the Wolf Rock and was the largest wreck ever to occur on the Cornish coast.
  34: 
  35: Her boilers still lie off St.
  36: 
  37: Michael's Mount.
  38: 
  39: The header graphic is a photo taken of the HMS Warspite during World War 2 in the Indian Ocean by Lieutenant D.
  40: 
  41: C.
  42: 
  43: Oulds, a Royal Navy official photographer; it is in the public domain.
  44: 
  45: Thanks to Barrie Mathers
  46: Charley Noble

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  40: 
  41: First published in PUNCH magazine, Volume 159, July 21, 1920, p.
  42: 
  43: 46.
  44: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  45: Here we have a vivid picture of how an old sailor might have described you and your messmates aboard one of those tall sailing ships at the close of the 19th century.
  46: 
  47: The crew of a ship was not exactly a "melting pot" but if you learned your work and "pulled your weight with a will" you earned the respect of the old shellbacks regardless of where you came from.
  48: 
  49: Of course, if you were the son of a prominent shipping family, you got a head start but you still needed to demonstrate capability to earn respect and promotion.
  50: 
  51: The header graphic by nautical artist Gordon Grant shows some of these sailors.
  52: 
  53: Charley Noble

Title: Lee Fore Brace
Author: Smith, Cicely Fox
Prose starts at line: 69
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 41.9
Avg prose line length: 96.5

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  64: 
  65: This long exposure to shared danger created strong bonds of friendship and brotherly love between mariners.
  66: 
  67: And the loss of a such a friend was at least as sad as the loss of a wife or parent.
  68: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  69: Here the poet describes with chilling accuracy the loss of Dan from such a point of view.
  70: 
  71: The frequent use of the name in her poetry makes me think she had a specific Dan in mind which makes the second half of the poem particularly moving.
  72: 
  73: This description of the incident displays her uncanny familiarity with shipboard life as hauling on the lee fore brace is one of the most dangerous jobs in a storm, with the bow plunging and rolling in mountainous seas.
  74: 
  75: "Mile-long greybeards" are large foam topped waves stretching wide across the ship's course.
  76: 
  77: "Brace" is one of the many thick ropes used to adjust the yards.
  78: 
  79: "Callao" is the largest and most important port in Peru.
  80: 
  81: This poem was adapted for singing in 1995 by Alan Fitzsimmons, as recorded on SEABOOT DUFF & HANDSPIKE GRUEL by Pinch o' Salt in 2000.
  82:

  84: 
  85: 31, and shows a crew hauling on the lee fore brace.
  86: 
  87: Jim Saville

  46:

  48:

  50: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]

  51: Here the poet gives the thoughts of a sailor who had been a part of the crew that were forced to abandon ship.
  52:

#482: 102005_Granfer Scroodle_Smith, Cicely Fox_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Granfer Scroodle
Author: Smith, Cicely Fox
Prose starts at line: 84
Lines to remove: 14
Avg verse line length: 25.9
Avg prose line length: 71.5

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  79: 
  80: A mark made by scoodle in place of a signature as he could not write.
  81: 
  82: When "he went west" is a colloquial expression meaning when he died.
  83: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  84: "He cut his cloth exceeding fine" is a polite way of saying he was very careful with his money.
  85: 
  86: It refers to an old saying "cut one's coat according to one's cloth" not that he was mean!
  87: "Four-and-nine" is Four Shillings and Nine pence [approx £0.
  88: 
  89: 28 modern money].
  90: 
  91: "His club deposits" In many areas it was common to pay a given amount a week into a burial fund (or club ) as a sort of insurance scheme to ensure you did not end up in a pauper's grave.
  92: 
  93: Such schemes still exist today.
  94: 
  95: "Benefit" in the final stanza again refers to the national assistance as it was then known.
  96: 
  97: JS

#483: 102006_Odyssey_Smith, Cicely Fox_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Odyssey
Author: Smith, Cicely Fox
Prose starts at line: 63
Lines to remove: 8
Avg verse line length: 38.1
Avg prose line length: 133.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  58: ” Said he.
  59: 
  60: From Punch,  April 4, 1934,  page 386
  61: "‘Omers" –  refers to Homer’s Odyssey
  62: "Billyboy" –  refers to a type of ship

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  63: "Preachin’ skipper"  –  many of the skippers were very religious and would hold compulsory services on deck almost daily.
  64: 
  65: "Signed on and paid off" – each sailor had to actually sign on board a ship (or make a mark) at the start of a voyage and at the end he would have to pay off any debts he incurred from purchases from ships stores for clothing etc.
  66: 
  67: "Blowed it" –  in this case means spending your money quickly (and probably unwisely)
  68: "The tack" – in this case tack refers to the food.
  69: 
  70: "Kicking mate" – Discipline could be hard on board a ship and a kicking mate was an officer who enforced his orders with his boots  (sometimes a kicking was called sea boot duff).


====================================================================================================
#484: 102009_The Implacable_Smith, Cicely Fox_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Implacable
Author: Smith, Cicely Fox
Prose starts at line: 42
Lines to remove: 9
Avg verse line length: 24.9
Avg prose line length: 109.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  37: First published Jan 20 1926 Punch p58 attributed to C.
  38: 
  39: F.
  40: 
  41: S

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  42: The HMS Implacable was a captured French ship formerly Duguay-Trouin captured during the Napoleonic Wars and put to use by the admiralty eventually becoming a training ship.
  43: 
  44: This poem was written by CFS to support a [successful] fund raising effort to refit her to continue in that task.
  45: 
  46: She finally left service and was commemorated by another CFS poem.
  47: 
  48: NB
  49: Cicely Fox Smith naturally used the English spelling as she was an Englishwoman but she also used vernacular spelling or the phonetic equivalent of the speech of the day, especially sailor speak
  50: Agin is therefore correctly spelt reference to the pronounciation of again and not an abbreviation or mis-type.

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 124: 
 125: From SHIPS AND FOLKS, edited by Cicely Fox Smith, published by Elkin Mathews, London, UK, © 1920, pp.
 126: 
 127: 28-32.
 128: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 129: Here we learn that an old shipmate has died, and the person hearing the news just can't quite believe it, and hopes that maybe somehow the news is incorrect and they may meet yet again.
 130: 
 131: I'm convinced that the pain and shock expressed in this poem is no idle poetic exercise and that the poem is a veiled reference to the loss of the poet's old shipmate Dan.
 132: 
 133: The header graphic is of a young sailor, a close friend of nautical historian Alan Villiers, who also lost his life falling from a yard in a Cape Horn gale in 1929.

  57: 
  58: "Barque" is a type of sailing boat not to be confused with a barge.
  59: 
  60: "Dead Men's Shoes" means just what it says.
  61: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  62: If a sailor were lost at sea his kit would be divided up between his mates for momentoes and the remainder sold off by the captain and, surprisingly often, the money sent to his family when the ship returned to its home port.
  63: 
  64: The poet arranged to have Alice Lee Wiley compose music for this poem so that it might be sung in the schools: published by Leonard, Gould & Bolttler, London, UK, © 1930 by Paul A Schmitt Music Co.
  65: 
  66: ; the song is dedicated to Everton Stidham.

Author: Smith, Cicely Fox
Prose starts at line: 62
Lines to remove: 9
Avg verse line length: 55.0
Avg prose line length: 98.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  57: From WINGS OF THE MORNING, edited by Cicely Fox Smith, published by Elkin Mathews, London, UK, © 1904, pp.
  58: 
  59: 57-59.
  60: 
  61: Notes from Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia:

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  62: "On January 22, 1879, Isandlwana was the site of the Battle of Isandlwana, where over 20,000 Zulu warriors defeated a contingent of British soldiers in the first engagement of the Anglo-Zulu War.
  63: 
  64: Almost the entire column of about 1,200 British soldiers was killed, and the regimental colours were lost.
  65: 
  66: Miss Fox Smith's line
  67: Only to save the colours -- tho' all beside be lost
  68: refers to the effort to save the colours that led to 2 posthumous Victoria Crosses for the young officers inolved (although these were not granted until 1907, a few years after this poem was published).
  69: 
  70: Charley Noble

#494: 102068_Shanghai Passage_Smith, Cicely Fox_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Shanghai Passage
Author: Smith, Cicely Fox
Prose starts at line: 67
Lines to remove: 20
Avg verse line length: 52.2
Avg prose line length: 79.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  62: It's not clear why the port of Shanghai has been associated with this term unless forced recruitment by shipping agents was the only way to secure a crew for such a long voyage.
  63: 
  64: "Rampin'" is an archaic slang word which means rampaging.
  65: 
  66: Lauderdale's

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  67: port watch"  — a ship's crew was divided into a number of groups called watches, usually port-watch and starboard-watch, that could be worked in shifts.
  68: 
  69: When in port it was usual practice to allow the sailors liberty one watch at a time.
  70: 
  71: Lauderdale's
  72: port watch" is therefore a section of crew from a recently docked ship.
  73: 
  74: "Seaboot duff" is a euphemism for a good kicking.
  75: 
  76: "Handspike gruel" is a euphemism for blood.
  77: 
  78: "Belayin'-pins" are large wooden pegs for tying off sails but often used as weapons.
  79: 
  80: "To tally on the fall" means to grab hold of a line that is hanging down and haul away on it.
  81: 
  82: This poem has been adapted for singing by Alan Fitzsimmons as recorded on SEA BOOT DUFF & HAND SPIKE GRUEL by Pinch o' Salt, © 2000.
  83: 
  84: The header graphic is from SHANGHAIED IN SAN FRANCISCO, by Bill Pickelhaupt, the front cover; the source of the original graphic is unknown.
  85: 
  86: Jim Saville


====================================================================================================
#495: 102089_Caesar's Camp_Smith, Cicely Fox_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Caesar's Camp
Author: Smith, Cicely Fox
Prose starts at line: 49
Lines to remove: 6
Avg verse line length: 39.9
Avg prose line length: 109.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

  49: "Caesar's Camp" was a British defended strong point in one of the first major battles in the Boer War:
  50: "The first battle of 1900 in South Africa took place on January 6, when Boer forces, commanded by General Joubert, tried to drive the British from their positions inside Ladysmith.
  51: 
  52: Ten thousand British troops, commanded by General Sir George White, defended the besieged town, which they had held for more than two months.

#496: 102093_The Casuarina Tree (Southern Rhodesia)_Smith, Cicely Fox_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Casuarina Tree (Southern Rhodesia)
Author: Smith, Cicely Fox
Prose starts at line: 56
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 27.1
Avg prose line length: 66.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  51: The poet visited Southern Rhodesia in her trip around Africa in 1938, trekking far inland to pay homage to the graves of her youthful heroes Cecil John Rhodes and Leander Starr Jameson.
  52: 
  53: Thanks to Barrie Mathers
  54: Charley Noble
  55: Glossary:

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  56: Duiker ---- Any of various small African antelopes of the genera Cephalophus or Sylvicapra, having short, backward-pointing horns.
  57: 
  58: Kloof ---- South Africa mountain pass: a gorge or mountain pass, usually wooded.
  59: 
  60: It is similar to the English dialect word clough for the same features.
  61: 
  62: Kraal ---- A rural village, typically consisting of huts surrounded by a stockade OR An enclosure for livestock.
  63: 
  64: This latter meaning is very similar to the American term Corral.
  65: 
  66: Causarina tree ---- A small tree, shrub that is considered one of the most versatile tree species in the tropics.
  67: 
  68: (C.
  69: 
  70: equisetifolia).
  71: 
  72: It is used for boomerangs, buildings and burning amongst other things.
  73: 
  74: JS

#497: 102096_In Sailortown_Smith, Cicely Fox_unknown.txt

Title: In Sailortown
Author: Smith, Cicely Fox
Prose starts at line: 73
Lines to remove: 9
Avg verse line length: 27.0
Avg prose line length: 103.6

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  68: 
  69: , New York, US, © 1926, pp.
  70: 
  71: 72-74.
  72: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  73: Here the poet is thinking back to the dockyard areas she knew and loved so well from Victoria, British Columbia, to those back in her homeland of England.
  74: 
  75: She uses the sailors' slang of the time in characterizing what she remembers and such characterizations often grate on our more culturally sensitized ears.
  76: 
  77: She shared that practice with other notable poets of her time such as Kipling and Masefield.
  78: 
  79: "Sojers" (soldiers) is put-down nautical slang for sailors who were not qualified as able-bodied seamen.
  80: 
  81: Charley Noble

#498: 102107_South Sea Whaler. “Scrimshaw” Model_Smith, Cicely Fox_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: South Sea Whaler. “Scrimshaw” Model
Author: Smith, Cicely Fox
Prose starts at line: 57
Lines to remove: 10
Avg verse line length: 18.3
Avg prose line length: 103.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  52: 
  53: Taken from Punch Magazine, June 14, 1933, p.
  54: 
  55: 
  56: Thanks to Barry Mathers

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  57: This was a poem about model boats that didn't make the cut for the poet's book about model boats.
  58: 
  59: "Harpooner" is a strong sailor who could throw the harpoon accurately, a skilled trade
  60: "Scrimshaw" is the art of carving and engraving of whalebone artifacts and the finished product.
  61: 
  62: Many whalermen would while away their time on long trips in this way and produce both utilitarian and decorative pieces.
  63: 
  64: "Tryworks" is a device for rendering whale blubber into whale oil on board ship.
  65: 
  66: "Nantucket sleigh rides" describes the very harrowing and dangerous time when a harpooned whale sped away towing the small whaleboat behind.

#499: 102120_Ex-Voto Breton Church Model_Smith, Cicely Fox_unknown.txt

Title: Ex-Voto Breton Church Model
Author: Smith, Cicely Fox
Prose starts at line: 74
Lines to remove: 11
Avg verse line length: 37.2
Avg prose line length: 76.3

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  69: 
  70: Many early sailors were both religious and superstitious and would not dream of setting out on a voyage without visiting their favourite shrine.
  71: 
  72: In some of these shrines there were models of the ships they would sail.
  73: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  74: These models (those that still remain) are the clearest descriptions of the earliest boats.
  75: 
  76: This poem was composed by the poet after a visit to such a sailor's church in San Telmo in Las Palmas.
  77: 
  78: The name of the ship in the title of this poem, Ex-Voto, should be italicized but was not because it would interfer with searching for this poem on this website.
  79: 
  80: The header graphic is a photograph from the same book, p.
  81: 
  82: 97, and shows this early model ship.
  83: 
  84: Jim Saville

#500: 102121_Departure_Smith, Cicely Fox_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Departure
Author: Smith, Cicely Fox
Prose starts at line: 65
Lines to remove: 13
Avg verse line length: 31.1
Avg prose line length: 71.6

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  60: 301.
  61: 
  62: Glossary:
  63: "Dusted my jacket"  implies he was beaten.
  64: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  65: "Barkey" is intended to be a sailor's pronounciation of Barque, a type of sailing ship.
  66: 
  67: "Halliard chorus" many of the jobs on board ship would have been done with the help of a shanty and there were different types of shanty for different types of job.
  68: 
  69: A halliard chorus was markedly different to a pumping chorus.
  70: 
  71: "Divil" is of course a colloquialism for devil
  72: NOTE
  73: In terms of the mores and manners of the day the term "darkey" was used for anybody with a dark coloured skin tone and was not seen as insulting.
  74: 
  75: It is preserved here for textual accuracy.
  76: 
  77: Thanks to Barrie Mathers

Avg prose line length: 104.6

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  33: 86-88.
  34: 
  35: It also appears in her earlier book Sailor Town: Sea Songs and Ballads, Elkin Mathews, 1914
  36: L2 "Her lines  upon the water" is a reference to the shape of the ship.
  37: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  38: L9 "seagull's piping" is a built in comparison between the call of the gulls and that of a bosun's pipe.
  39: 
  40: L11 "donkey's breakfast" is a reference to the palliasse filled with straw used as a matress by sailors.
  41: 
  42: L18 "pay you now your score" is a reference to a sailor settling up his debts at the drinking dens (maybe with signing-on money) before he sets sail again.
  43: 
  44: L20 "away my rolling river" is believed to be a reference to an outward bound shanty sung as the ship leaves port.
  45: 
  46: Another poem about the need to follow the sea.

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   2: 
   3: I watch a squirrel get run over by a car on my walk to work.
   4: 
   5: She is lying dead in the street and still has an acorn in her little hands.
   6: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   7: I am amazed at how she is able to hold on to her acorn after being tumbled like that, after bouncing so high off the street.
   8: 
   9: I walk over to the squirrel and see that her face is blown to bits and looks like uncased sausage spilling onto the asphalt.
  10: 
  11: But that acorn is still so tight in her hands.
  12: 
  13: I pick her up by her tail, take off my dress shirt and swaddle her in it, then put her in my bag.
  14: 
  15: I know right where she is as I walk into work, everybody looking at me, everybody asking me about my shirtlessness.
  16: 
  17: The world is as steady as if it were sewn into the skin of the universe.

   1: The One About the Robbers
   2: 
   3: You tell me a joke about two robbers who hide from the police.
   4: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   5: One robber hides as a sack of cats and the other robber hides as a sack of potatoes.
   6: 
   7: That is the punch line somehow, the sack of potatoes, but all I can think about is how my dad used to throw me over his shoulder when I was very small and call me his sack of potatoes.
   8: 
   9: I’ve got a sack of potatoeshe would yell, spinning around in a circle, the arm not holding me reaching out for a sale.
  10: 
  11: Does anyone want to buy my sack of potatoes?
  12: 
  13: No one ever wanted to buy me.
  14: 
  15: We were always the only two people in the room.

  36: 
  37: Fire in your mother’s belly.
  38: 
  39: There is a little boy wearing a fire shirt holding a baby lamb.
  40: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  41: There is a little girl in a fire skirt asking if she can ride the baby lamb like a horse.
  42: 
  43: There is you on top of me with thighs of fire while a hot red fog hovers in your hair.
  44: 
  45: There is me on top of you wearing a fire shirt and then pulling the fire shirt over my head and tossing it like a fireball through the fog at a new kind of dinosaur.
  46: 
  47: There are meteorites disintegrating in the atmosphere just a few thousand feet above us and tiny fireballs are falling down around us, pooling around us, forming a kind of fire lake which then forms a kind of fire cloud.
  48: 
  49: There is this feeling I get when I am with you.
  50: 
  51: There is our future house burning like a star on the hill.
  52: 
  53: There is our dark flickering shadow.
  54: 
  55: There is my hand on fire in your hand on fire, my body on fire above your body on fire, our tongues made of ash.
  56: 
  57: We are rocks on a distant and uninhabitable planet.
  58: 
  59: We have our whole life ahead of us.

  71: He sat at his desk again.
  72: 
  73: Another one?
  74: 
  75: This time he drafted:

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  76: After he calligraphed the puzzle of passion across the page, he woke the one in the pond of pink silk, and they proved it on the futon.
  77: 
  78: He heard the pluvial patter on the eaves, while they angled and slipped, perspiring on silk.
  79: 
  80: The stamping and snorting of the horses sweating in their armor was far too far away to be sensed by P, but he heard.
  81: 
  82: He felt the pond muddied and the roof cracked and the poems scattered.
  83: 
  84: How far was he now from this picture in his mind?
  85: 
  86: He worked to make his pleasure stay, pitiable and small against the portents rising, for P was afraid this afternoon would never be remembered after the bloody conquering.
  87: 
  88: But later the barbarians would bivouac in this house, the pond saved for drinking water, the path roughened by horses, and the  reverse of P’s scroll used for another man’s military diary, his afternoon’s foreboding and pleasure a preparation for the future, and in the future, a stay against another’s view of the past.
  89: 
  90: “P fromAlphabetique,” 2013 by Kara Kosaka

  29: (This one is white and in Chula Vista), and the paraphernalia
  30: Strewn around home: a few magazines summing up politics,
  31: A matchbox with a lavender automobile on the cover,

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]

  36:

  38: And are sold on the street in Tijuana.
  39:

  41: Their heads are always cocked to pick up something behind them.
  42: 
  43: And unless you have lived in a place where the fog
  44: Closes in like a face, it is impossible to be (even temporarily) relieved
  45: When it lifts to expose the freshly painted trim of the city, and it seems
  46: Like a fine day for knowledge: sunlight sleeping on top of the rocks
  47: And lots of white clouds scudding by like clean sheets
  48: Which, when the air in the bedroom is cold, you pull over your head
  49: And let the temperature slowly increase while you breathe.
  50: 
  51: But California has only a coast in common with this.

Prose starts at line: 3

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]

   1: Ninety-Fifth Street
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: Words can bang around in your headForever, if you let them and you give them room.
   4: 
   5: I used to love poetry, and mostly I still do,Though sometimes “I, too, dislike it.
   6: 
   7: ” There must beSomething real beyond the fiddle and perfunctoryConsolations and the quarrels—as of courseThere is, though what it is is difficult to say.
   8: 
   9: The salt is on the briar rose, the fog is in the fir trees.
  10: 
  11: I didn’t know what it was, and I don’t know now,But it was what I started out to do, and now, a lifetime later,All I’ve really done.
  12: 
  13: The Opening of the Field,Roots and Branches, Rivers and Mountains: I sat in my roomAlone, their fragments shored against the ruin or revelationThat was sure to come, breathing in their secret atmosphere,Repeating them until they almost seemed my own.
  14: 
  15: We like to think our lives are what they study to become,And yet so much of life is waiting, waiting on a whim.
  16: 
  17: So much of what we are is sheer coincidence,Like a sentence whose significance is retrospective,Made up out of elementary particles that are in some senseSimply sounds, like syllables that finally settle into place.
  18: 
  19: You probably think that this is a poem about poetry(And obviously it is), yet its real subject is time,For that’s what poetry is—a way to live through timeAnd sometimes, just for a while, to bring it back.
  20: 
  21: *     *     *
  22: *     *     *

#513: 102459_Like Gods_Koethe, John_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Like Gods
Author: Koethe, John
Prose starts at line: 81
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 117.6
Avg prose line length: 178.7

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  76: 
  77: Hopkins: “searching nature I tasteselfat one tankard, that of my own being.
  78: 
  79: ” Kant: “thefeelingof an existence without the least concept,” meaning that despite the certainty I have, I’ve no idea what I really am, or where, and as for “searching nature,” I have no idea even where to start.
  80: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  81: These matters mean the world to me, and yet no matter how I try to come to grips with them, they slip away.
  82: 
  83: Iandhereandnoware ever present, yet they vanish in the act of apprehension, as a poem turns into language as you write it down.
  84: 
  85: Dimensionless, atemporal, imprisoned in the present—even as I say them to myself the words fall short of what I thought I started out to say, like the conclusion of an argument too close to me to share, or like an empty thought balloon that hangs above me in the air.
  86: 
  87: It’s not the question of what makes me who I am through time—of how a figure in a photograph from 1985, a couple sitting in the garden of the small Hôtel des Marronniers just off the rue Jacob, could be the person who remembers her and thinks of him today—but of what constitutes me now, and of what made me then.
  88: 
  89: If giving it a name won’t help, then neither will pretending it’s divine.
  90: 
  91: If I should be supplanted by a bright recording angel knowing everything about me in the way the gods know all about their world, I wouldn’t have survived.
  92: 
  93: She takes the whole thing in—the house on Maxim Street, the bike rides down the hill on Wabash Street, my high school friends, their friends, the friends of friends of friends—with eyes that monitor my back, my face, the traces in my brain projected on a screen, thendegrees of separation linking me to nearly everyone who’s ever lived, a thing within a wilderness of things, with each one locked inside a universe with no outside, of which there’s nothing she can see.
  94: 
  95: How could it be an afterlife?
  96: 
  97: It’s just a different life, another life, complete or incomplete as anyone’s, consumed by questions that elude it, not because she can’t remember, but because the words that make them up are undefined: which one of them was I?
  98: 
  99: which world was mine?

Prose starts at line: 3

Avg verse line length: 13.0
Avg prose line length: 99.9

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: The Strangers
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: After we picked you up at the Omaha airport, we clamped you into a new car seat and listened to you yowl beneath the streetlights of Nebraska.
   4: 
   5: Our hotel suite was plump with toys, ready, we hoped, to soothe you into America.
   6: 
   7: But for a solid hour you watched the door, shrieking, Umma, the Korean word for mother.
   8: 
   9: Once or twice you glanced back at us and, in this netherworld where a door home had slammed shut forever, your terrified eyes paced between the past and the future.
  10: 
  11: Umma, you screamed, Umma! But your foster mother back in Seoul never appeared.
  12: 
  13: Your new mother and I lay on the bed, cooing your birth name, until, at last, you collapsed into our arms.
  14: 
  15: In time, even terror must yield to sleep.

Title: Alone Amongst Nature

Prose starts at line: 19

Avg prose line length: 116.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
