  14: 
  15: What spell turns you away from me?
  16: 
  17: Is some new girl the root of your anger?
  18: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  19: You can give yourself to me again, fickle girl, since no other has ever set lovely foot on my threshold.
  20: 
  21: Though my sorrow’s indebted to you for much grief, my anger will not be so fierce with you that rage would ever be justified in you, or your weeping eyes be disfigured with falling tears.
  22: 
  23: Is it because I show few signs of altered complexion, and my faith does not shout aloud in my face?
  24: 
  25: Beech-tree and pine, beloved of the Arcadian god, you will be witnesses, if trees know these passions.
  26: 
  27: Oh, how often my words echo under gentle shadows, and Cynthia is carved in your bark!
  28: Oh! How often has your injustice caused me pains that only your silent threshold knows?
  29: 
  30: I am used to suffering your tyrannous orders with diffidence, without moaning about it in noisy complaints.
  31: 
  32: For this I receive sacred springs, cold rocks, and rough sleep by a wilderness track: and whatever my complaining can tell of, must be uttered alone to melodious birds.
  33: 
  34: Yet whatever you are, let the woods echo ‘Cynthia’ to me, and let not the wild cliffs be free of your name.

#516: 102743_Death and Transience_Propertius, Sextus_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Death and Transience
Author: Propertius, Sextus
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 16
Avg verse line length: 20.0
Avg prose line length: 139.7

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Death and Transience
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: I do not fear the sad shadows, now, my Cynthia, or care about death, destined for the final fires: but this fear is harder to bear than my funeral procession, that perhaps my corpse would lack your love.
   4: 
   5: Cupid has not so lightly clung to my eyelids, that my dust can be void, love forgotten.
   6: 
   7: The hero, Protesilaus, could not forget his sweet wife even in the dark region: the Thessalian came as a shade to his former home, longing with ghostly hands to touch his delight.
   8: 
   9: Whatever I am there, I will always be known as your shadow: a great love crosses the shore of death.
  10: 
  11: Let the choir of lovely women of old, come to greet me there, those whom the spoils of Troy yielded to Argive men, none of whose beauty shall mean more to me than yours, Cynthia, and (O allow this, Earth, and be just) though a destined old age keeps you back, your bones will still be dear to my sad eyes.
  12: 
  13: May you, living, feel this when I am dust: then no place of death will be bitter to me.
  14: 
  15: How I fear lest you ignore my tomb, Cynthia, and some inimical passion draws you away from my ashes, and forces you, unwillingly, to dry the tears that fall!
  16: Constant threats will persuade a loyal girl.
  17: 
  18: So, while we can, let there be joy between lovers: no length of time’s enough for lasting love.

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: His Mistress’s Harshness.
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: First you must grieve, many times, at your mistress’s wrongs towards you, often requesting something, often being rejected.
   4: 
   5: And often chew your innocent fingernails in your teeth, and tap the ground nervously with your foot, in anger!
   6: My hair was drenched with scent: no use: nor my departing feet, delaying, with measured step.
   7: 
   8: Magic plants are worth nothing here, nor a Colchian witch of night, nor herbs distilled by Perimede’s hand, since we see no cause or visible blow from anywhere: still, it’s a dark path so many evils come by.
   9: 
  10: The patient doesn’t need a doctor, or a soft bed: it’s not the wind or weather hurts him.
  11: 
  12: He walks about – and suddenly his funeral startles his friends.
  13: 
  14: Whatever love is it’s unforeseen like this.
  15: 
  16: What deceitful fortune-teller have I not been victim of, what old woman has not pondered my dreams ten times?
  17: 
  18: If anyone wants to be my enemy, let him desire girls: and delight in boys if he wants to be my friend.
  19: 
  20: You go down the tranquil stream in a boat in safety: how can such tiny waves from the bank hurt you?
  21: 
  22: Often his mood alters with a single word: she will scarcely be satisfied with your blood.

   2: 
   3: Are you mad, then, that my anxiety does not stop you?
   4: 
   5: Am I less to you than chilly Illyria?
   6: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   7: Does he seem so great to you, whoever he is, that you’ll go anywhere the wind takes your sails, without me?
   8: 
   9: Can you hear the roar of the furious seas unmoved, and lie down on hard planks; tread the hoarfrost under your tender feet?
  10: 
  11: Cynthia, can you bear unaccustomed snow?
  12: 
  13: Oh, I wish that the days till the winter solstice were doubled, and the Pleiades delayed, the sailors sitting idle, the ropes be never loosed from the Tyrrhenian shore, and the hostile breezes not blow my prayers away! Yet may I never see such winds drop when your boat puts off, and the waves carry it onwards, leaving me rooted to the desolate strand, repeatedly crying out your cruelty with clenched fist.
  14: 
  15: Yet whatever you deserve from me, you who renounce me, may Sicilian Galatea not frown on your journey: pass with happy oars Epirus’s Acroceraunian cliffs, and be received by Illyrian Oricos’s calm waters.
  16: 
  17: No other girl will seduce me, mea vita, from bitterly uttering complaints about you at your threshold, nor will I fail to question the impatient sailors: ‘Tell in what harbour my girl is confined?
  18: 
  19: ’ and say ‘Though she lives on Thessaly’s shore, or beyond the Scythian, she’ll be mine.

  12:

  14: 
  15: And almost every night, soon as I slept, my poor brother would rise—dry mouth and bulging eyes (the way he’d dreamt himself!)—and haul me into the room, howling his stupid dream.
  16: 
  17: Truly convinced, I’d vowed to take him back to his primal state—child of the sun—and so we wandered, fed on wine from the caves and gypsy bread, me bound to find the place itself and the code.

   6: 
   7: If the issue is anorexia, taking starvation’s  dark spirit-flight, or anhedonia, running from  the skin’s having fun, consider the mushroom’s  fleshy erection, and the pumpkins, earth goddesses  and rotund Buddhas sprawled by compost’s funky aerosol.
   8: 
   9: For social phobia, desensitize among the rows  of corn’s parade, ticker tape leaves and Rasta tassels  that wind-strut and bring on the crows’ hop and rap.
  10: 
  11: Too much affect: meditate on potatoes, taciturn  as overturned stones.
  12: 
  13: Too little: visualize the hanging  tomatoes’ insides, the soft hearts, sentimental ornaments.
  14: 
  15: From the lettuce there is common sense for narcissism:  acceptance as side dish, garnish for a meaty sandwich.
  16: 
  17: If that leaf isn’t the dose, there’s always the soil  people shovel and level, rake and make wishful with seed,  feed leftovers from the compost’s vegan sewer,  the soil that wants for nothing and yields and yields.

 111: 
 112: 7th of April 1889: A woeful fact- that the human race is too extremely developed for its corporeal conditions, the nerves being evolved to an activity abnormal in such an enviroment.
 113: 
 114: Even the higher animals are in excess in this respect.
 115: 
 116: It may be questioned if Nature, or what we call nature, so far back as when she crossed the line from invertebrates to vertebrates, did not exceed her mission.
 117: 
 118: The planet does not supply the materials for happiness to higher existances.

  14: 
  15: We too are a species, I realized.
  16: 
  17: We too could know that as joy.

#533: 104804_“History of Scanderbeg” excerpt from Canto V_Frasheri, Naim_unknown.txt

Author: Frasheri, Naim
Prose starts at line: 31

Avg prose line length: 129.5

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  26: the blessed day is here!
  27: Field whiten, mount lighten,
  28: from valiant arms!
  29: In eagerness neigh the steed
  30: that king of Albania brings!

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  31: Epical poem “History of Scanderbeg” is the masterpiece of Naim Frashëri and is regarded as his poetic legacy for the fact that through this opus he expressed with pathos his ideals regarding liberation of Albania and the way to progress.
  32: 
  33: “History of Scanderbeg” is composed by 22 cantos in coherent timeline with the historical events.
  34: 
  35: In the core of this poem is the portrayal of Scanderbeg.
  36: 
  37: Naim has illustrated his portrait with romanticism, illuminated by European humanist principles and Albanian Renaissance ideals.

   8:

  12:

  18:

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]

   1: Thunder Can Break
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: FANFARE of drums, wooden bells: iron chapter; And our dividing airs are gathered home.
   4: 
   5: This day belong to a miracle of thunder; Iron has carried the forum With token gestures.
   6: 
   7: Thunder has spoken, Left no signatures: broken Barbaricans alone tell one tale the winds scatter.
   8: 
   9: Mountain or tower in sight, lo, your hostages - Iron has made, alas, masterpieces - Statuettes of legendary heroes - iron birds Held - fruit of flight - tight For barricaded in iron handiwork a miracle caged.
  10: 
  11: Bring them out we say, bring them out Faces and hands and feet, The stories behind the myth, the plot Which the ritual enacts.
  12: 
  13: Thunder can break - Earth, bind me fast - Obduracy, the disease of elephants.

#537: 105019_The Little Match Girl_McG, Knight of the White Elephant of Bur_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Little Match Girl
Author: McG, Knight of the White Elephant of Burmah William
Prose starts at line: 5
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 107.5
Avg prose line length: 189.5

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: The Little Match Girl
   2: 
   3: It was biting cold, and the falling snow, Which filled a poor little match girl’s heart with woe, Who was bareheaded and barefooted, as she went along the street, Crying, “Who’ll buy my matches?
   4: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   5: for I want pennies to buy some meat!” When she left home she had slippers on; But, alas! poor child, now they were gone.
   6: 
   7: For she lost both of them while hurrying across the street, Out of the way of two carriages which were near by her feet.
   8: 
   9: So the little girl went on, while the snow fell thick and fast; And the child’s heart felt cold and downcast, For nobody had bought any matches that day, Which filled her little mind with grief and dismay.
  10: 
  11: Alas! she was hungry and shivering with cold; So in a corner between two houses she made bold To take shelter from the violent storm.
  12: 
  13: Poor little waif! wishing to herself she’d never been born.
  14: 
  15: And she grew colder and colder, and feared to go home For fear of her father beating her; and she felt woe-begone Because she could carry home no pennies to buy bread, And to go home without pennies she was in dread.
  16: 
  17: The large flakes of snow covered her ringlets of fair hair; While the passers-by for her had no care, As they hurried along to their homes at a quick pace, While the cold wind blew in the match girl’s face.
  18: 
  19: As night wore on her hands were numb with cold, And no longer her strength could her uphold, When an idea into her little head came: She’d strike a match and warm her hands at the flame.
  20: 
  21: And she lighted the match, and it burned brightly, And it helped to fill her heart with glee; And she thought she was sitting at a stove very grand; But, alas! she was found dead, with a match in her hand! Her body was found half-covered with snow, And as the people gazed thereon their hearts were full of woe; And many present let fall a burning tear Because she was found dead on the last night of the year, In that mighty city of London, wherein is plenty of gold— But, alas! their charity towards street waifs is rather cold.
  22: 
  23: But I hope the match girl’s in Heaven, beside her Saviour dear, A bright reward for all the hardships she suffered here.


====================================================================================================
#538: 105025_Descriptive Jottings of London_McG, Knight of the White Elephant of Bur_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Descriptive Jottings of London
Author: McG, Knight of the White Elephant of Burmah William
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 30.0
Avg prose line length: 219.3

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Descriptive Jottings of London
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: As I stood upon London Bridge and viewed the mighty throng Of thousands of people in cabs and ’busses rapidly whirling along, All furiously driving to and fro, Up one street and down another as quick as they could go: Then I was struck with the discordant sound of human voices there, Which seemed to me like wild geese cackling in the air: And the river Thames is a most beautiful sight, To see the steamers sailing upon it by day and by night.
   4: 
   5: And the Tower of London is most gloomy to behold, And the crown of England lies there, begemmed with precious stones and gold; King Henry the Sixth was murdered there by the Duke of Glo’ster, And when he killed him with his sword he called him an impostor.
   6: 
   7: St.
   8: 
   9: Paul’s Cathedral is the finest building that ever I did see, There’s no building can surpass it in the city of Dundee, Because it’s magnificent to behold, With its beautiful dome and spire glottering like gold.
  10: 
  11: And as for Nelson’s Monument that stands in Trafalgar Square, It is a most stately monument I most solemnly declare, And towering defiantly very high, Which arrests strangers’ attention while passing by.
  12: 
  13: Then there’s two beautiful water-fountains spouting up very high, Where the weary traveller can drink when he feels dry; And at the foot of the monument there’s three bronze lions in grand array, Enough to make the stranger’s heart throb with dismay.
  14: 
  15: Then there’s Mr Spurgeon, a great preacher, which no one dare gainsay, I went to hear him preach on the Sabbath-day, And he made my heart feel light and gay, When I heard him preach and pray.
  16: 
  17: And the Tabernacle was crowded from ceiling to floor, And many were standing outside the door; He is an eloquent preacher I honestly declare, And I was struck with admiration as on him I did stare.
  18: 
  19: Then there’s Petticoat Lane I venture to say, It’s a wonderful place on the Sabbath-day; There wearing-apparel can be bought to suit the young or old, For the ready cash, silver, coppers, or gold.
  20: 
  21: Oh! mighty city of London! you are wonderful to see, And thy beauties no doubt fill the tourist’s heart with glee; But during my short stay, and while wandering there, Mr Spurgeon was the only man I heard speaking proper English I do declare.


====================================================================================================
#539: 105026_The Burial of the Rev. George Gilfillan_McG, Knight of the White Elephant of Bur_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Burial of the Rev. George Gilfillan
Author: McG, Knight of the White Elephant of Burmah William
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 17
Avg verse line length: 39.0
Avg prose line length: 243.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: The Burial of the Rev. George Gilfillan
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: On the Gilfillan burial day, In the Hill o’ Balgay, It was a most solemn sight to see, Not fewer than thirty thousand people assembled in Dundee, All watching the funeral procession of Gilfillan that day, That death had suddenly taken away, And was going to be buried in the Hill o’ Balgay.
   4: 
   5: There were about three thousand people in the procession alone, And many were shedding tears, and several did moan, And their bosoms heaved with pain, Because they knew they would never look upon his like again.
   6: 
   7: There could not be fewer than fifty carriages in the procession that day, And gentlemen in some of them that had come from far away, And in whispers some of them did say, As the hearse bore the precious corpse away, Along the Nethergate that day.
   8: 
   9: I’m sure he will be greatly missed by the poor, For he never turned them empty-handed away from his door; And to assist them in distress it didn’t give him pain, And I’m sure the poor will never look upon his like again.
  10: 
  11: On the Gilfillan burial day, in the Hill o’ Balgay, There was a body of policemen marshalled in grand array, And marched in front of the procession all the way; Also the relatives and friends of the deceas’d, Whom I hope from all sorrows has been releas’d, And whose soul I hope to heaven has fled away, To sing with saints above for ever and aye.
  12: 
  13: The Provost, Magistrates, and Town Council were in the procession that day; Also Mrs Gilfillan, who cried and sobbed all the way For her kind husband, that was always affable and gay, Which she will remember until her dying day.
  14: 
  15: When the procession arrived in the Hill o’ Balgay, The people were almost as hush as death, and many of them did say— As long as we live we’ll remember the day That the great Gilfillan was buried in the Hill o’Balgay.
  16: 
  17: When the body of the great Gilfillan was lowered into the grave, ’Twas then the people’s hearts with sorrow did heave; And with tearful eyes and bated breath, Mrs Gilfillan lamented her loving husband’s death.
  18: 
  19: Then she dropped a ringlet of immortelles into his grave, Then took one last fond look, and in sorrow did leave; And all the people left with sad hearts that day, And that ended the Gilfillan burial in the Hill o’ Balgay.

#540: 105028_An Address to the Rev. George Gilfillan_McG, Knight of the White Elephant of Bur_unknown.txt

Title: An Address to the Rev. George Gilfillan
Author: McG, Knight of the White Elephant of Burmah William
Prose starts at line: 7
Lines to remove: 11
Avg verse line length: 46.0
Avg prose line length: 200.3

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   2: 
   3: All hail to the Rev.
   4: 
   5: George Gilfillan of Dundee, He is the greatest preacher I did ever hear or see.
   6: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   7: He is a man of genius bright, And in him his congregation does delight, Because they find him to be honest and plain, Affable in temper, and seldom known to complain.
   8: 
   9: He preaches in a plain straightforward way, The people flock to hear him night and day, And hundreds from the doors are often turn’d away, Because he is the greatest preacher of the present day.
  10: 
  11: He has written the life of Sir Walter Scott, And while he lives he will never be forgot, Nor when he is dead, Because by his admirers it will be often read; And fill their minds with wonder and delight, And wile away the tedious hours on a cold winter’s night.
  12: 
  13: He has also written about the Bards of the Bible, Which occupied nearly three years in which he was not idle, Because when he sits down to write he does it with might and main, And to get an interview with him it would be almost vain, And in that he is always right, For the Bible tells us whatever your hands findeth to do, Do it with all your might.
  14: 
  15: Rev.
  16: 
  17: George Gilfillan of Dundee, I must conclude my muse, And to write in praise of thee my pen does not refuse, Nor does it give me pain to tell the world fearlessly, that when You are dead they shall not look upon your like again.

   4: 
   5: And for the longest time,malaprops haunted him.
   6: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   7: His older sisterdid what she could to train the bitten sealof   his brain to twirl the red ball on the nose of eloquence, and his grandmothertired of   insisting he utter the namesof   toys or foods — for every desirewas coded — and gave him whateverhe grunted and pointed to.
   8: 
   9: O, the man then a boythought, when I tower among themI should invent my own speechand leave others empty and afraidthat they did not know it, could not askor plead their case in the one tonguethat mattered.
  10: 
  11: I shall have themlook upon the simplest things,the man then a boy thought, and fill up with stolen awe,and point with their faces,their pupils wide as blackened coins,and hope with all the revenueshattered heart-glass can musterthat someone had graspedtheir need as need and notas the monstrous couplingof   sounds in a trance of whims.
  12: 
  13: Then, the grind of   his teethvowed, then the plazas of my citywill fill with my name,and their blood will matter as little to them as to me.

  43:

  45:

  47: 
  48: It joins the Hope-Princeton and Fraser Canyon to make the interior more easily accessible.
  49: 
  50: This helps encourage commercial development and tourism throughout the Province.
  51: 
  52: First explored by the Hudson's Bay Company, the Coquihalla Pass saw a progression of trappers, hunters, fur traders; and, in the late 1850's, prospectors entered the area in search of gold.
  53: 
  54: Now, with touring and commercial drivers discovering this fast route through the interior, the area's future has never looked brighter.

 110:

 659: 
 660: *** LITERAL TRANSLATION : Leaving the gates of darkness, O Death! hasten thou to a trace yoked with misery! Thou wilt not be received with lacerations of cheeks, nor with funeral ululation -- but with circling dances and the joy of songs.
 661: 
 662: Thou art terrible indeed, yet thou dwellest with Liberty, stern Genius! Borne on thy dark pinions over the swelling of Ocean, they return to their native country.
 663: 
 664: There, by the side of fountains beneath citron-groves, the lovers tell to their beloved what horrors, being men, they had endured from men.

 140: Young Zephyr his fresh flowers profusely throws,
 141: We'll tinge with livelier hues thy cheek;
 142: And, haply, from the nectar-breathing Rose
 143: Extract a Blush for Love!

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 144: The Pixies, in the superstition of Devonshire, are a race of beings invisibly small, and harmless or friendly to man.
 145: 
 146: At a small distance from a village in that county, half way up a wood-covered hill, is an excavation called the Pixies' Parlour.
 147: 
 148: The roots of old trees form its ceiling; and on its sides are innumerable cyphers, cut by the hand of their childhood.
 149: 
 150: At the foot of the hill flows the river Otter.
 151: 
 152: To this place the Author, during the Summer months of the year 1793, conducted a party of young ladies; one of whom, of stature elegantly small, and of complexion colourless yet clear, was proclaimed the Fairy Queen: on which occasion the following Irregular Ode was written.

  15: Written late in life, with the following note to his Highgate host and medical adviser: "My dear Gillman--The ground and matériel of this division of one's friends into ac, con and inquaintance, was given by Hartley Coleridge when he was scarcely five years old [1801].
  16: 
  17: On someone asking him if Anny Sealy (a little girl he went to school with) was an acquaintance of his, he replied, very fervently pressing his right hand to his heart, 'No, she is an inquaintance!' 'Well! 'tis a father's tale'; and the recollection soothes your old friend and inquaintance, S.
  18: 
  19: T.
  20: 
  21: Coleridge.

#552: 106091_Ode To The Departing Year_Coleridge, Samuel Taylor_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Ode To The Departing Year
Author: Coleridge, Samuel Taylor
Prose starts at line: 202
Lines to remove: 11
Avg verse line length: 34.8
Avg prose line length: 112.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 197: 
 198: Poems Occassioned By Political Events, Or Feelings Connected With Them.
 199: 
 200: ARGUMENT.
 201: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 202: The Ode commences with an address to the Divine Providence, that regulates into one vast harmony all the events of time, however calamitous some of them may appear to mortals.
 203: 
 204: The second Strophe calls on men to suspend their private joys and sorrows, and devote them for a while to the cause of human nature in general.
 205: 
 206: The first Epode speaks of the Empress of Russia, who died of an apoplexy on the 17th of November, 1796; having just concluded a subsidary treaty with the Kings combined against France.
 207: 
 208: The first and second Antistrophe describe the Image of the Departing Year, &c.
 209: 
 210: , as in a vision.
 211: 
 212: The second Epode prophesies, in anguish of spirit, the downfall of this country.

  87: 
  88: I feel nothing answering to it in my heart.
  89: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  90: Neither do I find, or reckon, the most solemn faith in God as a real object, the most arduous act of the reason and will; ­ O no! my dear, it is to pray, to pray as God would have us; this is what at times makes me turn cold to my soul.
  91: 
  92: Believe me, to pray with all your heart and strength, with the reason and the will, to believe vividly that God will listen to your voice through Christ, and verily do the thing he pleaseth thereupon ­ this is the last, the greatest achievement of the Christian's warfare on earth.
  93: 
  94: Teach us to pray, O Lord!' And then he burst into a flood of tears, and begged me to pray for him.
  95: 
  96: O what a sight was there!" Table Talk, vol.

 589: Some believe it is the elephant, some the hippopotamus; some affirm it is the wild-bull.
 590: 
 591: Poetically, it designates any large quadruped.
 592: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 593: The Saviour comes! while as the thousand years : The millennium:-- in which, I suppose, that man will continue to enjoy the highest hlory of which his human nature is capable.
 594: 
 595: -- That all who in past ages have endeavored to ameliorate the state of man, will rise and enjoy the fruits and flowers, the imperceptible seeds of which they had sown in their former life; and that the wicked will, during the same period, be suffering the remedies adapted to their several bad habits.
 596: 
 597: I suppose that this period will be followed by the passing away of this earth, and by our entering the state of pure intellect; when all creation shall rest from its labours.

Avg prose line length: 80.1

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 232: 
 233: To assist Reason by the stimulus of Imagination is the design of the following production.
 234: 
 235: In the execution of it much may be objectionable.
 236: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 237: The verse (particularly in the introduction of the Ode) may be accused of unwarrantable liberties; but they are liberties equally homogeneal with the exactness of Mathematical disquisition, and the boldness of Pindaric daring.
 238: 
 239: I have three strong champions to defend me against the attacks of Criticism: the Novelty, the Difficulty, and the Utility of the Work.
 240: 
 241: I may justly plume myself, that I first have drawn the Nymph Mathesis from the visionary caves of Abstracted Idea, and caused her to unite with Harmony.
 242: 
 243: The first-born of this Union I now present to you: with interested motives indeed--as I expect to receive in return the more valuable offspring of your Muse--
 244: Thine ever,
 245: S.
 246: 
 247: T.
 248: 
 249: C.
 250: 
 251: Christ's Hospital, March 31, 1791.

#556: 106197_The Three Graves. A Fragment Of A Sexton's Tale_Coleridge, Samuel Taylor_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Three Graves. A Fragment Of A Sexton's Tale
Author: Coleridge, Samuel Taylor
Prose starts at line: 433
Lines to remove: 15
Avg verse line length: 39.4
Avg prose line length: 173.9

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 428: 
 429: He, hearing the fall, ran up-stairs, and taking her in his arms, carried her off to Ellen's home; and after some fruitless attempts on her part toward a reconciliation with her mother, she was married to him.
 430: 
 431: -- And here the third part of the Tale begins.
 432: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 433: I was not led to choose this story from any partiality to tragic, much less to monstrous events (though at the time that I composed the verses, somewhat more than twelve years ago, I was less averse to such subjects than at present), but from finding in it a striking proof of the possible effect on the imagination from an Idea violently and suddenly impressed on it.
 434: 
 435: I had been reading Byran Edward's account of the effect of the Oby witchcraft on the Negroes in the West Indies, and Hearne's deeply interesting anecdotes of similar workings on the imagination of the Copper Indians (those of my readers who have it in their power will be well repaid for the trouble of the referring to those works for the passages alluded to), and I conceived the design of showing that instances of this kind are not peculiar to savage or barbarous tribes, and of illustrating the mode in which the mind is affected in these cases, and the progress and symptoms of the morbid action on the fancy from the beginning.
 436: 
 437: The Tale is supposed to be narrated by an old Sexton, in a country churchyard, to a traveller whose curiosity had been awakened by the appearance of three graves, close to each other, to two only of which there were gravestones.
 438: 
 439: On the first of these was the name, and dates, as usual; on the second, no name, but only a date, and the words, 'The Mercy of God is infinite.
 440: 
 441: '] ~ S.
 442: 
 443: T.
 444: 
 445: C.
 446: 
 447: , 1818.

#558: 106229_The Blossoming Of The Solitary Date-Tree. A Lament_Coleridge, Samuel Taylor_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Blossoming Of The Solitary Date-Tree. A Lament
Author: Coleridge, Samuel Taylor
Prose starts at line: 75
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 65.4
Avg prose line length: 121.9

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  70: 
  71: Rather let the Woman return at once to the dust, and let Adam remain here all the days of his now mortal life, and enjoy the respite thou mayest grant him, in this thy Paradise which thou gavest to him, and hast planted with every tree pleasant to the sight of man and of delicious fruitage.
  72: 
  73: ' And the word of the Most High answered Satan: 'The tender mercies of the wicked are cruel.
  74: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  75: Teacherous Fiend! guilt deep as thine could not be, yet the love of kind not extinguished.
  76: 
  77: But if, having done what thou hast done, thou hadst yet the heart of man within thee, and the yearning of the soul for its answering image and completing counterpart, O spirit desperately wicked! the sentence thou counsellest had been thy own.
  78: 
  79: The title of the following poem was suggested by a fact mentioned by Linnaeus, of a Date tree in a nobleman's garden, which year after year, had put forth a full show of blossoms, but never produced fruit, till a branch from a Date tree had been conveyed from a distance of some hundred leagues.
  80: 
  81: The first leaf of the MS.
  82: 
  83: from which the poem has been transcribed, and which contained he two or three introductory stanzas, is wanting: and the author has in vain taxed his memory to repair the loss.
  84: 
  85: But a rude draught of the poem contains the substance of the stanzas, and the reader is requested to receive it as the substitute.
  86: 
  87: It is not impossible, that some congenial spirit, whose years do not exceed those of the author, at the time the poem was written, may find a pleasure in restoring the Lament to its original integrity by a reduction of the thoughts to the requisite Metre.
  88: 
  89: S.
  90: 
  91: T.
  92: 
  93: C.

 375: 
 376: poem 8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]

   2: 
   3: I find it in a field of feathers, pink-crested,a knuckle of bone picked clean by the wind,a pale mohawk mounted on stone.
   4: 
   5: I bend down.
   6: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   7: Zeroed out of its head are two sockets, two airy planetsfull with sun, and taking asylum in onea millipede is coiled, a slick black hypnotist.
   8: 
   9: Polished, it spirals in on itselflike one of Saint Hilda’s fossil snakeswe studied in the school chapel’s stained glass.
  10: 
  11: As if the eye could dig itself into the earth then extend a curled feeler out, like a fern.
  12: 
  13: I turn the skull round in my palm like a pebble—it will not settle.
  14: 
  15: Otherwise, all is still: the grasses claw in, the world does not tilt.
  16: 
  17: Even the blue stand of scrub grows over;it has nothing on its mind.
  18: 
  19: But the skull will outlast the summer, a thought cut short,and I will pass it every day as I walkand stop just here, where the air hones its teethon bone, where the mind remembers itselfonly as a shell, and I will mourn what was once a world: one eye rolled to the daylight moon, the other pressed down into the earth.

Avg prose line length: 125.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]

   4: 
   5: He felt sleepy but, as soon as he closed his eyes, the desire for sleep immediately passed.
   6: 
   7: Markov opened his eyes and stretched out his hand for a book.
   8: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   9: But sleep again came over him and, not even reaching the book, Markov lay down and once more closed his eyes.
  10: 
  11: But, the moment his eyes closed, sleepiness left him again and his consciousness became so clear that Markov could solve in his head algebraical problems involving equations with two unknown quantities.
  12: 
  13: Markov was tormented for quite some time, not knowing what to do: should he sleep or should he liven himself up?
  14: 
  15: Finally, exhausted and thoroughly sick of himself and his room, Markov put on his coat and hat, took his walking cane and went out on to the street.
  16: 
  17: The fresh breeze calmed Makarov down, he became rather more at one with himself and felt like going back home to his room.
  18: 
  19: Upon going into his room, he experienced an agreeable bodily fatigue and felt like sleeping.
  20: 
  21: But, as soon as he lay down on the divan and closed his eyes, his sleepiness instantly evaporated.
  22: 
  23: In a fury, Markov jumped up from his divan and, hatless and coatless, raced off in the direction of Tavrichesky Park.

  10: 
  11: Civilization is what makes childhood a captivity narrative.
  12: 
  13: Writing is a refusal that captivity is the end.

  47: 
  48: Into the saddle he thrust him quick, Spurred the black mare with a bayonet prick.
  49: 
  50: Watched her gallop with plunge and with kick Away o'er the desert careering.
  51: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  52: Then he turned with a softened face, And loosened the strap of his cartridge-case, While his thoughts flew back to the dear old place In the sunny Hampshire clearing.
  53: 
  54: The young boy-private, glancing back, Saw the Bedouins' wild attack, And heard the sharp Martini crack.
  55: 
  56: But as he gazed, already The fierce fanatic Arab band Was closing in on every hand, Until one tawny swirl of sand, Concealed them in its eddy.
  57: 
  58: A squadron of British horse that night, Galloping hard in the shadowy light, Came on the scene of that last stern fight, And found the Corporal lying Silent and grim on the trampled sand, His rifle grasped in his stiffened hand, With the warrior pride of one who died 'Mid a ring of the dead and the dying.
  59: 
  60: And still when twilight shadows fall, After the evening bugle call, In bivouac or in barrack-hall, His comrades speak of the Corporal, His death and his devotion.
  61: 
  62: And there are some who like to say That perhaps a hidden meaning lay In the words he spoke, and that the day When his rough bold spirit passed away WAS the day that he won promotion.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: The Franklin's Maid (From 'The White Company')
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: The franklin he hath gone to roam, The franklin's maid she bides at home; But she is cold, and coy, and staid, And who may win the franklin's maid?
   4: 
   5: There came a knight of high renown In bassinet and ciclatoun; On bended knee full long he prayed - He might not win the franklin's maid.
   6: 
   7: There came a squire so debonair, His dress was rich, his words were fair.
   8: 
   9: He sweetly sang, he deftly played - He could not win the franklin's maid.
  10: 
  11: There came a mercer wonder-fine, With velvet cap and gaberdine; For all his ships, for all his trade, He could not buy the franklin's maid.
  12: 
  13: There came an archer bold and true, With bracer guard and stave of yew; His purse was light, his jerkin frayed - Haro, alas! the franklin's maid!
  14: Oh, some have laughed and some have cried, And some have scoured the countryside; But off they ride through wood and glade, The bowman and the franklin's maid.

   1: A Rover Chanty
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: A trader sailed from Stepney town - Wake her up! Shake her up! Try her with the mainsail! A trader sailed from Stepney town With a keg full of gold and a velvet gown: Ho, the bully rover Jack, Waiting with his yard aback Out upon the Lowland sea!
   4: The trader he had a daughter fair - Wake her up! Shake her up! Try her with the foresail The trader he had a daughter fair, She had gold in her ears, and gold in her hair: All for bully rover Jack, Waiting with his yard aback, Out upon the Lowland sea!
   5: 'Alas the day, oh daughter mine!' - Shake her up! Wake her up! Try her with the topsail! 'Alas the day, oh daughter mine! Yon red, red flag is a fearsome sign!' Ho, the bully rover Jack, Reaching on the weather tack, Out upon the Lowland sea!
   6: 'A fearsome flag!' the maiden cried - Wake her up! Shake her up! Try her with the jibsail! 'A fearsome flag!' the maiden cried, But comelier men I never have spied!' Ho, the bully rover Jack, Reaching on the weather tack, Out upon the Lowland sea!
   7: There's a wooden path that the rovers know - Wake her up! Shake her up! Try her with the headsails! There's a wooden path that the rovers know, Where none come back, though many must go: Ho, the bully rover Jack, Lying with his yard aback, Out upon the Lowland sea!
   8: Where is the trader of Stepney town?
   9: 
  10: - Wake her up! Shake her up! Every stick a-bending! Where is the trader of Stepney town?
  11: 
  12: There's gold on the capstan, and blood on the gown: Ho for bully rover Jack, Waiting with his yard aback, Out upon the Lowland sea!
  13: Where is the maiden who knelt at his side?
  14: 
  15: - Wake her up! Shake her up! Every stitch a-drawing! Where is the maiden who knelt at his side?
  16: 
  17: We gowned her in scarlet, and chose her our bride: Ho, the bully rover Jack, Reaching on the weather tack, Right across the Lowland sea!
  18: So it's up and its over to Stornoway Bay, Pack it on! Crack it on! Try her with the stunsails! It's off on a bowline to Stornoway Bay, Where the liquor is good and the lasses are gay: Waiting for their bully Jack, Watching for him sailing back, Right across the Lowland sea.

#571: 107137_Pot Macabre_Davidson, Donald Grady_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Pot Macabre
Author: Davidson, Donald Grady
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 11.0
Avg prose line length: 142.4

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Pot Macabre
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: “Press out an opiate juiceFrom berries culled in prick of June-time heat;Pound nettles in a cruseOf crimson sard till mixing is complete;And strain the brew through bags of sarcenet,Mumbling the runes that crazed Sir Dagonet.
   4: 
   5: ” So spoke the slobbering witch,Wagging her shaky head incessantly;Then, with an agile twitchStove oddly crackling through the briery.
   6: 
   7: I caught the swish of her broomstick up to the moon,And her tattered skirt afloat like a black balloon.
   8: 
   9: Old Witch, whither art gone?
  10: 
  11: Hopped off to the well like Chick-o’-my-Craney-Crow?
  12: 
  13: Here’s work for thy dudgeon, A brew and a bake for a devilish calico!What’s but a kettle ready for mad ferment,Black mouth a-grin at me, the innocent!I pressed and pounded duly,And sat to watch the slop at bubble slow;Fed coals with knots unrulyOf thornbush boles till pot-legs stood aglow.
  14: 
  15: And thrice the pot gave forth a piggish grunt,And thrice a bellowing as of hounds on hunt.
  16: 
  17: A great red swine sprang out,With bristling gleams as bright as Freyr’s boar;Then, at his grubbing snout,Two black dogs leaped, two white-fanged lusts for gore.
  18: 
  19: They three made hideous noise through brush and dew—Trembling I stooped and strained the mulling brew.
  20: 
  21: And there was born a girlWithin a sudden mist wizardry,And came some faint pipes’ thirl,While she danced, with lips turned sly, and beckoned me,And we danced mad till night’s low-burning wickSnuffed out, hearing like us the Old Hag’s stick.

   6:

#573: 107841_The Marriage of Heaven and Hell- [2] The Voice of the Devil_Blake, William_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Marriage of Heaven and Hell: [2] The Voice of the Devil
Author: Blake, William
Prose starts at line: 35
Lines to remove: 20
Avg verse line length: 47.7
Avg prose line length: 103.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  30: 
  31: Energy is Eternal Delight.
  32: 
  33: Those who restrain desire, do so because theirs is weak enough to be restrained; and the restrainer or reason usurps its place and governs the unwilling.
  34: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  35: And being restrained, it by degrees becomes passive, till it is only the shadow of desire.
  36: 
  37: The history of this is written in Paradise Lost, and the Governor or Reason is called Messiah.
  38: 
  39: And the original Archangel or possessor of the command of the heavenly host is called the Devil, or Satan, and his children are called Sin and Death.
  40: 
  41: But in the book of Job, Milton’s Messiah is called Satan.
  42: 
  43: For this history has been adopted by both parties.
  44: 
  45: It indeed appeared to Reason as if desire was cast out, but the Devil’s account is, that the Messiah fell, and formed a heaven of what he stole from the abyss.
  46: 
  47: This is shown in the Gospel, where he prays to the Father to send the Comforter or desire that Reason may have ideas to build on, the Jehovah of the Bible being no other than he who dwells in flaming fire.
  48: 
  49: Know that after Christ’s death he became Jehovah.
  50: 
  51: But in Milton, the Father is Destiny, the Son a ratio of the five senses, and the Holy Ghost vacuum!
  52: Note.
  53: 
  54: —The reason Milton wrote in fetters when he wrote of Angels and God, and at liberty when of Devils and Hell, is because he was a true poet, and of the Devil’s party without knowing it.

#574: 107887_The Marriage of Heaven and Hell- [4] Proverbs of Hell_Blake, William_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Marriage of Heaven and Hell: [4] Proverbs of Hell
Author: Blake, William
Prose starts at line: 142
Lines to remove: 13
Avg verse line length: 56.6
Avg prose line length: 99.4

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 137: 
 138: Truth can never be told so as to be understood and not to be believed.
 139: 
 140: Enough! or Too much.
 141: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 142: The ancient poets animated all sensible objects with Gods or Geniuses, calling them by the names and adorning them with properties of woods, rivers, mountains, lakes, cities, nations, and whatever their enlarged and numerous senses could perceive.
 143: 
 144: And particularly they studied the Genius of each city and country, placing it under its mental deity.
 145: 
 146: Till a system was formed, which some took advantage of and enslaved the vulgar by attempting to realize or abstract the mental deities from their objects.
 147: 
 148: Thus began Priesthood.
 149: 
 150: Choosing forms of worship from poetic tales.
 151: 
 152: And at length they pronounced that the Gods had ordered such things.
 153: 
 154: Thus men forgot that all deities reside in the human breast.

#576: 108480_Alice Ray- A Romance In Rhyme- Canto IV_Hale, Sarah Josepha Buell_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Alice Ray: A Romance In Rhyme: Canto IV
Author: Hale, Sarah Josepha Buell
Prose starts at line: 233
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 35.1
Avg prose line length: 98.3

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 228: ] (Note: Hale campaigned through several presidencies for the establishment of a national Thanksgiving Day; President Lincoln finally proclaimed the national holiday in 1863.
 229: 
 230: COMMENT
 231: As a fable about a young American woman's struggle with the conflicting demands of being a subject and being an aesthetic object, "Alice Ray" is fascinating from several angles.
 232: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 233: One approach would be to see it as a fable about fashion; as editor of Godey's Ladies' Book, Hale was an arbiter of women's fashions, yet in "Alice Ray" she condemns the fashionable world.
 234: 
 235: As in "The Three Hours," Hale engages with the problem of the relation between an ideal republican female subjectivity and the traditions of aristocracy (here, in the form of bodily spectacle).
 236: 
 237: Alice Ray's struggle with beauty relates broadly to eighteenth-century aesthetic theory (e.
 238: 
 239: g.
 240: 
 241: Burke, Kant), in which "the beautiful" was associated with women's objecthood and social connection (as opposed to "the sublime," male subjectivity, individualism).
 242: 
 243: "Alice Ray" thus offers a critique of terms of aesthetic value.
 244: 
 245: Perhaps most baffling in this fable is the "Bloody Spring" (a supernaturalized figure of cosmetics?
 246: 
 247: ), its witching flora and fauna, and its origin in the murder of a beautiful white woman by Indians.
 248: 
 249: Intense racial anxieties seem to be figured into the lore of the spring.
 250: 
 251: -Janet Gray


====================================================================================================

#579: 108878_Oh that I might capture_Chin-i, Hwang_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Oh that I might capture
Author: Chin-i, Hwang
Prose starts at line: 22
Lines to remove: 7
Avg verse line length: 42.5
Avg prose line length: 125.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  17: htm
  18: Hwang Chin-i's pen name was  Myong'wol,  meaning Bright  (or Full) Moon.
  19: 
  20: Hwang's reference to  a spring moon is most likely a reference to herself.
  21: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  22: Korean  kisaeng  were courtesans who entertained court officials and others of high rank.
  23: 
  24: Though frequently of lower birth, these women were often highly intelligent, trained in dancing, painting, and literature.
  25: 
  26: Profiting from the less-inhibited nature of their calling, the kisaeng felt free to express personal emotions in their writing, something men in the public eye usually avoided.
  27: 
  28: The language of kisaeng poetry often included fresh imagery, humorous similes and thinly veiled, risque metaphors.

#581: 109136_Definition of the Frontiers_MacLeish, Archibald_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Definition of the Frontiers
Author: MacLeish, Archibald
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 27.0
Avg prose line length: 126.9

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Definition of the Frontiers
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: First there is the wind but not like the familiar wind but long and without lapses or falling away or surges of air as is usual but rather like the persistent pressure of a river or a running tide.
   4: 
   5: This wind is from the other side and has an odor unlike the odor of the winds with us but like time if time had odor and were cold and carried a bitter and sharp taste like rust on the taste of snow or the fragrance of thunder.
   6: 
   7: When the air has this taste of time the frontiers are not far from us.
   8: 
   9: Then too there are the animals.
  10: 
  11: There are always animals under the small trees.
  12: 
  13: They belong neither to our side nor to theirs but are wild and because they are animals of such kind that wildness is unfamiliar in them as the horse for example or the goat and often sheep and dogs and like creatures their wandering there is strange and even terrifying signaling as it does the violation of custom and the subversion of order.
  14: 
  15: There are also the unnatural lovers the distortion of images the penetration of mirrors and the inarticulate meanings of the dreams.
  16: 
  17: The dreams are in turmoil like a squall of birds.
  18: 
  19: Finally there is the evasion of those with whom we have come.
  20: 
  21: It is at the frontiers that the companions desert us—that the girl returns to the old countrythat we are alone.

#585: 110232_The Nightingale of Avarayr_Alishan, Leo_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================

Author: Alishan, Leo
Prose starts at line: 63
Lines to remove: 13
Avg verse line length: 52.1
Avg prose line length: 79.1

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  58: The fount of Bahlav, flow into your bosoms' sea,-
  59: If you would that your country's glories for you be written,
  60: Come forth to Ardaz with your Patriarch, come with me!
  61: NB.
  62: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  63: Yeghishe was an Armenian historian of the fifth century AD, a contemporary of Vartan, who died in the battle of Avarayr in 451.
  64: 
  65: In his history of the Persian invasion he compares Vartan drenched in blood, to the red rose.
  66: 
  67: Hence the allusions in the poem.
  68: 
  69: Fr.
  70: 
  71: Alishan actually wrote the poem in ancient Armenian of roughly the same period.
  72: 
  73: This poem (from the seventh stanza onwards) is also a famous and rather beautiful song - there are at least two different musical versions of it.
  74: 
  75: In fact Vartan, and the other Leontines, as they are known, are now saints!

#588: 110665_Song of the Galley-Slaves_Kipling, Rudyard_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Song of the Galley-Slaves
Author: Kipling, Rudyard
Prose starts at line: 7
Lines to remove: 16
Avg verse line length: 40.0
Avg prose line length: 92.9

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   2: 
   3: We pulled for you when the wind was against us and the sails were low.
   4: 
   5: Will you never let us go?
   6: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   7: We ate bread and onions when you took towns, or ran aboard quickly when you were beaten back by the foe.
   8: 
   9: The Captains walked up and down the deck in fair weather singing songs, but we were below.
  10: 
  11: We fainted with our chins on the oars and you did not see that we were idle, for we still swung to and fro.
  12: 
  13: Will you never let us go?
  14: 
  15: The salt made the oar-handles like shark-skin; our knees were cut to the bone with salt-cracks; our hair was stuck to our foreheads; and our lips were cut to the gums, and you whipped us because we could not row.
  16: 
  17: Will you never let us go?
  18: 
  19: But, in a little time, we shall run out of the port-holes as the water runs along the oar-blade, and though you tell the others to row after us you will never catch us till you catch the oar-thresh and tie up the winds in the belly of the sail.
  20: 
  21: Aho!
  22: Will you never let us go?

   4: 
   5: I wake up to a severed goat head and look at it hard enough to remember the animal in its entirety, a functional thing.
   6: 
   7: The Saudis have built skyscrapers taller than the mountains in Makkah.
   8: 
   9: This is a sign of the apocalypse; we worry with our backs to each other and look for Isa in the faces of men who appear to spin gold straight from the guttural source.
  10: 
  11: I repeat the wordmustaqbillike a new prayer; when the dog barks at a brick wallmustaqbil, when anemones collapse back into gothic budsmustaqbil, when I wet my arms to my elbows in the sinkmustaqbil.
  12: 
  13: All while Israfil kicks his feet against a stone wall and cleans his trumpet with each utterance.
  14: 
  15: In the village, three men dragged a boy into our orchards and beat him to a pulp.
  16: 
  17: The woman who eloped was strangled and thrown into the river.
  18: 
  19: Pickpockets robbed the mourners at my uncle’s funeral —mustaqbil mustaqbil mustaq— my throat is infected by the thick-tongued promise; each night diluted into its prior belly.
  20: 
  21: I use language to build the gardens I’m destined to be expelled from, each imagined rose rendered true.

  11: Christ, I have no praise for you.
  12: 
  13: Beyond saying a vodka-wrecked troller and shacks the color of the desire to die, beyond saying predatory snails that glide on their bellies like the penitent, flexing their borers, beyond saying seraphim that bicker exactly like gulls, the shells that are my ears sing no psalms except I can name many small creatures in the world of a tide pool.
  14: 
  15: Christ, have mercy on all things that drown in air, I have no praise for you.
  16: 
  17: I say the tide: Tide! Tide! Tide! I say: Ebb! Flood! Ebb! Flood! I always start with "Ebb!" I always end with "Flood!" "Names" is from a sequence titled "Hard Weather Prayers.

Author: Mullen, Harryette
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 28.0
Avg prose line length: 143.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Sleeping with the Dictionary
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: I beg to dicker with my silver-tongued companion, whose lips are ready to read my shining gloss.
   4: 
   5: A versatile partner, conversant and well-versed in the verbal art, the dictionary is not averse to the solitary habits of the curiously wide-awake reader.
   6: 
   7: In the dark night’s insomnia, the book is a stimulating sedative, awakening my tired imagination to the hypnagogic trance of language.
   8: 
   9: Retiring to the canopy of the bedroom, turning on the bedside light, taking the big dictionary to bed, clutching the unabridged bulk, heavy with the weight of all the meanings between these covers, smoothing the thin sheets, thick with accented syllables—all are exercises in the conscious regimen of dreamers, who toss words on their tongues while turning illuminated pages.
  10: 
  11: To go through all these motions and procedures, groping in the dark for an alluring word, is the poet’s nocturnal mission.
  12: 
  13: Aroused by myriad possibilities, we try out the most perverse positions in the practice of our nightly act, the penetration of the denotative body of the work.
  14: 
  15: Any exit from the logic of language might be an entry in a symptomatic dictionary.
  16: 
  17: The alphabetical order of this ample block of knowledge might render a dense lexicon of lucid hallucinations.
  18: 
  19: Beside the bed, a pad lies open to record the meandering of migratory words.
  20: 
  21: In the rapid eye movement of the poet’s night vision, this dictum can be decoded, like the secret acrostic of a lover’s name.

Author: Janvier, Francis De Haes
Prose starts at line: 113
Lines to remove: 11
Avg verse line length: 57.9
Avg prose line length: 87.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 108: While yet his life-blood ebbed away through every gaping wound-
 109: While yet his voice grew tremulous, and death bedimmed his eye-
 110: He called his comrades to attest he had not feared to die!
 111: And, in his last expiring breath, a prayer to heaven was sent,
 112: That God, with his unfailing grace, would bless our President!

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 113: Lincoln's inclination to grant clemency to soldiers was embodied in this popular poem of the day.
 114: 
 115: The poem recalls Lincoln's pardon of Private William Scott of the 3rd Vermont Infantry.
 116: 
 117: Scott was sentenced to be executed after falling asleep on guard.
 118: 
 119: In the poem, Janvier depicts Lincoln frantically racing to the firing squad line-up to save the only son of Mrs.
 120: 
 121: Scott, a widow.
 122: 
 123: Although the account was mostly fiction the soldiers were convinced that it was true -- for them Father Abraham was truly "the last best hope of earth.

 327: "And I often pray that I'll never see another Amber Whale.
 328: 
 329: NOTES
 330: SINNET & RATLINES were lengths of rope.
 331: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 332: On board ship nothing useful was wasted and old pieces of rope would be unpicked and re-spun into lengths of fresh strong rope (Spunyarn) during idle hours or by crew temporarily unfit for more arduous work.
 333: 
 334: WATCH BELOW ==  Working hours on board ship were divided into watches and if a crewman wasn't working he was said to be on watch below.
 335: 
 336: KILLERS, FINBACKS, BLACKFISH, DEVIL FISH, RIGHT WHALES, SULPHUR BOOTOM, SPERM == Types of whale
 337: KANAKA, MAORI, YANKEE ==  Types or nationality of seamen (Kanaka usually meant Hawaiian)
 338: AMBER WHALE == Whalemen have a strange belief as to the formation of amber.
 339: 
 340: They say that it is a some internal part of a whale turned to stone; and they tell weird stories of enormous whales seen in the warm latitudes, that were almost entirely transformed into the precious substance.
 341: 
 342: 'Are your irons ready?
 343: 
 344: ' == The harpooner in a whale-boat had a range of instruments , or irons, to choose from and ropes etc had to be attached ready for use.
 345: 
 346: AMBER CASE == The head of a whale is divided into the "case" and the "junk" and both are rich sources of whale oil.
 347: 
 348: ROYAL CROSS TREES ==  A very high part of a ships mast where lights, if strung, could be seen from far off.

  82: I am Liberty! patient, deathless—set by Love at the Nation's door.

  50: but it’s time, for the thunderous applause to fade
  51: for the cymbals of silence to crash, to announce time’s funeral
  52: for Gliese 581c to open its clenched fists and spread gravity’s fingers
  53: 200 trillion kilometers away
  54: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  55: I + bird + music lie prostrate like a corpse, hiding at the bottom of a lake, then stand up to shake off water, then lie on a bed of shredded radish and fried glass noodles like a sliced raw fish, panting for air, wearing apricot blossoms behind our ears, then like strewn laundry fall onto the couch barely breathing, then do stuff like cooking, washing vegetables, dragging our chained feet, bleeding.
  56: 
  57: I + bird + music vomit what we’ve chomped down, the hour of departure is bound to
  58: return, the hour of long-haired tadpoles leaping into frog’s dream is bound to return.
  59: 
  60: White beard is bound to jabber away
  61: Girl, your body has so many holes for straws
  62: 
  63: But it’s time to bang on the black-and-white keyboards then a
  64: cool splash! It’s time to untie the birds strung to the piano


====================================================================================================
#608: 113977_Update on the Last Judgment_Hinsey, Ellen_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Update on the Last Judgment
Author: Hinsey, Ellen
Prose starts at line: 9
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 41.8
Avg prose line length: 110.5

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   4: 
   5: No hornblow of thunder.
   6: 
   7: The small plants of the earth will not tremble on the hillside as grace is prepared.
   8: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   9: The sky will neither drown us in its plenty, nor the ground crack and consume feet in its hunger.
  10: 
  11: No, bodies will not, in their last rags of flesh, creep from under the earth, and with breath once torn from them, choke and expel the old mud of the world.
  12: 
  13: Adam and Eve, incredulous, will not embrace again in their poverty, not knowing whether to shield themselves, or to emerge shameless from the past's shadow, astonished to again greetTerra Firma.
  14: 
  15: The book of the world, encrusted with deep-sea pearls and the blood of the lamb, will not open up its pages in which all deeds have been inscribed.
  16: 
  17: And the totality of history will not roll back together, all events fusing, once and for all, into the great blazing sphere of time.
  18: 
  19: None will sit on the right hand.
  20: 
  21: There will be no right hand.
  22: 
  23: And the figure of sorrow and grace, with his staff upright, its purple pennant caught in that final wind, will not be there to greet us, with the mercy of justice in his eyes.
  24: 
  25: No, never judgment.
  26: 
  27: Just the abyss into which all acts are thrown down, and the terrible white silence in which judgment either endures or burns.

#609: 114036_A Grave_Moore, Marianne_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: A Grave
Author: Moore, Marianne
Prose starts at line: 42
Lines to remove: 7
Avg verse line length: 40.0
Avg prose line length: 148.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  37: advances as usual, looking as if it were not that ocean in which
  38: dropped things are bound to sink —
  39: in which if they turn and twist, it is neither with volition nor
  40: consciousness.
  41: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  42: A Grave" was written shortly after the sinking of the Lusitania and after Moore's brother Warner joined the Navy as a chaplin and went out to sea.
  43: 
  44: The sea was one of Moore's favorite topics, but she was also very much aware of the sea as a grave.
  45: 
  46: The sea, for Moore, was both beautiful and deadly.
  47: 
  48: Once, when she and her mother were standing together admiring the sea, a man came and stood in from of them, Moore's mother remarked about how people seem to feel the need to stand in the middle of things instead of stepping back to get the full picture, and this incident became part of the poem.


====================================================================================================
#610: 114041_A Graveyard_Moore, Marianne_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: A Graveyard
Author: Moore, Marianne
Prose starts at line: 19
Lines to remove: 9
Avg verse line length: 52.9
Avg prose line length: 81.4

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  14: There are others besides you who have worn that look—
  15: whose expression is no longer a protest; the fish no longer investigate them
  16: for their bones have not lasted;
  17: men lower nets, unconscious of the fact that they are desecrating a grave,
  18: and row quickly away—the blades of the oars

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  19: moving together like the feet of water-spiders as if there were no such thing as death.
  20: 
  21: The wrinkles progress upon themselves in a phalanx—beautiful under networks of foam,
  22: and fade breathlessly while the sea rustles in and out of the seaweed;
  23: the birds swim through the air at top speed, emitting cat-calls as heretofore—
  24: the tortoise-shell scourges about the feet of the cliffs, in motion beneath them
  25: and the ocean, under the pulsation of light-houses and noise of bell-buoys,
  26: advances as usual, looking as if it were not that ocean in which dropped things are bound to sink—
  27: in which if they turn and twist, it is neither with volition nor consciousness.

   1: The Mystery Man in the Black Hat Speaks
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: I am the spirit of the dead African man lost in the Atlantic during storms and murders crossing those terrible waters during the Middle Passage.
   4: 
   5: My spirit though mixed in a mélange with blood of Cherokees and the spirits of Tom Ridge Tom Ross the Apache warrior Geronimo the Sioux Chief Sitting Bull and the Shawnee Chief Tecumseh and his younger brother Tenskwatawa the one-eyed prophet and a whole lot of others.
   6: 
   7: I rise up out of the ground out of the rivers walk and cut through mist fog tornado clouds hurricane winds come out of the ground from cracks of earthquakes the flaming lava of volcanoes and come here to this Mississippi River not far from Cahokia where the ancestors came upriver from the gulf and built those pyramids there to spite the white man.
   8:

  10: 
  11: I am the double-back winding swamp snake who can cure these tortured spirits living here in this hellfire & brimstone place if only they will listen to me tell them the righteous truth.
  12: 
  13: But until then I will come and go as I please as I want to sliding through the night with my mojo bone and juba shaking feather and appear whenever and wherever it suits me in my black hat and black cape sometimes riding a black horse and carrying a black whip that is my tongue that cracks and slips through the language we speak like a black mamba snake I move fast as an out-of-control brushfire strike deadly quick as a drone's exploding missile and then I'm gone just like that in the blinking flash of an eye.

  18: ('Tis not far off) visit his tomb with flowers;
  19: And may some pious hand with water fill
  20: The two small cells scoop'd in the marble there,
  21: That birds may come and drink upon his grave,
  22: Making it holy!------------------------------

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  23: To see his face no more: There is a beautiful story, delivered down to us from antiquity, which will here perhaps occur to the reader.
  24: 
  25: Icarius, when he gave Penelope in marriage to Ulysses, endeavoured to persuade him to dwell in Lacedaemon; and, when all he urged was to no purpose, he entreated his daughter to remain with him.
  26: 
  27: When Ulysses set out with his bride for Ithaca, the old man followeed the chariot, till, overcome by his importunity, Ulysses consented that it should be left with Penelope to decide whether she would proceed with him or return with her father.
  28: 
  29: It is related, says Pausanias, that she made no reply, but that she covered herself with her veil; and that Icarius, perceiving at once by it that she inclined to Ulysses, suffered her to depart with him.
  30: 
  31: A statue was afterwards placed by her father as a memorial in that part of the road where she had covered herself with a veil.
  32: 
  33: It was still standing there in the days of Pausanias, and was called the statue of Modesty.
  34: 
  35: Making it holy.
  36: 
  37: 
  38: : A Turkish superstition.

1179: Two months pass away, and an angel, appearing in a dream to Columbus, thus addresses him: "Return to Europe; though your Adversaries, such is the will of Heaven, shall let loose the hurricane against you.
1180: 
1181: A little while shall they triumph; insinuating themselves into the hearts of your followers, and making the World, which you came to bless, a scene of blood and slaughter.
1182: 
1183: Yet is there cause for rejoicing.
1184: 
1185: Your work is done.
1186: 
1187: The cross of Christ is planted here; and, in due time, all things shall be made perfect!"

  55:

  57: 
  58: That place is still known by the name of the Strid; and the mother's answer, as given in the first stanza, is to this day often repeated in Wharfedale.

#622: 115388_Italy - 32. National Prejudices_Rogers, Samuel_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Italy : 32. National Prejudices
Author: Rogers, Samuel
Prose starts at line: 132
Lines to remove: 16
Avg verse line length: 41.8
Avg prose line length: 143.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 127: 
 128: 3.
 129: 
 130: ) and which may still be heard in almost every hôtellerie at day-break.
 131: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 132: when at length they venture to turn against their rules, : As the descendants of an illustrious people have lately done.
 133: 
 134: Can it be believed that there are many among us, who, from a desire to be thought superior to common-place sentiments and vulgar feelings, affect an indifference to their cause?
 135: 
 136: 'If the Greeks,' they say, 'had the probity of other nations -- but they are false to a proverb!'  And is not falsehood the characteristic of slaves?
 137: 
 138: Man is the creature of circumstances.
 139: 
 140: Free, he has the qualities of a freeman; enslaved, those of a slave.
 141: 
 142: Hence  next-door neighbours are held up to us from our childhood as natural enemies ; and we are urged on like curs to worry each other.
 143: 
 144: 
 145: : Candour, generosity, how rare are they in the world; and how much is to be deplored the want of them!  When a minister in our parliament consents at last to a measure, which, for many reasons perhaps existing no longer, he had before refused to adopt, there should be no exultation as over the fallen, no taunt, no jeer.
 146: 
 147: How often may the resitance be continued lest an enemy should triumph, and the result of conviction be received as the symptom of fear!
