#624: 115419_Samson Agonistes_Milton, John_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Samson Agonistes
Author: Milton, John
Prose starts at line: 2387
Lines to remove: 18
Avg verse line length: 41.5
Avg prose line length: 238.7

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2382: 
2383: Augustus Caesar also had begun his Ajax, but unable to please his own judgment with what he had begun.
2384: 
2385: left it unfinisht.
2386: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2387: Seneca the Philosopher is by some thought the Author of those Tragedies (at least the best of them) that go under that name.
2388: 
2389: Gregory Nazianzen a Father of the Church, thought it not unbeseeming the sanctity of his person to write a
2390: Tragedy which he entitl'd, Christ suffering.
2391: 
2392: This is mention'd to vindicate Tragedy from the small esteem, or rather infamy, which in the account of many it undergoes at this day with other common Interludes; hap'ning through the Poets error of intermixing Comic stuff with Tragic sadness and gravity; or introducing trivial and vulgar persons, which by all judicious hath bin counted absurd; and brought in without discretion, corruptly to gratifie the people.
2393: 
2394: And though antient Tragedy use no Prologue, yet using sometimes, in case of self defence, or explanation, that which Martial calls an Epistle; in behalf of this Tragedy coming forth after the antient manner, much different from what among us passes for best, thus much before-hand may be Epistl'd; that Chorus is here introduc'd after the Greek manner, not antient only but modern, and still in use among the Italians.
2395: 
2396: In the modelling therefore of this Poem with good reason, the Antients and Italians are rather follow'd, as of much more authority and fame.
2397: 
2398: The measure of Verse us'd in the Chorus is of all sorts, call'd by the Greeks Monostrophic, or rather Apolelymenon, without regard had to Strophe, Antistrophe or Epod, which were a kind of Stanza's fram'd only for the Music, then us'd with the Chorus that sung; not essential to the Poem, and therefore not material; or being divided into Stanza's or Pauses they may be call'd Allaeostropha.
2399: 
2400: Division into Act and Scene referring chiefly to the Stage (to which this work never was intended) is here omitted.
2401: 
2402: It suffices if the whole Drama be found not produc't beyond the fift Act, of the style and uniformitie, and that commonly call'd the Plot, whether intricate or explicit, which is nothing indeed but such oeconomy, or disposition of the fable as may stand best with verisimilitude and decorum; they only will best judge who are not unacquainted with Aeschulus, Sophocles, and Euripides, the three Tragic Poets unequall'd yet by any, and the best rule to all who endeavour to write Tragedy.
2403: 
2404: The circumscription of time wherein the whole Drama begins and ends, is according to antient rule, and best example, within the space of 24 hours.


====================================================================================================

  27: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  28: Henry Lawes was a gentleman of his Majesty's chapel, and one of his band of music, and an intimate friend of Milton, as appears by his first publishing the Mask in 1637, the airs of which he set to music, and probably too those of his Arcades.
  29: 
  30: He was educated under Signor Coperario, and introduced a softer mixture of Italian airs, than had been practic'd before in our nation: as Mr.
  31: 
  32: Fenton says in his notes upon Waller, who has also honor'd him with a copy of verses inscrib'd "To Mr.
  33: 
  34: Henry Lawes who had then newly set a song of mine in the year 1635.
  35: 
  36: (line 9: --- and verse must lend her wing): There are three manuscript copies of this sonnet, two by Milton, the second corrected, and the third by another hand; and in all of them we read "must lend her wing," which we prefer to "must send her wing," as it is in the printed copies.
  37: 
  38: (line 13: Than his Casella, whom he woo'd to sing.
  39:

1345: ): Uriel, His name is derived from two Hebrew words which signify "God is my light.
1346: 
1347: " He is mention'd as a good Angel in the second book of Esdras, chapters 4 and 5; and the Jews and some Christians conceive him to be an Angel of light according to his name, and therefore he has properly his station in the sun.
1348:

1350: 
1351: ): A mountain in the borders of Armenia, not far from the spring of Tigris, as Xenophon affirms upon his own knowledge.
1352: 
1353: The poet lands Satan on this mountain, because it borders on Mesopotamia, in which the most judicious describers of Paradise place it.
1354: 
1355: --Hume.

1848: "This pendent world" therefore must mean the whole world, the new created universe, and "beheld far off" it appear'd in comparison with the empyreal Heaven no bigger than "a star of smallest magnitude;" nay not so large, it appear'd no bigger than such a star appears to be when it is "close by the moon," the superior light whereof makes any star that happens to be near her disk, to seem exceedingly small and almost disappear.

1321: 
1322: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1323: ): Ruining is here used as a deponent; it is a beautiful way of speaking, and very expressive of the idea; it is founded on the notion of the Latin "ruina" from "ruo.
1324: 
1325: " And Milton here follow'd the sense of the Italian word "rovinare" or "ruinare," which in the dictionary Della Crusca is explain'd by falling headlong and violently from a higher to a lower place.
1326: 
1327: --Pearce.
1328: 
1329: ~ Th.
1330:

#630: 115462_Sonnet VII- On His Being Arriv'd To The Age Of 23_Milton, John_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Sonnet VII: On His Being Arriv'd To The Age Of 23
Author: Milton, John
Prose starts at line: 31
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 91.0
Avg prose line length: 263.4

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  26: Sir,
  27: "Besides that in sundry respects I must acknowledge me to profit by you whenever we meet, you are often to me, and were yesterday especially, as a good watch-man to admonish that the hours of the night pass on (for so I call my life as yet obscure and unserviceable to mankind) and that the day is at hand, wherein Christ commands all to labor while there is light: which because I am persuaded you do to no other purpose, than out of a true desire that God should be honor'd in every one, I am ever ready, you know, when occasion is, to give you account, as I ought, though unask'd, of my tardy moving according to the precept of my conscience, which I firmly trust is not without God.
  28: 
  29: Yet now I will not strain for any set apology, but only refer myself to what my mind shall have at any time to declare herself at her best ease.
  30: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  31: Yet if you think, as you said, that too much love of learning is in fault, and that I have given up myself to dream away my years in the arms of studious retirement, like Endymion with the moon on Latmus hill; yet consider, that if it were no more but this, to overcome this, there is on the other side both ill more bewitchful to entice away, and natural years more available to withdraw to that which you wish me; as first all the fond hopes which forward youth and vanity are fledge with, none of which can sort with this Pluto's helmet, as Homer calls it, of obscurity, and would soon cause me to throw it off, if there were nothing else in't but an affected and fruitless curiosity of knowing; and then a natural desire of honor and renown, which I think possesses the breast of every scholar, as well of him that shall, as of him that never shall obtain it (if this be altogether bad) which would quickly oversway this flegm and melancholy of bashfulness, or that other humor, and prevail with me to prefer a life, that had at least some credit in it, some place given it, before a manner of living much disregarded and discountenanc'd.
  32: 
  33: There is besides this, as all well know, about this time of a man's life, a strong inclination, be it good or no, to build up a house and family of his own in the best manner he may; to which nothing is more helpful than the early entring into some credible employment, and nothing more cross than my way, which my wasting youth would presently bethink her of, and kill one love with another, if that were all.
  34: 
  35: But what delight or what peculiar conceit, may you in charity think, could hold out against the long knowledge of a contrary command from above, and the terrible seisure of him that hid his talent?
  36: 
  37: Therefore commit grace to grace, or nature to nature, there will be found on the other way more obvious temptations to bad, as gain, preferment, ambition, more winning presentments of good, and more prone affections of nature to incline and dispose, not counting outward causes, as expectations and murmurs of friends, scandals taken, and such like, than the bare love of notions could resist.
  38: 
  39: So that if it be that which you suppose, it had by this been round about begirt and overmaster'd, whether it had proceeded from virtue, vice, or nature in me.
  40: 
  41: Yet that you may see that I am some time suspicious of myself, and do take notice of a certain belatedness in me, I am the bolder to send you some of my nightward thoughts some while since, since they come in fitly, in a Petrarchian staza.
  42: 
  43: How soon hath Time &c.
  44: 
  45: ~ Th.
  46: 
  47: Newton, Milton's Works, 2nd edition, 1753.
  48: 
  49: (line 8): endu'th: endows.

  73: 
  74: &c.
  75: 
  76: These letters are dated in May 1655, and about the same time it is probable this sonnet was compos'd, which was added in the edition of 1673.
  77: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  78: (line 1: Avenge, O Lord, &c): Nor was this prayer in behalf of the persecuted protestants entirely without effect.
  79: 
  80: For Cromwell exerted himself in their favor, and his behaviour in this whole transaction is greatly to his honor, even as it is related by an historian, who was far from being partial to his memory.
  81: 
  82: "Nor would the Protector be backward in such a work, which might give the world a particular opinion of his piety and zeal for the protestant religion; but he proclaim'd a solemn fast, and caused large contributions to be gather'd for them throughout the kingdom of England and Wales.
  83: 
  84: Nor did he rest here, but sent his agents to the Duke of Savoy, a prince with whom he had no correspondence or commerce, and the next year so engag'd the Cardinal of France, and even terrify'd the Pope himself, without so much as doing any favor to the English Roman catholics, that that Duke thought it necessary to restore all that he had taken from them, and renew'd all those privileges they had formerly enjoy'd.
  85: 
  86: So great was the terror of his name; nothing being more usual than his saying, that 'his ships in the Mediterranean should visit Civita Vecchia, and the sound of his cannon should be heard in Rome.
  87: 
  88: '" See Echard.
  89: 
  90: Vol.
  91: 
  92: 2.
  93: 
  94: ~ Th.
  95: 
  96: Newton, Milton's Works, 2nd edition, 1753.

  36:

#636: 115517_Paradise Lost - Book XII._Milton, John_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Paradise Lost : Book XII.
Author: Milton, John
Prose starts at line: 1322
Lines to remove: 17
Avg verse line length: 47.5
Avg prose line length: 142.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1317: 
1318: And the reason of this denomination Junius derives from hence, because men fought with burnt stakes and firebrands, before arms were invented.
1319: 
1320: The number of Books in "Paradise Lost" is equal to those of the "Æneid".
1321: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1322: Our author in his first edition had divided his poem into ten books, but afterwards broke the seventh and the tenth of them into two different books, by the help of some small additions.
1323: 
1324: This second division was made with great judgement, as any one may see, who will be at the pains of examining it.
1325: 
1326: It was not done for the sake of such a chimerical beauty as that of resembling Virgil in this particular, but for the more just and regular disposition of this great work.
1327: 
1328: --Addison.
1329: 
1330: And thus we have finish'd our collections and remarks on this divine poem.
1331: 
1332: The reader probably may have observed that these two last books fall short of the sublimity and majesty of the rest : and so likewise do the two last books of the Iliad, and for the same reason, because the subject is a different kind from that of the foregoing ones.
1333: 
1334: The subject of these two last books of the Paradise Lost is history rather than poetry.
1335: 
1336: However we may still discover the same great genius, and there are intermix'd as many ornaments and graces of poetry, as the nature of the subject, and the author's fidelity and strict attachment to the truth of Scripture history, and the reduction of so many and such various events into so narrow a compass, would admit.
1337: 
1338: ~ Thomas Newton, Paradise Lost, 2nd edition, 1750.

1751: 
1752: Upon this he wrote his 'Doctrin and Disciplin of Divorce,' and to show that he was in earnest was actually treating about a second marriage, when the wife contrived to meet him at a friend's whom he often visited, and there fell prostrate before him, imploring forgiveness and reconciliation.
1753: 
1754: It is not to be doubted (says Mr.
1755: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1756: Fenton) but an interview of that nature, so little expected, must wonderfully affect him: and perhaps the impressions it made on his imagination contributed much to the painting of that pathetic scene in Paradise Lost, in which Eve addresseth herself to Adam for pardon and peace.
1757: 
1758: At the intercession of his friends who were present, after a short reluctance he generally sacrific'd all his resentment to her tears:
1759: "---- soon his heart relented
1760: Towards her, his life so late and sole delight,
1761: Now at his feet submissive in distress.
1762:

1766: ): To "tine" is deriv'd from the Saxon "tynan" to light, to kindle; from whence also we have the word "tinder.

1771: 
1772: A similar word, "tines", is used in Tolkien's translation of Sir Gawain and the Green Knight, and is defined as 'pointed branches of a deer's horn.

#639: 115539_Sonnet X. To The Lady Margaret Ley_Milton, John_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Sonnet X.  To The Lady Margaret Ley
Author: Milton, John
Prose starts at line: 18
Lines to remove: 13
Avg verse line length: 40.1
Avg prose line length: 127.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  13: Madam, me thinks I see him living yet;
  14: So well your words his noble vertues praise,
  15: That all both judge you to relate them true,
  16: And to possess them, Honour'd Margaret.
  17: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  18: 'We have given the title which is in Milton's Manuscript, "To the Lady Margaret Ley.
  19: 
  20: " She was the daughter of Sir James Ley, whose singular learning and abilities raised him through all the great posts of the law, till he came to be made Earl of Marlborough, and Lord High Treasurer, and Lord President of the Council to King James I.
  21: 
  22: He died in an advanc'd age, and Milton attributes his death to the breaking of the parlament; and it is true that the parlament was dissolved the 10th of March 1628-29, and he died on the 14th of the same month.
  23: 
  24: He left several sons and daughters; and the Lady Margaret was married to Captain Hobson of the Ile of Wight.
  25: 
  26: It appears from the accounts of Milton's life, that in the year 1643 he used frequently to visit this lady and her husband, and about that time we may suppose that this sonnet was compos'd.
  27: 
  28: ~ Th.
  29: 
  30: Newton, Milton's Works, 2nd edition, 1753.

#640: 115583_Heredities (1) Etymology_Martinez, J Michael_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Heredities (1) Etymology
Author: Martinez, J Michael
Prose starts at line: 11
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 73.2
Avg prose line length: 123.1

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   6: 
   7: Instead, she went to a curandera.
   8: 
   9: The curandera divined that a jealous relative had cast a curse on her and, now, her language of kindness was bound to her throat, the unspoken swelling her glands.
  10: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  11: As a child my grandmother spoke to santitos with a voice like a chestnut: ruddy and warm, seeds dropping from her mouth.
  12: 
  13: The santitos would take her words into themselves, her voice growing within them like grapevines.
  14: 
  15: During the tonsillitis, when the words no longer fell like seeds from her lips, the santito's vineyards of accent and voice grew vapid, dry as a parched mouth.
  16: 
  17: They went to her tongue and asked why silence imprisoned the words of the child, why lumps were present under her chin, why tears drew channels down her cheeks.
  18: 
  19: I asked my grandmother how her tongue replied.
  20: 
  21: After touching my cheek, she told me she had a dream that night: She was within her lungs and she rose like breath through the moist of her throat.
  22: 
  23: She remembered her tonsils swinging before her like fleshy apples, then a hand taking them into a fist, harvesting their sound.
  24: 
  25: She told me her throat opened in two spots like insect eyes and the names of her children came flying through her wounds like peacocks.
  26: 
  27: Patting my thigh, she said, "That is why the name of your mother is Maria, because she is a prayer, a song of praise to the Holy Mother.
  28: 
  29: " She told me this, then showed me two scars on her throat—tiny scars, like two eyelids stitched closed.

   6: 
   7: Instead, she went to a curandera.
   8: 
   9: The curandera divined that a jealous relative had cast a curse on her and, now, her language of kindness was bound to her throat, the unspoken swelling her glands.
  10: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  11: As a child my grandmother spoke to santitos with a voice like a chestnut: ruddy and warm, seeds dropping from her mouth.
  12: 
  13: The santitos would take her words into themselves, her voice growing within them like grapevines.
  14: 
  15: During the tonsillitis, when the words no longer fell like seeds from her lips, the santito's vineyards of accent and voice grew vapid, dry as a parched mouth.
  16: 
  17: They went to her tongue and asked why silence imprisoned the words of the child, why lumps were present under her chin, why tears drew channels down her cheeks.
  18: 
  19: I asked my grandmother how her tongue replied.
  20: 
  21: After touching my cheek, she told me she had a dream that night: She was within her lungs and she rose like breath through the moist of her throat.
  22: 
  23: She remembered her tonsils swinging before her like fleshy apples, then a hand taking them into a fist, harvesting their sound.
  24: 
  25: She told me her throat opened in two spots like insect eyes and the names of her children came flying through her wounds like peacocks.
  26: 
  27: Patting my thigh, she said, "That is why the name of your mother isMaria,because she is a prayer, a song of praise to the Holy Mother.
  28: 
  29: " She told me this, then showed me two scars on her throat—tiny scars, like two eyelids stitched closed.

  61: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]

  63: 
  64: Paper  tissue  snow-flecks  teardropped  with crimson  blood created  a  trail  behind  me  as  Iascended  the  many  tiers  of  the  wedding-cake concert hall.
  65: 
  66: BAREFOOT: PEARL PINK POLISHSitting  next  to someone  can  make  my  feet  curl:  shy,  self-destructiveand  oyster-like, they want to  shuck  their cases,  to  present  themselves,little undersea pinks; their skin  still  is  too  soft, their  toes still too long,their  ankles still too slender, for a modern fit.
  67: 
  68: But he  is not modern;  hesits like stone, and my bare feet are cool, they will not have to bleed.

  27: The Temples to which the above lines allude, are already half immersed in water; a few more years, and the stream which was once their mirror, will be their shroud.
  28: 
  29: It is curious to observe how general is the tradition of man’s deterioration: the Bramins say, that the Ganges first rose at Benares—a more sinful generation saw it recede to Hurdwar—a third had to follow it to Burahat—and the fourth age finds it still further off, as it has now its source amid the heights of Gungoutri.

 116: 
 117: In the middle was the golden throne, on which Alexander sat and gave audience.
 118:

 120: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

 122: 
 123: ⁠*4 Alexander's death was preceded by many omens, which sacrifice vainly strove to avert.
 124: 
 125: *5 After the conqueror's death, Roxana allured her gentler rival into her power, and poisoned her.
 126: 
 127: She was the beautiful daughter of a barbarian chief, made captive by Alexander, who was so struck with her charms, that he immediately married her.
 128: 
 129: Statira was the child of Darius, and inherited the evil fortunes of her ill-fated race.
 130: 
 131: *6 Pearls were favourite ornaments with the Persian ladies, who often wore them wreathed in their hair.
 132: 
 133: ⁠*7 The death of Alexander plunged all his vast empire into anarchy and slaughter.
 134: 
 135: He was the soul that animated the mighty force that afterwards wasted its energies in petty warfare.
 136: 
 137: The popular saying attributed to him might well be true, "That the survivors would celebrate his obsequies with bloody funeral games.
 138:

  28: 
  29: It must have been the inconvenience of ascent that drew forth the impassioned exclamation of the noble bard against all such avenues, he who would else have loved them for their very singularity, for their necessary absence from the every-day pageantry of life, from the deep shadows and vivid lights attendant on their narrow width, the height of the houses, and the numerous breaks caused by the projecting balconies and rich architectural decorations.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  42: of England, son of James Edward and Clementine, daughter of Prince Sobiesky, was born at Rome, in 1720.
  43: 
  44: In his attempts to recover the throne of his grandfather, he was supported by the courts of Rome and Versailles, but the battle of Culloden terminated his military career.
  45: 
  46: A reward of £30,000 being offered for his head, he concealed himself in the fastnesses of Scotland until the arrival of a French frigate in Lochnanach, in which he embarked for France, and bade a last adieu to Britain.
  47: 
  48: In the 52nd year of his age he espoused a Princess of Stolberg-Godern, but died, in 1788, aged 68 years.
  49: 
  50: His remains were entombed, at Frescati, with regal pomp.

#649: 115718_Erinna - My hand is on the lyre_Landon, Letitia Elizabeth_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Erinna - My hand is on the lyre
Author: Landon, Letitia Elizabeth
Prose starts at line: 503
Lines to remove: 17
Avg verse line length: 38.8
Avg prose line length: 138.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 498: 
 499: O lute of mine, that I shall wake no more!
 500: Such tearful music linger on thy strings,
 501: Consecrate unto sorrow and to love;
 502: Thy truth, thy tenderness, be all thy fame!

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 503: Among the obligations I owe to "The Brides of Florence," and to the information contained in its interesting notes, I must refer particularly for the origin of the present poem.
 504: 
 505: In one of those notes is the first, indeed the only account I ever met with of Erinna.
 506: 
 507: The following short quotation is sufficient for my present purpose:—"Erinna was a poetess from her cradle, and she only lived to the completion of her eighteenth year.
 508: 
 509: —Of Erinna very little is known; there is in the Grecian Anthology a sepulchral epigram by Antipater on this young poetess.
 510: 
 511: " A poem of the present kind had long floated on my imagination; and this gave it a local habitation and a name.
 512: 
 513: There seemed to me just enough known of Erinna to interest; and I have not attempted to write a classical fiction; feelings are what I wish to narrate, not incidents: my aim has been to draw the portrait and trace the changes of a highly poetical mind, too sensitive perhaps of the chill and bitterness belonging even to success.
 514: 
 515: The feelings which constitute poetry are the same in all ages, they are acted upon by similar causes.
 516: 
 517: Erinna is an ideal not a historical picture, and as such I submit it less to the judgment than to the kindness of my friends.
 518: 
 519: From The Golden Violet


====================================================================================================

  46: A rugged path leads to this beautiful and spacious cavern, which may well, in former days, have been the place of refuge supposed in the foregoing poem.
  47:

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  37: For the British banner keeps
  38: Safe the fortress where it sweeps.
  39: 
  40: During the celebrated siege of Gibraltar, the subjects of her most faithful Majesty, with becoming loyalty and gallantry, but with little knowledge of coming events, erected a small tower on the hill nearest to Gibraltar, from which her Majesty and the ladies of her court, were to witness the surrender of the fortress to her arms.
  41: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  42: This fortalice is called "the Queen's Chair," and from its summit may be enjoyed the most striking, grand, and complete view of the formation of the rock, as well as of its relative position with respect to surrounding objects.
  43: 
  44: At the spectator's feet is the Isthmus, dotted with Spanish sentinel-houses, that mark the limits of the neutral ground, and extend from the ruined fortress of Santa Barbarossa to that of St.
  45: 
  46: Philip.
  47: 
  48: The sandy soil beyond yields to British industry both fruits and vegetables; and the giant rock, that raises its bold form above the sea, is an appropriate emblem of the power, strength, and courage of that nation by which it is retained.
  49: 
  50: The Straits intervene, on the right, between the rock and the African coast, which there attains an elevation of 3,000 feet, and the blue waves of the Mediterranean wash the Isthmus on the left.
  51: 
  52: The accompanying plate was by:
  53: Artist: C.
  54: 
  55: Bentley - Engraved by: E.
  56: 
  57: Finden
  58: The view is from the Signal Tower at the foot of The Queen of Spain's Chair.
  59: 
  60: From Fisher's Drawing Room Scrap Book, 1838

  29: Yet having with all higher things connexion;
  30: Prayers, tears, redeem a world so harsh and cold,
  31: The future has its hope, the past its deep affection.
  32:

  33: The Cemetery of the Smolensko Church is situated about two versts from Petersburgh, on one of the islands on the mouth of the Neva, and less than a quarter of a mile from the gulf of Finland.
  34: 
  35: The curious ceremony represented takes place yearly, when the Russians gather from all parts, to scatter flowers on the graves, and to mourn over the dead, and afterwards proceed to regale themselves with soup, fruit of all kinds, and wine; in many instances spreading their cloths on the very graves over which they had been bitterly mourning.

#655: 115796_Crossing the River Tonse by a Jhoola_Landon, Letitia Elizabeth_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Crossing the River Tonse by a Jhoola
Author: Landon, Letitia Elizabeth
Prose starts at line: 35
Lines to remove: 17
Avg verse line length: 48.6
Avg prose line length: 128.1

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  30: 
  31: Slight as is the bridge, yet it can well sustain them;
  32: Hope carries on life’s passage to the last,
  33: Aiding in its labour, as it aided in its fancies.
  34: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  35: The natives in this part of India perform the operation of crossing their rivers by means of the jhoola, or rope-bridge; holding on with the hands and feet, and making a loop of their bodies: but, for those unaccustomed to their exercises, there is a wooden slide attached to the rope.
  36: 
  37: On the left bank of the Tonse, which is rather more elevated than the opposite one, a three-stranded rope is attached to a log of wood, secured among the rocks.
  38: 
  39: The rope being stretched across the river, (which is here eighty yards in width) is passed between the prongs of a wooden fork, planted firmly in the ground; and being again divided into three strands, is secured to the trunk of a tree, steadied by a heavy weight.
  40: 
  41: The slide, of hollowed wood, hangs like a moveable scale from the rope, having two handles, and a loop to which a thin cord is attached; by means of the latter, the two-handled chair, or slide, is drawn from the lower to the higher bank, the weight of the passenger being sufficient to accomplish the transit in the opposite direction.
  42: 
  43: This is one of Landon's 'concrete' poems in which the three-stranded rope of the jhoola is echoed by the three-lined verses.
  44: 
  45: The accompanying plate was by:
  46: Artist: W.
  47: 
  48: Purser - Engraved by: H.
  49: 
  50: Jorden
  51: From Fisher's Drawing Room Scrap Book, 1839


====================================================================================================

  17: Oh, mighty master of the past!
  18: THE BISHOP OF LIEGE SLAIN BY ORDER OF WILLIAM DE LA MARCK

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  19: While Louis of Bourbon proposed terms of accommodation, in a tone as decided as if he still filled the Episcopal throne, and as if the usurper kneeled a suppliant at his feet, the tyrant slowly raised himself in his chair, the amazement with which he was at first filled giving way gradually to rage, until, as the Bishop ceased, he looked to Nikkei Blok, and raised his finger without speaking a word: the ruffian struck, as if he had been doing his office in the common shambles, and the murdered Bishop sunk, without a groan, at the foot of his own episcopal throne.
  20:

Author: Landon, Letitia Elizabeth
Prose starts at line: 308

Avg prose line length: 127.1

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 303: 
 304: ‘Nay.
 305: 
 306: ' she said, ‘but I will unmantle you.
 307: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 308: I must see if you have kept your word to me, and come as the great earl that men call thee; and not heretofore as a private cavalier.
 309: 
 310: ' And, with a childish wonder, which her youth and rustic education rendered not only excusable but becoming, she examined and admired from head to foot, the noble form and princely attire of him who formed the proudest ornament of the court.
 311: 
 312: ‘But this other fair collar, so richly wrought, with some jewel, like a sheep hung by the middle, attached to it, what,' said the young countess, 'does it signify?
 313: 
 314: ' This collar,' said the earl, 'is the badge of the noble order of the Golden Fleece, once appertaining to the House of Burgundy.
 315: 
 316: It hath high privileges, my Amy, belonging to it—this most noble order—for even the King of Spain himself, who hath now succeeded to the honours and demesnes of Burgundy, may not sit in judgment upon a knight of the Golden Fleece, unless by assistance and consent of the great chapter of the order.
 317: 
 318: It belongs properly to Flanders; and Egmont and Orange have pride in seeing it displayed on an English bosom.
 319: 
 320: Kenilworth.
 321: 
 322: Versions from the German - 5th Series
 323: Literary Gazette, 1835

#658: 115824_Beverley Minster_Landon, Letitia Elizabeth_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Beverley Minster
Author: Landon, Letitia Elizabeth
Prose starts at line: 33
Lines to remove: 11
Avg verse line length: 39.4
Avg prose line length: 81.6

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  28: 
  29: There are both sympathy and warning here;
  30: Methinks as down we kneel by those old graves
  31: The past will pray with us.
  32: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  33: Beverley Minster is a remarkable example of Perpendicular Gothic style and is said to be the most impressive church in the UK that is not a cathedral.
  34: 
  35: There has been a religious building on the spot since at least 700 AD, when St John of Beverly founded a monastery.
  36: 
  37: A later church burned down in 1188, and the present building was started in 1220, though it took 200 years to complete.
  38: 
  39: It is said that the two towers on the West Front inspired Westminster Abbey.
  40: 
  41: The accompanying plate was by:
  42: Artist: Whittock - Engraved by: Fenner
  43: From Fisher's Drawing Room Scrap Book, 1836


====================================================================================================
#659: 115846_Fowey Harbour and Polruan Castle, &c._Landon, Letitia Elizabeth_unknown.txt

Title: Fowey Harbour and Polruan Castle, &c.
Author: Landon, Letitia Elizabeth
Prose starts at line: 42
Lines to remove: 11
Avg verse line length: 35.6
Avg prose line length: 109.9

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  37: Beside him stood a captive knight,
  38: And a banner before him lay:
  39: His ladye's cheek wore its deepest red,
  40: When she told him how she had been lord instead.
  41: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  42: Leland, when speaking of the "Frenchmen" having "diverse times assailed the town" of Fowey, "and last most notably, about Henry the Sixth's time," informs us, that "the wife of Thomas Treury, the 2d, with her men, repelled the French out of her house in her husband's absence; whereupon Thomas Treury builded a righte faire and stronge embateled towr in his house,—and vnto this day it is the glorie of the town building in Faweye.
  43: 
  44: " The tower fell to the ground about sixty years ago, and two busts of the heroine who so gallantly repulsed the enemy, were found in the ruins: they are still preserved.
  45: 
  46: The accompanying plate of Fowey Harbour, St Saviour's Chapel & Polruan Castle was by:
  47: Artist: T.
  48: 
  49: Allom - Engraved by: W.
  50: 
  51: LePetit
  52: From Fisher's Drawing Room Scrap Book, 1832

#660: 115851_Gibraltar—from the Sea_Landon, Letitia Elizabeth_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Gibraltar—from the Sea
Author: Landon, Letitia Elizabeth
Prose starts at line: 74
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 39.6
Avg prose line length: 74.5

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  69: 
  70: This view of the Rock of Gibraltar places it before the spectator in a new light, and conducts rapidly to reflection upon the boldness of those who attempted the reduction of such a fortress, as well as upon the bravery of those, who persevered in the defence of a citadel so bare, so bleak, so barren, so remote from any source of encouragement or supply.
  71: 
  72: The rocky faces, here expressed, look towards the waters of the Mediterranean, and down upon that singular accumulation of fine sand, which, originating at the very edge of the sea, ascends almost to the loftiest pinnacle of the rock.
  73: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  74: From the lowest extremity of this inclined plain, the water becomes suddenly deep.
  75: 
  76: One of the boldest efforts ever made to surprise the rock, took place at this approach.
  77: 
  78: A French officer, in imitation of the Gaul of olden time, attended by 500 followers, landed at the foot of the sandy slope, and, aided by the darkness of night, reached the highest point of the rock in safety.
  79: 
  80: From this rendezvous they were to have rushed down and surprised the garrison, while a second party was to commence an attack from below.
  81: 
  82: Their courage proved superior to their powers of attack and defence, and the morning only shone, to light the garrison of Gibraltar to the destruction of this brave little band of heroes.
  83: 
  84: The accompanying plate was by:
  85: Artist: C.
  86: 
  87: Bentley - Engraved by: J.
  88: 
  89: C.
  90: 
  91: Armytage
  92: From Fisher's Drawing Room Scrap Book, 1838

#662: 115859_A Birthday Tribute to Her Royal Highness the Princess Victoria_Landon, Letitia Elizabeth_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: A Birthday Tribute to Her Royal Highness the Princess Victoria
Author: Landon, Letitia Elizabeth
Prose starts at line: 390
Lines to remove: 13
Avg verse line length: 40.3
Avg prose line length: 107.9

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 385: To labour ere their strength be come,
 386: Or starve—such is the doom
 387: That makes of many an English home,
 388: One long and living tomb.
 389: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 390: This is no overcharged picture: many a cottage in our villages—many a court in our cities, attest its truth.
 391: 
 392: Example is the influence of a sovereign; and royal sympathy will avail to draw that attention which is the harbinger of remedy.
 393: 
 394: In the education of the poor lies the true preservative against the worst ills of want.
 395: 
 396: The first steps towards this object must be taken by the rich; this brings the two classes together, and for their mutual benefit.
 397: 
 398: Indifference is startled out of selfish indulgence—and ignorance awakened into hope.
 399: 
 400: Instruction forms the habit, and lays open the resource—while the schemes that originated in pity will be matured by thought; for to effect the beneficial result, it is the mind that must direct the heart.
 401: 
 402: Published 1837

#663: 115867_Carrick-a-Rede, Ireland_Landon, Letitia Elizabeth_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Carrick-a-Rede, Ireland
Author: Landon, Letitia Elizabeth
Prose starts at line: 34
Lines to remove: 20
Avg verse line length: 30.3
Avg prose line length: 92.9

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  29: He dwelt among those gloomy rocks,
  30: A solitary man.
  31: 
  32: The romantic anecdote, to which the above lines have reference, is a true one.
  33: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  34: —A manuscript journal of a Tour through the Western Islands of Scotland, and along the Northern Coast of Ireland, in 1746, contains the following passage:—
  35: "Carrick-a-Reid is a great rock, cut off from the shore by a chasm of fearful depth, through which the sea, when vexed by angry winds, boileth with great fury.
  36: 
  37: It is resorted to at this season of the year by fishers, for the taking of salmon, who sling themselves across the perilous gulf by means of a stout rope, or withe, as the name Carrick-a-Reid imports.
  38: 
  39: I was told, that, all through the inclemency of last winter, there dwelled here a solitary stranger, of noble mien, in an unseemly hut, made by his own hands.
  40: 
  41: The people, in speaking of the stranger, called him, from his aspect, 'The Man of Sorrow;' and ’tis not unlikely, poor gentleman, he was one of the rebels who fled out of Scotland.
  42: 
  43: In the second volume of "Wakefield's Ireland," a particular account of Carrick-a-Rede, its fishery, and "very extraordinary flying bridge," may be found.
  44: 
  45: The accompanying plate was by:
  46: Artist: T.
  47: 
  48: M.
  49: 
  50: Baynes - Engraved by: J.
  51: 
  52: Davies
  53: Fisher's Drawing Room Scrap Book, 1832

#664: 115868_Liverpool_Landon, Letitia Elizabeth_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Liverpool
Author: Landon, Letitia Elizabeth
Prose starts at line: 95
Lines to remove: 9
Avg verse line length: 29.4
Avg prose line length: 140.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  90: 
  91: Sail on, proud bark, a lofty aim
  92: It was that freighted thee,
  93: And for their sake who tread thy decks,
  94: God speed thee o’er the sea!

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  95: It need scarcely be stated, that the above verses refer to the Expedition which has been equipped by the enterprising merchants of Liverpool, to carry British commerce to the interior of Africa; and which is accompanied by the elder Lander, the faithful companion of the lamented Captain Clapperton.
  96: 
  97: Although the direct object of this Expedition is to establish, by means of the river Quorra or Niger, an intercourse with hitherto inaccessible nations, the advancement of our geographical knowledge has not been neglected, as a naval officer, distinguished for his scientific attainments, proceeds with it, in order to take observations and make surveys.
  98: 
  99: The accompanying plate 'Liverpool, from the Mersey.
 100: 
 101: Commencing at the Prince's Parade' was by:
 102: Artist: Samuel Austen - Engraved by: Robert Brandard
 103: From Fisher's Drawing Room Scrap Book, 1833

#665: 115875_Lines Suggested on Visiting Newstead Abbey_Landon, Letitia Elizabeth_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Lines Suggested on Visiting Newstead Abbey*
Author: Landon, Letitia Elizabeth
Prose starts at line: 78
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 47.4
Avg prose line length: 86.5

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  73: 
  74: ⁠* Newstead Abbey, celebrated as having been the paternal estate of Lord Byron, is situated in Nottinghamshire, within a short distance of Mansfield.
  75: 
  76: It was founded in 1170, by Henry II as a priory for Black Canons, and was granted, at the period of the dissolution of religious houses, to Sir John Byron, lieutenant of Sherwood forest, in Henry the Eighth’s time.
  77: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  78: The grantee incorporated part of the Abbey with his dwelling-house, but suffered the Church to fall into decay.
  79: 
  80: Although the estate continued in the Byron family until 1815, the mansion and offices, which are all in the ecclesiastical style, were much neglected, and the antique and valuable furniture of the chief apartments, alienated by the representatives of the family.
  81: 
  82: The eccentric author of Childe Harolde disposed of this patrimonial inheritance to T.
  83: 
  84: Clawton Esq.
  85: 
  86: , for the sum of £140,000, by whom it was resold to Colonel Wildman for £100,000.
  87: 
  88: It is now in a most perfect state of repair, and, independent of the interest it derives from having once belonged to, perhaps, the first of English poets, it possesses very considerable claim to admiration, as a splendid and beautiful private residence.
  89: 
  90: The accompanying plate 'Newstead Abbey, Nottinghamshire' was by:
  91: Artist: T.
  92: 
  93: Allom - Engraved by: D.
  94: 
  95: Buckle
  96: From Fisher's Drawing Room Scrap Book, 1839


====================================================================================================
#666: 115921_Hurdwar—The Gate of Vishnoo_Landon, Letitia Elizabeth_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Hurdwar—The Gate of Vishnoo
Author: Landon, Letitia Elizabeth
Prose starts at line: 48
Lines to remove: 17
Avg verse line length: 29.9
Avg prose line length: 107.7

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  43: Fling wide the ancient city’s gates,
  44: The hours of night are past,
  45: And Christ, the Conqueror, awaits
  46: Earth’s holiest and her last.
  47: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  48: Hurdwar signifies the Gate of Hari, or Vishnoo, the Saviour of the Hindoo mythology, and has, from the earliest times, been one of the most considerable places of Hindoo pilgrimage and purification.
  49: 
  50: Amongst the hordes who flock to immerse themselves in the holy stream, in the month of April, at the point where it first emancipates itself from the gigantic mountains which give it birth, are many victims of disease, or in the last stage of life, who have literally crawled hundreds of miles, apprehensive lest they should expire from exhaustion before they reach the sacred goal; and ere they arrive, exhibit signs of the most extravagant joy at finding themselves once more able to lave their limbs in the sacred stream.
  51: 
  52: The number of persons usually collected on these occasions varies from two to three thousand; and once in twelve years, when particular ceremonies are observed, they have been computed at a million.
  53: 
  54: The accompanying plate 'Hurdwar, The Gate of Hari or Vishnou' was by:
  55: Artist: J.
  56: 
  57: D.
  58: 
  59: Harding - Engraved by: F.
  60: 
  61: J.
  62: 
  63: Havell
  64: From Fisher's Drawing Room Scrap Book, 1838


====================================================================================================
#667: 115922_Miller’s Dale, Derbyshire_Landon, Letitia Elizabeth_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Miller’s Dale, Derbyshire
Author: Landon, Letitia Elizabeth
Prose starts at line: 45
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 31.6
Avg prose line length: 106.5

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  40: "Have any choice of mine;
  41: "I know in life one only lot,
  42: "So long as I am thine!"
  43: The Miller's Dale is one of the most picturesque passages in the interesting valley of the Wye.
  44: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  45: It extends, for about two miles, in a direction south-east from Wormhill Village, and the colouring of the landscape is diversified by the appearance of loadstone and tufa intersecting the strata of this limestone district.
  46: 
  47: The river, which is pent up within a narrow chasm beneath the mills, appears to rejoice at its release, as it quietly expands into a more ample stream, and glides leisurely away.
  48: 
  49: This delightful dale abounds in scenes that soothe and tranquillize the mind.
  50: 
  51: The stream is never turbulent, never still; though in some places the huge branches of the gnarled oak, or a weather-beaten elm, shoot from a fissure in the rock above, in a manner that Salvator would adopt; yet the light and graceful foliage with which it is accompanied, subdues every feature of wildness, and softens down the whole to beauty.
  52: 
  53: When darkness pervades the Dale, and the many windows are lighted up, and not even the outline of the buildings is to be traced against the dark mountains, fancy may take it for an illuminated palace raised by the magician’s power.
  54: 
  55: The accompanying plate was by:
  56: Artist: T.
  57: 
  58: Allom - Engraved by: J.
  59: 
  60: J.
  61: 
  62: Hinchliff
  63: From Fisher's Drawing Room Scrap Book, 1838

#668: 115923_Antioch_Landon, Letitia Elizabeth_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Antioch
Author: Landon, Letitia Elizabeth
Prose starts at line: 69
Lines to remove: 18
Avg verse line length: 32.6
Avg prose line length: 110.3

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  64: 
  65: I allude to the voyage down the Euphrates.
  66: 
  67: Conquest and commerce have been the two great principles of civilization.
  68: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  69: It is only of late years that we have seen the superiority of the sail over the sword.
  70: 
  71: The expedition, whose advantages I have ventured above to prophesy, is in the noblest spirit of enlightened enterprise.
  72: 
  73: We must take with us our knowledge; and so disturb, and eventually destroy the darkness, mental and moral, too long gathered on the East.
  74: 
  75: The generous earnestness of science, and the enthusiasm of enterprise, were never more nobly marked than in the concluding passage of Colonel Chesney's letter to the Admiralty, announcing the loss of the Tigris steamer:—
  76: "We are, therefore, continuing our descent and survey to Bussarah, hoping not only to bring up the mail from India within the specified time, but also, if it pleases God to spare us, to demonstrate the speed, economy, and commercial advantages of the river Euphrates, provided the decision of ministers shall be, in the true spirit of Englishmen, to give it a fair trial, rather than abandon the original purpose in consequence, of an unforeseen, and, as it is proved, an unavoidable calamity.
  77: 
  78: The accompanying plate 'Antioch, on the Approach from Suadeah' was by:
  79: Artist: W.
  80: 
  81: H.
  82: 
  83: Bartlett - Engraved by: J.
  84: 
  85: Redaway
  86: From Fisher's Drawing Room Scrap Book, 1837

Title: Alexander on the Banks of the Hyphasis
Author: Landon, Letitia Elizabeth
Prose starts at line: 142
Lines to remove: 11
Avg verse line length: 32.4
Avg prose line length: 114.7

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 137: Stirr'd by many a high emotion,
 138: But subdued, confined;—
 139: ⁠              ⁠Such are shadows of the hours,
 140: ⁠              ⁠Glorious in the far-off gloom,
 141: ⁠              ⁠But whose altar is the tomb!

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 142: There is something singularly fine in Alexander's appeal to his army, when the Indian world lay before them, but more present to their fears than to their hopes.
 143: 
 144: "For my own part," said the ardent conqueror, "I recognise no limits to the labours of a high-spirited man but the failure of adequate objects.
 145: 
 146: " Never was more noble motto for all human achievement; and it was from a lofty purpose that the Macedonians turned back on the banks of the Hyphasis.
 147: 
 148: But it is the same with all mortal enterprise: nothing is, in this world, carried out to its complete fulfilment.
 149: 
 150: Our mortality predominates in a world only meant to be a passage to another.
 151: 
 152: From The New Monthly Magazine, 1837 Volume 50

 128: And saith, in its rejoicing orison,
 129: Thank God, thank God, there is a grave; and hope
 130: That looks beyond to heaven!
 131: * The part marked as quotation is translated literally from Corinne's song.
 132: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 133: Its only merit is its exactness, for I have scarcely permitted myself to alter a word.
 134: 
 135: This brief passage is chosen as having less reference to the story than other parts equally beautiful.
 136: 
 137: There occurs, soon afterwards, one of those almost startling remarks which give such peculiarity of thought fulness to Madame de Stael's writings.
 138: 
 139: Corinne says, "Perhaps it is what we shall do to-morrow that will decide our fate; perhaps even yesterday have we said some word that nothing can recal.
 140: 
 141: " I know not what may be the effect on others, but I could never read this short, but true, remark without a feeling of terror.
 142:

 144: Painted by Baron Gerard⁠.

  68: Our history’s blazoned line,
  69: I know not one, brave Collingwood,
  70: That touches me like thine.
  71: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  72: There is a brief but most affecting memoir of Lord Collingwood, in Fisher’s National Portrait Gallery.
  73: 
  74: Feeling every hour his health failing him, he repeatedly petitioned to be recalled—his services were too valuable, and he died in his "high command.
  75: 
  76: " I know nothing more touching than the affectionate regrets he expresses in his letters to his children, that they are growing up in ignorance of their father.

#672: 115965_Genius - Glory of earth, and light from heaven_Landon, Letitia Elizabeth_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Genius - Glory of earth, and light from heaven
Author: Landon, Letitia Elizabeth
Prose starts at line: 105
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 54.2
Avg prose line length: 157.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 100: 
 101: There are two models, recently completed; the one a group of small figures, the subject, Samson slaying the Philistines; the other, a colossal figure of Milo, the Crotonian athlete, at the moment when, being unable to disengage his hands from the cleft of the tree he was endeavouring to tear asunder, he is devoured by wild beasts.
 102: 
 103: They are both perfectly miraculous.
 104: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 105: There is no evasion of difficulties, but a daring defiance, and a complete conquest of them.
 106: 
 107: We will not assert that there may not be slight inaccuracies of detail (although the parts are admirably marked); but we are free to declare, that they are such productions as only the most exalted and powerful genius could conceive and execute.
 108: 
 109: His Milo, we are informed, tumbled to pieces three times while he was about it, from his not having money to purchase the materials necessary for its support! He will need support no longer, or England is insensible to the noblest efforts of the human mind.
 110: 
 111: As something of the history of such a being must be interesting, we shall state the result of our inquiry.
 112: 
 113: In his boyhood Mr.
 114: 
 115: Lough amused himself in modelling the peasantry about him in common clay.
 116: 
 117: The accidental perusal of Gibbon's Decline and Fall gave a classical turn to his mind, and he sought London to improve it.
 118: 
 119: In London, for about two years, his course must have been one of intense study and prodigious labour, which nothing but the most undaunted spirit and irrepressible enthusiasm could have enabled human nature to sustain.
 120: 
 121: By this notice of him we trust to be the means of putting an end to his privations—of cheering him on his glorious way—of procuring him the support he so pre-eminently deserves—and of seeing him enabled, by the prosecution of his studies in an adequate manner at home and in Italy, to reflect back an honour upon his country and age,—and we shall rejoice in having been the instrument to make his value known and appreciated.
 122: 
 123: Literary Gazette, 1827

#673: 115977_Admiral Benbow_Landon, Letitia Elizabeth_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Admiral Benbow
Author: Landon, Letitia Elizabeth
Prose starts at line: 116
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 37.6
Avg prose line length: 57.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 111: 
 112: Being carried below, and proper dressings being applied, he caused himself to be again brought on deck, and continued the action.
 113: 
 114: At this critical moment, he was basely deserted by several of the captains under his command, two of whom were afterwards tried by court-martial and condemned to be shot.
 115: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 116: Benbow, however, sunk gradually under the mental distress occasioned by this transaction and the bodily suffering from his wound, and expired at Jamaica on the 4th of November, 1702.
 117: 
 118: The letter of his opponent, Du Casse, after the battle, is in the highest spirit of chivalry: "Sir, I had little hope on Monday last but to have supped in your cabin.
 119: 
 120: It has pleased God to order it otherwise: I am thankful for it.
 121: 
 122: As to those cowardly captains who deserted you, hang them up, for they richly deserve it.
 123: 
 124: —Your's, Du Casse.
 125:

 127: Artist: Sir G.

#674: 115981_Dr. Morrison and his Chinese Attendants_Landon, Letitia Elizabeth_unknown.txt

Title: Dr. Morrison and his Chinese Attendants
Author: Landon, Letitia Elizabeth
Prose starts at line: 22
Lines to remove: 16
Avg verse line length: 43.7
Avg prose line length: 134.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  17: To them the palm-branch and triumphal song—
  18: Conquerors, and yet the harbingers of peace.
  19: 
  20: Robert Morrison was born at Morpeth, in January 1782.
  21: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  22: He received ordination in London, according to the usages of the Presbyterian church, in which he had been educated; embarked for China on the 31st of January, 1807; proceeded, by way of America, to Macao, and soon afterwards reached Canton.
  23: 
  24: In the history of the acquisition of difficult languages, few facts can be found more memorable than that of his having been considered, in less than a year and a half from his arrival at Canton, the most correct Chinese scholar in the Factories, although destitute, in a very great degree, of the ordinary facilities of obtaining a language.
  25: 
  26: After four years' residence, he completed his Chinese grammar: in his seventh year he commenced the printing of his great work, the Anglo-Chinese dictionary, which consists of six quarto volumes, and occupied him eight years.
  27: 
  28: He had been in a declining state of health previously to Lord Napier's arrival at Macao, but his illness was so much increased by the fatigue he encountered in accompanying his lordship to Canton, that he expired on the 1st of August, 1834, only the eighth day after his arrival in that city.
  29: 
  30: The accompanying plate 'Li Shigong and Chen Laoyi translating the Bible as Morrison looks on' was by:
  31: Artist: G.
  32: 
  33: Chinnery - Engraved by: W.
  34: 
  35: Holl
  36: A facsimile autograph 'Robert Morrison' is also attached
  37: From Fisher's Drawing Room Scrap Book, 1838

Title: Benares
Author: Landon, Letitia Elizabeth
Prose starts at line: 30

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  25: 
  26: " The streets are crowded with "the sacred bulls devoted to Seeva, tame and familiar as mastiffs, walking lazily up and down, and lying across them.
  27: 
  28: Monkeys sacred to Hunooman, the divine ape who conquered Ceylon, are in some parts of the town equally numerous, clinging to all the roofs, and putting their heads or hands into every fruiterer's or confectioner's shop, and snatching the food from the children at their meals.
  29: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  30: Fakirs' houses occur at every turn, adorned with idols, and sending out an unceasing tinkling of vinas, bugals, and other discordant instruments: while religious mendicants, of every Hindoo sect, offering every conceivable deformity, which chalk, disease, matted locks, distorted limbs, and disgusting attitudes of penance, can shew, literally line the principal streets.
  31: 
  32: " "The houses are painted of a deep red, and covered with paintings, in gaudy colours, of flower-pots, men, women, bulls, elephants, gods and goddesses, in all their many-headed, many-handed, many-weaponed varieties.
  33: 
  34: " "The number of temples is very great, mostly small, and stand like shrines in the angles of the streets.
  35: 
  36: Many of them are entirely covered over with beautiful and elaborate carvings of flowers, animals, and palm branches, equalling in minuteness and richness the best specimens I have seen of Gothic or Grecian architecture.
  37: 
  38: " Tavernier mentions a belief of the Brahmins, whence the classic allegory of the golden, silver, brazen, and iron ages originated.
  39: 
  40: "This holy city," say they, "was originally built of gold, but, for the sins of mankind, it was successively degraded to stone, brick, and clay.
  41:

  43: Artist: W.
  44:

Author: Landon, Letitia Elizabeth

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  81: I must hasten from the shore.
  82: 
  83: One first kiss, and one last blessing—
  84: Farewell, love! we meet no more.
  85: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  86: The little sea-port of Kalendria looks, by moonlight, more like the creation of the artist's imagination than the realities of nature.
  87: 
  88: During the friendly silence of the moon, the bold and spiry cliffs, the precipices of shivered slate and fractured limestone, rarely relieved by verdure of any kind, softened by the calm, cold light that falls on each peak, rock, and tower, mercifully shrouds the nakedness and dreariness bared by the fierce and scorching beams of day.
  89: 
  90: At this lone and unfrequented spot, the arrival or departure of a vessel creates an unusual degree of bustle and interest; and if it were not that the couriers for Cyprus from Constantinople embark here, the inhabitants might soon forget that they owed allegiance to the city of the Sultan.
  91: 
  92: This too is the place where, in Tiberius's reign, the progress of the injurious Piso was arrested, after, by his plots and machinations, he had contributed to the death of Germanicus.
  93:

  68: 
  69: Your philosophers inculcate it, your poets rave about it, your every-day people look upon it as something between a pleasure and a duty—till poor London has its merits as little understood as any popular question which every body discusses.
  70: 
  71: I do own I have a most affectionate attachment for London—the deep voice of her multitudes "haunts me like a passion.
  72: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  73: " I delight in observing the infinite variety of her crowded streets, the rich merchandise of the shops, the vast buildings, whether raised for pomp, commerce, or charity, down to the barrel-organ, whose music is only common because it is beautiful.
  74: 
  75: The country is no more left as it was originally created, than Belgrave Square remains its pristine swamp.
  76: 
  77: The forest has been felled, the marsh drained, the enclosures planted, and the field ploughed.
  78: 
  79: All these, begging Mr.
  80: 
  81: Cowper’s pardon, are the works of man’s hands; and so is the town—the one is not more artificial than the other.
  82: 
  83: Both are the result of God’s good gifts—industry and intelligence exerted to the utmost.
  84: 
  85: Let any one ride down Highgate Hill on a summer’s day, see the immense mass of buildings spread like a dark panorama, hear the ceaseless and peculiar sound, which has been likened to the hollow roar of the ocean, but has an utterly differing tone; watch the dense cloud that hangs over all—one perpetual storm, which yet bursts not—and then say, if ever was witnessed hill or valley that so powerfully impressed the imagination with that sublime and awful feeling which is the epic of poetry.
  86: 
  87: Accompanying Plate by:
  88: Artist: Thomas Allom; Engraver: Joseph C.
  89: 
  90: Bentley
  91: From Fisher's Drawing Room Scrap Book, 1833

#679: 116062_Death of the Lion among the Ruins of Sbeitlah_Landon, Letitia Elizabeth_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Death of the Lion among the Ruins of Sbeitlah
Author: Landon, Letitia Elizabeth
Prose starts at line: 51
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 29.9
Avg prose line length: 169.9

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  46: And the grass is red with gore.
  47: 
  48: For the claws and skin we come—
  49: Let us bear our trophy home.
  50: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  51: Sbeitlah (anciently Sufetula) stands on a spacious plain, at the base of a range of hills that are clothed with the juniper, the cistus, and the pine, and on the right bank of the Wady-Sbeitlah, a limpid stream, rushing in whirling eddies through a deep, meandering, rocky chasm.
  52: 
  53: The principal surviving ruins consist of three contiguous temples, two triumphal arches, a palace, and an aqueduct which spans the stream.
  54: 
  55: Besides ruins of churches, triumphal arches, and other demonstrations of ancient pride, one paved street remains entire.
  56: 
  57: This lonely avenue, that formerly resounded with the trampling of the high-spirited steeds, as they drew, through crowds of admiring citizens, the gorgeous chariot of their imperial master, is now trodden, at long intervals, only by the Christian traveller, who, as his footstep falls, the sole interruption of a death-like silence, disturbs occasionally the lizard or the leffah, basking in the heat of noon.
  58: 
  59: Here, where "sad memory brings the light of other days around us," the solitude of day is succeeded by the terrific sounds that disturb the night—the bark of the prowling wolf, the melancholy scream of the night-bird, and the awful roar of the lordly lion.
  60: 
  61: The vicinity of Sbeitlah is still the Leonum arida natrix, and lion-hunting forms not only one of the chief amusements, but even most profitable occupations: so replete is every spot of ground, every shattered column, nay, every lion slain, with classical feeling and allusion, that this was nature's nursery whence one hundred lions at a time were furnished, for the sports of warlike Rome, at the command of Sylla: Pompey drew hence six hundred, and Caesar was content with four hundred of the fiercest.
  62: 
  63: The accompanying plate 'Ruins of Sbeitlah, the ancient Sufetula, Tunis' was by:
  64: Artist: C.
  65: 
  66: Bentley - Engraved by: S.
  67: 
  68: Lacey
  69: From Fisher's Drawing Room Scrap Book, 1838

#680: 116066_Infanticide in Madagascar_Landon, Letitia Elizabeth_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Infanticide in Madagascar
Author: Landon, Letitia Elizabeth
Prose starts at line: 80
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 28.9
Avg prose line length: 133.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  75: Cold, selfish, shunning care and cost,
  76: The poor are left unknown;
  77: I say, for every soul thus lost,
  78: We answer with our own.
  79: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  80: The Malagassy regard certain days as propitious to every procedure resulting from the events of those days, and other days as the reverse.
  81: 
  82: This delusive influence inculcates the belief, that all born on these inauspicious days will be its subjects and agents through life, and superinduces a conviction, that to spare and nurse the unhappy infants, born on such days, would be to cherish sorcerers, the chief instruments in inflicting every calamity they fear.
  83: 
  84: On the birth, therefore, of an infant, the great solicitude of the parents is to know its vintana, or destiny, which must be ascertained by certain rules.
  85: 
  86: Amongst the varied exhibitions of the domination of superstition, there is not, perhaps, presented a scene of more affecting wretchedness than the one displayed in the engraving.
  87: 
  88: An infant, perfectly helpless, and unconscious, smiling perhaps in innocence, is laid in a narrow entrance to a village, or a fold, through which there is barely room for cattle to pass, several of which are driven violently in, and made to pass over the spot on which the child is placed, while the parents, with agonizing feelings, stand by waiting the result.
  89: 
  90: If the oxen pass over without injuring the infant, the omen is propitious; the powerful and evil destiny is removed, and the parents may, without apprehension, embrace and cherish their offspring.
  91: 
  92: The accompanying plate was by:
  93: Artist: H.
  94: 
  95: Melville - Engraved by: J.
  96: 
  97: Redaway
  98: From Fisher's Drawing Room Scrap Book, 1838

Author: Landon, Letitia Elizabeth
Prose starts at line: 37
Lines to remove: 11
Avg verse line length: 35.3
Avg prose line length: 152.4

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  32: We must give peace, love, charity, to earth;
  33: And from old superstitions, vain beliefs,
  34: And false religions, realize the true:
  35: So morning springs from out the depths of night.
  36: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  37: The temple of Borro Boedoor was in former days the most celebrated Budha temple in the Island of Java equally distinguished for its extent and its magnificence.
  38: 
  39: These remarkable ruins, representing in a high style of Indian architecture a number of small Hindoo sacred buildings with their several idols, so peculiarly combined as to form one place of worship, are engraved from a drawing forming part of the collection brought to England by Sir Alexander Johnstone, to shew the moral and political influence which the religion of Budha had exercised in former days, and still continues to exercise; and the importance of instructing the two High-priests of Budha, (whose portraits are given in this volume,) whom he had brought over with him at the same time, in every branch of European science and literature, in order that they might, upon their return to Ceylon, be made use of as a powerful engine for enlightening those who professed their creed.
  40: 
  41: The accompanying plate was by:
  42: Artist: W.
  43: 
  44: Purser - Engraved by: S.
  45: 
  46: Bradshaw
  47: Form Fisher's Drawing Room Scrap Book, 1836

  44: 
  45: ⁠* We talk of the beauties of nature, I must own I am more pleased with those of art.
  46: 
  47: I know no spectacle more impressive than a great street in a great city,—take Piccadilly, for instance; the immense variety of faces that hurry past, each without interest in the other, for how rare it is to remark the greeting even of acquaintance; indeed, you may often walk for days, and not meet a creature you know.
  48: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  49: The houses, with all their daily life—associations of comfort, force you to think how man's ingenuity has been exerted for man's pleasure.
  50: 
  51: The shops, where every article is a triumph of ingenuity—some curious, some beautiful.
  52: 
  53: The sweep of the Green Park: grass close beside the worn pavement,—the beautiful garden of Lord Coventry,—the royal gift destined for the solace of the blind and of the aged friend.
  54: 
  55: Westminster Abbey rising in dim and dusky grandeur,—Westminster Abbey, where history becomes poetry, and whose illustrious dead are familiar to every memory.
  56: 
  57: The many carriages, each like a grade in the complicated grades of society; the wealth few pause to envy, the poverty still fewer pause to pity.
  58: 
  59: The gradual closing in of night, whose empire is here disputed by the lamps linked in one long line of light,—each holding its imprisoned flame, and, last, the triumphal arch at Hyde Park, while the open space behind is shrouded in unbroken darkness.

Author: Landon, Letitia Elizabeth

Avg prose line length: 90.9

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  51: Dreams of what cannot be;
  52: Gone is thy visionary smile,
  53: And thou art but a distant isle
  54: Upon a distant sea.
  55: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  56: The island of Corfu is situated at the entrance of the Adriatic Sea, and is the seat of government of the Septinsular Union.
  57: 
  58: It has been immortalized by Homer, and is the imaginary theatre on which many of the fables of mythology were represented.
  59: 
  60: The Venetians and Mussulmans have struggled, with a degree of ferocity disgraceful even to the sanguinary laws of war, for the possession of this spot, and its present independent position throws a species of ridicule upon the designs of the most powerful and resolute monarchs.
  61: 
  62: The extreme length of the island does not exceed thirty-five miles, its greatest breadth is twelve, and its superficies covers about eighty square leagues.
  63: 
  64: The population may be estimated at 6000 souls.
  65: 
  66: The accompanying plate 'Corfu and Manduchio from Mount Olivet, Grecian hills in the distance' was by:
