 116: And patient in my wo.
 117: 
 118: To me thy early grave appears
 119: An altar for my prayers and tears.
 120: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 121: Matlock and its vicinity, on the banks of the Derwent, in Derbyshire, are celebrated for their thermal springs, and romantic scenery.
 122: 
 123: The waters, which resemble those of Clifton, were discovered in 1698, and are useful in rheumatic affections, and incipient consumption.
 124: 
 125: The "Heights of Abraham" are a pile of picturesque rocks, in the fissures of which the roots of the most luxuriant trees are able to find sufficient nourishment.
 126: 
 127: The beautiful mineral, called Derbyshire spar, from which vases and chimney ornaments are formed, is obtained here.
 128:

  12:

  14: 
  15: If he tastes mud as bitter as this poemOf mine, then I win – and you love me.

#690: 116786_To Good Guys Dead_Hemingway, Ernest_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: To Good Guys Dead
Author: Hemingway, Ernest
Prose starts at line: 14
Lines to remove: 9
Avg verse line length: 15.8
Avg prose line length: 132.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   9: Democracy,
  10: Honor—
  11: Words and phrases,
  12: They either bitched or killed us.
  13: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  14: In line 2 Hemmingway is referring to no specific king but is, in fact, using a rallying cry from the  British Army which was used for centuries (allegedly).
  15: 
  16: For example at the start of a cavalry charge against the enemy an officer (often a nobleman) might yell "For King and Country" to encourage his soldiers to fight.
  17: 
  18: This goes back to the days when the monarch took a more dominant part in ruling the country than HM Queen Elizabeth does now.
  19: 
  20: The other phrases are similar rallying cries which are meaningless echoes of past days and he is using them to illustrate all the stupid reasons people give for wars and in doing so is trying to denegrate war itself.
  21: 
  22: Jim S

   1: From "Emancipation Of Women"
   2: 
   3: II
   4: Tao much has been written and said both in Poland and abroad regarding the inferiority of women for anyone still to engage with this formal paradox.
   5: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   6: The philosopher Trentowski raises this assumption to critical respectability when he says that, "All women sew and cook, yet when we need a well-sewn garment or a good dinner, we choose a tailor or a chef, and not a seamstress or a cook.
   7: 
   8: Rather than reply to this acerbum dicturrt, let us agree it is witty, although this is not a weighty virtue in a philosopher.
   9: 
  10: 
  11: III
  12: In our view woman is an organisation which is naturally higher than man The fundamental design of the structure of her body is more beautiful, because the skeleton divides into two almost equal halves.
  13: 
  14: Her whole nervous system is more subtle - her endurance greater - she can bear hunger, thirst and worries longer than man.
  15: 
  16: Indeed, it must be so naturally, since her organism is through motherhood responsible for TWO lives and must therefore be more perfectly equipped.
  17: 
  18: Aud so it is.
  19: 
  20: From her superiority comes woman's distinctive charm and social influence which in reality confers on her a priesthood, because woman, being the high­est tie between the lonely I and the public We, becomes the first priestess na­turally immolating egotism and prcviding a grounding for the collective social body.
  21: 
  22: All the insignia of the most ancient peoples representing settlements and cities and also virtues and inspirations, are embodied in female shapes.
  23: 
  24: I think that without the Trojan war there would have been no Europe, and not only I but everyone maintains there could have been no Hellas at all!


====================================================================================================

#694: 117760_from The Princess- O Swallow_Tennyson, Alfred Lord_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: from The Princess: O Swallow
Author: Tennyson, Alfred Lord
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 15
Avg verse line length: 28.0
Avg prose line length: 130.9

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: from The Princess: O Swallow
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: O Swallow, Swallow, flying, flying South, Fly to her, and fall upon her gilded eaves, And tell her, tell her, what I tell to thee.
   4: 
   5: O tell her, Swallow, thou that knowest each, That bright and fierce and fickle is the South, And dark and true and tender is the North.
   6: 
   7: O Swallow, Swallow, if I could follow, and light Upon her lattice, I would pipe and trill, And cheep and twitter twenty million loves.
   8: 
   9: O were I thou that she might take me in, And lay me on her bosom, and her heart Would rock the snowy cradle till I died.
  10: 
  11: Why lingereth she to clothe her heart with love, Delaying as the tender ash delays To clothe herself, when all the woods are green?
  12: 
  13: O tell her, Swallow, that thy brood is flown: Say to her, I do but wanton in the South, But in the North long since my nest is made.
  14: 
  15: O tell her, brief is life but love is long, And brief the sun of summer in the North, And brief the moon of beauty in the South.
  16: 
  17: O Swallow, flying from the golden woods, Fly to her, and pipe and woo her, and make her mine, And tell her, tell her, that I follow thee.

#695: 117777_from The Princess- Our Enemies Have Fall'n_Tennyson, Alfred Lord_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: from The Princess: Our Enemies Have Fall'n
Author: Tennyson, Alfred Lord
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 9
Avg verse line length: 42.0
Avg prose line length: 238.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: from The Princess: Our Enemies Have Fall'n
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: Our enemies have fall'n, have fall'n: the seed, The little seed they laugh'd at in the dark, Has risen and cleft the soil, and grown a bulk Of spanless girth, that lays on every side A thousand arms and rushes to the Sun.
   4: 
   5: Our enemies have fall'n, have fall'n: they came; The leaves were wet with women's tears: they heard A noise of songs they would not understand: They mark'd it with the red cross to the fall, And would have strown it, and are fall'n themselves.
   6: 
   7: Our enemies have fall'n, have fall'n: they came, The woodmen with their axes: lo the tree! But we will make it faggots for the hearth, And shape it plank and beam for roof and floor, And boats and bridges for the use of men.
   8: 
   9: Our enemies have fall'n, have fall'n: they struck; With their own blows they hurt themselves, nor knew There dwelt an iron nature in the grain: The glittering axe was broken in their arms, Their arms were shatter'd to the shoulder blade.
  10: 
  11: Our enemies have fall'n, but this shall grow A night of Summer from the heat, a breadth Of Autumn, dropping fruits of power; and roll'd With music in the growing breeze of Time, The tops shall strike from star to star, the fangs Shall move the stony bases of the world.

#696: 117787_In Memoriam A. H. H. 116_Tennyson, Alfred Lord_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: In Memoriam A. H. H. 116
Author: Tennyson, Alfred Lord
Prose starts at line: 24
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 32.3
Avg prose line length: 106.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  19: Less yearning for the friendship fled,
  20: Than some strong bond which is to be.
  21: 
  22: 1.
  23: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  24: First published anonymously in the volume with this title in 1850, though the 131 sections or separate poems that compose it were written and rewritten from 1833 to the time of publication.
  25: 
  26: Two of the 131 sections were added in later editions: LIX in 1851, and XXXIX in 1872.
  27: 
  28: The poem is in memory of Tennyson's friend Arthur Henry Hallam, son of the eminent historian.
  29: 
  30: Hallam was engaged to marry Tennyson's
  31: sister Emily, when he died suddenly of a stroke in Vienna on September 15, 1833, at the age of wenty-two.
  32: 
  33: Although written without any plan at first, the parts of the poem were finally arranged in a pattern to cover the period of about three years following Hallam's death.
  34: 
  35: Tennyson himself insisted that it is "a poem, not a biography .
  36: 
  37: 
  38: The different moods of sorrow as in a drama are dramatically given, and my conviction that fear, doubts, and suffering will find answer and relief only through Faith in a God of Love.
  39: 
  40: `I' is not always the author speaking of himself, but the voice of the human race speaking through him.
  41: 
  42: OBIIT MDCCCXXXIIII: he died in 1833.

#697: 117799_The Lotos-eaters_Tennyson, Alfred Lord_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Lotos-eaters
Author: Tennyson, Alfred Lord
Prose starts at line: 69
Lines to remove: 15
Avg verse line length: 155.4
Avg prose line length: 294.5

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  64: 
  65: Let what is broken so remain.
  66: 
  67: The Gods are hard to reconcile: 'Tis hard to settle order once again.
  68: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  69: There is confusion worse than death, Trouble on trouble, pain on pain, Long labour unto aged breath, Sore task to hearts worn out by many wars And eyes grown dim with gazing on the pilot-stars.
  70: 
  71: VII But, propt on beds of amaranth and moly, How sweet (while warm airs lull us, blowing lowly) With half-dropt eyelid still, Beneath a heaven dark and holy, To watch the long bright river drawing slowly His waters from the purple hill— To hear the dewy echoes calling From cave to cave thro' the thick-twined vine— To watch the emerald-colour'd water falling Thro' many a wov'n acanthus-wreath divine! Only to hear and see the far-off sparkling brine, Only to hear were sweet, stretch'd out beneath the pine.
  72: 
  73: VIII The Lotos blooms below the barren peak: The Lotos blows by every winding creek: All day the wind breathes low with mellower tone: Thro' every hollow cave and alley lone Round and round the spicy downs the yellow Lotos-dust is blown.
  74: 
  75: We have had enough of action, and of motion we, Roll'd to starboard, roll'd to larboard, when the surge was seething free, Where the wallowing monster spouted his foam-fountains in the sea.
  76: 
  77: Let us swear an oath, and keep it with an equal mind, In the hollow Lotos-land to live and lie reclined On the hills like Gods together, careless of mankind.
  78: 
  79: For they lie beside their nectar, and the bolts are hurl'd Far below them in the valleys, and the clouds are lightly curl'd Round their golden houses, girdled with the gleaming world: Where they smile in secret, looking over wasted lands, Blight and famine, plague and earthquake, roaring deeps and fiery sands, Clanging fights, and flaming towns, and sinking ships, and praying hands.
  80: 
  81: But they smile, they find a music centred in a doleful song Steaming up, a lamentation and an ancient tale of wrong, Like a tale of little meaning tho' the words are strong; Chanted from an ill-used race of men that cleave the soil, Sow the seed, and reap the harvest with enduring toil, Storing yearly little dues of wheat, and wine and oil; Till they perish and they suffer—some, 'tis whisper'd—down in hell Suffer endless anguish, others in Elysian valleys dwell, Resting weary limbs at last on beds of asphodel.
  82: 
  83: Surely, surely, slumber is more sweet than toil, the shore Than labour in the deep mid-ocean, wind and wave and oar; O, rest ye, brother mariners, we will not wander more.


====================================================================================================
#698: 117890_from Maud (Part II)_Tennyson, Alfred Lord_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: from Maud (Part II)
Author: Tennyson, Alfred Lord
Prose starts at line: 19
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 112.0
Avg prose line length: 229.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  14: 
  15: A shadow flits before me, Not thou, but like to thee: Ah Christ, that it were possible For one short hour to see The souls we loved, that they might tell us What and where they be.
  16: 
  17: It leads me forth at evening, It lightly winds and steals In a cold white robe before me, When all my spirit reels At the shouts, the leagues of lights, And the roaring of the wheels.
  18: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  19: Half the night I waste in sighs, Half in dreams I sorrow after The delight of early skies; In a wakeful doze I sorrow For the hand, the lips, the eyes, For the meeting of the morrow, The delight of happy laughter, The delight of low replies.
  20: 
  21: 'Tis a morning pure and sweet, And a dewy splendour falls On the little flower that clings To the turrets and the walls; 'Tis a morning pure and sweet, And the light and shadow fleet; She is walking in the meadow, And the woodland echo rings; In a moment we shall meet; She is singing in the meadow, And the rivulet at her feet Ripples on in light and shadow To the ballad that she sings.
  22: 
  23: So I hear her sing as of old, My bird with the shining head, My own dove with the tender eye?
  24: 
  25: But there rings on a sudden a passionate cry, There is some one dying or dead, And a sullen thunder is roll'd; For a tumult shakes the city, And I wake, my dream is fled; In the shuddering dawn, behold, Without knowledge, without pity, By the curtains of my bed That abiding phantom cold.
  26: 
  27: Get thee hence, nor come again, Mix not memory with doubt, Pass, thou deathlike type of pain, Pass and cease to move about! 'Tis the blot upon the brain That will show itself without.
  28: 
  29: Then I rise, the eave-drops fall, And the yellow vapours choke The great city sounding wide; The day comes, a dull red ball Wrapt in drifts of lurid smoke On the misty river-tide.
  30: 
  31: Thro' the hubbub of the market I steal, a wasted frame; It crosses here, it crosses there, Thro' all that crowd confused and loud, The shadow still the same; And on my heavy eyelids My anguish hangs like shame.
  32: 
  33: Alas for her that met me, That heard me softly call, Came glimmering thro' the laurels At the quiet evenfall, In the garden by the turrets Of the old manorial hall.
  34: 
  35: Would the happy spirit descend From the realms of light and song, In the chamber or the street, As she looks among the blest, Should I fear to greet my friend Or to say "Forgive the wrong," Or to ask her, "Take me, sweet, To the regions of thy rest"?
  36: 
  37: But the broad light glares and beats, And the shadow flits and fleets And will not let me be; And I loathe the squares and streets, And the faces that one meets, Hearts with no love for me: Always I long to creep Into some still cavern deep, There to weep, and weep, and weep My whole soul out to thee.


====================================================================================================
#699: 117927_In Memoriam A. H. H. OBIIT MDCCCXXXIII- 106_Tennyson, Alfred Lord_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: In Memoriam A. H. H. OBIIT MDCCCXXXIII: 106
Author: Tennyson, Alfred Lord
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 15
Avg verse line length: 43.0
Avg prose line length: 144.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: In Memoriam A. H. H. OBIIT MDCCCXXXIII: 106
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: Ring out, wild bells, to the wild sky,   The flying cloud, the frosty light:   The year is dying in the night;Ring out, wild bells, and let him die.
   4: 
   5: Ring out the old, ring in the new,   Ring, happy bells, across the snow:   The year is going, let him go;Ring out the false, ring in the true.
   6: 
   7: Ring out the grief that saps the mind   For those that here we see no more;   Ring out the feud of rich and poor,Ring in redress to all mankind.
   8: 
   9: Ring out a slowly dying cause,   And ancient forms of party strife;   Ring in the nobler modes of life,With sweeter manners, purer laws.
  10: 
  11: Ring out the want, the care, the sin,   The faithless coldness of the times;   Ring out, ring out my mournful rhymesBut ring the fuller minstrel in.
  12: 
  13: Ring out false pride in place and blood,   The civic slander and the spite;   Ring in the love of truth and right,Ring in the common love of good.
  14: 
  15: Ring out old shapes of foul disease;   Ring out the narrowing lust of gold;   Ring out the thousand wars of old,Ring in the thousand years of peace.
  16: 
  17: Ring in the valiant man and free,   The larger heart, the kindlier hand;   Ring out the darkness of the land,Ring in the Christ that is to be.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  53: 
  54: Found in his Musarum deliciae: or the Muses' recreation, containing several pieces of poetique wit, 2d edition.
  55: 
  56: 1656, 12mo.
  57: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  58: Quoted from Percy's Reliques, 'When the Scottish covenanters rose up in arms, and advanced to the English borders in 1639, many of the courtiers complimented the king by raising forces at their own expense.
  59: 
  60: Among these, none were more distinguished than the gallant Sir John Sucling, who raised a troop of horse, so richly accoutred, that it cost him 12,000 [pounds].
  61: 
  62: The like expensive equipment of other parts of the army made the king remark, that ''the Scots would fight stoutly, if it were but for the Englishmen's fine cloaths.
  63: 
  64: '' .
  65: 
  66: 
  67: When they came to action, the rugged Scots proved more than a match for the fine showy english: many of whom behaved remarkably ill, and among the rest this splendid troop of Sir John Suckling's.
  68: 
  69: ' This poem attributed by contemporaries to Sir John Mennis.

 465: Shut from the busy world of more incredulous.

 467: (line 48): Originally, "Cerulean-spotted.
 468: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 469: " Leigh Hunt says of this passage, "The admiration, pity, and horror, to be excited by humanity in a brute shape, were never perhaps called upon by a greater mixture of beauty and deformity than in the picture of this creature.
 470: 
 471: Our pity and suspicions are begged by the first word: the profuse and vital beauties with which she is covered seem proportioned to her misery and natural rights; and lest we should lose sight of them in this gorgeousness, the 'woman's mouth' fills us at once with shuddering and compassion.
 472: 
 473: (line 158): The manuscript reads "vulcanian," the first edition "volcanian.
 474: 
 475: " It seems to me more likely that the manuscript accords with the poet's intention than that printed text does, for this old orthography is the more characteristic of the vocabulary of this particular poem, as introducing the more conspicuously the mythic personal origin of the common noun "volcano" or "vulcano.
 476:

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  31: The old man may sleep, and the planets may wink;
  32: The shut rose shall dream of our loves, and awake
  33: Full blown, and such warmth for the morning's take;
  34: The stock-dove shall hatch her soft brace and shall coo,
  35: While I kiss to the melody, aching all through!

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  36: 'As far as I have been able to trace this poem, it appeared for the first time in the Life, Letters, and Literary Remains (1848), where it is dated 1818.
  37: 
  38: The statement in the Aldine Edition of 1876 that it was first printed in The Literary Pocket-book or Companion for the Lover of Nature and Art, for 1818, must derive from some misapprehension, as there is no such book.
  39: 
  40: The Pocket-book was started, by Hunt in 1819; and in a copy of the book for that year now in Sir Charles Dilke's possession Keats wrote the Song; but it is not printed in that or in either of the four later Pocket-books which complete the series.
  41: 
  42: ~ Poetical Works of John Keats, ed.
  43: 
  44: H.
  45: 
  46: Buxton Forman, Crowell publ.
  47: 
  48: 1895.

Author: Keats, John
Prose starts at line: 292

Avg verse line length: 41.8
Avg prose line length: 103.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 287: Was there a Poet born?
 288: 
 289: —but now no more,
 290: My wand’ring spirit must no further soar.
 291: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 292: I stood tip-toe upon a little hill : Leigh Hunt tells us in 'Lord Byron and Some of his Contemporaries' that "this poem was suggested to Keats by a delightful summer's-day, as he stood beside the gate that leads from the Battery on Hampstead Heath into a field by Caen Wood.
 293: 
 294: (lines 37-41) Of this passage Hunt says, "Any body who has seen a throng of young beeches, furnishing those natural clumpy seats at the root, must recognize the truth and grace of this description.
 295: 
 296: " He adds that the remainder of the poem, especially verses 47 to 86, "affords an exquisite proof of close observation of nature as well as the most luxuriant fancy.
 297: 
 298: (lines 61-80) Charles Cowden Clarke says Keats told him this passage was the recollection of the friends' "having frequently loitered over the rail of a foot-bridge that spanned .
 299: 
 300: 
 301: a little brook in the last field upon entering Edmonton.
 302: 
 303: " Keats, he says, "thought the picture correct, and acknowledged to a partiality for it.
 304: 
 305: ~The Poetical Works of John Keats, ed.
 306: 
 307: H.
 308: 
 309: Buxton Forman, Crowell publ.
 310: 
 311: 1895.

#705: 118326_The Cap And Bells; Or, The Jealousies- A Faery Tale -- Unfinished_Keats, John_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Cap And Bells; Or, The Jealousies: A Faery Tale -- Unfinished
Author: Keats, John
Prose starts at line: 1183
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 39.4
Avg prose line length: 92.5

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1178: 
1179: The late Dante Gabriel Rossetti wrote to me of this poem as "the only unworthy stuff Keats ever wrote except an early trifle or two," and again as "the to me hateful Cap and Bells.
1180: 
1181: " I confess that it seems to me entirely unworthy of Keats, though certainly a proof, if proof were needed, of his versatility.
1182: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1183: It has the character of a mere intellectual and mechanical exercise, performed at a time when those higher forces constituting the mainspring of poetry were exhausted; but even so I find it difficult to figure Keats as doing anything so aimless as this appears when regarded solely as an effort of the fancy.
1184: 
1185: He probably had a satirical under-current of meaning; and it needs no great stretch of the imagination to see the illicit passion of Emperor Elfinan, and his detestation for his authorized bride-elect, an oblique glance at the martial relations of George IV.
1186: 
1187: It is not difficult to suggest prototypes for many of the faery-land statesmen against whom Elfinan vows vengeance; and there are many particulars in which earthly incidents are too thickly strewn to leave one in the settled belief that the poet's programme was wholly unearthly.
1188: 
1189: --- H.
1190: 
1191: B.
1192: 
1193: F.
1194: 
1195: ~ Poetical Works of John Keats, ed.
1196: 
1197: H.
1198: 
1199: Buxton Forman, Crowell publ.
1200: 
1201: 1895.

#706: 118327_Endymion- Book I_Keats, John_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Endymion: Book I
Author: Keats, John
Prose starts at line: 1280
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 39.4
Avg prose line length: 188.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1275: 
1276: PREFACE.
1277: 
1278: Knowing within myself the manner in which this Poem has been produced, it is not without a feeling of regret that I make it public.
1279: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1280: What manner I mean, will be quite clear to the reader, who must soon perceive great inexperience, immaturity, and every error denoting a feverish attempt, rather than a deed accomplished.
1281: 
1282: The two first books, and indeed the two last, I feel sensible are not of such completion as to warrant their passing the press; nor should they if I thought a year's castigation would do them any good; -- it will not: the foundations are too sandy.
1283: 
1284: It is just that this youngster should die away: a sad thought for me, if I had not some hope that while it is dwindling I may be plotting, and fitting myself for verses fit to live.
1285: 
1286: This may be speaking too presumptuously, and may deserve a punishment: but no feeling man will be forward to inflict it: he will leave me alone, with the conviction that there is not a fiercer hell than the failure in a great object.
1287: 
1288: This is not written with the least atom of purpose to forestall criticisms of course, but from the desire I have to conciliate men who are competent to look, and who do look with a zealous eye, to the honor of English literature.
1289: 
1290: The imagination of a boy is healthy, and the mature imagination of a man is healthy; but there is a space of life between, in which the soul is in a ferment, the character undecided, the way of life uncertain, the ambition thick-sighted: thence proceeds mawkishness, and all the thousand bitters which those men I speak of must necessarily taste in going over the following pages.
1291: 
1292: I hope I have not in too late a day touched the beautiful mythology of Greece, and dulled its brightness: for I wish to try once more, before I bid it farewell.
1293: 
1294: Teignmouth, April 10, 1818.
1295: 
1296: [footnote] Woodhouse notes -- "[for I wish to try once more,] This alluded to his then intention of writing a poem on the fall of Hyperion.
1297: 
1298: He commenced this poem: but, thanks to the critics who fell foul of this work, he discontinued it.


====================================================================================================

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 107: 
 108: The town still has, like most country towns of any consequence, a Market Street.
 109: 
 110: Of the dykes, ditches, &c.
 111: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 112: , of "the Barton" I can give no account, as I do not know to what particular manor-house and demesne the term was ever applied at Teignmouth.
 113: 
 114: There is a touch of "local colour" in the white violets of stanza 6; for though primroses and violets are found in almost all parts of the country, white violets are not quite common about Teignmouth, but are to be found at Bishop's Teignton.
 115: 
 116: It is a pity that this choice little bit of trifling should be disfigured by the false rhyme 'critics' and 'Prickets'.
 117: 
 118: Keats does not seem to have been quite certain when he despatched his letter whether his "doggerel" had been written seriously or not; for he resumes prose with --
 119: "I know not if this rhyming fit has done anything: it will be safe with you, if worthy to put among my Lyrics.
 120: 
 121: We must consider these trifles worthy to go among his lyrics, in virtue of their fine sense of rhythm and their keen relish for out of door life.
 122: 
 123: ~ Poetical Works of John Keats, ed.
 124: 
 125: H.

1379:

1381:

1383: 
1384: (lines 689-92) Endymion conjectures whether his unknown love is one of the Hours, or one of the nymph Pleione's daughters by Atlas, transferred to heaven as the Pleiades.

#709: 118338_Hyperion. Book I_Keats, John_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Hyperion. Book I
Author: Keats, John
Prose starts at line: 459
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 39.4
Avg prose line length: 136.9

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 454: Forward he stoop'd over the airy shore,
 455: And plung'd all noiseless into the deep night.
 456: 
 457: 'Lord Houghton records, on the authority of Brown, that "Hyperion" was begun after the death of Tom Keats, when the poet took up his residence at Wentworth Place.
 458: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 459: (line 14): It seems to me that the power of realization shown in the first decade, and indeed throughout the fragment, answers all objections to the subject, and is the most absolute security for the nobility of the result which Keats would have achieved had he finished the poem.
 460: 
 461: It is impossible to over-estimate the value of such a landscape, so touched in with a few strokes of titanic meaning and completeness; and the whole sentiment of gigantic despair reflected around the fallen god of the Titan dynasty, and permeating the landscape, is resumed in the most perfect manner in the incident of the motionless fallen leaf, a line almost as intense and full of the essence of poetry as any line in our language.
 462: 
 463: It were ungracious to take exception to the poor Naiad; but she has not the convincing appropriateness of the rest of this sublime opening.
 464: 
 465: (line 51): Leigh Hunt's remarks upon Keats's failure to finish the poem are specially appropriate to this passage, "If any living poet could finish this fragment, we believe it is the author himself.
 466: 
 467: But perhaps he feels that he ought not.
 468: 
 469: A story which involves passion, almost of necessity involves speech; and though we may well enough describe beings greater than ourselves by comparison, unfortunately we cannot make them speak by comparison.
 470: 
 471: ~ Poetical Works of John Keats, ed.
 472: 
 473: H.
 474: 
 475: Buxton Forman, Crowell publ.
 476: 
 477: 1895.

#711: 118356_Sonnet. Written On A Blank Space At The End Of Chaucer's Tale Of 'The Floure And_Keats, John_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Sonnet. Written On A Blank Space At The End Of Chaucer's Tale Of 'The Floure And The Lefe'
Author: Keats, John
Prose starts at line: 23
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 53.6
Avg prose line length: 106.9

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  18: 
  19: 'This sonnet was published in The Examiner for the 16th of March 1817, having been written in February 1817 in the late Charles Cowden Clarke's "miniature 18mo.
  20: 
  21: copy of Chaucer," as recorded in Clarke's Recollections of Keats in The Gentleman's Magazine.
  22: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  23: When Clarke died, he bequeathed the Chaucer to Alexander Ireland, author of the Leigh Hunt, Lamb, and Hazlitt Bibliography.
  24: 
  25: The sonnet is said to have been "an extempore effusion, and without the alteration of a single word;" but as Clarke seems to have been asleep when it was written we are justified in construing the word 'extempore' with a certain latitude.
  26: 
  27: It was certainly most unusual for Keats to write that much without a single erasure, and it is quite possible that he jotted the sonnet down in pencil in a note-book which he certainly carried at that time and certainly did draft sonnets in.
  28: 
  29: In any case he probably had ample time and quiet, while Clarke was sleeping, to elaborate the two highly finished quatrains in his mind: the third quatrain and the couplet are of inferior merit, and might well be extemporary.
  30: 
  31: This early performance seems to have quite won the heart of the genial critic Hunt, for in inserting it in his paper he characterized it as "exquisite," and added that the author might "already lay true claim to that title: --
  32: 'The youngest he
  33: That sits in shadow of Apollo's tree.
  34: 
  35: ~ Poetical Works of John Keats, ed.
  36: 
  37: H.
  38: 
  39: Buxton Forman, Crowell publ.
  40: 
  41: 1895.

 128: He stood in his
 129: Shoes and he wonder'd.
 130: 
 131: 'In a letter to his sister, Keats makes a fresh start with -- "since I scribbled the Song we have walked through a beautiful Country to Kirkcudbright -- at which place I will write you a song about myself.
 132: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 133: "  He then proceeds with the very curious piece of doggerel now first given from the manuscript, and excuses himself on the plea of fatigue.
 134: 
 135: My chief purpose in including these verses here is that students may note the variety of the pieces of this class addressed to different correspondents.
 136: 
 137: Compare this with the Devon pieces sent to Haydon, and more particularly with The Gadfly, sent to Tom Keats a little later than this.
 138: 
 139: I presume this piece should be dated the 3rd of July 1818.
 140: 
 141: (stanza 2): This is a genuine autobiographic reminiscence of the time when the young Keatses lived with their grandmother after the death of their parents.
 142: 
 143: (stanza 4): There is an under-current of dissatisfaction with things Caledonian in this fourth stanza; and indeed I do not think Keats ever got entirely rid of this during the whole of the tour, albeit he enjoyed many transient visitations of true enthusiasm inspired both by fine scenery and by associations.
 144: 
 145: ~ Poetical Works of John Keats, ed.
 146:

  44:

  46:

#714: 118371_Spenserian Stanzas On Charles Armitage Brown_Keats, John_unknown.txt

Author: Keats, John
Prose starts at line: 39
Lines to remove: 11
Avg verse line length: 38.9
Avg prose line length: 131.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  34: Nor did he know each aged watchman's beat,
  35: Nor in obscured purlieus would he seek
  36: For curled Jewesses, with ankles neat,
  37: Who as they walk abroad, make tinkling with their feet.
  38: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  39: 'It is a brusque transition from the fervour and preternatural beauty of the dream sonnet to these amusing stanzas on Brown; but under the same date as that on which Keats told his brother of the dream, namely the 15th of April 1819, he records that "Brown, this morning, is writing some Spenserian stanzas against" Miss Brawne and the poet; "so," says the poet, "I shall amuse myself with him a little, in the manner of Spenser.
  40: 
  41: " It would not be fair to assume that all here is ironical; but the first stanza suggests that Keats's estimable friend was a "jolly" man, bald-headed, and "a trifle wider in the waist than formerly;" while, generally, one would suppose him to have been alive to the good things of the world.
  42: 
  43: ~ Poetical Works of John Keats, ed.
  44: 
  45: H.
  46: 
  47: Buxton Forman, Crowell publ.
  48: 
  49: 1895.

#715: 118385_Lines Written In The Highlands After A Visit To Burns's Country_Keats, John_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Lines Written In The Highlands After A Visit To Burns's Country
Author: Keats, John
Prose starts at line: 55
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 59.2
Avg prose line length: 117.6

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  50: Yet be his anchor e'er so fast, room is there for a prayer
  51: That man may never lose his mind on mountains black and bare;
  52: That he may stray league after league some great birth-place to find
  53: And keep his vision clear from speck, his inward sight unblind.
  54: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  55: 'After leaving Ayr Keats and Brown appear to have been detained by rain at some place twelve miles along the road, when Keats took the opportunity of going on with his letter to Reynolds begun at Maybole.
  56: 
  57: They were enroute for Glasgow (casually mentioned in a letter to Bailey begun at Inverary on the 18th of July), which they took on their way from Ayr to Loch Lomond and Inverary.
  58: 
  59: The poem given above is mentioned to Bailey as having been written within a few days of the sonnet in Burns's cottage, so that, although it is headed as above in the manuscript written at the end of Sir Charles Dilke's copy of Endymion, it seems more probable that the term Highlands was used in a lax popular sense than that the poem was composed after the visit to Staffa.
  60: 
  61: Indeed in the letter to Bailey he speaks of the whole tour as in the Highlands.
  62: 
  63: Keats expected to be by Loch Lomond about the 15th of July, and may have written this poem on high ground anywhere about the Loch, with the scenery of which he was very much impressed.
  64: 
  65: They did not ascend Ben Lomond as intended, being deterred by expense and need of rest.
  66: 
  67: ~ Poetical Works of John Keats, ed.
  68: 
  69: H.
  70: 
  71: Buxton Forman, Crowell publ.
  72: 
  73: 1895.

#717: 118389_Sonnet. Written Before Re-Read King Lear_Keats, John_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Sonnet.  Written Before Re-Read King Lear
Author: Keats, John
Prose starts at line: 19
Lines to remove: 17
Avg verse line length: 39.5
Avg prose line length: 133.3

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  14: When through the old oak forest I am gone,
  15: Let me not wander in a barren dream,
  16: But when I am consumed in the fire,
  17: Give me new Phoenix wings to fly at my desire.
  18: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  19: 'This sonnet appears to have been written on the 22nd of January 1818, in the folio Shakespeare containing the manuscript of the preceding poem; but I think Keats must have drafted it before writing it in the Shakespeare; and there is a second manuscript in Sir Charles Dilke's copy of Endymion.
  20: 
  21: A third may perhaps be presumed to be in America, as Keats, writing to his brothers on the 23rd of January 1818, transcribed the sonnet for them with the following remarks: --
  22: "I think a little change has taken place in my intellect lately; I cannot bear to be uninterested or unemployed, I, who for so long a time have been addicted to passiveness.
  23: 
  24: Nothing is finer for the purposes of great productions than a very gradual ripening of the intellectual powers.
  25: 
  26: As an instance of this -- observe -- I sat down yesterday to read 'King Lear' once again: the thing appeared to demand the prologue of a sonnet.
  27: 
  28: I wrote it, and began to read.
  29: 
  30: (I know you would like to see it.
  31: 
  32: A copy of the sonnet follows, and then the words, "So you see I am getting at it with a sort of determination and strength,.
  33: 
  34: 
  35: "  So far ass I have ascertained, the first appearance of the sonnet was with this letter, in the Life, Letters &c.

#718: 118392_Isabella; Or, The Pot Of Basil- A Story From Boccaccio_Keats, John_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Isabella; Or, The Pot Of Basil: A Story From Boccaccio
Author: Keats, John
Prose starts at line: 769
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 38.2
Avg prose line length: 143.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 764: 
 765: Taken in itself apart from the poem, it might be held to be an inopportune description; but in the context of this most tragic and pathetic story, it has to me a surpassing fitness -- a fitness astonishing in the work of a youth of Keats's age in 1818.
 766: 
 767: The idea of maternity thus connected as it were by chance with the image of this widowed girl on the borders of insanity emphasizes in the most beautiful way the helpless misery of a life wrecked by the wickedness of others, and throws into ghastly contrast the joy of what should have been and the agony of what was.
 768: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 769: (stanza XLVIII): Hunt observes here - "It is curious to see how the simple pathos of Boccaccio, or (which is the same thing) the simple intensity of the heroine's feelings, suffices our author more and more, as he gets to the end of his story.
 770: 
 771: And he has related it as happily, as if he had never written any poetry but that of the heart.
 772: 
 773: (stanza LIV): Whether the "savage and tartarly" assailants of Keats's day availed themselves of the word "leafits" in the 8th line for an accusation of word-coining, I do not know; but as far as I have been able to ascertain this diminutive of "leaf" is peculiar to the present passage.
 774: 
 775: (stanza LXII): Hunt says - "The passage about the tone of her voice, -- the poor lost-witted coaxing, -- the 'chuckle,' in which she asks after her Pilgrim and her Basil,-- is as true and touching an instance of the effect of a happy familiar word, as any in all poetry.
 776: 
 777: " It is difficult to imagine that these sentences of Hunt's were not somehow misprinted; but, as the review occurs only in the original issue of The Indicator, one has no means of testing this passage by comparison with later editions.
 778: 
 779: It can hardly be supposed that Hunt really thought the Pilgrim meant Lorenzo; and it ought not to be necessary to explain that the poor lost girl called after any pilgrim whom chance sent her way, enquiring of him where her Basil was.
 780: 
 781: ~ Poetical Works of John Keats, ed.
 782: 
 783: H.
 784: 
 785: Buxton Forman, Crowell publ.
 786: 
 787: 1895.

#719: 118394_Sonnet. Written On A Blank Page In Shakespeare's Poems, Facing 'A Lover's Compla_Keats, John_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Sonnet. Written On A Blank Page In Shakespeare's Poems, Facing 'A Lover's Complaint'
Author: Keats, John
Prose starts at line: 33
Lines to remove: 10
Avg verse line length: 65.7
Avg prose line length: 165.5

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  28: 
  29: It is a royal 8vo volume "printed for Thomas Wilson, No.
  30: 
  31: 10, London-House-yard, St.
  32: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  33: Paul's," in 1806; and this sonnet, of which a fac-simile is here given, is written upon the verso of the fly-title to A Lover's Complaint.
  34: 
  35: It seems fair to assume that the reason of its being so high up on the page is that it thus faces a space of equal size containing no words except a boldly printed heading of Shakespeare's poem, A Lover's Complaint, as if in that mournful moment Keats desired to appropriate to his last poetic utterance a style and title already immortal.
  36: 
  37: Lord Houghton gives a variant of the last line --
  38: 'Half-passionless, and so swoon on to death.
  39: 
  40: As there is no trace of this in the Shakespeare, there must have been another manuscript -- perhaps a pencilled draft -- and it is to be presumed that the words 'fall and swell', in line 11 of Lord Houghton's text occurred in that, 'swell and fall', the reading of the Shakespeare, being in that case an error of transcription on Keats's part.
  41: 
  42: The date of the poem is about the end of September or beginning of October 1820.

#721: 118404_Staffa_Keats, John_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Staffa
Author: Keats, John
Prose starts at line: 80
Lines to remove: 20
Avg verse line length: 36.1
Avg prose line length: 120.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  75: 
  76: This was probably on the 22nd of July.
  77: 
  78: On the 23rd he begins a fresh letter (Life, Letters &c.
  79: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  80: ) stating that just after he had posted the other the guide to Mull came in and made a bargain with them.
  81: 
  82: This latter letter is dated the 23rd of July, "Dunancullen" in the Life: "Dimancullen" is the name given in the same connexion in the New York World, where some Keats documents appeared; but probably the place indicated is Derrynaculen, which is at a situation on the walk through the southern part of the Isle of Mull corresponding with Keats's narrative.
  83: 
  84: This narrative seems to show that on the 23rd of July they crossed from Oban to Kerrera by one ferry and from Kerrera to Mull by another, and walked across the south of the Island to the western extremity to cross to Iona by boat.
  85: 
  86: By the 26th, Keats resumed his letter to Tom at Oban, and narrated that the thirty-seven miles of walking had been very miserable, and that he and Brown had taken a boat at a bargain to carry them from Iona to Staffa, and land them finally at the head of Loch Nakeal, whence they could return to Oban by a better route.
  87: 
  88: He vividly describes Staffa, including Fingal's Cave, breaks into verse with the lines given above, and resumes prose with,
  89: "I am sorry I am so indolent as to write such stuff as this.
  90: 
  91: " Probably the poem should be dated the 26th of July, 1818.
  92: 
  93: ~ Poetical Works of John Keats, ed.
  94: 
  95: H.
  96: 
  97: Buxton Forman, Crowell publ.
  98: 
  99: 1895.


====================================================================================================
#722: 118408_Acrostic - Georgiana Augusta Keats_Keats, John_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Acrostic : Georgiana Augusta Keats
Author: Keats, John
Prose starts at line: 28
Lines to remove: 15
Avg verse line length: 39.3
Avg prose line length: 152.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  23: Enchanted has it been the Lord knows where;
  24: And may it taste to you like good old wine,
  25: Take you to real happiness and give
  26: Sons, daughters and a home like honied hive.
  27: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  28: 'This acrostic seems to have been written at the foot of Helvellyn on the 27th of June 1818, for although it appears in the Winchester journal-letter of September 1819 as given in the New York World of the 25th of June 1877, it purports to be copied from an old letter which reached Liverpool after the George Keatses had sailed for America, and which was therefore returned to the poet.
  29: 
  30: The words "Foot of Helvellyn, June 27th," are printed in The World as if they belonged to the next piece copied into the journal-letter; but the context indicates that the date really belongs to the acrostic.
  31: 
  32: Keats (with his friend Charles Armitage Brown) was on the way to Carlisle, to take coach there for Dumfries and begin the walking tour in Scotland on which the first serious break-down of his health occurred.
  33: 
  34: Leaving London about the middle of June, they had seen the George Keatses off from Liverpool for America, and had then started walking from Lancaster; so that, by the time Keats was writing the Acrostic, he had already been walking several days; and four days later the friends reached Carlisle, ending there the English portion of their walk.
  35: 
  36: ~ Poetical Works of John Keats, ed.
  37: 
  38: H.
  39: 
  40: Buxton Forman, Crowell publ.
  41: 
  42: 1895.

  43: 'The copy of these stanzas in Tom Keats's copy-book has a reading in line 12 which ought perhas to supersede the printed text of 1817, namely, 'golden scalès light.
  44: 
  45: ' It seems highly likely that Keats really meant to carry his archaism to the extent of making scales a dissyllable, especially as the metre is thus corrected.
  46: 
  47: Lord Houghton states on the authority of the notes of Charles Armitage Brown, given to his lordship in 1832, that this is the earliest known composition of Keats, and was written while he was living at Edmonton.

#724: 118415_What The Thrush Said. Lines From A Letter To John Hamilton Reynolds_Keats, John_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: What The Thrush Said. Lines From A Letter To John Hamilton Reynolds
Author: Keats, John
Prose starts at line: 28
Lines to remove: 18
Avg verse line length: 42.8
Avg prose line length: 91.9

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  23: 'In an undated letter to Reynolds bearing the postmark "Hampstead, Feb.
  24: 
  25: 19, 1818" (Life, Letters &c.
  26: 
  27: , 1848, Volume 1, page 87), occurs the passage --

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  28: "I was led into these thoughts, my dear Reynolds, by the beauty of the morning operating on a sense of idleness.
  29: 
  30: I have not read any books -- the morning said I was right -- I had no idea but of the morning, and the thrush said I was right, seeming to say,"--
  31: and these fourteen lines of blank verse follow immediately on the word 'say', so that the title I have ventured to give to the lines accords at all events with the facts.
  32: 
  33: Keats seems to have been really writing in a kind of spiritual parallelism with the thrush's song : it will be noted that line 5 repeats the form of line 1, line 8 of line 4, while lines 11 and 12 are a still closer repetition of lines 9 and 10; so that the poem follows in a sense the thrush's method of repetition.
  34: 
  35: A later poet, perhaps a closer and more conscious observer than Keats, namely Robert Browning, says of the same bird in his 'Home--Thoughts from Abroad' --
  36: "That's the wise thrush; he sings each song twice over
  37: Lest you should think he never could recapture
  38: The first line careless rapture!"'
  39: ~ Poetical Works of John Keats, ed.
  40: 
  41: H.
  42: 
  43: Buxton Forman, Crowell publ.
  44: 
  45: 1895.

#725: 118422_Sonnet. Written On A Blank Space At The End Of Chaucer's Tale Of 'The Floure And_Keats, John_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Sonnet. Written On A Blank Space At The End Of Chaucer's Tale Of 'The Floure And The Lefe'
Author: Keats, John
Prose starts at line: 23
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 53.6
Avg prose line length: 106.9

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  18: 
  19: 'This sonnet was published in The Examiner for the 16th of March 1817, having been written in February 1817 in the late Charles Cowden Clarke's "miniature 18mo.
  20: 
  21: copy of Chaucer," as recorded in Clarke's Recollections of Keats in The Gentleman's Magazine.
  22: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  23: When Clarke died, he bequeathed the Chaucer to Alexander Ireland, author of the Leigh Hunt, Lamb, and Hazlitt Bibliography.
  24: 
  25: The sonnet is said to have been "an extempore effusion, and without the alteration of a single word;" but as Clarke seems to have been asleep when it was written we are justified in construing the word 'extempore' with a certain latitude.
  26: 
  27: It was certainly most unusual for Keats to write that much without a single erasure, and it is quite possible that he jotted the sonnet down in pencil in a note-book which he certainly carried at that time and certainly did draft sonnets in.
  28: 
  29: In any case he probably had ample time and quiet, while Clarke was sleeping, to elaborate the two highly finished quatrains in his mind: the third quatrain and the couplet are of inferior merit, and might well be extemporary.
  30: 
  31: This early performance seems to have quite won the heart of the genial critic Hunt, for in inserting it in his paper he characterized it as "exquisite," and added that the author might "already lay true claim to that title: --
  32: 'The youngest he
  33: That sits in shadow of Apollo's tree.
  34: 
  35: ~ Poetical Works of John Keats, ed.
  36: 
  37: H.
  38: 
  39: Buxton Forman, Crowell publ.
  40: 
  41: 1895.

#727: 118424_Sonnet To George Keats- Written In Sickness_Keats, John_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Sonnet To George Keats: Written In Sickness
Author: Keats, John
Prose starts at line: 18
Lines to remove: 11
Avg verse line length: 44.7
Avg prose line length: 145.7

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  13: The being whom your cares could e'en restore,
  14: From the cold grasp of Death, say can you guess
  15: The feelings which these lips can ne'er express;
  16: Feelings, deep fix'd in grateful memory's store.
  17: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  18: 'This sonnet is from a transcript in the handwriting of George Keats, which bears the date 1819; but I am disposed to think this date must have been wrongly affixed from memory.
  19: 
  20: The entire absence of high poetic feeling indicates a time of utter physical prostration; and I should imagine that the sonnet might possibly have been written in February 1820, when Keats was still so ill as to be forbidden to write, and that it might have been sent to George with the announcement of the illness; but it seems likelier that it was composed later on in the year, in reply to some letter written by George on receiving hat news -- a letter in which reply the younger brother might have reproached himself for leaving the elder, low in health and funds, and for rushing back to America to mend his own fortunes.
  21: 
  22: ~ Poetical Works of John Keats, ed.
  23: 
  24: H.
  25: 
  26: Buxton Forman, Crowell publ.
  27: 
  28: 1895.

  15: Smiling at eve upon the quiet sheaves --
  16: Sweet Sappho's cheek -- a smiling infant's breath --
  17: The gradual sand that through an hour-glass runs --
  18: A woodland rivulet -- a Poet's death.
  19: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  20: 'This sonnet appeared in The Examiner for the 23rd of February 1817, and is dated January 1817 in Lord Houghton's editions.
  21: 
  22: In line 5 The Examiner reads 'relieving of;' his Lordship reads 'relieved from,' and again 'And' for 'The' at the beginning of line 9, and 'sleeping' for 'smiling' at line 12.
  23: 
  24: The word 'relieving' in the earlier version must, I think, have been a slip, and not an intentional use of 'relieve' as an intransitive verb, though Keats was perhaps capable of such use in his early strife after freshness of speech.
  25: 
  26: ~ Poetical Works of John Keats, ed.
  27: 
  28: H.
  29:

#730: 118429_Spenserian Stanza. Written At The Close Of Canto II, Book V, Of 'The Faerie Quee_Keats, John_unknown.txt

Prose starts at line: 16
Lines to remove: 15
Avg verse line length: 47.7
Avg prose line length: 128.9

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  11: The one he struck stone-blind, the other's eyes wox dim.
  12: 
  13: 'This stanza, given by Lord Houghton in the Life, Letters &c.
  14: 
  15: (1848), Volume I, page 281, was preceded by the following note:--

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  16: "The copy of Spenser which Keats had in daily use, contains the following stanza, inserted at the close of Canto II, Book V.
  17: 
  18: His sympathies were very much on the side of the revolutionary 'Gyant,' who 'undertook for to repair' the 'realms and nations run awry,' and to suppress 'tyrants that make men subject to their law', 'and lordings curbe that commons over-aw,' while he grudged the legitamate victory, as he rejected the conservative philosophy, of the 'righteous Artegall' and ex post facto prophecy, his conviction of the ultimate triumph of freedom and equality by the power of transmitted knowledge.
  19: 
  20: I have no data whereby to fix the period of this commentary of Keats on the political attitude of Spenser; but I should judge it to belong to the end of 1818 or thereabouts.
  21: 
  22: The copy of Spenser in which the stanza was written is not now forthcoming: it passed into the hands of Miss Brawne, and was lost, with other books, many years after Keats's death.
  23: 
  24: ~ Poetical Works of John Keats, ed.
  25: 
  26: H.
  27: 
  28: Buxton Forman, Crowell publ.
  29: 
  30: 1895.

#733: 118453_To Ailsa Rock_Keats, John_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: To Ailsa Rock
Author: Keats, John
Prose starts at line: 23
Lines to remove: 20
Avg verse line length: 48.1
Avg prose line length: 104.4

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  18: First with the whales, last with the eagle-skies--
  19: Drowned wast thou till an earthquake made thee steep,
  20: Another cannot wake thy giant-size!
  21: 'From Kirkcudbright [Keats and Brown] went to Newton Stewart and thence through Wigtonshire to Port Patrick, visiting Glenluce and Stranraer on the way.
  22: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  23: From Port Patrick they crossed in the mail packet to Ireland, reaching Donaghadee on the 5th of July.
  24: 
  25: They walked from Donaghadee to Belfast and back, having abandoned the idea of seeing the Giant's Causeway on account of the expense,-- crossed again so as to sleep at Port Patrick on the 8th, and then resumed their Scotch walk.
  26: 
  27: Lord Houghton says,--
  28: "Returning from Ireland, the travellers proceeded northwards by the coast, Ailsa Rock constantly in their view.
  29: 
  30: That fine object first appeared to them, in the full sunlight, like a transparent tortoise asleep upon the calm water, then, as they advanced, displaying its lofty shoulders, and, as they still went on, losing its distinctness in the mountains of Arran and the extent of Cantire that rose behind.
  31: 
  32: His Lordship records that the sonnet to Ailsa Rock was written in the inn at Girvan; and, as Keats was at Maybole on the 11th, and Girvan is more than three quarters of the way from Port Patrick to Maybole, the sonnet should be dated the 10th or 11th of July 1818.
  33: 
  34: It appeared in Leigh Hunt's Literary Pocket-book for 1819.
  35: 
  36: ~ Poetical Works of John Keats, ed.
  37: 
  38: H.
  39: 
  40: Buxton Forman, Crowell publ.
  41: 
  42: 1895.

#734: 118454_Sonnet To Homer_Keats, John_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Sonnet To Homer
Author: Keats, John
Prose starts at line: 23
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 47.2
Avg prose line length: 130.6

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  18: 
  19: 'This admirable sonnet also occurs in manuscript in Sir Charles Dilke's copy of Endymion, and was included, like the Sonnet "When I have fears", in the Literary Remains (1848).
  20: 
  21: The date given in both places is 1818.
  22: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  23: The evidence of the manuscript on this point is of consequence as bearing on the relative positions of this sonnet and that 'On first looking into Chapman's Homer'.
  24: 
  25: I understand the "giant ignorance" of line I to have reference to Keats's inability to enjoy Homer in the original Greek, and not to an entire ignorance of the Iliad and Odyssey such as might have characterized the period before the sonnet on Chapman's version was written in 1816.
  26: 
  27: Indeed the second quatrain seems to me to be too well felt for so vague an attitude as Keats's must have been towards Homer before he knew any version at all; but the late Dante Gabriel Rossetti, whose intuitions in such matters were of the keenest, and entitled to the most careful consideration, held that the present sonnet must have preceded that of 1816, and received with considerable reserve the evidence as to the date which I communicated to him in the course of our correspondence.
  28: 
  29: It will be of interest to many lovers both of Keats and of Rossetti to learn that the latter poet whom we have but lately lost considered this sonnet to contain Keats's finest single line of poetry --
  30: 'There is a budding morrow in midnight,'
  31: a line which Rossetti told me he thought one of the finest "in all poetry.
  32: 
  33: " No one will dispute that it is a most astonishing line, more particularly for a young man of Keats's years in 1818.
  34: 
  35: ~ Poetical Works of John Keats, ed.
  36: 
  37: H.
  38: 
  39: Buxton Forman, Crowell publ.
  40: 
  41: 1895.

  36:

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]

  38: 'This song, belonging to the year 1818, has not, I believe, been published till now (1881).
  39: 
  40: It seems to me neither more nor less worthy of Keats's reputation than the Daisy's Song in the Extracts from an Opera; but, notwithstanding the brilliant qualities of some of the stanzas, I should have hesitated to be instrumental in adding it to the poet's published works, had it not been handed about in manuscript and more than once copied.

Title: Song. Written On A Blank Page In Beaumont And Fletcher's Works

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  24: Spirit! I flush
  25: With a Bacchanal blush,
  26: Just fresh from the banquet of Comus!
  27: Song.
  28: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  22: Verse, Fame, and Beauty are intense indeed,
  23: But Death intenser -- Death is Life's high meed.
  24: 
  25: 'This sonnet, first given in Life, Letters &c.
  26: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  27: (1848), was probably composed between the 19th of March and the 15 of April 1819.
  28: 
  29: Keats says in a letter, that he had intended not to send the Sonnet to his brother George and his wife, on account of their anxieties about his temperament; but he refers to other passages in his letter as "the best comment" on the sonnet, and ends the subject with a triumphant "I went to bed and enjoyed uninterrupted sleep: sane I went to bed, and sane I arose.
  30: 
  31: "  A man might well go to bed sane after writing the final couplet, which is a thoroughly self-contained and contemplative vein -- strangely so for the end of such a bitter series of "obstinate questionings.
  32: 
  33: ~ Poetical Works of John Keats, ed.
  34: 
  35: H.
  36: 
  37: Buxton Forman, Crowell publ.
  38: 
  39: 1895.

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  19: Content as theirs,
  20: Rich in the simple worship of a day.
  21: 
  22: 'First given in the Life, Letters &c.
  23: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  24: (1848) in a letter to Reynolds from Teignmouth, dated the 3rd of May 1818, wherein Keats says --
  25: "it is impossible to know how far knowledge will console us for the death of a friend, and the 'ills that flesh is heir to.
  26: 
  27: ' With respect to the affections and poetry, you must know by sympathy my thoughts that way, and I dare say these few lines will be but a ratification.
  28: 
  29: I wrote them on May-day, and intend to finish the ode all in good time.
  30: 
  31: Lord Houghton observes,-- "It is much to be regretted he did not finish this Ode; this commencement is in his best manner: the sentiment and expression perfect, as every traveller in modern Greece will recognize.
  32: 
  33: "  An Ode so propitiously begun would, if completed, have been a worthy ending for the Devonshire series, though including what I believe I am not alone in regarding as Keats's masterpiece, -- Isabella.
  34: 
  35: ~ Poetical Works of John Keats, ed.
  36:

 188: 
 189: He weeps and wonders somewhat too fondly; but his powers gather nobly on him as he proceeds.
 190: 
 191: " I confess that I should be disposed to rank all these symptoms of convulsion and hysteria in the same category as the fainting of lovers which Keats so frequently represented, -- a kind of thing which his astonishing powers of progress would infallibly have' outgrown had he lived a year or two longer.

#742: 118474_from Endymion_Keats, John_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: from Endymion
Author: Keats, John
Prose starts at line: 11
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 20.0
Avg prose line length: 258.7

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   6: 
   7: 
   8: 
   9: 
  10: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  11: BOOK I A thing of beauty is a joy for ever: Its loveliness increases; it will never Pass into nothingness; but still will keep A bower quiet for us, and a sleep Full of sweet dreams, and health, and quiet breathing.
  12: 
  13: Therefore, on every morrow, are we wreathing A flowery band to bind us to the earth, Spite of despondence, of the inhuman dearth Of noble natures, of the gloomy days, Of all the unhealthy and o'er-darkened ways Made for our searching: yes, in spite of all, Some shape of beauty moves away the pall From our dark spirits.
  14: 
  15: Such the sun, the moon, Trees old and young, sprouting a shady boon For simple sheep; and such are daffodils With the green world they live in; and clear rills That for themselves a cooling covert make 'Gainst the hot season; the mid forest brake, Rich with a sprinkling of fair musk-rose blooms: And such too is the grandeur of the dooms We have imagined for the mighty dead; All lovely tales that we have heard or read: An endless fountain of immortal drink, Pouring unto us from the heaven's brink.
  16: 
  17: Nor do we merely feel these essences For one short hour; no, even as the trees That whisper round a temple become soon Dear as the temple's self, so does the moon, The passion poesy, glories infinite, Haunt us till they become a cheering light Unto our souls, and bound to us so fast, That, whether there be shine, or gloom o'ercast; They always must be with us, or we die.
  18: 
  19: Therefore, 'tis with full happiness that I Will trace the story of Endymion.
  20: 
  21: The very music of the name has gone Into my being, and each pleasant scene Is growing fresh before me as the green Of our own valleys: so I will begin Now while I cannot hear the city's din; Now while the early budders are just new, And run in mazes of the youngest hue About old forests; while the willow trails Its delicate amber; and the dairy pails Bring home increase of milk.
  22: 
  23: And, as the year Grows lush in juicy stalks, I'll smoothly steer My little boat, for many quiet hours, With streams that deepen freshly into bowers.
  24: 
  25: Many and many a verse I hope to write, Before the daisies, vermeil rimm'd and white, Hide in deep herbage; and ere yet the bees Hum about globes of clover and sweet peas, I must be near the middle of my story.
  26: 
  27: O may no wintry season, bare and hoary, See it half finish'd: but let Autumn bold, With universal tinge of sober gold, Be all about me when I make an end.
  28: 
  29: And now, at once adventuresome, I send My herald thought into a wilderness: There let its trumpet blow, and quickly dress My uncertain path with green, that I may speed Easily onward, thorough flowers and weed.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  26: 
  27: 
  28: An article celebrating "The Departure of the Proprietors of this Paper from Prison" occupied the first page of The Examiner for Sunday, the 5th of February, 1815.
  29: 
  30: The opening is as follows: --

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  31: "The two years' imprisonment inflicted on the Proprietors of this Paper for differing with the Morning Post on the merits of the Prince Regent, expired on Thursday last; and on that day accordingly we quitted our respective Jails.
  32: 
  33: " On  the subject of how they felt on the occasion, Hunt excuses himself from particularity, but observes with characteristic pleasantness, "there is a feeling of space and of airy clearness about everything, which is alternately delightful and painful.
  34: 
  35: " .
  36: 
  37: 
  38: Hunt adduces the first line .
  39: 
  40: 
  41: as an example of Keats's "sense of the proper variety of versification without a due consideration of its principles," and very justly adds, "by no contrivance of any sort can we prevent this from jumping out of the heroic measure into mere rhythmicality.
  42: 
  43: Clarke records that when this and one or two other early poems of Keats were first shown by him to Hunt, Horace Smith, being present, remarked on the 13th line, "What a well-condensed expression for a youth so young!"
  44: ~ Poetical Works of John Keats, ed.
  45: 
  46: H.
  47: 
  48: Buxton Forman, Crowell publ.
  49: 
  50: 1895.

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  44: Methought I had beheld it from the flood.
  45: 
  46: 'In a letter to his friend Bailey, dated 23rd of January 1818 (Life, Letters &c.
  47: 
  48: , 1848), Keats says --

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  49: "I was at Hunt's the other day, and he surprised me with a real authenticated lock of Milton's hair.
  50: 
  51: I know you would like what I wrote thereon, so here it is -- as they say of a Sheep in a Nursery Book.
  52: 
  53: And after transcribing the poem he adds --
  54: "This I did at Hunt's, at his request.
  55: 
  56: Perhaps I should have done something better alone and at home.
  57: 
  58: In the folio Shakespeare in Sir Charles Dilke's possession these Lines are written in Keats's autograph, and there is another manuscript at the end of the copy of Endymion mentioned several times in these notes.
  59: 
  60: The date given by Keats to the poem is the 21st of January 1818.
  61: 
  62: I presume Lord Houghton gave the poem from the Bailey letter: the variations are inconsiderable.

#747: 118640_Fresh Air_Koch, Kenneth_unknown.txt

Title: Fresh Air
Author: Koch, Kenneth
Prose starts at line: 294
Lines to remove: 13
Avg verse line length: 53.0
Avg prose line length: 119.9

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 289: 
 290: ” I don’t know, air.
 291: 
 292: You are so strong, air.
 293: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 294: And she breaks my chains of straw, and we walk down the road, behind us the hideous fumes!
 295: Soon we reach the seaside, she is a young art student who places her head on my shoulder,
 296: I kiss her warm red lips, and here is the Strangler, reading theKenyonReview! Good luck to you, Strangler!
 297: Goodbye, Helen! goodbye, fumes! goodbye, abstracted dried-up boys! goodbye, dead trees! goodbye, skunks!
 298: Goodbye, manure! goodbye, critical manicure! goodbye, you big fat men standing on the east coast as well as the west giving poems the test! farewell, Valéry’s stern dictum!
 299: Until tomorrow, then, scum floating on the surface of poetry! goodbye for a moment, refuse that happens to land in poetry’s boundaries! adieu, stale eggs teaching imbeciles poetry to bolster up your egos! adios, boring anomalies of these same stale eggs!
 300: Ah, but the scum is deep! Come, let me help you! and soon we pass into the clear blue water.
 301: 
 302: Oh GOODBYE, castrati of poetry! farewell, stale pale skunky pentameters (the only honest English meter, gloop gloop!) until tomorrow, horrors! oh, farewell!
 303: 
 304: Hello, sea! good morning, sea! hello, clarity and excitement, you great expanse of green—
 305: 
 306: O green, beneath which all of them shall drown!

Author: Byron, George Gordon
Prose starts at line: 1022
Lines to remove: 11
Avg verse line length: 33.1
Avg prose line length: 89.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1017: 
1018: And if ye marvel Charles forgot
1019: To thank his tale, he wondered not,--
1020: The king had been an hour asleep.
1021: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1022: Byron wrote this poem based on the true story of Mazeppa from Voltaire's "The History of Charles XII, King of Sweden.
1023: 
1024: Byron despised his penmanship and therefore usually enlisted someone else to make the final copy of the manuscript.
1025: 
1026: The person who copied the manuscript of Mazeppa, to be forwarded to the publisher, was Mary Shelley, author of Frankenstein and wife of the poet, Percy B.
1027: 
1028: Shelley.
1029: 
1030: This was done when they came to visit Byron in Venice in 1818.
1031: 
1032: Although completed at that time, Mazeppa was not published until June 28, 1819.
