1656: The attendants of the pontiff then inquired from Giorgio why he had not revealed this to the governor of the city; to which he replied, that he had seen in his time a hundred dead bodies thrown into the river at the same place, without any inquiry being made respecting them; and that he had not, therefore, considered it as a matter of any importance.
1657: 
1658: The fishermen and seamen were then collected.
1659: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1660: and ordered to search the river, where on the following evening, they found the body of the duke, with his habit entire, and thirty ducats in his purse.
1661: 
1662: He was pierced with nine wounds, one of which was in his throat, the others in his hand, body, and limbs.
1663: 
1664: No sooner was the pontiff informed of the death of his son, and that he had been thrown, like filth, into the river, than, giving way to his grief, he shut himself up in a chamber, and wept bitterly.
1665: 
1666: The Cardinal of Segovia, and other attendants on the pope, went to the door, and after many hours spent in persuasions and exhortations, prevailed upon him to admit them.
1667: 
1668: From the evening of Wednesday till the following Saturday the pope took no food; nor did he sleep from Thursday morning till the same hour on the ensuing day.
1669: 
1670: At length, however, giving way to the entreaties of his attendants, he began to restrain his sorrow, and to consider the injury which his own health might sustain by the further indulgence of his grief.
1671: 
1672: " — Roscoe's Leo the Tenth, vol.
1673: 
1674: i.

Author: Byron, George Gordon
Prose starts at line: 40
Lines to remove: 9
Avg verse line length: 46.7
Avg prose line length: 138.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  35: Blest by the tongues that charmed my youthful ear,
  36: Mourned by the few my soul acknowledged here;
  37: Deplored by those in early days allied,
  38: And unremembered by the world beside.
  39: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  40: Upon the death of his daughter, Allegra, in April of 1822, Byron had her remains sent to the place that he had picked for himself to have been buried at, under the boughs of this tree in Harrow.
  41: 
  42: In May 26, he wrote in a letter; “A spot in the church yard, near the footpath on the brow of the hill looking towards Windsor, and a tomb under a large tree (bearing the name Peachie, or Peachy), where I used to sit for hours and hours when a boy.
  43: 
  44: This was my favorite spot; but as I wish to erect a tablet to her memory, the body had better be laid in the church”.
  45: 
  46: No tablet had ever been erected, and Allegra sleeps in her unmarked grave inside the church just right of the entry.
  47: 
  48: Pierre Richards

 579: 
 580: -- (I quote from memory).
 581: 
 582: ~ The Island, 2nd edition, 1823.
 583: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 584: There is a 15 page Appendix at the end of The Island, 2nd Edition, 1823, which is of an Extract from the Voyage by Captain Bligh.
 585: 
 586: At 15 pages, of course it is too long to include here, but the reader may find plentiful information of the Mutiny of the Bounty online.
 587: 
 588: But to whet your appetite, "On the 27th of December it blew a severe storm of wind from the eastward, in the course of which we suffered greatly.
 589: 
 590: One sea broke away the spare yards and spars out of the starboard mainchains; another broke into the ship and stove all the boats.
 591: 
 592: Several casks of beer that had been lashed on deck broke loose, and were washed overboard; and it was not without great risk and difficulty that we were able to secure the boats from being washed away entirely.
 593: 
 594: A great quantity of our bread was also damaged and rendered useless, for the sea had stove in our stern, and filled the cabin with water.
 595: 
 596: On the 5th of January, 1788, we saw the island of Teneriffe about twelve leagues distant, and next day, being Sunday, came to an anchor in the road of Santa Cruz.
 597: 
 598: There we took in the necessary supplies, and, having finished our business, sailed on the 10th.

#754: 118931_English Bards and Scotch Reviewers- A Satire_Byron, George Gordon_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: English Bards and Scotch Reviewers: A Satire
Author: Byron, George Gordon
Prose starts at line: 1359
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 45.3
Avg prose line length: 172.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1354: 
1355: It may be said that I quit England because I have censured there 'persons of honour and wit about the town'; but I am coming back again, and their vengeance will keep hot till my return.
1356: 
1357: Those who know me can testify that my motives for leaving England are very different from fears, literary or personal: those who do not, may one day be convinced.
1358: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1359: Since the publication of this thing, my name has not been concealed; I have been mostly in London, ready to answer for my transgressions, and in daily expectation of sundry cartels; but alas! 'The age of chivalry is over,' or, in the vulgar tongue, there is no spirit now-a-days.
1360: 
1361: There is a youth ycleped Hewston Clarke (subaudi esquire), a sizer of Emanuel College, and, I believe, a denizen of Berwick-upon-Tweed, whom I have introduced in these pages to much better company than he has been accustomed to meet: he is, notwithstanding, a very sad dog, and for no reason that I can discover, except a personal quarrel with a bear, kept by me at Cambridge to sit for a fellowship, and whom the jealousy of his Trinity contemporaries prevented from success, has been abusing me, and, what is worse, the defenceless innocent above mentioned, in 'The Satirist,' for one year and some months.
1362: 
1363: I am utterly unconscious of having given him any provocation; indeed, I am guiltless of having heard his name, till coupled with 'The Satirist.
1364: 
1365: ' He has therefore no reason to complain, and I dare say that, like Sir Fretful Plagiary, he is ratherpleased than otherwise.
1366: 
1367: I have now mentioned all who have done me the honour to notice me and mine, that is, my bear and my book, except the editor of 'The Satirist,' who, it seems, is a gentleman -- God wot! I wish he could impart a little of his gentility to his subordinate scribblers.
1368: 
1369: I hear that Mr.
1370: 
1371: Herningham is about to take up the cudgels for his Mæcenas, Lord Carslisle.
1372: 
1373: I hope not; he was one of the few, who, in the very short intercourse I had with him, treated me with kindness when a boy; and whatever he may say or do, 'pour on, I will endure.
1374: 
1375: ' I have nothing further to add, save a general note of thanksgiving to readers, purchasers, and publishers, and, in the words of Scott, I wish,
1376: 'To all and each a fair good night,
1377: And rosy dreams and slumbers light.

#756: 118954_Written After Swimming From Sestos To Abydos_Byron, George Gordon_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Written After Swimming From Sestos To Abydos
Author: Byron, George Gordon
Prose starts at line: 28
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 34.0
Avg prose line length: 178.3

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  23: He lost his labour, I my jest;
  24: For he was drown'd, and I've the ague.
  25: 
  26: May 9, 1810.
  27: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  28: "On the 3d of May, 1810, while the Salsette (Captain Bathurst) was lying in the Dardanelles, Lieutenant Ekenhead of that frigate and the writer of these rhymes swam from the European shore to the Asiatic -- by-the-by, from Abydos to Sestos would have been more correct.
  29: 
  30: The whole distance from the place whence we started to our landing on the other side, including the length we were carried by the current, was computed by those on board the frigate at upwards of four English miles; though the actual breadth is barely one.
  31: 
  32: The rapidity of the current is such that no boat can row directly across, and it may in some measure be estimated from the circumstance of the whole distance being accomplished by one of the parties in an hour and five, and by the other in an hour and ten, minutes.
  33: 
  34: The water was extremely cold from the melting of the moutain-snows.
  35: 
  36: About three weeks before, in April, we had made an attempt, but having ridden all the way from the Troad the same morning, and the water being an icy chillness, we found it necessary to postpone the completion till the frigate anchored below the castles, when we swam the straits, as just stated; entering a considerable way above the European, and landing below the Asiatic, fort.
  37: 
  38: Chevalier says that a young Jew swam the same distance for his mistress; and Oliver mentions its having been done by a Neapolitan; but our consul, Tarragona, remembered neither of these circumstances, and tried to dissuade us from the attempt.
  39: 
  40: A number of the Salsette's crew were known to have accomplished a greater distance; and the only thing that surprised me was, that, as doubts had been entertained of the truth of Leander's story, no traveller had ever endeavoured to ascertain its practicability.
  41: 
  42: ~ The Works of Lord Byron, vol.
  43: 
  44: 3.
  45: 
  46: , 1819.

 312: 
 313: ADVERTISEMENT.
 314: 
 315: At Ferrara, in the Library, are preserved the original MSS.
 316: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 317: of Tasso's "Gierusalemme" and of Guarini's "Pastor Fido," with letters of Tasso, one from Titian to Ariosto, and the inkstand and chair, the tomb and house, of the latter.
 318: 
 319: But, as misfortune has a greater interest for posterity, and little or none for the contemporary, the cell where Tasso was confined in the hospital of St Anna attracts a more fixed attention than the residence or monument of Ariosto — at least it had this affect on me.
 320: 
 321: There are two inscriptions, one the outer gate, the second over the cell itself, inviting, unnecessarily, the wonder and the indignation of the spectator.
 322: 
 323: Ferrara is much decayed and depopulated: the castle still exists entire; and I saw the court where Parisina and Hugo were beheaded, according to the annal of Gibbon.

#759: 118996_The Giaour- A Fragment Of A Turkish Tale_Byron, George Gordon_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Giaour: A Fragment Of A Turkish Tale
Author: Byron, George Gordon
Prose starts at line: 1847
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 41.8
Avg prose line length: 131.6

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1842: 
1843: A few years ago the wife of Muchtar Pacha complained to his father of his son's supposed infidelity; he asked with whom, and she had the barbarity to give in a list of the twelve handsomest women in Yanina.
1844: 
1845: They were seized, fastened up in sacks, and drowned in the lake the same night! One of the guards who was present informed me, that not one of the victims uttered a cry, or shewed a symptom of terror at so sudden a "wrench from all we know, from all we love.
1846: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1847: " The fate of Phrosine, the fariest of this sacrifice, is the subject of many a Romaic and Arnaout ditty.
1848: 
1849: The story in the text is one told of a young Venetian many years ago, and now nearly forgotten.
1850: 
1851: I heard it by accident recited by one of the coffee-house story-tellers who abound in the Levant, and sing or recite their narratives.
1852: 
1853: The additions and interpolations by the translator will be easily distinguished from the rest by the want of Eastern imagery; and I regret that my memory has retained so few fragments of the original.
1854: 
1855: For the contents of some of the notes I am indebted partly to D'Herbelot, and partly to that most eastern, and, as Mr Weber justly entitles it, "sublime tale," the "Caliph Vathek.
1856: 
1857: "  I do not know from what source the author of that singular volume may have drawn his materials; some of his incidents are to be found in the "Bibliotheque Orientale;" but for correctness of costume, beauty of description, and power of imagination, it far surpasses all European imitations; and bears such marks of originality, that those who have visited the East will find some difficulty in believing it to be more than a translation.
1858: 
1859: As an Eastern tale, even Rasselas must bow before it; his "Happy Valley" will not bear a comparison with the "Hall of Eblis.
1860: 
1861: ~ The Works of Lord Byron, vol.
1862: 
1863: 2.
1864: 
1865: , 1819.

  59: 
  60: 'O Morven of snow;': Morven: a lofty mountain in Aberdeenshire.
  61: 
  62: 'Gormal of snow,' is an expression frequently to be found in Ossian.
  63: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  64: 'Or the mist of the tempest that gather'd below;': This will not appear extraordinary to those who have been accustomed to the Mountains; it is by no means uncommon on attaining the top of Ben-e-vis, Ben-y-bourd, &c.
  65: 
  66: to perceive between the summit of the valley, clouds pouring down rain, and occasionally accompanied by lightning, while the spectator literally looks down upon the storm perfectly secure from its effects.
  67: 
  68: 'I breasted the billows': Breasting the lofty mountain.
  69: 
  70: ~Shakespeare.
  71: 
  72: 'The Dee's rushing tide,': The Dee is a beautiful river, which arises near Mar Lodge, and falls into the sea at New Aberdeen.
  73: 
  74: 'o'ershadow Colbleen;': Colbleen is a mountain near the verge of the Highlands, not far from the ruins of Dee Castle.

 232:

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 233: 'where godlike Falkland fell': Lucius Cary, Lord Viscount Falkland, the most accomplished man of his age, was killed at the battle of Newberry, charging in the ranks of Lord Byron's Regiment of Cavalry.
 234: 
 235: 'Earth shudders as her cave receives his bones,/ Loathing the offering': This is an historical fact; ;a violent tempest occurred immediately subsequent to the death or interment of Cromwell, which occasioned many disputes between Partizans and Cavaliers.
 236: 
 237: Both interpreted the circumstance into divine interposition, but whether as approbation or condemnation, we leave to the Casuists of that age to decide; I have made such use of the occurrence as suited the subject of my poem.
 238: 
 239: ~Byron

 820: 
 821: Giacomo, opposite the present fortress, beyond St.
 822: 
 823: Paul's.
 824: 
 825: It cannot be told  how strange appeared this proceeding in a prince, who, considering his own disposition, should, as it seemed, have been in such cases most indulgent.

  87: Such are the men who learning's treasures guard!
  88: Such is their practice, such is their reward!
  89: This much, at least, we may presume to say --
  90: The premium can't exceed the price they pay.
  91: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  92: No reflection is here intended against the person mentioned under the name of Magnes.
  93: 
  94: He is merely represented as performing an unavoidable function of his office: indeed, such an attempt could only recoil upon himself; as that gentleman is now as much distinguished by his eloquence, and the dignified propriety with which he fills his situation, as he was in his younger days, for wit and conviviality.
  95: 
  96: 'Yet prizing Bentley's, Brunk's, or Porson's': They were celebrated critics.
  97: 
  98: 'Porson': The present Greek professor at Trinity College, Cambridge; a man whose powers of mind and writings, may perhaps justify their preference.
  99: 
 100: ~Jones's Cabinet Edition of the Poets, 1825.

  76: 
  77: My heart is like a stone in my body.
  78: 
  79: All I have grasped I loose again from my hands.
  80: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  81: Liadain and Curithir were two poets who lived in Ireland in the seventh century.
  82: 
  83: They fell in love, but while Curithir was absent making preparations for their marriage, Liadain, for some unexplained reason, took the vows of a nun.
  84: 
  85: Curithir in despair became a monk.
  86: 
  87: At first they continued to see each other, but when this led to the breaking of their vows, Curithir left Liadain to spend his life in penance and thus save his soul.

  26: With Bishop Payne and Price he chants,
  27: With such surrounding host we can't
  28: Say he is dead!

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  29: Frederick Douglass (February 1818 – February 20, 1895) was an American abolitionist, editor, orator, author, statesman and reformer.
  30: 
  31: Called "The Sage of Anacostia" and "The Lion of Anacostia", Douglass is one of the most prominent figures in African American history and a formidable public presence.
  32: 
  33: He was a firm believer in the equality of all people, whether black, female, Native American, or recent immigrant.
  34: 
  35: He was fond of saying, "I would unite with anybody to do right and with nobody to do wrong.

   1: Closing the Seaport
   2: 
   3: All at the same level, wooden poles are driven into the waves;
   4: Ironically, the river is safest in its net of chains.
   5: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   6: Like a king deposed by his people, a boat spins as it sinks beneath the water’s power.
   7: 
   8: It’s not right to depend on a particular place; our fates are up to the creator.
   9: 
  10: Less than a day’s work results in both the fortunate and the hapless.
  11: 
  12: Even a hero’s faults and sorrows will live for thousands of years.
  13: 
  14: From the past to the present, the creator’s philosophy varies as much
  15: As the color in eternity of water and smoke.

#772: 120406_A Cry From Andersonville Prison_Comfort, William_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: A Cry From Andersonville Prison
Author: Comfort, William
Prose starts at line: 38
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 55.8
Avg prose line length: 130.1

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  33: And scores are laid beside them as day succeeds each day,
  34: And thus it shall be until we all shall pass away;
  35: And the last can say while dying with upturned glazing eye,
  36: Both faith and love are dead at home and they've left us here to die.
  37: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  38: William Comfort, who was with the 35th New Jersey Volunteers, wrote this poem in 1864 while he was being held in Andersonville Prison.
  39: 
  40: Prisoner exchanges between the North and South were halted on May 25, 1863, on the authority of General-in-Chief Henry Halleck.
  41: 
  42: Although some limited exchanges continued sporadically throughout the War, they were even fewer and farther between after Ulysses S.
  43: 
  44: Grant replaced Halleck as overall commander.
  45: 
  46: Southern refusal to consider blacks in the Federal ranks as soldiers eligible for exchange contributed to Grant's obstinance on the issue, as did his desire to deprive the Confederate Army of irreplaceable manpower.
  47: 
  48: To further discourage general exchanges, Grant named the detested Benjamin F.
  49: 
  50: "Beast" Butler as commissioner for exchanges.
  51: 
  52: Remembering the heavy hand General Butler had exercised in occupied New Orleans, the South was not eager to deal with him but finally did, although exchanges did not resume.
  53: 
  54: As a result of this political manuevering between the two governments, many Union soldiers were left to languish in overcrowded, unsanitary Southern prison camps.
  55: 
  56: The overwhelming convinction that their leaders had abandoned them after their devoted service to the Union cause gave rise to sentiments like the ones expressed in these heartbreaking verses.


====================================================================================================

#774: 120426_Elegy_Tichborne, Chidiock_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Elegy
Author: Tichborne, Chidiock
Prose starts at line: 23
Lines to remove: 7
Avg verse line length: 39.1
Avg prose line length: 74.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  18: I trod the earth and knew it was my tomb,
  19: And now I die, and now I am but made.
  20: 
  21: My glass is full, and yet my glass is run;
  22: And now I live, and now my life is done!

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  23: (popular version updated from the original, but with modernized spelling retained)
  24: This poem was written with his own hand in the tower of London before his execution.
  25: 
  26: It is sometimes given the title: "Tichborne's Elegy"
  27: AP poet Jonathan Robin has written a "
  28: Response Able Elegy
  29: " after the manner this poem by Chidiock Tichborne, and in his Author's Notes, includes both the popular version and the contemporary poetic rebuttal to it by Thomas Kyd.

#775: 120635_The Vision Of Sir Launfal_Lowell, James Russell_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Vision Of Sir Launfal
Author: Lowell, James Russell
Prose starts at line: 402
Lines to remove: 9
Avg verse line length: 37.8
Avg prose line length: 165.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 397: 
 398: Author's Note: According to the mythology of the Romancers, the San Greal, or Holy Grail, was the cup out of which Jesus partook of the last supper with his disciples.
 399: 
 400: It was brought into England by Joseph of descendants.
 401: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 402: It was incumbent upon those who had charge of it to be chaste in thought, word, and deed; but one of the keepers having broken this condition, the Holy Grail disappeared.
 403: 
 404: From that time it was a favorite enterprise of the knights of Arthur's court to go in search of it.
 405: 
 406: Sir Galahad was at last successful in finding it, as may be read in the seventeenth book of the Romance of King Arthur.
 407: 
 408: Tennyson has made Sir Galahad the subject of one of the most exquisite of his poems.
 409: 
 410: The plot (if I may give that name to any thing so slight) of the following poem is my own, and, to serve its purposes, I have enlarged the circle of competition in search of the miraculous cup in such a mannner as to include, not only other persons than the heroes of the Round Table, but also a period of time subsequent to the date of King Arthur's reign.

#776: 120878_The Hunter of the Uruguay to his Love_Costello, Louisa Stuart_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Hunter of the Uruguay to his Love
Author: Costello, Louisa Stuart
Prose starts at line: 54
Lines to remove: 17
Avg verse line length: 35.2
Avg prose line length: 101.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  49: The willows are waving to hail us home;
  50: When the hunter and his bride shall come:
  51: All the joys of summer stay for thee—
  52: Oh, come to our woody islands with me.
  53: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  54: "There are numerous wooded islands in the Uruguay river, consisting of willow, peach, and palm trees; they are the haunts of innumerable birds, remarkable for the splendour of their plumage and sweetness of their note.
  55: 
  56: The yaguarete, or leopard of South America, abounds here; and men pass the summer on these islands hunting them for the sake of their skins.
  57: 
  58: There are many rapids and eddies in some parts of this river, and the Indians use double canoes with oars, some seventy feet long.
  59: 
  60: "The ao is an amphibious animal, very ferocious and formidable.
  61: 
  62: "The cayman, an animal of which some tribes of Indians stand in strange fear, believing it can only be killed by the reflection of its basilisk eye.
  63: 
  64: "The bearded monkeys, a troop of which are called by the Portuguese a choir, from their singing in concert at sunrise and sunset.
  65: 
  66: "The ounce has a singular stratagem to lure his prey.
  67: 
  68: "—See Southey's Hist.
  69: 
  70: Brazil.

#777: 120887_The Destroying Spirit_Costello, Louisa Stuart_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Destroying Spirit
Author: Costello, Louisa Stuart
Prose starts at line: 62
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 39.9
Avg prose line length: 141.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  57: 
  58: "Mountains of sand and rock, elevated and hewn perpendicularly, present on the eastern shore of the Nile, the course of which they contract, an impregnable chain.
  59: 
  60: They extend themselves to a distance, by immense and frequent intersection, into the desert, the horrors of which they augment.
  61: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  62: "These barren and horrible mountains are the domain of a multitude of birds, which have there fixed their habitations, where they never meet with any disturbance, and from whence they spread themselves over the waters and through the country to search for prey.
  63: 
  64: The name of Dsjebel el Teir—Mountain of the Birds, given to this chain, indicates its inhabitants.
  65: 
  66: "—Sonnini's Egypt.
  67: 
  68: "An inundation of the Nile gives a correct picture of a deluge.
  69: 
  70: The cottages, being built of earth, could not stand one instant against the current.
  71: 
  72: The rapid stream carried off all that was before it, men, women, children, cattle, corn, all was washed away in a moment, and left the place where the village stood without any thing to indicate that there had ever been a house on the spot.
  73: 
  74: It is one vast ocean, out of which rise numerous islands and many magnificent ruins.
  75: 
  76: "On our way down, it was pleasing to see the difference of the country: all the lands that were under water before were now not only dried up, but already sown; the muddy villages carried off by the rapid current were all rebuilt; the fences opened, the fellahs at work in the fields, and all wore a different aspect; yet the waters had subsided only fifteen days.
  77: 
  78: "—Belzoni's Egypt.
  79: 
  80: For a description of a frightful valley, and traditions of evil spirits inhabiting temples of stone and decoying travellers, see Fraser's Tour through the Snowy Range of the Himmala.

#778: 120888_The Indian Cupid_Costello, Louisa Stuart_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Indian Cupid
Author: Costello, Louisa Stuart
Prose starts at line: 36
Lines to remove: 7
Avg verse line length: 36.1
Avg prose line length: 116.5

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  31: But, no! the vision is passing on,
  32: The bright forms vanish one by one—
  33: On the desolate shore I am left alone!
  34: Yet stay! oh, stay!—like lightning they move—
  35: To well, by thy fleetness, I know thou art Love!

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  36: The Indian Cupid is represented riding by moonlight on a parrot, or lory, and attended by dancing-girls or nymphs, the foremost of whom bears his colours, which are, a fish on a red ground.
  37: 
  38: His favourite place of resort is round Agra, and principally the plains of Matra.
  39: 
  40: His bow is of sugar-cane or flowers, with a string of bees, and his five arrows each pointed with an Indian blossom of a heating quality.
  41: 
  42: His name is Camdeo,—but he has at least twenty-three names.

 176: 
 177: We gave thanks for the story, for all parts of the storybecause it was by the light of those challenges we knewourselves—We asked for forgiveness.
 178:

#786: 121593_Dreams_Szymborska, Wisława_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Dreams
Author: Szymborska, Wisława
Prose starts at line: 7
Lines to remove: 13
Avg verse line length: 77.7
Avg prose line length: 195.1

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   2: 
   3: Despite the geologists’ knowledge and craft, mocking magnets, graphs, and maps— in a split second the dream piles before us mountains as stony as real life.
   4: 
   5: And since mountains, then valleys, plains with perfect infrastructures.
   6: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   7: Without engineers, contractors, workers, bulldozers, diggers, or supplies— raging highways, instant bridges, thickly populated pop-up cities.
   8: 
   9: Without directors, megaphones, and cameramen— crowds knowing exactly when to frighten us and when to vanish.
  10: 
  11: Without architects deft in their craft, without carpenters, bricklayers, concrete pourers—on the path a sudden house just like a toy, and in it vast halls that echo with our steps and walls constructed out of solid air.
  12: 
  13: Not just the scale, it’s also the precision—a specific watch, an entire fly, on the table a cloth with cross-stitched flowers, a bitten apple with teeth marks.
  14: 
  15: And we—unlike circus acrobats, conjurers, wizards, and hypnotists— can fly unfledged, we light dark tunnels with our eyes, we wax eloquent in unknown tongues, talking not with just anyone, but with the dead.
  16: 
  17: And as a bonus, despite our own freedom, the choices of our heart, our tastes, we’re swept away by amorous yearnings for—and the alarm clock rings.
  18: 
  19: So what can they tell us, the writers of dream books,the scholars of oneiric signs and omens, the doctors with couches for analyses— if anything fits, it’s accidental, and for one reason only, that in our dreamings, in their shadowings and gleamings, in their multiplings, inconceivablings, in their haphazardings and widescatterings at times even a clear-cut meaning may slip through.

  84: Khosru Parviz lived A.
  85: 
  86: D.
  87: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  88: 590; he was a prince of exalted virtues and great magnificence; he fought against the Greek emperors with success, but was at last defeated by Heraclius.
  89: 
  90: He is said to have married a daughter of the Greek Emperor Maurice, named Irene, called by the Persians Shireen, or Sweet.
  91: 
  92: Ferhad's history forms a tragical episode in this romance.
  93: 
  94: He was a sculptor, celebrated throughout the East for his great genius, and was daring enough to fix his affections on the beloved of the King.
  95: 
  96: The jealousy of Khosru was excited, and he lamented to his courtiers the existence of a passion which was so violent as not to be concealed, and which gave him great uneasiness.
  97: 
  98: He summoned Ferhad to his presence, and commissioned him to execute a work which should render his name immortal---to clear away all impediments which obstructed the passage of the great mountain of Beysitoun.
  99: 
 100: He commanded him, after having done this, to cause the rivers on the opposite side of the mountain to join.

#791: 121812_Ours_Rocha, Iliana_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Ours
Author: Rocha, Iliana
Prose starts at line: 27
Lines to remove: 15
Avg verse line length: 49.4
Avg prose line length: 123.4

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  22: 
  23: An exercise in loneliness, & once you’ve let it be still, a reward.
  24: 
  25: Lightning bugs, fireflies, depending on the region.
  26: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  27: Nomenclature in & of itself a way to divide, but we’re brought together through observation, a swarm of conclusions bright in the way they forgive the darkness.
  28: 
  29: We tell everyone we know about the field & the lightning bugs, & how we wouldn’t dare try writing them into a poem because we’d fail.
  30: 
  31: A poem, just a series of failures broken down into lines, a series of attempts to assuage the self scattered about & glowing.
  32: 
  33: Lightning bugs pulse, pulsate, beat, throb—all the glorious verbs we usually reserve for the human heart.
  34: 
  35: They don’t vanish, it is we who leave them, as if that isn’t the first movement in loss.
  36: 
  37: We leave because we’ll never understand their intimacy, because in understanding there is a slowing that would keep us from our lives.
  38: 
  39: For a few singular minutes we watch the lightning bugs while we brush mosquitoes away from ourselves.
  40: 
  41: & how many more sentences have we made with that preposition that keeps things at arm’s length, that ending offrom ourselves, from ourselves.


====================================================================================================

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Home Fire
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: Whether on the boulevard or gravel backroad, I do not easily raise my hand to those who toss up theirs in anonymous hello, merely to say “I’m passing this way.
   4: 
   5: ” Once out of shyness, now reluctance to tip my hand, I admire the shrubbery instead.
   6: 
   7: I’ve learned where the lines are drawn and keep the privet well trimmed.
   8: 
   9: I left one house with toys on the floor for another with quiet rugs and a bed where the moon comes in.
  10: 
  11: I’ve thrown myself at men in black turtlenecks only to find that home is best after all.
  12: 
  13: Home where I sit in the glider, knowing it needs oil, like my own rusty joints.
  14: 
  15: Where I coax blackberry to dogwood and winter to harvest, where my table is clothed in light.
  16: 
  17: Home where I walk out on the thin page of night, without waving or giving myself away, and return with my words burning like fire in the grate.


====================================================================================================

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]

   3: My mother sends the baby pictures she promised— egg hunting in Shelby Park, wooden blocks and Thumbelina tossed on the rug, knotty pine walls in a house lost to memory.
   4: 
   5: I separate outthe early ones, studying my navel or crumbs on the tray, taken before my awareness of Sylvania Superflash.
   6: 
   7: Here I am sitting on the dinette table, the near birthday cake striking me dumb.
   8: 
   9: Two places of wedding china, two glasses of milk, posed for the marvelous moment: the child squishes the fluted rosettes, mother claps her hands, father snaps the picture in the face of time.
  10: 
  11: When the sticky sweetis washed off the page, we are pasted in an album of blessed amnesia.
  12: 
  13: The father leaves the pine house and sees the child on weekends, the mother stores the china on the top shelf until it’s dull and crazed, the saucer-eyed girl grips her curved spoon like there’s no tomorrow.

   2:

   3: I lay back on the carpeted bottom stepOf the stairwell that like a well extended Darkly up to the window near the ceiling, Up where the Chinaman under the wide-brimmed hat That hid his face pulled the flowerpot that held No flower across the sill no one could reach.
   4: 
   5: There was a television on somewhere Above me, and the doomsday clock was ticking,Someone was saying.
   6: 
   7: Someone was saying somethingAbout a blockade and a quarantine, Who would blink first, lose face, or push the button.
   8: 
   9: A fat man banged a shoe against a desk.
  10: 
  11: The Chinaman however didn’t care.
  12: 
  13: Pulling his flowerpot of absent flowers, He was content to be a clot of darkness  Brightening the moment late sun caught the glass—The hat tip first, and then the hat, the arms,The rickshaw of the flowerpot he pulled.
  14: 
  15: And everywhere within the light’s slow fallInfinities of particles were fallingInto the flowerpot they’d never fill.

Title: Who Steals My Good Name
Author: Snodgrass, W D
Prose starts at line: 11

Avg verse line length: 51.0
Avg prose line length: 153.9

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   6: 
   7: 
   8: 
   9: 
  10: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  11: My pale stepdaughter, just off the school bus,  Scowled, "Well, that's the last time I say my name's  Snodgrass!" Just so, may that anonymous  Mexican male who prodigally claims  My clan lines, identity and the sixteen  Digits that unlock my bank account,  Think twice.
  12: 
  13: That less than proper name's been  Taken by three ex-wives, each for an amount  Past all you've squandered, each more than pleased  To change it back.
  14: 
  15: That surname you affect  May have more consequence than getting teased  By dumb kids or tracked down by bank detectives.
  16: 
  17: Don't underrate its history: one of ours played  Piano on his prison's weekly broadcast;  One got rich on a scammed quiz show; one made  A bungle costing the World Series.
  18: 
  19: My own past  Could subject you to guilt by association:  If you write anything more than false checks,  Abandon all hope of large press publication  Or prizes—critics shun the name like sex Without a condom.
  20: 
  21: Whoever steals my purse  Helps chain me to my writing desk again  For fun and profit.
  22: 
  23: So take thanks with my curse:  May your pen name help send you to your pen.

Prose starts at line: 4
Lines to remove: 17
Avg verse line length: 37.0
Avg prose line length: 168.7

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Altar Boy
   2: 
   3: Sin Título, from the seriesThe Tempest, 1998, by Arturo Rodríguez

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   4: I am the altar boy with feet flattened by the catechist’s paddle, my skin toasted like stalks of sugarcane at Lent, my shorts baptized in the salt pans of saints.
   5: 
   6: I don’t wear a mask (God hates carnival) but a wool hood, Holy Week’s, that Sister Rose knitted by the charcoal altar, her wooden teeth clacking as she hymned in Latin, the moles on her jowl like prickly pears for penance.
   7: 
   8: My own teeth are those grates that grilled the martyrs, & my little lamb’s ears quiver each afternoon when the wind coughs in fits and pale skies smoke with incense from a clandestine Mass, perhaps on a runaway shallop with sails sewn from stolen cassocks, perhaps on a newborn isle with a thatched church, novices crawling like iguanas around stations of the cross.
   9: 
  10: There’s no home for orphans like us raised in a convent by the wharf where the footless angel blows his trumpet for vesper, and the abbess marches us to the clapboard altar when the cock crows.
  11: 
  12: We sleep in straw cubbies, our sheets those crinkled newspapers that swaddled us like groupers in the foundling’s basket.
  13: 
  14: Hey, you, girl with the twisted neck, your dollhouse will keep on shrinking between your dirty legs.
  15: 
  16: Not even holy water can make you clean.
  17: 
  18: Hey, boy, the more you pull on the kite, the more your house of dreams will get lost in summer’s wayward clouds.
  19: 
  20: Let us live in the meadow, our true home, every bush a hearth, every pond a font: O blessed loam of nettles whose fireflies light the shrine at night, whose blue brooks spread out like veins of  Calvary.

#801: 122904_El Patio de Mi Casa_Menes, Orlando Ricardo_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: El Patio de Mi Casa
Author: Menes, Orlando Ricardo
Prose starts at line: 4
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 30.0
Avg prose line length: 151.7

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: El Patio de Mi Casa
   2: 
   3: El Patio de Mi Casa, 1990, by María Brito

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   4: My patio was once a schoolyard, or maybe a barracoon, perhaps both, & the ghosts of children nest under the pink sink, mouths agape for flakes of rust, or they creep to the ceiling, sucking on the five taps of blue water, their little lips abuzz like cicadas.
   5: 
   6: In the moonlight I see them bounce on my feather bed, bowed like an old donkey’s back, or they teeter-totter in my wicker chair darned with burlap string.
   7: 
   8: Leave them alone, I say to my mother, who wants to cleanse the house with carvacrol, trapping these children’s souls in beehives, then stringing them up with kites so they fly to the moon.
   9: 
  10: Let them drum our dented pots, let them screech happy carols, let them dance with tin spurs on their little feet.
  11: 
  12: Mother, I don’t care if they nibble our family photos, soil your heirlooms of lace, or steal what few grains of rice (more like gypsum ants) you hoard in the pink pantry.
  13: 
  14: Let them play cat’s cradle with spiderwebs, let them rummage in your armoire of moths, let them lurk in your shadows of ill will & tease you to laughter.
  15: 
  16: Ghosts are unruly, free to be fickle, unlike me, the pig-tailed girl you kept strapped to the sewing machine in the shed of planks by the mango tree too old to fruit.
  17: 
  18: Work & sweat will set you free, you said, just like Fidel on the radio.
  19: 
  20: Cut me out of those sepia photos on the wall, burn those baby braids you keep in porcelain, toss my first communion gown into the sea.
  21: 
  22: I wish I’d been born into a brood of mice, quick to grow, quick to breed, quick to die among the kapok trees.

   4:

  22: 
  23: (1) In the Book of Ezekiel, an obscure prophecy foretells that King Gog of the Magog people will start a devastating campaign against Israel, but God , by defeating Gog, will prepare the Jewish people for the arrival of the Messias.
  24: 
  25: Gog's name later became a symbol against Divine power.
  26: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  27: A Hungarian tradition strated by 'Anonymus', the chronicler fo King Béla III, considered the Hungarians the descendants of Gog.
  28: 
  29: (2) The name of the mountain pass in the Carpathians through which the conquering Magyars, led by Árpád, entered today's Hungary in 896, A.
  30: 
  31: D.
  32: 
  33: (3) Ady uses the place name 'Dévény', where the Danube enters Hungary from theWest (Nyugat =' West', the very name of the radical quarterly of Ady's time) The poem is Ady's Manifesto of the 'new' conquering the 'old', because the 'new' is, paradoxically, even more ancient in its roots.
  34: 
  35: (4) Reference to the cousin of St.
  36: 
  37: Stephen, Vazul (or Vászoly), who led a pagan rebellion against Stephen's Christianizing efforts.
  38: 
  39: He was punished by having molten lead poured into his ears.

 198: Stands the Church clock at ten to three?
 199: 
 200: And is there honey still for tea?
 201: 
 202: Written at Cafe des Westens, Berlin, May 1912

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 203: Grantchester is a tiny hamlet just outside Cambridge; set in the meadows along the Cam or Granta (the earlier name), and next door to the Trumpington of Chaucer's "The Reeve's Tale.
 204: 
 205: " All that Cambridge country is flat and comparatively uninteresting; patchworked with chalky fields bright with poppies; slow, shallow streams drifting between pollard willows; it is the beginning of the fen district, and from the brow of the Royston downs (thirteen miles away) it lies as level as a table-top with the great chapel of King's clear against the sky.
 206: 
 207: It is the favourite lament of Cambridge men that their "Umgebung" is so dull and monotonous compared with the rolling witchery of Oxfordshire.
 208: 
 209: Ironic that Poppy fields would play a bhg part in his life a few years later!

#810: 124145_To a Little Invisible Being Who is Expected Soon to Become Visible_Barbauld, Anna Lætitia_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: To a Little Invisible Being Who is Expected Soon to Become Visible
Author: Barbauld, Anna Lætitia
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 13
Avg verse line length: 66.0
Avg prose line length: 228.1

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: To a Little Invisible Being Who is Expected Soon to Become Visible
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: Germ of new life, whose powers expanding slow For many a moon their full perfection wait,— Haste, precious pledge of happy love, to go Auspicious borne through life's mysterious gate.
   4: 
   5: What powers lie folded in thy curious frame,— Senses from objects locked, and mind from thought! How little canst thou guess thy lofty claim To grasp at all the worlds the Almighty wrought! And see, the genial season's warmth to share, Fresh younglings shoot, and opening roses glow! Swarms of new life exulting fill the air,— Haste, infant bud of being, haste to blow! For thee the nurse prepares her lulling songs, The eager matrons count the lingering day; But far the most thy anxious parent longs On thy soft cheek a mother's kiss to lay.
   6: 
   7: She only asks to lay her burden down, That her glad arms that burden may resume; And nature's sharpest pangs her wishes crown, That free thee living from thy living tomb.
   8: 
   9: She longs to fold to her maternal breast Part of herself, yet to herself unknown; To see and to salute the stranger guest, Fed with her life through many a tedious moon.
  10: 
  11: Come, reap thy rich inheritance of love! Bask in the fondness of a Mother's eye! Nor wit nor eloquence her heart shall move Like the first accents of thy feeble cry.
  12: 
  13: Haste, little captive, burst thy prison doors! Launch on the living world, and spring to light! Nature for thee displays her various stores, Opens her thousand inlets of delight.
  14: 
  15: If charmed verse or muttered prayers had power, With favouring spells to speed thee on thy way, Anxious I'd bid my beads each passing hour, Till thy wished smile thy mother's pangs o'erpay.

 135: 
 136: THIS is a story of the old city of Bregenz that stands on the shore of Lake Constance, on the borders of Switzerland, Germany, and that province of Austria called the Tyrol.
 137: 
 138: A girl of Bregenz left her home and went to a Swiss village to live.
 139: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 140: She entered a household there, taught her master's children, and tended his cattle.
 141: 
 142: The people were kind to her, and in time she forgot that she was among strangers.
 143: 
 144: But one day she learned that the Swiss were planning to attack Bregenz by stealth.
 145: 
 146: Instantly all her old love of home awoke.
 147: 
 148: She stole from the house at night, mounted a horse, and rode to Bregenz, hoping to warn the city before the Swiss soldiers should arrive.
 149: 
 150: She had to cross the Rhine, but her steed carried her safely over, and she reached Bregenz in time.
 151: 
 152: The brave girl became the greatest heroine of her city; a picture of her on her charger is carved over the stone gateway on the hill, and the watchman of Bregenz calls her name each midnight.

   4:

   8: 
   9: reminding myself, all ends with what can be named and financed, so why not let my bones be picked by the ants.

  12: 
  13: reminding myself, I would do anything to not belong to a future human potential workshop, supported by a cast of thousands begging for all things mundane sanity brings, in general overcome by lack of suicidal tendencies.

#821: 127009_from The Testament of Love_Bridges, Robert_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: from The Testament of Love
Author: Bridges, Robert
Prose starts at line: 65
Lines to remove: 15
Avg verse line length: 304.6
Avg prose line length: 473.5

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  60: ev’n as in a plant when the sap mounteth secretly and its wintry stalk breaketh out in the prolific miracle of Spring, or as the red blood floodeth into a beating heart to build the animal body comely and strong; so she in her transcendant rivalry would flush his spirit with pleasurable ichor of heaven: and where she hath found responsiv faculty in some richly favour’d soul— L’anima vaga delle cose belle, as saith the Florentine,—she wil inaugurate her feast of dedication, and even in thatt earliest onset, when yet infant Desire hath neither goal nor clue to fix the dream, ev’n then, altho’ it graspeth nought and passeth in its airy vision away, and dieth out of remembrance, ’tis in its earnest of life and dawn of bliss purer and hath less of earthly tinge than any other after-attainment of the understanding: for all man’s knowledge kenneth also of toil and flaw and even his noblest works, tho’ they illume the dark with individual consummation, are cast upon by the irrelevant black shadows of time and fate.
  61: 
  62: 
  63: Repudiation of pleasur is a reason’d folly of imperfection.
  64: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  65: Ther is no motiv can rebate or decompose the intrinsic joy of activ life, whereon all function whatsoever in man is based.
  66: 
  67: Consider how this mortal sensibility hath a wide jurisdiction of range in all degrees, from mountainous gravity to imperceptible faintest tenuities:—The imponderable fragrance of my window-jasmin, that from her starry cup of red-stemm’d ivory invadeth my being, as she floateth it forth, and wantoning unabash’d asserteth her idea in the omnipotent blaze of the tormented sun-ball, checquering the grey wall with shadow-tracery of her shapely fronds; this frail unique spice of perfumery, in which she holdeth monopoly by royal licence of Nature, is but one of a thousand angelic species, original beauties that win conscience in man: a like marvel hangeth o’er the rosebed, and where the honeysuckle escapeth in serpentine sprays from its dark-cloister’d clamber thru’ the old holly-bush, spreading its joybunches to finger at the sky in revel above rivalry.
  68: 
  69: Legion is their name; Lily-of-the-vale, Violet, Verbena, Mignonette, Hyacinth, Heliotrope, Sweet-briar, Pinks and Peas, Lilac and Wallflower, or such white and purple blooms that sleep i’ the sun, and their heavy perfumes withhold to mingle their heart’s incense with the wonder-dreams, love-laden prayers and reveries that steal forth from earth, under the dome of night: and tho’ these blossomy breaths, that hav presumed the title of their gay genitors, enter but singly into our neighboring sense, that hath no panorama, yet the mind’s eye is not blind unto their multitudinous presences:—I know that if odour wer visible as color is, I’d see the summer garden aureoled in rainbow clouds, with such warfare of hues as a painter might choose to show his sunset sky or a forest aflame; while o’er the country-side the wide clover-pastures and the beanfields of June would wear a mantle, thick as when in late October, at the drooping of day the dark grey mist arising blotteth out the land with ghostly shroud.
  70: 
  71: Now these and such-like influences of tender specialty must not—so fine they be— fall in neglect and all their loveliness be lost, being to the soul deep springs of happiness, and full of lovingkindness to the natural man, who is apt kindly to judge of good by comfortable effect.
  72: 
  73: Thus all men ever hav judged the wholesomness of food from the comfort of body ensuing thereupon, whereby all animals retrieve their proper diet; but if when in discomfort ’tis for pleasant hope of health restored we swallow nauseous medicines, so mystics use asceticism, yea, and no man readier than they to assert eventual happiness to justify their conduct.
  74: 
  75: Whence it is not strange (for so scientific minds in search of truth digest assimilable hypotheses) they should extend their pragmatism, and from their happiness deduce the very existence and the natur of God, and take religious consolation for the ground of faith: as if the pleasur of life wer the sign-manual of Nature when she set her hand to her covenant.
  76: 
  77: But man, vain of his Reason and thinking more to assure its independence, wil disclaim complicity with human emotion; and regarding his Mother deemeth it dutiful and nobler in honesty coldly to criticize than purblindly to love; and in pride of this quarrel he hath been led in the end to make distinction of kind 'twixt Pleasur and Happiness; observing truly enough how one may hav pleasure and yet miss happiness; but this warpeth the sense and common use of speech, since all tongues in the world call children and silly folk happy and sometimes ev’n brutes.
  78: 
  79: The name of happiness is but a wider term for the unalloy’d conditions of the Pleasur of Life, attendant on all function, and not to be deny’d to th’ soul, unless forsooth in our thought of nature spiritual is by definition unnatural.


====================================================================================================

#823: 127693_The Fury of Aerial Bombardment_Eberhart, Richard_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Fury of Aerial Bombardment
Author: Eberhart, Richard
Prose starts at line: 27
Lines to remove: 9
Avg verse line length: 42.3
Avg prose line length: 167.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  22: Of Van Wettering I speak, and Averill,
  23: Names on a list, whose faces I do not recall
  24: But they are gone to early death, who late in school
  25: Distinguished the belt feed lever from the belt holding pawl.
  26: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  27: In his collection of essays "Of Poetry and Poets," Eberhart said that he wrote "The Fury of Aerial Bombardment" in 1944 while, as a Navy officer, teaching aerial free gunnery; that too often names of his students turned up on the death lists; and that this depressed him so much that, feeling acutely the ruthlessness and senselessness of war, he wrote the first three stanzas of the poem.
  28: 
  29: It was probably a week or two later that, feeling something should be added, something quite removed from the passion of the first three stanzas, he composed the final stanza.
  30: 
  31: This, he wrote, it is said, in relation to the others made the poem particularly modern and, if he had not added it, he would probably never have published the poem.
  32: 
  33: "This is an example of a certain fortuitous quality determining the fate of a poem.
  34: 
  35: From reader "waziegler"

#825: 128831_Cumnor Hall_Mickle, William Julius_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Cumnor Hall
Author: Mickle, William Julius
Prose starts at line: 155
Lines to remove: 9
Avg verse line length: 36.2
Avg prose line length: 101.6

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 150: Full manye a travellor oft hath sigh'd,
 151: And pensive wepte the countess' falle,
 152: As wand'ring onwards they've espied
 153: The haunted tow'rs of Cumnor Halle.
 154: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 155: The speaker in this poem is Amy Robsart, the wife of Lord Robert Dudley, earl of Leicester.
 156: 
 157: The latter was a favorite of Elizabeth I, and therefore was determined to keep the marriage secret.
 158: 
 159: In 1560 he told his wife to go to Cumnor Place, where she was found lying dead.
 160: 
 161: There is no conclusive evidence against Dudley, but there is no doubt that her death was in his interests.
 162: 
 163: The story is the basis of Scott's Kenilworth, and Scott in his preface acknowledges the influence of this poem and quotes it in full.

#826: 128834_phabetical_Vassilakis, Nico_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: phabetical
Author: Vassilakis, Nico
Prose starts at line: 5
Lines to remove: 11
Avg verse line length: 40.5
Avg prose line length: 168.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: phabetical
   2: 
   3: Nico Vassilakis uses various processes to bring us to his visual poems.
   4: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   5: In “phabetical” he uses a toy microscope with a built-in video camera to capture highly magnified images of text, often with his hand moving the microscope across the page to capture still text in motion.
   6: 
   7: As he has done here, Vassilakis sometimes modifies the settings on the camera so that the texts are captured in unnatural colors, and he sometimes reverses the polarity of these to further alter their materiality.
   8: 
   9: In this poem, he has used a software process to band many slips of texts into columns and rows, and he has captured these blocks of text in motion so that we can see all of the middle column but only half of the two columns to either side of it.
  10: 
  11: The result uses Greek letters (an homage to his ancestry) so abstracted that they appear before us almost as concrete images: birds, an arm reaching out, a child kicking a ball.
  12: 
  13: He forces us to see not the common symbols of our alphabet but instead the “phabet”: the pictographs from which all alphabets arose.
  14: 
  15: —Geof HuthMore About Visual Poetry > >


====================================================================================================

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Vagabonds
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: Pitiful brother—the dreadful nights I owed him!“I’ve got no real involvement in the business.
   4: 
   5: I toyed with his weakness, so—it was my fault—we wound up back in exile and enslavement.
   6: 
   7: ”He saw me as a loser, a weird child; he added his own prods.
   8: 
   9: I answered my satanic doctor, jeering, and made it out the window.
  10: 
  11: All down a landscape crossed by unheard-of music, I spun my dreams of a nighttime wealth to come.
  12: 
  13: After that more or less healthy pastime, I’d stretch out on a pallet.
  14: 
  15: And almost every night, soon as I slept, my poor brother would rise—dry mouth and bulging eyes (the way he’d dreamt himself!)—and haul me into the room, howling his stupid dream.
  16: 
  17: Truly convinced, I’d vowed to take him back to his primal state—child of the sun—and so we wandered, fed on wine from the caves and gypsy bread, me bound to find the place itself and the code.

   4:

  77: And heroes sprang full-armored from the humblest walks of men!
  78: O vanished majesty of days! Rise, type and mould to-day,
  79: And teach our sons to follow on where duty leads the way;
  80: That whatsoever trial comes, defying doubt and fear,
  81: They in the thickest fight shall stand and proudly answer, "Here!"

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  82: George Thomas, a Virginian by birth, graduated from West Point in 1840 (12th in a class of 42) and after fighting in the Mexican War returned to the Academy as an instructor.
  83: 
  84: When the War Between the States broke out, Thomas's allegiance to the Union outweighed his attachment to the Old Dominion, and he remained with the Federal Army.
  85: 
  86: Thomas stayed in the Army after the War's end and died in 1870, the same year as Robert E.
  87: 
  88: Lee.
  89: 
  90: The Battle of Chickamauga was considered to be one of Thomas's finest hours, despite the Union loss, and earned him the nickname "The Rock of Chickamauga.

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: Scott Helmes is a longtime visual poet who has produced works in a variety of forms, including mathematical poetry and rubber-stamped poetry.
   4: 
   5: His "haiku #62" is part of a series of striking poems created from scraps of colored text torn out of glossy magazines and arrayed in three tiers.
   6: 
   7: These tiers approximate the look of haiku, and the text flutters in and out of different colors and typefaces, giving the poems their ineffable beauty.
   8: 
   9: —Geof Huth
  10: 
  11: More About Visual Poetry >>

#831: 129200_untitled_Gallo, Philip_unknown.txt

Prose starts at line: 3

Avg verse line length: 8.0
Avg prose line length: 101.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: untitled
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: Philip Gallo is a typographer-poet, or "typoet," and his work depends on the careful alignment of simple words for its effects.
   4: 
   5: "untitled" makes reference to the concrete poetry of the middle of the twentieth century.
   6: 
   7: Diter Rot, whose name serves as the central text of this poem, was famous for a number of rigid typographical poems, including one that played with the letters "t" and "u" to produce, in varying ways, the words "tu" (you) and "ut" ("do" on the musical scale).
   8: 
   9: Gallo's poem also appears to allude to "ping pong" by Eugen Gomringer, another early concrete poet.
  10: 
  11: —Geof Huth
  12: 
  13: More About Visual Poetry >>

   3: The body of the boy who took his flightoff the cliff at Kilcloher into the seawas hauled up by curragh-men, out at first lightfishing mackerel in the estuary.
   4: 
   5: “No requiem or rosary” said the priest,“nor consecrated ground for burial,”as if the boy had flown outside the paleof mercy or redemption or God’s love.
   6: 
   7: “Forgive them, for they know not what they do,”quoth Argyle to the corpse’s people,who heard in what he said a sort of riddle,as if he meant their coreligionistsand not their sodden, sadly broken boy.
   8: 
   9: Either way, they took some comfort in itand readied better than accustomed fareof food and spirits; by their own reckoning:the greater sin, the greater so the toll.
  10:

  12:

  14: 
  15: What say his leaping was a leap of faith,into his father’s beckoning embrace?
  16: 
  17: ”They killed no fatted calf.
  18: 
  19: They filled the hole.

Author: Lynch, Thomas P
Prose starts at line: 5
Lines to remove: 7
Avg verse line length: 28.0
Avg prose line length: 229.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: His Ambulations
   2: 
   3: On shanks’ mare Argyle talked to himself.
   4: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   5: Alone, he’d carry on whole colloquiesen route to some poor corpse’s obsequies—these dialogues, the way he kept his witsabout him, body and soul together,fit for the wretched work of sin-eating.
   6: 
   7: Sometimes he counted words or parts of wordsas if they amounted to something morethan sound and sense attuned between his ears,as, for example, how coincident:the way grace and gratis, wherefore gratitudepartook a kinship such as cousins do,singing the same tune in different voices,much as grave and gravitas, then gravitykept one earthbound, grounded, humble as the mud—the humus, so-called, God wrought humans from.
   8: 
   9: Or how from Adam’s rib was fashioned Eve—bone of his own bone, flesh of his flesh—whom he got gravid by implanting seed,in her unfathomably fecund Eden.
  10: 
  11: The memory of a woman’s companywould bring his ambulations to a haltto aim his gaping face due heavenward, the dewy air her touch, her taste, sweet salt.

   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]

   3: Thin gruel, shallow graves, whiskey watered down,the ne’er-do-well and good-for-nothing crowdof cornerboys and gobshites were amongArgyle’s manifold perturbations.
   4: 
   5: Worse still, the episcopal vexations: their excellencies, eminence and graces,red-cassocked dandies and mitered wankers,the croziered posers in their bishoprics with their Easter duties and Peter’s pence,their ledgers full of mortal, venial sins—keepers of the till and tally, bankersof indulgences and dispensations;their bulls and bans and excommunications,nothing but contumely and bamboozles.
   6: 
   7: For all their vestiture, rings and unctions,preaching to bishops, like farting at skunks, was nothing but a mug’s game to the sin-eater,so in earshot of them mum is what he kept.
   8: 
   9: Still, he thought there might be something to it:a life apart from this life where the soulslong dead and gone were neither dead nor gone.
  10: 
  11: Some days he felt so happily haunted,by loving ghosts and gods upholding him.
  12: 
  13: Some days he felt entirely alone.

#837: 129992_Sassoon's Public Statement Of Defiance_Sassoon, Siegfried_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Sassoon's Public Statement Of Defiance
Author: Sassoon, Siegfried
Prose starts at line: 7
Lines to remove: 9
Avg verse line length: 93.0
Avg prose line length: 209.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   2: 
   3: "I am making this statement as an act of wilful defiance of military authority, because I believe the war is being deliberately prolonged by those who have the power to end it.
   4: 
   5: I am a soldier, convinced that I am acting on behalf of soldiers.
   6: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   7: I believe that this war, upon which I entered as a war of defence and liberation has now become a war of aggression and conquest.
   8: 
   9: I believe that the purposes for which I and my fellow soldiers entered upon this war should have been so clearly stated as to have made it impossible to change them, and that, had this been done, the objects witch actuated us would now be attainable by negotiation.
  10: 
  11: I have seen and endured the suffering of the troops, and I can no longer be a party to prolong these sufferings for ends which I believe to be evil and unjust.
  12: 
  13: I am not protesting against the conduct of the war, but against the political errors and insincerity's for which the fighting men are being sacrificed.
  14: 
  15: On behalf of those who are suffering now I make this protest against the deception which is being practised on them; also I believe that I may help to destroy the callous complacence with which the majority of those at home regard the continuance of agonies which they do not share, and which they have not sufficient imagination to realise.


====================================================================================================
#838: 130009_On Passing The New Menin Gate_Sassoon, Siegfried_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: On Passing The New Menin Gate
Author: Sassoon, Siegfried
Prose starts at line: 30
Lines to remove: 16
Avg verse line length: 42.0
Avg prose line length: 151.3

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  25: 
  26: The Menin Gate war memorial at Ypres was built and opened in 1927.
  27: 
  28: It commemorates the British soldiers whose bodies were never found.
  29: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  30: On its huge panels are carved 54,896 names of men with no known grave who died in this area between 1914 and August 1917.
  31: 
  32: The designer thought there would be plenty of room for all the names, but there was not: a further 34,984 names of missing soldiers (from August 1917 to the end of the war) are carved on panels at Tyne Cot cemetery not far away.
  33: 
  34: The Menin Gate is an integral part of Ypres and the Menin Road, along which people and traffic pass daily, runs through it.
  35: 
  36: Every night of the year, at 8.
  37: 
  38: 00, the road is closed while 'The Last Post', the traditional bugle call marking the end of the day for soldiers in action, is played.
  39: 
  40: At the opening ceremony in 1927, these words were spoken: 'It was resolved that here at Ypres, where so many of the missing are known to have fallen, there should be erected a memorial worthy of them which should give expression to the nation's gratitude for their sacrifice and their sympathy with those who mourned them.
  41: 
  42: A memorial has been erected which, in its simple grandeur, fulfils this object, and now it can be said of each one in whose honour we are assembled here today: "He is not missing; he is here!" '
  43: The Menin Gate is one of the most-visited monuments on the increasingly well-trodden war memorial tourist trail.
  44: 
  45: Many are drawn by that evening ceremony (which is maintained and carried out by the Fire Brigade).


====================================================================================================
#839: 130125_Two Nudes_Bang, Mary Jo_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Two Nudes
Author: Bang, Mary Jo
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 17
Avg verse line length: 9.0
Avg prose line length: 129.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Two Nudes
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: I was working in a bookstore and as an antidote to the twin torment of exhaustion and boredom, one day I went with a friend on a walking tour.
   4: 
   5: We made it as far as Berlin and there I met the man I would move with to a boarding house, then to furnished rooms in the flat of a civil servant, and from there one morning in January to the Registry to be married.
   6: 
   7: Afterward we moved to a studio apartment and two years later to the school where boys returning from the war would remove their collars and sew them back on with red thread to demonstrate the end of their allegiance to the cruel and fastidious past.
   8: 
   9: Everyone wanted to be launched into a place from which you could look back and ask whether the red was also meant to enact spilled blood.
  10: 
  11: You could say so, but only if you want to insist that history's minutia is best read as allegory.
  12: 
  13: The fact is, history didn't exist then.
  14: 
  15: Each day was a twenty-four hour stand-still on a bridge from which we discretely looked into the distance, hoping to catch sight of the future.
  16: 
  17: It's near where you're standing now.
  18: 
  19: One day we were lying in the sun dressed in nothing but our skin when a camera came by and devoured us.

#840: 130263_The Loves of the Angels_Moore, Thomas_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Loves of the Angels
Author: Moore, Thomas
Prose starts at line: 2063
Lines to remove: 16
Avg verse line length: 34.8
Avg prose line length: 175.4

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2058: 
2059: 'the
2060: Angels
2061: of God,' instead of 'the
2062: Sons

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2063: ' - a mistake which, assisted by the allegorizing comments of Philo, and the rhapsodical fictions of the Book of Enoch, was more than sufficient to affect the imaginations of such half-Pagan writers as Clemens Alexandrinus, Tertullian, and Lactantius, who, chiefly among the Fathers, have indulged themselves in fanciful reveries upon the subject.
2064: 
2065: 
2066: The foundation of my story, therefore, has little to do with Holy Writ as have the dreams of the latter Platonists, or the reveries of the Jewish divines; and, in appropriating the notion thus to the uses of poetry, I have done no more than establish it in that region of fiction, to which the opinions of the most rational Fathers, and of all other Christians theologians, have long ago consigned it.
2067: 
2068: In addition to the fitness of the subject for poetry, it struck me also as capable of affording an allegorical medium, through which might be shadowed out.
2069: 
2070: 
2071: the fall of the soul from its original purity - the loss of light and happiness which it suffers, in the pursuit of this world's perishable pleasures - and the punishments, both from conscience and divine justice, with which impurity, pride, and presumptuous inquiry into the awful secrets of God, are sure to be visited.
2072: 
2073: The beautiful story of Cupid and Psyche owes its chief charm to this sort of 'veiled meaning', and it has been my wish.
2074: 
2075: 
2076: to communicate the same
2077: moral
2078: interest to the following pages.

#845: 132615_Spring - The First Pastoral ; or Damon_Pope, Alexander_unknown.txt

Prose starts at line: 212
Lines to remove: 17
