[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 207: 
 208: (line 100: A wond'rous Tree that sacred Monarchs bears): An allusion to the Royal Oak, in which Charles II.
 209: 
 210: had been hid from the pursuit after the battle of Worcester.
 211: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 212: (line 105: The Thistle springs, to which the Lily yields,): Alludes to the device of the Scots monarchs, the thistle worn by Queen Anne; and to the arms of France, the fleur de lys.
 213: 
 214: In the early part of Queen Anne's reign the royal arms were the same as those of her father.
 215: 
 216: The union with Scotland occasioned a change of armorial bearings; and they then appeared, England and Scotland impaled in the first and fourth quarter; France in the second; and Ireland in the third.
 217: 
 218: On the great seal prepared in the year of the union (1706) we have England and Scotland only, and a new badge, the rose and thistle conjoined.
 219: 
 220: The Scottish order of the Thistle was re-established Dec.
 221: 
 222: 31, 1703.
 223: 
 224: Annals of England, III.
 225: 
 226: 173-4, and 182.
 227: 
 228: ~ Globe edition, The Poetical Works of Alexander Pope, 1885.

  40:

  44: himself was unable to oppose him, had recourse to his God, Thorgerd, to whom he sacrificed his son Erling.
  45:

#847: 133158_Here War Is Simple_Auden, W H_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Here War Is Simple
Author: Auden, W H
Prose starts at line: 23
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 30.0
Avg prose line length: 135.7

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  18: Where life is evil now:
  19: Nanking.
  20: 
  21: Dachau.
  22: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  23: In August 1937 Japanese forces invaded China and embarked on a savage war which lasted until 1945 and in which at least 10m Chinese civilians were killed.
  24: 
  25: In November the Japanese attacked Nanking, then China's capital city; by December they had taken it, and began a six week series of atrocities against the citizens.
  26: 
  27: The soldiers raped, looted and burned, and upwards of 300,000 people were massacred with extreme cruelty.
  28: 
  29: The concentration camp at Dachau in Germany was opened on March 9 1933, less than a week after Hitler became supreme ruler.
  30: 
  31: Almost at once several thousand people were imprisoned there (without trial) because they opposed Hitler's Nazi government.
  32: 
  33: They included Communists, Socialists and Liberals, many of them academics and other distinguished people.
  34: 
  35: Later, thousands of German and Austrian gypsies and Jews were held there before being deported to death camps set up in Poland.
  36: 
  37: The Dachau camp was run by the SS, and with great brutality; many prisoners died there from ill-treatment, or were killed.
  38: 
  39: In 1944 and 1945, when the Germans were hastily emptying concentration camps set up outside Germany, many surviving Jews were sent to Dachau on 'death marches'; those who collapsed were left to die.
  40: 
  41: When American troops liberated Dachau in 1945 they found many dead, but also 33,000 starving survivors - only 2,531 of whom were Jewish.


====================================================================================================

 616: "Mount Arafa, situated about a mile from Mecca, is held in great veneration by the Mussulmans, as a place very proper for penitence.
 617: 
 618: Its fitness in this respect is accounted for by a tradition that Adam and Eve, on being banished out of Paradise, in order to do penance for their transgression were parted from each other, and after a separation of six score years, met again upon this mountain.

Title: Sidetracks IX
Author: Yang, Jeffrey
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 8
Avg verse line length: 13.0
Avg prose line length: 316.4

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Sidetracks IX
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: the Cold War just ended    a lone sun in the belly of the flying bird white sails drift into an alternate river of  time    all languages circulate against the state of enslavement    my identity suspect    exile is crossing the void of a journey without a destination—my life
   4: intoxicated—tram gently rocks through the center of  Vienna whisky bottle polished off in a room in Stockholm    I make ghostly faces in the mirror    a South African poet a French poet and I belt out “The Internationale” on Osborne Street    adjusting pace to march straight into first light
   5: the moon is my mother    softly smooth out those secret slips of paper the birth of suffering flashes to mind    precisely because of life’s incompleteness it completes itself    the defensive line of the fathers turns into forest    a chainsaw screams out of human will    behind the cemetery the city glitters and shines
   6: the setting sun and an elegy for the twentieth-century    scattered chronicles and crossed-out blacklists    the wave that has yet to form has already transmigrated     postwar flags ceaselessly change colors meanings that survive underground draw water    from the cracks between words spit out the bubbles    collect postage stamps collect shards of thought    butterflies flutter above a forgotten line of defense
   7: I am Celan in 1947    crossing the border from Bucharest to Vienna the smuggler has the smell of a skunk    North Star of my childhood leads the way    no identity card except a manuscript of poems overnight at an abandoned train station    a stooped shadow stalks through the starlight    German the enemy of the mother tongueit is now time  for stone to bloom
   8: I dream of a raging storm    a forest as if a crazed herd of  horses whirls me away    embrace a pillow in the clouds    hug the family tightly waves crash against the port side of a battered wooden boat    moss blindfolds the rocks    perch on the branch of language    coffins of war or epidemic take flight    shadows in the field dig up potatoes to prepare for winter
   9: searching for an unfamiliar city in which I can be reborn    crow-black clouds bow their heads to smell the tobacco leaves    the sea leaves a watermark on banknotes    angels on the gallery walls fly away in a hurry    the bronze statue on the public square overflows with hostility    time is like walking a dog bounding prancing running wildly swiftly stops and turns the corner    scratches an itch against a tree then pees and moves on and on    without a leash
  10: Translated from the Chinese

   3: That sparrow on the iron railing, not worth a farthing, purchases a realm its shrill cries measure, trading dying for being.
   4: 
   5: It's up to no good, out to overturn a kingdom just by swooping into the right kitchen, or upsetting somebody's aim.
   6: 
   7: For my pleasure, I'll call it Good News, or Little Egypt.
   8:

  12:

  16:

#855: 133772_Secret Life_Lee, Li-Young_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Secret Life
Author: Lee, Li-Young
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 9
Avg verse line length: 11.0
Avg prose line length: 247.6

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Secret Life
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: Alone with time, he waits for his parents to wake, a boy growing old at the dining room table, pressing into the pages of one of his father's big books the flowers he picked all morning in his mother's garden, magnolia, hibiscus, azalea, peony, pear, tulip, iris; reading in another book their names he knows, and then the names from their secret lives; lives alchemical, nautical, genital; names unpronounceable fascicles of italic script; secrets botanical description could never trace: accessory to empire, party to delusions of an afterlife, kin to the toothed, mouthed, furred, horned, brained.
   4: 
   5: Flowers seem to a boy, who doesn't know better, like the winged, the walking, the swimming and crawling things abstracted from time, and stilled by inward gazing.
   6: 
   7: Copying their pictures, replete with diagrams, he finds in the words for their parts, the accounts of their histories, and their scattered pollen, something to do with his own fate and the perfection of all dying things.
   8: 
   9: And when it's time, he discovers in the kitchen the note left for him that says his parents have gone and will return by noon.
  10: 
  11: And when it's time, the dove calls from its hiding place and leaves the morning greener and the one who hears the dove more alone.

  13: thought his courage and perseverance was worthy of being commemorated in verse; and

  88: 
  89: Only then did Captain Salmond order that those men who could swim to save themselves by swimming to the boats; Lt Col Seaton, however, recognising that rushing the lifeboats would risk swamping them and endangering the women and children, ordered the men to stand fast.
  90: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  91: The soldiers did not move, even as the ship broke up barely twenty minutes after striking the rock.
  92: 
  93: Some of the soldiers managed to swim the  2 km to shore over the next twelve hours, but most either drowned or were taken by the frenzied sharks that quickly arrived on the scene.
  94: 
  95: Next morning the schooner Lioness discovered one of the cutters, and after saving the occupants of the second boat made her way to the scene of the disaster arriving in the afternoon, where she rescued as many people as possible.
  96: 
  97: It was reported that of the 643 people aboard the Birkenhead only 193 were saved.
  98: 
  99: This disaster was the origin of the phrase "Women and Children First!" which became the standard procedure in maritime disasters, while the "Birkenhead Drill" carried out by the soldiers became the epitome of courageous behaviour in hopeless circumstances.

 165: 'desert isles 'twas he that raised': Although Venice was built a considerable time before the era here assigned for the birth of Independence, the republic had not yet attained to any great degree of power and splendour.
 166: 
 167: 'Iberian's double chain;' The Low Countries were not only oppressed by grievous taxations, but likewise threatened with the establishment of the Inquisition, when the Seven Provinces revolted, and shook off the yoke of Spain.
 168:

 170:

 172:

 176: 
 177: ': The noble stand made by Pascal Paoli and his associates against the usurpation of the French must endear them to all the sons of Liberty and Independence.

  42: 'The following whimsical and otherwise worthless stanzas of Hugh of Werbenwag (about 1250) constitute the only intimation that occurs to our remembrance of a temporal jurisdiction acknowledged or appealed to by the German Troubadours in affairs of the heart; and even here the complaint is to no authority constituted for the especial purpose, but to the king (Conrad), with a further appeal to the emperor, and thence in due gradation to the pope; subject also most curiously to the acknowledged right of the accused to the legal wager of battel if claimed.

  75: solitary, severely depressed and/or enlightened humans that commit suicide by seeking out alien faces and looking at them; these humans may feel happy inside an insane nervous breakdown
  76:

  78:

  82:

   3: My dear little Blossoms, there are now in this world, and always will be, a great many grannies beside myself, both in petticoats and pantaloons, some a deal younger, to be sure, but all monstrous wise and of my own family name.
   4: 
   5: These old women, who never had chick or child of their own, but who always know how to bring up other people's children, will tell you with long faces that my enchanting, quieting, soothing volume, my all-sufficient anodyne for cross, peevish, won't-be-comforted little bairns, ought be laid aside for more learned books, such as they could select and publish.
   6: 
   7: Fudge! I tell you that all their batterings can't deface my beauties, nor their wise pratings equal my wiser prattlings; and all imitators of my refreshing songs might as well write another Billy Shakespeare as another Mother Goose—we two great poets were born together, and shall go out of the world together.
   8: 
   9: No, no, my melodies will never die,
  10: While nurses sing, or babies cry.

1498:

1500: 
1501: At last, having been before advis’d by Hector’s ghost, and now by the appearance of his mother Venus, he is prevail’d upon to leave the town, and settle his household gods in another country.
1502: 
1503: In order to this, he carries off his father on his shoulders, and leads his little son by the hand, his wife following them behind.
1504: 
1505: When he comes to the place appointed for the general rendezvouze, he finds a great confluence of people, but misses his wife whose ghost afterwards appears to him, and tells him the land which was design’d for him.

1549:

1551:

1553: 
1554: Upon this, Æneas, by the advice of one of his generals, and a vision of his father, builds a city for the women, old men, and others, who were either unfit for war, or weary of the voyage, and sails for Italy.
1555: 
1556: Venus procures of Neptune a safe voyage for him and all his men, excepting only his pilot Palinurus, who is unfortunately lost

1283:

1285:

1287: 
1288: He is cast on several shores, and meets with very surprising adventures, till at length he lands on Sicily, where his father Anchises dies.
1289: 
1290: This is the place which he was sailing from, when the tempest rose, and threw him upon the Carthaginian coast.

#874: 135988_Descriptive Jottings of London_McGonagall, Knight of the White Elephant_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Descriptive Jottings of London
Author: McGonagall, Knight of the White Elephant of Burmah William
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 30.0
Avg prose line length: 219.3

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Descriptive Jottings of London
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: As I stood upon London Bridge and viewed the mighty throng Of thousands of people in cabs and ’busses rapidly whirling along, All furiously driving to and fro, Up one street and down another as quick as they could go: Then I was struck with the discordant sound of human voices there, Which seemed to me like wild geese cackling in the air: And the river Thames is a most beautiful sight, To see the steamers sailing upon it by day and by night.
   4: 
   5: And the Tower of London is most gloomy to behold, And the crown of England lies there, begemmed with precious stones and gold; King Henry the Sixth was murdered there by the Duke of Glo’ster, And when he killed him with his sword he called him an impostor.
   6: 
   7: St.
   8: 
   9: Paul’s Cathedral is the finest building that ever I did see, There’s no building can surpass it in the city of Dundee, Because it’s magnificent to behold, With its beautiful dome and spire glottering like gold.
  10: 
  11: And as for Nelson’s Monument that stands in Trafalgar Square, It is a most stately monument I most solemnly declare, And towering defiantly very high, Which arrests strangers’ attention while passing by.
  12: 
  13: Then there’s two beautiful water-fountains spouting up very high, Where the weary traveller can drink when he feels dry; And at the foot of the monument there’s three bronze lions in grand array, Enough to make the stranger’s heart throb with dismay.
  14: 
  15: Then there’s Mr Spurgeon, a great preacher, which no one dare gainsay, I went to hear him preach on the Sabbath-day, And he made my heart feel light and gay, When I heard him preach and pray.
  16: 
  17: And the Tabernacle was crowded from ceiling to floor, And many were standing outside the door; He is an eloquent preacher I honestly declare, And I was struck with admiration as on him I did stare.
  18: 
  19: Then there’s Petticoat Lane I venture to say, It’s a wonderful place on the Sabbath-day; There wearing-apparel can be bought to suit the young or old, For the ready cash, silver, coppers, or gold.
  20: 
  21: Oh! mighty city of London! you are wonderful to see, And thy beauties no doubt fill the tourist’s heart with glee; But during my short stay, and while wandering there, Mr Spurgeon was the only man I heard speaking proper English I do declare.


====================================================================================================
#875: 135991_An Address to the Rev. George Gilfillan_McGonagall, Knight of the White Elephant_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: An Address to the Rev. George Gilfillan
Author: McGonagall, Knight of the White Elephant of Burmah William
Prose starts at line: 7
Lines to remove: 11
Avg verse line length: 46.0
Avg prose line length: 200.3

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   2: 
   3: All hail to the Rev.
   4: 
   5: George Gilfillan of Dundee, He is the greatest preacher I did ever hear or see.
   6: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   7: He is a man of genius bright, And in him his congregation does delight, Because they find him to be honest and plain, Affable in temper, and seldom known to complain.
   8: 
   9: He preaches in a plain straightforward way, The people flock to hear him night and day, And hundreds from the doors are often turn’d away, Because he is the greatest preacher of the present day.
  10: 
  11: He has written the life of Sir Walter Scott, And while he lives he will never be forgot, Nor when he is dead, Because by his admirers it will be often read; And fill their minds with wonder and delight, And wile away the tedious hours on a cold winter’s night.
  12: 
  13: He has also written about the Bards of the Bible, Which occupied nearly three years in which he was not idle, Because when he sits down to write he does it with might and main, And to get an interview with him it would be almost vain, And in that he is always right, For the Bible tells us whatever your hands findeth to do, Do it with all your might.
  14: 
  15: Rev.
  16: 
  17: George Gilfillan of Dundee, I must conclude my muse, And to write in praise of thee my pen does not refuse, Nor does it give me pain to tell the world fearlessly, that when You are dead they shall not look upon your like again.


====================================================================================================
#876: 135996_The Burial of the Rev. George Gilfillan_McGonagall, Knight of the White Elephant_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Burial of the Rev. George Gilfillan
Author: McGonagall, Knight of the White Elephant of Burmah William
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 17
Avg verse line length: 39.0
Avg prose line length: 243.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: The Burial of the Rev. George Gilfillan
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: On the Gilfillan burial day, In the Hill o’ Balgay, It was a most solemn sight to see, Not fewer than thirty thousand people assembled in Dundee, All watching the funeral procession of Gilfillan that day, That death had suddenly taken away, And was going to be buried in the Hill o’ Balgay.
   4: 
   5: There were about three thousand people in the procession alone, And many were shedding tears, and several did moan, And their bosoms heaved with pain, Because they knew they would never look upon his like again.
   6: 
   7: There could not be fewer than fifty carriages in the procession that day, And gentlemen in some of them that had come from far away, And in whispers some of them did say, As the hearse bore the precious corpse away, Along the Nethergate that day.
   8: 
   9: I’m sure he will be greatly missed by the poor, For he never turned them empty-handed away from his door; And to assist them in distress it didn’t give him pain, And I’m sure the poor will never look upon his like again.
  10: 
  11: On the Gilfillan burial day, in the Hill o’ Balgay, There was a body of policemen marshalled in grand array, And marched in front of the procession all the way; Also the relatives and friends of the deceas’d, Whom I hope from all sorrows has been releas’d, And whose soul I hope to heaven has fled away, To sing with saints above for ever and aye.
  12: 
  13: The Provost, Magistrates, and Town Council were in the procession that day; Also Mrs Gilfillan, who cried and sobbed all the way For her kind husband, that was always affable and gay, Which she will remember until her dying day.
  14: 
  15: When the procession arrived in the Hill o’ Balgay, The people were almost as hush as death, and many of them did say— As long as we live we’ll remember the day That the great Gilfillan was buried in the Hill o’Balgay.
  16: 
  17: When the body of the great Gilfillan was lowered into the grave, ’Twas then the people’s hearts with sorrow did heave; And with tearful eyes and bated breath, Mrs Gilfillan lamented her loving husband’s death.
  18: 
  19: Then she dropped a ringlet of immortelles into his grave, Then took one last fond look, and in sorrow did leave; And all the people left with sad hearts that day, And that ended the Gilfillan burial in the Hill o’ Balgay.

#877: 135998_The Little Match Girl_McGonagall, Knight of the White Elephant_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Little Match Girl
Author: McGonagall, Knight of the White Elephant of Burmah William
Prose starts at line: 5
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 107.5
Avg prose line length: 189.5

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: The Little Match Girl
   2: 
   3: It was biting cold, and the falling snow, Which filled a poor little match girl’s heart with woe, Who was bareheaded and barefooted, as she went along the street, Crying, “Who’ll buy my matches?
   4: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   5: for I want pennies to buy some meat!” When she left home she had slippers on; But, alas! poor child, now they were gone.
   6: 
   7: For she lost both of them while hurrying across the street, Out of the way of two carriages which were near by her feet.
   8: 
   9: So the little girl went on, while the snow fell thick and fast; And the child’s heart felt cold and downcast, For nobody had bought any matches that day, Which filled her little mind with grief and dismay.
  10: 
  11: Alas! she was hungry and shivering with cold; So in a corner between two houses she made bold To take shelter from the violent storm.
  12: 
  13: Poor little waif! wishing to herself she’d never been born.
  14: 
  15: And she grew colder and colder, and feared to go home For fear of her father beating her; and she felt woe-begone Because she could carry home no pennies to buy bread, And to go home without pennies she was in dread.
  16: 
  17: The large flakes of snow covered her ringlets of fair hair; While the passers-by for her had no care, As they hurried along to their homes at a quick pace, While the cold wind blew in the match girl’s face.
  18: 
  19: As night wore on her hands were numb with cold, And no longer her strength could her uphold, When an idea into her little head came: She’d strike a match and warm her hands at the flame.
  20: 
  21: And she lighted the match, and it burned brightly, And it helped to fill her heart with glee; And she thought she was sitting at a stove very grand; But, alas! she was found dead, with a match in her hand! Her body was found half-covered with snow, And as the people gazed thereon their hearts were full of woe; And many present let fall a burning tear Because she was found dead on the last night of the year, In that mighty city of London, wherein is plenty of gold— But, alas! their charity towards street waifs is rather cold.
  22: 
  23: But I hope the match girl’s in Heaven, beside her Saviour dear, A bright reward for all the hardships she suffered here.

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Shine, Perishing Republic
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: While this America settles in the mould of its vulgarity, heavily thickening to empire
   4: And protest, only a bubble in the molten mass, pops and sighs out, and the mass hardens,
   5: I sadly smiling remember that the flower fades to make fruit, the fruit rots to make earth.
   6: 
   7: Out of the mother; and through the spring exultances, ripeness and decadence; and home to the mother.
   8: 
   9: You making haste haste on decay: not blameworthy; life is good, be it stubbornly long or suddenly
  10: A mortal splendor: meteors are not needed less than mountains: shine, perishing republic.
  11: 
  12: But for my children, I would have them keep their distance from the thickening center; corruption
  13: Never has been compulsory, when the cities lie at the monster's feet there are left the mountains.
  14: 
  15: And boys, be in nothing so moderate as in love of man, a clever servant, insufferable master.
  16: 
  17: There is the trap that catches noblest spirits, that caught — they say — God, when he walked on earth.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  12: 
  13: The weather is very hot.
  14: 
  15: Today, large scissors that will cut and cut represent mercy for the alpaca.
  16: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  17: When something is lost in the park, to whom do we look but this ever-prepared beast which seems to secretly carry all things?
  18: 
  19: And when children think about the objects they have lost—dolls, teddy bears, flying rats, trees with seven voices (they can be hidden in only one place)—they remember the alpaca, their infinitely prepared companion.
  20: 
  21: But look at those eyes, those astonished eyes without knowledge; they only ask why she has been harnessed for such a long trip and why no one comes to relieve her.
  22: 
  23: The high plateau is to blame for this tragedy—the mother alpaca incessantly stares at it.
  24: 
  25: The mountain was also casting off burdens, and so its summit became clear, and filled the eyes of the mother alpaca.
  26: 
  27: She was taken down from the plateau and situated near a nonsensical horizon, and when she turns her neck, she continues looking for the older alpaca, for the one who sheds a pack on high, and returns to the sun's radiance.
  28: 
  29: "What have you and I done to our Andean cordillera?
  30: 
  31: " I ask the alpaca.

  22: 
  23: Heaven is a tornado  siren canceling school.
  24: 
  25: Heaven is pressed in a pleather booth at the Olive Garden, sipping Pepsi between my gapped teeth, listening to my father mispronounce his meal.

   4: 
   5: Like discovering in a sea chest a short obsidian head.
   6: 
   7: Like looking through a padlock   and seeing an undeserved dawn.
   8: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   9: As impossible as all these, as melancholy and lonely, was it to see the green truck that with the punctuality   of a sacrament delivered the coal each month.
  10: 
  11: On the slope its strained   heart would announce itself vociferously, at the brink of death, and it   would stop in front of the house as if to deliver the agonizing news of   the fall of Troy.
  12: 
  13: And then a man, wrapped in sacking, would pitch   his cargo, resonant and angular, into an orange-painted crate.
  14: 
  15: Like opening a Bible and finding three leaves of laurel.
  16: 
  17: Like lifting   a stone and remembering someone’s name.
  18: 
  19: Like finding the same   snail again a hundred miles away.
  20: 
  21: As impossible as all these, as melancholy and lonely, would it be to find, fifteen years later, the same coal    deliveryman carrying on his trade, bent from the strain, determined   to show the heavens that a man might do that job his entire life, that   he scraped in the mines, that he stole thread from his wife to sew his   sacking, that he dreamed of infinite excavations, of tunnels, and that   they might forgive him for not having done more than that.

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]

   1: Caelica 29: The nurse-life wheat within his green husk growing
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: The nurse-life wheat within his green husk growing, Flatters our hope, and tickles our desire, Nature’s true riches in sweet beauties showing, Which sets all hearts, with labor’s love, on fire.
   4: 
   5: No less fair is the wheat when golden ear Shows unto hope the joys of near enjoying; Fair and sweet is the bud, more sweet and fair the rose, which proves that time is not destroying.
   6: 
   7: Caelica, your youth, the morning of delight, Enamel’d o’er with beauties white and red, All sense and thoughts did to belief invite, That love and glory there are brought to bed;
   8: 
   9: And your ripe year’s love-noon; he goes no higher,
  10: 
  11: Turns all the spirits of man into desire.

   1: Royalty
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: One fine morning, in the country of a very gentle people, a magnificent man and woman were shouting in the public square.
   4: 
   5: “My friends, I want her to be queen!” “I want to be queen!” She was laughing and trembling.
   6: 
   7: He spoke to their friends of revelation, of trials completed.
   8: 
   9: They swooned against each other.
  10: 
  11: In fact they were regents for a whole morning as crimson hangings were raised against the houses, and for the whole afternoon, as they moved toward groves of palm trees.

   1: Homeless Heart
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: When I think of finishing the work, when I think of the finished work, a great sadness overtakes me, a sadness paradoxically like joy.
   4: 
   5: The circumstances of doing put away, the being of it takes possession, like a tenant in a rented house.
   6: 
   7: Where are you now, homeless heart?
   8: 
   9: Caught in a hinge, or secreted behind drywall, like your nameless predecessors now that they have been given names?
  10: 
  11: Best not to dwell on our situation, but to dwell in it is deeply refreshing.
  12: 
  13: Like a sideboard covered with decanters and fruit.
  14: 
  15: As a box kite is to a kite.
  16: 
  17: The inside of stumbling.
  18: 
  19: The way to breath.
  20: 
  21: The caricature on the blackboard.

#889: 137554_mi'kmaq book of the dead_And, Miekal_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: mi'kmaq book of the dead
Author: And, Miekal
Prose starts at line: 5
Lines to remove: 7
Avg verse line length: 41.0
Avg prose line length: 129.5

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: mi'kmaq book of the dead
   2: 
   3: mIEKAL aND often incorporates alien scripts into his work.
   4: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   5: These can be undecipherable writing systems of history, scripts unfamiliar to most people, and scripts invented by him or others.
   6: 
   7: He uses these to allow us to see written language with new eyes, to appreciate its visual forms, and to face the process of searching for meaning in a foreign textscape.
   8: 
   9: His "mi'kmaq book of the dead" combines seemingly recognizable characters with apparently pictographic ones, encouraging us to pick out a meaning we will never quite find on our own.
  10: 
  11: —Geof Huth More About Visual Poetry >>

 106: 
 107: VIII Mon.
 108: 
 109: October hath xxxi days.
 110: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 111: Time was my spouse and I could not agree, Striving about superiority: The text which saith that man and wife are one, Was the chief argument we stood upon: She held, they both one woman should become; I held they should be man, and both but one.
 112: 
 113: Thus we contended daily, but the strife Could not be ended, till both were one Wife.
 114: 
 115: IX Mon.
 116: 
 117: November hath xxx days.
 118: 
 119: My neighbour H—-y by his pleasing tongue, Hath won a Girl that’s rich, wise, fair and young, The Match (he saith) is half concluded, he Indeed is wondrous willing; but not she.
 120: 
 121: And reason good, for he has run thro’all Almost the story of the Prodigal; Yet swears he never with the hogs did dine; That’s true, for none would trust him with their swine.
 122: 
 123: X Mon.
 124: 
 125: December hath xxxi days.
 126: 
 127: She that will eat her breakfast in her bed, And spend the morn in dressing of her head, And sit at dinner like a maiden bride, And talk of nothing all day but of pride; God in his mercy may do much to save her, But what a case is he in that shall have her.

  13: Which relish not toReasonnor toSense
  14: Like Cats in Airpumps, to subsist we strive
  15: On Joys too thin to keep the Soul alive.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: X Mon. December [1744] hath xxxi days.
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: This World’s an Inn, all Travellers are we; And this World’s Goods th’Accommodations be.
   4: 
   5: Our Life is nothing but a Winter’s Day; Some only break their Fast, and so away.
   6: 
   7: Others stay Dinner, and depart full fed.
   8: 
   9: The deepest Age but sups and goes to bed.
  10: 
  11: He’s most in Debt that lingers out the Day; Who dies betimes has less and less to pay.

#893: 137911_Justice In Masquerade, Or Scroggs Upon Scroggs_College, Stephen_unknown.txt

Title: Justice In Masquerade, Or Scroggs Upon Scroggs
Author: College, Stephen
Prose starts at line: 47
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 47.8
Avg prose line length: 143.1

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  42: 
  43: His father had intended him for the church, and had procured him the reversion of a good living, but he took arms for the king, and was captain of a foot company, which entirely changed his fortune.
  44: 
  45: He then entered at Gray's Inn, and in 1669 was made serjeant, and knighted, and soon after became king's serjeant.
  46: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  47: May 31, 1678, being at the time a judge of the Common Pleas, he was promoted to the chief seat in the King's Bench through the Earl of Danby, and there ensured many convictions of the supposed popish conspirators.
  48: 
  49: However, in the full belief that the sway of parliament was all-powerful, and that Shaftesbury was guiding the destinies of the state, he one day asked a lord of the privy council, if the lord president (Shaftesbury) really had that influence with the king which he seemed to have?
  50: 
  51: The reply was, 'No; no more than your footman hath with you.
  52: 
  53: ' Scroggs was converted, and threw cold water on the plot, for which he was impeached; but he escaped on the dissolution of parliament, and retired to Weald-hall, near Burntwood, in Essex, with the loss, however, of his place.
  54: 
  55: He died of a polypus in the heart in 1683* *[Some say he died in Essex-street, but surely this must be a blunder for Essex] having survived his wife, a daughter of Matthew Blucke, Esq.
  56: 
  57: , some time.
  58: 
  59: This judge was a great lover of good living; and Sir Matthew Hale, whose taste was quite different, refused Scroggs the privilege of a serjeant when he was arrested, which made a great talk at the time.
  60: 
  61: His son and heir, Sir William Scroggs, sold his estate to Alderman Erasmus Smith.
  62: 
  63: No man was more smartly lampooned by the wits of the day than this turncoat chief justice.
  64: 
  65: - Memoirs of the Life of Judge Jeffreys, by Woolrych, London: Henry Colburn, 1827.

   1: Home Again, Home Again
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: The children are back, the children are back— They’ve come to take refuge, exhale and unpack; The marriage has faltered, the job has gone bad, Come open the door for them, Mother and Dad.
   4: 
   5: The city apartment is leaky and cold, The landlord lascivious, greedy and old— The mattress is lumpy, the oven’s encrusted, The freezer, the fan, and the toilet have rusted.
   6: 
   7: The company caved, the boss went broke, The job and the love affair, all up in smoke.
   8: 
   9: The anguish of loneliness comes as a shock— O heart in the doldrums, O heart in hock.
  10: 
  11: And so they return with their piles of possessions, Their terrified cats and their mournful expressions, Reclaiming the bedrooms they had in their teens, Clean towels, warm comforter, glass figurines.
  12: 
  13: Downstairs in the kitchen the father and mother Don’t say a word, but they look at each other As down from the hill comes Jill, comes Jack.
  14: 
  15: The children are back.
  16: 
  17: The children are back.

#896: 138060_One O'Clock in the Morning_Baudelaire, Charles_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: One O'Clock in the Morning
Author: Baudelaire, Charles
Prose starts at line: 7
Lines to remove: 18
Avg verse line length: 59.0
Avg prose line length: 207.3

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   2: 
   3: At last! I am alone! Nothing can be heard but the rumbling of a few belated and weary cabs.
   4: 
   5: For a few hours at least silence will be ours, if not sleep.
   6: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   7: At last! The tyranny of the human face has disappeared, and now there will be no one but myself to make me suffer.
   8: 
   9: At last! I am allowed to relax in a bath of darkness! First a double turn of the key in the lock.
  10: 
  11: This turn of the key will, it seems to me, increase my solitude and strengthen the barricades that, for the moment, separate me from the world.
  12: 
  13: Horrible life! Horrible city! Let us glance back over the events of the day: saw several writers, one of them asking me if you could go to Russia by land (he thought Russia was an island, I suppose); disagreed liberally with the editor of a review who to all my objections kept saying: "Here we are on the side of respectability," implying that all the other periodicals were run by rascals; bowed to twenty or more persons of whom fifteen were unknown to me; distributed hand shakes in about the same proportion without having first taken the precaution of buying gloves; to kill time during a shower, dropped in on a dance who asked me to design her a costume of Venustre; went to pay court to a theatrical director who in dismissing me said; "Perhaps you would do well to see Z….
  14: 
  15: ; he is the dullest, stupidest and most celebrated of our authors; with him you might get somewhere.
  16: 
  17: Consult him and then we'll see": boasted (why?
  18: 
  19: ) of several ugly things I never did, and cravenly denied some other misdeeds that I had accomplished with the greatest delight; offense of fanfaronnade, crime against human dignity; refused a slight favor to a friend and gave a written recommendation to a perfect rogue; Lord! let's hope that's all!
  20: Dissatisfied with everything, dissatisfied with myself, I long to redeem myself and to restore my pride in the silence and solitude of the night.
  21: 
  22: Souls of those whom I have loved, souls of those whom I have sung, strengthen me, sustain me, keep me from the vanities of the world and its contaminating fumes; and You, dear God! grant me grace to produce a few beautiful verses to prove to myself that I am not the lowest of men, that I am not inferior to those whom I despise.
  23: 
  24: Translated from \

#897: 138198_Windows_Baudelaire, Charles_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Windows
Author: Baudelaire, Charles
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 7.0
Avg prose line length: 107.6

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Windows
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: Looking from outside into an open window one never sees as much as when one looks through a closed window.
   4: 
   5: There is nothing more profound, more mysterious, more pregnant, more insidious, more dazzling than a window lighted by a single candle.
   6: 
   7: What one can see out in the sunlight is always less interesting than what goes on behind a windowpane.
   8: 
   9: In that black or luminous square life lives, life dreams, life suffers.
  10: 
  11: Across the ocean of roofs I can see a middle-aged woman, her face already lined, who is forever bending over something and who never goes out.
  12: 
  13: Out of her face, her dress, and her gestures, out of practically nothing at all, I have made up this woman's story, or rather legend, and sometimes I tell it to myself and weep.
  14: 
  15: If it had been an old man I could have made up his just as well.
  16: 
  17: And I go to bed proud to have lived and to have suffered in some one besides myself.
  18: 
  19: Perhaps you will say "Are you sure that your story is the really one?
  20: 
  21: But what does it matter what reality is outside myself, so long as it has helped me to live, to feel that I am, and what I am?

#898: 138357_Speech- Bottom's Dream_Shakespeare, William_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Speech: Bottom's Dream
Author: Shakespeare, William
Prose starts at line: 33
Lines to remove: 11
Avg verse line length: 36.1
Avg prose line length: 87.7

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  28: 
  29: Man is but an ass if he go about to expound this dream.
  30: 
  31: Methought I was—there is no man can tell what.
  32: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  33: Methought I was, and methought I had—but man is but a patched fool if he will offer to say what methought I had.
  34: 
  35: The eye of man hath not heard, the ear of man hath not seen, man’s hand is not able to taste, his tongue to conceive, nor his heart to report what my dream was.
  36: 
  37: I will get Peter Quince to write a ballad of this dream.
  38: 
  39: It shall be called “Bottom’s Dream” because it hath no bottom.
  40: 
  41: And I will sing it in the latter end of a play before the duke.
  42: 
  43: Peradventure, to make it the more gracious, I shall sing it at her death.

#899: 138438_Sonnet 135- Whoever hath her wish, thou hast thy Will_Shakespeare, William_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Sonnet 135: Whoever hath her wish, thou hast thy Will
Author: Shakespeare, William
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 11
Avg verse line length: 53.0
Avg prose line length: 98.3

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Sonnet 135: Whoever hath her wish, thou hast thy Will
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: Whoever hath her wish, thou hast thy Will, And Will to boot, and Will in overplus; More than enough am I that vex thee still, To thy sweet will making addition thus.
   4: 
   5: Wilt thou, whose will is large and spacious, Not once vouchsafe to hide my will in thine?
   6: 
   7: Shall will in others seem right gracious, And in my will no fair acceptance shine?
   8: 
   9: The sea, all water, yet receives rain still, And in abundance addeth to his store; So thou being rich in Will add to thy Will One will of mine, to make thy large Will more.
  10: 
  11: Let no unkind, no fair beseechers kill;
  12: 
  13: Think all but one, and me in that one Will.

   4: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

  10:

  12: 
  13: If I point the arm, the gun, toward me, I see that this soldier is very thin.
  14: 
  15: It’s almost unreal, how thin he is.

#901: 138645_Ball's Bluff_Lander, Frederick West_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Ball's Bluff
Author: Lander, Frederick West
Prose starts at line: 43
Lines to remove: 7
Avg verse line length: 34.7
Avg prose line length: 191.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  38: Old State — some souls are rudely sped —
  39: This record for thy Twentieth Corps —
  40: Imprisoned, wounded, dying, dead,
  41: It only asks, "Has Sparta more?
  42: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  43: The Battle of Balls Bluff was fought on the steep, rocky shores of the Potomac River near Leesburg, Virginia, in October of 1861.
  44: 
  45: Following the devastating Union defeat (in which one of Abraham Lincoln's closest friends lost his life), a Confederate officer was heard to say that "fewer of the Massachusetts officers would have been killed, had they not been too proud to surrender".
  46: 
  47: This poem, written by General Lander as a response to that allegation, mentions several of those officers by name, including the grandson of Paul Revere and Oliver Wendell Holmes, Jr.
  48: 
  49: By war's end, the 20th Massachusetts (also known as "the Harvard Regiment") had suffered more casualties than any other Massachusetts regiment, answering the question posed by the last line of the poem.


====================================================================================================

   3: In the heart of the white summer mist lay a green little piece of the world;

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   4: And the tops of the beeches were lost in the mist, and the mist ringed us round;
   5: All the low leaves were silvered with dew, and the herbage with dew was impearled;
   6: And the turmoil of life was but vaguely divined through the mist as a sound.
   7: 
   8: In the heart of the mist there was warmth, for the soil full of sun was aglow,
   9: Like a fruit when it colors,—and fragrance from flowers, and a scent from the soil;
  10: And a lamb in the grass, in the flowers, in the dew, nibbled, whiter than snow;
  11: And the white summer mist was a fold for us both against sorrow and toil.
  12: 
  13: From the fields in the mist came a bleating, a sound as of longing and need:
  14: But the lamb from the grass in its little green heaven never lifted its head:
  15: It was innocent, whiter than snow; it was glad in the flowers, took no heed;
  16: But the sound from the fields in the mist made me grieve as for one that is dead.
  17: 
  18: And behold! ’t was a dream I had dreamed, and a voice made me wake with a start,
  19: Saying: “Hark! once again in the flesh shall ye twain live your life for a span;
  20: But since whiteness of snow is as nought in mine eyes without pity of heart,
  21: Lo! the lamb shall be born as a wolf, with a wolf’s heart, but thou as a man!”


====================================================================================================

 225: 
 226: The Indian believes that if the “wekolis” or whippoorwill alights upon the roof of his cabin and sings its sweet plaintive song, it portends death to one of its inmates.
 227: 
 228: The o men is almost universally regarded in New England.
 229: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 230: The author recollects once hearing an elderly lady relate with singular pathos, an incident of the kind She was blest with a son of rare endowments and great piety.
 231: 
 232: In the absence of his father he was wont to minister at the family altar; and unlike the stern practices of the Pilgrims, from whose stock he was lineally descended, he prostrated himself in prayer in the lowliest humility.
 233: 
 234: It was touching to hear his clear low voice, and see his spiritual face while kneeling at this holy duty.
 235: 
 236: One quiet moonlight night while thus engaged, the mother's heart sank within her to hear the plaintive notes of the whippoorwill blending with the voice of prayer.
 237: 
 238: It sat upon the roof and continued its song long after the devotions had ceased.
 239: 
 240: The tears rushed to her eyes, and she embraced her son in a transport of grief.
 241: 
 242: She felt it must be ominous.
 243: 
 244: In one week he was borne away, and the daisies grew, and the birds sang over his grave.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  75: Though Agra does not boast the sanctity of Benares, Bindrabund, Hurdwar, and other celebrated scenes venerated by the Hindoos, it is held in very considerable estimation as being the reputed birth-place of Vishnu.
  76: 
  77: It is washed by the Jumna, a river not less sacred than the Ganges, and its population was never wholly converted to Mohammedism.
  78: 
  79: The city, if not originally erected by the Moghuls, was beautified.
  80: 
  81: and enlarged by them, and preferred by Acbar, Jehanguire, and Shah Jehan, to Delhi, the capital of the empire.
  82: 
  83: Though now falling into decay, it is still one of the best built native cities of Hindoostan.
  84: 
  85: The mosques and tombs in the fort, and the environs, are the wonders of the world; and in addition to these attractions, it possesses one deeply interesting to the European visitant, who finds at Agra the largest native community of Christians in all India.
  86: 
  87: "By fierce command, or threatening steel unquailed
  88: "The bigot zeal of Brahma's faith prevailed.
  89: 
  90: Notwithstanding the vast extent, and the frequency of the Moosulmaun conquests, and notwithstanding their intolerance of any religion save their own, the followers of Mohammed bear a very small proportion to the Hindoo community.
  91: 
  92: The victors offered the nations they subdued the alternative of conversion or death, and the repetition of the two first verses of the Koran was the sign of conversion; but even these proselytes can scarcely be termed true believers, since they still cling to many of the old superstitions, and frequently pay homage at heathen shrines.

  78: Notes upon the Ganges might be swelled with ease into a volume, so much is there to interest and delight in the history of this mighty river.
  79: 
  80: The brief record of some of its principal features, contained in the Poem, will suffice to conjure up a host of recollections in the hearts of those who have traversed its waste of waters, and they perchance lead others to make a more intimate acquaintance with a country which very unaccountably appears to have excited comparatively little attention.
  81: 
  82: "With the hoarse cry of desert birds, and the loud rush of wings.
  83: 
  84: When our vessel has been moored for the night in some lonely part of the Ganges, I have been frequently kept awake for several hours by the dissonant cries of the numberless birds which, long after sunset, made the banks of the river echo with their screams: and I can only compare the sound of rushing wings frequently heard in the evening, proceeding from flocks of wild fowl soaring in clouds above the head, to the sound of a mighty torrent.

#908: 139613_Indian Graves_Roberts, Emma_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Indian Graves
Author: Roberts, Emma
Prose starts at line: 145
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 36.9
Avg prose line length: 158.9

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 140: From Oriental Scenes, 1832
 141: There cannot be a stronger contrast than that between the burial-places of the Christian and the Moosulman in India.
 142: 
 143: A few of the former stand alone in picturesque spots, but they are generally crowded together in small enclosures of consecrated ground, not usually kept with the neatness and order which is so soothing to the spirits of the living.
 144: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 145: Few Europeans can view without horror the crowded but neglected cemetery in which they may expect to find a grave.
 146: 
 147: Choked up with weeds, the resort of carrion birds and loathsome beasts, and rarely visited, except upon those melancholy occasions in which another exile is deposited in his final resting-place, they present the most dismal memento mori imaginable.
 148: 
 149: Moosulman tombs, on the contrary, afford one of the most pleasing spectacles which India produces.
 150: 
 151: They are generally built in some well-frequented place, nor do the living object to make them their habitation.
 152: 
 153: "Dwellers amid the tombs" are to be found to this day in India, recalling to the memory many passages in the Scriptures.
 154: 
 155: When not sufficiently commodious to afford a shelter, they are still favourite spots for the bivouac of travellers.
 156: 
 157: Innumerable pictures might be made from the three objects so continually combined together in every part of India, a tree, a tomb, and a well.
 158: 
 159: The first and last may form the attraction; but they are seldom without a living group, who at least on one day in the week light a lamp upon the monumental stone, and strew it with flowers.
 160: 
 161: An officer of rank found the crumbling remnants of an old tomb in the close vicinity of a house he had lately purchased: it was an unsightly object; but knowing that, if he removed it, such an act of desecration would bring him into bad odour with his servants, he restored it to its pristine state.
 162: 
 163: The native attendants were delighted by the mark of respect paid to the deceased, and instantly performed their part by furnishing the tomb with a lamp.

 285: "Avenged in seas of blood, the deep disgrace,
 286: "Their nobler fathers had sustained of old.
 287: 
 288: The Jauts, a turbulent race, who have become much celebrated in later years, had not raised themselves to distinction during the period of the Moosulmaun conquests of Hindoostan.
 289: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 290: They were formidable enemies of the weak descendants of Aurungzebe, and wrested a large portion of his territory from the degenerate Emperors of Delhi.
 291: 
 292: Agra was taken from these people by the British forces under Lord Lake; and lately the conquest of Bhurtpore, (the capital of a petty native state, one of the numerous acquisitions of the Jauts, which was considered by them to be impregnable,) has reduced their pride still lower.
 293: 
 294: "Here is the blest reality, not even—"
 295: The scene from the Rambaugh must strike every stranger's eye with its resemblance to those bright creations of the pencil, which few can gaze upon without a wish to roam through landscapes of similar beauty.
 296: 
 297: The smooth sands of the Jumna, dotted with the slender snowy heron, and its gardens gleaming with light pavilions, and peopled with the brown and pink dove, the green pigeon, the blue jay, and myriads of smaller birds of glittering plumage, brought Danby's "Enchanted Island" to the author's memory.
 298: 
 299: At Arrah, in Behar, the resemblance to this favourite of the youthful fancy, was still more strong; for there, in the centre of a large tank, arose an island richly wooded, and literally swarming with water-fowl of the most.
 300: 
 301: brilliant white.
 302: 
 303: At Agra, all that is beautiful in nature or art appears in the most magnificent profusion.
 304: 
 305: The innumerable buildings of white marble of the most picturesque forms, rising in the midst of the richest luxuriance of flower and foliage which adorn the banks of a bright and rapid river, form altogether a scene of beauty which the magic of the painter has never surpassed.
 306: 
 307: The scenery round Agra has been beautifully delineated by Mr.
 308: 
 309: Daniell, whose views of Hindoostan afford a very accurate idea of the country, and are highly gratifying to those who have visited places illustrated by his master- hand.

  73: "The throne of Timur's heirs!"
  74: Note.
  75: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  76: - Amongst the objects of curiosity shown to the stranger, at Agra, are the fragments of a marble throne which belonged to the Mogul emperors.
  77: 
  78: When the weakness and degeneracy displayed by the successors of Aurungzebe invited foreign aggressions, the Jauts, a warlike people, obtained possession of a considerable territory, together with the city of Agra, the favourite residence of Acbar, Jehanghire, and of Shah Jehan they stripped the palace of its silver ceilings, and tore down the silver doors from the Taaje Mahal.
  79: 
  80: The leader of the invaders demanded to be brought to the marble musnud of the Moosulman conquerors, which no one else had ever ascended.
  81: 
  82: It is said, that on approaching, with an intent to seat himself upon it, the marble broke in two pieces; and the Moosulman inhabitants of Agra are fond of descanting upon the miracle which saved the throne of Acbar from profanation.
  83: 
  84: From Oriental Scenes, 1832
  85: The conquest of Agra by the Jauts has been aready mentioned: they respected the tombs of the Moosulmauns, and contented themselves with merely carrying off their silver doors; but their triumphs inflicted the severest mortification upon the proud Moghuls who had mocked the idolaters for so great a number of years, and planted the crescent on the prostrate shrines of their deities.

  95: The history of Rajasthan opens a wide field for the lovers of romance; its annals, whether ancient or modern, are fertile in striking incidents, and not the least interesting feature in these stirring records, is the influence permitted in former times, and still retained, though in a lesser degree, by the women.
  96: 
  97: Hindoo females were not secluded from society before the Moosulmaun's conquests: the practice was acquired from those jealous strangers, who, closely immuring their own women, treated those who were allowed greater freedom with indignity.
  98: 
  99: In the Mahratta states, however, they still enjoy perfect liberty; and throughout the central provinces have numerous privileges which give them great importance in the state.

  21: 
  22: But Stow may be left to tell us the rest of the sad story.
  23: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  24: The Protector '(as a good continent Prince, cleane and faultlesse of himselfe, sent out of heaven into the vicious world for the amendment of men's manners) hee caused the Bishop of London to put her to open penance, going before the Crosse in procession upon a Sunday with a taper in her hand.
  25: 
  26: In which she went, in countenance and pace demure, so womanly; and albeit she were out of all aray saue her Kirtle onely, yet went she so faire and louely, namely while the wondering of the people cast a comely red in her cheekes (of which shee before had most misse) that her great shame wanne her much praise, among those that were more amorous of her body then curious of her soule.
  27: 
  28: And many good folke also that hated her liuing, and were glad to see sinne corrected: yet pittied they more her penance then reioyced therein, when they considered that the Protector procured it more of a corrupt intent then any vertuous affection.
  29: 
  30: ' She was brought from the Bishop's Palace, clothed in a white sheet, with a Cross carried before her, and a wax taper in her hand.
  31: 
  32: ~ Chapters In the History of Old S.
  33: 
  34: Paul's, 1881.

  10:

  12:

  14: 
  15: I read of sunnier lands beyond the sea, And, dreaming, wander to a fairer clime, Recalled, too suddenly, by — ‘If you please, a dime!’

  65: P.
  66: 
  67: S.
  68: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  69: Among the number of scurrilities in the North Britons, there are also to be found a few very unlucky facts; and too true it is, that the freedom of this country, compared with that of its sister kingdom, will vanish into arbitrary petty tyranny.
  70: 
  71: Would an Englishman believe, that it was practicable for two engrossers to seize upon a Printer, and escort him under a strong military guard, from Leith to the city of Edinburgh, and then to have his papers burnt, merely because they spoke to the same purpose as does the word of God, and our acts of parliament, against engrossers and forestallers?
  72: 
  73: No!—Would he believe that a Scotsman may be starved to death, with money in his pocket; yea, many thousands of them; yet dare not for the souls of them complain upon those who retain all the victual in the country, till they have an exorbitant price, more than the labours of the people can afford! No.
  74: 
  75: —For God's love, let not these, and many other scandalous abuses of freedom, transpire to the ears of Mr.
  76: 
  77: Wilkes, or we must certainly be ashamed of the contempt, justly poured upon us for our pusillanimity.

   3: I sing this bodyad libitum, Europe scraped raw between my teeth until,presto, “Ave Maria” floats to the surface from a Tituba tributary of “Swanee.
   4: 
   5: ” Until I’m alegatodarkling whole note, my voice shimmering up from the Atlantic’s hold; until I’m a coda of sail song whipped in salted wind; until my chorus swells like a lynched tongue; until the nocturnes boiling beneath the roof of my mouth extinguish each burning cross.
   6: 
   7: I sing this life in testimony totempo rubato, to time stolen body by body by body by body from one passage to another; I sing tremolo to the opus of loss.
   8: 
   9: I sing this storystaccatoandstretto, a fugue of blackface and blued-up arias.
  10: 
  11: I sing with one hand smoldering in the steely canon, the otherlento, slow, languorous: lingered in the fields of “Babylon’s Falling” .

#919: 140444_Dedication_Carroll, Lewis_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Dedication
Author: Carroll, Lewis
Prose starts at line: 24
Lines to remove: 7
Avg verse line length: 35.2
Avg prose line length: 89.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  19: The heart-love of a child!
  20: Away, fond thoughts, and vex my soul no more!
  21: Work claims my wakeful nights, my busy days-
  22: Albeit bright memories of that sunlit shore
  23: Yet haunt my dreaming gaze!

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  24: This form is known as an Acrostic since the letters at the start of each line spell out a particular message in the case GERTRUDE CHATAWAY.
  25: 
  26: However Carroll shows his true skill since it is doubly labelled and the first word in each verse also forms the name GIRT RUDE CHAT AWAY.
  27: 
  28: This is not quite the right spelling but is phonetically correct.
  29: 
  30: (Thanks to Morag)


====================================================================================================

Title: Theme With Variations

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  27: I never nursed a dear gazelle,
  28: To glad me with its soft black eye,
  29: But when it came to know me well,
  30: And love me, it was sure to die!
  31: Lewis's satirical 'explanation' of this nonsense poem is as follows:

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  32: 'Why is it that Poetry has never yet been subjected to that process of Dilution which has proved so advantageous  to her sister-art Music?
  33: 
  34: The Diluter gives us first a few notes of some well-known Air, then a dozen bars of his own, then a few more notes of the Air, and so on alternately:  thus saving the listener, if not from all risk of recognizing the melody at all, at least from the too-exciting  transports which it might produce in more concentrated  form.
  35: 
  36: The process is termed "setting" by Composers, and any one, that has ever experienced the emotion of being unexpectedly  set down in a heap of mortar, will recognize the truthfulness  of this happy phrase.
  37: 
  38: For truly, just as the genuine Epicure lingers lovingly over a morsel of supreme Venison--whose every fibre seems to murmer "Excelsior!"--yet swallows, ere returning to the toothsome dainty, great mouthfuls of oatmeal-porridge and winkles: and just as the perfect Connoisseur in Claret permits himself but one delicate sip, and then tosses all a pint or more of boarding-school beer: so also----'

#925: 141063_The Hero Of The Drum_Bungay, George W_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Hero Of The Drum
Author: Bungay, George W
Prose starts at line: 56
Lines to remove: 17
Avg verse line length: 26.4
Avg prose line length: 98.7

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  51: Thought the drum could beat no more, made the dastard rebels run.
  52: 
  53: The dastard rebels run,
  54: Run, run, run.
  55: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  56: According to the Michigan Historical Center, Robert Henry Hendershot, known as "the Drummer Boy of the Rappahannock," served as a drummer boy for the Eighth Michigan.
  57: 
  58: [Robert's] regiment was stationed near the Seventh Michigan during the Battle of Fredericksburg, Virginia.
  59: 
  60: On December 11, 1862, the Seventh was trying to cross the Rappahannock River under fire.
  61: 
  62: Robert answered a call for volunteers and ran to help push the boats.
  63: 
  64: He had crossed the river when a shell fragment hit his drum and broke it into pieces, so he picked up a musket.
  65: 
  66: He encountered a Confederate soldier and, taking him as prisoner, brought him back to the Seventh Michigan.
  67: 
  68: The story of a boy capturing a man made him a hero.
  69: 
  70: Robert survived the war and toured the nation putting on drumming performances and telling of his experiences.
  71: 
  72: Many poems were written about him; "The Hero of the Drum" is one of those poems.

   9: Meaning:
  10: Drink the nectar of pure Nada, O Mind.
  11: 
  12: Sri Rama is the incarnation of Omkara, which is the essence of the Vedas and the Shastras.
  13:

  15: 
  16: The seven notes are the bells tied to the bow and the three styles, Ghana, Naya and Desya are the strings of the bow.
  17: 
  18: The gatis are the numerous arrows and the sangatis are his soft speech.
  19: 
  20: What is the good fortune of Tyagaraja to have got this gift from the Lord.

  47:

  22:

  24: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  25: Thy features are sunk and wan; they diminish to my troubled sight; yet they are a faint resemblance unto the charms of my beloved; and thy hair, which seems luminous, falls over thy shadowy form.
  26: 
  27: Sometimes thy features seem to waver--it must be in the twilight, when all has a dubious shade; but I cannot always catch those loved features--it appears to me as though they were fading wholly away; but suddenly, by an effort of the imagination, I again identify them, and secretly determine never more to look off of them.
  28: 
  29: How celestial dost thou appear, skimming over the tops of the hills.
  30: 
  31: A faint moonbeam catches thy robes of silvery mist.
  32: 
  33: I respire eagerly the bleak breeze that passes over thy dubious form; I inhale it with ardent, melancholy delight, for it is impregnated with thy spirit.
  34: 
  35: Soon will this heart of clay cease to beat; then will my soul too be free.
  36: 
  37: My body, which is of concentrated atoms, shall lie by thine in the narrow grave, which it will not deny me to share with it; and then together shall our spirits wander over the mountains, or re-visit the scenes of our youth.

  25: 
  26: ~ Acts 2:37 ~
  27: In this plight, therefore, he went home, and refrained himself as long as he could, that his wife and children should not perceive his distress; but he could not be silent long, because that his trouble increased: wherefore at length he brake his mind to his wife and children; and thus he began to talk to them: "O my dear wife," said he, "and you the children of my bowels, I, your dear friend, am in myself undone, by reason of a burden that lies hard upon me; moreover, I am for certain informed, that this our city will be burned with fire from heaven; in which fearful overthrow, both myself, with thee, my wife, and you my sweet babes, shall miserably come to ruin; except (the which yet I see not) some way of escape can be found, whereby we may be delivered.
  28: 
  29: " At this his relations were sore amazed; not for that they believed that what he had said to them was true, but because they thought that some frenzy distemper had got into his head; therefore, it drawing towards night, and they hoping that sleep might settle his brains, with all haste they got him to bed: but the night was as troublesome to him as the day; wherefore, instead of sleeping, he spent it in sighs and tears.
  30: 
  31: So, when the morning was come, they would know how he did: he told them, "Worse and worse.
  32: 
  33: " He also set to talking to them again; but they began to be hardened.
  34: 
  35: They also thought to drive away his distemper by harsh and surly conduct to him: sometimes they would deride; sometimes they would chide; and sometimes they would quite neglect him.
  36: 
  37: Wherefore he began to retire himself to his chamber, to pray for and pity them, and also to condole his own misery.
  38: 
  39: He would also walk solitarily in the fields, sometimes reading and sometimes praying; and thus for some days he spent his time.

   2: 
   3: For me, biography is a lantern, burning in the midst of parenthetical opaqueness.
   4: 
   5: In a sense, it is a ruse, a phantasmic meandering, brighter or dimmer, according to the ecletic happenstance of terror.
   6: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   7: Me, I’ve been sired in anomaly, in an imagery of brewing grenadine riddles, a parallel poesis spawned from curious seismographic molten.
   8: 
   9: I say curious, because the original stalking arc has disappeared into the wilderness of an a priori blizzard, which gives birth to a level, like a portal of fire conjoined with the lightning field of mystery.
  10: 
  11: I call it the poetic guardian dove, the hieratic alien wing.
  12: 
  13: It is the non-local field, the non-particle acid, flowing into my cognitive iodine rays, into the vicious fires of my tarantella marshes.
  14: 
  15: So I dance with vibration, with the solar arc spinning backward around the miraculous force of a double green horizon.
  16: 
  17: Simultaneously, I escape the territorial, while remaining within the burning loops of my own momentary seizures, guarded by ferns, legs plowing land, the face and the mind guided by stars.
  18: 
  19: So, I am a martyr of drills, of spates of specific lingual flooding, casting at times, a mist or a mirage, like a caravan of yaks, transporting tungsten and water.
  20: 
  21: Conversely, to give a graph of dates, to single out a bevy of personal social lesions, would invert me, would turn me around a diurnal bundle of glass, staggered, with a less than fiery temperature, partially nulling my sensitivity to falling phonemic peppers, to the inclination towards victory which burns in the dawn above heaven.
  22: 
  23: For me, this is the green locale, the pleroma of eternal solar essence, glinting, full of fabulous maelstrom diamonds, an empowered hegira of drift, of claustrophobic rainbow spectrums which empty themselves, and return to themselves, like having an image go out and return to itself, so that its power transmutes by the very energy of its looping; and I think of myself, the poet sending signals into mystery, and having them return to me with oneiric wings and spirals, so much so, that I forget my prosaic locale with its stultifying anchors, with its familial dotage and image reports, with its dates inscribed in trapezoidal feces.
  24: 
  25: I am only concerned with simultaneity and height, with rays of monomial kindling, guiding the neo-cortex through ravens, into the ecstasy of x-rays and blackness.
