#943: 142958_Sheltered Garden_D, H_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Sheltered Garden
Author: D, H
Prose starts at line: 11
Lines to remove: 15
Avg verse line length: 57.8
Avg prose line length: 149.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   6: 
   7: Every way ends, every road, every foot-path leads at last to the hill-crest— then you retrace your steps, or find the same slope on the other side, precipitate.
   8: 
   9: I have had enough— border-pinks, clove-pinks, wax-lilies, herbs, sweet-cress.
  10: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  11: O for some sharp swish of a branch— there is no scent of resin in this place, no taste of bark, of coarse weeds, aromatic, astringent— only border on border of scented pinks.
  12: 
  13: Have you seen fruit under cover that wanted light— pears wadded in cloth, protected from the frost, melons, almost ripe, smothered in straw?
  14: 
  15: Why not let the pears cling to the empty branch?
  16: 
  17: All your coaxing will only make a bitter fruit— let them cling, ripen of themselves, test their own worth, nipped, shrivelled by the frost, to fall at last but fair with a russet coat.
  18: 
  19: Or the melon— let it bleach yellow in the winter light, even tart to the taste— it is better to taste of frost— the exquisite frost— than of wadding and of dead grass.
  20: 
  21: For this beauty, beauty without strength, chokes out life.
  22: 
  23: I want wind to break, scatter these pink-stalks, snap off their spiced heads, fling them about with dead leaves— spread the paths with twigs, limbs broken off, trail great pine branches, hurled from some far wood right across the melon-patch, break pear and quince— leave half-trees, torn, twisted but showing the fight was valiant.
  24: 
  25: O to blot out this garden to forget, to find a new beauty in some terrible wind-tortured place.

   4:

   8:

  10:

  12: 
  13: Band of iris-flowers above the waves, you are painted blue, painted like a fresh prow stained among the salt weeds.

Title: Eurydice
Author: D, H
Prose starts at line: 19
Lines to remove: 11
Avg verse line length: 111.6
Avg prose line length: 426.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  14: 
  15: what was it you saw in my face?
  16: 
  17: the light of your own face, the fire of your own presence?
  18: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  19: What had my face to offer but reflex of the earth, hyacinth colour caught from the raw fissure in the rock where the light struck, and the colour of azure crocuses and the bright surface of gold crocuses and of the wind-flower, swift in its veins as lightning and as white.
  20: 
  21: III Saffron from the fringe of the earth, wild saffron that has bent over the sharp edge of earth, all the flowers that cut through the earth, all, all the flowers are lost; everything is lost, everything is crossed with black, black upon black and worse than black, this colourless light.
  22: 
  23: IV Fringe upon fringe of blue crocuses, crocuses, walled against blue of themselves, blue of that upper earth, blue of the depth upon depth of flowers, lost; flowers, if I could have taken once my breath of them, enough of them, more than earth, even than of the upper earth, had passed with me beneath the earth; if I could have caught up from the earth, the whole of the flowers of the earth, if once I could have breathed into myself the very golden crocuses and the red, and the very golden hearts of the first saffron, the whole of the golden mass, the whole of the great fragrance, I could have dared the loss.
  24: 
  25: V So for your arrogance and your ruthlessness I have lost the earth   and the flowers of the earth, and the live souls above the earth, and you who passed across the light and reached ruthless; you who have your own light, who are to yourself a presence, who need no presence; yet for all your arrogance and your glance, I tell you this: such loss is no loss, such terror, such coils and strands and pitfalls of blackness, such terror is no loss; hell is no worse than your earth above the earth, hell is no worse, no, nor your flowers nor your veins of light nor your presence, a loss; my hell is no worse than yours though you pass among the flowers and speak with the spirits above earth.
  26: 
  27: VI Against the black I have more fervour than you in all the splendour of that place, against the blackness and the stark grey I have more light; and the flowers, if I should tell you, you would turn from your own fit paths toward hell, turn again and glance back and I would sink into a place even more terrible than this.
  28: 
  29: VII At least I have the flowers of myself, and my thoughts, no god can take that; I have the fervour of myself for a presence and my own spirit for light; and my spirit with its loss knows this; though small against the black, small against the formless rocks, hell must break before I am lost; before I am lost, hell must open like a red rose for the dead to pass.

   1: Sea-Heroes
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]

   3: Crash on crash of the sea,straining to wreck men; sea-boards, continents,raging against the world, furious,stay at last, for against your furyand your mad fight,the line of heroes stands, godlike:Akroneos, Oknolos, Elatreus,helm-of-boat, loosener-of-helm, dweller-by-sea,Nauteus, sea-man,Prumneos, stern-of-ship,Agchilalos, sea-girt,Elatreus, oar-shaft:lover-of-the-sea, lover-of-the-sea-ebb,lover-of-the-swift-sea,Ponteus, Proreus, Oöos:Anabesneos, who breaks to angeras a wave to froth:Amphiolos, one caught between wave-shock and wave-shock:Eurualos, board sea-wrack,like Ares, man’s death,and Naubolidos, best in shape,of all first in size:Phaekous, sea’s thunderbolt—ah, crash on crash of great names—man-tamer, man’s-help, perfect Laodamos:and last the sons of great Alkinöos,Laodamos, Halios, and god-like Clytomeos.
   4: 
   5: Of all nations, of all cities,of all continents,she is favoured above the rest,for she gives men as great as the sea,to battle against the elements and evil:greater even than the sea,they live beyond wrack and death of cities,and each god-like name spokenis as a shrine in a godless place.
   6: 
   7: But to name you,we, reverent, are breathless,weak with pain and old loss,and exile and despair—our hearts break but to speakyour name, Oknaleos—and may we but call you in the feverish wrackof our storm-strewn beach, Eretmeos,our hurt is quiet and our hearts tamed,as the sea may yet be tamed,and we vow to float great ships,named for each hero,and oar-blades, cut of mountain-treesas such men might have shaped:Eretmeos, and the sea is swept,baffled by the lordly shape,Akroneos has pines for his ship’s keel;to love, to mate the sea?
   8: 
   9: Ah there is Ponteos,the very deep roar,hailing you dear—they clamour to Ponteos,and to Proëosleap, swift to kiss, to curl, to creep,lover to mistress.
  10: 
  11: What wave, what love, what foam,For Oöos who moves swift as the sea?
  12: 
  13: Ah stay, my heart, the weightof lovers, of lonelinessdrowns me,alas that their very namesso press to break my heartwith heart-sick weariness,what would they be,the very gods,rearing their mighty lengthbeside the unharvested sea?

#947: 143065_The Charge Of The Mule Brigade_Americas, Anonymous_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Charge Of The Mule Brigade
Author: Americas, Anonymous
Prose starts at line: 74
Lines to remove: 15
Avg verse line length: 30.8
Avg prose line length: 172.5

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  69: 
  70: On the evening of October 28, 1863, during the Chattanooga campaign, Confederate troops under the command of General James Longstreet attacked the Federal forces of General John W.
  71: 
  72: Geary.
  73: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  74: General Joseph Hooker had left Geary's troops to guard the road along which ran the "Cracker Line," the round-about route by which Union troops were forced to supply occupied Chattanooga.
  75: 
  76: Although the fighting was disorganized and confused, it raged until 4:00 the following morning and ended in Confederate failure to break the Cracker Line.
  77: 
  78: One of the more enduring and amusing stories to emerge from the Battle of Wauhatchie concerns a purported "charge" by a herd of Union mules, who broke loose from their skinners and dashed headlong into Confederate lines.
  79: 
  80: In his account of the engagement, which appears in Battles and Leaders, overall Union commander Ulysses S.
  81: 
  82: Grant claimed that Southern troops under General Evander Law mistook the runaway mules for a cavalry charge and fell back in confusion.
  83: 
  84: Mule As delightful as the anecdote may be, however, there is no real evidence that it ever happened, since Law's men had been driven back by Generals Hector Tyndale and Orland Smith long before the mules slipped their harnesses and began their precipitous flight towards freedom.
  85: 
  86: Nevertheless, the story spread quickly and was accepted as truthful; there was even talk of brevetting the mules as horses.
  87: 
  88: This poem, an obvious parody on Alfred Lord Tennyson's famous "Charge of the Light Brigade," was probably composed shortly after the incident and gained widespread circulation.

  18: 
  19: , 1995), attributes it to James Lewis, a Missouri Confederate who was held prisoner at the military prison in Alton, Illinois.
  20:

  22:

  24:

  26: 
  27: Louis, Missouri, "held, in addition to prisoners of war, Union army deserters, bounty jumpers, spies, bushwhackers, and disloyal citizens.
  28: 
  29: Originally a medical college, the building held around 500 with safety but usually 1,000 were confined there.
  30: 
  31: The inmates were a desperate and violent group, and the building was twice set on fire by them.
  32: 
  33: A number tried to escape by attacking the guards or tunneling under the walls.

#949: 143131_The Vulture (Parody of Poe's 'Raven')_Americas, Anonymous_unknown.txt

Title: The Vulture (Parody of Poe's "Raven")
Author: Americas, Anonymous
Prose starts at line: 129
Lines to remove: 7
Avg verse line length: 53.0
Avg prose line length: 130.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 124: And his smoke from out my curtains, and his stains from out my floor,
 125: Shall be sifted never more.
 126: 
 127: "The Vulture" is one of the earliest parodies of Edgar Allan Poe's "The Raven.
 128: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 129: " It appeared unsigned in the December 1853 issue of "Graham's Magazine," where many of Poe's original poems, short stories and articles were published.
 130: 
 131: Although the parody is uncredited, it shares a page with another poem by the noted American humorist John G.
 132: 
 133: Saxe, who may possibly have been the author of "The Vulture" as well.
 134: 
 135: In the poem, the "vulture" is a sponger or deadbeat who sets up residence in his friend's house and proceeds to terrify him in far more ingenious ways than Poe's raven did his reluctant host.

#951: 143184_The Red Zouave_Americas, Anonymous_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Red Zouave
Author: Americas, Anonymous
Prose starts at line: 134
Lines to remove: 15
Avg verse line length: 38.9
Avg prose line length: 206.6

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 129: " or the pass-word, "Duquesne.
 130: 
 131: Each spectre must give, as he passes this spot,
 132: The parole of dishonour, "MANASSAS and SCOTT.
 133: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 134: Although Virginia is justly famed for its Civil War battlefields, it also enjoys numerous associations with the nation's early colonial history.
 135: 
 136: The anonymous writer of this poem, which appeared in the November 1861 issue of The Southern Literary Messenger, seized upon an interesting coincidence connected with that history to take a backhanded swipe at General Winfield Scott, the first commander-in-chief of the Union Army.
 137: 
 138: The following note preceded the poem: "It is singular that Braddock and Scott should each have landed an army at the same port, invaded a country by the same road, fled from an enemy of inferior strength, and signalized themselves as the heroes of the two most complete and disastrous routs known to American history.
 139: 
 140: Edward Braddock (1695-1755) was a British general whose name is inextricably linked with the disastrous colonial loss at Fort Duquesne during the French and Indian War in 1755.
 141: 
 142: Despite being warned by staff officer George Washington that his Indian opponents preferred to attack from ambush, Braddock failed to take proper precautions and exposed his forces unnecessarily.
 143: 
 144: When the Indians opened fire from behind trees, only a few miles short of Fort Duquesne, Braddock lost more than half his troops and over three-quarters of his officers and was himself mortally wounded.
 145: 
 146: Washington led the survivors of the assault to safety.
 147: 
 148: Braddock's forces launched their campaign from the port city of Alexandria, as did Federal troops under Scott more than 100 years later in July 1861 when they followed a route similar to Braddock's on their way to a humiliating defeat at the hands of the Confederate Army at Manassas.


====================================================================================================
#952: 143268_The Copperheads_Americas, Anonymous_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Copperheads
Author: Americas, Anonymous
Prose starts at line: 55
Lines to remove: 7
Avg verse line length: 31.9
Avg prose line length: 131.5

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  50: 
  51: The Copperheads were Northern Democrats opposed to the Union's war policy.
  52: 
  53: They favoured a negotiated peace with the Confederate States Of America.
  54: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  55: United States President Abraham Lincoln assumed strong executive powers in suppressing them, including their arrests, suspension of the press, suspension of habeas corpus, and censorship.
  56: 
  57: Copperhead organisations included the Knights of the Golden Circle, Order of American Knights, and Sons of Liberty.
  58: 
  59: The main strongholds of the Copperhead movement were in Ohio, Illinios, and Indiana.
  60: 
  61: " As this poem expresses rather dramatically, the Copperheads were looked on by Northerners as traitors, cowards, and Southern sympathisers.

  63: F 1737

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  64: Habib Najjar (carpenter) is a legendary character who gave his name to a shrine below mount Silpuis at Antakiya.
  65: 
  66: Though not mentioned by name in the Qu'ran (36: 12ff), Muslim tradition finds him there under the description of a man who was put to death in a village for urging the villagers not to reject the three apostles who had come with the divine message.
  67: 
  68: Some scholars have suggested that Habib is the Agabus of Acts, II: 28, but there is not enough evidence to substantiate this suggestion.
  69: 
  70: Cf G.
  71: 
  72: Vajda's article in E.
  73: 
  74: I.


====================================================================================================
#955: 143538_Masnawi_Rumi, Mewlana Jalaluddin_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Masnawi
Author: Rumi, Mewlana Jalaluddin
Prose starts at line: 269
Lines to remove: 13
Avg verse line length: 87.7
Avg prose line length: 137.7

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 264: 
 265: The present then depends on what one requested while asleep.
 266: 
 267: God teaches in every way.
 268: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 269: A thief hanged on the gallows is an object lesson as is the person whom the king gives a robe of honor; but you should consider the difference between those two preachers.
 270: 
 271: Even suffering is a divine grace, and hell becomes a place of worship as souls turn back to God just as being in prison or suffering pain often urges one to pray for relief.
 272: 
 273: Yet after people are released or healed, they often forget to seek God.
 274: 
 275: Believers, however, do not need to suffer, because even in ease they are mindful that suffering is constantly present.
 276: 
 277: An intelligent child that has been punished does not forget the punishment; but the stupid child forgets it and is punished again.
 278: 
 279: The wickedness and vice of humans can be great, because they are what veil the better element, which is also great.
 280: 
 281: These veils cannot be removed without great striving, and Rumi recommended that the best method is to mingle with friends who have turned their backs to the world and their faces to God.


====================================================================================================
#956: 144178_The Mystery_Glangel, Amergin_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Mystery
Author: Glangel, Amergin
Prose starts at line: 27
Lines to remove: 7
Avg verse line length: 36.7
Avg prose line length: 148.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  22: 
  23: (If not I)
  24: This poem is ascribed to Amergin, a Milesian prince or druid who settled in Ireland hundreds of years before Christ
  25: and is from the Leabhar Gabhala, or Book of Invasions.
  26: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  27: "The three short pieces of verse ascribed to Amergin are certainly very ancient and very strange.
  28: 
  29: But as the whole story of the Milesian Invasion is wrapped in mystery and is quite possibly a rationalized account of early Irish mythology no faith can be placed in the alleged date or genuineness of Amergin's verses.
  30: 
  31: They are of interest, because as Irish tradition has them as being the first verses made in Ireland, so it may very well be they actually do present the oldest surviving lines of any vernacular tongue in Europe except Greece.
  32: 
  33: " by Douglas Hyde, The Story of Early Gaelic Literature

   4: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   5: Assis sur un rocher ou sous un parasol rouge, allongés dans le pré bourdonnant d'insectes, les deux mains sous la nuque, agenouillés dans la fraîcheur et l'obscurité d'une église, ou tassés sur une chaise de paille entre les quatre murs de la chambre, tête basse, les yeux fixés sur un rectangle de papier blanc, nous rêvons à des estuaires, des tumultes, des ressacs, des embellies et des marées.
   6: 
   7: Nous écoutons monter en nous le chant inépuisable de la mer qui dans nos têtes afflue puis se retire, comme revient puis s'éloigne le curieux désir que nous avons du ciel, de l'amour, et de tout ce que nous ne pourrons jamais toucher des mains.
   8: 
   9: •La mer en nous essaie des phrases.
  10: 
  11: Depuis des lustres, la même voix épelle le même alphabet dans le même cerveau d'enfant.
  12: 
  13: Elle balbutie des mots vite envolés, accrochés aux herbes des plages, à la peau brunie des baigneurs, à la proue des barques, aux mâtures.
  14: 
  15: Des mots quelconques, pour rien et pour quiconque.
  16: 
  17: Il n'y est question que de l'amour.
  18: 
  19: C'est pourquoi nous ne savons trop que dire et souffrons que le regard d'autrui s'attarde sur notre visage quand nous voudrions qu'il se pose à même notre cœur.
  20: 
  21: Nos lèvres sont si maladroites, notre corps invisible dans la nuit opaque, et nos mains mal-habiles, des éclairs ou des ailes pourtant au bout des doigts.
  22: 
  23: fromA Story of Blue

#958: 144362_Corporal Schnapps_Work, Henry Clay_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Corporal Schnapps
Author: Work, Henry Clay
Prose starts at line: 64
Lines to remove: 7
Avg verse line length: 31.6
Avg prose line length: 165.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  59: Vill schmile no more on me;
  60: Put schtill I fights de pattles of te flag
  61: To set mine countries free.
  62: 
  63: CHORUS

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  64: Along with the blacks and the Irish, the Germans were fair game for the pens of songwriters during the War Between the States.
  65: 
  66: Written in dialect, "Corporal Schnapps" pokes fun at a German emigrant who enlists in the Union Army at the urging of his sweetheart, only to have her run off with another man and return to Germany as soon as he's gone.
  67: 
  68: Despite his heartache, however, Corporal Schnapps is loyal to his new homeland and stays at his post, determined to fight "de pattles of te flag.
  69: 
  70: Although ethnic parodies of this kind would not be tolerated in today's society, they were commonplace during the War and were considered acceptable as public entertainment.


====================================================================================================

   1: Mary
   2: 
   3: My mother is obsessed with reading about Jesus these days.
   4: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   5: I see books piled by her bed, most of them borrowed from my library: novels, handbooks, sectarian polemics, writers coming to blows.
   6: 
   7: Sometimes when I’m passing by her room she calls on me to step between them and resolve their disputes.
   8: 
   9: (A little while ago I came to the aid of a historian called Kamal Salibi, whose forehead had been split open by a Catholic stone.
  10: 
  11: What a diligent reader she is when she’s searching for Jesus, this woman I never failed to disappoint: I was not martyred in the first intifada, nor in the second, nor in the third.
  12: 
  13: And just between you and me, I won’t be martyred in any future intifada either, nor will  I be killed by some booby-trapped stork.
  14: 
  15: As she reads, her orthodox imagination crucifies me with every page.
  16: 
  17: 
  18: while I do nothing but supply it with more books and nails.

#960: 144559_After after_Popsickle, Pinka_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: After after
Author: Popsickle, Pinka
Prose starts at line: 5
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 86.0
Avg prose line length: 140.1

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: After after
   2: 
   3: After the monsoon high noon sun was sliced thinly in unequal measure, the bread buttered, the harvest husked, and the earth split between dharti1and za(jo)meen2;
   4: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   5: and after new nations plucked old tongues from the same branch of the old vad3tree, disregarded the chatter of its many djinns as birdsong, and straightened its hanging roots into rulings and borders in courts and school notebook pages;
   6: 
   7: and after history was freshly re-inked in jamun juice on familiar roads that spaghettied endlessly, having lost their way and their voice along with their names of dead emperors—because to name is to remember and to write is to record;
   8: 
   9: and after the farmer hurled insults at the government, hulled his tamarind, hailed the rain gods, and हलed4away at broken soil and system because to him हल was solution to everything;
  10: 
  11: and after I learnt—to ride a bike, kiss a boy, break open poems and pain like a pomegranate spilling secrets, jewels and blue bloodstains—and that elections were fought with gulmohar stamens regardless of whom you voted for;
  12: 
  13: and after our fiery spirits kept us alive through the winter, wanting to burn it all to the ground until they burnt down our homes and our faith and our 'friends' choked the hosepipe with their foot;
  14: 
  15: after it all turns to shit or ashes—whichever comes first; after debilitated is the new disabled and we are possibly all branded as mad; after all the spoons in the land are smelted into armour made to able-bodied measure leaving us to rage like we love—naked—breasts exposed immodestly;
  16: 
  17: after I-love-you and I-care-for-you do not mean the same thing because they are exhausting—so exhausting that they can no longer be done simultaneously, and we have exhausted exhaustion…
  18: 
  19: Then,
  20: friend,
  21: meet me at the intersection—
  22: we will rest in the debris and marvel at the glorious blaze we be—
  23: failures united, ignited.

#962: 144617_Hearts Of Oak_Garrick, David_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Hearts Of Oak
Author: Garrick, David
Prose starts at line: 40
Lines to remove: 11
Avg verse line length: 46.0
Avg prose line length: 92.3

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  35: 
  36: Heart of oak are our ships, jolly tars are our men,
  37: we always are ready; Steady, boys, steady!
  38: We'll fight and we'll conquer again and again.
  39: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  40: This was written primarily as a music-hall song and was sold as a 'broad-side' to encourage men to enlist in the navy.
  41: 
  42: The wonderful year mentioned in the first verse is 1759, during which British forces were victorious in several battles.
  43: 
  44: On land at Fort Ticonderoga and Fort Niagra, and the plains of Abraham.
  45: 
  46: At sea at the Battle of Lagos and Pondicherry and most decisively at Quiberon Bay.
  47: 
  48: The 'flat-bottoms' are not some anatomical oddity but the name given to large, barge like, vessels which were used to transport troops for a water born invasion.
  49: 
  50: JS

#963: 144627_Labile_Basinski, Michael_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Labile
Author: Basinski, Michael
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 11
Avg verse line length: 6.0
Avg prose line length: 92.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Labile
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: Michael Basinski creates visual poems that are colorful cacophonies of text and shape.
   4: 
   5: His handwritten poems, which often serve as scores for equally exuberant sound poems, are filled to the margin with broken lines of text that curl into one another, read from different directions, and are often filled with nonsense words of his own invention.
   6: 
   7: "Labile" is a good example of a visual poem that defiantly spurns convention.
   8: 
   9: It is a neo-Dadaist poem intent on shaking the reader out of quiet acceptance and somnolence.
  10: 
  11: —Geof Huth
  12: 
  13: More About Visual Poetry >>

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Silver Roses
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: The strings, as if they knewthe lovers are about to meet, beginto soar, and when he marches in the doorthey soar some more—half ecstasy, half pain,the musical equivalent of rain—while children who have grown up with one staresteal further looks across a crowded room,as goners tend to do.
   4: 
   5: My father loved it too,warned me at dinner that he’d be a wrecklong before the final trio came(Ja, ja, she sighed, and gave him up forever);he found his Sophie better late than neverand took the fifth about his silent tearsbut like him I’m a softie, with a massivegift for feeling blue.
   6: 
   7: I went with others, threwbouquets and caution to the whirling wind,believing that the rhapsody on stagewould waft its wonders up to our cheap seats;but mirrors can be beautiful fierce cheats,delusions of an over-smitten mind;I relished trouser roles until I hadno petals left to strew.
   8: 
   9: Up, down the avenueI wandered like a ghost, I wondered whya miracle is always a mirage,then plodded home and set back all the clocks,spent hard-won funds installing strong new locks,telling myself if violence like thiscould never sound like violins, I wouldto art, not life, be true.
  10: 
  11: And I am trying tofathom the way I got from there to here,the joy that snuck up when I’d sworn off joy:we’ve made a sterling start, we’ve got a planto watch it on your satin couch downtownand I’ll be there upon the stroke of eight,bearing in my trembling ungloved handa silver rose for you.

#970: 146528_Macquarie Harbour_Ingamells, Rex_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Macquarie Harbour
Author: Ingamells, Rex
Prose starts at line: 27
Lines to remove: 9
Avg verse line length: 30.3
Avg prose line length: 111.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  22: bleak ranges; then the moonlight spills
  23: broad arrows on their backs.
  24: 
  25: This poem was written by Rex Ingamells folowing a trip to Tasmania.
  26: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  27: Once known as Van Diemans's Land, (Demon's Land by the prisoners who were transorted there) Macquarie Harbour is on the East coast where from approx.
  28: 
  29: 1820 to 1833 Sarah Island had the reputation of being the most foul Penal settlement.
  30: 
  31: it was a camp intended to subdue those men who had previously attempted escape from other settlements, or, who had committed crimes as prisoners.
  32: 
  33: There was no escape from Sarah Island.
  34: 
  35: Even if the prisoner reached the mainland he either died from starvation and exposure or was caught and received the customary 100 lashes.

#973: 146749_The Oil Of Mercy_Trench, Richard Chenebix_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Oil Of Mercy
Author: Trench, Richard Chenebix
Prose starts at line: 167
Lines to remove: 11
Avg verse line length: 32.5
Avg prose line length: 288.3

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 162: 
 163: In the "Recognitions" of Clement, 1.
 164: 
 165: 1, c.
 166: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 167: 45, an Ebionite book, and therefore only acknowledging the humanity of Christ, he is, consistently with this view, said, not himself to anoint, but to have been anointed with the oil from the Tree of Life.
 168: 
 169: The connexion between the Tree of Life and the Cross of Christ has been twice wrought up into sublime dramatic poems by Calderon; once in his Auto, entitled "El Arbor del mejor Fruto;" and again in that which is indeed only the same poem in a later and more perfect form, "La Sibila del Oriente.
 170: 
 171: " We have the same tradition of Seth going to the gates of Paradise in the fine old Cornish Mystery of "The Creation of the World," which was lately published with an English translation; and allusions to it are frequent in all the popular literature of the Middle Ages; see, for instance, Göthe's recension of the "Reineke Fuchs," near the beginning of the tenth book; and I remember a curious passage about it in Mandeville's "Travels.
 172: 
 173: " Rückert, in the following poem, has given the tradition in somewhat a different shape.
 174: 
 175: I may just observe that this poem is an attempt--I will confess a most unsuccessful one--to write English verse in the Spanish assonant rhyme, of which the principle is, that words are considered to rhyme which have the same vowel-sounds, though the consonants are different: thus, angel and raiment having the same vowel-sounds, a--e, are perfect assonant rhymes.
 176: 
 177: As in the Persian Ghazel, there is but one rhyme running through the whole poem, and in this all the alternate lines, beginning with the second, terminate: and of course the rhythmical effect of the poem is to be judged, not by any half-dozen lines apart, but by the total impression which the whole Poem continuously read leaves on the ear.


====================================================================================================
#974: 146753_Alexander At The Gates of Paradise. A Legend From The Talmud_Trench, Richard Chenebix_unknown.txt

 137: 
 138: ii.
 139: 
 140: p.
 141: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 142: 321, with whom I trust that my readers will not agree, for he has scarcely patience to finish this "narrische Talmudische Fabel," as he styles it.
 143: 
 144: It reappears, slightly modified, in the Persian tradition, according to which Alexander, having conquered the world, determined to seek out the fountain of life.
 145: 
 146: 
 147: In like manner, in the Christian poems of the middle ages, Alexander is made to recognise at last the vanity and emptiness of all the glory which he has won, and is hardly turned from his purpose of going forth at last in search of the lost Paradise.
 148: 
 149: See Rosenkranz "Gesch.
 150: 
 151: d.
 152: 
 153: Deutschen Poesie in Mittelalter," p.
 154: 
 155: 367.
 156: 
 157: Very notable is this making of Alexander, and no other -- the man from whom the confession comes, that the world has not that which can truly satisfy man's spirit, but that he still yearns for something beyond.
 158: 
 159: It is like, in the Scripture, the same confession coming from the lips of Solomon; for in each case the experiment has been made under the most favourable circumstances: so that in one case, as in the other, it may be asked, "What can the man do that cometh after the king?

#975: 146754_Chidher's Well_Trench, Richard Chenebix_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Chidher's Well
Author: Trench, Richard Chenebix
Prose starts at line: 91
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 23.0
Avg prose line length: 216.9

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  86: Of Chidher's Well,.
  87: 
  88: 
  89: Von Hammer, in his very interesting introduction to his "History of Persian Poetry," gives a good account.
  90: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  91: Among other things he says, "Contemporary with Moses lived the Prophet Chiser, of whom some hold that he is the same with Elias, while others altogether distinguish them.
  92: 
  93: He is one of the chief personages of Eastern Mythology, the ever-ready helper of the oppressed, the Genius of spring, the deliverer in peril, the admonisher of princes, the avenger of unrighteousness, the guide through the wilderness of the world, and, finally, the ever-youthful guardian of the fountain of life.
  94: 
  95: As such he revives the youth of men, and beasts, and plants, gives back lost beauty, and in spring arrays the dead earth with its fresh garments of green.
  96: 
  97: His fountain bestows on whosoever drinks it eternal beauty, youth, and wisdom.
  98: 
  99: What wonder then that all mortals with burning desire seek it, though as yet not one, not even Alexander, the conqueror of the world, who, in quest of it, undertook an expedition into the land of darkness, has found it!" Probably this, his journey through the land of darkness, is but a mythic form of his expedition through the Libyan desert to the temple of Jupiter Ammon.
 100: 
 101: On this poem I may observe, that it is the first of several in the volume written with an arrangement of rhyme hardly familiar to the English reader, which yet is that of a great part, as I believe, of the lyric poetry of the East, and which may not, perhaps, be unworthy of a place among us.
 102: 
 103: According to the laws of the Ghazel,--for poems in this metre are so entitled,--the two first lines must rhyme, and then this rhyme repeats itself in the second line of each succeeding couplet, which is, in fact, a new stanza, till the end of the poem,--the termination of the first line in each these following couplets being left free.
 104: 
 105: This single rule of the one repeated rhyme being observed, the Ghazel admits otherwise of the greatest possible variety; it may be composed, as is this present, in short trochaics, in longer or shorter iambics, or, in fact, in lines of whatsoever length or arrangement of syllables the poet will.
 106: 
 107: In Germany, the Ghazel has been perfectly domesticated.
 108: 
 109: Rückert and Count Platen are, I believe, considered to have cultivated it with the greatest success.


====================================================================================================
#976: 146760_The Pantheist; or, The Origin Of Evil_Trench, Richard Chenebix_unknown.txt

Author: Trench, Richard Chenebix
Prose starts at line: 65

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  60: Nor ask I now who open left the well,
  61: Whereinto, walking carelessly, I fell;
  62: Not how I stumbled in the well, but how
  63: I may get out, is all my question now.
  64: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  65: The doctrine of evil as not indeed evil, but only an inferior kind of good, to which the Pantheist is of necessity driven, is wrought out with great skill and frequency by the Eastern Mystics--often comes out in their writings in its most offensive shapes.
  66: 
  67: It is curious to notice how completely they have anticipated this view, which continually reappears in the philosophical systems of our own day, and is in them brought forward as some mighty discovery, as a key to all the perplexities of the actual world.
  68: 
  69: See Tholuck's "Ssufismus," p.
  70: 
  71: 255, seq.
  72: 
  73: , and ""Blüthensammlung aus der Morgenländischen Mystik," pp.
  74: 
  75: 133, 145.

#978: 146789_The Eastern Narcissus_Trench, Richard Chenebix_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Eastern Narcissus
Author: Trench, Richard Chenebix
Prose starts at line: 39
Lines to remove: 15
Avg verse line length: 41.7
Avg prose line length: 135.5

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  34: And didst plunge headlong in without a care.
  35: 
  36: Oh happy! if thou struggle back to-day,
  37: Ere the strong whirlpool drags thee down for aye.
  38: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  39: In the attempt made by the Neo-Platonists to put a new life into the old Grecian Mythology, Narcissus falling in love with his own image in the water-brook was made the symbol of man casting himself forth into the world of shows and appearances, and expecting to find the good that would answer to his nature there, but indeed finding nothing but disappointment and death.
  40: 
  41: --  The fable is Feridoddin Attar's, who, born in 1216, perished in the invasion of Dschengischan at the beginning of the next century.
  42: 
  43: The account of the manner in which he was converted to the life of contemplative piety is remarkable.
  44: 
  45: He was originally a rich merchant of spices.
  46: 
  47: A pious dervisch entered his warehouse and craved an alms.
  48: 
  49: Ferid bade him to be gone.
  50: 
  51: The dervisch answered, "That can I do easily, for I possess nothing save my hood; but thou, with so many heavy sacks, how wilt thou contrive to be gone when the hour of thy departure has arrived?
  52: 
  53: " These words made so deep an impression on Ferid, that, from that moment, he gave up his worldly strivings, and dedicated himself to the spiritual life.

 271: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 272: This poem was first suggested by some words in the "Sirenes, sive Voluptas," in Lord Bacon's "Sapientia Veterum.
 273: 
 274: " [Orpheus] "laudes Deorum cantans et reboans, Sirenum voces confudit et summovit: meditationes enim rerum divinarum voluptates sensûs non tantum potestate, sed etiam suavitate superant.
 275: 
 276: "  According to the author of the "Orphic Argonautics," the song of Orpheus ended the enchantment of the Sirens, and caused them to fling themselves into the sea, where they were changed into rocks.
 277: 
 278: Lord Bacon gives finely the meaning of the shore white with bones (stanza xix.
 279: 
 280: ), which yet were unable to deter others from approaching;--how it teaches us "exempla calamitatum, licet clara et conspicua, contra voluptatum corruptelas non multum proficere.
 281: 
 282: The classical reader will at once recognise, in more than one passage, my obligations to Pindar.

  33: 
  34: The bay was then named after the wrecked ship.
  35: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  36: It became a place of shelter for coastal shipping and prison labour was brought in to enlarge the area with a breakwater.
  37: 
  38: Work began on the construction of a prison, the first wing completed in 1879 but the first prisoners did not move in until 1886.
  39: 
  40: The prison was closed in 1903 but re-opened during the 1914-1918 war.
  41: 
  42: Over 500 German prisoners of war were held there but the building was once again closed after WW1.
  43: 
  44: Many years later due to the ravages of war and vandals the ruin is but a shell of it's former self but the atmosphere within the remaining walls is tangible.
  45: 
  46: ~Von~

  25: With all their works, found in his mastering art
  26: Speech as of powers whose uttered word laid bare
  27: The world's great heart.
  28: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]

  29: From the depths of the sea, from the wellsprings of earth, from the wastes of the midmost night,
  30: From the fountains of darkness and tempest and thunder, from heights where the soul would be,
  31: The spell of the mage of music evoked their sense, as an unknown light
  32: From the depths of the sea.
  33: 
  34: As a vision of heaven from the hollows of ocean, that none but a god might see,
  35: Rose out of the silence of things unknown of a presence, a form, a might,
  36: And we heard as a prophet that hears God's message against him, and may not flee.
  37: 
  38: Eye might not endure it, but ear and heart with a rapture of dark delight,
  39: With a terror and wonder whose core was joy, and a passion of thought set free,
  40: Felt inly the rising of doom divine as a sundawn risen to sight
  41: From the depths of the sea.

  26: 
  27: Then, there was no weather.
  28: 
  29: I can’t tell you how perfect that was.
  30: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  31: As it happens I had been gazing up at the dusk stars, as I can be found doing more or less day and night, for I like to think they are growing younger as I die, come by some time and tell me what you think.
  32: 
  33: Under torture—some atrocious form of tickling, for example—I guess I’d describe myself as a fairly good egg in hot water.
  34: 
  35: Family motto roughly translates,April wizards bring May blizzards.
  36: 
  37: We tend to be apprehended eventually, after a futile but all the more spirited attempt at first degree self-impersonation; however, this is not the time for levity, we happen to be speaking of a serious medical goodnight kiss.
  38: 
  39: Traditionally, we are then detained at a local mental facility known for its celebrated alumni, though in recent decades secret and permanent socialist elements in the government have seen to it that the lowest scum of humanity now appear to have open access to those once hallowed halls smeared withourshit and vomit.
  40: 
  41: What I’m getting at is this: after a relatively brief stay, we are invariably released with some deranged doctor’s or other’s blessing, a mixture of relief and disgust on the part of the staff, and the secret eye-signal that will get you into any movie house in Milwaukee free for the next year.
  42: 
  43: Some of us like to get together once a day, rain or shine, and gather furtively at the picnic grounds under those tall wavering candleflame pines, where neither moth nor rust can reach, nor faintest scream, and exchange ribald tales verging on satanic perversion, each drawing his iridescent injection from the same oceanic martini, very dry, about two tears’ worth of vermouth, in an unremembered dream.

  18: 
  19: He could be forgiven.
  20: 
  21: The blizzard I visit your city disguised as will never be over and never arrive.
  22: 
  23: I think what he was trying to say was that at some point I’d begin to notice I was freezing, wasn’t dressed right, had nowhere to go, and was staggering into a blinding snow that no one else could see.
  24: 
  25: I think he meant, the cold will make you what I am today.

  16: 
  17: It’s not going to happen overnight.
  18:

  20: 
  21: The elderly father, strictly speaking, of never really having been there.
  22: 
  23: I will sit down and eat my bowl of dust like all the rest.

#985: 147122_Bees of Eleusis_Wright, Franz_unknown.txt

Author: Wright, Franz
Prose starts at line: 9

Avg prose line length: 149.6

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   4: 
   5: These stored forms of light taken under the ground.
   6: 
   7: Taken by mouth.
   8: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   9: First those who by birth hold in secret the word; then placed on the tongues of the new ones, into whose ears it is meant to be whispered.
  10: 
  11: Word murdered, forgotten so long ago, placed as a kiss on the lips of the soon-to-be-no-longer breathing who mean to enter death with open eyes, with mouths saying Death, what death?
  12: 
  13: We have no word for it in our country where the bride of a brighter oblivion reigns.
  14: 
  15: Not the purple-haired god but the child queen, the raped girl, come back from the dead hand in hand with the child she conceived there, returned in a resurrected virginity, wind through green wheat.
  16: 
  17: Present-day site of a minor refinery in Christ.
  18: 
  19: Although by the tenth generation already the children of light (“in their dark garments”) had trampled and smashed and generally raped the two thousand years of this precinct and its holy meal, intolerable mirror.
  20: 
  21: Men who’d designed and bowed down to a law derived from the sayings of one who appeared here to say that the law is abolished, it is too late, all that is over with.
  22: 
  23: Men who bungled their way through the next eighteen centuries before finally descending into the earth themselves, and what they found there they used, and we thank you for destroying the destroyers of the world.
  24: 
  25: And here at the end this is as good as any other entrance to the underplace, journey of the fallen leaf back to the branch, to the bees of Eleusis among olive blossoms, untroubled among crimson wildflowers.
  26: 
  27: Four thousand years later: same flowers, same bees.

   6: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

   8:

  10: 
  11: She tosses her head to and fro to pull herself together for the wait.
  12: 
  13: From her dream she is frightened by the quarrelling and often by the coarse laughter out of the inn.
  14: 
  15: She takes a step, ready for the journey.
  16: 
  17: Then she imagines sleepily that she is on the way home, and hangs on to herself from sleepiness, once again the cab seats rattle.

  55: Burning leaven.
  56: 
  57: Head ringing with psilocybin and gin, I kneel in the foregroundof my own life quarter-sized, self-consciously humbled,like the donor in Altdorfer’s Crucifixion peering throughthe shadow of the cross to the city emptied of day laborersthat rides at ease in the sun, bay deliciously windswept,the curdled blue of high summer fadingout beyond the spruce where she stands in her living robes —and still I cannot comprehend how incidental we areto our own redemption, though the sacrifice remains intimatein violence, the half-accepting flinch of the faceas if breasting the parapet or tensed into the impactof a tube train, the rapt mother in the privacy of her distress.
  58: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  59: Here is the gate of horn, the hacked boughof ash that even dying shivers forth gaily its barrowloads of leaves.
  60: 
  61: jack clemo Let there be a chamber wherein no other light comes Not that I forget, but that, increasingly, the objects of my memorybecome ripe for disparagement: irrational or petit bourgeois,complicit in imperial power, conjurors of airslapped down by wolfish lecturers with gestures of ennui,pared nails and implacable smiles, vicious with piety.
  62: 
  63: Little traitor, I defend them with a wounded stare and no more —perhaps, I find my place among them, being so cold and all.
  64: 
  65: Bone-white pits of china clay gouged throughthat vision, the extravagant gaze of grace balanced upon us,its soteriology divorced from nature — something terrifyingin declaration, his unforgiving line like being hunted.
  66: 
  67: From the steeply-banked clay tips new dumps of refuse clatterto extend the protectorate of sand, sparse pricklesof mica like fields in snow — above all, the dogma never thaws.
  68: 
  69: And nothing.
  70: 
  71: The day we climbed slowly out of Antequerathrough the cloud base stippled in dew, the lightly slung bluebells of nazarenes blazed between karst and darkness,wild rose and orchid, the unaccountable blood of the peonyaching toward a sound that was both forsakenness and longing —wolves baying somewhere deep in the park —and I turned to you and wanted to know what next?
  72: 
  73: Lost, we turned and turned and turned about among the stacks.
  74: 
  75: Wings drilling the invisible host from cover to coveralerted us, the cramped and sullen thorns in anguish loomed.
  76: 
  77: Until, picking our way down a gully deepening into spate,the fog whitened, glared alarmingly, then lifted in one sweepfrom the sheer drop-off of the cliff — we sawas if through glass the road receding among gray rocks | the citadel.

  82: 
  83: Weeks later we learned that one of my classmates, a robust girl who shot baskets as well as any boy, had succumbed to the illness and died.
  84: 
  85: That night, my mother placed her hand on my forehead–her smooth palm, her touch, gentle–and said to my barely awake dad, “Our daughter has a raging fever.
  86: 
  87: ” Like a miracle, I was still her child.
  88: 
  89: Comforted, I slept.

  11: D.

  14:

  15: was on a walk on the 13th of April, 1830, apparently in Maidstone - later in his letter there is a spectacular drawing with the caption "Boxley, Kent.
  16: 
  17: "  Before this poem he describes the scenery in prose, "The prominent lights became, all at once, powdered with gold; and the whole tree assumed the appearance of a delicate piece of fret-work, compounded of glass and fire.
  18: 
  19: This feature in the landscape is one of the principal characteristics of spring; and were I required to describe that delightful season, in a single line, I do not think it could be done more satisfactorily than in the words of Cowper,-- 'Shadow of sunshine, intermingling quick' --  So quickly, indeed, that I have been almost tempted, more than once, to exchange that powerful term, 'sun-bursts,' for the more equivocal compound, 'sun-shot.
  20: 
  21: ' The effect of these momentary gleams, I have attempted to convey some idea of, in the lines which follow.

#993: 148202_Flitton_A, D_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Flitton
Author: A, D
Prose starts at line: 195
Lines to remove: 15
Avg verse line length: 28.4
Avg prose line length: 97.9

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 190: 
 191: The distinguished and amiable, but ill-fated lady Jane, came of this stock.
 192: 
 193: The Columbarium of the Greys is entered from the nave.
 194: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 195: It consists of four apartments in the form of a cross, the chancel-end of the church occupying the angle formed by its south and west arms.
 196: 
 197: 'Where, o'er the Founder's grave,': This was Henry, earl of Kent, who built the first room in 1605.
 198: 
 199: He married Mary, daughter of Sir John Cotton; and their effigies, splendidly habited and crowned, lie directly fronting the gates above mentioned.
 200: 
 201: The other apartments were subsequently erected.
 202: 
 203: 'Was ruffled with the cells of those': Wordsworth has,
 204: "-------the ground beneath
 205: Is ruffled with the cells of death.
 206: 
 207: These graves are on the north side of the church, in a spot, which, I believe, is not easy of access.
 208: 
 209: There are but few gravestones in this part of the cemetery; the billowy ridges here adverted to (very many of which seem, from their size, raised over the remains of infants), being, in most instances, the only memorials for the dead.

#994: 148203_Elstow Church_A, D_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Elstow Church
Author: A, D
Prose starts at line: 116
Lines to remove: 18
Avg verse line length: 34.4
Avg prose line length: 92.3

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 111: 
 112: D.
 113: 
 114: A.
 115: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 116: writes of Elstow for August 19, 1831, for the Year Book of Daily Recreation and Information.
 117: 
 118: "The village of Elstow is situate about a mile and a half from Bedford, and is noted as the site of an abbey of Benedictine nuns.
 119: 
 120: It is called 'Elnestov,' in Domesday-book, and, at the date of that survey, was held of Judith, countess of Huntingdon, by the monks of St.
 121: 
 122: Mary.
 123: 
 124: The population in 1821 was 548.
 125: 
 126: 
 127: There is in the south aisle of the church a memorial for Elizabeth Herwy, whom Mr.
 128: 
 129: Lysons calls the last abbess of Elstow, and he endeavours to account for the circumstances of the dates in the inscription being left blank, by supposing that she outlived the dissolution.
 130: 
 131: This, however, is not the fact, as she had three or more successors.
 132: 
 133: The 'prayer' referred to, is that, so usual on sepulchral monuments, previous to the reformation.

#995: 148355_The King's Tragedy James I. Of Scots.—20th February 1437_Rossetti, Dante Gabriel_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The King's Tragedy   James I. Of Scots.—20th February 1437
Author: Rossetti, Dante Gabriel
Prose starts at line: 1010
Lines to remove: 9
Avg verse line length: 35.0
Avg prose line length: 128.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1005: “Alas for the woful thing,
1006: That a poet true and a friend of man,
1007: In desperate days of bale and ban,
1008: Should needs be born a King!”
1009: NOTE

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1010: Tradition says that Catherine Douglas, in honour of her heroic act when she barred the door with her arm against the murderers of James the First of Scots, received popularly the name of “Barlass.
1011: 
1012: ” This name remains to her descendants, the Barlas family, in Scotland, who bear for their crest a broken arm.
1013: 
1014: She married Alexander Lovell of Bolunnie.
1015: 
1016: A few stanzas from King James's lovely poem, known as The King's Quair, are quoted in the course of this ballad.
1017: 
1018: The writer must express regret for the necessity which has compelled him to shorten the ten-syllabled lines to eight syllables, in order that they might harmonise with the ballad metre.

#996: 148635_The Aungelys Song Within._Hoccleve, Thomas_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Aungelys Song Within.
Author: Hoccleve, Thomas
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 17
Avg verse line length: 25.0
Avg prose line length: 176.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: The Aungelys Song Within.
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: Al worshippe, wisdam, welthe and worthinesse,     All bounte, beawte, ioye and blisfulheed,All honure, vertue, and alle myghtynesse,All grace & thankyng, vnto thin godheede,ffrom whom alle grace & mercy doth procede!     Ay praised be thu, lord, in Trinite,And euere honured be thi maieste!
   4: That be mankynde oure nombre is encreased,     Of this that longe have be in pilgrymage;And now is alle hire noyows laboure cessed,That was be-gonne here first[ë] dayës age.
   5: 
   6: Here is the port of sekire áryuáge     Honured be thu, blissed lord on hye,  And wolcome be ye to owre companye!
   7: Now passed be youre perilous auentures,     and alle youre Auenture hath an endë take.
   8: 
   9: Right wolcome be ye, blissed crëatures!Tyme it is, þat scrippe & burdon ye forsake,ffor now ye schal no longere iourne make;
  10: and aftir laboure, tyme is of quiete;Alle hevinesse & Anguysch is for-gete.
  11: 
  12: For ye have don a nobill victory,     And youre labourë nobly díspended,That so ageyn youre treble enemyeYoure selffë myghtely haue défendid;And þat ye have mysdon, it is amended     Be sustenaunce of purgatory peyne;Thanked be thu, [o] Ihesu souereyne!
  13: In heven blisse, here schul ye be with vs     Vnto the day of fynall iugëment,To wichë day ye schul a-bydë thus,And preisë god with al youre hool entent,While þat youre bodi, be assignëment     Of god, is turned to correpcïoun,And fully schal haue hire purgacioun.
  14: 
  15: For Reasoun [sayeth] wele, & god-is lawe,     That he þat hath don alle his besynesse(ffor god-is will) youre lustës to withdrawe—Encombryng yow with muche vnthryftynesse,—That from þat fowle and wofull wrechidnesse     I-clensid be, and alle renewyd cleneThat manere weye, youre flesch is, þat I mene.
  16: 
  17: So at the last[ë] day thei schal a-ryse,     And come be-fore that Iugë souereyn,To yow conioyned in a wondere wiseIn a good áccorde withowt ony peyne,And in this ioye eternally remayne.
  18: 
  19: What ioye is here, ye schul assaye & see,Honured be the hey[ë] maieste!


====================================================================================================
#997: 148637_'What tyme þat the pilgrymes had songyne in this wise, hire aungeles wiche þat l_Hoccleve, Thomas_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: "What tyme þat the pilgrymes had songyne in this wise, hire aungeles wiche þat led them, ansuerid a-
Author: Hoccleve, Thomas
Prose starts at line: 1
Lines to remove: 13
Avg verse line length: 0
Avg prose line length: 195.4

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: "What tyme þat the pilgrymes had songyne in this wise, hire aungeles wiche þat led them, ansuerid a-
   2: 
   3: All-myghti lord, oure blisful lord Ihesu,     Thu myroure of the fadier in maieste,In whom is seyn his myght and his vertue,The welle of witte & wisdaum is in the,To whom-is presence now retourned we be     With this pylgrymës which to the we bringe;To thin honoure ful ioyefully we synge.
   4: 
   5: Towardës the, ful longe thei haue trauayled;     Thu wost thi selfe, how thei han be distressed.
   6: 
   7: The falsë feend so sorë hem asseyled,And greuously diseased & oppressed;But be thi grace, his malice was repressed,     And thrughe thy mercy weel th[e]i be releved,And hire entent, fully thei han acheved.
   8: 
   9: What laboure & what anguysch have we had,     Sithe þat we took them in oure gouernaunce,Thu wost Ihesu; and now, [lord,] we be gladdeOf alle þat we have don to thi pleasaunce;Wherfore thu wilt with reward us auaunce     Suche as the list a-bove[n] in thi blisse;Eternall Ioye, we schul it neuere mysse.
  10: 
  11: Lo, we presente in-to thin hand a-geyn,     alle-myghty lord, þat to vs þou hast betake,
  12: ivhonured be thu, Ihesu souereyn,Of that we have labóurëd for thi sake,Of this labourë, now an ende thu make!     Thi crëaturës, vnto thi presence,  Receyve hem of thin heighe benevolence!
  13: For thow [that] thei han erred or myswent,     Thei have it a-bought with woundës hard & sore,And purgeid with grete peyne & [with] torment,And duely to hem was Iugëd therfore,Alle-thow thei hadde deserued muchë more,     The remenaunt is relessed, of thi grace;In heven is assigned hirë place.

   2: 
   3: Honured be thu, blisful lord Ihesu,       and preysed mote thu be in eueri place,So full of myght, [of] mercy and vertue,Of blisse, of bounte, of piete and of grace!Who is honurë, may no thing deface;     Who is [ther] that withstondë may thi myght?
   4: 
   5: But servë the, of fors mote eueri wight.
   6: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   7: Honúred be thu, Ihesu, heven kyng,     That hast be-taken to my gouernaunce  Suche one that hath, a-bove al othire thing,Abowed to the with lowely obeysaunce,And loued the with sadde perséueraunce,—     Thi counseil and thin hey comaundëmentObseruyng with his hertely hool entent.
   8: 
   9: He hath nought walked be the wey[ë]s large,     That to the worlde so lusty be, & grene;But he hath be ententif to thi charge,ffrom dedly synne to kepe him selfë clene,And gon to the wey of trauayle & of tene,     Of penaunce and of tribulacïoun,In grevous formës of temptacïoun.
  10: 
  11: So hath he had in erthe his purgatórye,     wich þat he hath susteyned wilfully;Wherforë, now receyve him to thi glorye,And take him up in[to] thi blisse an hye,with the to be in ioye eternally,     In what degre that to him is condigne,Right as thi selffë liketh to assigne.
  12: 
  13: Honoured be thu, Ihesu graciows,     That man became thi selfe, for mannës nede;And man thu taughtist to be vertuows,To servë the be veray love & dreed,
  14: Rewardyng hem with blisse for hirë mede     That don hire devoire as thei may & kan:Thanked be thu, [o] Ihesu, god and man!

   4: 
   5: was neuere to vs fleschë halfe so goode;
   6: ffor wonderly oure ioyes it doth renewe.
   7: 
   8: honured be thu, blissed lord Ihesu!

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   9: Whan thu were died, to hellë þou descended,     And fette hem owt þat [longe] lay there in peyne;ffor be thi deth, oure mis was alle a-mended.
  10: 
  11: The thrid day, thu a-roos to lyffe a-geyneWith highe tryumphe, & ioyë souereyn:     As champioun [the chef] of hie vertue,Honured be þou, blissed lord Ihesu!
  12: The grevous iourney þat thu took on hande,     hath clerly maad, to eueri wight appere,In sothfastnesse to see & vnderstonde,—To þat only was thi talent & thi chiereSo suffisaunt, lo,—that oure raunsoum were     Superhabundaunt over þat was due;Honured be thu, blisseful lord Ihesu!
  13: On thursday, a noble soper þou made,     Where thu ordeyned first thi sacrament;But muchë more it doth oure hertës glade,The worthi dyner of this day present,In which þou schewest thi self omnipotent,     Rising from deth to lyve, it is ful trewe:Honured be thu, blisful lord Ihesu!
  14: Now for this festë schal we say the graces,     And worthi is, with alle oure diligence,And thank the here, & [eke] in allë places,Of thi ful bountevous benevolence,Thi myght, thi grace, thi souereyn excellence:     Thu art the ground & welle of alle vertue:Honured be thu, blisfull lord Ihesu!

#1001: 148647_The Recordyng Of Aungeles Song Of The Natiuite Of Oure Lady._Hoccleve, Thomas_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Recordyng Of Aungeles Song Of The Natiuite Of Oure Lady.
Author: Hoccleve, Thomas
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 60.0
Avg prose line length: 181.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: The Recordyng Of Aungeles Song Of The Natiuite Of Oure Lady.
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: HOnured be thu, blisseful lord benigne,     That now vntó man wil be merciábleAs he may se apertly be a signe,A braunche, þat sprongen is ful profitable,fful fresch & faire, & heily commendable     Of Iesse-is Rote, þat called is marie,That schal the blisseful appil fructifie.
   4: 
   5: A blisful flour, owt of this spray schal springe;     The fruyt þer-of schal be ful precïous;A causë haue [we] for to ioye & synge,In honure of þat maidë gracïous,That gret comfort schal cause[n] vnto vs;     ffor now schal faste oure company encrees,And god with man schal makë smallë pees.
   6: 
   7: Now be we glad, in honure of this maide,     That schal be modier of the kyng eterne,Be whom the raunsom fully schal be paidffor man, þat loken is in hellë herne.
   8: 
   9: Now schal we haue no power for to warne     Man for [to] entre in-to paradise;The lord wil sette him at so highe a price.
  10: 
  11: Thu, lucifer, þat list in helle I-bounde,     That whylom were one of oure companye,  This maidë schal the vtterly confounde,And do the muchë schame & vilanye,Which Eua hast deceyuëd traytouresly,     And made hire trust[en] on thi fals behest,Wherby thu hast hire lynage alle arest.
  12: 
  13: Thu cursed caitiff! mawgre thi malice!     fful sone he schal be sette owt of thin hande;Reseised schal he be with paradise;Thu schalt not be of powire to with-stande;But, as an hound þat tied is with a bande,     So schalt thu eternally lyn in thi peyne;Ne no counfort getist thu, thow þou pleyne.
  14: 
  15: To gret distresse & gret desólacioun     A maidë first was déceyvëd be the:Vnto thi schame and [thi] confusïoun,A blissed maidë schal thi ladi be.
  16: 
  17: But weel is him þat schal þat maidë see,
  18: And schal be schent to salue hire, & grete,And say "heil, mary, maidë faire & sweet!"
  19: Who euere it be, þat schal do this messáge,     fful weel is him that fyndë may that grace:It schal him weel suffisë for his wage,To see þat blissed sweet[ë] lady face.
  20: 
  21: Now with alle ioyës, myrthë & soláce,     ffor loue of hire honure, we [synge] this dayWith alle the songes & myrthës þat we may.

Avg verse line length: 62.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: The Aungeles Songe In The Feste Of The Epiphanie Of Oure lord.
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: HOnured be this blissed holy festë day     In worshippe of the sweet[ë] welle of liffe,
   4: With alle the ioyes & mirthë þat we may,for Crist, the kirke hath chosë to his wiffe;And fynally abated is þat striffe,     Þat him betwyn, & man, hath longë be;Honured be this blessed Trinite!
   5: Owt of this welle, so noble licoure ran,     So faire, so fressh, so lusty, hony-sweet,That sith this first day þat the world be-gan,With suche a wellë might[ë] no man mete.
   6: 
   7: Alle heuynesse & malice is for-gete     As toward man; excused clene is hee;honured be the blissed Trinite!
   8: This day, so lowe he wold him self incline,     The thrid[dë] festë with his highe personeTo honure, turnyng watir in-to wynne.
   9: 
  10: This day was Ihesu baptised of seint Iohn;The fadir-is voice was herd owt of his trone:     "This is my loued sone, þat liketh me.
  11: 
  12: "honured be the souereyn Trinite!
  13: And þat he schuld haue recorde Autentyk,     The thrid[dë] persone, on oure lord a-light,The holy gost, vn-to a dowe I-lyk,That pleyn[ë]ly was seyn of eueri wight.
  14: 
  15: Thus blissed hath he watir, god al-myght,     In honure of this [highe] solemnite.
  16: 
  17: Honured be the blissed Trinite!

 245: is an agreement to order

 247: between breath
 248: and voice.

  96: When forth coom Miss, all don'd i' silk,
  97: Enoof to captivate us—
  98: Hoo gan poor Zeke some buttermilk,
  99: An' a plate o' cowd potatoes!

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 100: This was written at the commencement of Canning's term of office as Prime Minister of Great Britain in 1827.
 101: 
 102: At only 119 days it is one of the shortest terms of office for a Prime Minister.
 103: 
 104: Billy Pit (Line 15) is probably William Pitt (the younger) a previous Prime Minister of Great Britain.
 105: 
 106: Dank or Donk in Line 27 means damp, depressing.
 107: 
 108: Line 42 Sir John Copley, afterwards Lord Lyndhurst.
 109: 
 110: Line 43 Clippins; the woolsack Traditional seat of the Lord Chancellor in the House of Lords.
 111: 
 112: Line 62/63 refers to the fact that it was stated in the newspapers, that Mr.
 113: 
 114: Brougham had left the North in posthaste for London, on hearing of the change in the Administration.

Author: Bamford, Samuel
Prose starts at line: 96
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 27.0
Avg prose line length: 47.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  91: An' left the big sinner,
  92: Beawt Michaelmas dinner.
  93: 
  94: In his introduction to the poem Bamford writes "On the 7th November, 1838, at a torch-light meeting, held at Rochdale, Feargus O'Connor said they (the Chartists) would have Universal Suffrage by the 29th of September next.
  95: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  96: On that day they would have the "Michaelmas Goose;" if they did not get it on that day, they would have the gander on the 30th.
  97: 
  98: But he pledged his life and his honour they would have Universal Suffrage by that day.
  99: 
 100: They didn't!
 101: This poem was taken from Bamford's book Homely Rhymes, Poems and Reminiscences.

#1011: 149147_La Lyonnaise,_Bamford, Samuel_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: La Lyonnaise,
Author: Bamford, Samuel
Prose starts at line: 243
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 34.8
Avg prose line length: 113.3

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 238: 
 239: Live citizens and freemen, or life with freedom lose;
 240: Soldiers, come join the people; and cursed be our foes!
 241: This poem was "Respectfully inscribed" to
 242: EBENEZER ELLIOT,

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 243: Who, of all the English bards, has pleaded most eloquently and perseveringly the cause of the labouring millions.
 244: 
 245: In Bamford's book Homely Rhymes, Poems and Reminiscences, this poem is introduced as follows:-
 246: This Poem was first published in April, 1839; it was inscribed, as at present to the before-mentioned bard, and was addressed to "The Hand-loom Weavers of Lancashire, and the Persons styled Chartists," in the hope that the reading of the piece, with the accompanying introductory remarks, and the post-scriptum, might have some effect in counteracting the baneful influence of the Chartist demagogues, who, having wickedly devised the plan of "a National Holiday," or "Sacred Month," as they called it, were then urging their followers to attempt carrying it into effect.
 247: 
 248: Whatever of an exciting tendency was to be found in the Poem, brought with it, in the same pages, a counteracting admonition; and the author hopes it was not then, nor has been since, altogether forgotten, either by the employers or the employed.
 249: 
 250: For the meaning of the many Lancashire dialect words in Bamford's poetry it is suggested you look here.
 251: 
 252: http://www.
 253: 
 254: gerald-massey.
 255: 
 256: org.
 257: 
 258: uk/bamford/b_glossary.
 259: 
 260: htm
 261: The site contains a good deal of information concerning the Poet.

  72: In thy extremity.
  73:

  75:

  76: This was written on the approach of Bamford's trial at York, in 1820 following his arrest in connection with the infamous "Peterloo Massacre" in Manchester the previous year.
