#1014: 149234_Kentucky Belle_Woolson, Constance Fenimore_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Kentucky Belle
Author: Woolson, Constance Fenimore
Prose starts at line: 170
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 58.5
Avg prose line length: 184.9

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 165: 
 166: Educated partly at home and partly in a local school, he briefly attended Transylvania University but was suspended for dueling in 1844 and never took a degree.
 167: 
 168: He saw service as a first lieutenant at the Battle of Buena Vista during the Mexican War with the First Regiment of Mounted Volunteers but returned to Lexington at war's end and became a prominent businessman dealing in hemp and jean cloth.
 169: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 170: His enthusiasm for the military life stayed with him, however, and he organized the Kentucky Rifles, an exclusive militia group that was decidely pro-secession and ultimately joined the Confederate Army in September of 1861.
 171: 
 172: Morgan quickly established himself as a daring and successful cavalry leader, and he was promoted to colonel on April 4, 1862.
 173: 
 174: Although the only battle of any major significance in which he took part was Shiloh on April 6-7, 1862, his reputation continued to grow as a result of his Second Kentucky Cavalry Regiment's continual harrassment of the Union Army through a series of raids into Kentucky.
 175: 
 176: On December 11, 1862, just one day before his marriage to Martha Ready (his first wife, Becky, had died in July 1861), Morgan was promoted to brigadier general.
 177: 
 178: Morgan is perhaps best remembered, with no small justification, for his amazing escape from the Ohio State Penetentiary in Columbus.
 179: 
 180: Captured after a raid near New Lisbon, Ohio, on July 26, 1863, Morgan and a number of his men were branded as "criminals" (rather than as prisoners of war) and incarcerated in the state prison.
 181: 
 182: On November 27, following months of surreptitious tunneling, he and six of his officers took an unscheduled leave from what was thought to be an escape-proof facility and resumed their raids into Kentucky.
 183: 
 184: Morgan's luck ran out on September 3, 1864, when he and men were surprised by Union troops at Greenville, Tennessee.
 185: 
 186: Morgan had not fared well while in captivity, and rather than face further imprisonment, he attempted to escape but was shot and killed.
 187: 
 188: Morgan's remains were first interred in Richmond's Hollywood Cemetery but were removed to Lexington in 1868 and buried beside those of his younger brother Tom, who was moved at the same time from Lebanon, Kentucky, where he had been buried following his death in battle on July 5, 1863.


====================================================================================================

  54: 'That sotto voce cons the song
  55: He'll sing when dark is spread;
  56: And Night's vague hours are sweet and long,
  57: And we are laid abed.
  58: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  59: Monday,9th April, 1917 Edward Thomas volunteered to occupy a forward observation post on the Western Front.
  60: 
  61: At 36 minutes and 12 seconds past seven o'clock in the morning, a shell landed close to him.
  62: 
  63: It left no mark on his body, but the blast stopped his heart, and his pocket watch.
  64: 
  65: The pocket watch has been one of the most poignant exhibits in the Imperial War Museum, and is kept in the Edward Thomas Collection, at Cardiff University Library.

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: At the Bridal Shop
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: The gowns and dresses hang like fleece in their glaring whiteness, sheepskin-softness,
   4: 
   5: the ruffled matrimonial love in which the brides- in-waiting dance around, expectantly, hummingbirds to tulips.
   6: 
   7: I was dragged here: David’s Bridal, off the concrete-gray arterial highways of a naval town.
   8: 
   9: I sink into the flush bachelors’ couch, along with other men sprinkled throughout the shop, as my friend and her female compatriots parade taffeta dresses in monstrous shades of pastels—persimmons, lilacs, periwinkles—the colors of weddings and religious holidays.
  10: 
  11: Trains drag on the floor, sleeves drape like limp, pressed sheets of candied fruits, ribbons fluttering like pale leaves.
  12: 
  13: I watch families gathered together: the women, like worshippers, circling around the smiling brides-to-be, as if they were the anointed ones.
  14: 
  15: The men, in turn, submerge deeper into couches, into sleep, while the haloed, veiled women cannot contain their joy, they flash their winning smiles, and they are beautiful.

#1018: 150196_Dabodi_Zedong, Mao_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Dabodi
Author: Zedong, Mao
Prose starts at line: 14
Lines to remove: 15
Avg verse line length: 34.2
Avg prose line length: 115.6

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   9: A furious battle once raged here,
  10: The village walls, bullet-scarred,
  11: Now adorn hill and pass
  12: And make them doubly fair.
  13: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  14: Dabodi (Tapoti) is a town seventeen miles northwest of Juichin in Kiangsi Province and is said to be a colourful place, with high mounds of red clay and green pine woods.
  15: 
  16: Rice paddies and farmhouses with grey tile roofs and white walls also add their colours.
  17: 
  18: Willows line the streams.
  19: 
  20: After rain, there are rainbows in the sky with as many colours as the landscape.
  21: 
  22: Dabodi is the site of a battle which actually took place at the beginning of 1929.
  23: 
  24: Initially the Red Army suffered several defeats but, in the winter of 1929, they fought a desperate but succesful battle with stones and bare hands.
  25: 
  26: Mao revisted the site several times and wrote this poem 4 years later.
  27: 
  28: This poem repeats one of Mao’s favourite situations  —  a landscape beautiful in itself, made more attractive by the Red Army's victory and the presence of Communist soldiers and flags, adding their own colours (including blood) to those of the town and country.


====================================================================================================
#1019: 150290_The Earthly Paradise- Apology_Morris, William_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Earthly Paradise: Apology
Author: Morris, William
Prose starts at line: 56
Lines to remove: 10
Avg verse line length: 38.1
Avg prose line length: 110.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  51: 
  52: NOTES
  53: Form:
  54: ababbcc1.
  55: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  56: The entire poem consists of twenty-four long narrative poems held together by a framework, after the fashion of Chaucer's Canterbury Tales.
  57: 
  58: They are supposed to be told on a remote island where some Norwegian wanderers of the fourteenth century find the descendants of
  59: a band of Greeks who had settled there long before.
  60: 
  61: Islanders and strangers meet monthly for a whole year, and tell alternate stories from ancient sources--Greek and Norse.
  62: 
  63: "The Lady of the Land" is one of the June tales from The Earthly Paradise.
  64: 
  65: It is a retelling of the shorter story in the fourth chapter of The Voyage of Sir John Maundeville, a fourteenth-century book of travel and romance.


====================================================================================================
#1020: 150435_Campin’ Round Coonamble_Paterson, A B Banjo_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Campin’ Round Coonamble
Author: Paterson, A B Banjo
Prose starts at line: 67
Lines to remove: 9
Avg verse line length: 22.4
Avg prose line length: 108.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  62: Them, if they oppress us,
  63: Then we’ll go again
  64: Campin’ round Coonamble,
  65: Campin’ in the rain.
  66: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  67: Written when reporting for the Sydney Morning Herald on the shearing troubles at Coonamble.
  68: 
  69: In 1902 the Machine Shearer’s Union organised a strike for better wages and conditions.
  70: 
  71: Trouble came to a head at Wingadee, the biggest sheds in the Coonamble district, where pickets were arranged by the shearers.
  72: 
  73: The phrase ‘on the bike’ refers to the shearers, who used bicycles to ride to and from Coonamble with news; the shearers’ camp was at Woodlands outside Coonamble.
  74: 
  75: Paterson was sent by the Sydney Morning Heralds to report on the situation.


====================================================================================================

  63: The Barcoo Shire is a remote rural shire located in western Queensland in the heart of the channel country.
  64: 
  65: Encompassing the towns of Jundah, Windorah and Stonehenge with a total shire population of approximately 460.
  66: 
  67: The Shire’s primary river systems are the Thomson and Barcoo, which amalgamate above Windorah to become Cooper’s Creek.
  68: 
  69: All rivers and creeks within the Shire merge and flow southwest towards South Australia, terminating at Lake Eyre.
  70: 
  71: Covering a region of 60901sq km, the Barcoo Shire adjoins the North-East, South Australian border and is bordered by the shires of Diamantina, Longreach, Winton, Isisford, Quilpie and Bulloo.
  72: 
  73: The country displays extremes of dry red expanses to flooding plains with masses of wildflowers.
  74: 
  75: The Shire's predominant industry is beef production with opal mining, tourism and hospitality to a lesser extent.
  76: 
  77: Due to drought and economics wool production has declined considerably.
  78: 
  79: The discovery of oil and gas reserves within the shire has seen substantial development in this industry.
  80: 
  81: Maggee's Shanty
  82: Approximately 90km from Jundah towards Yaraka is the historic site of the shanty immortalised in Banjo Patterson's poem "A Bush Christening", not far from the ruins of the Cobb & Co pub and the lonely grave of goldminer Richard Magoffin who perished in 1885.


====================================================================================================
#1022: 150542_Hawker, the Standard Bearer_Paterson, A B Banjo_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Hawker, the Standard Bearer
Author: Paterson, A B Banjo
Prose starts at line: 69
Lines to remove: 13
Avg verse line length: 36.1
Avg prose line length: 107.6

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  64: The risks of the storm and the sea,
  65: And his name shall be written in stars of flame,
  66: On the topmost walls of the Temple of Fame,
  67: For the rest of the world to see.
  68: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  69: Harry George Hawker (1889-1921) established several British and world aviation  records.
  70: 
  71: He was a test pilot during World War 1 and in May 1919, accompanied by Lieutenant-Commander K Mackenzie Grieve, he began a trans-Atlantic flight in a Sopwith single-engined aircraft from Newfoundland.
  72: 
  73: Engine trouble finally caused them to alight on the sea and they were rescued one and a half hours later by a ship without a radio transmitter.
  74: 
  75: News of their rescue was delayed for 6 days and they were given up for lost.
  76: 
  77: This poem was written during this time when both men were feared dead.
  78: 
  79: Both men were congratulated by King George V and awarded the Air force Cross.
  80: 
  81: Hawker was killed during a practice flight for the 1921 Aerial Derby when his aircraft caught fire.

  34:

  36:

#1024: 150582_The Man from Snowy River_Paterson, A B Banjo_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Man from Snowy River
Author: Paterson, A B Banjo
Prose starts at line: 134
Lines to remove: 11
Avg verse line length: 53.0
Avg prose line length: 125.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 129: And where around the Overflow the reed -beds sweep and sway
 130: To the breezes, and the rolling plains are wide,
 131: The man from Snowy River is a household word today,
 132: And the stockmen tell the story of his ride.
 133: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 134: Now  remembered mainly from the film with the same name, this poems was taken from the book " The Man from Snowy River and Other Verses" by A B (Banjo), Paterson.
 135: 
 136: The poem tells the story of a valuable horse which escapes and the princely sum offered by its owner for its safe return.
 137: 
 138: All the riders in the area gather to pursue the wild bush horses and cut the valuable horse from the mob.
 139: 
 140: But the country defeats them all - except for 'The Man from Snowy River'.
 141: 
 142: His personal courage and skill has turned him into a legend.
 143: 
 144: It is thought that Paterson based the character of The Man from Snowy River on Jack Riley from Corryong, although this is often disputed with the argument put that Paterson created a composite character from a number of people he met.

  25: Raree-show—A peep-show; originally a “rarityshow,” usually of pictures carried about in a box.
  26: 
  27: Thermopylae—A narrow mountain pass in Greece which was the scene of a great battle in 480 B.
  28: 
  29: C.
  30: 
  31: , where Leonidas at the head of 300 Spartans held the pass for three days against a large Persian army, until by treachery the Persians learned of a secret path over the mountain, and, attacking the Spartans in front and rear destroyed all but one of that gallant band.
  32: 
  33: Inkerman—A battle in the Crimean war, fought on the 5th November, 1854.
  34: 
  35: The defeat of the Russians in this battle was mainly due to the British soldiers.

#1028: 151052_Memorials On The Slain At Chickamauga_Melville, Herman_unknown.txt

Author: Melville, Herman
Prose starts at line: 24

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  19: 
  20: The will, that never can relent —
  21: The aim, survivor of the bafflement,
  22: Make this memorial due.
  23: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  24: The Battle of Chickamauga was fought on September 19 through 21, 1863, just south of Chattanooga, Tennessee.
  25: 
  26: The forces of Confederate General Braxton Bragg defeated Federal troops under General William Rosecrans in a ferocious battle that claimed a combined total of almost 35,000 lives.
  27: 
  28: As was so often the case, the victorious Confederates were unable to take advantage of their success and allowed the Federals to retire to Chattanooga unmolested.
  29: 
  30: Melville's poem is a tribute to those who gave their lives in a contest the outcome of which they were never to know.

 120: —The House being ready, Victoria prepares to receive the nations whom she has invited.
 121: 
 122: They approach—the various countries of Europe, Asia, Africa, of the American continent, the Australian colonies, and those of Polynesia—some of them greater than any which ever paid tribute to Rome, or did homage to a medieval monarch, and their products superior to those which in olden times were fit gifts from one king to another.
 123: 
 124: II.
 125: 
 126: —Victoria salutes the other Australian colonies, and asks them to unite with her in greeting her other guests.
 127:

 129: 
 130: ), America (the South American Republics, Empire of Brazil, Dominion of Canada, and the United States of North America); then France, Spain, and Portugal; Italy, Greece, Russia, Switzerland; then Holland and Belgium, Denmark, Austria, Germany, Norway, and Sweden; then Britain.
 131:

 133: 
 134: —The triumphs of Peace and of Toil.
 135: 
 136: IV.
 137: 
 138: —Aspirations for the future of Australia—that she may be happy, a generous friend, but, if need be, a formidable enemy.

  31: The fealty pledged, the kingdom given in trust.
  32: 
  33: The term parhfinder is a little ambiguous.
  34: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  35: A number of the early settlers in Australia were trailblazers who paved the way for the people and towns who would follow.
  36: 
  37: Some of these were labelled as pathfinders for example Rev William Kennedy whose life and work is described in Blazing the Western Trails: The Story of the Life and Work of William Kennedy, Pathfinder, Preacher and Pioneer.
  38: 
  39: (Glebe, NSW: JA Packer print: 1935).
  40: 
  41: Possibly this was referring to the Australian Aboriginal though.
  42: 
  43: We can't have one without the other really as the 2 races intermingled so much in life and death, whether by killing each other or living together in some ways.
  44:

  46: 
  47: Line 25: sums it up: The fealty pledged, the kingdom given in trust.
  48: 
  49: Their ties were now pledged to the land and the country.

   1: Afternoon
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: In the morning that comes up behind the roof, in the shelter of the bridge, in the corner of  the cypresses that rise above the wall, a rooster  has crowed.
   4: 
   5: In the bell tower that rips the air with its shining point, the notes ring out and already the morning din can be heard in the street; the only street that goes from the river to the mountain  dividing the woods.
   6: 
   7: One looks for some other words but the ideas are always just as dark, just as simple and singularly painful.
   8: 
   9: There is hardly more than the eyes, the open air, the grass and the water in the distance with, around every bend, a well or a cool basin.
  10: 
  11: In the right-hand corner the last house with a larger head at the window.
  12: 
  13: The trees are extremely alive and all those familiar companions walk along the demolished wall that is crushed into the thorns with bursts of laughter.
  14: 
  15: Above the ravine the din augments, swells, and if the car passes on the upper road one no longer knows if it is the flowers or the little bells that are chiming.
  16: 
  17: Under the blazing sun, when the landscape is on fire, the traveler crosses the stream on a very narrow bridge, before a dark hole where the trees line the water that falls asleep in the afternoon.
  18: 
  19: And, against the trembling background of the woods, the motionless man.

#1038: 151788_Hymns to the Night - 1_Novalis_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Hymns to the Night : 1
Author: Novalis
Prose starts at line: 35
Lines to remove: 9
Avg verse line length: 105.5
Avg prose line length: 242.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  30: 
  31: Precious balm drips from thy hand out of its bundle of poppies.
  32: 
  33: Thou upliftest the heavy-laden wings of the soul.
  34: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  35: Darkly and inexpressibly are we moved — joy-startled, I see a grave face that, tender and worshipful, inclines toward me, and, amid manifold entangled locks, reveals the youthful loveliness of the Mother.
  36: 
  37: How poor and childish a thing seems to me now the Light — how joyous and welcome the departure of the day — because the Night turns away from thee thy servants, you now strew in the gulfs of space those flashing globes, to proclaim thy omnipotence — thy return — in seasons of thy absence.
  38: 
  39: More heavenly than those glittering stars we hold the eternal eyes which the Night hath opened within us.
  40: 
  41: Farther they see than the palest of those countless hosts — needing no aid from the light, they penetrate the depths of a loving soul — that fills a loftier region with bliss ineffable.
  42: 
  43: Glory to the queen of the world, to the great prophet of the holier worlds, to the guardian of blissful love — she sends thee to me — thou tenderly beloved — the gracious sun of the Night, — now am I awake — for now am I thine and mine — thou hast made me know the Night — made of me a man — consume with spirit-fire my body, that I, turned to finer air, may mingle more closely with thee, and then our bridal night endure forever.


====================================================================================================

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]

  10: 
  11: To the Light a season was set; but everlasting and boundless is the dominion of the Night.
  12: 
  13: — Endless is the duration of sleep.
  14: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  15: Holy Sleep — gladden not too seldom in this earthly day-labor, the devoted servant of the Night.
  16: 
  17: Fools alone mistake thee, knowing nought of sleep but the shadow which, in the twilight of the real Night, thou pitifully castest over us.
  18: 
  19: They feel thee not in the golden flood of the grapes — in the magic oil of the almond tree — and the brown juice of the poppy.
  20: 
  21: They know not that it is thou who hauntest the bosom of the tender maiden, and makest a heaven of her lap — never suspect it is thou, opening the doors to Heaven, that steppest to meet them out of ancient stories, bearing the key to the dwellings of the blessed, silent messenger of secrets infinite.


====================================================================================================
#1040: 151795_Hymns to the Night - 3_Novalis_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Hymns to the Night : 3
Author: Novalis
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 15
Avg verse line length: 22.0
Avg prose line length: 172.4

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Hymns to the Night : 3
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: Once when I was shedding bitter tears, when, dissolved in pain, my hope was melting away, and I stood alone by the barren mound which in its narrow dark bosom hid the vanished form of my life — lonely as never yet was lonely man, driven by anxiety unspeakable — powerless, and no longer anything but a conscious misery.
   4: 
   5: — As there I looked about me for help, unable to go on or to turn back, and clung to the fleeting, extinguished life with an endless longing: — then, out of the blue distances — from the hills of my ancient bliss, came a shiver of twilight — and at once snapt the bond of birth — the chains of the Light.
   6: 
   7: Away fled the glory of the world, and with it my mourning — the sadness flowed together into a new, unfathomable world — Thou, Night-inspiration, heavenly Slumber, didst come upon me — the region gently upheaved itself; over it hovered my unbound, newborn spirit.
   8: 
   9: The mound became a cloud of dust — and through the cloud I saw the glorified face of my beloved.
  10: 
  11: In her eyes eternity reposed — I laid hold of her hands, and the tears became a sparkling bond that could not be broken.
  12: 
  13: Into the distance swept by, like a tempest, thousands of years.
  14: 
  15: On her neck I welcomed the new life with ecstatic tears.
  16: 
  17: It was the first, the only dream — and just since then I have held fast an eternal, unchangeable faith in the heaven of the Night, and its Light, the Beloved.


====================================================================================================

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   9: Had been youngwives, diverted here during childbirth,our gentle qualities stripped from us bythe naked pain of thatcircumstance,who left behind husbands so enamored of us, so tormented by the horror of those last moments (the notion that we had gone down that awful black hole pain-sundered from ourselves) that they had never loved again.
  10: 
  11: Had been bulkymen,quietly content,whoin our first youth,had come to grasp ourown unremarkableness and had, cheerfully (as if bemusedly accepting aheavy burdenshifted our life's focus;if we would not begreat, we would beuseful;would be rich, and kind, andthereby able to effect good: smiling, hands in pockets, watching the worldwe had subtly improved walking past (this empty dowry filled; that education secretly funded).
  12: 
  13: Had been affable, joking servants, of whom our masters had grown fond for thecheeringwords we managed as they launched forthon daysfull of import.
  14: 
  15: Had been grandmothers,tolerantand frank, recipientsofcertaindark secretswho, by the quality of their unjudging listening, granted tacit forgiveness, and thus let in the sun.
  16: 
  17: What I mean to say is, we hadbeen considerable.
  18: 
  19: Hadbeen loved.
  20: 
  21: Not lonely, not lost, not freakish,but wise, each in his or her own way.
  22: 
  23: Our departures caused pain.
  24: 
  25: Those who hadlovedus sat upon their beds, heads in hand; lowered their faces to tabletops, making animal noises.
  26: 
  27: We had beenloved, I say, and remembering us, even many years later, people would smile, briefly gladdened at the memory.


====================================================================================================
#1042: 151925_Nothing On Earth Permanent_Great, Alfred The_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Nothing On Earth Permanent
Author: Great, Alfred The
Prose starts at line: 44
Lines to remove: 7
Avg verse line length: 22.7
Avg prose line length: 142.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  39: Does not ever remain.
  40: 
  41: From King Alfred's Metres of Boethius circa 880
  42: A poem of nature on the surface but underneath appears a different message.
  43: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  44: 'Quickly are obscured all other stars' possibly refers to the absorption of the minor kingdoms of the south of England at that time into Alfred's sway.
  45: 
  46: 'The stark storm, when it strong comes from north and east' possibly refers to the constant attacks on his kingdom by the Danes whose repulsion on land and on sea left Alfred and the Saxons in a much more secure position.
  47: 
  48: 'Alas! that on earth aught of permanent work in the world does not remain' is a possible reference to the likelihood of more rebellion after his death leading to the dis-unification of his kingdom.
  49: 
  50: JS


====================================================================================================
#1043: 152010_Fusion Series # 2570_Touchon, Cecil_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Fusion Series # 2570
Author: Touchon, Cecil
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 13
Avg verse line length: 20.0
Avg prose line length: 134.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Fusion Series # 2570
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: Cecil Touchon’s work is radically post-textual, yet encumbered by nothing but text and the space surrounding it.
   4: 
   5: His technique, as demonstrated aptly here, is to dismantle physical pages of text and reconstitute them in ways that enhance the visual continuities of text and undermine their meaningful sequentiality.
   6: 
   7: This is the ultimate form of deconstruction, a literal (in the hand, of the letter) slicing of the page into pieces that Touchon repositions into a new jigsaw puzzle, different than the one that he began with.
   8: 
   9: This piece is particularly austere, presenting only three colors for our consideration: a mottled white, a red-brown, and a glimpse of black peeking through from the base of the collage.
  10: 
  11: We are invited to consider this poem as a piece of writing transmogrified into a visual field through which we might glimpse what it means to be text, to understand text, and to inhabit text.
  12: 
  13: —Geof Huth
  14: 
  15: More About Visual Poetry > >

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   4: 
   5: The Ferris Wheel is an overgrown version of his own bells and whistle eyes.
   6: 
   7: His Flashers, his mother calls them.
   8: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   9: The Tilt-A-Whirl is the angle his head tilts when the Flirt Program goes into effect, usually in the vicinity of a Cindy or a Carrie, though once he found himself tilting at the school librarian which caused him to wheel in reverse into the Civil War section knocking over a cart of books that were waiting to be shelved under B.
  10: 
  11: There’s a dangerously low stratosphere of pink cotton-candy clouds being carried around by the children.
  12: 
  13: If Robo-Boy goes near them, the alarms will go off.
  14: 
  15: It’s the kind of sticky that would cause joint-lock for sure.
  16: 
  17: In a darker, safer corner Robo-Boy finds the Whack-A-Mole game.
  18: 
  19: He pays a dollar and starts whacking the plastic moles on their heads each time they pop up from the much-dented log.
  20: 
  21: He wins bear after bear.
  22: 
  23: It’s only when he's lugging them home, the largest one skidding face-down along the sidewalk getting dirt on its white nose and light blue belly, that he remembers the program: Wac-A-Mole Realism™—the disc on the installer’s desk.
  24: 
  25: Suddenly it all fits together: the way a deliciously strange thought will start wafting out of his unconscious—and then WHAM, it disappears.

#1045: 152097_Lusty Youth Should Us Ensue_England, Henry VIII King of_unknown.txt

Title: Lusty Youth Should Us Ensue
Author: England, Henry VIII King of
Prose starts at line: 13
Lines to remove: 9
Avg verse line length: 75.5
Avg prose line length: 116.4

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   8: 
   9: How should Youth himself best use But all disdainers for to refuse?
  10: 
  11: Youth has, as chief assurance, Honest Mirth with Virtue's pastance.
  12: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  13: For in them consisteth great honour, Though that disdainers would therein put error, For they do sue to get them grace All only riches to purchase.
  14: 
  15: With Good Order, Counsel, and Equity, Good Lord, grant us our mansion to be! For without their good guidance Youth should fall in great mischance.
  16: 
  17: For Youth is frail and prompt to do, As well vices as virtues to ensue.
  18: 
  19: Wherefore by these he must be guided And Virtue's pastance must be therein used.
  20: 
  21: Now unto God this prayer we make, That this rude play may well be take, And that we may our faults amend, An bliss obtain at our last end.

#1046: 152324_Painting Biddle City_Chan, Marianne_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Painting Biddle City
Author: Chan, Marianne
Prose starts at line: 5
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 39.5
Avg prose line length: 110.4

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Painting Biddle City
   2: 
   3: Biddle City was painted by no one, but I will paint it now.
   4: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   5: First, I will use my flat, long-haired brush, spread gray-blue paint evenly over the canvas.
   6: 
   7: Then, I will capture the art deco building by the capitol, the free-standing barber shop.
   8: 
   9: With its Red Cedar River full of coruscating water and its Old Town Mexican bakery, popcorn shop on Turner.
  10: 
  11: With the bar—I’ve forgotten its name—on the river, golden lights, high ceilings, the community theater actor drinking her vodka water through a paper straw.
  12: 
  13: And the ring-necked doves, I will paint them, extending their wings to glide around the bell tower of St.
  14: 
  15: Mary’s Cathedral.
  16: 
  17: With the state representative tightening his tie after a pretzel bun burger on Michigan Ave.
  18: 
  19: With the folk singer at Gone Wired plucking her strings with her callused fingers.
  20: 
  21: And everyone is a little bit drunk on the streets of Biddle City, even the forlorn mechanic who lifts his grease-stained hair out of his eyes with his forearm.
  22: 
  23: I will paint them all, the jobless man, his lovesick face, at the bus stop, the weary college student entering the well-lit diner, the recently-killed deer, murdered by a car, resting her nose on the curb.

Author: Ciccariello, Peter
Prose starts at line: 5
Lines to remove: 7
Avg verse line length: 51.5
Avg prose line length: 107.5

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: The Disremembered Glossolalist
   2: 
   3: Peter Ciccariello provides an interesting dilemma to readers of his work.
   4: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   5: His process usually begins with the writing of a standard lineated poem, but he takes the text of that poem and wraps it around the landforms and ruins of an invented realm that he creates through meticulous computer modeling.
   6: 
   7: The results are stunning and enigmatic textscapes that a reader must sift through carefully to imagine what they originally were and what they originally communicated.
   8: 
   9: —Geof Huth
  10: 
  11: More About Visual Poetry >>

  20:

  24:

  26:

  12:

  14: 
  15: Break their teeth, O God, in their mouth: break out the great teeth of the young lions, O LORD.
  16: 
  17: Let them melt away as waters [which] run continually: [when] he bendeth [his bow to shoot] his arrows, let them be as cut in pieces.
  18: 
  19: As a snail [which] melteth, let [every one of them] pass away: [like] the untimely birth of a woman, [that] they may not see the sun.
  20: 
  21: Before your pots can feel the thorns, he shall take them away as with a whirlwind, both living, and in [his] wrath.
  22: 
  23: The righteous shall rejoice when he seeth the vengeance: he shall wash his feet in the blood of the wicked.
  24: 
  25: So that a man shall say, Verily [there is] a reward for the righteous: verily he is a God that judgeth in the earth.

  18:

  20: 
  21: For [there is] no faithfulness in their mouth; their inward part [is] very wickedness; their throat [is] an open sepulchre; they flatter with their tongue.
  22: 
  23: Destroy thou them, O God; let them fall by their own counsels; cast them out in the multitude of their transgressions; for they have rebelled against thee.
  24: 
  25: But let all those that put their trust in thee rejoice: let them ever shout for joy, because thou defendest them: let them also that love thy name be joyful in thee.
  26: 
  27: For thou, LORD, wilt bless the righteous; with favour wilt thou compass him as [with] a shield.

  10:

  12:

  14: 
  15: They search out iniquities; they accomplish a diligent search: both the inward [thought] of every one [of them,] and the heart, [is] deep.
  16:

  18: 
  19: So they shall make their own tongue to fall upon themselves: all that see them shall flee away.
  20: 
  21: And all men shall fear, and shall declare the work of God; for they shall wisely consider of his doing.
  22: 
  23: The righteous shall be glad in the LORD, and shall trust in him; and all the upright in heart shall glory.

   5: They that trust in the LORD [shall be] as mount Zion, [which] cannot be removed, [but] abideth for ever.
   6: 
   7: As the mountains [are] round about Jerusalem, so the LORD [is] round about his people from henceforth even for ever.
   8: 
   9: For the rod of the wicked shall not rest upon the lot of the righteous; lest the righteous put forth their hands unto iniquity.
  10: 
  11: Do good, O LORD, unto [those that be] good, and [to them that are] upright in their hearts.
  12: 
  13: As for such as turn aside unto their crooked ways, the LORD shall lead them forth with the workers of iniquity: [but] peace [shall be] upon Israel.


====================================================================================================

Author: Fu, Du
Prose starts at line: 11
Lines to remove: 17

Avg prose line length: 106.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   6: 
   7: Youth and vigor last but a little time.
   8: 
   9: —- Each of us now has greying temples.
  10: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  11: Half of the friends we ask each other about are dead, and our shocked cries sear the heart.
  12: 
  13: Who could have guessed that it would be twenty years before I sat once more beneath your roof?
  14: 
  15: Last time we parted you were still unmarried, but now here suddenly is a row of boys and girls who smilingly pay their respects to their father's old friend.
  16: 
  17: They ask me where I have come from; but before I have finished dealing with their questions, the children are hurried off to fetch us wine.
  18: 
  19: Spring chives are cut in the rainy dark, and there is freshly steamed rice mixed with yellow millet.
  20: 
  21: `Come, we don't meet often!' you hospitably urge, pouring out ten cupfuls in rapid succession.
  22: 
  23: That I am still not drunk after ten cups of wine is due to the strength of the emotion which your unchanging friendship inspires.
  24: 
  25: Tomorrow the peak will lie between us, and each will be lost to the other, swallowed up in the world's affairs.
  26: 
  27: Tu Fu (prose translation by David Hawkes)

#1095: 153839_The Idler_Dunbar-Nelson, Alice Moore_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Idler
Author: Dunbar-Nelson, Alice Moore
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 11
Avg verse line length: 9.0
Avg prose line length: 139.7

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: The Idler
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: An idle lingerer on the wayside's road,  He gathers up his work and yawns away;  A little longer, ere the tiresome load  Shall be reduced to ashes or to clay.
   4: 
   5: No matter if the world has marched along,  And scorned his slowness as it quickly passed;  No matter, if amid the busy throng,  He greets some face, infantile at the last.
   6: 
   7: His mission?
   8: 
   9: Well, there is but one,  And if it is a mission he knows it, nay,  To be a happy idler, to lounge and sun,  And dreaming, pass his long-drawn days away.
  10: 
  11: So dreams he on, his happy life to pass  Content, without ambitions painful sighs,  Until the sands run down into the glass;  He smiles—content—unmoved and dies.
  12: 
  13: And yet, with all the pity that you feel  For this poor mothling of that flame, the world;  Are you the better for your desperate deal,  When you, like him, into infinitude are hurled?


====================================================================================================
#1096: 153914_The Interpretation of Nature and_Bacon, Francis_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Interpretation of Nature and
Author: Bacon, Francis
Prose starts at line: 569
Lines to remove: 17
Avg verse line length: 157.9
Avg prose line length: 270.3

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 564: 
 565: Hence it is that men cease not from abstracting nature till they come to potential and uninformed matter, nor on the other hand from dissecting nature till they reach the atom; things which, even if true, can do but little for the welfare of mankind.
 566: 
 567: LXVII.
 568: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 569: A caution must also be given to the understanding against the intemperance which systems of philosophy manifest in giving or withholding assent; because intemperance of this kind seems to establish Idols and in some sort to perpetuate them, leaving no way open to reach and dislodge them.
 570: 
 571: This excess is of two kinds: the first being manifest in those who are ready in deciding, and render sciences dogmatic and magisterial; the other in those who deny that we can know anything, and so introduce a wandering kind of inquiry that leads to nothing; of which kinds the former subdues, the latter weakens the understanding.
 572: 
 573: For the philosophy of Aristotle, after having by hostile confutations destroyed all the rest (as the Ottomans serve their brothers), has laid down the law on all points; which done, he proceeds himself to raise new questions of his own suggestion, and dispose of them likewise; so that nothing may remain that is not certain and decided: a practice which holds and is in use among his successors.
 574: 
 575: The school of Plato, on the other hand, introduced Acatalepsia, at first in jest and irony, and in disdain of the older sophists, Protagoras, Hippias, and the rest, who were of nothing else so much ashamed as of seeming to doubt about anything.
 576: 
 577: But the New Academy made a dogma of it, and held it as a tenet.
 578: 
 579: And though their's is a fairer seeming way than arbitrary decisions; since they say that they by no means destroy all investigation, like Pyrrho and his Refrainers, but allow of some things to be followed as probable, though of none to be maintained as true; yet still when the human mind has once despaired of finding truth, its interest in all things grows fainter; and the result is that men turn aside to pleasant disputations and discourses and roam as it were from object to object, rather than keep on a course of severe inquisition.
 580: 
 581: But, as I said at the beginning and am ever urging, the human senses and understanding, weak as they are, are not to be deprived of their authority, but to be supplied with helps.
 582: 
 583: LXVIII.
 584: 
 585: So much concerning the several classes of Idols, and their equipage: all of which must be renounced and put away with a fixed and solemn determination, and the understanding thoroughly freed and cleansed; the entrance into the kingdom of man, founded on the sciences, being not much other than the entrance into the kingdom of heaven, whereinto none may enter except as a little child.


====================================================================================================

  29: In Flanders now.

  34: 
  35: C.
  36:

   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]

   4: 
   5: The dog of work gnaws the day’s short bone,snarls a mountainside into lavender and green.
   6:

   8: 
   9: Element of pitcher, sky, rockface, blank canvasplastic and vast in one off-center patch.
  10: 
  11: To copy what’s invisible, to improvisea soul of things and remake solid lifeinto fresh anxious unlifelike form.

   4:

  12: 
  13: Then again, who wants to wake to change,its pulped, smelly suit of meat, drawing flies?
  14: 
  15: My night-watch hot girl, moon-maiden, mom,let me get just one night’s sleep without regret,released from your foxy ticklish fondlings,your latest smell of windblown fresh-cut grass.

  18:

   4: 
   5: 
   6: We feel somehow between usstill water crushed by that sea,so constant it seems not to be.
   7:

   9: 
  10: Northern harrier, owl face, they sea-changed your name,who listens with your faceand shows not love but want, speed, life in flight toward, forever toward,pausing at every chanceto use what ocean-bornbayside air sustains youby resisting you.

  13: 
  14: delivers us
  15: 
  16: to another amazed
  17: 
  18: agonized place.

   4:

  10:

   4: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

   6:

   8: 
   9: They drop on the blades of dormant grass.
  10: 
  11: They alight on the cobblestones and live awhile in silence, they dissolve before dawn.
  12: 
  13: The wet limestone walls of the mission glow proudly after the night of snowfall.

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 190: From Thy sanctuaries—Israel's God!—
 191: Giving strength and strong defences
 192: 150:   To the nation.
 193: 
 194: Blessed be God!

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 195: It has sometimes seemed to me as if the spirit of the psalms might be more livingly conveyed to English readers by a style somewhat akin to that which is here attempted.
 196: 
 197: These specimens indeed somewhat fail to bring out the strict parallelism of the original; but they retain in measure a numerous prose, and in the higher passages are helped by a faint colouring of rhyme.
 198: 
 199: These observations only apply to one aspect of the psalm—the poetical.
 200: 
 201: The sacred must be marked by the ecclesiastical rhyme, or by an archaic and majestic prose.

  75: Their own poor Little Jim.
  76: 
  77: This is a very typical ballad of "young life cut short".
  78: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  79: Notice that, although Little Jim's father is a coalminer, the thatched cottage he lives in is, of course, kept neat and spotless!!
  80: The death scene naturally entails inclement weather and equally predictable is the father's return from work just too late for his son's last moments.
  81: 
  82: The setting is reputed to be in Polesworth, near Tamworth
  83: Many irreverent parodies were written after this poem appeared; perhaps the best known being a version of the touching eighth stanza:
  84: "I have no pain, dear mother, now, .
  85: 
  86: But, oh, I am so dry;
  87: Connect me to a brewery
  88: And leave me there to die.

  66: In Russian folklore he is the most evil and most powerful antagonist.
  67: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  68: In England this folklore personage was transformed into Sauron by Tolkien and later into Lord Voldemort.
  69: 
  70: While his soul was alive Koschei remained immortal and his soul was concealed in a needle which was hid in an egg, which was hid in a duck, which was hid in a hare.
  71: 
  72: The hare was in a chest and the chest was buried under the very same green oak which grew in the bay on the island.
  73:

  77:

#1113: 155368_Man's Short Life and Foolish Ambition_Cavendish, Duchess of Newcastle Margaret_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Man's Short Life and Foolish Ambition
Author: Cavendish, Duchess of Newcastle Margaret
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 37.0
Avg prose line length: 125.6

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Man's Short Life and Foolish Ambition
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: In gardens sweet each flower mark did I,How they did spring, bud, blow, wither and die.
   4: 
   5: With that, contemplating of man's short stay,Saw man like to those flowers pass away.
   6: 
   7: Yet built he houses, thick and strong and high,As if he'd live to all Eternity.
   8: 
   9: Hoards up a mass of wealth, yet cannot fillHis empty mind, but covet will he still.
  10: 
  11: To gain or keep, such falsehood will he use!Wrong, right or truth—no base ways will refuse.
  12: 
  13: I would not blame him could he death out keep,Or ease his pains or be secure of sleep:Or buy Heaven's mansions—like the gods become,And with his gold rule stars and moon and sun:Command the winds to blow, seas to obey,Level their waves and make their breezes stay.
  14: 
  15: But he no power hath unless to die,And care in life is only misery.
  16: 
  17: This care is but a word, an empty sound,Wherein there is no soul nor substance found; Yet as his heir he makes it to inherit, And all he has he leaves unto this spirit.
  18: 
  19: To get this Child of Fame and this bare word,He fears no dangers, neither fire nor sword: All horrid pains and death he will endure,Or any thing can he but fame procure.
  20: 
  21: O man, O man, what high ambition growsWithin his brain, and yet how low he goes!To be contented only with a sound,Wherein is neither peace nor life nor body found.


====================================================================================================

Author: Cavendish, Duchess of Newcastle Margaret
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 13
Avg verse line length: 25.0
Avg prose line length: 108.3

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: An Apology For Her Poetry
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: I language want to dress my fancies in, The hair's uncurled, the garment's loose and thin.
   4: 
   5: Had they but silver lace to make them gay,They'd be more courted than in poor array; Or, had they art, would make a better show;But they are plain; yet cleanly do they go.
   6: 
   7: The world in bravery doth take delight,And glistering shows do more attract the sight: And every one doth honor a rich hood,As if the outside made the inside good.
   8: 
   9: And every one doth bow and give the place, Not for the man's sake but the silver lace.
  10: 
  11: Let me intreat in my poor book's behalf,That all will not adore the golden calf.
  12: 
  13: Consider, pray, gold hath no life therein,And life, in nature, is the richest thing.
  14: 
  15: Be just, let Fancy have the upper place,And then my verses may perchance find grace.

  36: 
  37: C.
  38:

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 572: 
 573: It was perfect, the golden solitude, the golden emptiness, Something-Or- Other, something surely humble.
 574: 
 575: There was a rapturous ring of silence abiding perfectly.
 576: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 577: There was no question of being alive or not being alive, of likes and dislikes, of near or far, no question of giving or gratitude, no question of mercy or judgment, or of suffering or its opposite or anything.
 578: 
 579: It was the womb itself, aloneness, alaya vijnana the universal store, the Great Free Treasure, the Great Victory, infinite completion, the joyful mysterious essence of Arrangement.
 580: 
 581: It seemed like one smiling smile, one adorable adoration, one gracious and adorable charity, everlasting safety, refreshing afternoon, roses, infinite brilliant immaterial gold ash, the Golden Age.
 582: 
 583: The 'golden' came from the sun in my eyelids, and the 'eternity' from my sudden instant realization as I woke up that I had just been where it all came from and where it was all returning, the everlasting So, and so never coming or going; therefore I call it the golden eternity but you can call it anything you want.
 584: 
 585: As I regained consciousness I felt so sorry I had a body and a mind suddenly realizing I didn't even have a body and a mind and nothing had ever happened and everything is alright forever and forever and forever, O thank you thank you thank you.
 586: 
 587: 65
 588: This is the first teaching from the golden eternity.
 589: 
 590: 66
 591: The second teaching from the golden eternity is that there never was a first teaching from the golden eternity.
 592: 
 593: So be sure.

#1118: 156236_Dialogues_Aretino, Pietro_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Dialogues
Author: Aretino, Pietro
Prose starts at line: 27
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 103.9
Avg prose line length: 225.5

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  22: 
  23: NANNA Because the reverend father summoned the three friars and leaning on the shoulder of one of them, a tall, soft-skinned rascal who had shot up prematurely, he ordered the others to take his little sparrow, which was resting quietly, out of its nest.
  24: 
  25: Then the most adept and attractive young fellow of the bunch cradled the General’s songster in the palm of his hand and began stroking its back, as one strokes the tail of a cat which first purrs, then pants, and soon cannot keep still.
  26: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  27: The sparrow lifted its crest, and then the doughty General grabbed hold of the youngest, prettiest nun, threw her tunic over her head, and made her rest her forehead against the back of the bed.
  28: 
  29: Then, deliberately prying open with his fingers the leaves of her ass-hole Missal and wholly rapt his thoughts, he contemplated her crotch, whose form was neither close to bone with leanness nor puffed out with fat, but something in between — rounded, quivering, glistening like a piece of ivory that seems instinct with life.
  30: 
  31: Those tiny dimples one sees on pretty women’s chins and cheeks could also be seen on her dainty buttocks, whose softness was softer than that of a mill mouse born and raised in flour, and that nuns limbs were all so smooth that a hand placed gently on her loins would have slid down her leg as quickly as a foot slides on ice, and hair no more dared grow on her than it would on an egg.
  32: 
  33: ANTONIA So the father General consumed his day in contemplation, eh?
  34: 
  35: NANNA:    No, I wouldn’t say he consumed it, because placing his paintbrush, which he first moistened with spit, in her tiny color cup, he made her twist and turn as women do in the birth throes or the mother’s malady.
  36: 
  37: And to be doubly sure that his nail would be driven more tightly into her slit, he motioned to his back and his favorite punk pulled his breeches down to his heels and applied his clyster to the reverend’s visibilium, while all the time the General himself kept his eyes fixed on the two other young louts, who, having settled the sisters neatly and comfortably on the bed, were now pounding the sauce in the mortar to the great despair of the last little sister.
  38: 
  39: Poor thing, she was so squint-eyed and swarthy that she had been spurned by all.
  40: 
  41: So, she filled the glass tool with water heated to wash the messer`s hands, sat on a pillow on the floor, pushed the soles of her feet against the cell wall, and then came straight down on that great crozier, burying in her body as a sword is thrust into a scabbard.
  42: 
  43: Overcome by the scent of pleasure, I was more worn out than pawns are frayed by usury, and began rubbing my dear little monkey with my hand like cats in January rub their backsides on a roof.
  44: 
  45: translated by Raymond Rosenthal, Stein and Day, New York, 1971)

   6: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

  12:

  14:

Lines to remove: 7
Avg verse line length: 39.9
Avg prose line length: 187.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  25: 
  26: So stands the splendid prodigy -- A scene
  27: Of individual and of British glory --
  28: And the rich meed has Gunby nobly earn'd.
  29: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  30: Written on John Gunby's Royal Clarence Vase, described by William Hone, 'An immense bason of copper, and its iron shaft, or foot, clothed with two thousand four hundred pieces of glass, contruct a vase fourteen feet high, twelve feet wide across the brim, weighing upwards of eight tons, and capable of holding eight pipes of wine.
  31: 
  32: Each piece of glass is richly cut with mathematical precision, and is beautifully colored; the colors are gold, ruby, and emerald, and they are enamelled upon one side of the glass.
  33: 
  34: These colored sides being cemented upon the metal body, and rendered perfectly air-tight in that junction, the exterior is a gem-like surface of inconceivable splendor.
  35: 
  36: ' ~ The Year Book of Daily Recreation and Information, August 24, 1831.

#1121: 157460_De Progress ob Progresshun!_Henderson, Elliott Blaine_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: De Progress ob Progresshun!
Author: Henderson, Elliott Blaine
Prose starts at line: 11
Lines to remove: 18
Avg verse line length: 11.4
Avg prose line length: 178.9

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   6: 
   7: W.
   8: 
   9: WOLF, Columbus Ohio.
  10: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  11: Feller citizens ob deez United States, an' extinguished constiterrunts ob de universal domain, an' ladies ob de world-wide expanse:
  12: Ah rize to declah, proclaim, eulogize, expulgate, frustercate, promulgate an' say:
  13: Parogorically on de effulgence ob de glorification an' transcendency ob de progress ob de progresshun ob de twentieth century; frum de time dat Lazarus tarnd Ravens into Buzzahds an' backed up de waters ob de Mississippi ocean, till dey rized so high dat de worl' was in kerclipse.
  14: 
  15: Dis am er wonderful century! Mos' excroosheatin'.
  16: 
  17: De age in which de posterity ob Adam views back an' down de bullervards ob de ages an' centuries, passed an' comin.
  18: 
  19: An' we find dat de bullervard am smoothed an' greased 'slick ez glass by de constant comin' an' passin' ob de various nations, in dey transactions an' doings, in excervatin' de worl'.
  20: 
  21: An' who froo de instrumentality ob providence hab vitooperrated an' sallervated de extremity ob time, necessarily, an' done captivated an' twisted erbout de pinacle ob astronomy an' oranized de horrerscope ob dooterronony an' navigation so enthusiastically in sich er way an' manner ez to digest an' disfranchise de proverbial state ob antiquity beyond de posserbillities ob non realization, an' precipitation.
  22: 
  23: Yes sah! dis am er great century! Puffeckly mahbellous! An' it devastates, capsizes an' precippertates mah abberrishes mentality, when ah tries to 'splore de great an' mysterical regions ob mystery, fillerbusterin' de reconstruction ob fundermental exclusion an' der jinein' hands wiff circumstances, catchin' de bull ob opposition by de tail an' dahby circumventin' an' preventin' de stoppin' ob de world's progress, an' frenollersizein' de frennerlogical conclusion ob valorism!
  24: An' ez Shakeerspire says we shall 'vance on an' on, till we run pass de stars.
  25: 
  26: Faster den race hosses.
  27: 
  28: Yea! faster den de kyars! De clouds ob oppesition will kerfrollic off wiff strife, an' we'll hab er gyarden ob eeden fo' all ob ah life.

Title: toon tune
Author: Morin, Gustave
Prose starts at line: 7
Lines to remove: 7
Avg verse line length: 37.7
Avg prose line length: 87.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   2: 
   3: gustave morin's primary form is the collage poem.
   4: 
   5: His "toon tune" is a remarkable piece of craftsmanship.
   6: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   7: Its sixty-three individual fragments of text are cut into the shapes of jigsaw puzzle pieces and are fit perfectly together in a rectangular grid.
   8: 
   9: The "words" of the poem consist almost entirely of the extravagant visualizations of onomatopoeia from comic books, producing a visual symphony of crashes and cries.
  10: 
  11: —Geof Huth
  12: 
  13: More About Visual Poetry >>

Avg verse line length: 21.9
Avg prose line length: 96.6

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  70: 
  71: No, rather better than ever.
  72: 
  73: Then why I am I in disarray?
  74: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  75: I know that God has done me a great honor, since I love the most beautiful of women and she me, as far as I know.
  76: 
  77: But I am elsewhere, and I do not know how she is, which kills me with sorrow, for I do not often have the opportunity to go there.
  78: 
  79: Now, Love, what shall I do?
  80: 
  81: Shall I ever be cured of you?
  82: 
  83: Right now I think I will die of the desire that comes upon me, if the fair one invites me to be near her, where she sleeps, so that I can caress and kiss and hold next to mine her body, white, round, and smooth.
  84: 
  85: Sweet lady, have pity on your faithful lover! Hands joined, head bowed, I commend myself to your mercy.
  86: 
  87: For I swear to you in faith that I have never loved anyone as much as you.
  88: 
  89: And if the right moment occurs, show me your best behavior, for I really desire it so.

  51: 
  52: (To better hide the dark thoughts and the pain, I sing and play around, I have pleasure and solace; I make an effort, because I know how to sing and laugh.
  53: 
  54: Still, I am dying, but show no sign of it, and by Love am so overcome, for Love has conquered me by force and battle.
  55: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  56: Never has God created martyrdom and travail that I could not undergo peacefully, except for lovesickness.
  57: 
  58: Still, although it weighs on me, I suffer it, for Love makes me love where he pleases.
  59: 
  60: And I say to you that if I am not loved, it is not the fault of my passivity.
  61: 
  62: I am the servant and friend and vassal of my lady, and I do not ask from her any other favor but this: secretly, to turn her fair eyes to me, for when I am distraught they do me much good.
  63: 
  64: In my heart I blame and accuse myself for following so my desires.
  65: 
  66: Noone should say such things, because we never know what our destiny will be.
  67: 
  68: What shall I do, then, with her beautiful, secret glances?
  69: 
  70: Shall I fail them?
  71: 
  72: Better that the world itself fail me.
  73: 
  74: Corona, I send greetings and love, and I pray my lady that she aid and assist me.

  93: — Pierre, if for two or three years the world were made as I would like, the ladies (I tell you the truth) would no longer be pursued.
  94:

  96: 
  97: — Bernard, it is not seeming for women to court, it is rather the man who pursues and asks for mercy.
  98: 
  99: Madder than he who sows in the sand, in my opinion, is he who denigrates their virtue, and such a man is badly educated.
 100: 
 101: — Pierre, my heart is very sad when I remember that false one who killed me, I know not why, unless it was because I loved her truly.
 102: 
 103: I have long been in quarantine, and if I prolonged it, I would find her worse still.
 104: 
 105: — Bernard, folly has gained you, for you leave off love, through which one gains worth and valor.
 106: 
 107: — Pierre, he who loves is mad, for the traitresses among them have undone joy and worth and valor.

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  62: Bel Vezer, si no fos
  63: mos enans totz en vos
  64: laissat agra chansos
  65: per mal dels enoyos.
  66: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  67: (The fair season of Easter, with new green, brings us leaves and flowers of various colors, so that all lovers are gay, and sing, except for me, weeping and lamenting, for I taste of no joy.
  68: 
  69: I make my case to you all, gentlefolk, against my lady and Love; for these two traitors, in whom I had trusted, make me live in sorrow, for all the good and honor I have done for the fair one, who neither values nor succors me.
  70: 
  71: Since the time when we were both children I love and court her.
  72: 
  73: And my love doubles evey day of the year.
  74: 
  75: And if we don't make love now and aren't friendly, she can just try asking later on, when we are old, if I feel like it.
  76: 
  77: Alas! What is life worth to me, if I cannot see every day my true, natural joy in bed, under the window, her body all white like the Christmas snow, so that in common we can take measure to see if we are equal?
  78: 
  79: It's the season henceforth, fair and precious lady, that in secret you give me a kiss as recompense, for no other reason than that I desire it.
  80: 
  81: For such a kiss is worth two of the other kind, those that are given by constraint.
  82: 
  83: Fair-to-See, if my welfare were not entirely dependent on you, I would have left off singing because of the meanness of the bluestockings.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 102: 
 103: And if I say what I think, I see my injuries doubled.
 104: 
 105: Whatever I do, or don't do, I can't accomplish for my own good.
 106: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 107: And if I love her in dishonor, I shall be scorned by all; and the majority will consider me a passive cuckold.
 108: 
 109: But if I lose her friendship, I hold myself disinherited by love, and may God never permit me again to compose verses and songs.
 110: 
 111: Since I am involved in madness, I should be mad if I did not chose the lesser of these two evils.
 112: 
 113: for it is better, in my opinion, to have half of her than to loose everything through folly; for I have never seen an unfaithful lover win out for himself in love.
 114: 
 115: Since you want another lover, my lady, I shall not forbid it.
 116: 
 117: And I agree more from fear than from anything else.
 118: 
 119: And if ever someone should be grateful for forced labor, I should be rewarded, who have pardoned so great a wrong.
 120: 
 121: With the water that flows from my eyes, I send greetings, more than a hundred, that I transmit to the most fair and noble one.
 122: 
 123: Often do I remember what she would do on parting — how she would cover her face, so that she would be saying neither yes nor no.
 124: 
 125: Garsio, now go and sing my song, and bring it to my Messenger, who was there, and to whom I demand what counsel he [she] would give.

#1129: 157550_Can vei la lauzeta_Ventadorn, Bernard De_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Can vei la lauzeta
Author: Ventadorn, Bernard De
Prose starts at line: 115
Lines to remove: 17
Avg verse line length: 30.1
Avg prose line length: 95.7

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 110: 
 111: I despair of women; never more shall I trust them.
 112: 
 113: As once I exalted them, now shall I cast them down.
 114: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 115: Since I see that not one of them is for me against she who destroys and confounds me, I doubt and mistrust them all, since I well know they are all the same.
 116: 
 117: And in this I see that my lady is very much a woman, and that is why I criticize her.
 118: 
 119: For she does not want that which she should want, and that which she is forbidden, she does.
 120: 
 121: I am fallen very low, and I have acted like the fool on the bridge.
 122: 
 123: And I don't know why this has happened to me, unless it's because I tried to mount too high.
 124: 
 125: Since nothing works any more with my lady — neither prayers nor pity nor my rights concerning her; and since it no longer pleases her that I love her, I will never more say it to her.
 126: 
 127: And so I take my leave and go away from her.
 128: 
 129: She has killed me, and I respond to her with death.
 130: 
 131: And I leave, since she doesn't retain me, I the unhappy one, into exile, I know not where.


====================================================================================================

  84:

  86:

  88: 
  89: Good are all the wrongs she does me, but I ask God one gift: that my mouth, which is fasting, receive from her a sweet kiss as break-fast.
  90: 
  91: I demand too great a reward of she who rewards so generously; and when I reason to her, she changes my reasons.
  92: 
  93: My reason changes and shifts, but I hardly change at all my faithful heart, which desires her so much that all my desires are for her for whom I sigh.
  94: 
  95: And since she does not sigh [for me], I know that in her my death is contemplated, when I contemplate her great beauty.
  96: 
  97: I contemplate my death, since I cannot pleasure in her and am not pleasured.
  98: 
  99: But I am such a good patient that I can await in patience.

 101:

 103: 
 104: This poem is perfectly made, without a single badly-made word, beyond the land of Normandy, beyound the wild and deep sea.
 105:

 107:

 109: 
 110: By grace of the king I am English, and Norman, and if it were not for My Magnet, I would remain here until after Christmas.

#1136: 157827_The Blacksmith_Lover, Samuel_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Blacksmith
Author: Lover, Samuel
Prose starts at line: 420
Lines to remove: 15
Avg verse line length: 47.0
Avg prose line length: 87.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 415: Such judges have been; in whom the suaviter in modo, fortiter in re, has rendered their sentences but more terrible.
 416: 
 417: 5.
 418: 
 419: 'Maybe God will be good to him--and he'll be dhrown'd!'

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 420: This passage may seem grotesque to the English reader, but not to those conversant with Ireland.
 421: 
 422: In the first place, there is a deep trust amongst the Irish people that 'the prayer of the innocent' is never unavailing.
 423: 
 424: In the second, the phrase 'God will be good to him,' is not of the author's making, but a national form of speech; and that a grant of Divine favour should be inferred from the anticipated fact of a man being drowned, is but one of those grotesque figures of speech that Ireland abounds in, but which, on investigation, and taken with the context, will be found to contain this meaning--that Heaven will grant the prayer of injured innocence.
 425: 
 426: 6.
 427: 
 428: 'Of that warning so terrible--'Vengeance is mine!''
 429: For it is written, Vengeance is mine, I will repay, saith the Lord
 430: 
 431: Romans
 432: xii.
 433: 
 434: 19

Title: Father Roach
Author: Lover, Samuel
Prose starts at line: 314

Avg verse line length: 49.1

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 309: ' As for a joke carrying reproof, that is a common mode of fence in Ireland, and no one understands it better than the Irish priest, himself a Celt, and 'to the manner born;' and many a tough fellow that would stand without flinching under a battery of serious rebuke, will wince under a witticism.
 310: 
 311: 7.
 312: 
 313: 'On potatoes, perhaps, or, at most, griddle bread;'

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 314: The domestic utensil called 'griddle' in Ireland, goes by the name of 'girdle' in Scotland, and is so spelt in Johnson's dictionary, with the definition 'a round iron plate for baking.
 315: 
 316: ' The griddle bread of Ireland is a flat cake of about an inch and a half in thickness, generally made of whole wheaten meal mixed with water and without yeast.
 317: 
 318: 8.
 319: 
 320: 'Would the murderer of Frank e'er confess to his brother?
 321: 
 322: Here was a very crafty culprit; for while to the senses of the world in general it would appear impossible that the murderer would have chosen the brother of his victim for his confessor, yet that very act was the surest to paralyze the action of the person most interested in making a discovery, for even if any chance had afterwards thrown in the priest's way a clue to the mystery, yet he, having been already entrusted with the fatal secret under 'the solemn seal of confession,' was precluded from making any use of it, as a word, or a look of his, indicating or suggesting even a suspicion in the true direction, would have been a violation of the sacred trust reposed in him.
 323: 
 324: The priest was, in fact, as the last line of the stanza states, committed 'To silent knowledge of guilty deed.
 325: 
 326: 9.
 327: 
 328: 'The daylight hears what thine arm hath done,'
 329: The moment the culprit made an
 330: open declaration
 331: of having committed murder, his words reached the ear of the priest under a new condition, and left him a free agent to publish the guilt.

#1146: 158928_Pernambuco in May_Roberts, Theodore Goodridge_unknown.txt

Prose starts at line: 51

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  46: 38.
  47: 
  48: Author's Note:
  49: The harbour and city of Pernambuco are behind a reef.
  50: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  51: The reef is topped by a brick wall built long ago, when the port was a possession of Holland, by workmen who knew their trade of raising barriers against the sea.
  52: 
  53: But the rollers of three hundred years have knocked a few holes in the good Dutch brickwork through which spray bursts upon the opaque green (and shark infested) waters of the harbour like the smoke of great guns and with a booming as of guns.
  54: 
  55: I was there in May, which is not the best time to visit Pernambuco.
  56: 
  57: Thanks to Frank Staplin
