[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  34: 
  35: Amen.
  36: 
  37: From THE LOST SHIPMATE: Poems of the Sea
  38: Author's Notes:

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  39: In the old days before the building of the light houses, the poor “noddies” of many a Newfoundland outport prayed for wrecks—aye, and with easy consciences.
  40: 
  41: Only a few hundreds of them who took to deep-sea voyaging ever learned anything of the world and its peoples.
  42: 
  43: All the world, excepting their own desolate bays and “down Nort”, was “up-along” to them.
  44: 
  45: Montreal, Pernambuco, London, Oporto, Boston, Halifax—all were included in up-along to them; and up-along was a grand, rich place where all men were gentlemen wearing collars and coats, eating figgy-duff every day and smoking all they wanted to.
  46: 
  47: The folk of up-along had the easy end of life; so why shouldn’t they contribute something of their goods and gear to poor but honest noddies now and then, even if against their inclinations—aye, even if at the cost of their lives?
  48: 
  49: The header graphic is painted by George Morland and is titled "The Wreckers," 1775.
  50: 
  51: Boston Museum of Fine Art, Boston, Massachusetts.
  52: 
  53: Charley Noble


====================================================================================================
#1148: 158945_Mermaids_Roberts, Theodore Goodridge_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Mermaids
Author: Roberts, Theodore Goodridge
Prose starts at line: 44
Lines to remove: 13
Avg verse line length: 31.9
Avg prose line length: 98.3

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  39: From THAT FAR RIVER: Selected Poems of Theodore Goodridge Roberts, edited by Martin Ware, © 1934, p.
  40: 
  41: 45.
  42: 
  43: Author's notes:

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  44: I am strong for mermaids, though I must admit that some of them are mischievously inclined.
  45: 
  46: I believe in them: but there are dusty professors, with long noses stuck into books, who argue that the whole mermaid tradition is founded on nothing more or other than seals glimpsed suddenly and unexpectedly by drunken sailors and fishermen.
  47: 
  48: Seals!  I have seen seals—and maybe I’ve seen mermaids.
  49: 
  50: Nobody but a fool, and certainly not a sailor with three sheets in the wind, would mistake a seal for a mermaid.
  51: 
  52: Some people are always trying to take such joys as mermaids and fairies out of our difficult lives.
  53: 
  54: But here are some verses which prove that mermaids are not seals.
  55: 
  56: Thanks to Frank Staplin

 100:

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 297: 
 298: 3 See the Dedication of his remarks on the Dunciad to Mr.
 299: 
 300: Lewis Theobald.
 301: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 302: 4 This sagacious scholiast is pleased to create an imaginary editor of Milton; who, he says, by the blunders, interpolations, and vile alterations, lost Paradise a second time.
 303: 
 304: This is a postulation which surely none of his readers can have the heart to deny him; because otherwise he would have wanted a fair opportunity of calling Milton himself, in the person of this phantom, fool, ignorance,  idiot, and the like critical compellations, which he plentifully bestows on him.
 305: 
 306: But though he had no taste in poetry, he was otherwise a man of very considerable abilities, and of great erudition.
 307: 
 308: 5 See a poem published some time ago under that title, said to be the production of several ngenious and prolific heads; one contributing a simile, another a character, and certain gentlemen four shrewd lines wholly made up of asterisks.
 309: 
 310: 6 See the preface to his edition of Sallust; and read, if you are able, the Scholia of sixteen annotations by him collected, besides his own.

#1151: 159129_The Canterbury Tales; EPILOGUE_Chaucer, Geoffrey_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Canterbury Tales; EPILOGUE
Author: Chaucer, Geoffrey
Prose starts at line: 59
Lines to remove: 12
Avg verse line length: 37.4
Avg prose line length: 72.3

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  54: Telle us som moral thyng that we may leere
  55: Som wit, and thanne wol we gladly heere!"
  56: "I graunte, ywis," quod he, "but I moot thynke
  57: Upon som honeste thyng, while that I drynke.
  58: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  59: Although this is a short chapter and misleading by title, it was used by Chaucer to connect the Phisicien and the Pardoner together.
  60: 
  61: For Chaucer's reasons he felt this needed a seperate chapter in this Prose story to connect the two.
  62: 
  63: If you have noticed, each character has an epilogue at the end of their story that connects the ending to the beginning of the next person.
  64: 
  65: Here Chaucer took and made the epilogue and expanded it between these two diverse personas.
  66: 
  67: the Pardoners tale
  68: oldpoetry.
  69: 
  70: com/poetry/40840

#1152: 159155_from Troilus and Criseyde- Book V_Chaucer, Geoffrey_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: from Troilus and Criseyde: Book V
Author: Chaucer, Geoffrey
Prose starts at line: 61
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 135.1
Avg prose line length: 261.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  56: 
  57: — The wrath, as I bigan yow for to sey e, Of Troilus, the Grekis boughten deere; For thousandes his hondes maden deye, As he that was with-outen any peere, Save Ector, in his tyme, as I kan heere.
  58: 
  59: But weilaway, save only Goddes wille! Despitously hym slough the fierse Achille.
  60: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  61: And whan that he was slayn in this maner e, His lighte goost ful blisfully is went Up to the holownesse of the eighthe spere, In convers letynge everich element; And ther he saugh, with ful avysement, The erratik sterres, herkenyng armonyeWith sown es fulle of hevenyssh melodie.
  62: 
  63: And doun from thenn es faste he gan avyseThis litel spot of erthe, that with the se Embrac ed is, and fully gan despiseThis wrecched world, and held al vanitee To respect of the pleyn feliciteeThat is in hevene above; and at the last e, Ther he was slayn, his lokyng doun he caste; And in hym-self he lough right at the wo Of hem that wepten for his deth so fast e; And dampned al oure werk that foloweth so The blynde lust, the which that may not laste, And sholden al our herte on heven caste.
  64: 
  65: And forth he wente, shortly for to telle, Ther as Mercúrye sorted hym to dwelle.
  66: 
  67: — Swich fyn hath, lo, this Troilus for lov e, Swich fyn hath al his grete worthynesse; Swich fyn hath his estat reál above, Swich fyn his lust, swich fyn hath his noblesse: Swich fyn hath false worldes brotelnesse! And thus bigan his lovyng of Criseyde, As I have told, and in this wise he deyde.
  68: 
  69: O yong e fresshe folkes, he or she, In which that love up groweth with your age, Repeyreth hoom fro worldly vanytee, And of youre herte up-casteth the visageTo thilk e God that after his ymageYow made, and thynketh al nys but a fair eThis world, that passeth soone as flour es faire.
  70: 
  71: And loveth hym, the which that right for lov eUpon a crois, oure soul es for to beye, First starf, and roos, and sit in hevene above; For he nyl falsen no wight, dar I seye, That wol his herte al holly on him leye.
  72: 
  73: And sin he best to love is, and most meke, What nedeth feynede loves for to seke?
  74: 
  75: Lo here, of payens cors ed olde rites, Lo here, what alle hir goddes may availle; Lo here, thise wrecched worldes appetites; Lo here, the fyn and guerdoun for travailleOf Jove, Appollo, of Mars, of swich rascaill e! Lo here, the forme of olde clerkis specheIn poetrie, if ye hir bok es seche.
  76: 
  77: — O moral Gower, this book I direct eTo the, and to the, philosophical Strod e, To vouchen sauf, ther nede is, to correcte, Of youre benignitees and zeles goode.
  78: 
  79: And to that sothfast Crist, that starf on rode, With al myn herte of mercy evere I preye; And to the Lord right thus I speke and seye: Thou oon, and two, and three, eterne on lyv e, That regnest ay in three, and two, and oon, Uncircumscript, and al maist circumscrive, Us from visible and invisible foon Defende; and to thy mercy, everichon, So make us, Jesus, for thi mercy digne, For love of mayde and moder thyn benigne! Amen.

   1: The cars
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]

   3: Sprinting across the freeway just ahead of them having set his left foot downdirectly onto the pavement from the ledge of the cement divide and edging hisother leg forward deliberately—caught the way sports pages show an athlete withmuscles condensed in the effort of crossing through a particular space—and thenshe sees the cars coming towards him giving off that early morning shine acrosstheir hoods almost colorless but precipitous in the four-lane parallel rush of metaland cannot tell if any driver straining into the distance further ahead has seen himor possibly has caught that glint off the long black flashlight he appears to carrywith its up-beam turned on full and faintly visible due to the angle of early sunfalling over the midwestern plains fanning out in every direction away from thesudden view of the airport hub’s acclaimed architectural design.
   4: 
   5: She sees the brief alignment of his body methodically finding its way across thefreeway lanes blue baseball cap fit snugly over his head to just above the hairlinewhere now dusky skin of his neck breaks into the picture.
   6: 
   7: He’s made it halfway,she thinks, but she can’t stop the cars rushing towards him even as he scans withconcentration the worn lanes for the thing he’s lost as if he’s walking through thedark and shining his flashlight wherever the object might have landed, his rightknee   still lifting purposefully upward and forward.
   8: 
   9: — for C.
  10: 
  11: W.

#1155: 159501_The Tollund Man_Heaney, Seamus_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Tollund Man
Author: Heaney, Seamus
Prose starts at line: 61
Lines to remove: 11
Avg verse line length: 25.5
Avg prose line length: 186.5

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  56: 
  57: *Heaney purposely writes that he will go to Aarhus to see the Tollund Man even though he knows that he is on display in Silkeborg, Denmark.
  58: 
  59: But in Heaney's opinion "Aarhus" goes better with the metrical feet.
  60: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  61: The famous Irish poet and Nobel Prize winner Seamus Heaney wrote an extract of his famous poem "The Tollund Man" in the guest book for Silkeborg Museum in 1973.
  62: 
  63: Seamus Heaney gave a talk at Silkeborg Museum in 1996, where he described his childhood memories of the bog:
  64: "When I was a child and an adolescent I lived among peat-diggers and I also worked in the peat bog myself.
  65: 
  66: I loved the structure the peat bank revealed after the spade had worked its way through the surface of the peat.
  67: 
  68: I loved the mystery and silence of the place when the work was done at the end of the day and I would stand there alone while the larks became quiet and the lapwings started calling, while a snipe would suddenly take off and disappear.
  69: 
  70: 
  71: About his poem - Bogland - Seamus Heaney told the following: "The title of the poem refers to the bogs I knew while I was growing up and the stories I had heard about the things that could be preserved in the bog such as supplies of butter that were kept there, and about the things that were even more astonishing to a child, such as the skeleton of an Irish elk which our neighbours had dug out".

#1162: 159832_Voices Of The Night - A Psalm Of Life_Longfellow, Henry Wadsworth_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Voices Of The Night : A Psalm Of Life
Author: Longfellow, Henry Wadsworth
Prose starts at line: 51
Lines to remove: 18
Avg verse line length: 30.4
Avg prose line length: 75.4

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  46: 
  47: The lyrical form of this poem is abab.
  48: 
  49: "Mr.
  50: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  51: Longfellow said of this poem: 'I kept it some time in manuscript, unwilling to show it to any one, it being a voice from my inmost heart, at a time when I was rallying from depression.
  52: 
  53: ' Before it was published in the Knickerbocker Magazine, October, 1838, it was read by the poet to his college class at the close of a lecture on Goethe.
  54: 
  55: Its title, though used now exclusively for this poem, was originally, in the poet's mind, a generic one.
  56: 
  57: He notes from time to time that he has written a psalm, a psalm of death, or another psalm of life.
  58: 
  59: The 'psalmist' is thus the poet himself.
  60: 
  61: When printed in the Knickerbocker it bore as a motto the lines from Crashaw:
  62: Life that shall send
  63: A challenge to its end,
  64: And when it comes, say, Welcome, friend.
  65: 
  66: 13.
  67: 
  68: This line is a translation of "Ars longa vita brevis est" (an aphorism by Hippocrates).

 102: 
 103: *** Our ancestors dedicated the inventions of their wisdom to this deity, inscribing all their own writings with the name of Hermes.
 104: 
 105: --- Iamblichus.

#1165: 159950_The Blind Girl Of Castel-Cuille. (From The Gascon of Jasmin)_Longfellow, Henry Wadsworth_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Blind Girl Of Castel-Cuille.  (From The Gascon of Jasmin)
Author: Longfellow, Henry Wadsworth
Prose starts at line: 453
Lines to remove: 18
Avg verse line length: 35.4
Avg prose line length: 91.3

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 448: 'Only the Lowland tongue of Scotland might
 449: Rehearse this little tragedy aright:
 450: Let me attempt it with an English quill;
 451: And take, O reader, for the deed the will.
 452: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 453: Jasmin, the author of this beautiful poem, is to the South of France what Burns is to the South of Scotland - the represenative of the heart of the people, -- one of those happy bards who are born with their mouths full of birds (la bouco pleno d'aouzelous).
 454: 
 455: He has written his own biography in a poetic form, and the simple narrative of his poverty, his struggles, and his triumphs, is very touching.
 456: 
 457: He still lives at Agen, on the Garonne; and long may he live there to delight his native land with native songs!
 458: Those who may feel interested in knowing something about 'Jasmin, Coiffeur' -- for such is his calling -- will find a description of his person and mode of life in the graphic pages of Bearn and the Pyrenees (vol.
 459: 
 460: i.
 461: 
 462: p.
 463: 
 464: 369, et seq.
 465: 
 466: ) by Louisa Stewart Costello, whose charming pen has done so much to illustrate the French provinces and their literature.
 467: 
 468: ~ Longfellow's Poetical Works, pb.
 469: 
 470: Routledge, 1883.

  76: 
  77: These indomitables came half way round the globe at Britain's first call.
  78: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

  80:

  82: 
  83: They have won fame and the world's admiration as the "Anzacs.
  84: 
  85: " a word made by running together the first letters of their official title.
  86: 
  87: Australia's own name for her soldier is Bill--Jim.
  88: 
  89: 'The Graves of Gallipoli" is one of the most noble and tender poems that have come to us out of the war.

#1170: 160260_A Convict's Lament on the Death of Captain Logan_Oceania, Anonymous_unknown.txt

Title: A Convict's Lament on the Death of Captain Logan
Author: Oceania, Anonymous
Prose starts at line: 59
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 38.2
Avg prose line length: 100.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  54: 
  55: Fellow prisoners be exhilerated;
  56: your former sufferings you will not mind,
  57: for it's when from bondage you are extricated
  58: you'll leave such tyrants far behind!

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  59: Captain Patrick Logan was Commandant at Moreton Bay penal settlement from 1825 until his death in 1830.
  60: 
  61: It is said that this man incurred the hatred of every convict in the settlement because of his harsh discipline.
  62: 
  63: (this is presumed to be from the convicts point of view)
  64: Patrick Logan was in many ways quite an extraordinary man.
  65: 
  66: He was a Queensland explorer who discovered the Logan River, climbed Mounty Lindsay and covered much of Brisbane Valley on his trips; it was on one of these explorations that he was killed on 17th October, 1830.
  67: 
  68: As he was alone it is not known if Aboriginals or Convicts murdered him.
  69: 
  70: In modern times there is a Water Retention Dam called 'Wivenhoe' covering much of the land where Logan travelled and one point of this Dam is known as 'Logan's Inlet',  presumed to be the place where Logan met his death.
  71: 
  72: Emu Plains: A penal settlement about 36 miles from sydney on the Nepean river.
  73: 
  74: This was established in 1820 as an agricultural project for convicts.
  75: 
  76: Port Macquarie: Became a penal station in 1823
  77: Castle Hill and Toongabbie" 2 penal settlements outside Parramatta, a Sydney suburb.

 105:

#1174: 160874_Yanko, The Noble Negro_Upham, Thomas Cogswell_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Yanko, The Noble Negro
Author: Upham, Thomas Cogswell
Prose starts at line: 187
Lines to remove: 11
Avg verse line length: 31.6
Avg prose line length: 131.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 182: Whate'er his color, man is man,
 183: A negro's heart like any other;
 184: And Heaven, in its capacious plan,
 185: Bids us to treat him as a brother.
 186: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 187: [The incidents, which are the foundation of the following stanzas, are matters of fact, and not mere poetical fiction.
 188: 
 189: A few years since, two children were left by an English gentleman on board a vessel, in the care of a negro, who belonged to his family.
 190: 
 191: His object in leaving them was merely to make a short visit to another vessel, in the expectation of returning very soon.
 192: 
 193: In the mean time a storm arose, and the vessel, in which the children were, was wrecked.
 194: 
 195: The children, however, were saved through the disinterested kindness of the negro, who, in order that room might be made for them in the boat which conveyed the survivors, willingly and cheerfully remained on the wreck, and perished.
 196: 
 197: -- Some notices of this affecting story may be found in Roberts's Memoirs of Miss Hannah Moore.

#1176: 160902_The Old House_Upham, Thomas Cogswell_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Old House
Author: Upham, Thomas Cogswell
Prose starts at line: 321
Lines to remove: 9
Avg verse line length: 39.6
Avg prose line length: 135.6

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 316: But who hath gained by yielding to despair?
 317: 
 318: I'll wipe my tears, with half my story told,
 319: And take my Pilgrim staff, now the Old House is sold.
 320: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 321: [One of the painful things of this life, is its frequent and necessary separations.
 322: 
 323: As a general thing, no one leaves the home of his fathers, the place of his early experiences and associations, without regret.
 324: 
 325: But this regret is often alleviated by the consideration, that he may occasionally return and renew for a time the pleasures of his youth.
 326: 
 327: It becomes, therefore, an exceedingly painful moment, when he learns, as is sometimes the case, that the place of his childhood's residence, either in consequence of death or misfortune, has passed into other hands.
 328: 
 329: -- From that moment he feels, that one of the strong ties, which bound him to earth and its happiness, is sundered.

 232: O'er ruined home and bleeding heart.
 233: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 234: 'Colonel Isaac Hayne, of South Carolina, was a valuable and distinguished officer of the Revolution.
 235: 
 236: He was taken prisoner by the British, under the command of Lord Rawdon; and though great interest was made in his behalf, both by Englishmen and Americans, he was executed as a Rebel.
 237: 
 238: His wife had died but a short time before.
 239: 
 240: His eldest son, a boy of thirteen, was permitted to stay with his father in the prison; but he was so shocked and overcome at the execution as to become insane.
 241: 
 242: See the Life of Marion and Thacher's Military Journal.
 243: 
 244: ' ~ American Cottage Life.
 245: 
 246: A Series of Poems, 2nd edition, 1851.

#1182: 160961_The Winter Evening_Upham, Thomas Cogswell_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Winter Evening
Author: Upham, Thomas Cogswell
Prose starts at line: 374
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 41.2
Avg prose line length: 143.6

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 369: Recall the happy faces once so dear,
 370: Recall the Winter Eve, and all its social cheer.
 371: 
 372: [The Winter Evening constitutes in the Farmer's life, more truly and emphatically than in the life of any other class of persons, a period by itself, a select season, a portion of time, known and recognized by its distinctive traits, and blessed with its peculiar pleasuress.
 373: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 374: It is a season of the year, when there is, to a considerable extent, a relaxation from that constant toil, which occupies him in the more genial months.
 375: 
 376: He is at home, in the bosom of his family; and in the exercise and interchange of domestic feelings enjoys a degree of humble happiness, which the wealthy and luxurious have but little conception of.
 377: 
 378: We have here, therefore, a distinct and interesting subject, which, poetry, coming from a heart that can understand and fully sympathize with rural life, may properly and successfully adopt as its own.
 379: 
 380: Stanza XXII: Passaconaway: This is the name of a distinguished Indian Sachem, residing at the place known by the Indian name of Penacook, whose dominions, chiefly upon the banks of the Merrimack and Piscatawa rivers, were very extensive.
 381: 
 382: "He excelled the other Sachems," says Belknap, in his history of New Hampshire, Vol.
 383: 
 384: 1.
 385: 
 386: chap.
 387: 
 388: 5, "in sagacity, duplicity, and moderation; but his principle qualification was his skill in some of the secret operations of nature, which gave him the reputation of a sorcerer, and extended his fame and influence among all the neighboring tribes.
 389: 
 390: They believed that it was in his power to make water burn, and trees dance, and to metamorphose himself into a flame; that in winter he could raise a green leaf from the ashes of a dry one, adn a living serpent from the skin of one that was dead.
 391: 
 392: Stanza XXV: 'Seogee: The Lake Winnipisseogee in New Hampshire.

 147: Woolsey's Pallace: Cardinal Wolsey built Hampton Court Palace, but later offered it to Henry VIII, in an attempt to retain kingly favour.

 153: Marlbrough's : The Duke of Marlborough, considered a Whig profiteer by many Tories, began building Blenheim in 1705.
 154: 
 155: It was still unfinished 15 years later.

   4: 
   5: This summer she’s starting a novel.
   6: 
   7: It’s in trouble already.
   8: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   9: The characters are easy—a girl and her friend who is a girl and the boy down the block with his first car,   an older boy, sixteen, who sometimes these warm evenings leaves his house to go dancing   in dressy clothes though it’s still light out.
  10: 
  11: The girl has a brother who has lots of friends,   is good in math, and just plain good which   doesn’t help the story.
  12: 
  13: The story should have rescues & escapes in it which means who’s the bad guy; he couldn’t be   the brother or the grandpa or the father either, or even the boy down the block with his first car.
  14: 
  15: People in novels have to need something, she thinks, that it takes about two hundred pages to get.
  16: 
  17: She can’t imagine that.
  18: 
  19: Nothing she needs can be got; if it could she’d go get it: the answer to nightmares; a mother who’d be proud of her; doing things   a mother could be proud of; having hips & knowing how to squeal at the beach laughing when the boy down the block picked her up & carried her   & threw her in the water.
  20: 
  21: If she’d laughed   squealing he might still take her swimming   & his mother wouldn’t say she’s crazy, she would   not have got her teeth into his shoulder till   well yes she bit him, and the marks lasted & lasted, his mother said so,   but that couldn’t be in a novel.
  22: 
  23: She’ll never squeal laughing, she’d never not bite him, she hates cute girls, she hates   boys who like them.
  24: 
  25: Biting is embarrassing and wrong & she has no intention of doing it again   but she would if he did if he dared, and there’s no story if there’s no hope of change.

  24:

  58:

  60:

  62:

  64: 
  65: Yates, in 1891, I at once set it to mu­sic.

   1: Two Traveling Together
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]

   3: I came to encounter a coyoteI left all sorts of things behindYou couldn’t get on a plane unless you traveled lightBack then there were weight restrictions for planes, they don’t have them any longer, American bodies have no restrictions, they’ve become so big that there aren’t restrictions on the weight of bodies or luggage any more, but back then, I can’t even count how many times I picked up my bags and stepped on the scale, no matter how many times I weighed myself, I still wasn’t the least bit lighterNot knowing what else to do, I took out my booksThen I took out my clothesThen I went to the bathroom and defecatedThen I took out more clothesThen I threw upThen I took out more booksThen I stripped off all my clothes, held my bag, and stood on the scale, but I wasn’t the least bit lighterKnow what I mean?
   4: 
   5: That’s what it means to go on a tripThat’s what it means to leave the place where you liveTrips and then more tripsThere are things you need to carry with you to surviveNot knowing what else to do, I called my husband, filed for divorce, talked to my children and told them Mommy wouldn’t be home for a while, in other words, it was only after I abandoned my relationships, my attachments, and even my language that I was light enough to get on the plane, when I arrived, all I had was a few changes of clothes, some cash, my passport, my visa waiver, my credit cards, and an  international driver’s licenseIn California, the sky was blue, there was nothing but seashore, wild land, and housing developments, it was hazy and hard to see in the evenings, it was as if everything was immersed in mother’s milk, my toes got cold, I bought some socks, but after wearing them three days, the cheap things were ready to fall apart, I looked long and hard at them, feeling like a coyote(Yeah, I tell people I came aloneBut that is not entirely trueI was always thinking about the coyoteThe two of us traveling together)I saw dead raccoonsI saw dead skunksI smelled them tooSomeone I met the first day said to meThe whole place smells like skunk, must be a dead one somewhereIt was an unfamiliar scent, but now I know it wellThe whole place smells like skunk, must be a dead one somewhereI know to say that to people nowIn any case, I didn’t seeAny coyotes(Two traveling together)Someone in the streetTold me to get the hell out of hereWhy had I come?
   6: 
   7: I couldn’t find what I wanted, I had come so far but,get the hell out, this isn’t the place where the coyotes are, they’re farther away, in deeper places, where there is nothing, where there is much more emptinessSo I headed eastFrom the western edge of the continent to the eastThe interstatesWith odd numbers run north and southWhile even numbers run east and westThose in the 500s are the bypasses for I-5 (north-south)Those in the 800s are the bypasses for I-8 (east-west)I took I-5 south to I-580I went further south to I-8 then went eastEast, east, eastAnd even further eastIn Arizona, I took I-17At Flagstaff, I took US Route 89I dashed into a roadside motel, slept, and wokeAnd started driving againThe morning light shone brilliantlyEach time I stopped to fill up with gas, I bought some brownies, each individually wrapped, I tore off the wrappers with one hand and ate them as I drove, the ridiculously sweet lumps stuck to the roof  of my mouth, when I stopped in front of a motel that night, my fingers didn’t want to leave the steering wheel, at the registration desk, the words I needed to say in English didn’t rise to my lips, even though  I knew them all too well(Two traveling together)There was a woman standing at the side of the road, I called out to her in broken English, asking her what was the matter, she answered in what was also broken EnglishWould you mind taking me to the nearest gas station?
   8: 
   9: She sat in the passenger’s seatI’m NavajoWhere are you from?
  10: 
  11: From California, I answeredNo, that’s not what I meantWhat tribe are you from?
  12: 
  13: she asked(Two traveling together)From Kayenta I took US Route 163 toward Monument ValleyI had heard that coyotes lived there long agoThat it’s an amazing place, the moon rises, the sun setsI imagined it would be like seeing the oceanBut when I got there, it wasn’t like the ocean at allRocks soared into the airRocks, rocks, even more rocksRed rocksIn the dustI watched the sun set over themBy the time I got back to Route 163, the sun had sunk deep beyond the horizon, the only thing I could see was the road in front of me,  I drove on looking for a place to sleep, but I didn’t see a thing, there wasn’t anything to see, air rushed through my cracked window,  letting out a long, thin, high-pitched whistleHii-iuu-uuuuuHii-iuu-uuuuuLike a reed fluteMy thin, hard window was slightly open, the wind rushed in but couldn’t escapeHii-iuuuUuu-uuuuuUuu-hiiuuuuu(Two of us heard it)I drove a long way before spying a large motel, I saw the vacancy sign as I approached, I thought I’d have to drive for hours and hours before finding a place to sleep, I thought I wouldn’t stop, that I’d drive all night without stopping, but the place I found was part of a chain you see in every city, the bed was big and deep, and there was lots of hot water in the tub(Two of us were there)The next morningThe car was completely filthyThe whole thing was covered with bright red dirt and sandThe windshield was covered with the splattered bodies of countless insectsNo one knew I had slept there, nor that I was leaving, nor which direction I was headed, no one knewIt was a day that invitedDeath along the roadsideI hadn’t even driven for five minutes before I saw it —A single, dead coyoteLying on its back, legs in the air(It was both me andMy travel companion, too)

Title: After The Marne, Joffre Visited The Front By Car
Author: Marinetti, Filippo Tommaso
Prose starts at line: 10
Lines to remove: 13
Avg verse line length: 26.6
Avg prose line length: 95.4

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   5: parole in liberte
   6: (words in freedom).
   7: 
   8: Often realized as collages,
   9: Marinetti

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  10: 's poems are dissonant compositions with nonsense words in various typefaces and sizes meandering freely about the page, resulting in a chaotic pattern.
  11: 
  12: He distorted, stretched, and fragmented words, so that they lost all connection to their original meaning.
  13: 
  14: This offering is designed like a military map.
  15: 
  16: The letter forms M and S dominate this composition.
  17: 
  18: M refers to the word "Marne" (location of the battle) and portrays the outline of mountains.
  19: 
  20: The S renders the curves of the Seine River surrounding Paris and are supposed to evoke the spirals of the reverses in military strategy.
  21: 
  22: Smaller surrounding text recalls the sounds and formations within a military battle.

Prose starts at line: 88
Lines to remove: 9
Avg verse line length: 32.6
Avg prose line length: 127.4

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  83: "Oppressed by might, and want and care,
  84: Meekly subdued" the "men," we hear,
  85: But bravely, and without a fear,
  86: The women wear the buttons.
  87: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  88: In the aftermath of the Southern defeat, almost anything that smacked of the Confederacy was forbidden, including Rebel flags, uniforms, and military insignia.
  89: 
  90: Uniform buttons were included in the ban and had to be either covered with fabric or removed entirely from a garment.
  91: 
  92: Buttons immediately became a coveted item among the ladies, who did, indeed, make jewlery from them.
  93: 
  94: One of the more spectacular sets consists of a necklace, bracelet, and earrings made entirely from the buttons of well-known generals and staff officers and is on display in the Museum of the Confederacy.
  95: 
  96: This poem was first published in The Metropolitan Record.

#1193: 161944_Plaint in a Major Key_Sánchez, Jorge_unknown.txt

Author: Sánchez, Jorge
Prose starts at line: 19
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 55.0
Avg prose line length: 105.5

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  14: 
  15: Life blooms amid the Ten Thousand Things, but does not bloom amid the Ten Thousand Things.
  16: 
  17: Shrivel-eyed I wake up and tend to the One here and now, clamoring to be let out.
  18: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  19: Down with the gate, out with the boy, to the rooms of life’s necessities, first to void and next to fill.
  20: 
  21: The Order is only order which is disorder, the only Disorder is the disorder that is order.
  22: 
  23: We usher ourselves, each in our own way, back down the way for various brushings, combings, other groomings.
  24: 
  25: Each in our own way we urge the other toward some kind of growth: one to assume, the other   to renounce; one to grow larger, the other to grow smaller, thereby growing larger.
  26: 
  27: Words do not work, and when they do not, other words might.
  28: 
  29: This makes more sense than it seems, works more often than it doesn’t, except when it really doesn’t, and then that disorder creeps back in.
  30: 
  31: In five minutes, a different challenge.
  32: 
  33: In five hours, a different One.
  34: 
  35: Six more hours, the One is rubbing eyes, untangled like a dragon, shucked and undone like an oyster.
  36: 
  37: The night slowly rolls abed and the words form stories form sleep, the sleep of the Ten Thousand Things, the sleep that will echo the next day in the night’s rumbling sounds, in the bright light of morning.

   2: 
   3: It's a rush, a sploosh of sewage, twenty thousand cubic metres being pumped in, stirred and settled out and wasted off, looped back, macerated, digested, clarified and returned to the river.
   4: 
   5: I'm used to the idea.
   6: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   7: I fork the screenings out—a stink-mass of loopaper and whathaveyou, rags, cotton buds, you name it.
   8: 
   9: I measure the intake through a flume and if there's too much, I waste it off down the stormflow, it's not my problem.
  10: 
  11: When you think of all the milk we get from Unigate, fats and proteins and detergents foaming up and the rain and all the public sewers pumping in all day, it's like a prisoner up to his neck in water in a cell with only a hand-pump to keep himself conscious, the whole place is always on the point of going under.
  12: 
  13: So we only treat the primary flow, we keep it moving up these screws, we get the solids settled out and then push the activated sludge back through.
  14: 
  15: Not much I can do.
  16: 
  17: I walk on metal grilles above smelly water, I climb the ladder, I stand on a bridge above a brown lagoon, little flocs of sludge and clarified liquor spilling over the edge of the outer circle.
  18: 
  19: The bridge is turning very slowly, sweeping the spill-off round and I'm thinking illicit sneaking thoughts—no one can see me up here, just me and machinery and tiny organisms.
  20: 
  21: I'm in charge as far as Dartmoor, the metabolism of the whole South West, starting with clouds and flushing down through buildings and bodies into this underground grid of pipes, all ending up with me up here on my bridge—a flare of methane burning off blue at one end of the works and a culvert of clean water discharging out the other end, twenty BOD, nine ammonia, all the time, as and when

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   2: 
   3: All hail to the Rev.
   4: 
   5: George Gilfillan of Dundee, He is the greatest preacher I did ever hear or see.
   6: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   7: He is a man of genius bright, And in him his congregation does delight, Because they find him to be honest and plain, Affable in temper, and seldom known to complain.
   8: 
   9: He preaches in a plain straightforward way, The people flock to hear him night and day, And hundreds from the doors are often turn’d away, Because he is the greatest preacher of the present day.
  10: 
  11: He has written the life of Sir Walter Scott, And while he lives he will never be forgot, Nor when he is dead, Because by his admirers it will be often read; And fill their minds with wonder and delight, And wile away the tedious hours on a cold winter’s night.
  12: 
  13: He has also written about the Bards of the Bible, Which occupied nearly three years in which he was not idle, Because when he sits down to write he does it with might and main, And to get an interview with him it would be almost vain, And in that he is always right, For the Bible tells us whatever your hands findeth to do, Do it with all your might.
  14: 
  15: Rev.
  16: 
  17: George Gilfillan of Dundee, I must conclude my muse, And to write in praise of thee my pen does not refuse, Nor does it give me pain to tell the world fearlessly, that when You are dead they shall not look upon your like again.

#1199: 162973_The Little Match Girl_W, Knight of the White Elephant of Burma_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Little Match Girl
Author: W, Knight of the White Elephant of Burmah
Prose starts at line: 5
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 107.5
Avg prose line length: 189.5

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: The Little Match Girl
   2: 
   3: It was biting cold, and the falling snow, Which filled a poor little match girl’s heart with woe, Who was bareheaded and barefooted, as she went along the street, Crying, “Who’ll buy my matches?
   4: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   5: for I want pennies to buy some meat!” When she left home she had slippers on; But, alas! poor child, now they were gone.
   6: 
   7: For she lost both of them while hurrying across the street, Out of the way of two carriages which were near by her feet.
   8: 
   9: So the little girl went on, while the snow fell thick and fast; And the child’s heart felt cold and downcast, For nobody had bought any matches that day, Which filled her little mind with grief and dismay.
  10: 
  11: Alas! she was hungry and shivering with cold; So in a corner between two houses she made bold To take shelter from the violent storm.
  12: 
  13: Poor little waif! wishing to herself she’d never been born.
  14: 
  15: And she grew colder and colder, and feared to go home For fear of her father beating her; and she felt woe-begone Because she could carry home no pennies to buy bread, And to go home without pennies she was in dread.
  16: 
  17: The large flakes of snow covered her ringlets of fair hair; While the passers-by for her had no care, As they hurried along to their homes at a quick pace, While the cold wind blew in the match girl’s face.
  18: 
  19: As night wore on her hands were numb with cold, And no longer her strength could her uphold, When an idea into her little head came: She’d strike a match and warm her hands at the flame.
  20: 
  21: And she lighted the match, and it burned brightly, And it helped to fill her heart with glee; And she thought she was sitting at a stove very grand; But, alas! she was found dead, with a match in her hand! Her body was found half-covered with snow, And as the people gazed thereon their hearts were full of woe; And many present let fall a burning tear Because she was found dead on the last night of the year, In that mighty city of London, wherein is plenty of gold— But, alas! their charity towards street waifs is rather cold.
  22: 
  23: But I hope the match girl’s in Heaven, beside her Saviour dear, A bright reward for all the hardships she suffered here.


====================================================================================================
#1200: 162975_Descriptive Jottings of London_W, Knight of the White Elephant of Burma_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Descriptive Jottings of London
Author: W, Knight of the White Elephant of Burmah
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 30.0
Avg prose line length: 219.3

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Descriptive Jottings of London
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: As I stood upon London Bridge and viewed the mighty throng Of thousands of people in cabs and ’busses rapidly whirling along, All furiously driving to and fro, Up one street and down another as quick as they could go: Then I was struck with the discordant sound of human voices there, Which seemed to me like wild geese cackling in the air: And the river Thames is a most beautiful sight, To see the steamers sailing upon it by day and by night.
   4: 
   5: And the Tower of London is most gloomy to behold, And the crown of England lies there, begemmed with precious stones and gold; King Henry the Sixth was murdered there by the Duke of Glo’ster, And when he killed him with his sword he called him an impostor.
   6: 
   7: St.
   8: 
   9: Paul’s Cathedral is the finest building that ever I did see, There’s no building can surpass it in the city of Dundee, Because it’s magnificent to behold, With its beautiful dome and spire glottering like gold.
  10: 
  11: And as for Nelson’s Monument that stands in Trafalgar Square, It is a most stately monument I most solemnly declare, And towering defiantly very high, Which arrests strangers’ attention while passing by.
  12: 
  13: Then there’s two beautiful water-fountains spouting up very high, Where the weary traveller can drink when he feels dry; And at the foot of the monument there’s three bronze lions in grand array, Enough to make the stranger’s heart throb with dismay.
  14: 
  15: Then there’s Mr Spurgeon, a great preacher, which no one dare gainsay, I went to hear him preach on the Sabbath-day, And he made my heart feel light and gay, When I heard him preach and pray.
  16: 
  17: And the Tabernacle was crowded from ceiling to floor, And many were standing outside the door; He is an eloquent preacher I honestly declare, And I was struck with admiration as on him I did stare.
  18: 
  19: Then there’s Petticoat Lane I venture to say, It’s a wonderful place on the Sabbath-day; There wearing-apparel can be bought to suit the young or old, For the ready cash, silver, coppers, or gold.
  20: 
  21: Oh! mighty city of London! you are wonderful to see, And thy beauties no doubt fill the tourist’s heart with glee; But during my short stay, and while wandering there, Mr Spurgeon was the only man I heard speaking proper English I do declare.


====================================================================================================
#1201: 162976_The Burial of the Rev. George Gilfillan_W, Knight of the White Elephant of Burma_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Burial of the Rev. George Gilfillan
Author: W, Knight of the White Elephant of Burmah
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 17
Avg verse line length: 39.0
Avg prose line length: 243.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: The Burial of the Rev. George Gilfillan
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: On the Gilfillan burial day, In the Hill o’ Balgay, It was a most solemn sight to see, Not fewer than thirty thousand people assembled in Dundee, All watching the funeral procession of Gilfillan that day, That death had suddenly taken away, And was going to be buried in the Hill o’ Balgay.
   4: 
   5: There were about three thousand people in the procession alone, And many were shedding tears, and several did moan, And their bosoms heaved with pain, Because they knew they would never look upon his like again.
   6: 
   7: There could not be fewer than fifty carriages in the procession that day, And gentlemen in some of them that had come from far away, And in whispers some of them did say, As the hearse bore the precious corpse away, Along the Nethergate that day.
   8: 
   9: I’m sure he will be greatly missed by the poor, For he never turned them empty-handed away from his door; And to assist them in distress it didn’t give him pain, And I’m sure the poor will never look upon his like again.
  10: 
  11: On the Gilfillan burial day, in the Hill o’ Balgay, There was a body of policemen marshalled in grand array, And marched in front of the procession all the way; Also the relatives and friends of the deceas’d, Whom I hope from all sorrows has been releas’d, And whose soul I hope to heaven has fled away, To sing with saints above for ever and aye.
  12: 
  13: The Provost, Magistrates, and Town Council were in the procession that day; Also Mrs Gilfillan, who cried and sobbed all the way For her kind husband, that was always affable and gay, Which she will remember until her dying day.
  14: 
  15: When the procession arrived in the Hill o’ Balgay, The people were almost as hush as death, and many of them did say— As long as we live we’ll remember the day That the great Gilfillan was buried in the Hill o’Balgay.
  16: 
  17: When the body of the great Gilfillan was lowered into the grave, ’Twas then the people’s hearts with sorrow did heave; And with tearful eyes and bated breath, Mrs Gilfillan lamented her loving husband’s death.
  18: 
  19: Then she dropped a ringlet of immortelles into his grave, Then took one last fond look, and in sorrow did leave; And all the people left with sad hearts that day, And that ended the Gilfillan burial in the Hill o’ Balgay.

   3: The time came to build a permanence, for which was sought anarchitect, who formed all forms first in the mind.
   4: 
   5: But which?
   6: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   7: To understand each form, another was needed: the lines of a blueprint, the marks of an alphabet, the modeling of a diorama.
   8: 
   9: These, too, took explanation: schools of thought to interpret the lines, a grammar police to stay on script, a rhetoric and its dictator to rally model citizens—while others tried to make sense of these in books full of diagrams, jargon, theoretical models, one of which said: “Beware the architect.
  10: 
  11: The ‘master builder’ of the ancients cannot help but construct form on top of form when searching for an ideal, each layer obscuring the plain connection of things: as when two people, with a mere touch, know they could never formulate what they mean to each other.
  12: 
  13: To enter Babel, one must follow HebrewBabhelon the way from Akkadianbab-ilu, the Gate of God—but only ruins remain of mankind’s attempt to converse one on One.
  14: 
  15: A shorter journey ends at Merriam-Webster, the monument of an heretical sect that attempted to define all of His creation.
  16: 
  17: The orthodoxy noted its curious feature: a word’s meaning is determined by how it is used in relation to other words, whose meanings are found likewise: the monument was built on no foundation.
  18: 
  19: A search ensued for the loose word that, if pulled out, would cause indescribable destruction.
  20: 
  21: The mind that shapes thebumblebee’sname out of onomatopoeicbombelnis in turn shaped by the name of the bumblebee, which comes to evoke in the mind afternoons of anab-e-shahi and beards entangled, his scent now as distant as the summer it sowed, ripe years in which we could not tell the bee from the bumble, and to which the bumblebee, in its briefness, paid no mind.

   3: The stranger walks into the dark room where the two men sit at the table and talk of travel.
   4: 
   5: The stranger joins in the conversation, saying: 'I have also traveled' and the two men look up and seem surprised at his sudden appearance.
   6: 
   7: In the corners of the ceiling there is a sound as of very swift wings, a muttering of motors, and a chattering of thin voices.
   8: 
   9: The stranger disappears.
  10: 
  11: His voice is heard first in this corner, then in that, until it fades away somewhere near the open window.
  12: 
  13: Where the stranger stood the two men find a railway ticket to an unknown destination.

  19:

  25:

  27:

  29: 
  30: There is the red tinge of consumptive blood flickering behind the moon-green glass pillars of light.
  31: 
  32: Blood of red Samson, red blood of Samson, the red thief is sprinkling blood on the slanting pillars of the falling sanctuary of light that is doomed to succumb soon to the black ice-pack of night.
  33: 
  34: Then there will be night and, suddenly thrust into dark night, the red sex of the Samson-sun must later rise out of eastern whiteness and destroy the night.
  35: 
  36: Then the pillars of the black shattered temple of night glow with a white light and a red light of consumptive blood, but again later comes night then again the same Samson as the temples crash each time when the red thief scatters blood on the pillars of the light or the pillars of the night.
  37: 
  38: And the thief is Samson and the red sun is Samson and Samson is the thief and Samson is the sun.

   2: 
   3: Clouds darken the plain.
   4: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   5: From all sides, the mountains of the horizon move forward; the plain shrinks, crumpled into valleys that grow deeper.
   6: 
   7: The three rivers become torrents that flow swiftly in their cavernous beds towards those dark spots where they meet: the cities.
   8: 
   9: Then the sun again.
  10: 
  11: The mountains move back to the distant circular horizon; the valleys disappear, and the three rivers flow placidly in their scarcely perceptible beds of luminous sands.
  12: 
  13: The cities glisten with their crystal walls and the hard light is reflected from house to house along the glass streets.
  14: 
  15: Men no longer drag their dark-blue shadows like long chains that rattled on the opaque cobble stones.
  16: 
  17: Silence of light: frozen wines of sound.
  18: 
  19: No wind stirs, sleepily coiled around the towers that are transparent stems bearing the white flowers of clouds which float, vehicles for our pure thoughts, like water-lilies on the surface of a stream until they fade into the blue depth of space.

   6:

   8: 
   9: •La mer en nous essaie des phrases.
  10: 
  11: Depuis des lustres, la même voix épelle le même alphabet dans le même cerveau d'enfant.
  12:

  14: 
  15: Des mots quelconques, pour rien et pour quiconque.
  16: 
  17: Il n'y est question que de l'amour.
  18: 
  19: C'est pourquoi nous ne savons trop que dire et souffrons que le regard d'autrui s'attarde sur notre visage quand nous voudrions qu'il se pose à même notre cœur.
  20: 
  21: Nos lèvres sont si maladroites, notre corps invisible dans la nuit opaque, et nos mains mal-habiles, des éclairs ou des ailes pourtant au bout des doigts.
  22: 
  23: fromA Story of Blue

#1211: 163466_Rudiger - A Ballad_Southey, Robert_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Rudiger - A Ballad
Author: Southey, Robert
Prose starts at line: 218
Lines to remove: 12
Avg verse line length: 29.4
Avg prose line length: 155.4

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 213: And now he shriek'd, for now his frame
 214: The huge black arms clasp'd round,
 215: And dragg'd the wretched Rudiger
 216: Adown the dark profound.
 217: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 218: Author Note: Divers Princes and Noblemen being assembled in a beautiful and fair Palace, which was situate upon the river Rhine, they beheld a boat or small barge make toward the shore, drawn by a Swan in a silver chain, the one end fastened about her neck, the other to the vessel; and in it an unknown soldier, a man of a comely personage and graceful presence, who stept upon the shore; which done, the boat guided by the Swan left him, and floated down the river.
 219: 
 220: This man fell afterward in league with a fair gentlewoman, married her, and by her had many children.
 221: 
 222: After some years, the same Swan came with the same barge into the same place; the soldier entering into it, was carried thence the way he came, left wife, children and family, and was never seen amongst them after.
 223: 
 224: Now who can judge this to be other than one of those spirits that are named Incubi?
 225: 
 226: says Thomas Heywood.
 227: 
 228: I have adopted his story, but not his solution, making the unknown soldier not an evil spirit, but one who had
 229: purchased happiness of a malevolent being, by the promised sacrifice of his first-born child.

#1212: 163512_An Elegie on Henry, fourth Erle of Northumberlande_Skelton, John_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: An Elegie on Henry, fourth Erle of Northumberlande
Author: Skelton, John
Prose starts at line: 279
Lines to remove: 18
Avg verse line length: 42.8
Avg prose line length: 117.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 274: The Father, the Sonn, and the Holy Ghost,
 275: In Trinitate one God of myghtes moste!
 276: Quoted from Percy's Reliques, 'The subject, .
 277: 
 278: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 279: is the death of Henry Percy, fourth Earl of Northumberland, who fell a victim to the avarice of Henry VII.
 280: 
 281: In 1489, the parliament had granted the king a subsidy, for carrying on the war in Bretagne.
 282: 
 283: This tax was found so heavy in the North, that the whole country was in a flame.
 284: 
 285: The Earl of Northumberland, then lord-lieutenant for Yorkshire, wrote to inform the king of the discontent, and praying an abatement.
 286: 
 287: But nothing is so unrelenting as avarice: the king wrote back, that not a penny should be abated.
 288: 
 289: This message being delivered by the earl with too little caution, the populace rose, and supposing him to be the promoter of their calamity, broke into his house, and murdered him, with several of his attendants; who yet are charged by Skelton with being backward in their duty on this occasion.
 290: 
 291: This melancholy event happened at the earl's seat at Cocklodge, near Thirske, in Yorkshire, April 28, 1489.
 292: 
 293: 
 294: The following poem, which appears to have been written soon after the event, is printed from an ancient MS.
 295: 
 296: copy, preserved in the British Museum.

 118: 
 119: That song that waits for nothing but our melody.
 120:

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 121: We are of the morning, of the gently sloping hour that comes slowly down from the sun.
 122: 
 123: The old clothes in the corner are tinged with the morning's color, which will have to be worn.
 124: 
 125: The lark's song widens the silence.
 126: 
 127: Deep in the forest, the cuckoo, the woodpecker, the chiaroscuro of ancient musics.
 128: 
 129: Heavy wagons clench their signal-lights toward the heights of the opaque sky.
 130: 
 131: I moved with closed words across the homeland that sleeps me.
 132: 
 133: From this far country, where you respond to me without my hearing a word of yours, without perhaps my words ever reaching you, from this country where perhaps we understand each other, I overhear the most contradictory noises, which veil and deny your voice, and which would like to make me believe that I'm speaking alone.

#1215: 164141_The Dry Bones_Hoover, Paul_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Dry Bones
Author: Hoover, Paul
Prose starts at line: 13
Lines to remove: 17
Avg verse line length: 24.0
Avg prose line length: 245.1

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   8: 
   9: 
  10: 
  11: 
  12: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  13: And into the heavens, as on a bright day after rain,there came the shapes of four creatures,and they each had the likeness of a man,and each man had four wings outstretchedand each wing had four eyes emblazoned, wide open,given to weeping at the worlds they contained:an eye-world of light, of fire and air,of water and its mirror, heart and its first fear;and in each world were four names,entangled in its forest of letters,whereupon I could read: Dow Jones, Cargill,Chevron, and DeKalb of the frozen seed,bearing but once and giving up its need; and under each name were discovered four meanings,literal, figurative, rational, dim,and under each meaning a counter-meaning, with its likeness of Freud, Marx, Hegel, and Lacan; and the four figures passed as one overhead,their wingtips linked like molten silver joined.
  14: 
  15: For I, Ezekiel, had been given to eatthe very substance of God, and my eyes were open and my mouth spake,as spring opens winter and winter closes fall;and the earth turned rightly, to my senses sweet.
  16: 
  17: Son of man, they called me, a proverb and a sign.
  18: 
  19: Say: I am a sign of the city, the cauldronwhere men burn down to desire.
  20: 
  21: Say: I am the proverb of nothing and one,boiling over the fire, rising out of beliefand falling, like a tyrant, out of derision alone.
  22: 
  23: And lo, a likeness, as of the appearance of fire,the error of presence, of nothing as one,and lo, another likeness, the appearance of water, the error of absence, of something as none;for water surrounds all shapes that enterbut has no shape of its own, and fire is the shape of ruin alone.
  24: 
  25: For the princes of the sea shall cast their garments upon the land’s end:their scholar’s robes, sharkskin suits, and alligator shoes, their Nikes,Reeboks, and Chuvashian mittensknitted by the children of shepherds, by tinsmiths and ladies’ men, in the dark at the back of the store; for the princes of fire consume what they love, with the reckless ambition of gods.
  26: 
  27: Yea, as I spake to dry bones that lay upon the earth,they danced into being, and chattered, one and one,down the hallways of my desert, the thresholds of my river.
  28: 
  29: For the Lord builds ruined palaces and plants desolation,he receives what is absent; possesses all that is gone.

#1223: 165004_The Battle Of The Wazzir_Dennis, C J_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Battle Of The Wazzir
Author: Dennis, C J
Prose starts at line: 216
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 51.0
Avg prose line length: 112.7

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 211: In his book The Making of the Sentimental Bloke, Alec H.
 212: 
 213: Chisholm writes:
 214: On Good Friday of 1915, when Australian and New Zealand troops were about to leave Egypt for the front, some of them determined to exact punishment for certain injuries they believed themselves to have incurred at brothels in the street known to them as "The Wazzir", or "The Wozzer" - the Haret et Wasser, near Shepherd's Hotel in Cairo.
 215: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 216: The bad drink sold in the neighbourhood led this demonstration to greater lengths than were intended: the street was fired and clashes occurred between the demonstrators and British military police, plus the Egyptian fire brigade.
 217: 
 218: Some months later men of the 2nd Australian Division tried to repeat this scene in the "Second Battle of the Wazzir.
 219: 
 220: " "These two affairs," says the Official History to Australia in the War of 1914-18, "made a good deal of noise at the time.
 221: 
 222: They were not heroic, but they also differed very little from what at Oxford and Cambridge and in Australian universities is known as a 'rag.
 223: 
 224: '" Dennis wrote the accompanying verses soon after reports of the first "Battle of the Wazzir" reached Australia.
 225: 
 226: He intended them for inclusion in The Moods of Ginger Mick, but when the censor intervened he stopped publication and issued only a few copies in "unrevised proof" form, dated 12 July 1916.
 227: 
 228: The story, of course, purports to be told by the Sentimental Bloke on the authority of Ginger Mick.
 229: 
 230: On 24 March 1915, Dennis wrote to J.
 231: 
 232: G.
 233: 
 234: Roberts regarding the problems he was having with the censorship of this poem

#1227: 165340_Teaching XVIII_Gibran, Khalil_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Teaching XVIII
Author: Gibran, Khalil
Prose starts at line: 6
Lines to remove: 15
Avg verse line length: 24.0
Avg prose line length: 120.6

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Teaching XVIII
   2: 
   3: Then said a teacher, "Speak to us of Teaching.
   4: 
   5: And he said:

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   6: No man can reveal to you aught but that which already lies half asleep in the dawning of our knowledge.
   7: 
   8: The teacher who walks in the shadow of the temple, among his followers, gives not of his wisdom but rather of his faith and his lovingness.
   9: 
  10: If he is indeed wise he does not bid you enter the house of wisdom, but rather leads you to the threshold of your own mind.
  11: 
  12: The astronomer may speak to you of his understanding of space, but he cannot give you his understanding.
  13: 
  14: The musician may sing to you of the rhythm which is in all space, but he cannot give you the ear which arrests the rhythm nor the voice that echoes it.
  15: 
  16: And he who is versed in the science of numbers can tell of the regions of weight and measure, but he cannot conduct you thither.
  17: 
  18: For the vision of one man lends not its wings to another man.
  19: 
  20: And even as each one of you stands alone in God's knowledge, so must each one of you be alone in his knowledge of God and in his understanding of the earth.


====================================================================================================
#1228: 165344_Reason And Passion XV_Gibran, Khalil_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Reason And Passion XV
Author: Gibran, Khalil
Prose starts at line: 10
Lines to remove: 20
Avg verse line length: 76.0
Avg prose line length: 125.5

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   5: And he answered saying:
   6: Your soul is oftentimes a battlefield, upon which your reason and your judgment wage war against passion and your appetite.
   7: 
   8: Would that I could be the peacemaker in your soul, that I might turn the discord and the rivalry of your elements into oneness and melody.
   9: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  10: But how shall I, unless you yourselves be also the peacemakers, nay, the lovers of all your elements?
  11: 
  12: Your reason and your passion are the rudder and the sails of your seafaring soul.
  13: 
  14: If either your sails or our rudder be broken, you can but toss and drift, or else be held at a standstill in mid-seas.
  15: 
  16: For reason, ruling alone, is a force confining; and passion, unattended, is a flame that burns to its own destruction.
  17: 
  18: Therefore let your soul exalt your reason to the height of passion; that it may sing;
  19: And let it direct your passion with reason, that your passion may live through its own daily resurrection, and like the phoenix rise above its own ashes.
  20: 
  21: I would have you consider your judgment and your appetite even as you would two loved guests in your house.
  22: 
  23: Surely you would not honour one guest above the other; for he who is more mindful of one loses the love and the faith of both.
  24: 
  25: Among the hills, when you sit in the cool shade of the white poplars, sharing the peace and serenity of distant fields and meadows - then let your heart say in silence, "God rests in reason.
  26: 
  27: And when the storm comes, and the mighty wind shakes the forest, and thunder and lightning proclaim the majesty of the sky, - then let your heart say in awe, "God moves in passion.
  28: 
  29: And since you are a breath In God's sphere, and a leaf in God's forest, you too should rest in reason and move in passion.


====================================================================================================
#1229: 165348_The House Of Fortune III_Gibran, Khalil_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The House Of Fortune III
Author: Gibran, Khalil
Prose starts at line: 13
Lines to remove: 15
Avg verse line length: 72.7
Avg prose line length: 136.6

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   8: 
   9: And my heart spoke to the daughter of Love saying, "Oh Love, where can I find Contentment?
  10: 
  11: I heard that she had come here to join you.
  12: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  13: And the daughter of Love responded, "Contentment has already gone to preach her gospel in the city, where greed and corruption are paramount; we are not in need of her.
  14: 
  15: Fortune craves not Contentment, for it is an earthly hope, and its desires are embraced by union with objects, while Contentment is naught but heartfelt.
  16: 
  17: The eternal soul is never contented; it ever seeks exaltation.
  18: 
  19: Then my heart looked upon Life of Beauty and said: "Thou art all knowledge; enlighten me as to the mystery of Woman.
  20: 
  21: " And he answered, "Oh human heart, woman is your own reflection, and whatever you are, she is; wherever you live, she lives; she is like religion if not interpreted by the ignorant, and like a moon, if not veiled with clouds, and like a breeze, if not poisoned with impurities.
  22: 
  23: And my heart walked toward Knowledge, the daughter of Love and Beauty, and said, "Bestow upon me wisdom, that I might share it with the people.
  24: 
  25: " And she responded, "Say not wisdom, but rather fortune, for real fortune comes not from outside, but begins in the Holy of Holies of life.
  26: 
  27: Share of thyself with the people.

#1230: 165355_Work Chapter VII_Gibran, Khalil_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Work Chapter VII
Author: Gibran, Khalil
Prose starts at line: 41
Lines to remove: 16
Avg verse line length: 80.1
Avg prose line length: 120.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  36: It is to sow seeds with tenderness and reap the harvest with joy, even as if your beloved were to eat the fruit.
  37: 
  38: It is to charge all things you fashion with a breath of your own spirit,
  39: And to know that all the blessed dead are standing about you and watching.
  40: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  41: Often have I heard you say, as if speaking in sleep, "he who works in marble, and finds the shape of his own soul in the stone, is a nobler than he who ploughs the soil.
  42: 
  43: And he who seizes the rainbow to lay it on a cloth in the likeness of man, is more than he who makes the sandals for our feet.
  44: 
  45: But I say, not in sleep but in the over-wakefulness of noontide, that the wind speaks not more sweetly to the giant oaks than to the least of all the blades of grass;
  46: And he alone is great who turns the voice of the wind into a song made sweeter by his own loving.
  47: 
  48: Work is love made visible.
  49: 
  50: And if you cannot work with love but only with distaste, it is better that you should leave your work and sit at the gate of the temple and take alms of those who work with joy.
  51: 
  52: For if you bake bread with indifference, you bake a bitter bread that feeds but half man's hunger.
  53: 
  54: And if you grudge the crushing of the grapes, your grudge distills a poison in the wine.
  55: 
  56: And if you sing though as angels, and love not the singing, you muffle man's ears to the voices of the day and the voices of the night.
