#1231: 165361_Vision X_Gibran, Khalil_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Vision X
Author: Gibran, Khalil
Prose starts at line: 7
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 87.0
Avg prose line length: 157.9

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   2: 
   3: There in the middle of the field, by the side of a crystalline stream, I saw a bird-cage whose rods and hinges were fashioned by an expert's hands.
   4: 
   5: In one corner lay a dead bird, and in another were two basins — one empty of water and the other of seeds.
   6: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   7: I stood there reverently, as if the lifeless bird and the murmur of the water were worthy of deep silence and respect — something worth of examination and meditation by the heard and conscience.
   8: 
   9: As I engrossed myself in view and thought, I found that the poor creature had died of thirst beside a stream of water, and of hunger in the midst of a rich field, cradle of life; like a rich man locked inside his iron safe, perishing from hunger amid heaps of gold.
  10: 
  11: Before my eyes I saw the cage turned suddenly into a human skeleton, and the dead bird into a man's heart which was bleeding from a deep wound that looked like the lips of a sorrowing woman.
  12: 
  13: A voice came from that wound saying, "I am the human heart, prisoner of substance and victim of earthly laws.
  14: 
  15: "In God's field of Beauty, at the edge of the stream of life, I was imprisoned in the cage of laws made by man.
  16: 
  17: "In the center of beautiful Creation I died neglected because I was kept from enjoying the freedom of God's bounty.
  18: 
  19: "Everything of beauty that awakens my love and desire is a disgrace, according to man's conceptions; everything of goodness that I crave is but naught, according to his judgment.
  20: 
  21: "I am the lost human heart, imprisoned in the foul dungeon of man's dictates, tied with chains of earthly authority, dead and forgotten by laughing humanity whose tongue is tied and whose eyes are empty of visible tears.
  22: 
  23: All these words I heard, and I saw them emerging with a stream of ever thinning blood from that wounded heart.
  24: 
  25: More was said, but my misted eyes and crying should prevented further sight or hearing.


====================================================================================================
#1232: 165365_Joy And Sorrow Chapter VIII_Gibran, Khalil_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Joy And Sorrow Chapter VIII
Author: Gibran, Khalil
Prose starts at line: 14
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 45.1
Avg prose line length: 93.5

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   9: 
  10: And how else can it be?
  11: 
  12: The deeper that sorrow carves into your being, the more joy you can contain.
  13: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  14: Is not the cup that hold your wine the very cup that was burned in the potter's oven?
  15: 
  16: And is not the lute that soothes your spirit, the very wood that was hollowed with knives?
  17: 
  18: When you are joyous, look deep into your heart and you shall find it is only that which has given you sorrow that is giving you joy.
  19: 
  20: When you are sorrowful look again in your heart, and you shall see that in truth you are weeping for that which has been your delight.
  21: 
  22: Some of you say, "Joy is greater than sorrow," and others say, "Nay, sorrow is the greater.
  23: 
  24: But I say unto you, they are inseparable.
  25: 
  26: Together they come, and when one sits alone with you at your board, remember that the other is asleep upon your bed.
  27: 
  28: Verily you are suspended like scales between your sorrow and your joy.
  29: 
  30: Only when you are empty are you at standstill and balanced.
  31: 
  32: When the treasure-keeper lifts you to weigh his gold and his silver, needs must your joy or your sorrow rise or fall.

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: And the weaver said, "Speak to us of Clothes.
   4: 
   5: And he answered:
   6: Your clothes conceal much of your beauty, yet they hide not the unbeautiful.
   7: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   8: And though you seek in garments the freedom of privacy you may find in them a harness and a chain.
   9: 
  10: Would that you could meet the sun and the wind with more of your skin and less of your raiment,
  11: For the breath of life is in the sunlight and the hand of life is in the wind.
  12: 
  13: Some of you say, "It is the north wind who has woven the clothes to wear.
  14: 
  15: But shame was his loom, and the softening of the sinews was his thread.
  16: 
  17: And when his work was done he laughed in the forest.
  18: 
  19: Forget not that modesty is for a shield against the eye of the unclean.
  20: 
  21: And when the unclean shall be no more, what were modesty but a fetter and a fouling of the mind?
  22: 
  23: And forget not that the earth delights to feel your bare feet and the winds long to play with your hair.


====================================================================================================
#1234: 165371_Chapter 9 - The Seven Selves_Gibran, Khalil_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Chapter 9 - The Seven Selves
Author: Gibran, Khalil
Prose starts at line: 18
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 85.1
Avg prose line length: 142.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  13: 
  14: Third Self: And what of me, the love-ridden self, the flaming brand of wild passion and fantastic desires?
  15: 
  16: It is I the love-sick self who would rebel against this madman.
  17: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  18: Fourth Self: I, amongst you all, am the most miserable, for naught was given me but odious hatred and destructive loathing.
  19: 
  20: It is I, the tempest-like self, the one born in the black caves of Hell, who would protest against serving this madman.
  21: 
  22: Fifth Self: Nay, it is I, the thinking self, the fanciful self, the self of hunger and thirst, the one doomed to wander without rest in search of unknown things and things not yet created; it is I, not you, who would rebel.
  23: 
  24: Sixth Self: And I, the working self, the pitiful labourer, who, with patient hands, and longing eyes, fashion the days into images and give the formless elements new and eternal forms-it is I, the solitary one, who would rebel against this restless madman.
  25: 
  26: Seventh Self: How strange that you all would rebel against this man, because each and every one of you has a preordained fate to fulfil.
  27: 
  28: Ah! could I but be like one of you, a self with a determined lot! But I have none, I am the do-nothing self, the one who sits in the dumb, empty nowhere and nowhen, while you are busy re-creating life.
  29: 
  30: Is it you or I, neighbours, who should rebel?
  31: 
  32: When the seventh self thus spake the other six selves looked with pity upon him but said nothing more; and as the night grew deeper one after the other went to sleep enfolded with a new and happy submission.
  33: 
  34: But the seventh self remained watching and gazing at nothingness, which is behind all things.
  35: 
  36: From - "The Madman"


====================================================================================================
#1235: 165373_The Palace And The Hut XXIX_Gibran, Khalil_unknown.txt

Author: Gibran, Khalil
Prose starts at line: 6

Avg prose line length: 113.1

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: The Palace And The Hut  XXIX
   2: 
   3: Part One
   4: As night fell and the light glittered in the great house, the servants stood at the massive door awaiting the coming of the guests; and upon their velvet garments shown golden buttons.
   5: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   6: The magnificent carriages drew into the palace park and the nobles entered, dressed in gorgeous raiment and decorated with jewels.
   7: 
   8: The instruments filled the air with pleasant melodies while the dignitaries danced to the soothing music.
   9: 
  10: At midnight the finest and most palatable foods were served on a beautiful table embellished with all kinds of the rarest flowers.
  11: 
  12: The feasters dined and drank abundantly, until the sequence of the wine began to play its part.
  13: 
  14: At dawn the throng dispersed boisterously, after spending a long night of intoxication and gluttony which hurried their worn bodies into their deep beds with unnatural sleep.
  15: 
  16: Part Two
  17: At eventide, a man attired in the dress of heavy work stood before the door of his small house and knocked at the door.
  18: 
  19: As it opened, he entered and greeted the occupants in a cheerful manner, and then sat between his children who were playing at the fireplace.
  20: 
  21: In a short time, his wife had the meal prepared and they sat at a wooden table consuming their food.
  22: 
  23: After eating they gathered around the oil lamp and talked of the day's events.
  24: 
  25: When the early night had lapsed, all stood silently and surrendered themselves to the King of Slumber with a song of praise and a prayer of gratitude on their lips.

#1236: 165375_Time XXI_Gibran, Khalil_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Time XXI
Author: Gibran, Khalil
Prose starts at line: 8
Lines to remove: 17
Avg verse line length: 32.5
Avg prose line length: 95.9

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: And an astronomer said, "Master, what of Time?
   4: 
   5: And he answered:
   6: You would measure time the measureless and the immeasurable.
   7: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   8: You would adjust your conduct and even direct the course of your spirit according to hours and seasons.
   9: 
  10: Of time you would make a stream upon whose bank you would sit and watch its flowing.
  11: 
  12: Yet the timeless in you is aware of life's timelessness,
  13: And knows that yesterday is but today's memory and tomorrow is today's dream.
  14: 
  15: And that that which sings and contemplates in you is still dwelling within the bounds of that first moment which scattered the stars into space.
  16: 
  17: Who among you does not feel that his power to love is boundless?
  18: 
  19: And yet who does not feel that very love, though boundless, encompassed within the centre of his being, and moving not form love thought to love thought, nor from love deeds to other love deeds?
  20: 
  21: And is not time even as love is, undivided and paceless?
  22: 
  23: But if in you thought you must measure time into seasons, let each season encircle all the other seasons,
  24: And let today embrace the past with remembrance and the future with longing.

#1237: 165380_Pain XVI_Gibran, Khalil_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Pain XVI
Author: Gibran, Khalil
Prose starts at line: 8
Lines to remove: 14
Avg verse line length: 34.0
Avg prose line length: 92.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: And a woman spoke, saying, "Tell us of Pain.
   4: 
   5: And he said:
   6: Your pain is the breaking of the shell that encloses your understanding.
   7: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   8: Even as the stone of the fruit must break, that its heart may stand in the sun, so must you know pain.
   9: 
  10: And could you keep your heart in wonder at the daily miracles of your life, your pain would not seem less wondrous than your joy;
  11: And you would accept the seasons of your heart, even as you have always accepted the seasons that pass over your fields.
  12: 
  13: And you would watch with serenity through the winters of your grief.
  14: 
  15: Much of your pain is self-chosen.
  16: 
  17: It is the bitter potion by which the physician within you heals your sick self.
  18: 
  19: Therefore trust the physician, and drink his remedy in silence and tranquillity:
  20: For his hand, though heavy and hard, is guided by the tender hand of the Unseen,
  21: And the cup he brings, though it burn your lips, has been fashioned of the clay which the Potter has moistened with His own sacred tears.


====================================================================================================
#1238: 165393_Buying And Selling Chapter XI_Gibran, Khalil_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Buying And Selling Chapter XI
Author: Gibran, Khalil
Prose starts at line: 8
Lines to remove: 20
Avg verse line length: 51.8
Avg prose line length: 100.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: And a merchant said, "Speak to us of Buying and Selling.
   4: 
   5: And he answered and said:
   6: To you the earth yields her fruit, and you shall not want if you but know how to fill your hands.
   7: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   8: It is in exchanging the gifts of the earth that you shall find abundance and be satisfied.
   9: 
  10: Yet unless the exchange be in love and kindly justice, it will but lead some to greed and others to hunger.
  11: 
  12: When in the market place you toilers of the sea and fields and vineyards meet the weavers and the potters and the gatherers of spices, -
  13: Invoke then the master spirit of the earth, to come into your midst and sanctify the scales and the reckoning that weighs value against value.
  14: 
  15: And suffer not the barren-handed to take part in your transactions, who would sell their words for your labour.
  16: 
  17: To such men you should say,
  18: "Come with us to the field, or go with our brothers to the sea and cast your net;
  19: For the land and the sea shall be bountiful to you even as to us.
  20: 
  21: And if there come the singers and the dancers and the flute players, - buy of their gifts also.
  22: 
  23: For they too are gatherers of fruit and frankincense, and that which they bring, though fashioned of dreams, is raiment and food for your soul.
  24: 
  25: And before you leave the marketplace, see that no one has gone his way with empty hands.
  26: 
  27: For the master spirit of the earth shall not sleep peacefully upon the wind till the needs of the least of you are satisfied.


====================================================================================================
#1239: 165396_Giving Chapter V_Gibran, Khalil_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Giving Chapter V
Author: Gibran, Khalil
Prose starts at line: 46
Lines to remove: 16
Avg verse line length: 70.7
Avg prose line length: 106.4

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  41: 
  42: The trees in your orchard say not so, nor the flocks in your pasture.
  43: 
  44: They give that they may live, for to withhold is to perish.
  45: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  46: Surely he who is worthy to receive his days and his nights is worthy of all else from you.
  47: 
  48: And he who has deserved to drink from the ocean of life deserves to fill his cup from your little stream.
  49: 
  50: And what desert greater shall there be than that which lies in the courage and the confidence, nay the charity, of receiving?
  51: 
  52: And who are you that men should rend their bosom and unveil their pride, that you may see their worth naked and their pride unabashed?
  53: 
  54: See first that you yourself deserve to be a giver, and an instrument of giving.
  55: 
  56: For in truth it is life that gives unto life - while you, who deem yourself a giver, are but a witness.
  57: 
  58: And you receivers - and you are all receivers - assume no weight of gratitude, lest you lay a yoke upon yourself and upon him who gives.
  59: 
  60: Rather rise together with the giver on his gifts as on wings;
  61: For to be overmindful of your debt, is to doubt his generosity who has the free-hearted earth for mother, and God for father.


====================================================================================================
#1240: 165412_The Creation I_Gibran, Khalil_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Creation I
Author: Gibran, Khalil
Prose starts at line: 7
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 50.3
Avg prose line length: 143.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   2: 
   3: The God separated a spirit from Himself and fashioned it into Beauty.
   4: 
   5: He showered upon her all the blessings of gracefulness and kindness.
   6: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   7: He gave her the cup of happiness and said, "Drink not from this cup unless you forget the past and the future, for happiness is naught but the moment.
   8: 
   9: " And He also gave her a cup of sorrow and said, "Drink from this cup and you will understand the meaning of the fleeting instants of the joy of life, for sorrow ever abounds.
  10: 
  11: And the God bestowed upon her a love that would desert he forever upon her first sigh of earthly satisfaction, and a sweetness that would vanish with her first awareness of flattery.
  12: 
  13: And He gave her wisdom from heaven to lead to the all-righteous path, and placed in the depth of her heart and eye that sees the unseen, and created in he an affection and goodness toward all things.
  14: 
  15: He dressed her with raiment of hopes spun by the angels of heaven from the sinews of the rainbow.
  16: 
  17: And He cloaked her in the shadow of confusion, which is the dawn of life and light.
  18: 
  19: Then the God took consuming fire from the furnace of anger, and searing wind from the desert of ignorance, and sharp- cutting sands from the shore of selfishness, and coarse earth from under the feet of ages, and combined them all and fashioned Man.
  20: 
  21: He gave to Man a blind power that rages and drives him into a madness which extinguishes only before gratification of desire, and placed life in him which is the specter of death.
  22: 
  23: And the god laughed and cried.
  24: 
  25: He felt an overwhelming love and pity for Man, and sheltered him beneath His guidance.

#1241: 165448_A Political Litany_Freneau, Philip Morin_unknown.txt

Author: Freneau, Philip Morin
Prose starts at line: 11
Lines to remove: 15
Avg verse line length: 54.7
Avg prose line length: 170.6

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   6: from British dependence, but also
   7: From a junto that labour with absolute power, Whose schemes disappointed have made them look sour, From the lords of the council, who fight against freedom, Who still follow on where delusion shall lead them.
   8: 
   9: From the group at St.
  10: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  11: James's, who slight our petitions, And fools that are waiting for further submissions— From a nation whose manners are rough and severe, From scoundrels and rascals,—do keep us all clear.
  12: 
  13: From pirates sent out by command of the king To murder and plunder, but never to swing.
  14: 
  15: From Wallace and Greaves, and Vipers and Roses, Whom, if heaven pleases, we'll give bloody noses.
  16: 
  17: From the valiant Dunmore, with his crew of banditti, Who plunder Virginians at Williamsburg city, From hot-headed Montague, mighty to swear, The little fat man with his pretty white hair.
  18: 
  19: From bishops in Britain, who butchers are grown, From slaves that would die for a smile from the throne, From assemblies that vote against Congress proceedings, (Who now see the fruit of their stupid misleadings.
  20: 
  21: ) From Tryon the mighty, who flies from our city, And swelled with importance disdains the committee: (But since he is pleased to proclaim us his foes, What the devil care we where the devil he goes.
  22: 
  23: ) From the caitiff, lord North, who would bind us in chains, From a royal king Log, with his tooth-full of brains, Who dreams, and is certain (when taking a nap) He has conquered our lands, as they lay on his map.
  24: 
  25: From a kingdom that bullies, and hectors, and swears, We send up to heaven our wishes and prayers That we, disunited, may freemen be still, And Britain go on—to be damned if she will.

   8:

  10:

  12:

  14: 
  15: Do you knowhow much I paid for my best rages?
  16: 
  17: I want them all back if they’reso To Die For.
  18: 
  19: Else shred my palms,wash my face with spit, let the whip unlace my flesh and free the naked blood, let me be tumbled to immortalitywith the stew of flood debristhat is my life.

#1243: 165656_The Poor Unhappy Transported Felon_Revel, James_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Poor Unhappy Transported Felon
Author: Revel, James
Prose starts at line: 380
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 38.7
Avg prose line length: 105.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 375: FINIS:
 376: Original Source: James Revel, The Poor Unhappy Transported Felon's Sorrowful Account of His Fourteen Years Transportation, at Virginia, in America.
 377: 
 378: In Six Parts.
 379: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 380: Being a Remarkable and Succinct History of the Life of James Revel, the Unhappy Sufferer Who Was Put Apprentice by His Father to a Tinman, Near Moorfields, Where He Got into Bad Company and Before Long Ran Away, and Went Robbing with a Gang of Thieves, But His Master Soon Got Him Back Again; Yet Would Not Be Be [sic] Kept from His Old Companions, But Went Thieving with Them Again, for Which He Was Transported Fourteen Years.
 381: 
 382: With an Account of the Way the Transports Work, and the Punishment They Receive for Committing Any Fault.
 383: 
 384: Concluding with a Word of Advice for All Young Men.
 385: 
 386: (York: C.
 387: 
 388: Croshaw, ca.
 389: 
 390: 1800).
 391: 
 392: Purportedly written in 1660, this poem was found by John Melville Jennings and the first known publication date is 1800.
 393: 
 394: There is speculation whether it was actually written as suggested, or later to capitalize on a popular trend of harrowing narratives.
 395: 
 396: It also isn't known if Revel was an indentured servant, or if he actually existed.
 397: 
 398: There are no known records of his being shipped to the Virginia colonies, though the practice did occur.

#1244: 165952_Envelope Artifact_Young, Mark_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Envelope Artifact
Author: Young, Mark
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 17.0
Avg prose line length: 93.7

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Envelope Artifact
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: Mark Young is a New Zealander who has lived most of his life in Australia, and he is known primarily as a poet.
   4: 
   5: As a visual poet, he brings a vibrant literary sense to the text as visual object.
   6: 
   7: He has arrayed phrases and individual words upon a field that takes the form of a traditional chess set, compelling the reader to construct meaning out of the various ways a string of words can be constructed.
   8: 
   9: The reader can read up, down, diagonally, and even in a continuous spiral.
  10: 
  11: In the end, the poem becomes a textual movie—every block upon the page a single frame in that movie—and the film flickers before us, sending our minds in different directions, exciting the retina, and teasing the mind.
  12: 
  13: Meaning is not easy or certain in this visual poem.
  14: 
  15: Instead, it surges toward us and swirls away, both brazen and coy.
  16: 
  17: This is a poem about thinking, meaning, and the isolated and collective beauty of words.
  18: 
  19: —Geof Huth
  20: 
  21: More About Visual Poetry > >

 145: ”   Wealth of the fettered, illth of the lettered, left his realism, like rock dust, unweathered: one who eyes the needle of the present to knit the future’s garb.
 146: 
 147: In his own buttoned guise he seemed to speak to the man Friday in Everyman boned and lined and veined for the twelve great fatigues to the Promised Land:   “The golden mean of the dark wayfarer’s way between black Scylla and white Charybdis, I have traveled; subdued ifs in the way; from vile-canaille balconies and nigger heavens, seen day beasts and night beasts of prey in the disemboweling pits of Europe and America, in the death-worming bowels of Asia and Africa; and, although a Dumb Ox (like young Aquinas), I have not forgot the rainbows and the olive leaves against the orient sky.
 148: 
 149: “The basso profundo Gibbon of Putney —not the lyric tenor, Thomas of Celano— hymns the Dies Irae!”

   3: This tree has two million and seventy-five thousand leaves.
   4: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   5: Perhaps I missed a leaf or two but I do feel triumphant at having persisted in counting by hand branch by branch and marked down on paper with pencil each total.
   6: 
   7: Adding them up was a pleasure I could understand; I did something on my own that was not dependent on others, and to count leaves is not less meaningful than to count the stars, as astronomers are always doing.
   8: 
   9: They want the facts to be sure they have them all.
  10: 
  11: It would help them to know whether the world is finite.
  12: 
  13: I discovered one tree that is finite.
  14: 
  15: I must try counting the hairs on my head, and you too.
  16: 
  17: We could swap information.

  27: when she is standing in aureoles.
  28: 
  29: She never hears who calls and grieves -
  30: she - flesh and airy ghost…
  31: The title is probably an ankicisation of Lora

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  32: Yavorov was inspired by two women; Mina Todovara and Lora Karavelova, and he dedicated most of his works to them.
  33: 
  34: Mina was his true first love but she died a painful death caused by tuberculosis.
  35: 
  36: Some years after Mina died he met Lora, the daughter of the statesman Petko Karavelov.
  37: 
  38: Lora was a strong, jealous, and sometimes mean, woman.
  39: 
  40: Though married
  41: they were intimidated by the institution of marriage.
  42: 
  43: She died of gunshot wounds.
  44: 
  45: Some say he shot her, some say it was suicide.
  46: 
  47: Yavorov attempted suicide himself but only managed to blind himself but he finally managed to complete the job 2 years later.

  26: but the old road, the Gulf road is lost among the years.

  29: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]

  30: It is known that in 1864 explorer J G McDonald covered thousands of square miles of the country around the Gulf of Carpentaria.
  31: 
  32: He set out on an expedition from Bowen (Queensland) and travelled some of the toughest and wildest country in australia to reach the present site of Burketown, a distance af 1,580 miles.
  33: 
  34: Settlers followed with their cattle and by 1868 most of the suitable grazing country had been taken up.
  35: 
  36: Morning Glory: this refers to a swirling mass of cloud that comes in fromthe sea and looks like a storm is about to break, however as the sun rises the cloud disperses.

   2:

   7: transition-place, land-sea place where freshwater / meets and mixes with salt yourm / tidal culture pro by peninsulas / Holocene history, a river-eroded / or glacially scoured valley / flooded with rising seas a brackish body with an opening / creeks flowing / a free connection to the ocean / a dynamic system diluted sea / the shocked river systembar-built, lagoonish / by barrier beaches and barrier spits / you- plain / on a stable tectonic edge / marginal coast of minimal tide / offshore banks built by sand and shore, sediment remade / into bounty, into overwash flats and dunes / the mainland ridge engulfed, shore currents the spits / swelling with the littoral swervea dense salt wedge tunnels towards land, sl-

#1252: 166338_Miserrimus_Adams, Oscar Fay_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Miserrimus
Author: Adams, Oscar Fay
Prose starts at line: 23
Lines to remove: 7
Avg verse line length: 32.8
Avg prose line length: 99.5

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  18: As virtues, and thereof wax emulous,—
  19: He only that such shameful honour wins,
  20: (Not this non-juring priest), should cry aloud
  21: Past hope,
  22: "Miserrimus! Miserrimus!"

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  23: This is the sole inscription on the stone which covers the remains of the Reverend Thomas Morris, in the north walk of the cloisters at Worcester Cathedral.
  24: 
  25: He was a Minor Canon of Worcester who refused to take the oath of allegiance to William III.
  26: 
  27: , and was consequently reduced to great poverty.
  28: 
  29: He died at the age of eighty-eight, and at his request this single word was placed upon his tombstone.

#1253: 166364_Wheal Emma Leat_Lopez, Tony_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Wheal Emma Leat
Author: Lopez, Tony
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 9
Avg verse line length: 15.0
Avg prose line length: 176.4

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Wheal Emma Leat
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: Wheal Emma and Brookwood are abandoned copper mines whose remains are located near Buckfastleigh, within the Dartmoor National Park, an area with a long history of widespread industrial activity.
   4: 
   5: From this one locality, in the second half of the nineteenth century, more than thirty thousand tons of copper ore were raised, processed, and shipped for smelting.
   6: 
   7: In 1859, in order to stabilize and increase the power supply, Wheal Emma Leat (a fifteen-mile-long channel) was cut across moorland and around woodland valleys to transport water from the River Swincombe and to feed the mines by supplementing the Mardle, a tributary of the Dart.
   8: 
   9: Some of this now empty moorland waterway can be walked today on Dartmoor.
  10: 
  11: I am grateful to Kevin and Donna Cox, owners of the Brook Manor estate, for showing my collaborator,Ignacio Acosta, and me over the remains of mine workings on their land.

#1257: 166520_The Dying Comrade_Allen, Charles R_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Dying Comrade
Author: Allen, Charles R
Prose starts at line: 43
Lines to remove: 7
Avg verse line length: 31.3
Avg prose line length: 205.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  38: I will soon cross the dark river,
  39: The river we all so much dread,
  40: Altho my memory may not last forever,
  41: I hope that Flag may float o'er head.
  42: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  43: Surviving the War and returning to his home and family did not necessarily mean that a soldier's sufferings were at an end.
  44: 
  45: Many men sustained grievous wounds in battle that would plague them until their dying day, causing constant discomfort and pain and sometimes even death many years after the fact.
  46: 
  47: In this poem, which was written in 1911 or 1912, the poet laments not just the wounds that have troubled him for 46 years but also the fact that the government for which he sacrificed so much has done so little for him in his disabled state.
  48: 
  49: Although he has been reduced to living on charity and may wish that some of the money spent on battlefield monuments had been put to better use caring for veterans of the conflict, he still expresses great pride in the part that he and his comrades played in preserving the Union.

#1260: 166925_Ch 03 On The Excellence Of Contentment Story 07_di, Sa_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Ch 03 On The Excellence Of Contentment Story 07
Author: di, Sa
Prose starts at line: 5
Lines to remove: 17
Avg verse line length: 45.0
Avg prose line length: 90.6

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Ch 03 On The Excellence Of Contentment Story 07
   2: 
   3: Two Khorasani dervishes travelled together.
   4: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   5: One of them, being weak, broke his fast every second night whilst the other who was strong consumed every day three meals.
   6: 
   7: It happened that they were captured at the gate of a town on suspicion of being spies; whereon each of them was confined in a closet and the aperture of it walled up with mud bricks.
   8: 
   9: After two weeks it became known that they were guiltless.
  10: 
  11: Accordingly the doors were opened and the strong man was found to be dead whilst the weak fellow had remained alive.
  12: 
  13: The people were astonished but a sage averred that the contrary would have been astonishing because one of them having been voracious possessed no strength to suffer hunger and perished whilst the other who was abstemious merely persevered in his habit and remained safe.
  14: 
  15: When eating little has become the nature of a man
  16: He takes it easy when a calamity befalls him
  17: But when the body becomes strong in affluence
  18: He will die when a hardship overtakes him.
  19: 
  20: THE GULISTAN OF SA'DI
  21: Translated by Richard Francis Burton (1821-1890)


====================================================================================================

   8: They refrain from putting their hands to the sword.
   9: 
  10: What bravery will they display in battle array
  11: When their hands are empty and affairs deplorable?
  12: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  13: I was on terms of friendship with one of those who had acted treacherously and reproached him, telling him that it was base, ungrateful, despicable and undutiful to abandon an old master when his affairs have changed a little and to disregard the obligations incurred for benefits received during many years.
  14: 
  15: He replied: "If I inform thee, perhaps thou wilt excuse me for my horse had no barley and my saddle-cloth was pawned.
  16: 
  17: A sultan who grudges money to his troops, they cannot bravely risk their lives for him.
  18: 
  19: Give gold to the soldier that he may serve thee.
  20: 
  21: If thou with-holdest gold, he will serve elsewhere.
  22: 
  23: When a warrior is full, he will be brave in fight but if his belly be
  24: empty, he will be brave in flight.
  25: 
  26: THE GULISTAN OF SA'DI
  27: Translated by Richard Francis Burton (1821-1890)

#1262: 166962_Ch 03 On The Excellence Of Contentment Story 20_di, Sa_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Ch 03 On The Excellence Of Contentment Story 20
Author: di, Sa
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 16
Avg verse line length: 47.0
Avg prose line length: 112.9

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Ch 03 On The Excellence Of Contentment Story 20
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: A king with some of his courtiers had during a hunting party and in the winter season strayed far from inhabited places but when the night set in he perceived the house of a dehqan and said: ‘We shall spend the night there to avoid the injury of the cold.
   4: 
   5: ’ One of the veziers, however, objected alleging that it was unworthy of the high dignity of a padshah to take refuge in the house of a dehqan and that it would be best to pitch tents and to light fires on the spot.
   6: 
   7: The dehqan who had become aware of what was taking place prepared some food he had ready in his house, offered it, kissed the ground of service and said: ‘The high dignity of the sultan would not have been so much lowered, but the courtiers did not wish the dignity of the dehqan to become high.
   8: 
   9: ’ The king who was pleased with these words moved for the night into the man’s house and bestowed a dress of honour upon him the next morning.
  10: 
  11: When he accompanied the king a few paces at the departure he was heard to say:
  12: ‘Nothing was lost of the sultan’s power and pomp
  13: By accepting the hospitality of a dehqan,
  14: But the corner of the dehqan’s cap reached the sun
  15: When a sultan such as thou overshadowed his head.
  16: 
  17: THE GULISTAN OF SA'DI
  18: Translated by Richard Francis Burton (1821-1890)

#1263: 166980_Ch 02 The Morals Of Dervishes Story 37_di, Sa_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Ch 02 The Morals Of Dervishes Story 37
Author: di, Sa
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 38.0
Avg prose line length: 92.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Ch 02 The Morals Of Dervishes Story 37
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: A dervish arrived in a place, the owner of which was of a noble disposition, and had surrounded himself with a company of distinguished and eloquent men, each of whom uttered something elegant or jocular, according to the fashion of wits.
   4: 
   5: The dervish who had travelled through the desert and was fatigued had eaten nothing.
   6: 
   7: One of the company asked him by way of encouragement likewise to say something.
   8: 
   9: The dervish replied: ‘I do not possess distinction and eloquence like you and have read nothing so you must be satisfied with one distich of mine.
  10: 
  11: ’ The company having agreed with pleasure he recited:
  12: ‘I am hungry and opposite to a table of food
  13: Like a bachelor at the door of a bath of females.
  14: 
  15: The company, having thus been apprised of his famished condition, produced a table with bread but as he began to eat greedily the host said: ‘Friend, at any rate stop a while till my servants roast some minced meat’; whereon the dervish lifted his head and recited:
  16: ‘Do not order pounded meat for my table.
  17: 
  18: To a pounded man simple bread is pounded meat.
  19: 
  20: THE GULISTAN OF SA'DI
  21: Translated by Richard Francis Burton (1821-1890)

#1264: 167135_Ch 02 The Morals Of Dervishes Story 14_di, Sa_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Ch 02 The Morals Of Dervishes Story 14
Author: di, Sa
Prose starts at line: 5
Lines to remove: 18
Avg verse line length: 58.0
Avg prose line length: 93.9

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Ch 02 The Morals Of Dervishes Story 14
   2: 
   3: A dervish who had fallen into want stole a blanket from the house of a friend.
   4: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   5: The judge ordered his hand to be amputated but the owner of the blanket interceded, saying that he had condoned the fault.
   6: 
   7: The judge rejoined: ‘Thy intercession cannot persuade me to neglect the provision of the law.
   8: 
   9: ’ The man continued: ‘Thou hast spoken the truth but amputation is not applicable to a person who steals some property dedicated to pious uses.
  10: 
  11: More over a beggar possesses nothing and whatever belongs to a dervish is dedicated to the use of the needy.
  12: 
  13: ’ Thereon the judge released the culprit, saying: ‘The world must indeed have become too narrow for thee that thou hast committed no theft except from the house of such a friend.
  14: 
  15: ’ He replied: ‘Hast thou not heard the saying: Sweep out the house of friends and do not knock at the door of foes.
  16: 
  17: If thou sinkest in a calamity be not helpless.
  18: 
  19: Strip thy foes of their skins and thy friends of their fur-coats.
  20: 
  21: THE GULISTAN OF SA'DI
  22: Translated by Richard Francis Burton (1821-1890)

#1265: 167168_Introductory 03_di, Sa_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Introductory 03
Author: di, Sa
Prose starts at line: 135
Lines to remove: 18
Avg verse line length: 71.7
Avg prose line length: 125.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 130: Take a leaf from my rose-garden.
 131: 
 132: A flower endures but five or six days
 133: But this rose-garden is always delightful.
 134: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 135: After I had uttered these words he threw away the flowers from his skirts, and attached himself to mine, saying: ‘When a generous fellow makes a promise he keeps it.
 136: 
 137: On the same day I happened to write two chapters, namely on polite society and the rules of conversation, in a style acceptable to orators and instructive to letter-writers.
 138: 
 139: In short, some roses of the garden still remained when the book of the Rose-garden was finished but it will in reality be completed only after approbation in the court of the Shah, who is the refuge of the world, the shadow of God, the ray of his grace, the treasury of the age, the asylum of the Faith, strengthened by heaven, aided against enemies, the arm of the victorious government, the lamp of the resplendent religion, the beauty of mankind, the boast of Islam, Sa’d son of Atabek the great, the majestic Shahanshah, owner of the necks of nations, lord of the kings of Arabia and Persia, the sultan of the land and the sea, the heir of the kingdom of Solomon, Muzaffaruddin Ibu Bekr, son of Sa’d Zanki, may Allah the most high perpetuate the prosperity of them both and direct their inclinations to every good thing.
 140: 
 141: Perused with a kind glance,
 142: Adorned with approbation by the sovereign,
 143: It will be a Chinese picture-gallery or design of the Arzank,
 144: Hopes are entertained that he will not be wearied
 145: By these contents because a Pose-garden is not a place of displeasure.
 146: 
 147: The more so as its august preface is dedicated
 148: To Sa’d Abu Bekr Sa’d the son of Zanki.
 149: 
 150: Introduction from THE GULISTAN OF SA'DI
 151: Titled: THE CAUSE FOR COMPOSING THE GULISTAN
 152: Translated by Richard Francis Burton (1821-1890)

#1266: 167169_Ch 03 On The Excellence Of Contentment Story 04_di, Sa_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Ch 03 On The Excellence Of Contentment Story 04
Author: di, Sa
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 18
Avg verse line length: 47.0
Avg prose line length: 85.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Ch 03 On The Excellence Of Contentment Story 04
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: One of the kings of Persia had sent an able physician to wait upon the Mustafa, the benediction of Allah and peace be on him; and he remained for some years in the Arab country without anyone coming to him to make a trial of his ability or desiring to be treated by him.
   4: 
   5: He went to the Prophet, salutation to him, and complained that although he had been sent to treat the companions, none of them had up to this time taken notice of him or required the services incumbent upon him.
   6: 
   7: The Apostle, salutation to him, replied: ‘It is a law with these people not to eat until appetite overpowers them and when some of it yet remains they withdraw their hands from food.
   8: 
   9: ’ The doctor said: ‘This is the cause of health’, and kissing the earth of service departed.
  10: 
  11: The sage begins to speak
  12: Or points his fingers to the dish
  13: When silence would be dangerous
  14: Or abstinence would bring on death.
  15: 
  16: No doubt his wisdom is in speaking
  17: And his eating bears the fruit of health.
  18: 
  19: THE GULISTAN OF SA'DI
  20: Translated by Richard Francis Burton (1821-1890)

 433: I walk across the Bridge of Change where I have so often watched by the towers of the Conciergerie.
 434: 
 435: Now, water laves a little higher up the stair from the River to the Quay, hiding some of the steps from me.
 436: 
 437: Boats nudge at the edge.
 438: 
 439: I walk along the Boulevard past the great gold and blue corner clock, the ornate wrought-iron gate and fence of the Place of Justice (its name changed from the time of kings), past the shadow and spire of Sainte Chapelle.
 440: 
 441: I cross the Bridge of Saint Michel into the Latin Quarter.
 442: 
 443: But I do not look for the Street of the Cat Who Fishes or the Street of the Harp.
 444: 
 445: I turn right, wandering a bit, and suddenly, as if by chance, find myself at this street, and here I will wait, for it is our street, Rue Gît le Coeur: Here Lies the Heart.
 446: 
 447: for Roger Aplon—1975

  14: 
  15: I dreamtof those hands for weeks before the trip, weeks even before Istepped off the plane, thousands of useless dead flowers dryingto sienna, silent in their fall.
  16: 
  17: Every night, days before, I dreamtthose hands climbing over the iron gate of my grandparents' house, overgrate and spikes, some caughtin the groove between its sharpenedteeth, others biting where they pinched my skin.

#1269: 167329_The Hasty Pudding_Barlow, Joel_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Hasty Pudding
Author: Barlow, Joel
Prose starts at line: 489
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 43.9
Avg prose line length: 110.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 484: 
 485: The vicious habits which in this little piece I endeavor to combat, seem to me not so difficult to cure.
 486: 
 487: No class of people has any  interest  in supporting them; unless it be the interest which certain families may feel in vying with each other in sumptuous entertainments.
 488: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 489: There may indeed be some instances of depraved appetites, which no arguments will conquer; but these must be rare.
 490: 
 491: There are very few persons but what would always prefer a plain dish for themselves, and would prefer it likewise for their guests, if there were no risk of reputation in this case.
 492: 
 493: This difficulty can only be removed by example; and the example should proceed from those whose situation enables them to take the lead in forming the manners of a nation.
 494: 
 495: Persons of this description in America, I should hope, are neither above nor below the influence of truth and reason, when conveyed in language suited to the subject.
 496: 
 497: Whether the manner I have chosen to address my arguments to them be such as to promise any success is what I cannot decide.
 498: 
 499: But I certainly had hopes of doing some good, or I should not have taken the pains of putting so many rimes together.
 500: 
 501: The example of domestic virtues has doubtless a great effect.
 502: 
 503: I only wish to rank  simplicity of diet  among the virtues.
 504: 
 505: In that case I should hope it will be cherished and more esteemed by others than it is at present.
 506: 
 507: THE AUTHOR

#1270: 167606_Holy Willie's Prayer_Burns, Robert_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Holy Willie's Prayer
Author: Burns, Robert
Prose starts at line: 124
Lines to remove: 11
Avg verse line length: 28.4
Avg prose line length: 98.7

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 119: splore = row;
 120: kail = cabbage;
 121: gear = wealth
 122: 'Holy Willie' was Willie Fisher, and elder of the Presbyterian Kirk.
 123: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 124: He accused the kirk treasurer, Gavin Hamilton, of such crimes as digging his garden on a Sunday (hence 'kail an potatoes').
 125: 
 126: The matter was judged by the Presbytery of Ayr, with Robert Aiken representing Hamilton, and Willie Fisher lost.
 127: 
 128: Presbyterians at that time believed in predestination - the idea that whether you went to Heaven or Hell was decided by God before you were even born.
 129: 
 130: Obviously this could lead to the unpleasant state of mind revealed here.
 131: 
 132: Browning did one of his monologue poems on the same subject - I can't remember the name.
 133: 
 134: Information provider by Oldpoetry reader Morag.

#1271: 167639_To Miss Jessie Lewars_Burns, Robert_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: To Miss Jessie Lewars
Author: Burns, Robert
Prose starts at line: 84
Lines to remove: 12
Avg verse line length: 29.2
Avg prose line length: 76.4

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  79: True friend I bless the poet skill
  80: Which won a friend like thee,
  81: Whose love 'twixt hopes of home and heaven
  82: Is with me constantly.
  83: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  84: This is reportedly the last poem ever written by The Bard, just 5 days before he died in Dumfries, July 21st 1796 (Aged 37)
  85: The poem was kept by her family and eventually was 'descovered' in the possession of an old Scotsman in Dunedin New Zealand.
  86: 
  87: It was returned to Scotland by a Mr William Smith of Westerhouse, Carluke.
  88: 
  89: This poem was not included in any of Burn's published works.
  90: 
  91: Jessie Lewars helped Burns's mother nurse in his last days.
  92: 
  93: Jessie Lewars married a Mr Thompson who lived at Dumfries.
  94: 
  95: Thanks to Dreamweaver for poem notes.

  18: The Cross—The constellation of the Southern Cross, which appears to become lower in the sky towards the morning.

  21: 
  22: The fiery Scorpion—The brilliant constellation Scorpio.
  23: 
  24: It contains Antares, a star of the first magnitude, which shines with a reddish light.

  17: And he looked wonderful but he had never felt sillier,
  18: And she said, I can't place the face but the aroma is familiar,
  19: And Columbus didn't say a word,
  20: All he said was, I am Columbus, the fifteenth-century Admiral Byrd,
  21: And, just as he thought, her disposition was very malleable,

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  22: And she said, Here are my jewels, and she wasn't penurious like Cornelia the mother of the Gracchi, she wasn't referring to her children, no, she was referring to her jewels, which were very very valuable,
  23: So Columbus said, Somebody show me the sunset and somebody did and he set sail for it,
  24: And he discovered America and they put him in jail for it,
  25: And the fetters gave him welts,
  26: And they named America after somebody else,
  27: So the sad fate of Columbus ought to be pointed out to every child and every voter,
  28: Because it has a very important moral, which is, Don't be a discoverer, be a promoter.

#1275: 168207_While God He Leaves Me Reason, God He Will Leave Me Jim_Booth, Mary_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: While God He Leaves Me Reason, God He Will Leave Me Jim
Author: Booth, Mary
Prose starts at line: 43
Lines to remove: 7
Avg verse line length: 55.3
Avg prose line length: 166.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  38: "Hush, there is Uncle Abraham a-knocking at the door;
  39: He calls for other mother's sons, 'Three hundred thousand more!'
  40: Be still, Old Uncle Abraham; 'twill do no good to call:
  41: You think my house is full of boys; ah, Jimmy was my all.
  42: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  43: This poem, which lays out with grim starkness the reaction of a mother upon discovering that her only son has fallen in battle, recreates a scene played out in countless homes North and South during the War.
  44: 
  45: Some women reacted stoically; others, like the mother portrayed herein, broke down under the weight of their grief and simply refused to believe the terrible news.
  46: 
  47: Since God has bereft her of her son, He has (as the poem's title implies) taken her reason as well.
  48: 
  49: The call for "three hundred thousand more" volunteers was issued by Abraham Lincoln in the summer of 1862, when it had become apparent to all that the War was not going to be a short-lived affair.


====================================================================================================

   3: I must go down to the seas again, to the lonely sea and the sky,And all I ask is a tall ship and a star to steer her by;And the wheel’s kick and the wind’s song and the white sail’s shaking,And a grey mist on the sea’s face, and a grey dawn breaking.
   4: 
   5: I must go down to the seas again, for the call of the running tideIs a wild call and a clear call that may not be denied;And all I ask is a windy day with the white clouds flying,And the flung spray and the blown spume, and the sea-gulls crying.
   6:

  38:

  40: 
  41: It ended, and another endingworld spun in its place.
  42: 
  43: It ended, and we woke up and ordered Greek coffees,drew the hot liquid through our teeth, as everywhere, the apocalypse rumbled,the apocalypse remembered, our dear, beloved apocalypse—it driftedslowly from the trees all around us, so loud we stopped hearing it.

   4: 
   5: & wept we wrung the wet the sweatwe wracked our lips we rang for words to wardoff sleep to warn to want ourselves.
   6: 
   7: to wantthe earth we mouthed it wound our vowels untilit fit, in fits the earth we mounted roused& rocked we harped we yawned & tried to yawp& tried to fix, affixed, we facted, felt.
   8: 
   9: we fattened fanfared anthemed hammered, feltthe words’ worth stagnate, snap in half in heatthe wane the melt what words we’d hoarded halved& holey, porous.
  10:

  12: 
  13: & we: still washed for sounds to mark.
  14: 
  15: & marked.

#1279: 168870_The Traveller; or, A Prospect of Society_Goldsmith, Oliver_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Traveller; or, A Prospect of Society
Author: Goldsmith, Oliver
Prose starts at line: 522
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 43.1
Avg prose line length: 107.1

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 517: 
 518: Hydaspes: The ancient name of the Jelum, a river of India.
 519: 
 520: Alexander crossed the Hydaspes to give battle to Porus.
 521: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 522: 'To stop too fearful, and too faint to go,': This line was contributed by Johnson.
 523: 
 524: 'Zeck's iron crown, and Damiens' bed of steel,': George and Luke Zeck headed an insurrection against tyranny in Hungary, a.
 525: 
 526: d.
 527: 
 528: 1514, and George, who had been appointed to the sovereignty, was punished by having a red-hot iron crown placed on his head.
 529: 
 530: Robert Francois Damiens, an enthusiast, who, when the prodigalities of Louis XV.
 531: 
 532: of France caused great indignation, fancied by alarming the king he would procure a change of measures, stabbed him when stepping out of his carriage, January 5th, 1757.
 533: 
 534: Being seized and examined, he said he did not intend to kill the king; and this statement was in some measure borne out by his knife having two blades - the one he used was the shorter.
 535: 
 536: He was condemned to be broken alive by four horses.
 537: 
 538: This sentence, with additional barbarities, was carried into execution, and, to the eternal disgrace of the people and the time, in presence of a vast concourse of all ranks.
 539: 
 540: It was the most atrocious exhibition that ever took place in a civilized country.

#1281: 169110_from The Spring Flowers Own- “The morning after - my death”_Adnan, Etel_unknown.txt

Title: from The Spring Flowers Own: “The morning after / my death”
Author: Adnan, Etel
Prose starts at line: 5
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 124.0
Avg prose line length: 224.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: from The Spring Flowers Own: “The morning after / my death”
   2: 
   3: The morning after my death we will sit in cafés but I will not be there I will not be * There was the great death of birds the moon was consumed with fire the stars were visible until noon.
   4: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   5: Green was the forest drenched with shadows the roads were serpentine A redwood tree stood alone with its lean and lit body unable to follow the cars that went by with frenzy a tree is always an immutable traveller.
   6: 
   7: The moon darkened at dawn the mountain quivered with anticipation and the ocean was double-shaded: the blue of its surface with the blue of flowers mingled in horizontal water trails there was a breeze to witness the hour * The sun darkened at the fifth hour of the day the beach was covered with conversations pebbles started to pour into holes and waves came in like horses.
   8: 
   9: * The moon darkened on Christmas eve angels ate lemons in illuminated churches there was a blue rug planted with stars above our heads lemonade and war news competed for our attention our breath was warmer than the hills.
  10: 
  11: * There was a great slaughter of rocks   of spring leaves of creeks the stars showed fully the last king of the Mountain gave battle and got killed.
  12: 
  13: We lay on the grass covered dried blood with our bodies green blades swayed between our teeth.
  14: 
  15: * We went out to sea a bank of whales was heading South a young man among us a hero tried to straddle one of the sea creatures his body emerged as a muddy pool
  16: 
  17: as mud we waved goodbye to his remnants happy not to have to bury him in the early hours of the day We got drunk in a barroom the small town of Fairfax had just gone to bed cherry trees were bending under the weight of their flowers: they were involved in a ceremonial dance to which no one had ever been invited.
  18: 
  19: * I know flowers to be funeral companions they make poisons and venoms and eat abandoned stone walls I know flowers shine stronger than the sun their eclipse means the end of times but I love flowers for their treachery their fragile bodies grace my imagination’s avenues without their presence my mind would be an unmarked grave.
  20: 
  21: * We met a great storm at sea looked back at the rocking cliffs the sand was going under black birds were leaving the storm ate friends and foes alike water turned into salt for my wounds.
  22: 
  23: * Flowers end in frozen patterns artificial gardens cover the floors we get up close to midnight search with powerful lights the tiniest shrubs on the meadows A stream desperately is running to the ocean *

#1283: 169300_The Sermon of the Birds_Robinson, Roland_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Sermon of the Birds
Author: Robinson, Roland
Prose starts at line: 39
Lines to remove: 7
Avg verse line length: 46.1
Avg prose line length: 120.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  34: And the beauty of earth in the splendour that He crated.
  35: 
  36: And I went back and told my people of what I had seen,
  37: And the sermon of praise I heard in the mountain range.
  38: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  39: This story was told to Roland Robinson by Alexander Vesper, an Aboriginal man from New South Wales.
  40: 
  41: Robinson has attempted to reproduce the story and words as Vesper related it to him.
  42: 
  43: Alexander Vesper is n Aboriginal a bushman, able to interpret for himself the song of the birds.
  44: 
  45: Whether he imagined this bird choir or not, the fact that he could tell such a story as this shows that he was perhaps a good poet himself, that lacked only the technique to enable him to write poetry.

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  29: Old Jacky Mumbulla, King Merriman too,
  30: them fierce old fellers, they're all gone now.
  31: 
  32: An' the wild honey's still in the gumtree bough.
  33: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  34: This poem was written by Roland Robinson from the words of Percy Mumbulla, an Australian Aboriginal.
  35: 
  36: It is ungrammatical, written as it was spoken telling the story of the Australian Native Bee (Stingless)
  37: Coolamon: a wooden drinking vessell also used for carrying water.
  38: 
  39: Honey-bul: a mixture of water and honey from Banksia flowers and Native bee honey.
  40: 
  41: Eyetalian bees:  refer to Italian  (stinging) honey bees

   1: Birds on Statues
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: On one side of the pond, a woman heads west in stone, while on the other, it’s a man heading east, but with the same extravagant gestures of headlong flight—one leg thrown back and both hands launched forward.
   4: 
   5: And sometimes it’s on the tip of one of the lifted heels that a pigeon sits, and sometimes it’s on a thumb, but usually it’s on a head, often one on each, making a mockery of the phrase “in headlong flight.
   6: 
   7: 
   8: Though now they’re rebuilding the pond, so they’ve drained it, with the odd result that the pigeons have gone and have been replaced by crows.
   9: 
  10: They too particularly like to perch on the statues’ heads, but, determined to assert their alterity, they make sure that they’re always facing backward.

#1286: 169989_Madhushala (The Tavern)_Bachchan, Harivansh Rai_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Madhushala (The Tavern)
Author: Bachchan, Harivansh Rai
Prose starts at line: 220
Lines to remove: 11
Avg verse line length: 53.9
Avg prose line length: 148.7

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 215: 
 216: [ ed: The 20 translated above are from the popular musical rendition of the poem by Manna Dey and Bachchan Sr.
 217: 
 218: himself.
 219: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 220: The poem shows traces of the Persian Sufi style and is patterned, to some extent, on the Rubaiyat of Omar Khayyam.
 221: 
 222: Bachchan, who has translated the Rubaiyat into Hindi, has acknowledged the Persian influence in his work and indeed it is this aspect of his poetry that sets it apart form the work of the major Hindi poets of our time.
 223: 
 224: The range of the 135 verses of Madhushala is wide: wine and the tavern or wine-house serve as the basic metaphors in the poem and symbolise the fillness
 225: and intoxication of life as well as its pain and frustration.
 226: 
 227: Love, Beauty, Pain, Sorrow, Death --- all of these and more are woven into the rich texture
 228: of the poem.
 229: 
 230: Madhushala embodies the entire philosophy of Bachchan: the passionate yearning of the soul for beauty ending only in frustration, the pathetic scarcity and transience of beauty in the world, the agony of disillusionment, the inevitability of death and a stoic acceptance of fatalism as the only armour for the soul -- these are the themes of not only Madhushalabut of all of Bachchan's poetry.


====================================================================================================
#1287: 171319_The Tradition of the Golden Spurs_Ingelow, Jean_unknown.txt

Author: Ingelow, Jean
Prose starts at line: 465

Avg prose line length: 150.3

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 460: 
 461: Hath nothing pass'd that spell to break, to bear that charm away;
 462: And still it spans the silvery flood, for all the vale beside,
 463: But never since hath known the foot of Bridegroom or of Bride!
 464: Note:

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 465: About the year 870, the Danes under Hingvar, invaded East Anglia, which was then governed by Edmund, a king of singular virtue and piety.
 466: 
 467: After defending his people with great valour, Edmund was at last defeated in a battle fought near Hoxne in Suffolk.
 468: 
 469: Being hotly pursued, he concealed himself under a bridge called Gold-bridge.
 470: 
 471: The glittering of his golden spurs discovered him to a newly-married couple who were returning home by moonlight, and the bride betrayed him to his enemies.
 472: 
 473: The heathen Danes offered him his crown and his life if he would deny the Christian faith; but he continued steadfast, and when he was dragged on to the bridge, he pronounced a malediction (or warning) on all who should afterwards pass over it on their way to be married: the dread of which is still so strong in the neighbourhood, that it is said no bride or bridegroom has ever been known to pass
 474: over it to this day.

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  46: 
  47: Curtin.
  48: 
  49: andrew Gregg Curtin (1817-1894) was the Governor of Pennsylvania.
  50: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  51: A Whig politician, he had been nominated for the governorship in 1860 by Republicans, who hoped he would help carry Pennsylvania for Abraham Lincoln in the upcoming presidential election.
  52: 
  53: Curtin and Lincoln were both elected, and when the War began the following year, Curtin proved himself as capable a wartime administrator as Lincoln.
  54: 
  55: He supplied the Union war effort with both men and materials  and made it a point to provide for the dependents of Pennsylvania soldiers as well.
  56: 
  57: He was elected to a second term in 1863.
  58: 
  59: Although he was considered briefly for the Vice Presidency in 1868, he lost the nomination to Schuyler Colfax and went instead to Russia as Ulysses S.
  60: 
  61: Grant's minister.
  62: 
  63: Curtin returned home in 1872 and eventually changed party allegiance, serving three terms as a Democratic Congressman.

#1290: 172803_A Second Review Of The Grand Army_Harte, Francis Bret_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: A Second Review Of The Grand Army
Author: Harte, Francis Bret
Prose starts at line: 102
Lines to remove: 15
Avg verse line length: 38.9
Avg prose line length: 127.1

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  97: 
  98: The troops marched down Pennsylvania Avenue past President Andrew Johnson and their commanding generals and were wildly cheered by crowds of onlookers who lined both sides of the street.
  99: 
 100: Following the lavish spectacle, the armies were disbanded and sent home.
 101: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 102: Although those who had fallen in battle were memorialized by banners of black crepe and ambulances that trailed along behind each brigade, the poet evidently felt that the review paled in comparison with the sacrifices of those who had given their lives on the battlefield.
 103: 
 104: The "dusky martyrs of Pillow's fight" referred to in the sixth verse were the soldiers of the 11th U.
 105: 
 106: S.
 107: 
 108: Colored Troops, who died in the battle for Fort Pillow, Tennessee, on April 12, 1864.
 109: 
 110: Northern and Southern accounts of the battle differ dramatically.
 111: 
 112: The Committee on the Conduct of the War maintained that the Confederates, under the command of General Nathan Bedford Forrest, murdered most of the garrison following its surrender because of the presence of black troops.
 113: 
 114: Southern accounts claimed that the garrison had not surrendered and that the black soldiers were killed in combat.
 115: 
 116: Most modern scholars have concluded that a massacre did take place; how much of the blame can be laid at the feet of Forrest himself is difficult to assess.

  98:

 100:

#1297: 173382_Furfurcar (Roaring Cliff)_Damadian, Mihran_unknown.txt

Author: Damadian, Mihran
Prose starts at line: 97
Lines to remove: 13
Avg verse line length: 29.8
Avg prose line length: 112.4

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  92: Boom out, with loud acclaim;
  93: Let Roaring Cliff, Armenia’s pride,
  94: Be aye an honored name;
  95: And let our land, from age to age,
  96: Still celebrate its fame!

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  97: FURFURCAR is an overhanging mountain with inaccessible rocky sides, around which, at the mouth of each pass, were ranged the seven villages that made up Dalvorig.
  98: 
  99: Anyone climbing the path from Porkh to Hosnood hears the roaring (in local dialect furfur) of the wind.
 100: 
 101: This peculiar sound is caused by the fierce current of the whirl striking the folds of the rocks; and from this the place took its name.
 102: 
 103: Zovasar, Andok, Maratoog and Gepin are the highest summits of the mountains of Sassoun.
 104: 
 105: Furfurcar is not as high, but the passes and valleys that surround it, and the perpendicular height of its sides, make it almost impregnable.
 106: 
 107: For many years its brave mountaineers were able to defend themselves successfully against all attacks.
 108: 
 109: This poem was written while they were still unconquered.

#1299: 173471_When My Sorrow Was Born_Gibran, Kahlil_unknown.txt

Author: Gibran, Kahlil
Prose starts at line: 7
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 68.3
Avg prose line length: 104.7

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   2: 
   3: When my Sorrow was born I nursed it with care, and watched over itwith loving tenderness.
   4: 
   5: And my Sorrow grew like all living things, strong and beautifuland full of wondrous delights.
   6: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   7: And we loved one another, my Sorrow and I, and we loved the worldabout us; for Sorrow had a kindly heart and mine was kindly withSorrow.
   8: 
   9: And when we conversed, my Sorrow and I, our days were winged andour nights were girdled with dreams; for Sorrow had an eloquenttongue, and mine was eloquent with Sorrow.
  10: 
  11: And when we sang together, my Sorrow and I, our neighbors sat attheir windows and listened; for our songs were deep as the sea andour melodies were full of strange memories.
  12: 
  13: And when we walked together, my Sorrow and I, people gazed at uswith gentle eyes and whispered in words of exceeding sweetness.
  14: 
  15: And there were those who looked with envy upon us, for Sorrow wasa noble thing and I was proud with Sorrow.
  16: 
  17: But my Sorrow died, like all living things, and alone I am left tomuse and ponder.
  18: 
  19: And now when I speak my words fall heavily upon my ears.
  20: 
  21: And when I sing my songs my neighbours come not to listen.
  22: 
  23: And when I walk the streets no one looks at me.
  24: 
  25: Only in my sleep I hear voices saying in pity, “See, there liesthe man whose Sorrow is dead.
