#1300: 173479_The Seven Selves_Gibran, Kahlil_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Seven Selves
Author: Gibran, Kahlil
Prose starts at line: 17
Lines to remove: 17
Avg verse line length: 93.5
Avg prose line length: 154.6

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  12: 
  13: Third Self:  And what of me, the love-ridden self, the flaming brandof wild passion and fantastic desires?
  14: 
  15: It is I the love-sick selfwho would rebel against this madman.
  16: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  17: Fourth Self:  I, amongst you all, am the most miserable, for naughtwas given me but odious hatred and destructive loathing.
  18: 
  19: It isI, the tempest-like self, the one born in the black caves of Hell,who would protest against serving this madman.
  20: 
  21: Fifth Self:  Nay, it is I, the thinking self, the fanciful self,the self of hunger and thirst, the one doomed to wander withoutrest in search of unknown things and things not yet created; it isI, not you, who would rebel.
  22: 
  23: Sixth Self:  And I, the working self, the pitiful labourer, who,with patient hands, and longing eyes, fashion the days into imagesand give the formless elements new and eternal forms—it is I, thesolitary one, who would rebel against this restless madman.
  24: 
  25: Seventh Self:  How strange that you all would rebel against thisman, because each and every one of you has a preordained fate tofulfill.
  26: 
  27: Ah! could I but be like one of you, a self with a determinedlot!  But I have none, I am the do-nothing self, the one who sitsin the dumb, empty nowhere and nowhen, while you are busy re-creatinglife.
  28: 
  29: Is it you or I, neighbours, who should rebel?
  30: 
  31: When the seventh self thus spake the other six selves looked withpity upon him but said nothing more; and as the night grew deeperone after the other went to sleep enfolded with a new and happysubmission.
  32: 
  33: But the seventh self remained watching and gazing at nothingness,which is behind all things.

Title: The Three Ants
Author: Gibran, Kahlil
Prose starts at line: 11

Avg prose line length: 133.4

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   6: 
   7: The first ant said, “These hills and plains are the most barren Ihave known.
   8: 
   9: I have searched all day for a grain of some sort, andthere is none to be found.
  10: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  11: ”Said the second ant, “I too have found nothing, though I havevisited every nook and glade.
  12: 
  13: This is, I believe, what my peoplecall the soft, moving land where nothing grows.
  14: 
  15: ”Then the third ant raised his head and said, “My friends, we arestanding now on the nose of the Supreme Ant, the mighty and infiniteAnt, whose body is so great that we cannot see it, whose shadowis so vast that we cannot trace it, whose voice is so loud that wecannot hear it; and He is omnipresent.
  16: 
  17: ”When the third ant spoke thus the other ants looked at each otherand laughed.
  18: 
  19: At that moment the man moved and in his sleep raised his hand andscratched his nose, and the three ants were crushed.

   4:

   6: 
   7: ”Then the autumn leaf lay down upon the earth and slept.
   8:

  10:

   1: The Pomegranate
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: Once when I was living in the heart of a pomegranate, I heard a seedsaying, “Someday I shall become a tree, and the wind will sing inmy branches, and the sun will dance on my leaves, and I shall bestrong and beautiful through all the seasons.
   4: 
   5: ”Then another seed spoke and said, “When I was as young as you, Itoo held such views; but now that I can weigh and measure things,I see that my hopes were vain.
   6: 
   7: ”And a third seed spoke also, “I see in us nothing that promises sogreat a future.
   8: 
   9: ”And a fourth said, “But what a mockery our life would be, withouta greater future!”Said a fifth, “Why dispute what we shall be, when we know not evenwhat we are.
  10: 
  11: ”But a sixth replied, “Whatever we are, that we shall continue tobe.
  12: 
  13: ”And a seventh said, “I have such a clear idea how everything willbe, but I cannot put it into words.
  14: 
  15: ”Then an eight spoke—and a ninth—and a tenth—and then many—untilall were speaking, and I could distinguish nothing for the manyvoices.
  16: 
  17: And so I moved that very day into the heart of a quince, where theseeds are few and almost silent.

   2: 
   3: Once there ruled in the distant city of Wirani a king who was bothmighty and wise.
   4: 
   5: And he was feared for his might and loved forhis wisdom.
   6: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   7: Now, in the heart of that city was a well, whose water was cool andcrystalline, from which all the inhabitants drank, even the kingand his courtiers; for there was no other well.
   8: 
   9: One night when all were asleep, a witch entered the city, and pouredseven drops of strange liquid into the well, and said, “From thishour he who drinks this water shall become mad.
  10: 
  11: ”Next morning all the inhabitants, save the king and his lordchamberlain, drank from the well and became mad, even as the witchhad foretold.
  12: 
  13: And during that day the people in the narrow streets and in themarket places did naught but whisper to one another, “The king ismad.
  14: 
  15: Our king and his lord chamberlain have lost their reason.
  16: 
  17: Surely we cannot be ruled by a mad king.
  18: 
  19: We must dethrone him.
  20: 
  21: ”That evening the king ordered a golden goblet to be filled from thewell.
  22: 
  23: And when it was brought to him he drank deeply, and gave itto his lord chamberlain to drink.
  24: 
  25: And there was great rejoicing in that distant city of Wirani,because its king and its lord chamberlain had regained their reason.

  31: 
  32: 25 and 26]
  33: Xenophanes on the geologic cycle:

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  34: “Xenophanes thinks that a mixture of the earth with the sea is going on…He says that he has demonstrations of the following kind: shells are found inland and in the mountains, and in the quarries in Syracuse he says that an impression of a fish and of seaweed has been found, while an impression of a bay-leaf was found in Paros in the depth of the rock, and in Malta flat shapes of all marine objects.
  35: 
  36: These, he says, were produced when everything was long ago covered with mud, and the impression dried in the mud.
  37: 
  38: All mankind is destroyed whenever the earth is carried down into the sea and becomes mud; then there is another beginning of coming-to-be (“genesis”), and this foundation happens for all the worlds.
  39: 
  40: ”  [Hippolytus, Ref.
  41: 
  42: 1.
  43: 
  44: 14.
  45: 
  46: 5]

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: The Bait
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: Saturday mornings, beforemy weekly chores,I used to sneak out of the houseand across the street,grabbing the first grasshopperwalking in the damp California grassalong the stream.
   4: 
   5: Carefully hiding a silver hookbeneath its green wings,I'd float it outacross the gentle ripplestowards the end of its life.
   6: 
   7: Just like that.
   8: 
   9: I'd give it the hookand let it ride.
  10: 
  11: All I ever expected for itwas that big-mouth bassawaiting its arrival.
  12: 
  13: I didn't thinkthat I was giving up one lifeto get another,that even childhoodwas full of sacrifice.
  14: 
  15: I'd just take the bright green thing,pluck it off its only stalk,and give it away as ifit were mine to give.
  16: 
  17: I knew someone out therewould be fooled,that someone would acceptthe precious gift.
  18: 
  19: So I just sent it alongwith a plea of a prayer,hoping it would spread its wings this timeand fly across that wet glass sky,no concern for what inspiredits life, or mine,only instinct guiding paintowards the other side.

 124: 
 125: * The gloves, to which Eliza's assistance was solicited, were knit upon wires.
 126: 
 127: * "Ere we divide it," &c.
 128: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 129: Alluding to the proverbial expression current amongst the Zetland fishermen, viz.
 130: 
 131: "Do not divide the fish before it comes into the boat," is often applied, as in the present case, to check the progress of air-built castles.
 132: 
 133: * "At least none but the comic muse," &c.
 134: 
 135: The former poem, beginning "Avaunt! ye Nine," &c.
 136: 
 137: was addressed to the Muses, on account of their treatment of the lady to whom this epistle is written.

#1315: 174056_Verses- In Humble Imitation of Burns_Chalmers, Margaret_unknown.txt

Title: Verses: In Humble Imitation of Burns
Author: Chalmers, Margaret
Prose starts at line: 166
Lines to remove: 9
Avg verse line length: 26.8
Avg prose line length: 118.6

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 161: Their help combine,
 162: Gang ye a fleechin to the Three ,
 163: Ne'er fash the Nine .
 164: 
 165: Authors Note:

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 166: I beg it may not be supposed, that these Verses express my ideas respecting the information and intelligence of the Ayrshire Bard with regard to this country.
 167: 
 168: But the thought striking me, that had he been alive, he might, perhaps, have been amused with the novelty of a poetic essay from a Zetland Authoress; my feeble attempt is made on the supposition of his giving the reins to his enlivening vein of raillery and burlesque.
 169: 
 170: Well am I convinced, although I have attempted the Imitation , that he is inimitable .
 171: 
 172: Why then embark in the vain pursuit of imitating the inimitable?
 173: 
 174: I stand reproved.

 286: The female of the Halcyon,
 287: Love, the seductive Sirens,
 288: All know the fatal songs
 289: Dangerous and inhuman.
 290: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 291: The sailors, hearing the female Halycon sing, prepared to die, safe however around mid-December, when these birds make their nests, and one knows that then the sea will be calm.
 292: 
 293: Like Love and the Sirens, these birds sing so melodiously that even the life of those who hear them is not too great a price to pay for such music.
 294: 
 295: This cherubim
 296: One may distinguish among the angelic hierarchies, vowed to the service and glory of the divine, beings with unknown forms and the most amazing beauty.
 297: 
 298: The cherubim are winged oxen, but in no way monstrous.
 299: 
 300: When the good God intends.
 301: 
 302: Those who practice poetry search for and love only the perfection that is God Himself.
 303: 
 304: And will this divine grace, this supreme perfection depart those for whom life exists only to discover and glorify them?
 305: 
 306: That seems impossible, and, to my mind, poets have the right to hope after their death for the everlasting happiness that obtains complete knowledge of God, that is to say of the sublime beauty.

#1318: 174599_A Word With The West_Thompson, John Reuben_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: A Word With The West
Author: Thompson, John Reuben
Prose starts at line: 160
Lines to remove: 13
Avg verse line length: 60.2
Avg prose line length: 138.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 155: 
 156: S.
 157: 
 158: Congress, and wrote about his wartime experiences.
 159: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 160: He died of pneumonia in 1891 after serving as a pallbearer at Sherman's funeral and standing hatless in the rain.
 161: 
 162: The remaining stanzas of the poem constitute a plea to the border states of Tennessee, Kentucky, and Missouri to stand with the Confederacy against the Union.
 163: 
 164: The "former bold clan chief" mentioned in the fifth stanza of the poem is Albert Sidney Johnston, Jefferson Davis's favorite general and former Secretary of War for the Republic of Texas, who was killed in the first day's fighting at the Battle of Shiloh in April of 1862.
 165: 
 166: So far as is know, he and Joe Johnston were not related.
 167: 
 168: The "McNiel" referred to in the penultimate stanza is Union General John McNeil, a native of Nova Scotia who worked as a hatter first in Boston and then in St.
 169: 
 170: Louis and served in the Missouri State legislature.
 171: 
 172: He was not well loved by Missourians with Southern leanings after administering a sound drubbing to Confederate forces at Fulton, Missouri, on July 17, 1861.

  81: Following Captain Latane's death in hand-to-hand combat, his younger brother James loaded his body on a farm cart and carried it to Westwood, the nearby home of Mrs.
  82:

  84:

  86: 
  87: Brockenbrough, Mrs.
  88: 
  89: Willoughby Newton, who read the funeral service, a handful of women and children, and a few slaves.
  90: 
  91: Immediately after the War, William D.
  92: 
  93: Washington painted an oil on canvas entitled "The Burial of Latane.
  94: 
  95: " Engravings of the painting published soon thereafter and made available at reasonable cost were hung in parlors throughout the South.
  96: 
  97: The picture quickly became a major symbol of mourning for "the Lost Cause.

  32: We made a certain attempt to be sincere in the above verses; but even at that no doubt a lot of affectation crept in.

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: Four in the morning by the river, our bodies like silhouettes, not bodies, in the sodium light.
   4: 
   5: Our backs against the asphalt, the hum-threat of mosquitoes about our ears, brushing ankles, us sweating in the after-storm with the sky gone clear.
   6: 
   7: Meteors hide behind the dull scrim of light—this same shower witnessed for two thousand years.
   8: 
   9: We catch their movement in our periphery, two hundred every hour, like small animals moving in the dark that are sensed more than seen.
  10: 
  11: Some tear through the sky’s veil, burn like the bright-carpet of an animal eye mirroring the headlight thrown onto it.
  12: 
  13: It’s hard to imagine all that burning made of dust; it’s hard to imagine us, the unexplainable ranging within us, keeping us.
  14: 
  15: It’s hard to imagine watching every yawn and grief disappear, either in space or in the water beneath that space.
  16: 
  17: But that is where we are.

#1325: 175685_The Pipe_Mallarmé, Stéphane_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Pipe
Author: Mallarmé, Stéphane
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 9
Avg verse line length: 8.0
Avg prose line length: 403.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: The Pipe
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: Yesterday I found my pipe while pondering a long evening of work, of fine winter work.
   4: 
   5: Thrown aside were my cigarettes, with all the childish joys of summer, into the past which the leaves shining blue in the sun, the muslins, illuminate, and taken up once again was the grave pipe of a serious man who wants to smoke for a long while without being disturbed, so as better to work: but I was not prepared for the surprise that this abandoned object had in store for me; for hardly had I drawn the first puff when I forgot the grand books I was planning to write, and, amazed, moved to a feeling of tenderness, I breathed in the air of the previous winter which was now coming back to me.
   6: 
   7: I had not been in contact with my faithful sweetheart since returning to France, and now all of London, London as I had lived it a year ago entirely alone, appeared before my eyes: first the dear fogs that muffle one’s brains and have an odor of their own there when they penetrate beneath the casements.
   8: 
   9: My tobacco had the scent of a somber room with leather furniture sprinkled by coal dust, on which the thin black cat would curl and stretch; the big fires! and the maid with red arms pouring coals, and the noise of those coals falling from the sheet-iron bucket into the iron scuttle in the morning—when the postman gave the solemn double knock that kept me alive! Once again I saw through the windows those sickly trees of the deserted square—I saw the open sea, crossed so often that winter, shivering on the deck of the steamer wet with drizzle and blackened from the fumes—with my poor wandering beloved, decked out in traveller’s clothes, a long dress, dull as the dust of the roads, a coat clinging damply to her cold shoulders, one of those straw hats with no feather and hardly any ribbons that wealthy ladies throw away upon arrival, mangled as they are by the sea, and that poor loved ones refurbish for many another season.
  10: 
  11: Around her neck was wound the terrible handkerchief that one waves when saying goodbye forever.

  14:

   3: The welcome Sun from sea Freake is returned, And cheereth with his beams the naked earth, Which gains with his coming her apparel And had his absence six long months mourned.
   4: 
   5: Out of her fragrant sides she sends to greet him The rashed primrose and the violet; While she the fields and meadows doth beset With flowers, and hangs the trees with pearl to meet him.
   6: 
   7: Amid this hope and joy she doth forget, To kill the hemlock which doth grow too fast, And chill the adder making too much haste, With his black sons revived with the heat;
   8: 
   9: Till summer comes with diverse colours clad,
  10: 
  11: Much like my Epigrams both good and bad.

   6:

   8:

  12:

   5:

   7: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   8: You had asked for Earl Grey cookies sandwiched around buttercream or marshmallows made of chocolate, but all the tea bags had been dunked and the chocolate melted over biscotti.
   9: 
  10: When I came bearing the salted and twisted news, the room was empty but for a heel.
  11: 
  12: It was black as a bunting, and wound with zippers, and every time the car rocked it looked ready to fly and escape into the cold, tangled air of   travel that always feels heavy with joy and desire, and a little sadness, always a little sadness, because of the leaving, which is what I do when I realize I’m in the wrong room and that numbers have betrayed me again while I was hunting and gathering, foraging like Homo habilis who probably never lost his cave.
  13: 
  14: Out of patience, I opened every door marked with threes and eights, those conjoined twins disastrously separated at birth, and roused the scabbed eyes of sleepers like a beggar, no, an angel, a begging angel who has written on his heart will work for love.
  15: 
  16: Having not found our room, not heard the sharp swing of   your voice, I descended upon the passenger cars and row upon row of couples asleep or staring out the windows like zombies trying to remember what happens next once the newspaper is well-thumbed, the tea has gone cold, and the conversation is dead.
  17: 
  18: I called for you, in vain, even using your secret names, the ones only the night knows: wind-kiss, brilliant-fruit, dervish-moon    .
  19: 
  20: 
  21: Over and over, I said your names, over and over until they filled the wounded air of  the car and when there was no more room for another sound, they caught and hooked the ring of   the brakes hugging the rails.
  22: 
  23: Just when I thought I wouldn’t find you, you were there, the train was pulling away, and I was watching you slowly eat a dish of whipped cream and bananas— the house special — in a cafe in a city we didn’t know.
  24: 
  25: When you finished, we started walking down a road that bent like a smile, a shy smile, like the one the Japanese cat wore on your purse.
  26: 
  27: The road, we were told, would take us to the end of   the line where all lovers in search of   joy packed on bullet trains — they’re the fastest on two continents — arrive every hour.

  22: 
  23: Mothers are God again, and they will not go quietly; they know everything born will need to be fed, even children hung from low branches in their jean jackets and muddy tennis shoes, carried out of the wood into the light of everyone's suffering.

#1338: 177636_Rosalind and Helen- a Modern Eclogue_Shelley, Percy Bysshe_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Rosalind and Helen: a Modern Eclogue
Author: Shelley, Percy Bysshe
Prose starts at line: 1673
Lines to remove: 15
Avg verse line length: 33.7
Avg prose line length: 144.9

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1668: 
1669: Ollier, London, 1819 (spring).
1670: 
1671: Note by Mrs.
1672: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1673: Shelley: 'Rosalind and Helen was begun at Marlow, and thrown aside -- till I found it; and, at my request, it was completed.
1674: 
1675: Shelley had no care for any of his poems that did not emanate from the depths of his mind and develop some high or abstruse truth.
1676: 
1677: When he does touch on human life and the human heart, no pictures can be more faithful, more delicate, more subtle, or more pathetic.
1678: 
1679: He never mentioned Love but he shed a grace borrowed from his own nature, that scarcely any other poet has bestowed, on that passion.
1680: 
1681: When he spoke of it as the law of life, which inasmuch as we rebel against we err and injure ourselves and others, he promulgated that which he considered an irrefragable truth.
1682: 
1683: In his eyes it was the essence of our being, and all woe and pain arose from the war made against it by selfishness, or insensibility, or mistake.
1684: 
1685: By reverting in his mind to this first principle, he discovered the source of many emotions, and could disclose the secrets of all hearts; and his delineations of passion and emotion touch the finest chords of our nature.
1686: 
1687: Rosalind and Helen was finished during the summer of 1818, while we were at the baths of Lucca.


====================================================================================================
#1339: 177679_Peter Bell The Third_Shelley, Percy Bysshe_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Peter Bell The Third
Author: Shelley, Percy Bysshe
Prose starts at line: 1050
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 32.3
Avg prose line length: 195.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1045: 
1046: Note by Mrs.
1047: 
1048: Shelley: 'In this new edition I have added Peter Bell the Third.
1049: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1050: A critique on Wordsworth's Peter Bell reached us at Leghorn, which amused Shelley exceedingly, and suggested this poem.
1051: 
1052: I need scarcely observe that nothing personal to the author of Peter Bell is intended in this poem.
1053: 
1054: No man ever admired Wordsworth's poetry more; -- he read it perpetually, and taught others to appreciate its beauties.
1055: 
1056: This poem is, like all others written by Shelley, ideal.
1057: 
1058: He conceived the idealism of a poet -- a man of lofty and creative genius -- quitting the glorious calling of discovering and announcing the beautiful and good, to support and propagate ignorant prejudices and pernicious errors; imparting to the unenlightened, not that ardour for truth and spirit of toleration which Shelley looked on as the sources of the moral improvement and happiness of mankind, but false and injurious opinions, that evil was good, and that ignorance and force were the best allies of purity and virtue.
1059: 
1060: His idea was that a man gifted, even as transcendently as the author of Peter Bell, with the highest qualities of genius, must, if he fostered such errors, be infected with dulness.
1061: 
1062: This poem was written as a warning -- not as a narration of the reality.
1063: 
1064: He was unaquainted personally with Wordsworth or with Coleridge (to whom he alludes in the fifth part of the poem), and therefore, I repeat, his poem is purely ideal; -- it contains something of criticism on the compositions of those great poets, but nothing injurious to the men themselves.
1065: 
1066: No poem contains more of Shelley's peculiar views with regard to the errors into which many of the wisest have fallen, and the pernicious effects of certain opinions on society.
1067: 
1068: Much of it is beautifully written: and, though, like the burlesque drama of Swellfoot, it must be looked on as a plaything, it has so much merit and poetry -- so much of himself in it -- that it cannot failt to interest greatly, and by right belongs to the world for those whose instruction and benefit it was written.


====================================================================================================
#1340: 177783_Fragments Of An Unfinished Drama_Shelley, Percy Bysshe_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Fragments Of An Unfinished Drama
Author: Shelley, Percy Bysshe
Prose starts at line: 383
Lines to remove: 11
Avg verse line length: 34.7
Avg prose line length: 130.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 378: 
 379: Written at Pisa during the late winter or early spring of 1822.
 380: 
 381: Note from Mrs.
 382: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 383: Shelley: 'The following fragments are part of a Drama undertaken for the amusement of the individuals who composed our intimate society, but left unfinished.
 384: 
 385: I have preserved a sketch of the story as far as it had been shadowed in the poet's mind.
 386: 
 387: An Enchantress, living in one of the islands of the Indian Archipelago, saves the life of a Pirate, a man of savage but noble nature.
 388: 
 389: She becomes enamoured of him; and he, inconstant to his mortal love, for a while returns her passion; but at length, recalling the memory of her whom he left, and who laments his loss, he escapes from the Enchanted Island, and returns to his lady.
 390: 
 391: His mode of life makes him again go to sea, and the Enchantress seizes the opportunity to bring him, by a spirit-brewed tempest, back to her Island.
 392: 
 393: '~1839.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 964: 
 965: These baths were of great use to Shelley in soothing his nervous irritability.
 966: 
 967: We made several excursions in the neighbourhood.
 968: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 969: The country around is fertile, and diversified and rendered picturesque by ranges of near hills and more distant mountains.
 970: 
 971: The peasantry are a handsome intelligent race; and there was a gladsome sunny heaven spread over us, that rendered home and every scene we visited cheerful and bright.
 972: 
 973: During some of the hottest days of August, Shelley made a solitary journey on foot to the summit of Monte San Pellegrino -- a mountain of some height, on the top of which there is a chapel, the object, during certain days of the year, of many pilgrimages.
 974: 
 975: The excursion delighted him while it lasted; though he exerted himself too much, and the effect was considerable lsasitude and weakness on his return.
 976: 
 977: During the expedition he conceived the idea, and wrote, in the three days immediately succeeding to his return, the Witch of Atlas.
 978: 
 979: This poem is peculiarly characteristic of his tastes -- wildly fanciful, full of brilliant imagery, and discarding human interest and passion, to revel in the fantastic ideas that his imagination suggested.


====================================================================================================

Author: Shelley, Percy Bysshe
Prose starts at line: 894

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 889: 
 890: , 1824, indicates the time when the text was finally revised by Shelley.
 891: 
 892: Note by Mrs.
 893: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 894: Shelley: 'From the Baths of Lucca, in 1818, Shelley visited Venice; and, circumstances rendering it eligible that we should remain a few weeks in the neighbourhood of that city, he accepted the offer of Lord Byron, who lent him the use of a villa he rented near Este; and he sent for his family from Lucca to join him.
 895: 
 896: I Capuccini was a villa built on the site of a Capuchin convent, demolished when the French suppressed religious houses; it was situated on the very overhanging brow of a low hill at the foot of a range of higher ones.
 897: 
 898: The house was cheerful and pleasant; a vine-trellised walk, a pergola, as it is called in Italian, led from the hall-door to a summer-house at the end of the garden, which Shelley made his study, and in which he began the Prometheus; and here also, as he mentions in a letter, he wrote Julian and Maddalo.
 899: 
 900: A slight ravine, with a road in its depth, divided the garden from the hill, on which stood the ruins of the ancient castle of Este, whose dark massive wall gave forth an echo, and from whose ruined crevices owls and bats flitted forth at night, as the crescent moon sunk behind the black and heavy battlements.
 901: 
 902: We looked from the garden over the wide plain of Lombardy, bounded to the west by the far Apennines, while to the east the horizon was lost in misty distance.
 903: 
 904: After the picturesque but limited view of mountain, ravine, and chestnutwood, at the Baths of Lucca, there was something infinitely gratifying to the eye in the wide range of prospect commanded by our new abode.

   1: Apprehension
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: ‘Oh! sister, he is so swift and tall, Though I want the ride, he will spoil it all, For, when he sets out, he will let me fall,
   4: 
   5: And give me a bump, I know! Mamma, what was it I heard you say, About the world’s hobbies, the other day, How some would get on and gallop away,
   6: 
   7: To end with an overthrow?
   8: 
   9: ’ ‘I said, little prattler, the world was a race, That many would mount with a smile on the face, And ride to their ruin, or fall in disgrace:
  10: 
  11: That him, who was deaf to fear, And did not look our for a rein or a guide, His courser might cast on the highway side, In the mud, rocks and brambles, to end his ride,
  12: 
  13: Perchance with a sight and a tear!’ ‘Oh! sister, sister! I fear to try; For Brutus’s back is so live and high! It creeps at my touch – and he winks his eye—
  14: 
  15: I’m sure he is going to jump! Come! dear mother, tell us some more About the world’s ride, as you did before, Who helped it up – and all how it bore
  16: 
  17: The fall, and got over the bump!’

   2: 
   3: May 4th, 1898.
   4: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]

   5: —To-day, fishing down the Swiftwater, I found Joseph Jefferson on a big rock in the middle of the brook, casting the fly for trout.
   6: 
   7: He said he had fished this very stream three-and-forty years ago; and near by, in the Paradise Valley, he wrote his famous play.
   8: 
   9: —Leaf from my Diary.
  10: 
  11: We met on Nature's stage,
  12: And May had set the scene,
  13: With bishop-caps standing in delicate ranks,
  14: And violets blossoming over the banks,
  15: While the brook ran full between.
  16: 
  17: The waters rang your call,
  18: With frolicsome waves a-twinkle,—
  19: They knew you as boy, and they knew you as man,
  20: And every wave, as it merrily ran,
  21: Cried, “Enter Rip van Winkle!”

   3: Unstable dream, according to the place,Be steadfast once, or else at least be true.
   4: 
   5: By tasted sweetness make me not to rueThe sudden loss of thy false feignèd grace.
   6: 
   7: By good respect in such a dangerous caseThou broughtest not her into this tossing mewBut madest my sprite live, my care to renew,My body in tempest her succour to embrace.
   8: 
   9: The body dead, the sprite had his desire,Painless was th'one, th'other in delight.
  10:

  12: 
  13: And where it was at wish, it could not remain,
  14: 
  15: Such mocks of dreams they turn to deadly pain.

   3: Avising the bright beams of these fair eyesWhere he is that mine oft moisteth and washeth,The wearied mind straight from the heart departethFor to rest in his worldly paradiseAnd find the sweet bitter under this guise.
   4: 
   5: What webs he hath wrought well he perceivethWhereby with himself on love he plainethThat spurreth with fire and bridleth with ice.
   6: 
   7: Thus is it in such extremity brought,In frozen thought, now and now it standeth in flame.
   8: 
   9: Twixt misery and wealth, twixt earnest and game,But few glad, and many diverse thoughtWith sore repentance of his hardiness.
  10: 
  11: Of such a root cometh fruit fruitless.

   2:

   4:

   6: 
   7: Wherewithall unto the hert's forest he fleeth, Leaving his enterprise with pain and cry, And there him hideth and not appeareth.
   8: 
   9: What may I do when my master feareth But in the field with him to live and die?
  10: 
  11: For good is the life ending faithfully.

   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]

   4: 
   5: Senec and Plato call me from thy loreTo perfect wealth, my wit for to endeavour.
   6: 
   7: In blind error when I did persever,Thy sharp repulse, that pricketh aye so sore,Hath taught me to set in trifles no storeAnd scape forth, since liberty is lever.
   8: 
   9: Therefore farewell; go trouble younger heartsAnd in me claim no more authority.
  10: 
  11: With idle youth go use thy propertyAnd thereon spend thy many brittle darts,For hitherto though I have lost all my time,Me lusteth no lenger rotten boughs to climb.

   8:

  12:

  14: 
  15: I desire to perish, and yet I ask health.
  16: 
  17: I love another, and thus I hate myself.
  18: 
  19: I feed me in sorrow and laugh in all my pain; Likewise displeaseth me both life and death, And my delight is causer of this strife.

  71: So that Platonic realm where Mathematicsmustexist to be discovered by Ramanujan or Hardy or Arcturans tucked in anywhere in time or space isjustthat space where earlier equations live, likelove’s a roseortears are rain, which Hardy’sandRamanujan’s respective ancestors discovered independently?

  74:

  76: 
  77: That hadn’t the acclaimed predictive potency of mathematics best be cast asa reminder of forgotten shock—the shock our shaggy kind must once have felt, framing for the first time well-formed sentences about the world that was, and then about the world about to be, and so extended human sensibility  and thrust it forth as backward through the night of time?
  78: 
  79: Yes, if diffidently.

#1359: 179725_Photo of a Man on Sunset Drive- 1914, 2008_Blanco, Richard_unknown.txt

Author: Blanco, Richard
Prose starts at line: 11

Avg prose line length: 223.6

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   6: 
   7: 
   8: 
   9: 
  10: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  11: And so it began: the earth torn, split open by a dirt road cutting through palmettos and wild tamarind trees defending the land against the sun.
  12: 
  13: Beside the road, a shack leaning into the wind, on the wooden porch, crates of avocados and limes, white chickens pecking at the floor boards, and a man under the shadow of his straw hat, staring into the camera in 1914.
  14: 
  15: He doesn't know within a lifetime the unclaimed land behind him will be cleared of scrub and sawgrass, the soil will be turned, made to give back what the farmers wish, their lonely houses will stand acres apart from one another, jailed behind the boughs of their orchards.
  16: 
  17: He'll never buy sugar at the general store, mail love letters at the post office, or take a train at the depot of the town that will rise out of hundred-million years of coral rock on promises of paradise.
  18: 
  19: He'll never ride a Model-T puttering down the dirt road that will be paved over, stretch farther and farther west into the horizon, reaching for the setting sun after which it will be named.
  20: 
  21: He can't even begin to imagine the shadows of buildings rising taller than the palm trees, the street lights glowing like counterfeit stars dotting the sky above the road, the thousands who will take the road everyday, who'll also call this place home less than a hundred years after the photograph of him hanging today in City Hall as testament.
  22: 
  23: He'll never meet me, the engineer hired to transform the road again, bring back tree shadows and birdsongs, build another promise of another paradise meant to last another forever.
  24: 
  25: He'll never see me, the poet standing before him, trying to read his mind across time, wondering if he was thinking what I'm today, both of us looking down the road that will stretch on for years after I too disappear into a photo.

  14: 
  15: Only then—either one gives until breaking or one does not.

  18: 
  19: O Forefathers! You who have always refused to die,Who knew how to resist Death from the Sine to the Seine,And now in the fragile veins of my indomitable blood,Guard my dreams as you did your thin-legged migrant sons!O Ancestors! Defend the roofs of Paris in this dominical fog,The roofs that protect my dead.
  20: 
  21: Let me leave this tower so dangerously secureAnd descend to the streets, joining my brothersWho have blue eyes and hard hands.

#1363: 180212_'A Prayer'_Ehrmann, Max_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: "A Prayer"
Author: Ehrmann, Max
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 10.0
Avg prose line length: 122.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: "A Prayer"
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: Let me do my work each day; and if the darkened hours of despair overcome me, may I not forget the strength that comforted me in the desolation of other times.
   4: 
   5: May I still remember the bright hours that found me walking over the silent hills of my childhood, or dreaming on the margin of a quiet river, when a light glowed within me, and I promised my early God to have courage amid the tempests of the changing years.
   6: 
   7: Spare me from bitterness and from the sharp passions of unguarded moments.
   8: 
   9: May I not forget that poverty and riches are of the spirit.
  10: 
  11: Though the world knows me not, may my thoughts and actions be such as shall keep me friendly with myself.
  12: 
  13: Lift up my eyes from the earth, and let me not forget the uses of the stars.
  14: 
  15: Forbid that I should judge others lest I condemn myself.
  16: 
  17: Let me not follow the clamor of the world, but walk calmly in my path.
  18: 
  19: Give me a few friends who will love me for what I am; and keep ever burning before my vagrant steps the  kindly light of hope.
  20: 
  21: And though age and infirmity overtake me, and I come not within sight of the castle of my dreams, teach me still to be thankful for life, and for time's olden memories that are good and sweet; and may the evening's twilight find me gentle still.

 230:

 232: 
 233: ': An allusion to the old belief that certain trees bore barnacles each of which contained a perfectly formed goose, known as the solan goose.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  10: Tho’ thou hast op’d thine eyes in endless day;
  11: And nought, on earth, can chase away my grief
  12: But faith - pleading the merits of the Cross,
  13: And Him, who’s promise gives us sure relief.
  14: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  15: ane Johnston Schoolcraft, the daughter of Irish trader John Johnston and Ojibwa leader Susan Johnston, emerged as one of the earliest Native American writers.
  16: 
  17: Although only a small portion of her writing was published during her lifetime, her profound influence on her husband, Henry Rowe Schoolcraft, greatly contributed to the development of formal American folklore studies.
  18: 
  19: Even during their era, the American literary community acknowledged that she was the driving creative force behind their collaborative efforts.
  20: 
  21: Tragically, William Henry Schoolcraft, her firstborn, passed away in 1827, shortly before his third birthday.
  22: 
  23: It was a devastating loss for Jane Johnston Schoolcraft and her family.
  24: 
  25: Note: In this context, the term "sonnet" refers to a small poem in a general sense, rather than adhering strictly to the specific form.

#1367: 180896_Glencoe_Stewart, Douglas Alexander_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Glencoe
Author: Stewart, Douglas Alexander
Prose starts at line: 28
Lines to remove: 15
Avg verse line length: 24.4
Avg prose line length: 118.1

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  23: Sigh, wind in the pine,
  24: Cover it with snow;
  25: But terrible things were done
  26: Long, long ago.
  27: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  28: Early in the morning of 13 February 1692, in the aftermath of the Glorious Revolution and the Jacobite uprising of 1689 led by John Graham of Claverhouse, an infamous massacre took place in the Valley of Glencoe, in the Highlands of Scotland.
  29: 
  30: This incident is referred to as the Massacre of Glencoe, or in Scottish Gaelic, 'Mort Ghlinne Comhann' (murder of Glen Coe).
  31: 
  32: The massacre began simultaneously in three settlements along the glen—Invercoe, Inverrigan, and Achnacon—although the killing took place all over the glen as fleeing MacDonalds were pursued.
  33: 
  34: Thirty-eight MacDonalds from the Clan MacDonald of Glencoe were killed by the guests who had accepted their hospitality, on the grounds that the MacDonalds had not been prompt in pledging allegiance to the new monarchs, William and Mary.
  35: 
  36: Another forty women and children died of exposure after their homes were burned.
  37: 
  38: http://en.
  39: 
  40: wikipedia.
  41: 
  42: org/wiki/MassacreofGlencoe#OathofallegiancetoWilliam

 139: 
 140: , Sydney, Australia, © 1899, pp.
 141: 
 142: 35-39.
 143: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 144: The story told by a stevedore in this poem is set in the period during and shortly after the American Civil War, and describes this ship's exploits as a Rebel blockade runner and later as a slave trader.
 145: 
 146: The use of the pejorative term "nigger" in this poem was typically used among the White stevedores as they worked on the Sydney docks.
 147: 
 148: It's usage is regrettable but an accurate reflection of the racism rampant in Australia (and in many other parts of the world) in the 1890's.
 149: 
 150: "lots of graft" is old British labour slang for "lots of effort.
 151: 
 152: Charley Noble

   2: 
   3: You that I loved all my life long, you are not the one.
   4: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   5: You that I followed, my line or path or way, that I followed singing, and you earth and air of the world the way went through, and you who stood around it so it could be the way, you forests and cities, you deer and opossums struck by the lonely hunter and left decaying, you paralyzed obese ones who sat on a falling porch in a deep green holler and observed me, your bald dog barking, as I stumbled past in a hurry along my line, you are not the one.
   6: 
   7: But you are the one, you that I loved all my life long, you I still love so in my dying mind I grasp me loving you when we are gone.
   8: 
   9: You are the one, you path or way or line that winds beside the house where she and I live on, still longing though long gone for the health of all forests and cities, and one day to visit them, one day be rich and free enough to go and see the restricted wonders of the earth.
  10: 
  11: And you are the one, old ladies fated from birth to ugliness, obesity and dearth, who sat beside my path one day as I flashed by.
  12: 
  13: And you are the one, all tumble-down shacks in disregarded hills and animals the car on the road kills and leaves stinking in the sun.

#1373: 181085_BETTER DAYS_Moritz, A F_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: BETTER DAYS
Author: Moritz, A F
Prose starts at line: 3
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 11.0
Avg prose line length: 142.8

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: BETTER DAYS
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: Never anymore in a wash of sweetness and awe  does the summer when I was seventeen come back  to mind against my will, like a bird crossing  my vision.
   4: 
   5: Summer of moist nights full of girls  and boys ripened, holy drunkenness and violation  of the comic boundaries, defiances that never  failed or brought disaster.
   6: 
   7: Days on the backs  and in the breath of horses, between rivers  and pools that reflected the cicadas' whine,  enervation and strength creeping in smooth waves  over muscular water.
   8: 
   9: All those things accepted,  once, with unnoticing hunger, as an infant  accepts the nipple, never come back to mind  against the will.
  10: 
  11: What comes unsummoned now,  blotting out every other thought and image,  is a part of the past not so deep or far away:  the time of poverty, of struggle to find means  not hateful—the muddy seedtime of early manhood.
  12: 
  13: What returns are those moments in the diner  night after night with each night's one cup of coffee,  watching an old man, who always at the same hour  came in and smiled, ordered his tea and opened  his drawing pad.
  14: 
  15: What did he fill it with?
  16: 
  17: And where's he gone?
  18: 
  19: Those days, that studious worker,  hand moving and eyes eager in the sour light,  that artist always in the same worn-out suit,  are my nostalgia now.
  20: 
  21: That old man comes back,  the friend I saw each day and never spoke to,  because I hoped soon to disappear from there,  as I have disappeared, into the heaven of better days.

#1379: 181786_General B.F. Butler_Bierce, Ambrose_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: General B.F. Butler
Author: Bierce, Ambrose
Prose starts at line: 7
Lines to remove: 7
Avg verse line length: 28.2
Avg prose line length: 210.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   2: 
   3: Thy flesh to earth, thy soul to God,
   4: We gave, O gallant brother;
   5: And o'er thy grave the awkward squad
   6: Fired into one another!

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   7: An inept political general, Benjamin Butler is best remembered for his tenure as commander of Union troops in occupied New Orleans and for the colorful nicknames bestowed upon him by the citizens of that city.
   8: 
   9: The best known of these were "Beast" Butler, in honor of his proclamation that any Southern lady who did not treat Federal soldiers with respect could in turn be treated as a "lady of the night," and "Spoons" Butler, since many Southerners believed that the general enriched himself by appropriating the silverware and other precious possessions of the citizenry as spoils of war.
  10: 
  11: The ladies of New Orleans retaliated (albeit behind closed doors) by having portraits of Butler painted on the bottoms of their chamber pots.
  12: 
  13: Poems like Ambrose Bierce's indicate that many in the North were no more impressed with Butler than Southerners


====================================================================================================
#1380: 181873_The Imperfect Enjoyment_Rochester, John Wilmot Earl of_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Imperfect Enjoyment
Author: Rochester, John Wilmot Earl of
Prose starts at line: 24
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 110.3
Avg prose line length: 196.3

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  19: “All this to love and rapture’s due; Must we not pay a debt to pleasure too?
  20: 
  21: 
  22: But I, the most forlorn, lost man alive, To show my wished obedience vainly strive: I sigh, alas! and kiss, but cannot swive.
  23: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  24: Eager desires confound my first intent, Succeeding shame does more success prevent, And rage at last confirms me impotent.
  25: 
  26: Ev’n her fair hand, which might bid heat return To frozen age, and make cold hermits burn, Applied to my dear cinder, warms no more Than fire to ashes could past flames restore.
  27: 
  28: Trembling, confused, despairing, limber, dry, A wishing, weak, unmoving lump I lie.
  29: 
  30: This dart of love, whose piercing point, oft tried, With virgin blood ten thousand maids has dyed, Which nature still directed with such art That it through every cunt reached every heart— Stiffly resolved, ’twould carelessly invade Woman or man, nor ought its fury stayed: Where’er it pierced, a cunt it found or made— Now languid lies in this unhappy hour, Shrunk up and sapless like a withered flower.
  31: 
  32: Thou treacherous, base deserter of my flame, False to my passion, fatal to my fame, Through what mistaken magic dost thou prove So true to lewdness, so untrue to love?
  33: 
  34: What oyster-cinder-beggar-common whore Didst thou e’er fail in all thy life before?
  35: 
  36: When vice, disease, and scandal lead the way, With what officious haste doest thou obey! Like a rude, roaring hector in the streets Who scuffles, cuffs, and justles all he meets, But if his king or country claim his aid, The rakehell villain shrinks and hides his head; Ev’n so thy brutal valor is displayed, Breaks every stew, does each small whore invade, But when great Love the onset does command, Base recreant to thy prince, thou dar’st not stand.
  37: 
  38: Worst part of me, and henceforth hated most, Through all the town a common fucking post, On whom each whore relieves her tingling cunt As hogs on gates do rub themselves and grunt, Mayst thou to ravenous chancres be a prey, Or in consuming weepings waste away; May strangury and stone thy days attend; May’st thou never piss, who didst refuse to spend When all my joys did on false thee depend.
  39: 
  40: And may ten thousand abler pricks agree
  41: 
  42: To do the wronged Corinna right for thee.


====================================================================================================
#1381: 181875_Upon Nothing_Rochester, John Wilmot Earl of_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Upon Nothing
Author: Rochester, John Wilmot Earl of
Prose starts at line: 7
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 96.7
Avg prose line length: 209.7

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   2: 
   3: Nothing! thou elder brother even to Shade: That hadst a being ere the world was made, And well fixed, art alone of ending not afraid.
   4: 
   5: Ere Time and Place were, Time and Place were not, When primitive Nothing Something straight begot; Then all proceeded from the great united What.
   6: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   7: Something, the general attribute of all, Severed from thee, its sole original, Into thy boundless self must undistinguished fall;
   8: 
   9: Yet Something did thy mighty power command, And from fruitful Emptiness’s hand Snatched men, beasts, birds, fire, air, and land.
  10: 
  11: Matter the wicked’st offspring of thy race, By Form assisted, flew from thy embrace, And rebel Light obscured thy reverend dusky face.
  12: 
  13: With Form and Matter, Time and Place did join; Body, thy foe, with these did leagues combine To spoil thy peaceful realm, and ruin all thy line;   But turncoat Time assists the foe in vain,  And bribed by thee, destroys their short-lived reign, And to thy hungry womb drives back thy slaves again.
  14: 
  15: Though mysteries are barred from laic eyes, And the divine alone with warrant pries Into thy bosom, where truth in private lies,   Yet this of thee the wise may truly say, Thou from the virtuous nothing dost delay, And to be part with thee the wicked wisely pray.
  16: 
  17: Great Negative, how vainly would the wiseInquire, define, distinguish, teach, devise, Didst thou not stand to point their blind philosophies!   Is, or Is Not, the two great ends of Fate, And True or False, the subject of debate, That perfect or destroy the vast designs of state—
  18: 
  19: When they have racked the politician’s breast, Within thy Bosom most securely rest, And when reduced to thee, are least unsafe and best.
  20: 
  21: But Nothing, why does Something still permit That sacred monarchs should at council sit With persons highly thought at best for nothing fit,   While weighty Something modestly abstains From princes’ coffers, and from statemen’s brains, And Nothing there like stately Nothing reigns?
  22: 
  23: Nothing! who dwell’st with fools in grave disguise For whom they reverend shapes and forms devise, Lawn sleeves, and furs, and gowns, when they like thee look wise:   French truth, Dutch prowess, British policy, Hibernian learning, Scotch civility, Spaniards’ dispatch, Danes’ wit are mainly seen in thee.
  24: 
  25: The great man’s gratitude to his best friend, Kings’ promises, whores’ vows—towards thee may bend, Flow swiftly into thee, and in thee ever end.


====================================================================================================
#1382: 181901_Sheridan_Berryhill, Samuel Newton_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Sheridan
Author: Berryhill, Samuel Newton
Prose starts at line: 90
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 29.6
Avg prose line length: 148.5

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  85: For Yankee flesh shall be his meat,
  86: Sheridan.
  87: 
  88: As the presidential election of 1864 approached, Abraham Lincoln knew he was in trouble.
  89: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  90: The War was not going well, and unless his generals could serve up some convincing victories before the good citizens of the north went to the polls in November, Mr.
  91: 
  92: Lincoln knew he would soon be handing the keys to the White House over to Democratic challenger George B.
  93: 
  94: McClellan.
  95: 
  96: Fortunately for Lincoln, his generals would not fail him.
  97: 
  98: William Tecumseh Sherman would wreak havoc "from Atlanta to the sea," and -- much closer to home -- Philip Sheridan would chase Confederate General Jubal Early out of the Shenandoah Valley (and right out of Robert E.
  99: 
 100: Lee's Army of Northern Virginia into an early retirement).
 101: 
 102: This poem, by Mississippian Samuel Berryhill, paints a grim, altogether too realistic picture of Sheridan's destructive rampage through the "breadbasket of the South.
 103: 
 104: " Although acknowledging Sheridan as the author of "this wide-spread ruin dire," Berryhill ultimately holds Lincoln responsible for the campaign, referring to the President as "Moloch" (a false Canaanite god of the Old Testament, who was represented by a bull's head upon which children were sacrificed).
 105: 
 106: Confederate partisan Colonel John Singleton Mosby is compared to Roderic Dhu, a gallant Highland chieftain who figures favorably in Sir Walter Scott's "The Lady of the Lake.
 107: 
 108: The poem's final stanza -- "The 'crow' that flies on pinions fleet/Need take no 'rations' there to eat" -- refers to Sheridan's boast that when he was done with the Valley, a crow flying over would need to carry its own provisions.


====================================================================================================
#1383: 181902_To Major General B.F. Butler, U.S.A._Berryhill, Samuel Newton_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: To Major General B.F. Butler, U.S.A.
Author: Berryhill, Samuel Newton
Prose starts at line: 51
Lines to remove: 7
Avg verse line length: 30.8
Avg prose line length: 217.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  46: 
  47: And they whose sires in olden time
  48: Burnt women at the stake,
  49: To recompense the deed sublime,
  50: Of you a god will make!

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  51: An inept political general, Benjamin Butler is best remembered for his tenure as commander of Union troops in occupied New Orleans and for the colorful nicknames bestowed upon him by the citizens of that city.
  52: 
  53: The best known of these were "Beast" Butler, in honor of his proclamation that any Southern lady who did not treat Federal soldiers with respect could in turn be treated as a "lady of the night," and "Spoons" Butler, since many Southerners believed that the general enriched himself by appropriating the silverware and other precious possessions of the citizenry as spoils of war.
  54: 
  55: The ladies of New Orleans retaliated (albeit behind closed doors) by having portraits of Butler painted on the bottoms of their chamber pots.
  56: 
  57: Poems like Ambrose Bierce's indicate that many in the North were no more impressed with Butler than Southerners like Samuel Berryhill were.


====================================================================================================

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: “Find Work”
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: I tie my Hat—I crease my Shawl—Life's little duties do—preciselyAs the very leastWere infinite—to me— —Emily Dickinson, #443
   4: 
   5: 
   6: 
   7: 
   8: 
   9: 
  10: 
  11: My mother’s mother, widowed very young of her first love, and of that love’s first fruit, moved through her father’s farm, her country tongue and country heart anaesthetized and mute with labor.
  12: 
  13: So her kind was taught to do— “Find work,” she would reply to every grief— and her one dictum, whether false or true, tolled heavy with her passionate belief.
  14: 
  15: Widowed again, with children, in her prime, she spoke so little it was hard to bear so much composure, such a truce with time spent in the lifelong practice of despair.
  16: 
  17: But I recall her floors, scrubbed white as bone, her dishes, and how painfully they shone.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   1: Sidetracks IX
   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   3: the Cold War just ended    a lone sun in the belly of the flying bird white sails drift into an alternate river of  time    all languages circulate against the state of enslavement    my identity suspect    exile is crossing the void of a journey without a destination—my life
   4: intoxicated—tram gently rocks through the center of  Vienna whisky bottle polished off in a room in Stockholm    I make ghostly faces in the mirror    a South African poet a French poet and I belt out “The Internationale” on Osborne Street    adjusting pace to march straight into first light
   5: the moon is my mother    softly smooth out those secret slips of paper the birth of suffering flashes to mind    precisely because of life’s incompleteness it completes itself    the defensive line of the fathers turns into forest    a chainsaw screams out of human will    behind the cemetery the city glitters and shines
   6: the setting sun and an elegy for the twentieth-century    scattered chronicles and crossed-out blacklists    the wave that has yet to form has already transmigrated     postwar flags ceaselessly change colors meanings that survive underground draw water    from the cracks between words spit out the bubbles    collect postage stamps collect shards of thought    butterflies flutter above a forgotten line of defense
   7: I am Celan in 1947    crossing the border from Bucharest to Vienna the smuggler has the smell of a skunk    North Star of my childhood leads the way    no identity card except a manuscript of poems overnight at an abandoned train station    a stooped shadow stalks through the starlight    German the enemy of the mother tongueit is now time  for stone to bloom
   8: I dream of a raging storm    a forest as if a crazed herd of  horses whirls me away    embrace a pillow in the clouds    hug the family tightly waves crash against the port side of a battered wooden boat    moss blindfolds the rocks    perch on the branch of language    coffins of war or epidemic take flight    shadows in the field dig up potatoes to prepare for winter
   9: searching for an unfamiliar city in which I can be reborn    crow-black clouds bow their heads to smell the tobacco leaves    the sea leaves a watermark on banknotes    angels on the gallery walls fly away in a hurry    the bronze statue on the public square overflows with hostility    time is like walking a dog bounding prancing running wildly swiftly stops and turns the corner    scratches an itch against a tree then pees and moves on and on    without a leash
  10: Translated from the Chinese

   2: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]

   3: The ship wherein Theseus and the youth of Athens returned had thirty oars, and was preserved by the Athenians    .
   4: 
   5: 
   6: for they took away the old planks as they decayed, putting in new and stronger timber in their place, insomuch that this ship became a standing example among the philosophers, for the logical question of things that grow; one side holding that the ship remained the same, and the other contending that it was not the same.
   7: 
   8: — Plutarch, Vita Thesel
   9: 
  10: 
  11: The answer of course is that the shipdoesn’t exist, that “ship”is an abstraction, a conception,an imaginary tarp thrownacross the garden of the real.
  12: 
  13: The answer is that the cheappeasantry of things toils all dayin the kingdom of  language,every ship like a casketof words: bulkhead, transom,mast steps

   4: 
   5: It is far too expensive for me,but the handwritten label [1915] brings it to my chest in armfuls of red.

  12:

  16: 
  17: In the mirror, the old coat blushes.
  18: 
  19: This pocket may once have sheltered somethingprecious — a necklace, a love letter, ora fresh egg, feather-warm, its shell brittlearound a hidden inner glow, held looselyso it couldn’t crack, couldn’t leak through seams,so it couldn’t stain the dress within.

  69: One tender accent, low and deep,
  70: Shrined 'midst thy founts and haunted rocks to dwell!
  71: Might my last breath send music to thy shore!
  72: —Oh! linger, seamen, linger on the oar!

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  73: * It will be remembered, that this beautiful Island was sacred to the ancient Greeks, from having been the birth-place of Apollo and Diana.
  74: 
  75: None were born or died there—the mothers and the dying were carried to the neighbouring islet of Rhane.
  76: 
  77: Solemn expeditions, with much priestly pomp, were frequently made from Athens to enforce this ordinance, particularly to propitiate the Gods in time of public calamity.
  78: 
  79: Our era refers to the celebrated lustration, at the time of the Peloponnesian war, during the plague of Athens.
  80: 
  81: From The Winter's Wreath, 1831

#1396: 183851_Körner And His Sister_Hemans, Felicia Dorothea_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Körner And His Sister
Author: Hemans, Felicia Dorothea
Prose starts at line: 73
Lines to remove: 12
Avg verse line length: 41.0
Avg prose line length: 130.6

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  68: That love, where love is but a fount of tears.
  69: 
  70: Brother, sweet sister! peace around ye dwell:
  71: Lyre, Sword, and Flower, farewell!
  72: From Records of Woman: with Other Poems, 1828

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  73: Charles Theodore Korner, the celebrated young German poet and soldier, was killed in a skirmish with a detachment of French troops, on the 20th of August, 1813, a few hours after the composition of his popular piece, "The Sword-song.
  74: 
  75: " He was buried at the village of Wobbelin in Mecklenburgh, under a beautiful oak, in a recess of which he had frequently deposited verses composed by him while campaigning in its vicinity.
  76: 
  77: The monument erected to his memory is of cast iron; and the upper part is wrought into a lyre and sword, a favourite emblem of Korner's, from which one of his works had been entitled.
  78: 
  79: Near the grave of the poet is that of his only sister, who died of grief for his loss, having only survived him long enough to complete his portrait, and a drawing of his burial-place.
  80: 
  81: Over the gate of the cemetery is engraved one of his own lines:
  82: "Vergiss die treuen Todten nicht.
  83: 
  84: Forget not the faithful dead.


====================================================================================================

  29: Caswallon (or Cassivelaunus) was elected to the supreme command of the Britons, (as recorded in the Triads,) for the purpose of opposing Cæsar, under the title of Elected Chief of Battle.
  30: 
  31: Whatever impression the disciplined legions of Rome might have made on the Britons in the first instance, the subsequent departure of Cæsar they considered as a cause of triumph; and it is stated that Caswallon proclaimed an assembly of the various states of the island, for the purpose of celebrating that event by feasting and public rejoicing.
  32: 
  33: Cambrian Biography.
  34: 
  35: Welsh Melodies, 1822
  36: Music by Parry

#1398: 183884_Song of The Battle of Morgarten_Hemans, Felicia Dorothea_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Song of The Battle of Morgarten
Author: Hemans, Felicia Dorothea
Prose starts at line: 154
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 46.9
Avg prose line length: 167.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 149: 
 150: Thus rejected, they nevertheless resolved to expose their lives for their country, and posted themselves on the eminence above Morgarten, beyond the frontiers of the Canton.
 151: 
 152: The 15th October 1315 dawned.
 153: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 154: The sun darted its first rays on the shields and armour of the advancing host; and this being the first army ever known to have attempted the frontiers of the Cantons, the Swiss viewed its long line with various emotions.
 155: 
 156: Montfort de Tettnang led the cavalry into the narrow pass, and soon filled the whole space between the mountain and the lake.
 157: 
 158: The fifty exiles on the eminence raised a sudden shout, and rolled down heaps of rocks and stones among the crowded ranks.
 159: 
 160: The confederates on the mountain, perceiving the impression made by this attack, rushed down in close array, and fell upon the flank of the disordered column.
 161: 
 162: With massy clubs they dashed in pieces the armour of the enemy, and dealt their blows and thrusts with long pikes.
 163: 
 164: The narrowness of the defile admitted of no evolutions, and a slight frost having injured the road, the horses were impeded in all their motions; many leaped into the lake; all were startled; and at last the whole column gave way, and fell suddenly back on the infantry, which had already advanced into the pass; and these last, as the nature of the country did not allow them to open their files, were run over by the fugitives, and many of them trampled to death.
 165: 
 166: A general route now ensued; the Swiss continued the slaughter; and Duke Leopold was, with much difficulty, rescued by a peasant, who, knowing the bye-paths of the mountains, led him to Winterthur, where the historian of the times saw him arrive in the evening, pale, sullen, and dismayed.
 167: 
 168: Thus did the confederates, without much loss, and in less than three hours, gain a decisive victory.
 169: 
 170: See Planta's History of the Helvetic Confederacy.
 171: 
 172: The Edinburgh Magazine, 1823


====================================================================================================

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]

  74: An Indian woman, driven to despair by her husband's desertion of her for another wife, entered a canoe with her children, and rowed it down the Mississippi towards a cataract.
  75: 
  76: Her voice was heard from the shore singing a mournful death-song, until overpowered by the sound of the waters in which she perished.
  77: 
  78: The tale is related in Long's Expedition to the source of St.
  79:

  20: Which shall flow down the waves of long ages to be.
  21: 
  22: Sheath the sword which hath given them unperishing themes,
  23: And pour the bright mead: let the wine-cup foam high,
  24: That those may rejoice who have fear'd not to die!

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  25: * Wine, as well as mead, is frequently mentioned in the poems of the ancient British bards.
  26: 
  27: † The horn was used for two purposes—to sound the alarm in war, and to drink the mead at feasts.
  28: 
  29: ‡ Dyfed, (said to signify a land abounding with streams of water,) the modern Pembrokeshire.
  30: 
  31: "Grufydd ab Rhys ab Tewdwr, having resisted the English successfully in the time of Stephen, and at last obtained from them an honourable peace, made a great feast at his palace in Ystrad Tywi to celebrate this event.
  32: 
  33: To this feast, which was continued for forty days, he invited all who would come in peace from Gwynedd, Powys, the Deheubarth, Glamorgan, and the marches.
  34: 
  35: Against the appointed time he prepared all kinds of delicious viands and liquors; with every entertainment of vocal and instrumental song; thus patronising the poets and musicians.
  36: 
  37: He encouraged, too, all sorts of representations and manly games, and afterwards sent away all those who had excelled in them with honourable gifts.
  38: 
  39: Cambrian Biography.
  40: 
  41: Welsh Melodies, 1822
  42: Music by Parry

#1401: 183920_Arabella Stuart_Hemans, Felicia Dorothea_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Arabella Stuart
Author: Hemans, Felicia Dorothea
Prose starts at line: 389
Lines to remove: 20
Avg verse line length: 40.0
Avg prose line length: 171.0

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 384: 
 385: From this they found means to concert a romantic plan of escape; and having won over a female attendant, by whose assistance she was disguised in male attire, Arabella, though faint from recent sickness and suffering, stole out in the night, and at last reached an appointed spot, where a boat and servants were in waiting.
 386: 
 387: She embarked; and, at break of day, a French vessel engaged to receive her, was discovered and gained.
 388: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 389: As Seymour, however, had not yet arrived, she was desirous that the vessel should lie at anchor for him; but this wish was overruled by her companions, who, contrary to her entreaties, hoisted sail, "which," says D'Israeli, "occasioned so fatal a termination to this romantic adventure.
 390: 
 391: Seymour, indeed, had escaped from the Tower;–he reached the wharf, and found his confidential man waiting with a boat, and arrived at Lee.
 392: 
 393: The time passed; the waves were rising; Arabella was not there; but in the distance he descried a vessel.
 394: 
 395: Hiring a fisherman to take him on board, he discovered, to his grief, on hailing it, that it was not the French ship charged with his Arabella; in despair and confusion he found another ship from Newcastle, which for a large sum altered its course, and landed him in Flanders.
 396: 
 397: "–Arabella, meantime, whilst imploring her attendants to linger, and earnestly looking out for the expected boat of her husband, was overtaken in Calais Roads by a vessel in the King's service, and brought back to a captivity, under the suffering of which her mind and constitution gradually sank.
 398: 
 399: –"What passed in that dreadful imprisonment, cannot perhaps be recovered for authentic history,–but enough is known; that her mind grew impaired, that she finally lost her reason, and, if the duration of her imprisonment was short, that it was only terminated by her death.
 400: 
 401: Some effusions, often begun and never ended, written and erased, incoherent and rational, yet remain among her papers.
 402: 
 403: " –D'ISRAELI's Curiosities of Literature.
 404: 
 405: –The following poem, meant as some record of her fate, and the imagined fluctuations of her thoughts and feelings, is supposed to commence during the time of her first imprisonment, whilst her mind was yet buoyed up by the consciousness of Seymour's affection, and the cherished hope of eventual deliverance.
 406: 
 407: --The Author
 408: From Records of Women, 1828

  69: While within their silent cave
  70: The men of Grütli sleep!

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]

  71: The three founders of the Helvetic Confederacy are thought to sleep in a cavern near the Lake of Lucerne.
  72: 
  73: The herdsmen call them the Three Tells; and say that they lie there in their antique garb, in quiet slumber; and when Switzerland is in her utmost need, they will awaken and regain the liberties of the land.
  74: 
  75: ⁠See Quarterly Review, No.
  76: 
  77: 44.
  78:
