#1404: 183984_Bernardo del Carpio_Hemans, Felicia Dorothea_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Bernardo del Carpio
Author: Hemans, Felicia Dorothea
Prose starts at line: 67
Lines to remove: 17
Avg verse line length: 62.0
Avg prose line length: 128.7

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  62: He cast one long deep troubled look, then turn'd from that sad place.
  63: 
  64: His hope was crush 'd, his after-fate untold in martial strain,
  65: —His banner led the spears no more amidst the hills of Spain.
  66: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  67: The celebrated Spanish champion, Bernardo del Carpio, having made many ineffectual efforts to procure the release of his father, the Count Saldana, who had been imprisoned by King Alfonso of Asturias, almost from the time of Bernardo's birth, at last took up arms in despair.
  68: 
  69: The war which he maintained proved so destructive, that the men of the land gathered round the king, and united in demanding Saldana's liberty.
  70: 
  71: Alfonso accordingly offered Bernardo immediate possession of his father's person, in exchange for his Castle of Carpio.
  72: 
  73: Bernardo, without hesitation, gave up his strong hold with all his captives, and being assured that his father was then on his way from prison, rode forth with the king to meet him.
  74: 
  75: "And when he saw his father approaching, he exclaimed, (says the ancient Chronicle) Oh God! is the Count of Saldana indeed coming?
  76: 
  77: "—"Look where he is," replied the cruel king, "and now go and greet him whom you have so long desired to see.
  78: 
  79: " The remainder of the story will be found related in the ballad.
  80: 
  81: The Chronicles and Romances leave us nearly in the dark as to Bernardo's further history after this event.
  82: 
  83: The New Monthly Magazine, 1825

  28: CHORUS.
  29: 
  30: Then shall their spirits rejoice in her smile,
  31: Who died for the crown of the Beautiful Isle.
  32: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  33: Note:Ynys Prydain was the ancient Welsh name of Britain, and signifies fair or beautiful isle.
  34: 
  35: The Bard of the Palace, under the ancient Welsh princes, always accompanied the army when it marched into an enemy's country; and, while it was preparing for battle or dividing the spoils, he performed an ancient song, called Unbennaeth Prydain, the Monarchy of Britain.
  36: 
  37: It has been conjectured that this poem referred to the tradition of the Welsh, that the whole island had once been possessed by their ancestors, who were driven into a corner of it by their Saxon invaders.
  38: 
  39: When the prince had received his share of the spoils, the bard, for the performance of this song, was rewarded with the most valuable beast that remained.
  40: 
  41: —Jones's
  42: Historical Account of the Welsh Bards.
  43: 
  44: Welsh Melodies, 1822
  45: Music by Parry

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 858: 
 859: It was usual to hang up the person condemned, with a willow-branch, to the first tree; but, if circumstances obliged them to dispatch him with a poniard, they left it in his body, that it might be known he had not been assassinated, but executed by a Free Judge.
 860: 
 861: All the transactions of the Sages, or Seers, (as they called themselves,) were enveloped in mystery, and it is even now unknown by what signs they revealed themselves to each other.
 862: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 863: At length their power became so extensive and redoubtable, that the Princes of the Empire found it necessary to unite their exertions for its suppression, in which they were at length successful.
 864: 
 865: The following account of this extraordinary association is given by Madame de Staël:—"Des juges mysterieux inconnus l'un à l’autre, toujours masqués, et se rassemblant pendant la nuit, punissoient dans le silence, et gravoient seulement sur le poignard qu'ils enforçoient dans le sein du coupable ce mot terrible: Tribunal Secret.
 866: 
 867: Its prévenoient le condamné, en faisant crier trois fois sous les fenêtres de sa maison, Malheur, Malheur, Malheur! Alors l'infortuné savoit que par-tout, dans l'étranger, dans son concitoyen, dans son parent même, il pouvoit trouver son meurtrier.
 868: 
 869: La solitude, la foule, les villes, les campagnes, tout étoit rempli par la présence invisible de cette conscience armée qui poursuivoit les criminels.
 870: 
 871: On conçoit comment cette terrible institution pouvoit être necessaire, dans un temps où chaque homme étoit fort contre tous, au lieu que tous doivent être forts contre chacun.
 872: 
 873: Il falloit que la justice surprit le criminel avant qu'il pût s'en defendre; mais cette punition qui planoit dans les airs comme une ombre vengeresse, cette sentence mortelle qui pouvoit receler le sein même d'un ami, frappoit d’une invincible terreur.
 874: 
 875: L'Allemagne.
 876: 
 877: Vol.
 878: 
 879: II.
 880: 
 881: The Edinburgh Magazine, 1822

  72: 481) of the circumstances attending the death and burial of William the Conqueror.
  73:

  75:

  77:

  79: 
  80: ' Cette protestation frappa de componction les Seigneurs et les Evêques qui l'entendirent; ils firent immédiatement autour du cercueil une collecte pour racheter d' Ascelin, le place même où son Souverain seroit enterré; ils lui promirent que plus tard on le compenseroit pour la perte de son heritage, et ils lui tinrent parole; car le fait qu'il avait rappelé était de notorieté publique.
  81:

 280:

 282: 
 283: <2>
 284: A French royalist officer, dying upon a field of battle, and hearing some one near him uttering the most plaintive lamentations, turned towards the sufferer, and thus addressed him:—"My friend, whoever you may be, remember that your God expired upon the cross—your King upon the scaffold,—and he who now speaks to you has had his limbs shot from under him.

 960: And man holds festivals below!
 961: NOTES.
 962: 
 963: (1) The original of the scene here described is presented by the mountain called the Feldberg, in the Bergstrasse.
 964: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 965: "Des masses énormes de rochers, en tassées l'une sur l'autre depuis le sommet de la montagne jusqu' à son pied, viennent y présenter un aspect superbe qu'aucune description ne saurait rendre.
 966: 
 967: Ce furent, dit-on, des géans, quien se livrant un combat du haut des montagnes, lancèrent les uns sur les autres ces énormes masses de rochers.
 968: 
 969: On arrive avec beaucoup de peine jusqu'au sommet du Feldberg, en suivant un sentier qui passe à côté de cette chaine de rochers.
 970: 
 971: On entend continuellement un bruit sourd qui parait venir d'un ruisseau au dessous des rochers; mais on a beau descendre, en se glissant à travers les ouvertures qui s’y trouvent, on ne decouvrira jamais le ruisseau.
 972: 
 973: La colonne dite Riesensäule se trouve un peu plus haut qu'à la moitie de la montagne; c'est un bloc de granit taillé, d'une longueur de 30 pieds et d'un diamétre de 4 pieds.
 974: 
 975: Il y a plus de probabilité de croire que les anciens Germains voulaient faire de ce bloc une colonne pour l'ériger en l'honneur de leur dieu Odin, que de prétendre, comme le font plusieurs auteurs, que les Romains aient eu le dessein de la transporter dans leur capitale.
 976: 
 977: On voit un peu plus haut un autre bloc d'une forme presque carrée, qu'on appelle Riesenaltar (autel du géant) qui, à en juger pas sa grosseur et sa forme, était destiné à servir de piédestal à la colonne susdite.
 978: 
 979: Manuel pour les Voyageurs sur le Rhin.
 980: 
 981: (2) Minnesingers, (bards of love), the appellation of the German Minstrels in the Middle Ages.
 982: 
 983: The Edinburgh Magazine, 1822

  38: ⁠Lift up thy voice, O Rhine!

  39: "But I wish you could have heard Sir Walter Scott describe a glorious sight, which had been witnessed by a friend of his!—the crossing of the Rhine at Ehren-breit-stein by the German army of Liberators on their victorious return from France.
  40: 
  41: "At the first gleam of the river," he said, "they all burst forth into the national chaunt 'Am Rhein! am Rhein!'—they were two days passing over; and the rocks and the castle were ringing to the song the whole time;—for each band renewed it while crossing; and the Cossacks, with the clash and the clang, and the roll of their stormy war-music, catching the enthusiasm of the scene, swelled forth the chorus 'Am Rhein! am Rhein!'

#1412: 184145_The Cross of the South_Hemans, Felicia Dorothea_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: The Cross of the South
Author: Hemans, Felicia Dorothea
Prose starts at line: 48
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 49.7
Avg prose line length: 116.1

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  43: Soars high o'er the Andes, to mingle with thee!
  44: † Alluding to the vision of Constantine the Great.
  45: 
  46: "The pleasure we felt on discovering the southern cross, was warmly shared by such of the crew as had lived in the colonies.
  47: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  48: In the solitude of the seas, we hail a star, as a friend from whom we have been long separated.
  49: 
  50: Among the Portuguese and Spaniards, peculiar motives seem to increase this feeling; a religious sentiment attaches them to a constellation, the form of which recalls the sign of the faith planted by their ancestors in the deserts of the new world.
  51: 
  52: The two great stars which mark the summit and the foot of the cross, having nearly the same right ascension, it follows hence, that the constellation is almost perpendicular, at the moment when it passes the meridian.
  53: 
  54: This circumstance is known to every nation that lives beyond the tropics, or in the southern hemisphere.
  55: 
  56: It has been observed at what hour of the night, in different seasons, the cross of the south is erect or inclined.
  57: 
  58: It is a time-piece that advances very regularly nearly four minutes a day, and no other group of stars exhibits, to the naked eye, an observation of time so easily made.
  59: 
  60: How often have we heard our guides exclaim in the savannas of Venezuela, or in the desert extending from Lima to Truxillo, 'midnight is past, the cross begins to bend.
  61: 
  62: Dr.
  63: 
  64: Humboldt's Travels.
  65: 
  66: The Literary Gazette, 1821

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 128: Language, where all th’ indignant soul awoke,
 129: Till his deep thought found voice—then, calmly stern,
 130: And sov’reign in despair, he cried, "Return!
 131: Tell him who sent thee hither, thou hast seen
 132: Marius the Exile rest where Carthage once hath been!"

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 133: Marius, during the time of his exile, seeking refuge in Africa, had landed at Carthage; when an officer, sent by the Roman Governor of Africa, came, and thus addressed him—"Marius, I come from the Prætor Sextilius, to tell you, that he forbids you to set foot in Africa.
 134: 
 135: If you obey not, he will support the Senate's decree, and treat you as a public enemy.
 136: 
 137: " Marius, upon hearing this, was struck dumb with grief and indignation.
 138: 
 139: He uttered not a word for some time, but regarded the officer with a menacing aspect.
 140: 
 141: At length, the officer inquired what answer he should carry to the Governor?
 142: 
 143: "Go and tell him," said the unfortunate man, with a sigh, "that thou hast seen the exiled Marius sitting on the ruins of Carthage.
 144: 
 145: See Plutarch.

#1414: 184174_Owen Glyndwr's War-Song_Hemans, Felicia Dorothea_unknown.txt

Author: Hemans, Felicia Dorothea
Prose starts at line: 72

#1416: 184327_Dartmoor. A prize Poem_Hemans, Felicia Dorothea_unknown.txt

Author: Hemans, Felicia Dorothea
Prose starts at line: 469
Lines to remove: 13
Avg verse line length: 41.4
Avg prose line length: 149.4

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 464: 
 465: "They had no poet, and they died.
 466: 
 467: Pope's Translation
 468: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 469: 4  On the east of Dartmoor are some Druidical remains, one of which is a Cromlech, whose three rough pillars of granite support a ponderous table-stone, and form a kind of large irregular tripod.
 470: 
 471: 5  In some of the Druid festivals, fires were lighted on all the cairns and eminences around, by priests, carrying sacred torches.
 472: 
 473: All the household fires were previously extinguished, and those who were thought worthy of such a privilege, were allowed to relight them with a flaming brand, kindled at the consecrated cairn-fire.
 474: 
 475: 6  The French prisoners, taken in the wars with Napoleon, were confined in a depot on Dartmoor.
 476: 
 477: 7  In allusion to a plan for the erection of a great national school-house on Dartmoor, where it was proposed to educate the children of convicts.
 478: 
 479: In 1820, the Royal Society of Literature advertised their intention of awarding a prize for the best poem on “Dartmoor;" and, as might have been expected, many competitors entered the field.
 480: 
 481: In the following June, the palm was awarded to Mrs Hemans for the composition which follows.

  19: Note: Ho Xuan Huong, like her mother, was a vo le, a concubine, or wife of second rank.
  20: 
  21: Traditionally, Vietnamese women wielded considerable economic and political power, but by 1800 the condition of women had deteriorated as the Vietnamese nation itself began a collapse under domestic and foreign pressures.
  22:

#1418: 184390_Forby Sutherland_McCrae, George Gordon_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Forby Sutherland
Author: McCrae, George Gordon
Prose starts at line: 206
Lines to remove: 20
Avg verse line length: 49.2
Avg prose line length: 167.2

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 201: 
 202: Special, undoubtedly, to the Aborigines who lived here for thousands of years.
 203: 
 204: Special, historically, in that both Cook and Phillip came here first and each first hoisted a British flag here.
 205: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 206: And special geographically, being defined on almost all sides by lovely waterways.
 207: 
 208: Cook's tragic sailor didn't directly provide his name to Sutherland Shire; nor did the railway enthusiast John Sutherland MP.
 209: 
 210: But both deserve immemorial places in our Shire folk lore.
 211: 
 212: How dull to think that our Shire's name is but a consequence of careless spelling! I prefer to sense a cosmic will at work behind the five incredible coincidences: Forby Sutherland's death in 1770, Mitchell's choice of Southerland in 1835, the spelling error that legalised Sutherland later in 1835, John Sutherland's name for the station opened in 1885, and the siting of the Council Chambers in Sutherland township in 1906.
 213: 
 214: Look at the sheer improbability this way…
 215: Why, when the Endeavour was at sea for all of three years with 94 aboard, would a Scottish sailor called Sutherland happen to die during the single week the little ship was in Botany Bay - and be buried on the Kurnell Peninsula?
 216: 
 217: Why, when a Scottish Surveyor-General wanted to confer "Southerland" on the area between Georges River and Port Hacking, would an unknown clerk instead record the name "Sutherland"?
 218: 
 219: Why, when a new railway station across the Georges was to open in 1885, would it take the name of a Scottish carpenter-MP Sutherland, the only Sutherland ever in a NSW Ministry - and who died before the 1880s ended anyway?
 220: 
 221: Why, when Council Chambers might have been sited anywhere in the new Shire, would the choice fall on a site adjacent to Sutherland railway station in what would be become the suburb of Sutherland?
 222: 
 223: If you are reluctant to believe that the Hand of Providence guided the bureaucratic hand that perpetuated that fateful misspelling, you are left with Alice in Wonderland mumbling nothing more profound than, "Curiouser and curiouser".
 224: 
 225: Information supplied by Sutherland Shire Council


====================================================================================================
#1419: 184607_Florio - A Tale, For Fine Gentleman And Fine Ladies. In Two Parts_More, Hannah_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Florio : A Tale, For Fine Gentleman And Fine Ladies. In Two Parts
Author: More, Hannah
Prose starts at line: 1187
Lines to remove: 18
Avg verse line length: 34.7
Avg prose line length: 119.9

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1182: : A celebrated Cook and Confectioner.
1183: 
1184: To The Honourable Horace Walpole.
1185: 
1186: My Dear Sir,

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1187: It would be very flattering to me, if I might hope that the little Tale, which I now take the liberty of presenting to you, could amuse a few moments of your tedious indisposition.
1188: 
1189: It is, I confess, but a paltry return for the many hours of agreeable information and elegant amusement which I have received from your spirited and very entertaining writings: yet I am persuaded, that you will receive it with favour, as a small offering of esteem and gratitude; as an offering of which the intention alone makes all the little value.
1190: 
1191: The slight verses, Sir, which I place under your protection, will not, I fear, impress the world with a very favourable idea of my poetical powers: But I shall, at least, be suspected of having some taste, and of keeping good company, when I confess that some of the pleasantest hours of my life have been passed in your conversation.
1192: 
1193: I should be unjust to your very engaging and well-bred turn of wit, if I did not declare that, among all the lively and brilliant things I have heard from you, I do not remember ever to have heard an unkind or an ungenerous one.
1194: 
1195: Let me be allowed to bear my feeble testimony to your temperate use of this charming faculty, so delightful in itself, but which can only be safely trusted in such hands as yours, where it is guarded by politeness, and directed by humanity.
1196: 
1197: I have the honour to be,
1198: SIR,
1199: Your much obliged
1200: And most obedient,
1201: Humble Servant,
1202: THE AUTHOR.
1203: 
1204: January 27, 1786.

1319: I have supposed them not to be the fragments of one unhappy planet, but coeval in their birth, to have revolved from the beginning in the same sphere.
1320:

1322: 
1323: The reciprocal attractions of the planets must have been altered, they must have been accelerated or retarded in their course, and such an extraordinary event, had it happened since the creation of man, could hardly have been unrecorded, if not in the writings of the learned, at least in the traditions of the vulgar.

   2: 
   3: Inward lush unpetaling purpose in pink blooms of sleep, and I no longer needed to be separate.
   4: 
   5: I was living there then, at the edge of the sea.
   6: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   7: And my friends came to visit, trying for a baby, not sure how to read me on that island of dozy sunlight.
   8: 
   9: And there it was: familiarity edged with fear, the way we’d feed each other sandwiches and wonder if we should have wanted something other.
  10: 
  11: We walked the folded cliffs over conifer fronds and mud runneling rocks slick with dropped fruit and rotting camellias to pause at the first ridge.
  12: 
  13: We looked through high pines at the blue moving tides, then his finger caught a snag in the water and another and we saw — glinting fins wheeling the sheen, thousands playing in pods coming closer like the souls slippering into our bodies, attaching to matter as flippers angle into a ferrying strand.
  14: 
  15: We too are a species, I realized.
  16: 
  17: We too could know that as joy.

#1424: 185291_A Monumental Column - A Funeral Elegy_Webster, John_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: A Monumental Column : A Funeral Elegy
Author: Webster, John
Prose starts at line: 400
Lines to remove: 17
Avg verse line length: 42.8
Avg prose line length: 130.5

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 395: 
 396: My impresa to your lordship,
 397: A swan flying to a laurel for shelter, the mot, Amor est mihi causa.
 398: 
 399: My right noble lord,

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 400: I present to your voidest leisure of survey these few sparks found out in our most glorious prince his ashes.
 401: 
 402: I could not have thought this worthy your view, but that it aims at the preservation of his fame, than which I know not anything (but the sacred lives of both their majesties and their sweet issue) that can be dearer unto you.
 403: 
 404: Were my whole life turned into leisure, and that leisure accompanied with all the Muses, it were not able to draw a map large enough of him; for his praise is an high-going sea that wants both shore and bottom.
 405: 
 406: Neither do I, my noble lord, present you with this night-piece to make his death-bed still float in those compassionate rivers of your eyes: you have already, with much lead upon your heart, sounded both the sorrow royal and your own.
 407: 
 408: O, that care should ever attain to so ambitious a title! Only, here though I dare not say you shall find him live, for that assurance were worth many kingdoms, yet you shall perceive him draw a little breath, such as gives us comfort his critical day is past, and the glory of a new life risen, neither subject to physic nor fortune.
 409: 
 410: For my defects in this undertaking, my wish presents itself with that of Martial's;
 411: O utinam mores animumque effingere possem!
 412: Pulchrior in terris nulla tabella foret.
 413: 
 414: Howsoever, your protection is able to give it noble lustre, and bind me by that honourable courtesy to be ever
 415: Your honour's truly devoted servant,
 416: John Webster

#1427: 185358_Carney, The Brave Standard Bearer_Bush-Banks, Olivia Ward_unknown.txt
====================================================================================================
Title: Carney, The Brave Standard Bearer
Author: Bush-Banks, Olivia Ward
Prose starts at line: 63
Lines to remove: 19
Avg verse line length: 30.8
Avg prose line length: 80.9

[VERSE CONTEXT - Last few lines of poem]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  58: We can ne'er forget this hero,
  59: Or the gallant Fifty-Fourth,
  60: Fighting on the field at Wagner,
  61: With the brave ones of the North.
  62: 

[PROSE TO REMOVE - Will be deleted]
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  63: William Harvey Carney (1840 - 1908) was an African American soldier during the American Civil War who received the Medal of Honor for his actions during the Battle of Fort Wagner on July 18th 1863 .
  64: 
  65: Chronologically speaking his action was the first by a coloured soldier to receive the top award for gallantry.
  66: 
  67: However he was not awarded the medal until 37 years later on May 23rd 1900 , after others had recieved theirs.
  68: 
  69: The picture was taken a few months later.
  70: 
  71: Sgt Carney, leaning on a walking stick holds the actual flag he saved.
  72: 
  73: It is a mark of the man that as a final tribute, all flags in the Massachusetts  Commonwealth were lowered to half staff for his funeral, the first time that had been done for any citizen, black or white.
  74: 
  75: http://www.
  76: 
  77: homeofheroes.
  78: 
  79: com/hallofheroes/1stfloor/flag/1bfahist5carney.
  80: 
  81: html
